title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]What I have reviewed[/th]
        [th]What conclusion I reached[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Immersion/Game World/Story[/b][/td]
        [td]Death Stranding is about the daily life after a psychic, destructive event that has completely turned our world upside down in the near future. The circumstances of this catastrophe remain barely comprehensible until the very end, but the consequences are clearly felt everywhere: the world order is gone, almost the entire human race fell victim to the event and the survivors withdrew to self-sufficient cities.

This retreat is necessary, because the outside world is harsh and every infrastructure is gone. Ghostly beings, the so-called BTs, which can only be made visible with the help of babies in portable tanks, attack anyone who makes too much noise. Falling time rain makes wet people age in seconds and postmen addicted to deliveries attack anyone carrying packages.

As Sam Porter Bridges, played by Norman Reedus, we are a legendary messenger and deliver our freight. In the end it is the messengers of services like Bridges, Fragile and Co. who keep the last remnants of civilization alive by bringing things like food or medicine to those who need it. But the Bridges Group, under President Bridget, is planning the reunification of the former USA. Under the banner of the UCA (United Cities of America), we are being asked to connect the last cities with each other through a new network technology.

This initial situation ultimately forms the basis for the previously mysterious gameplay of Death Stranding: the game is a single, giant fetch quest.
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Gameplay[/b][/td]
        [td]So we deliver packages and it's quite possible that the gameplay aspects of Death Stranding remained a mystery for so long back then because the gameplay - admittedly - sounds rather boring at first. But it's not, because Kojima is doing everything he can to make these packaged deliveries as complex, challenging and varied as possible. With success.

Because although we always have to walk, climb and stumble from A to B, it is not just a simple delivery order. There are countless things that we have to consider and prepare so that the arduous journey to our destination is made easier or even possible in the first place. This already starts with the cargo itself.

Sam has no conventional inventory system in which our equipment simply disappears invisibly. Every single item is worn visibly: on the back, attached to the suit or even in the hand - and that becomes a lot very quickly. Usually the packages pile up on our backs and we drag ourselves through the inhospitable, impassable terrain. With every step the delivery swings back and forth and we have to keep our balance at the push of a button or we fall painfully to the ground.

The latter not only damages the cargo, but also makes our Bridge Baby cry, which we have to keep happy, however, to be able to detect lurking danger from GDs.

On the way to the delivery destination, new parcels that have been lost on other deliveries can always be found. So if there is still space, we can take extra freight with us if we are on the way. But it can be worthwhile picking up the parcels, because on the way there are smaller mailboxes where we can unload lost freight - albeit with a reduction in the reward.

Once we arrive at our destination, our delivery is then evaluated according to various criteria. Did we take the direct route or did we dawdle? Is the freight damaged or even broken? And then the reward follows through "Likes" - the experience points of Death Stranding. The better the customers like our work, the more Likes we get and the better we get at our job. This way we can gradually carry more weight and keep our endurance longer.

Afterwards we can take a little breather in private rooms, which can be found in every bigger city. These rooms are always located in delivery centres that all look the same; unfortunately we are not allowed to enter the cities themselves. The fact that we are locked out of such important places seems a bit disappointing and makes the beautiful world of Death Stranding more monotonous than it should be.

If you fear that there is no action in Death Stranding, you can rest assured. It's not only nature that stands in our way, there are also enemies to fight. The creepy BTs and the aggressive MULEs each have their own designated areas and sometimes we just have to go through them. However, we are almost always in a defensive position here, because our goal is not to challenge a fight, but to protect ourselves and our cargo.

There are also weapons in Death Stranding, but they are only added after about 15 to 20 hours of play - so for now we are dependent on stealth and our fists. Especially when it comes to the MULEs. This loose band of mad messengers is only interested in stealing our cargo, so they patrol certain areas and alert each other when they discover loot. In the high grass we can escape the glances, a regularly used scanner finds us at the beginning of the game almost every time. Then it's either flee or fight.
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Tech[/b][/td]
        [td]First of all: Death Stranding already runs with a GTX 1050 in Full HD with absolutely fluid 60 frames per second, which is probably due to the relatively modest engine. In addition, the game uses DLSS 2.0 technology, which takes anti-aliasing to a new level and provides much more sharpness, especially in the small details. (My GPUs: 2 x RTX 2080Ti)

But for this you need a graphics card of the RTX series from NVIDIA. Despite the graphics, strange animation glitches still occur in some places. For example, if we climb up a steep rock, Sam likes to get stuck in the landscape or jerks around on the edges.
[/td]
    [/tr]
 [tr]
        [td][b]Conclusion[/b][/td]
        [td]I wasn't sure what to think about the game, until I played it. The story is pretty weird, the gameplay beyond the brute action I usually appreciate and guess what happens most of the time during your delivery? Nothing. 
		
		However, the strong focus on inventory management, the many ways to get around and the complex effects of indirect multiplayer have completely taken me away from my personal life for hours now. Every delivery was its own little adventure and every time there was this deep satisfaction as I made my way through the world.

This also requires a little patience, because the ways can be long and getting lost is not unlikely - if then unexpectedly BTs appear or suddenly MULEs give me a good beating ... it can sometimes be quite frustrating. The will and the staying power to accept the new situation are then particularly important.

These are the core competencies of Sam Porter, who is actually more of a boyscout and mountaineer than a normal postman. The more parcels you deliver, the bigger, the more fantastic, the weirder Death Stranding becomes. Don't be intimidated by the strange concept of the game at the start, the story behind Hideo Kojima's latest project holds many moments for which it is more than worthwhile to mobilize the last reserves and continue. Step by step.

And hey: Norman Reedus
[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Fantastic game, loved the whole thing. People that have dismissed this game as a "walking simulator" are missing out on one of the best game of the last decade. It does simulate walking with more game mechanics than likely any game before, but this is not a bad thing. It makes travelling and traversal a core element of gameplay. This allows for a much more engaging open world in much the same way being able to climb anything did for Zelda BotW. Of course you will not spend the whole game on foot either, far from it. You get access to vehicles and can build roads and other mid game structures to aid you in traversing and surviving your journey. There is also combat with multiple weapon types and other assorted gadgets. If you have played Metal Gear you should get an idea what to expect, but also know that while there is combat and it is really cool and interesting to learn how to fight the non human enemies, combat is not a main focus of the gameplay. The shared world aspect is also a standout adding a lot of encouragement and seemed to often provide a structure in the right place to help you out, all provided by other players. Structures you build may also show up in other players games to help them and the game lets you know who has used your stuff and vice versa through a social point system. I really enjoyed the story, it is plainly just great science fiction through and through. It's creative, It has a lot of mystery, some suspense, it's engaging. It take's it's time getting to the meat and bones of what is going on but I also spent a good chunk of time in the mid game building, delivering and not progressing the story. Had I not done that I'm sure the pacing would have been great. That said, they really bring it all together in the end. The conclusion felt satisfying and I never felt the big questions I had the whole game were unanswered. A true masterclass in storytelling from Kojima. I highly recommend this game to anyone that loves good sci-fi and can enjoy a game that isn't always about killing everything that's in front of you. The challenge of a difficult journey and helping others along the way does actually make for a damn fine video game and one that deserves more acknowledgement than what it got.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I truly loved this game. It's an experience that sticks with you. It's a bizarre narrative on inevitability that doesn't come off as preachy or obnoxious. But, the spreading of hope and a possible future to a collapsed society feels rewarding in both gameplay and narrative. This game is not a game to just pick up and play in a casual sense. The gameplay itself could be a deterrent for a lot of people. The game gets arduous and very frustrating at times. Some occasions feel unfair but they also tend to be short lived. I love hiking and this gameplay actually appeals to me for multiple reasons but it still definitely gets tedious at times. I am a big fan of Kojima games so I may be bias (Ignore the multiple collectors items on my desk from years of collecting.) 

As for my conclusion, This game is best viewed as an experience than as a game. Sure it has scoring, progression, combat, upgrades, and customization, but that isn't what you will be thinking about after finishing the game. Beautiful visuals, killer soundtrack, and compelling story telling that makes the absolutely bizarre seem commonplace makes for something that is truly unique. I see myself putting many more hours into this game even after the story.

game is honestly a 10/10.  that being said it has some of the worst i mean woooorrrssstttt, driving physics.  i mean for a game where you deliver packages from one to point to another.  Motorcycles honestly clip and hang up on everything imaginable.  from the smallest of rocks to cracks in the road. not to mention somtimes just not being able to steer. also wait till you try to jump. You either hardly getting a foot off the ground to damn near floating through the air like your on the moon.  
Honestly im venting because i cant jump these silly trenches/canyons atm.  Its becoming one of my all time favorite games.  The game is so much more enjoyable on foot.  this game is like nothing else i ever played.  
But whoever designed and programmed the vehicles, burn. burn for what you did. 

Ps why would you make a street like sport bike and not somthan akin to a dirt bike.  Anyway buy this game its a good one!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game does its themes better through gameplay than Kojima's typically weird writing style. The feeling of comradery you have with other players was more compelling than any of the characters in this game. I think Kojima's a better idea guy than a writer, and you can see that in the themes and gameplay. If you want a deep and engrossing story, you should probably look elsewhere. Most cutscenes either had me laughing my ass off or cringing from how strange it felt. I think Norman Reedo does a pretty good job, and I think Mads Mikkelsen did a FANTASTIC job, but there wasn't enough of the two here to justify a glowing review.  

People HATE the gameplay of this game but I went into it knowing i'd like it, and I did. You pick gear, walk to a place, rinse and repeat. Sometimes your enemy is the environment, sometimes it's dudes with pointy sticks or guns, and sometimes it's spooky flying ghosts. The enemies get stale by the end of the game, but they serve their purpose well. I think the game shines more when you're hiking alone in your thoughts, but that's what a lot of people disliked so maybe I'm crazy. More games should require preparation as part of their gameplay loop, and I felt this game really did a good job of making you stop and think about your next move. Sure- you CAN just pack everything under the sun and trek off to your next destination, but don't be surprised when you get really frustrated from tipping over for the fourth time. My only complaint gameplay wise is that it could've pushed this idea further. 

TL;DR: Story sucks, but the themes of connection shine through in the multiplayer feature. Gameplay is mostly you walking and planning your route, so don't expect the combat to be fleshed out like MGS games. If this sounds awesome to you, you'll probably like it. if not, I'd suggest doing more research or staying away.

review: The irony of describing a game as a 'walking simulator' is that if you ever had a game that was an actual walking simulator, with in-depth walking mechanics and things to walk to, it would not be a 'walking simulator'. Death Stranding is that actual walking simulator, and it is supremely enjoyable.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game explores the question of "If you have someone who can't stand to touch or look other people in the eye and whose only real skill is being able to carry a lot of stuff in his backpack, how much would you have to change about the world to make that guy into a superhero?" It turns out you have to change a crazy amount.

This game explores that world in detail.

This the greatest army training simulator.
You wanna know what it's like to be in the army? Here you go. Play as some jaded, miserable cunt. Humping around in the mountains in the rain with a million pounds of useless gear on your back. Just to get shit on by everyone if you do less than perfect. And you subsist on energy drinks, beer, and bugs.

Also there's tar ghosts and babies.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Overall, it's fun, the world is immersive and the quests are perfectly normal. I wouldn't call it ground breaking but if you want a decently fun quest style game with great effects, this is what you're looking for. I think RDR2 and Farcry 5 are probably better as far as story goes, but the "trippy" elements of this game are interesting to me. "Walking simulator" is a valid title for sure. Combat leaves much to be desired but that's not really what this game is about. There is a "stalking" and "walking into danger" vibe that's pretty common through the game. 

I would give it 3.5 or 4 stars out of 5 if I was rating it. The graphics alone make it worth trying out if you have a machine that can handle it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[i](The review is completely spoiler-free.)[/i]

[h3]I appreciate it, but wouldn't actively recommend. 👍🤔[/h3]

It’s a kind of experience that you just don’t go around encouraging people to play, because it’s not [i]pleasant[/i] in the way games usually are, and will not appeal to majority. I think [b]you need to know you want it[/b] before you go in. I know what [i]I[/i] wanted - a Hideo Kojima Game about death. 🐋 Worked out just partially… But I don’t regret it. ❤

In order to appreciate it you need to pay attention and be willing to seek the satisfaction from playing in areas [b]other than instant dopamine spikes[/b] that recent games (especially mobile) conditioned us to. It’s rather difficult to digest. That’s why you might not be willing to invest money and time into it. It is however a fantastic treat for those who analyse game design, art, symbolism and are generally more appreciative than judging.

[i]Death Stranding[/i] is a very convoluted sci-fi thriller story wrapped in mechanics of terrain traversal, pathfinding, sightseeing, a bit of stealth, some shooting, and last but not least - appreciation. 🙏 But let’s ask the right question:

[b]Is this something that I should buy and play?[/b] 💦

The game has a AAA price tag. It is fairly long, especially if you're taking your time - I've heard people finish it in 30 hours, but I personally took like 110 hours to finish it to the credits - that’s cause I enjoyed my stay. 😄

[b]Is it well-spent time?[/b]

If you're in for the story... I'm afraid you'd be disappointed. 💀 In my opinion, this aspect could have been so much better. I think it's Kojima's unedited writing who's to blame. The pacing, dialogues, digestibility, conclusion - all are crippled in some way. And I say it with pity, because I’d love this game to be a masterpiece, because it has all the potential, but unfortunately just doesn’t deliver (hehe). 😢 So if you’re interested in the story - you could watch a “film” version of gameplay on YouTube; be advised however that quite a lot of lore is exposed via completely optional text “interviews” and emails, so you might be even more confused by the mechanics of the world. But then again, these could also probably be found on the net. [b]But but but! But there’s a reason this game is not a film[/b]. 🤔 Because it would suck as one. 😄 Honestly if this was a film or a series, it would be a 5/10 mess for me by cinematography standards. This is a [b][i]game[/i][/b] experience, there’s so much more to it than the story and storytelling, that I’d argue that the story isn’t even the biggest or most important aspect.

If you’re in for the gameplay… It’s been said a thousand times and the game is even marketed as [i]genre-defying[/i]. The majority of it is preparation for a trip, planning your route, checking out with cargo to be delivered and departure. Your enemies are slippery and rough terrain, the caustic rain that puts time pressure on you, the very few people that are still present on the surface and would very much like to come into possession of your belongings, and the ghosts of the dead who want to take you to the other side. So at least it’s a nice mix.

You probably have heard the “walking simulator” critique. It’s ironic how valid it is, and how it’s mostly meant to be [b]negative[/b], whereas I think it’s absolutely great. ❤ I’m not sure if people who found that as a downside have ever been on a mountain hike. For the first time in a video game I’ve experienced the lifelike difficulty of going down a hill with tens of kilograms of weight on my back. 💦 [b]It really does simulate walking[/b]. You can trip over inconspicuous rocks. You will regret not controlling your momentum. 🐋 And it’s not meant to be [i]pleasant[/i] if you think effortlessly traversing from point A to B is what’s [i]pleasant[/i]. That’s what I was writing about earlier - [b]if you value the [i]process[/i] over the [i]result[/i][/b] (which, by the way, I think is the healthy thing to do in life), if you find reward in the challenge - then this game might be for you.

The game tries to stay fresh for the tens of hours by gradually introducing new means of transportation, survival tools, weapons of defense and offense. There are a few biomes of environment, so it also freshens things up as you arrive in a new one.

I think many things that people find offensively “bad” have been intentional decisions in design. The game wants you to feel accomplished by first dragging you through hell and later putting it in contrast to how easy things are after you put the pioneer’s effort in building the infrastructure.

If you’re in for the experience… [b]It’s absolutely unique.[/b] You hike mountains, you ride motorcycles. There’s this ethereal feeling of isolation in freedom, as you’re on your solitary journey through the world so empty and rather unwelcoming, but one that can take you by surprise with its beautiful vistas. And yet at the same time you also feel connected to the other human players by the unprecedented [b]strands system[/b]. The footsteps you leave can be seen by other players. The paths you tread will be shared with others - hell you even contribute to treading out the grass that grows along them. Together with other players you will collaborate in creating the useful infrastructure of roads and other facilities that help you (and them!) on your way. And many, many more aspects that are state-of-the-art game design. ❤

It’s a story about connections. What is it trying to tell? To compliment people for their effort? To treat children with dignity? To find beauty in small things around you? That touch is necessary for you to be a healthy human? To be considerate and caring? That there’s salvation in mundane repetitive tasks of everyday and nihilism is not the way? With a bit of imagination and determination, you will find a lot of beautiful symbolic meaning in the story, about the connections you make with others throughout your life.

The one thing that’s [b]absolutely masterful[/b] and [b]couldn’t have been better[/b] in my opinion - is music. Kojima is known for having a taste in music and apart from the flawless score by Ludvig Forssell that perfectly emphasises on the dreamlike, mysterious atmosphere of electronic future that clashes with scientifically-tangible afterlife, the game is filled with commercial music that [b]was not[/b] specifically created for the game (apart from several pieces that [i]actually were[/i]), but effectively not only fits, contributes to and enriches, but even expands the experience. [b]Low Roar[/b], who’s the artist most exposed in the soundtrack, was such a discovery for me that I almost immediately went and bought the “Songs from Death Stranding” CD album (along with the actual OST) which features their best pieces. 👍👍👍👍👍 The songs reflect the game so perfectly - in lyrics, in timbre - it’s hard to believe they weren’t written specifically for it. (Actually I think they might have contributed heavily as inspiration.) The music, which I can listen to while driving or working, has effectively expanded my game experience onto the real world.

Is it worth it?

I have to admire and appreciate how Kojima approached the design of this one. He spoke in interviews that he wanted people to take something from this game that they could apply in their lives. And it’s absolutely great. Actually, I think it’s what art is for, and games can be art (apart from entertainment, which serves a different purpose). What I’m trying to say is that you might not need this game - you might already know what it tries to teach. 😄💦 But then again, even if you already know these principles it's good to refresh them from time to time. Especially in times of enforced isolation it's nice to play a game about being connected.

tl;dr 8/10, basically a mountain hike with ghosts

[i]i wanna feel
something again
memorable[/i]

Keep on keeping on, humanity. ❤

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Okay, I get how it's not everyone's cup of tea but, in my opinion, this game is a work of art. Yes its weird. Yes, its hiking simulator 2019. It can be slow, but I did not find it boring at all. And the story..... fucking incredible. The music... Fucking incredible. Hideo Kojima unleashed is a wonderful thing. I can't believe this game did badly when it originally released on ps4 last year.
Im gonna have to put the people who didn't like this in the same category as the people who said interstellar wasn't good, too dumb to properly follow it.
I don't want another death stranding but I do want to see what else Hideo Kojima can do.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I've been gaming since before gaming was even a term and this is in my top 10 of all time list. I rarely spend full AAA price on games and I almost never write reviews. I bought this with 95% certainty that I would return it and I'm so glad I tried it out.

As long as you go into this game with the full understanding that the entire point of the game is delivering packages from point A to point B and you're OK with that, you'll love it. The DS universe is incredible. I'm not sure if Kojima is a genius or a nutcase. Probably both. The lore is probably my favorite part. The story is fantastic and the graphics are some of the best I've ever seen.

Like most open world games, the missions can get a bit grindy but if you push through it, it will be worth it.

If you're even on the fence about this, just buy it. Set a timer on your phone for 1hr and 45 mins and if the timer goes off and you still aren't sure, return it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Just play it, you won't regret it!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Super fun and relaxing game, though the first few hours I wasn't sure if I made a good decision buying it (About 1-2 hours of cutscenes on a game I wasn't sure I was gonna like pushed me away), but I'm more than glad I kept playing! It is definitely a game you will either love or hate, and I think that's largely due to how unusual it's gameplay/story is. But I don't think that the term "walking simulator" is entirely accurate for describing this game, as it may give the idea that it is like other games which are often described as that. 

DayZ always comes to mind when I think of the majority of gameplay largely being a "walking simulator", but that feeling of being bored or the discomfort that brings was something I never experienced in Death Stranding. I think this largely comes from the fact that travel in a game like DayZ is consistently a perceived hinderance in the players mind, or an obstacle in the way of the true gameplay that your're just enduring to try to reach. Even though Death Stranding can invoke similar frustrations at times, the game shines in its ability to actually make it fun and satisfying to travel the world. The exploration/"walking" isn't a separate entity from the gameplay, but rather a well thought out, ingrained part of it that keeps you immersed - rather than another means to an end.

The beauty of the world and the graphics that back it up make it invoke feelings similar to hiking at times, and the gratification/rewards from accomplishing deliveries is executed extremely well. The story has great moments but also noticeably bad ones, but is gripping enough to keep me interested and striving to understand more on the more outlandish aspects of it. I would say that getting my first vehicle was the point that cemented my liking of the game, as it washed away many worries or uncertainties I had about how long my appeal for the gameplay would last in the long run, and I feel that is a good point for players to push to before giving up on the game. (Also, if you're a completionist type of player like me, this game is amazing in making that feel extremely satisfying)

Once again, this game is definitely not for everyone. I was extremely hesitant myself on buying it, since most games others say are relaxing but fun rarely have done the same for me. Luckily It turned out to be a game I love, but that uncertainty of what side of the coin you'll be on for loving or hating it (combined with the actual meat of its gameplay experience coming in after the max amount of time allowed to be played to refund) makes it somewhat risky to buy at it's price tag. I think it is an outstanding and amazing game, and if you share in the worries I had about the gameplay before playing, as well as know going in this isn't a typical action packed AAA game, then I think you might be on the side of loving it like I do and thoroughly enjoy your experience.


UPDATE(Beat Game): This is one of my favorite games of all time now. Absolutely amazing and the story made me ball my eyes out. Deserves all the praise it gets.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a polarising experience, you will love it or hate it. Either way, this game is worth playing and I will personally cherish this game.

I have never played a Kojima game before, I had never understood the hype around the designer. I was originally skeptical of this game, often labelled a walking SIM. However after playing death stranding I reject this idea. Playing Death Stranding has been one of the best experiences I've had in gaming period. Kojima's creativity and imagination is what fuels this amazing game, the design and details across the whole game from the basic 3D printed models found in your private room to the complexity of DOOMS and BBs. It all works, and to put it in plain English, is cool as f**k.

I must admit the gameplay is not for everyone and perhaps the weakest point of the game. The combat is somewhat lack-luster and the balance physics system can often be frustrating. However, there is still an action packed experience and a lot of fun and enjoyment in slugging deliveries across an apocalyptic America.

The narrative is deeply intriguing, interacting with a wide variety of core characters all who are dynamic and profoundly interesting in their own right. Who themselves are woven into the beautiful cinematics and experiences across America's various landscapes and settings. This is complemented further by the various dimensions or beaches which create a rich, surreal, dystopian atmosphere like no other.

Death Stranding also presents a reflection of modern society's fragmentation and political climate. Kojima contrasts these ideas present in the narrative further through the core gameplay with likes and shared structures amongst fellow porters.

The soundtrack of Death Stranding is stellar. Expertly curated and composed sparking various emotions and thoughts. With well placed triggers throughout the game as well as the ability to relax in your own private room to said soundtrack. This is how music in gaming should be done.

To conclude, Death Stranding not only made me think, but it made me feel something.

There are a lot of strange things that happen, and frankly some of the game is down right cheesy.  But once you hit the "central region", the game really opens up and starts making a lot more sense. I realized that the problem I actually had with the game at first was that it was SO unique that it seemed very foreign to me.  This is literally a new genre of game - in my nearly 30 years of gaming I've never seen anything like it.  The sheer uniqueness of the gameplay makes it very compelling.  Combine that gameplay with a very well thought out story and an amazingly beautiful and believable world and this ends up being an unforgettable experience.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I thoroughly enjoyed it. I think everyone should experience it. Definitely a no-brainer on sale, but I am plenty happy with my $60 purchase. Some notes:

1. Expectations. This is not a 3rd person shooter. Do not expect constant action. While it is true, a lot of time is spent walking/traveling, there are compelling systems in place to make it interesting. There is shooting and stealth as well, but it is not the main attraction (despite being quite good).

2. It is a Hideo Kojima game. There is story. Lots of story. [i] Story. [/i] There are tons of cutscenes, and everything about the story is original. Its weird, its easy to get lost in, but ultimately very good. If you are a fan of Kojima's stories, you probably have already played this, but if not, you definitely should.

3. Its long. There is a lot of game, and it takes a while just to get through the story. There is also quite a bit of end game content if you really enjoy the gameplay. However, I don't think you are missing anything important by skipping side missions and end game content.

4. It is unique and original. I love when AAA titles try new things. Everything about this game is trying something new. This is something worth supporting, simply so all big budget games are not reworks of the same formula. Sure this isn't perfect, but its different and new, and therefore exciting.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Graphically this game is amazing no two ways about it and the game managed to keep me interested even just being a package delivery service game. That being said some of the game design elements felt like they could be refined for a more streamlined experience and the story got a bit confusing at times due to too many buzz words being thrown around.

All in all a good game.
7/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Id say Empty Symbolism, Metaphor, and Landscapes about sums up this title. 

I decided to give Death Stranding a try and play it all the way through to see what the hype was about. Mainly due to the fact that, like the memes would suggest, it looks and feels like FedEx package Delivery simulator. 

Sadly that isnt true at all. At least FedEx Delivery people get to see some landscape variety, and see a bit of color during their day. 

Death Stranding is a game about moving random nonsense from Point A to Point B. And somewhere in between Edgy Character Number 6 spoon feeds you some reason why it matters. Really its like a lot of Kojima titles. It feels like it was written and designed by that Edge Lord kid you used to make fun of back in highschool, and most of the characters personalities read about the same. Really flowery lengthy philosophical nothing burgers abound in every single dialogue. 

You play as Norman Reedus. Literally just the same version of himself from the Walking Dead nearly. Who is about as warm and personable as a bag of rocks you dont want to hug because their pointy. For some reason you have a relationship with the president. Who dies in your arms during the first hour long cutscene that is the start of the game. and now you have to walk across the country alone.... for "Reasons". 

Gameplay is as follows. 

Boring Terrain -> Cross with your Package -> Deliver it really fast. Oh and dont take too long. Because the rain is time travel rain and makes it degrade really fast. Cus "Dead Things or Something"

Rinse. Repeat. BUT WAIT! You can now build an object you can deliver things too. In order to build a bridge. To cross a stream. So you can then deliver another package with "Story" written across it with bold letters a little bit faster. 

Once in a blue moon you have to fight something. Even on harder difficulty this is just designed to waste your time and Ruin your packages. These last a minute tops. 

The Fights are centered around forced Stealth components. Because it wouldnt be a Kojima game if the "Stealth Optional" didnt feel like it was shoved down your throat like a sponge covered in week old crusty chocolate. Where you have to avoid "Watcher" dead things. Which will drag you to the big Dead things that want to eat you and explode. So you throw your blood at them. and this kills them for some reason. 

Its often way faster to just kill the big dead thing than screw around "Stealthing". Which honestly makes the use of the Baby from the trailer 99% a waste of time that just screams at you anytime you stub your toe (You can blessedly mute it, thank god)

Everything is just a nothing burger of nonsense about "Being the Bridge to unite america" and "Human Connection" and "Look we have another sponsor. Drink 15 of these to get a buff from Monster Energy Drink"

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The visuals and graphics design, the sound design, the out of the box storyline, the acting and VFX effects.... the entire thing is just bonkers! Loving every second of this game! (Also works through GeForce Now streaming service which is just awesome in case you left your gaming rig/laptop at home and have your phone/tablet/ultrabook with you.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: the game is good

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A little background to the game, an explosion happened, fourth or fifth, I forget, but more importantly, the USA was changed for good. What was America turned into Norway, both in looks and size.  All people socially distanced, hiding themselves in bunkers. For a long time they kept the required 2m separation apart from one another. 

Although cut off from the outside world, people managed to retain their different regional accents, including well spoken English (BBC accent) and Spanish. Surprisingly, playing through this post-apocalyptic game so far, I haven’t encountered any  Irish. Because of this, I say it has broken the mold somewhat to other games of this ilk , thank god Colin Moriarty from Fall Out 3 isn’t here. 

As for the visuals, well its basically photo realistic, it looks amazing on a good rig. Dare I say it, it probably holds up to next generation consoles. 

The game is unique, and I had some amazing experiences travelling the world.  Walking through the waste land you really have a feeling of isolation. The only games I can compare it to where I had similar experiences are  Another World or ICO, that weird alone creepy feeling. 

The BT’s are genuinely scary, don’t ask me to describe them just play, it’s a Hideo Game. I have no idea what will happen next, but the story and the game play are so unique and bizarre (I did say this is a Hideo Game).

Gameplay includes allot of walking and managing your packages, not the one in the nether regions, but actual packages. It sounds boring but it’s a pretty cool concept and its actually fun. The combat I have experienced is a little clunky, reminiscent of the first Dead Space. It feels part of the character though, you not supposed to be a ninja or Daryl Dixon for that matter (crossbows are not available in the game).

One downside, there are major exposition dumps, but luckily not to a Mass Effect level, but close.  

Games should be rewarded by their originality and this is highly original. Beware though, it’s a game I class as Marmite, you either love it or hate it. As much as I hate Marmite, I love this game.  I am compelled to carry on. Unless there are some shite sandwiches  later on, I will go and say now, for me personally, this is one of the best games I have played  this year. 

9/10 – (-1 point deduction, too many rocks)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Owned since its release on PC but only just got around to playing and completing it over the past week, I absolutely no-lifed the shit out of this game and enjoyed every second of it. My initial worry was "okay so, how do you make a game about been a postman engaging" and of course, in good old fashioned Hideo Kojima style, even though I didn't understand a lot of what was actually going on, I still loved it because it was so different and weird, the story kept driving me forward and I WANTED to understand as much as possible.

there were always several ways you could deliver orders and they had several parameters that were required for a successful delivery which had me thinking "hmm okay so how can i get THESE packages from A to B, I could walk, take a vehicle, use ziplines. How heavy is the package? What gear should I use to facilitate its safe arrival, what supplies should I take? Will I run into enemies on the way?". Along with thinking about whether or not you had to keep the specified package upright, if you could only carry it by hand, maybe you weren't allowed to submerge said package in water so taking that route through the water maybe isn't the best idea. The game actively challenged you to think about each and every delivery and actually gave me a sense of accomplishment when I got it there in good time and in top nick, even after battling through the harsh post apocalyptic world that tries everything to stop you and ruin those packages, especially the timefall, that rapidly "ages" everything it touches.

What I loved the most was the online interactivity with other players, you could see certain people structures and use them, upgrade them, give them a like to show your appreciation to those players for using there resources to not only help themselves but to help others...there was a strong sense of camaraderie with your fellow porters, even though you could never actually see or speak to them directly...it strangely brought the world to life even more.

Of course it wasn't all about just running around delivering packages, there is combat and boss fights through the course of the game and you can very quickly find your demise or completely lose items or orders if you're careless.

Norman and Mads did a fantastic job and I don't think the game would have been as good or the same without them. I didn't realise until recently that Death Stranding didn't actually do as well as expected, that it generally got a bad rap for been "boring" which I personally couldn't agree less with but to each their own. Its a game with longevity and requires a lot of travelling about to and from locations which are made to feel longer due to the rocky, hilly, unpredictable environments or times when you have to slow down due to BTs or MULEs...maybe i'm just used to long travel times because I primarily play big open world MMOs but i never really saw an order and thought "fuck me I gotta go all the way over there or back over there again" I just did it and tried to take as many different routes as possible so I wasn't looking at the same things all the time. The game supplies you with a bounty of tools, you kind of have to meet the game halfway at that point and build the world.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Weirdly enough, this game triggers my resource gathering OCD I usually only get from RTS games. If you like to hoard in games, this game will exploit and reward that obsession. No doubt, I highly recommend this game when you're sick of nose-bleeding twitch shooters.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is one of those games that comes around once a generation. It might be the weirdest game I've ever played but that doesn't take away anything. I honestly thought this game looked boring and didn't think I'd ever play it but I picked it up on a sale and I don't regret it. If you have a gripe about all the famous people, I get that and I had the same complaint before I played it. I feel like Kojima did that because they're simply his favorite actors and wanted to include them in something he did. It constantly feels like he threw in all of his favorite things into this game which is something I'd want to do in a similar situation. 

The beauty of the game comes from the subtlety that hides behind the plot devices that are repeatedly slammed into your head which might steer some people away or be glossed over for that reason. It deals with social isolation, death, dopamine feedback loops, life-altering trauma and the collapse of nations while masquerading as a game about a biker babysitter who gets a job with Amazon and chugs Monster. I rarely find the urge in games to read all of the codex type files but its a shame not to in this game.

Normally I judge a game off of the entertainment value and this one has plenty, but this time I'm judging a game by the way it makes me play. Cooperation is at the forefront of the game mechanics with a satisfying system of liking to try to make you rethink the ways in which you get your oxytocin. If I could judge a game just on the intent behind it, I think this game would get the top award thus far in my life. Regardless of what you've seen about this game, its one of those things you will have to experience yourself to understand.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I liked this game, but I actually thought the main story would take longer and be more challenging. Maybe I should have increased the difficulty; on normal I beat the main series of "quests" (and a bunch of optional deliveries) in just under 50 hours. I really enjoyed the story, however, and thought Death Stranding was very entertaining overall.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is a weird one, though I'm not NOT recommending it because of that. The weird stuff is cool. The story is really interesting and is why I played for as long as I did, but there are some issues that make this game not fun.

As far as good things: It looks great, graphics are amazing. Voice acting, while everybody sounds super subdued they feel real and it makes sense for the setting. The music they included is great, I liked both the original soundtrack as well as the licenced songs. And as previously stated, I enjoyed the story.

The core gameplay is essentially just a walking simulator but with extra mechanics, you need to balance your weight, be careful of your momentum, make sure your cargo is set optimally etc. It comes down to basically just pressing 3 different keys over and over at all times so you won't fall over. After a few hours you won't need one of them because you realize it's just telling you where rocks are that you can already see, but then they introduce the BT enemies and while they are around I felt the need to continually press the button again. The weight mechanics felt odd as well, it has the mechanics for you to organize your gear the way you want to, the better optimized, the easier to move around, but the problem is there is a button that auto organizes your stuff so it's the best it can be each time, you can also do this in the field, so there is no reason to do it yourself. 

It just felt, so monotonous, with no real reason to do anything other than the main story. You get paid in "Likes" for completing NPC's deliveries or other players dropped packages. There doesn't some to be any thing I can do with these likes, it feels like it's supposed to be a currency, but there is nothing I can buy with them, or if I can, not in the first four hours.

Then there is the combat, you need to fight these slime monster things occasionally and it feels so, so bad. Not enjoyable at all, it feels slower than the main game, which is saying something. I don't understand how the action moments of an already slow game drag the pacing down even further.

I tried to like this game, I really did. It looked really fun on watching a few other players play through the first few hours. But I just didn't enjoy it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Pros: 
Great visuals
incredible facial animation 
nice soundtrack
awesome landscapes
unique and interesting story
huge open world 

Cons:
over-saturated with lore details and data
combat is simplistic and boring
very slow-paced
fetch questing gets repetitive and boring

Overall:
Death Stranding is a cool concept with some jaw-dropping scenes full of weird, unique surprises.  However, the grinding gets tedious fairly early on in the game, there are some longer cut scenes that drag the narrative down, and there is WAAAY too much data to read and understand in emails, interviews, tips, etc.   If you are looking for an action game, this may disappoint you.  I would classify this as an atmospheric adventure sci-fi questing game.  The price was worth it for me just for the outstanding graphics and soundtrack, its probably the coolest looking game ever made (IMO).  Unfortunately, the gameplay is only mediocre.  

visuals and audio: A+
gameplay: C-
overall: B

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I've only been playing this game for about 7 hours but I have to say it is one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. There are times that I truly forget that I am playing a game. The music is emotional and comes in at the right times to really give you the feeling that you truly are there. The gameplay itself is unique however the pacing of the game allows you to get accustomed to the controls. This game isn't for everyone but I still highly recommend it.

Edit: So I just finished the game and I have to say you will love this game! The writing, the music, the acting, the gameplay, everything about this game is amazing. There are a few small issues but that's mostly due to the limitations of the game engine. If you buy this game then at least give it a chance, I recommend getting through the first 3 chapters.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding has a lot going for it and I like it a lot.  It is not going to be everyone’s cup of tea with shear Sci-Fi and great story line with moments of frustration and monotony.  You need to progress to a certain level (No Spoilers) before you really feel like you are really travelling.  
Splendid, beautiful and immersive, I keep wanting to load up and deliver the packages.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I've not liked any AAA games for the last decade or so. This is mostly because none of them are willing to take any chances and I'm tired of the 107th version of the FPS or whatever. Kojima is willing to take chances and experiment with different styles of gameplay and I think it really set this one aside. I found the story quite compelling and was not able to guess the ending. The game mechanics were just difficult enough to keep me trying. All-in-all a very good game.

I'll note that experienced a lighting glitch completely throughout the game and never found a way to fix it. It did remove quite a bit of immersion, almost leading me to thumb down it. However I recognize this is likely a unique bug that has to do with my hardware setup, since I don't see many others complaining about it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The game captures Hideo Kojima's love for humanity and thoughts as an artist on the solutions to existential angst and nihilism. Its a wild ride, and worth every minute of it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is likely the only game that succeeded in making fetch quests fun, by gameplay loop and mechanics alone.

As is usual with Kojima's games, especially late ones, great worldbuilding and totally unique atmosphere go hand in hand with 3rd grade student tier writing (mainly dialogues). If you can suffer through those there's an interesting story to follow, complete with expected Kojima-style plot twists and turns.

Visually the game is very appealing (making better use of Decima engine than its own creators with Horizon Zero Dawn), with exception of poor dysfunctional AA implementation. Optimization is as good as MGSV had back in the day. However, many people - myself included - are experiencing "Access Violation" crashes, which can range in occurrence from once every few days to every 3 minutes, completely bringing any attempts to progress to a halt. Month and a half later it still hasn't been addressed despite mounting threads with 300+ posts. Despite that, I still feel inclined to smack that [url=https://youtu.be/S00cDEywCl8?t=681]Thumbs Up[/url] button for game's uncompromising creative vision alone.

[b]The best walking sim out there, 8/10[/b]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Excellent game!  Keep on keeping on!
Im not sure if its the inventory management, the story, the lonely world tripping over random rocks, but I am thoroughly enjoying learning more of the story as I traverse the differing landscapes.  Lots of exploring to do, hidden little bits of story and crazy cut scenes from trying random things.
Graphics are great, just 1 disappointment that ultra-wide formats do some weird stuff.  Also have when I play it for extended periods some textures dont load, which makes for game breaker.  Time to save and quit when that happens.  Probably for the best when I realize I played for 8 hours already today

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
At first I really liked this game. The graphics are amazing, and the sound track is one of the best I've ever heard. However, once the honeymoon was over, I hated this game and uninstalled it.

Came down to it not being any fun. Controls were really frustrating. For example, I would try to hold down both the left and right mouse buttons to stabilize Sam while, and if too close to the bike and he would start to pick more stuff up. What!? I found a lot of scenarios where I needed to tweak the default controls to compensate for stupid crap like that.

The final nail in the coffin was auto-save. I really hate auto-save in just about any game. This game is the worst. It is nearly impossible to tell when a save has been done, so when you're done playing and you want to go to bed, or do something else, well, you might lose a ton of progress. IT. IS. A. GAME. I should be able to save whenever I WANT TO.

Games are supposed to be fun, and if I find myself grinding away, fighting the controls, and overall not having fun, I stop. I don't have time to waste on a game like this.

Don't waste your money. Want to enjoy the graphics and soundtrack? Watch some YouTube vids of the game play.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The first Strand type game with Norman Reedus. 10/10.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: goty

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
[b]Death Stranding[/b] (DST) is a post-apocalyptic open world title not belonging to any genre, as it builds a unique gameplay from scratch. Players impersonate Sam, one of the few Porters that dare to brave the desolation left by the Stranding, a mysterious event that broke the barrier between the world of the dead and that of the living. After rejoining the UCA, Sam is tasked with traveling to the other side of the continent, uniting all the survivors in the process to restore America to its former glory. His journey through the wastelands will go beyond any expectation, and become a legendary tale.

🟩 [b]The Good Side[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Unique, satisfying gameplay formula[/b]
DST has a unique take on the open-world gameplay style, as it has players traversing incredibly vast stretches of land where the main obstacle are not enemies or dungeons, but the landscape itself. Most gameplay consists in fulfilling delivery contracts - which may sound boring. Instead this title manages to make an astoundingly creative experience out of it. With a vast array of tools ranging from simple ladders to advanced vehicles, each player will forge their own path to destination, with a reward system that keeps interest up till the very end.

[*][b]Incredible visuals & art direction[/b]
From mountain, river to the desolation of urban remains, this game is nothing short of majestic at every turn. Amazing landscapes only seldom found in your average open world, here instead become commonplace, with maniacal attention to the smallest detail. Models, animations and effects are of masterpiece-quality without any flaw or inconsistency.

[*][b]Revolutionary multiplayer[/b]
DST uses a unique asynchronous multiplayer, where structures built by others may appear in your world, and vice-versa. Not only that, but players will also be able to upgrade each others' structures, contribute to larger projects such as highways, and leave signs around in a fashion similar to Dark Souls - other than "like" each others' structures, exchanging XP in the process.

[*][b]Overall great story[/b]
Hideo Kojima did it again, as expected he managed to cook up an extremely convoluted story that branches into philosophy, human existentialism, history and a dozen other subjects with equal complexity, while also narrating the adventures, betrayals and losses of Sam and his companions. Too bad it loses a lot later on, but it's overall memorable.

[*][b]Amazing soundtrack[/b]
The music accompanying the most iconic moments and boss fights is nothing short of perfect, amplifying the magnitude of those moments tenfold. The selection of tracks employed here suits masterfully each situation, contributing to the narrative pathos.
[/list]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2173866322

🟥 [b]The Bad Side[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Mediocre boss fights[/b]
The bosses of DST are mostly disappointing, either having simplistic patterns with zero evolution in the course of battle, recycled designs, and/or being hulking bullet sponges without any unique mechanic to them. Combat might not be the main focus of the game, but in contrast with the overall quality, these fights do not live up to par.

[*][b]Control problems[/b]
Many players (including myself) have experienced a repetition / delay in game inputs, both on KBM or Gamepad. This bug can lead to weapon misfires, unwanted actions, and very well your death in the most serious combat situations. A nasty bug that definitely makes the experience more annoying.

[*][b]Story pacing becomes a drag later on[/b]
As you approach the late/end story phases, an excessive repetition of already seen scenes, along with some good old complete nonsense that contradicts things stated earlier on, ruins the narrative pacing quite a lot. It becomes a mess for the sake of BEING a mess - in the later stages.

[/list]
[h3]Rating: Excellent[/h3]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1989090445]Click here for the complete Rating Chart[/url]
[i]It took me 91 hours to finish all side content and complete the game on Hard. For this amount of content and excellent quality, I can suggest buying the game for full price without remorse.[/i]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2179653514

[h1]In-Depth Breakdown[/h1]
🎮 [b]Gameplay Analysis[/b]
Gameplay is divided into Exploration, Character Management, Deliveries and Combat.

[b]Exploration[/b]
Initially plays out on foot, though soon enough will be supported by vehicles and more advanced means later on. Traversing the landscape has a variety of mechanics to it including fatigue, stamina to resist effort, balancing your character to prevent falling down, and various environment phenomena such as storms. There is not much to explore as the world turned into a wasteland, the few and far between points of interest are almost all mission-related, though some collectibles and secondary NPCs can be found by the attentive explorer. 

A handy map will enable planning your paths, your scanner will reveal hazards and items around you, while the structures of other players may help you in your journey if they spawn in the right place. The land is vast, varied and full of unexpected dangers.

[b]Character Management[/b]
Is done on the fly while exploring or in a more complete way at one of the many outposts available. You will be able to use 3D printing to craft weapons, equipment, utility via terminals, with the resources found while exploring or gained by leveling up the trust with each outpost with successful deliveries. Making sure you have all the necessary equip and managing your weight is fundamental, depending on what type of mission will be your next. Being overburdened with cargo will lead to massive maluses, and quick stamina loss. Your character can level up passive stats as he makes more and more successful deliveries, each will benefit him differently such as more cargo capacity, or better balance.

[b]Deliveries[/b]
Are the main activity and are divided into several categories, from standard ones to time-sensitive or with other special conditions. Making sure the cargo arrives in good state is the primary concern, as too much damage to it will void the contract and in some cases trigger a game over. Depending on time, cargo status, weight and other factors you will receive a rating, equivalent to a certain amount of reputation with a particular client. Leveling up reputation unlocks weapon blueprints, gadgets and many useful tools. 

[b]Combat[/b]
Plays out in third-person and can be either melee or with guns, grenades and devices. Killing people is possible but strongly discouraged as it has terrible consequences - a vast array of non-lethal weapons is available and effective. Not only humans but also monsters from the "other side" will be your enemies, either being stealth or fighting them openly are viable strategies. Combat may not be the main focus but holds up quite well and has mechanics like dodging, parrying, headshots and status effects to build a serviceable system. Enemy AI is not too brilliant however, rather predictable.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2178459199

[h2]Technical Breakdown[/h2]
[u]PC Specs: RTX2080Ti, Ryzen 3900X, 32GB RAM DDR4[/u]

[list]
[*][b]Critical Problems[/b]
None.

[*][b]Optimization[/b]
Miraculous. The game uses very small CPU and GPU percentages compared to the amazing quality delivered.

[*][b]Performance[/b]
The game runs without issues in 1440p 85hz maxed out.

[*][b]Bugs[/b]
Control input issues. Using a gamepad might degrade performance, Force Off steam input in proprieties to fix this.

[*][b]Other Issues[/b]
None.
[/list]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Don't expect action. This is the Millenial version of Solitaire. You bring packages from Point-A to Point-B. Sometimes its really difficult and frustrating. The mechanics are traversal. The story is bound with surealism and very well done. 
My only complaint is the vehicle mechanics on slopes. Other than that, a very tightly bound game. If you're expecting something easy-going and slower paced, you'll be happy. If you're expecting a shooter - you're wrong.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I liked the game but it's not for everyone. 

Graphics:
Great graphics, nice details. I like landscapes which are fairly amazing although a bit plain, mostly stones while vegetation is rare (I guess due to the story, but still would be nice to have a bit more variety)

Music:
Nice and calming, it is set to play in the specific moments of the game, if you want to hear it more often you need to set it up (although it seems to stop every now and again)
Tracks unlock as you progress through the game, not for streaming due to licencing.

Mechanics:
Prepare for grind.
If you just follow the story, it will be a rough ride through the tough terrain but a nice experience nonetheless. However if you try to complete most additional orders, build and upgrade infrastructure, get best standing with all the locations, etc - then it’s going to be a long grind. 
For story-only, I would advise to play “offline”, with the world not polluted with other players' structures, it will make it a bit more difficult but will add to the experience.
If you plan to do more, then you should use “online” mode to have structures from other players appear in your game, even though sometimes it feels like too much “noise” (the game itself decides when and how much to show from other players).
The boss fights are not so good either.

Story:
That’s a tough one.
The story is so twisted and abstract that it's hard to understand it for a while (if at all).
Main theme is recreating [strike]USA[/strike] UCA from the perspective of [strike]Amazon[/strike] delivery guy, and it feels rather cringeworthy.
While the story is interesting, too many times I had moments of “wtf head scratch”.
I think the story would fare much better if the game theme was “joining colonies on planet Mars” (wouldn’t be much of a difference)

Summary:
tldr; interesting game, good looking, nice but rare music, cringeworthy story, grind

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
After 20+ hours not even my compulsion to see what happens will allow me to play this game any longer.  It is an absolute dredge to do ANYTHING in this game, with the second half of the game full of time wasting, forced long journeys just to....annoy I would assume?

Sam controls like crap.  The vehicles control like crap.  You get stuck on the smallest rocks and due to the mostly terrible controls you will miss ladders, tumble down cliffs and things like that.  I also had a weird issue using a bluetooth xbox one s controller, that it would do multiple inputs to a single button press sometimes (like hitting start to open the menu and it would open/close rapidly a few times for some reason). This is the only game I have this issue in.  The game technically runs AMAZINGLY, playing at 4K60 for the entire length of the game with no stutters, although the game did crash once and I lost a ton of progress.

Ultimately, the game is seemingly designed to be a an absolute chore and slog, which IMHO is.....awful.  I didn't find the game fun to play past hour 5,  with wanting to know more about the story and the very small feeling of accomplishment when you complete a delivery keeping me going.  Honestly, watch a story recap (thats at least 45 minutes long) and wait for it to enter your impulse buy price range.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is about helping each other in times of crises. The NPC gives you lots of positive reactions because of what you are doing to them. I know, I get that the advertisement for this game is kind of dark but it really is just about helping other people specially with what's happening today with COVID-19. For a sci-fi game, it has spiritual themes and that makes this a game have a unique story.

Gameplay-wise, it is just simple really. You are courier and you pick-up and deliver those things. The challenge is you need to plan the gear that you will bring with you along with the "cargo" that you will be delivering. You cannot just bring anything because you have some limitations such as how high the boxes stack up and/or the weight of all of it including your gear. There are hazards in the world that you can counter with some specific gear and you need to check that every time you go out.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Not an easy decision to put thumb down.

Pro:
- great, weird-in-a-good-way story
- interesting concept and game play
- great attention to detail (no surprise with a Kojima game)
- great music score
- Half-Life cross-over

Con:
- becomes BOOOORING too quickly!
- Severe resource scarceness for single-player compared to multi-player!
(I miss a choice at game start - pure single-player -> more resources or less pricy costs - multi-player -> as-is resources and cost)
- combat is underwhelming, esp. against human enemies

As I prefer single-player, the need for boring resource farming beat all the good, in the end,
On single-player, one can get through the main story no problem - but side-activities like trying to complete roads (even without upgrading them to level 2 or 3) is close to impossible without extremely boring resource farming. Travelling without roads becomes boring and annoying quickly.

If you can get it on a STRONG DISCOUNT - go for it, it's worth it just for the weirdness alone.
But for full price - simply no!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is fantastic. I almost never finish games these days, but this one had no problem keeping my attention throughout. It's something different.

I've seen it get a fair amount of hate as a "walking simulator." There's a lot more to it than that. It's true you spend large chunks of time trekking across the map, but you're not just walking, you're *traversing,* making decisions about your route, taking advantage of a bunch of tools at your disposal. It's more of a backpacking simulator than a walking simulator. If you like grueling treks across the wilderness, or even if you don't like the actual thing but can understand the sense of accomplishment there, this aspect of the game is hugely satisfying. And, like I said, there's a lot more going on. That fairly mundane baseline is essential for the emotional magnitude of the game's other mechanics -- without spoilers, let's just say it lulls you into a sense of calm so the other stuff really hits home. And they really keep it fresh -- throughout the majority of the game they're continuously introducing new mechanics, and finding ways of messing with your comfort zone. 

Overall the controls are great. You feel very physically connected to the world. There were a few moments where the interface caused frustration, and if I was feeling impatient the frequent micro-cutscenes were a little tiresome. No deal-breakers there though.

The story is wacky. It's a lot of fun once you get into it. It's confusing at first, but gradually comes together into something undeniably unique and frequently surprising. Personally, the parts I liked least about this game have to do with the campiness that features prominently in its core narrative. It's not that I hate camp, it's just that in this context some of the cheese here feels like a blemish on an otherwise perfectly realized world. Maybe it won't seem cheesy to everyone -- it's really not any cheesier than the majority of games, it's just noticeable here. Even with the cheese I ultimately loved the storyline. The characters are excellent and the game managed to illicit more feeling from my cold, jaded heart than anything else so far in 2020.  

It's worth noting that a few of the cutscenes are LONG. Mostly this feels earned, but they drop a big one on you right near the beginning of the game, and I will admit I wasn't sure if this game was for me at that point. Stick with it.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
As a long-time Kojima Productions fan who was disappointed with MGSV's messy implementation of busy mechanics that cluttered and obscured key story elements to the point of cumulative frustration, I am extremely impressed by Death Stranding. I'm going to keep this brief, and let other reviewers do the bulk of the... heavy lifting...

The way this game's mechanics unfurl before you is a really enjoyable experience. What at first seems to be a potentially tedious hiking simulator offers up ample in-game rewards for your initial slog, in the form of tools which ease your task significantly, trek by trek. The net result of this progression is that you feel that you  are working hard, and getting rewarded for it: 'likes' from real players who are using the structures, handouts, and roads [b] you've [/b] built; incremental upgrades to your tools and weapons; unlocked vehicles... Death Stranding is like a study on what positive feedback means to the human who wants to play and be rewarded. Themes of oxytocin and the neuroscience of 'reward' and the value of social connection play out in optionally-read 'interview' data that fills you in on backstory as you progress. These themes set up a cohesive, yet often pleasingly unintrusive 'strand' which inspires a nice impetus to keep playing to see what will come.

Traditionally, I hate grinding with a passion. It is--for me--play distilled into the kind of meaningless work that I use videogames to try to escape from in the first place. But the game rewards you for grinding, without keeping you at arm's length for tens of hours first; the golden ring is always in sight, and the tangible, useful rewards that shooting for them nets you are near-certain. Almost every action that you can do serves some kind of purpose which feeds into the overall systemic web of mechanics that will make your game easier the more of these actions you fulfil. But you're the agent here; grinding is something you'll do when you want to do it (and if I do, you will), and you won't have to do it when you don't want to.

This is a very rewarding time-sink of a game, with neat thematic layers exploded into various elements of the game: plot exposition; gameplay; the Dark-Souls-esque 'convoluted time'-flavoured online multi-verse co-operation which really re-invigorates a sense of humanity through a very brute lack of firearms and egoic grandstanding (can you imagine?). After the mess of The Phantom Pain (opinion!) this is a great return to form for Kojima Productions.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Alright, so yeah, it's a walking simulator, but it's also much more than that, it's an experience about people connecting with each other and sticking with one another to overcome challenges we all can't fix on our own; with wacky interesting lore of the universe they have uniquely created.

I recommend this to ANYONE who likes stories, movies, relaxing, horror as well as survival games. 

Because whilst your walking up a mountain, or down, a song could pop on half way up, and then you're surrounded by BTs (invisible enemies in the game), and then each region of the game you unlock, more of the story you uncover.

I wasn't going to think I'd like this game, but I'm not going to lie, I love this game for what it is, as well as its universe. 
It's wacky, crazy and interesting all at the same time, whilst feeling believable. You get attached to the characters and feel like they're real too.

If you still don't know, I suggest buying it and testing it for one and a half hours, and if you don't like it? Hell, you can refund it and no harm is done. But I do suggest buying it and trying it out, you may find out you love it, such as me.
I haven't even finished the story yet.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is so-so.

On the one hand, the game is unique. Story is weird as af but makes me very curious to know more. The game mechanics and the idea of sharing resources with other players is very interesting. It feels very good to work together and the sharing. Actors-Actresses are also great. World is beautiful.

On the other hand, gameplay wise is basically a walking sim. 90% you will be just carrying resources from A to B. There is a lot of repetitive cutscenes-transition animation that makes it very tedious too. Even though you can skip them but since there is a lot of them, it's getting really tiring. You get more tools and weapons in the later stage of the game but a lot of times you can just ignore it and not really use them.

In conclusion, I think Kojima took a lot of (bad) elements from MGS5 and continued with it in Death Stranding. The open-world aspect is interesting but the world is quite generic. Same as MGS5 you go from one location and do the same quest over and over again which in the case of Death Stranding is carrying items from A to B. The way the story progresses is weird. It's not exactly linear but every time you finish an order they tease you with a tiny bit of lore you don't understand. At the beginning or by the end of a chapter they may tease you with bigger cutscenes but you still don't understand anything.

All in all, I miss the linear, compact experience from MGS1-4. MGS5 lack variety and it's basically a grindfest of same quests and the pace of the story is weird. Sadly Kojima continued this in Death Stranding but managed to at least make an interesting concept of resources sharing.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Me before playing DS: Lmao wtf is this walking/delivery simulator bullshit that Hideo spent 5 years of his life span on? This is really what we get after waiting so long?

Me after playing DS: This is one of the best games I have ever played in my life.

Point is, this game does appear to be boring but it is one of those games you have to play to truly understand and grasp what the creator was going for. At first glance it does look like a boring game and truth be told, at times it can be. But the awesome narrative will keep you going forward and wanting to make the next delivery. The story is amazing, and it's full of popular actors/directors playing the characters of the game such as Norman Reedus, Mads Mikkelson, and Guillermo Del Toro that really do the games plot justice with their professional acting. The visuals are some of the best I've seen and the optimization is spot on. Gameplay wise, don't get this if you're looking for a fun experience and couldn't care less for story. The gameplay consists of delivering packages over the continent to link up the remaining cities, and to do this you need to tough out certain terrain, bring supplies to help you cross certain paths and hope other players have set up devices for you to use as well to make it to your destination while braving BT and terrorist territories. As you go you unlock more equipment that make the job easier such as vehicles, mechs, and weapons. Boss fights are very unique and fun too, but they take a while to get to, and each combat sequence means something which is why there is very few. 

If you want to experience an amazing story with some different gameplay from other games that can sometimes be fun or infuriating with some occasional (yet really cool) action, or if you're just a Kojima fanboy, get this game. Anyone looking to dive right into a fun game that gets to the point, stay away. I can't really give this game a score as it's more of its own experience from other games, with nothing really else to compare it to.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I have really struggled with this game. There was so much hype around it, when it had a small Steam sale earlier this month I thought I'd pick it up and it would keep me entertained for the month.Unfortunately, this is one of those games that really does NOT live up to the hype. I can't tell you the last time I experienced a title with so many cut scenes. I appreciate that Kojima is considered an auteur; but this time around I can't help but feel that if he wanted to make a movie or mini-series? Then he should go make one...I rather wish I'd not persevered with it as much as I have, as I could refund it quite frankly. Now I'm caught between simply uninstalling it and moving on, or trying to continue playing and complete the title - but I'm not sure I've got the patience for it.Addendum: I forced myself to finish it, my opinion hasn't particularly improved. Generally frustrating game if one can actually call it that. I sincerely doubt I'll ever buy another Kojima title.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Excellent atmosphere -- visuals, music, ambiance were all really incredible.The gameplay itself was good, for the most part. Content is varied and there are a lot of choices you can make (mostly about your loadout), all of which have a clear/satisfying impact on play. There are several competing systems that make these decisions interesting -- weight and energy vs. speed, terrain maneuverability, contract efficiency, firepower, stealth, etc. I went into the game expecting it to be mostly post office simulator, so I got a solid chunk of enjoyment out of this.Mechanics were fine -- supporting all of the systems in play is mostly enough for me. They work acceptably, though not perfectly. E.g., movement is a bit buggy in edge cases. Moving on a steep hill, if you hit the wrong terrain, you might just teleport instantly 50 yards down a slope and take a bunch of damage/drop a bunch of stuff. Not great, but if you know that these kinds of issues exist, it's not terribly taxing to play around.Menuing and UX were not great. The whole experience of being in your private room is super annoying. Cutscenes and animations on every interaction. Weird camera switches. Have to aim with the mouse before you can use a hotkey. The inventory management menuing was redundant 3 times over. Not a showstopper, but a completely unnecessary pain point.The delivery of the worldbuilding, plot, and message of the game are all piss-poor. My best guess at an explanation is that the game was very directly idea-driven -- Kojima had a theme in mind and then a bunch of specific scenes and visuals that he wanted to see, and then he backfit everything else into those fixed points piecemeal. The result is a complete clusterfuck with a minimum of coherence in any axis. If the game weren't so centrally focused on exploration and story, I wouldn't mind a fraction as much, but as it is, I find neither the world nor narrative to be a compelling reason to play the game.If you go into the game expecting it to make absolutely no sense as you're playing it, and the description "futuristic, pretty fedex simulator with famous actors, ghosts, and birth metaphors" interests you, then it's worth getting, but I'd pay $20 for it at most.
