title: DEATH STRANDING
review: A very polarizing experience, but I enjoyed my time playing.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: [h1] Death Stranding: [/h1]For years since the release of MGS1 on the original playstation, gamers have been asking themselves whether or not Hideo Kojima is a narcissistic madman or an industry savant. With the corporate shackles off from leaving Konami, and having his first independent release with his own studio we can finally begin to answer that question. [h1] Preface: [/h1]I originally played through Death Stranding on PS4 Pro, and went in with healthy skepticism yet was hoping for a special gaming experience. And I must say that personally I think Death Stranding is a great game. I think it has niche appeal and will not resonate with your average video game enthusiast, however the audience it aims for will love this experience. The story admittedly can be preachy at times and over dramatic. The gameplay can sometimes feel monotonous. And you may or may not grow to like the main cast of characters. However I think if you look beyond certain flaws the game has you'll find one of the most unique interactive experiences you'll ever potentially have. It's not a game you can watch someone else play or get a grasp of through gameplay footage, even I wouldn't watch someone else play Death Stranding. It must be experienced first hand by actually playing it to really understand it's appeal. Despite the game socially commentating on how we live in an isolationist society relying too much on parasocial relationships, it ironically asks the player to experience the game alone to best enjoy it (Asynchronous multiplayer system aside which is actually great). [h1] Rambling: [/h1]The game itself deconstructs traversal making the environment an obstacle whereas in a regular game that would be via enemies, over the top set pieces, or static puzzles. And in stereotypical open world/sandbox games traversal is relatively boring by just holding down a direction waiting for your destination to appear without having to consider your surroundings. Death Stranding really makes you consider your approach to the "Journey" as opposed to the destination itself. What I mean by that is the planning of what equipment to take, how much cargo you want to take on, the route you'll follow, and consideration of potential hazards that come along the way. This also includes potentially being flexible since things can go south fast and you have to be ready to improvise in those situations. Reaching the end of a delivery is satisfying, but only because of how difficult and arduous deliveries can be. Luckily the game becomes easier as you play along by unlocking tools/resources over time that'll make your trips less stressful.The story while a bit convoluted and may sometimes even make you cringe (The more self-indulgent side to Kojima that you may or may not like) has some well executed overarching positive messages that can be felt the further you progress into the game. There's a decent amount of character growth and discovery as you learn more about the world around you while going west to reconnect a fictionally fractured America. I'd like to think that the abstract and vague presentation of the story's themes allows for open interpretation on what Kojima was trying to communicate to the player. Sometimes the symbolism is clever and other times you might roll your eyes.Personally I cared more about the character driven narrative in Sam's personal journey with BB as they cross the country together than the reconnecting of the post-apocalyptic America plot line (Not that the overarching plot was bad, but it felt weaker than the individual character stories), but that may just be me. There's a lot of lore for people into finding out every little detail of the game through written logs in the form of emails, interviews, and memory chips that help with unanswered questions and some plot holes. It's a shame that this bit of world building is implemented this way, but I don't think they would have been able to fit it in with the regular cutscene sequences. Also I think Kojima wanted you to work for the "full picture" in terms of the story (This can be a good or bad thing depending on the player's sensibilities). The ending itself will probably get you emotionally and will cause you to take some time to think introspectively about a lot of different things. Unrelated but it's ironic that the events in-game are parallel in an abstract sort of way to how things are currently going now IRL (As of the time I'm writing this review) in 2020, but that's neither here nor there. Playing through Death Stranding made me realize what qualities I really like and do not like in the way Kojima crafts his games. I think the campy nature of MGS3 made its way here just toning it down a bit with the goofiness and increasing the character drama. I also think the worlds that Kojima builds are very atmospheric and immersive with Death Stranding being the best out of all his titles in that regard. He has a knack for bringing together talented people like the actors that portray the characters in-game, and the music he's curated that come in as BGM when necessary. Speaking of the soundtrack its amazing, the music really fits the tone and themes of the game. However the story telling is a mixed bag sometimes it's awe inspiring and engaging, other times it feels needlessly drawn out for the sake of over the top theatrics similar but maybe not quite as bad as MGS4. (I'm using Metal Gear games as a point of reference since there are certain elements/conventions from those games storytelling wise that are here in Death Stranding).[h1] Concluding Thoughts: [/h1]Ultimately Death Stranding shines for me personally because it's a perfectly imperfect game if that makes any sense (In an odd way I think that's part of why I like it so much). The positives outweigh the negatives in terms of the execution of all the ideas put into place here. Kojima put all his eggs in this basket and I think he mostly succeeded in the creation of this avant-garde styled interactive experience. It may or may not be a masterpiece to some, but I believe this will be a game that will be talked about for a long time regardless, especially as it ages. I think how it's perceived by the public matters a lot less than the fact it exists at all in the first place, finally finding it's place on PC. So I implore you to please enjoy what it has to offer, the good and the bad. To those that give Death Stranding a chance, take your time, and enjoy the ride. It's a game that is much more rewarding going at your own pace (As opposed to rushing yourself), and taking in the world that Kojima built. It's easy to fall into the trap of only doing side quests, but I'd recommend primarily focusing on the main campaign if you don't want to get burnt out (If this is your first rodeo with the game). If you just do those simple things you'll probably find something that resonates with you in Death Stranding. So just keep on keeping on.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: [h1] I swear if this was an indie game, people would give this game a "meh" and hop on to the next game. [/h1]Do you remember the awesome trailers of this game before its release? Or how people discussed awesome theories everywhere? Or how incredible was the BB fan theories? Or how we were dreaded by the mysterious 5 humanoid figures floating in the sky in the first beach trailer? Or how metaphorical and a mysterious mindfck we thought this was going to be? You do? Well sucks to be you then because THEY MADE EVERYTHING COMPLETELY LITERAL!The game started interesting with cutscenes and heavy dialogues. Then the gameplay happened and it was surprisingly satisfying. I was genuinely happy with the gameplay. Then I completely forgot about the story and instead build roads etc. like crazy. Then it got boring and I remembered that the game had a story and decided to go with the main quests for a while. Then the story became repetitive and boring and I went back to building crap and delivering sh*t to some irrelevant NPCs again. This cycle continued until the last snowy mountain area. Then I snapped and stopped giving 2 cents about deliveries and all those side quests and went for the story without any detour.When I was at that point, the game lost its charm in my opinion when it took everything too literal. When the game finally (reluctantly and half assed) decided to reveal some things I was like "yeah I thought so" or "duh" or "really? that's it?". Also let's not forget that this is such a dialogue and cutscene heavy game but it expects you to stop caring about them most of the time and instead go read lots and lots of texts in the form of mails and interviews etc.The game also likes to drag itself on and on and on and on and on by leaving you hanging every time the story is about to advance. I've never sighed this much before while playing a game I think. Game reveals (not really) most of its secrets at the very last chapter but by that time you already figure out everything for like 12 times thanks to same cutscenes/dialogues repeating themselves from different POVs.Lastly, dialogues are sometimes dull and slooooow so enjoy catching some Zs.After playing this for 96 hours straight I can safely say that I hate this game as much as I love it. I don't think I'll ever touch it again though. So yeah buy it and play it. It's a different game and has a different pace. But don't get your hopes up too much and overrate it before playing it.[spoiler] I CAN'T BELIEVE THEY WENT WITH THE "POWER OF FRIENDSHIP" TROPE FOR THE ENDING OH GOD! [/spoiler][spoiler] Die-Hardman's facial animations and acting in the last chapter was god tier work! It was pure art! [/spoiler]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game makes me feel things i never thought i'd feel, the story while convoluted, conveys a message in a beautiful display, Kojima's directing skills are still unmatched on this media, the cast is top notch and the graphics are beautiful. There's nothing like walking around a landscape i'd probably never visit in real life, the icelandic inspired views are some of the most beautiful things you'll see in a videogame and the soundtrack that plays in the middle of the missions are simply the best i've ever heard, hand-picked by Hideo himself, a delightful taste in music that unveils emotions and goes well with the plot and what's going on inside Sam's head. In gameplay matters it's pretty simple yet enjoyable, the physics are not the best, but overall it works just fine and it's mostly fun. Nothing else to say about it, i fell in love with it last year, truly a masterpiece that is mostly misunderstood and one of the best game experiences i've ever played.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Honestly One of the Best Games I've Played

This game features avant-garde gameplay coupled with a seriously esoteric story. It's new and refreshing, and that's part of what makes this game so much fun to play, but there is a lot more to the game than just that. As of right now, I haven't finished the game, but I already feel confident in saying that this experimental title probably holds the most meaningful game mechanics I've ever experienced.

Death Stranding, at bottom, is all about one thing: building bridges. Not literally of course, though it is possible to build bridges, but figuratively speaking. In terms of story, the country is divided, and it is your job to bring it together by spreading the message that we are stronger together than divided. A common message, to be sure, but it is not just the story of the game which holds this meaning, it is the gameplay itself, specifically, it is the way that the disparate "singleplayer" experiences bleed together into a "quasi-muliplayer" experience. Every structure you (the player) places could show up in someone else's game, their parallel universe, thereby easing their journey of uniting the country. This collective easing of each others' journeys is what builds the bridges between us, the players, and it is what makes this game so unique: it's about competition and mutually beneficial relationships with others.

Often when I find myself climbing a mountain, crossing a waterfall, or barely escaping from a band of terrorists with my life, I deliberately try to place items, signs, or structures in the hopes that, maybe, just maybe, I can make the job of the next player to follow in my footsteps easier. I build roads to connect all the cities to enable both myself and other players to more easily traverse the otherwise shattered landscapes of Death Stranding's world easier. And whenever I find myself in trouble, with sparse equipment and empty weapons, I can usually find my way out of any sticky situation more easily by relying upon the bridges other players have built to make my journey easier in turn; bridges that come in the form of ladders, ziplines, motorcycles, shelters, or even the literal bridges built by others to make my journey easier.

It is truly a wonderful experience. We are each on our own odyssey, unable to work together on the same one, but able to help others on their way as we briefly cross paths in the world of death stranding. It is a powerful message, one which I hope can be realized outside of this video game also... whether that be in the real world, or in other video games also. Kojima's latest masterpiece is truly a revolutionary title.

And to give us accolades and motivation for helping others along in their journey, we are given likes, likes which (even in the game) are said to release oxytocin, though I'm sure that for me, as well as many others, it isn't simply about the likes. In fact, I believe that Kojima specifically put the MULE enemies, porters who are so hooked on delivering cargo, into the game to remind us that we are not there just to deliver packages for likes, but to finish our mission and to help others finish theirs. In a nutshell: we're here to build bridges.

So for anyone who is tired of playing murder-simulators, or other games where violence and competition is the answer to all of life's problems, I recommend that you give this innovative new walking-simulator a try.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The best game I've ever played. Masterpiece. I'm fully aware that a lot of people don't like the gameplay but there hasn't been a point in the game when I felt like the gameplay was boring. The story keeps you coming back to the game. I find that it's a perfect game to listen music to while playing. Bought it at full retail, no regrets.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This isn't a shoot em up, you spend your time trying to find routes to deliver packages. The game is fairly easy and the most tense parts are at the start. The story was ok but i must warn everyone the game ends with almost a 2 hour long outro and that just has cutscenes where you listen to people talk about the most boring stuff ever and this almost ruins the game. Over all it was relaxing to play. As far as game play goes its was good and performance wise no problems at all.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
You did it. 30 years old man cried. 
Very emotional story. Gameplay's mechanic and scenario are harmonically co-exists with each other. This game is a masterpiece.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I can't believe I spent money on this game.  

TL;DR
If you get it, spare yourself the full price and for the love of your precious time and joy in life, skip all optional content.  By doing this, you stand a chance to maximize the great parts (visuals, creative setting, story) and minimize the horrible parts (the entirety of the gameplay).

Pros
The world they create is wonderful, very creative and intriguing.  The context and story are are very good.  

Cons 
However, the gameplay is punishing and unfun.  Completely unfun.  What a waste.  

You're a mailman.  Literally.  I mean, most game quests are glorified delivery quests, but there's usually some kind of fun game mechanics involved.  Not here.  You just run, but not just run, they make running slow and hard to actually do.  Not only that, but there's a cargo degradation mechanism and baddies that are so cumbersome to avoid.  Since you're a mailman, combat isn't really a thing here.  So avoid you must as your cargo degrades.  and oh yeah, who cares about delivering the cargo because you get a star sticker on your virtual leg.  Yay.  Oh and pat on the back from a virtual AI.  Woot, I feel so nice, the hologram of a fictional character in a video game telling me I'm a legend.  That makes it worthwhile.

I wanted to like it.  It's so creative.  It just isn't fun.  It would have been a good movie, but it's not a good game so I guess I'll never actually experience the good parts.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The story is quite interesting, because it is so alien. It was the main motivator for me.
However, after being sent over snow mountains, only to get a new order to go back, and then back again, I lost motivation. Maybe I watch the conclusion of the story online.

Graphics, quality and performance are very good though.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: One of the best single player experiences I've had in a long time. Amazing atmosphere, amazing visuals, sometimes challenging gameplay, where you deliver cargo while traversing through rough terrain, and protecting your cargo from being damaged from falls, anomalous entities, and rogue M.U.L.E.s. If you're a completionist and like to 100% games, this is the perfect game for doing so.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Great, but not for everyone

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: good

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Kojima pushing the limits again. Post-cinema? Games as philosophical tools? Art? Hard to pin it down, but Death Stranding certainly takes a step aside from what is produced today and dares to explore other territories and in doing so, ponder on the possibilities of games, films, or any audiovisual contemporary medium as channels for ontological deliberations. Masterpiece.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
DEATH STRANDING has some gorgeous landscapes.  Mossy, boulder-strewn plains divided by flowing rivers, dusty dunes that feel almost Martian, all overlooked by an imposing, snow-capped mountain range.  It may not have a lot in common with the America it's supposed to represent, but then this IS a future where rain causes anything it touches to age decades within minutes.  When you put it like that, it's a wonder new canyons aren't forming by the week.

"Timefall" is just one of many arcane concepts thrown at us in the opening hours of DEATH STRANDING, along with "BTs," "voidouts," and "chiral crystals."  But the story is still more or less straightforward- at first.  You are Sam, a courier in a post-apocalyptic world turned upside-down by the appearance of the spectral BTs, and your mission is to link up settlements and shelters in order to rebuild America.  You do this by delivering packages.  Lots and lots of packages.  This is the big idea behind DEATH STRANDING's gameplay: a game about loading yourself up with weight, and trying to balance that weight as you negotiate a challenging terrain.  Carefully controlling your character's momentum, using the triggers to maintain balance, and keeping track of your weight distribution are all essential- at first.  It's a unique idea for a core gameplay loop, and in theory it puts a new spin on the familiar tropes of open-world gameplay.  In practice?  Well... the physics governing your movement are pretty well-programmed, and the animations are impressively detailed.  Watching Sam nimbly step across the terrain is something to behold, and the game milks this quiet spectacle for all it's worth*, frequently pulling back the camera to view him as a tiny figure making his way across the vast landscape, playing the occasional artsy indie track to set the mood.  And that mood is bleak and quiet... downbeat and slow... and more than a little boring.

And here we reach the elephant in the room.  Actually, DEATH STRANDING can get *very* boring at times.  It often turns into the kind of non-game where you need to have a podcast or YouTube video on just to keep going.  To its credit, the game peppers the landscape with a variety of obstacles- when you're not figuring out how to ascend a slope or cross a river, you'll be evading packs of bandits or sneaking by the BTs.  But all the same, it gets monotonous very easily, which isn't helped by how much the game drags some things out.  The act of completing a delivery springs to mind- instead of just showing one "Mission Complete!" screen with all your stats readily available, the game slowly loads every stat before giving you your final grade, THEN showing a bunch of different stats that affect your current rating, THEN informing you of any new benefits you've unlocked, THEN playing a message from your client that inevitably boils down to "Wow, great job you did!"

So why did I play it for at least sixty hours?  No, really, what the hell is wrong with me?  I mean, I was readily aware of this game's flaws after less than a dozen hours, but I kept at it anyways.  Partially just to see where the hell Hideo Kojima was going with all this... but also, I have to admit, DEATH STRANDING does some things I haven't really seen in other open-world games.  For starters, it's one of the only open-world games I've played where your mode of travel significantly evolves over the course of the game.  In most open-world games, you spend the whole game either walking, riding, driving, or parkouring across the game world, and all that changes is how much of the map you unlock.  Meanwhile in DEATH STRANDING, you progress from laboriously crossing the terrain on foot, to riding a motorbike, and eventually erecting entire  roads and ziplines to help you navigate more efficiently.  There's something bizarrely addictive about doing deliveries to unlock access to more supplies, so I can erect more bridges, roads, and ziplines.  It feels like the first time I've ever seen a AAA open-world game make construction a core part of gameplay, rather than a tacked-on extra like in FALLOUT 4.

I also have to give props to the bola gun.  DEATH STRANDING occasionally sends you off to bandit camps where rogue deliverymen try to steal your goods, and you're encouraged to take them out nonlethally.  One of the methods for doing so is a gun that fires a bola at the target, which wraps around them before causing them to trip and fall to the ground.  To put it plainly, this weapon is fucking hilarious, and possibly the first instance I've seen where the nonlethal option is much MORE fun than the regular guns.  Aiming a bola at a charging enemy, before firing and watching it wrap around them in slow-motion, sending them tumbling to the ground- that NEVER gets old.  I highly recommend bola guns be implemented as a standard option in every shooter going forward, and possibly all video games in general.

Unfortunately, the rest of the combat is a total letdown.  There's no creativity in any of the other weapons, and while the game makes a big deal out of how you have to use your own blood for ammo against the BTs- thus creating a hypothetically interesting tug-of-war between your need to defeat enemies versus your own survival- the fact remains that virtually every fight in the game was a cakewalk, including most of the boss fights.  In fact, for a game about death, it's shockingly easy to avoid getting killed.  The times when I died from being genuinely beaten- rather than just experimentation or not understanding game mechanics- could probably be counted on one hand.

Perhaps as befits its origins, DEATH STRANDING is one of the most ambitious, original AAA games to be released in years- but that's not the same thing as being a good game.   All the same, I can't help but feel greatness was within reach.  I actually really want to see another game use the same construction and carrying mechanics to tell a better story.  There's potential for a great game set in, say, a medieval setting, where your character has to carry goods from town to town, and slowly tame a harsh wilderness.  And I'm certainly curious to see what Hideo Kojima does next. I just have a bad feeling it won't be "finally hire a decent editor."

*I hasten to add this spectacle is impressive as long as DEATH STRANDING is actually running properly, which it often did not on my laptop. Even at the lowest resolution and mostly while running in a window, it was highly inconsistent- sometimes the game loaded quickly and ran smoothly, other times it would get stuck at 21% loaded, or have a framerate in the single digits.  And yes, I'm aware my gaming laptop was probably under the recommended specs, but the issue I still have is this:  Why SHOULD I have to get a better system to play this game?  Kojima's previous game was also developed primarily for the PS4 and Xbone, and it ran fine on my OLD laptop.  How does it make any sense that graphical standards advance so quickly that I can't even keep pace if I upgrade my system?  DEATH STRANDING is yet another fine example of how the game industry's graphical arms-race hurts gaming by limiting the number of people who can play the game without buying the newest hardware.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
First of all, I gotta say I went into this game blind, no talk with friends, no trailers outside the first teaser shown, nothing. 

This game is an incredibly detailed and accurate simulator, I just thought it would be something else? I thought it'd be some type of story or something, but regardless it's a really great simulator! I now understand what it's like to be an Amazon delivery driver during the pandemic. 

Nah but really, I did truly go into this game blind, and it is a piece of art that will change future gaming. I enjoy how cinematic it is, and went through without even skipping for the first 40 hours or so just because it was so immersive and fun.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
There is this saying about reality: The Graphics are awesome, but the gameplay is crap. Well this game comes pretty close to reality on the graphical end of things. 😉

The gameplay is another story however, and while definitely not terrible, it is the weaker part of Death Stranding. 
Going back and forth, making deliveries, interrupted with the odd fight here and there, and some pretty cool horror elements, that’s it really! At least you can also take part in rebuilding things, which is nice, and there are some vehicles to use later on, although a Monster Truck is missing.  😉 

👍👍👍 -+- 👍👍👍

Another quote I remember is about art being an umbrella in the shit storm of life, and maybe I’m lucky to have realized a long time ago, that everyone on this planet is struggling in some way or other; so I guess everyone needs art in their life, too.
And Death Stranding is such a magnificent cinematic work of art, It has to be said; you’ll find some amazing moments, if you have the patience to put up with it’s slow pace and the gameplay which is a bit on the repetitive side.

[i]Of course, the slow pace could be seen as a message:[/i]

[b]If you want enlightenment, you will have to put up with suffering.[/b]

The networking in this game does make me question social networks even more, with their likes, a lot of them fake, or the real likes for and from fake people for real fake news. Is it a problem of the internet, or just a mirror of real life? Is this game mirroring both?
In real life a courier at least gets some real feedback, when someone receives a parcel, there is some real interaction, but unfortunately even irl this is changing nowadays with this current epidemic, and as a courier you might be placing parcels into some unpersonal collect station instead. What a cold world we live in.
And apparently you get a rise of oxytocin for likes? Maybe I’m wired differently (I’m sure I am, haha), but I don’t really get much out of that or social media as a whole. It’s too much of a fake world. I want flesh and blood, endorphins and adrenalin. 😉 Not rice crispies and some metrosexual twitter feed. 😉

Do you need likes from people you never met irl to boost your ego?

Is oxytocin addictive? Isn’t hugging someone a healthier way?
And wearing tight latex could even keep your Fragile body save from viruses! 😉 

👍👍👍 -+- 👍👍👍

There are many masks people wear to hide their struggle and darkness. When do masks become part of a person, part of a soul? How much of the ego is real? In a world full of egoic people, can one function without an ego? How far are you willing to lose yourself in something, to find yourself?

I remember a river I visited earlier this year in spring, which had loads of piles of balanced Zen Stones on the embankment on the other side near a hiking trail. Now I’m not a person who likes to hike, I’m more of a cyclist, and prefer a bit more speed, a faster pace, but of course I had to walk a few meters and explore to find those stone piles, where someone else had meditated.

It’s nice to wander off the beaten track, even to get lost sometimes, and to question the reality you live in. I seems to me that a lot of people just keep moving to stop themselves from falling over, as they are haunted by their inner dialog; so to stand still is like a threat to them. 

You can’t always meditate either, there has to be a balance of stillness, motion and emotion.

There is no peace without war, no joy without suffering, no light without the dark. 
Every end is a new beginning, for every door which closes, another one opens. 
There is no order without chaos.

It’s quite possible that humanity or the civilisation that we know will end one day, maybe sooner than we would like to think.

[i]There is no strength without fragility.[/i]

[b]Thank you, Sam.[/b] 👍

…

What is the opposite of a Like, if there are no Dislikes?

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It ended seeming to drag on and on. They play you the credits twice. Beat it on the hardest difficulty and had no trouble with as deathless a run as is possible. No NG+ no replayability. I'm a Kojima fan but the story was so telegraphed it felt forced.

Interesting tech for the game, mechanically. But I would wait until a sale. I wish I had waited for it to be 50-75% off.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Unique, intelligent, sensitive, Kojima created such a remarkable experience. There is not much you can compare to Death Stranding, it has an unmistakable style, is distinctive, unruly, even rebellious.

My favourite moments are just sitting anywhere around in this breathtaking landscape, listening to the utterly beautiful soundtrack.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Best game of 2020. I guess it didn't come out in 2020, it just released on Steam in 2020.

You play Sam. You will learn to love Sam. No one else can be Sam but you, except for everyone else.

Build stuff. Drive cool vehicles. Make your baby happy. Get lots of likes. Reconnect the internet. Deliver the things.

The worst part of this game is everything is explained in amazing detail, but if I tried to tell you it would spoil half the game and you'd think I was insane. After this, I might be.

11/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I thought this game would be worse because of all the talk about it.  However, it was amazing.  There are horror elements, but I would consider it more of a thriller than a horror, and if you enjoy Kojima's story telling, you'll enjoy this too.  This game was worth every penny and I found myself thinking this game was practically a movie, just like many of Kojima's titles. Though it didn't force you into too much, with the longest cutscenes towards the end, it still never surpassed the time lengths of his previous titles. If you want a new, original story, with very original and strange elements, I highly recommend this game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This may be one of the dumbest and pointless games in history.  The gameplay is mediocre, the physics are off (just enough to be really annoying) and after playing for several hours, I still don't understand what the point of the game is.   If I could receive a refund at this point I'd happily do so, but don't waste your money unless you have a need for a super boring, pointless game and have plenty of time to waste.  Best part, my "reverse trike" simply vanished from the game.... apparently you can build a new one if you have the blueprint which I have no idea how to obtain.  

Possibly the worst game in history.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
so, death stranding. finally comes to pc, after 5 years of witing for the release on consoles and 1 for the pc edition. i will begin by saying that i was extremely excited about the game, and have been theorizing since the announcement trailer (i'll keep coming); when i managed to get my hands on the game i was obviously shaking by excitement since the game was really hyped by some players yet hated by others, and that only made my interest on what kind of game i was getting myself into.

So, the game is all booted up, i get some unique requests about my personal info (all good, just your birth date and your constellation, for chiral analysis).

i play the first chapter, and im shocked by how creative and just indescribably cool the world and feeling was, since the first minutes i knew this game was something on a different league (and i'm going to be honest, also the jank is on another league).

so i keep on playing, with an incredible urge of feeling as much as i could everything, the refined organization of the items, the incredibly deep feeling of walking, the weird uncanny yet particular characters,  the beautiful and bleak loneliness of a world where you're just about the only living thing, except a few freaks with lightning sticks.

then, it happens. i get one particular mission, a difficult one at that; and i just couldn't do it, sam dies, and i have to reenter my body and spend 5 hours delivering an already fucked up delivery that wasnt even going to give me a good score (i later discovered that i could've just canceled the order. foolish me.)

i felt, really, damn, bad. i felt lost and disappointed; thought i was going to drop the game then and there.

but something grew in me, something i had discovered in games like dark souls and sekiro, that feeling of "fuck it, push beyond it and go forth, get it done."
and so i did, i kept on pushing, the same way that sam struggles walking with 150 Kgs of cargo after a bad rain and some lightning stick men insisting to help him complete his order.
going through and through i eventually break in a very open area of the map and, right there, i get it. i get why i was doing this, i get why i kept pushing to the end, i get why i kept delivering those packages, even the secondary ones:
that loneliness, that sense of being on your own in this huge world, it feels so emptying yet beautiful, in a mistifying way. and yet there was always a sense of connection; signs, player cargo, tools dropped by other players and structures, all made you feel like you were everything and nothing, its a weird pool of emotions i have to say. but it was so immersive and fullfilling, that i wanted more, and still do. i will probably 100% the game, since the world of the death stranding is so weirdly beautiful.

game has a ton of jank but its the most unique shit you will get to play in this century so try it out or dont if you're a cod player ok bye.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Already finish the game on PS4 and got all the trophies there, LOVE EVERYTHING about the game already! 

- great story and interesting characters - the villain is so-so compared to other great villains in Kojima's games.
- mechanics are different and interesting, you feel progress and getting better at doing deliveries as you do the main quests and side quests.
- the environment design and art direction is AMAZING (I recommend the artbook is really well done) and the music, it adds a lot to the game experience  (wish it have a feature like MGS 5 to listen music tracks while playing)

Is my favorite 2020 game, like it so much got it again on PC and looks real nice, and the extra features and cosmetics, I'm looking foward to get them. Is not for everyone in terms of mechanics and story, but it is an experience and with all the rougelike, battle royale, hacks and slash games that keep coming this one feels different and new. 

I recommend enjoy the game and finish it at your own pace, if you wnat to get all achievements might take awhile and some grind

- build all the roads
- build zip-lines to travel fast back
- use the equipment depending the area and the mission

My last achievement in PS$ was collecting all the chips, is easier with a guide and once you have all unlocked with fast travel places. Most of them are close to a place you been before.

Love how other players can help you with leaving messages and the like system.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Let's start with what the game is not:
1: it's not a combat/action/stealth game, forget MGS
2: it's not a RPG with customizable character and choice and consequences, the narrative is completly linear and you are a spectator.

The gameplay is slow paced, requires planning ahead, and the core gameplay is delivering stuff from A to B, but it's not a simple walking simulator, there are many mechanics involved, a lot of tools to build. And the map has many dangers.

The narrative is completly linear, but very interesting and weird. Coupled with the many real life actors involved, the superb motion capture and face animation, and the photorealistic graphics, the experience is between watching an author sci-fi movie and playing a game.

To give it's best it needs a quite powerfull rig, especially an RTX card with DLSS makes its graphics to look stunning and the gameplay to be superfluid.

For anyone beeing in the mood for this kind of gameplay and even being sligthly interested in weird sci-fi distopic settings, Death Stranding is an unique game worthy to experience.

I could not make it through the entire story because the gameplay felt like a chore.

- Graphics 8/10 - large but rather empty environments that looks great with DLSS
- Gameplay 5/10 - different gameplay than I've ever seen in a game that becomes tedious and boring very fast
- Story 7/10 - interesting story and characters with excellent voice acting and fresh ideas that however drags on unnecessarily long. 
- Performance 8/10 - with the inclusion of DLSS technology, this game easily hits high frame rates at high resolutions

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I can't recommend that game.
First of all, I had to endure 6 hours of the game to actually get to play a total of 1 hour.
Since this is a game and not a movie I am not so fond on such a grand exposition dump.
But the main problem is, that although there are some interesting meta layers embedded in the story, the way they are executed is anything, but subtle. Like a game that wants to be interlectual, but thinks their audience is compiled out of morons. That's why the game explaines everything in detail to you and then repeats it up to three times !!
I really like this different approach to gameplay. Here the game is literaly, running from one end of the map to another, which is boring in most games, because it hinders the actual gameplay, but here it is the actual gameplay. Since it is somewhat challengeing it's quiet enternaining. Problem is, it was fun for 20 hours, not the 40 it was build around.
So I think this game is cool, because it's so different and it's cool, that Sony financed it, but I think Kojima went a little overboard. A little bit of supervision and streamlining would have helped the game. I mean it's so different, because Sony has let Kojima do his thing and without that courage something so special, would have never been built. But at the same time it's flawse, make it to cumbersome for the enjoyment I get from it,
Therfore I am glad this game exists and it has some very special strong points, you won't find anywher else. But at the same time, because of it's many flawse, it's not for me.
I can not recommend this game, but I will say, if you are the right person this might be a game great to you, but you have to accept, that the author thinks of you as an idiot and from the beginning till the end the only thing you will be doing is crossing the map, while some guy on the radio explaines some shit to you for the fours time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: made respect for Pos Laju Malaysia for delivering our courier all this while

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Like many may have wrote: This game is not for everyone!

If you are looking for an action-game, you wont find it here. The game is a "walking simulator" with some sporadic action. Its a slow paced game that allows you to play in a pace that stands in stark contrast to most other games. Giving you time to enjoy the landscape, think and plan ahead! But giving you the freedom to tackle the challenges up ahead in the way that you want to.

The game focuses on story and the progress you make on your way. Better equipment and structures helping you overcome obstacles that were time-consuming and difficult at the start of the game.

The indirect way you help other players or get helped is motivating.

For me this is a true masterpiece and innovation i was craving for for a long time. Focusing on value of life and companionship.
What it means to be alone and to be connected with other people.

Im enjoying every minute of it!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Kojima's done it again. An absolute masterpiece. A magnum opus that any and every developer should strive to imitate. With an all-star cast of actors and voice-overs this game does nothing but deliver Gus Van Sant and Jim Jarmusch levels of storytelling. Beautiful direction and cinematography during every cutscene will have you spamming your F12 key to take screenshot after screenshot to savor the moments that you wish you could relive. A worthy successor to his masterful Metal Gear series (barring MGSV, that game kinda sucked), Death Stranding does not dissapoint. It's a piece of art for the ages. one that history will look back on in awe, and wonderment.

My only beef with the game is that he didn't give David Hayter a cameo, or a shout out, or anything to recognize the mans contributions to Kojima's legacy. Like come on Hideo, give the guy a break.

TLDR; This game is a fucking 10 and if you don't think so, you can straight up get fucked.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Strange, bizarre, hilariously stupid, deeply interesting, and 100% Kojima.

This is what happens when you have a "George Lucas"-style visionary have his way, and I wouldn't have it any other way.
Death Stranding is probably one of the most unique games I have played and (while I am only wading through this crater lake of a game) it has captivated me the entire time.

I isolated myself from 95% of the marketing and was thoroughly impressed. While I very much enjoy playing this game and it's surprising intricacies for a Amazon delivery simulator in a craggy hell, this is obviously not for everyone to enjoy. I watched several impressions/reviews and they all line up on these points.

It's really fever dream like, it's obvious that Kojima is off the walls, and it's a weirdly satisfying but often cumbersome game.

If you haven't experienced Hideo Kojima's games prior, I'd encourage you to watch gameplay of them at least. You will be either taxed by the almost suffocating and questionable gameplay choices or overwhelmed by the intense and surreal feeling that accompanies his games. Likewise, being prepared makes you enjoy a very memorable game that doesn't suffer from today's triple AAA money vacuums.

It's worth the ~60 I put in. Don't get this game expecting a quick distraction for a few days... Because this is does feel like a hike across the USA, and it isn't much quicker than in real life.

(I'll update this review once I actually complete the game, so far it's very enjoyable and I have played a little bit every day.)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: A grand narrative and back story, profoundly fun playability, and astonishing graphics all collide in DEATH STRANDING. Kojima’s years of work within the industry indeed show off within this title – And, although I could go on talking about the various aspects that make this game one of its kind, I prefer to encourage you to play it, especially if you are into intriguing, mysterious and bewildering stories. Notwithstanding some cheesy parts, a little number of bugs and a (sustained) confusion through the first hours of gameplay, this game, along with its beautiful soundtrack, really gets your feelings going.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
In true Hideo Kojima fashion, the game's story is sprawling and ambitious, and is the main draw and highlight to Death Stranding. Except unlike Metal Gear Solid, you don't have to have any frame of reference or prior knowledge of the game to enjoy it or like it.

Coming into the game with next to no knowledge of the game's story or reviews, found the core gameplay actually pretty fun for what's essentially a package delivery horror-adventure game. However, after finishing the main storyline, doesn't feel like there's much else to do. I'm going to give it more time and see if I'm correct, but that's my feeling initially.

Ran into some issues with controls, especially around movement which didn't feel super fluid 100% of the time (stopping when sprinting, using the floating carriers, aiming reticle placement, to name a few issues). Also had some issues with the seriously blatant product placement, but not enough to take me out of the game. Some of the voice acting can be pretty off-putting.

But I think those points aside, game's story is pretty captivating and engaging, and at some points, very movie-like, which really felt like what their team was going for. If you're looking for something new and story-heavy, pick this up.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE!!! 
-If you can enjoy the basic goals of game the longer you play the more rewarding and easy it will become. 
-There are multiple ways to play this game. 
-There is a combat and guns. But you will be mostly travelling. 
-The main story is about 25 hours long if you marathon. But about 100+ hours if you are a completionist. *Play on the hardest difficulty if you want to do 100% of the achievements on your first playthrough. If not it'll take an extra 50+ Hours... 
-Online connection is required if you want the full game experience.
-There are long cut-scenes and many game menus.  *Most menus are skipable. 
-The acting is top notch. 
-Embrace how weird it is at times.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: As with any Hideo Kojima game, Death Stranding is meticulously crafted, beautiful to look at, strange beyond words, and not for everyone.  I still don't understand much of the lore, but I don't think I really need to.  It takes a while to get past the first few missions, and many gamers might give up soon after they've started, but if you stick with it you'll eventually get a feel for the unique gameplay.  The sense of accomplishment you get from completing orders grows with each delivery, especially once you've begun to encounter more of the world's dangers and manage to overcome them - either by luck or by trial and error.  Any fan of Kojima owes it to themselves to check out Death Stranding - there's truly no other game quite like it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is fascinating, they actually managed to make a delivery simulator fun.

Update: Dont usually write reviews, but this game deserves more love, so I will do my part to spread it.

Finished the game - it is a true masterpiece, a great work of art. The ''ending'' is far from disappointing; the story is written by a genius. The combat is not difficult, but satisfying while giving you breath taking scenes, in a video game. And the game is well optimised for PC, solid 60 fps with a gtx 970, everything on high.

Overall, I think this game is not for everyone, especially people who dont enjoy taking their time exploring an open world. I think that it did however elevate the story driven games  (as the Witcher developers have also done in their own way) to an almost untouchable level for the moment. 

The music is lit. If you ever visited Iceland, you might even more appreciate this game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
*** The Ultimate Social Distancing Simulator ***

I was on the fence a long time about buying this game. I am glad I didn't miss out. After 40 hours of playing, I thought it was time to write a review as my way of saying thanks to the creators for giving me an awesome experience that is different from everything else out there.

The most amazing thing about this game is the multiplayer element. Without it, it wouldn't be much of a game really. You can enjoy other people's stuff, and they can enjoy yours. There is something just satisfying about it that is hard to explain. It's not like regular online games where people get over competitive, and do everything they can to ruin your fun. You never have to worry about aimbot jerks and god mode hackers. You just share "likes", and keep puting one foot in front of the other.

Be aware that sometimes people will compare the multiplayer element to dark souls. Well, being a huge souls fan, I can say it's not like that at all. You can not invade people, or be invaded. You share structures and can donate equipment and materials. Sometimes people can throw you items during a boss fight. It's great fun, and feels like you are all working together to build a better world.

If you are in to competitive games worried about kill/death ratio stuff, then this isn't for you. If you are tired of the same old crap paying 10 to 20 bucks for some silly new skin, this could be for you. It's both relaxing with times of intense terror thrown in to keep you on your toes. The story and world are also highly immersive.

Finally, you can make pee mushrooms that other people can help you grow. Good stuff.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: In short, you won't truly be able to know if this game is for you or not by just watching gameplay alone. For me, initially watching videos of people playing Death Stranding was pretty stale and boring, but once I actually played it for myself, I began to appreciate what this game is all about. The attention to detail, breathtaking environment, and captivating soundtracks give you such an immersive experience for such an odd game. I like to refer to this as an Amazon delivery simulator.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Utterly unique game.  It combines better than triple A production values , such as the most photo realistic beautiful scenery ever, with the bold vision you sometimes get from the best indie game makers. It breaks every rule in the book, so wont be for everyone,  but for most of us it's an amazing game.

Quite a few criticise the story as unrealistic. IMO the story is actually far more real than the partly fake story’s we tell each other about the world in the news and other media.  I guess the reviewers who appreciate the story's relevance are maybe a step ahead of most  - e.g. they might know the very different way that Japan has already been responding to Technological Unemployment these past few years. They might be engaged in politics, rather than just hearing about it on the news.  They might read some of the most discerning writers on environmentalism like Cynan Jones or Kingsnorth.    Or just be more open than most to new perspectives.  And also not bothered by the literary liberties like the "childish" metaphoric character names.

One draw back of the game is that the hiking simulator part can feel like hard work especially when you need to haul a heavy load on the clock.  So maybe not a game to play after a hard days work  - even though it does have relaxing qualities,  as many mention.

This game as a strong social purpose.   If somehow our civilisation makes it to the 22nd century without collapse,  history should record Hideo Kojima as one of the heroes who saved the world!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death Stranding is A true unique experience. The game is definitely not for everyone however it was for me. This game is good if you want a break from the standard beat em up action singleplayer games which are plentiful in the genre. Be aware this is a very long game, you are not going to be going anywhere very fast, and the story takes a bit to get going. However once you get into the wacky out of this world story your hooked. or at least i was. i fully recommend this game if your looking for a story based game with 10/10 music and are not afraid to sink some time into the world that Kojima dreamed up.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
In Death Stranding you travel through identical landscapes between bases doing delivery quests for likes. You can build things like ladders and bridges to help with this since you will keep travelling that distance again and again. First time you arrive to a new base you unlock it's connection to other players. That means their ladders and bridges start appearing in your world, making travelling easier.

The story vibes of post apocalyptic anime but it feels like Kojima has these visions of certain moments, certain scenes, that are cool. It's just that they haven't successfully built up the in-game realism to justify the scenes. And there are plenty of glaring almost juvenile writing. A few examples that are straight eye-sores:

[list]
[*]The president dies in roughly the first scene, so her daughter is now the president? The US is a monarchy now? And her middle name is AMERICA?

 [*]The right hand of the president is called DIEHARDMAN and has a skeleton mask. DIE HARD MAN? Was that idea from a 10 year old? And the skeleton mask? He just has that. Noone else has any masks. Similarly we have DEADMAN. Your mother named you that? Or you thought it was cool so you chose that? Did you go to your colleagues and tell them that you were no longer John Smith, you were DEADMAN? [i] Now I'm definetly going to get the ladies! [/i]

[*]There is a woman leading a delivery company who wants to get in touch with you. You've met once and it was not a friendly meeting. Since you were sleeping she decides to use your shower while you are literally sleeping 3 meters away? Do you know any women that would break into peoples apartments that they've met once and then proceed to use their shower?

[*] There is a story with a couple that were separated in a disaster and you rejoin them, but it is so painfully badly written my eyes were bleeding. The girl who should probably be around 30 behaves like a 8-year old.

[/list]
It goes on.

My main problem in the end is the gameplay loop. Your reward for continuing to play is that you get more vehicles and eventually roads that you can grind up resources to build. These make travelling easier, like the game knows that it's boring so it rewards you with doing the boring things quicker. This type of gameplay has certainly been around a long time. I just think it's a bad one and I'm sorry to see Death Stranding take that route.

There is potentially some combat. Sometimes you enter an area with the ghosts called BT. However, you can just scan, take a few steps, and if you see one with your scan you can one shot them with a blood/poop grenade and then move forward. So you rarely need to actually fight. Certainly there are also some crazy humans in the wastelands but they can be avoided.

I think there is an overall message Kojima tries to convey here, about collaboration, about sending positive reinforcements. Sending likes. We work together against the hardships of the game by building bridges. If someone else has built a bridge that I make use of I send them a bunch of likes, similarly I get some when others use infrastructure I've built. [u]I really like that idea[/u]. Especially as a metaphor for society at large. But what if the gameplay was complex and interesting like Dark Souls? And we would still collaborate. It would have been a way better product.

I gave this game 39 hours but the grinding became too cumbersume and the story and writing did not compensate. Some enjoy this type of games, hell MMOs are still popular and they have plenty of go fetch quests that many like. But this wasn't for me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Ok, so most people assume this game is just a walking simulator.
I'm going to stop you right there. 

Ok, yes, in the most basic form you do spend a lot of time hauling stuff to and from, but in reality it really isn't that as a whole.
So, some backstory : I picked up this game based on the recommendation of my best friend. Before I picked up this game I had watched a few negative reviews (one was most notably by Video game Dunky,) talking about how boring and bad this game was.

Most reviews who complain about this game or who say that this is just a walking simulator, frankly, are simply spewing a bunch of misinformation and B.S. No really, they are.
The game is very much a stealth oriented, open world exploration game.

In fact, I would actually go so far as to say that the element of doing deliveries is more secondary (at least for me,) than going in and doing stealth runs or combat runs against Mules / BTs while I do optional deliveries that make the world a more complete place.

Just the other day I went and completed the building of a highway that lets people just drive cars around instead of hauling on foot. And, in doing so I had as much fun as I would have doing the open world elements of MGS as I do in this?
Why? I chalk it up to playstyle if anything else.


I've gotten a bit off track, but to summarize, this game is what I consider a hidden and niche gem. It's exactly like if you spent hours in the open world of MGS Phantom Pain but, with the focus being more on the development and stealth element, rather than primarily on the combat and recourse attainment element.
The world feels alive when you're contributing to the world and interacting with players, player's deliveries, and helping other players indirectly through their structures or other development projects. 

It's extremely calming, relaxing, exciting, and full of tension all at once. I really would recommend people this game if you loved the open world element of MGS Phantom Pain.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Its has the best story ive ever seen in any game or movie and there is still plenty to do after you beat the game too

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I want to preface my review by saying I bought this game at launch on PS4, and finished it there, then pre-ordered it on PC and am in the middle of a second playthrough.

This game is not a "walking simulator." It has real gameplay, and it's very good. You just have to stick with the game long enough for it to open up.
The story is not "nonsense." It explains itself, and it's very good. You just have to stick with the game long enough for you to understand.
If you watched a youtuber play the opening hour of this game, and think it's boring, or garbage nonsensical storytelling, you have seen NOTHING, of what this game actually has to offer. It just takes a while to get there. The opening is designed to be slow, and the story at the beginning is designed to confuse you. If you just expect to understand the game's whole universe at the start of a 50-60 hour experience, then I don't know what to tell you. Boo hoo if a murder mystery novel doesn't tell you who the murderer is in the first chapter.
It's a slow experience, meant to be savored and enjoyed without trying to rush everything. If you can't deal with that and need instant gratification, this game isn't for you. If you refuse to indulge the game's plot because it's "too crazy" or "too stupid," then you're probably going to hate it all the way through, because you've already decided not to give it a chance. It's weird, yes. Weird is not a bad thing in fiction, and never has been. You will be confused, and you will have to think on things and sometimes draw your own conclusions, that's just how it is. If it isn't for you, it isn't for you.

But for the people who this game is for, MAN, is it good.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is a massive change of pace from almost every other game out there. With a focus mainly on dialogue, exploration and thought, it slows down the pace and makes you move a little slower. As you move through the game's massive world, you realize that while at first everything seems calm as you trek through rolling hills and craggy outcrops, the game assaults you with sudden bouts of extreme tension and action. By a third of the way through the game, you begin to leave any safe haven with an underlying sense of caution and dread, but one that can never overpower your curiosity and need for exploration.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Without even knowing, Death Stranding is the game I waited my whole (gaming) life for.

When I saw the E3-trailer 2018 I completely fell in love with Death Stranding – the confusing pictures, beautiful music and Norman Reedus as main character – I just had to play it. I nearly bought a PS4 for it, so you can imagine how I felt when it was announced on steam – I was jumping for joy.

You play as Sam Porter Bridges, one of a few package deliverers who supply the remnants of American civilization with the things they need to survive. Because of the Death Stranding, a cataclysmic event that wiped out most of the population, the remaining people live in fortified cities or underground shelters. You’re tasked to go from coast to coast to connect all cities and preppers onto a network to reunite them and make America whole again.

The structure of the story is multidimensional: As the Death Stranding happened several years before the story starts, the characters know the world and the (for the uninitiated seemingly) weird stuff that determines their days. Not much is explained in the beginning of game. As a player, you always sit on the edge of your seat and hope to grasp the bigger picture or get some kind of explanation for any of the incomprehensible elements of this game. But Kojima just throws more odd stuff at you.
I really liked this withholding of information. It made for a strong immersive experience and I played every day for many hours. It also allowed to focus a bit more on the gameplay (you unlock new equipment, weapons and modes of transportation in short succession) – just as it gets a little bit repetitive after the first half of the game, the story catches up and completely captivates you once again, only this time you get the (somewhat) coherent mind-blowing revelation.

The gameplay contains a really unique “semi-online”-mechanic. You can build structures – ladders, bridges, ziplines – to better traverse the ruins of former America. Other players can see and use your structures and you can use theirs. In Sam’s mission to cross the country all by himself, this gives a nice feeling of connectedness and the sense of striving for a common goal (despite never directly interacting with one another).
The currency is Death Stranding are likes. What sounds a bit bizarre at the beginning really adds to the motivation in the long run; just like we know today from social media, you really get that little euphoria boost every time someone gives you a like.

The cast of characters is just brilliant – from Norman Reedus and Mads Mikkelson to Léa Seydoux, Margaret Qualley and Guillermo del Toro – everyone fits into their role perfectly.
Music and soundtrack are often triggered when reaching certain points in the environment. Most songs are from Low Roar, though not produced for the game itself, fit into the story and the landscape like they were originally made for Death Stranding.

Sam says at the beginning: “I deliver packages. That’s all I do.” What’s sounds straightforward at the start quickly becomes much more – by delivering packages and rebuilding America, Sam – the lone wolf and outsider – becomes the new nation’s great hero. As he crosses the continent, Sam meets people, forges connections and puts his fractured past and therefore himself back together. He becomes a part of the world.

I like this game so much, I finished every achievement and spent a lot of time doing stuff that wasn’t really necessary. The game was just perfect for me at this point. The weeks I played it only really consisted of two things: Playing Death Stranding and thinking about playing Death Stranding.

What a game!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
You have to be in the mood to play a game like this. It's not like an ubisoft open world game. It's not going to give things to you. It's there to frustrate you. Until its not. It's about building a community and not being alone. 

The soundtrack is amazing. I love the mechanics. It makes other open world games feel hollow with how it forces you to understand terrain. And the music and presentation is great too.

I didn't really care that much about the story and there are some bits that go on too long. But by the end it also got to me. Overall an experience that only Kojima could create and deliver. It hooked me in a way that many other games have not.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Pros:
-The story is incredible. Many plot twists that are suspenseful and surprising. Also thought-provoking issues and emotional cutscenes
-The graphics are outstanding. Beautiful scenery.
-The voice actors appear with their own likeness in the game. Some celebrities as well. Not one bad voice-over
-Not a sandbox. You go through a forward progression but it is open world and go at your own pace
-Many difficulty levels
-The horror part of it is really, REALLY frightening
-The story is built on cooperation- you and others in the game contribute to the success, or failure, of getting things done
-Real physics come into play when carrying things, as in you can lose your balance, fall ,etc., and weighted cargo in your vehicle can slow you down, just like in real life

Cons:
-not a point-and-click easy game
-You need to think- on inventory management, routes of getting places, and how to do it, with or without equipment, with or without facing "the bad guys" (no spoilers)
-If you are not ok with moral dilemmas, hard choices and having to keep people alive, even though some want to kill you, this is not the game for you
-If you're not ok with a game where you need to rest, eat, drink, build stuff to help yourself survive, this is not the game for you

Overall verdict: Outstanding. The information you get about a whole bunch of deep topics from the NPC's about what is going on is astounding. The story concept is wonderful. Frustrating at times because I didn't want to deal with some enemies, but had no choice. The horror is frightening, and you need to be quick on your feet and have a plan before encountering them on the way to somewhere, because you may not be able to save yourself if you don't.  When an npc offers you a blueprint to build something, it's for a reason. You can sometimes get by without it, in the next part of what you need to do to progress the story, but sometimes you can't and need to build it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death stranding, where do I even start?

This has been my most anticipated for almost 3 years now since I had seen the original teaser trailers. My friends were quick to joke with me about how the game was going to be a walking and USPS simulator. But after I played this game I'm glad the game play is exactly that.

Death Stranding is now my favorite game of all time. There's something so magical and unique about it that no other game quite delivers on. At first I figured I would enjoy the Kojima story and the game play would be something to pass the time between the cut scenes, but I found myself staying up countless nights just completing orders and delivering packages. 

I don't wanna say much to spoil the game play or story but all I can say is the game might not be for everyone but I think everyone should at least try it.

I think you get the most from the game by trying everything and immersing yourself completely in the game and story.

I hope that if you play the game you'll come to enjoy it as I have and it becomes just as special to you as it did for me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
THIS IS THE FIRST STRAND TYPE GAME. 
Okay, but it's kinda like Animal Crossing except instead of a villager, you're Norman Reedus. And you have to carry all your items on your back. Remember when Tom Nook made you build those houses and you had to gather the materials for them first. Yeah, that's what you gotta do but like more intense. Also you have a baby attached to your chest that detects these spooky ghost things that will pull you into the underworld. Also, you can't die, you kinda just respawn on a beach or something. 

When you build structures, other people will see it and can give you LIKES. Makes it easier for other people running through the game after you. And they'll do the same for you. Because we're all connected through STRANDS. Protip: when you get to chapter 3, prioritize building roads. It'll help you A LOT in the long run (or...drive...rather...)

This isn't a fast paced shooter or even a stealth reconnaissance game. It's a take-your-time walking simulator where you help other people on your way to make deliveries. The combat is a complete joke, so don't expect anything there. Kojima def took some cues and concepts from MGSV (gear loadouts, main/side/automated missions, some dude on a radio telling you what to do) and recycled them here, but it's pretty different. There are definitely some stressful moments avoiding BTs (those ghosty things) but overall it can be pretty relaxing with some beautiful views. I'm running on a 5 year old GTX 970 and it still looks great.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
To say this game is strange is an understatement to be sure. Although if you pay attention to the dialogue, read a few journal entries here and there, and immerse yourself in the world it becomes less weird. Kojima has done a very interesting thing with Death Stranding. This game is an all new kind of post-apocalyptic experience. Everything is presented to you with so much unflinching sincerity that you just end up going "Alright I guess this is happening now" and maybe an hour or so later you'll learn the method to the madness. 

What? the gameplay? it's pretty great no complaints there aside from the vehicle physics being way too bouncy at times.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death Stranding makes no sense. That's a good thing. From the outset you're given lots of shreds of information, and then you deliver packages. It's very soothing until the ghost monsters show up. Make no mistake, this is a post-apocalyptic horror game, no matter how pretty it is. The direction and plot are fantastic, with vibrant characterizations given to even the smallest characters. The writing is on point and the cameos are fun. The gameplay itself can sometimes lead to frustration, but most of that frustration will be caused by you, the player. This is not a game you play fast. You don't get to start out ready to rock and roll. Death Stranding is a cautious stroll, waiting to lull you in with its scenic vistas, only for you to realize that you're sinking ever deeper into a black abyss, unable to claw yourself away from this game.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] IT'S A WALKING SIMULATOR [/h1]

Only 10h in, but so far I have  had a very unique, fun experience. Is it a walking simulator? Yes, it is a walking simulator. It is a massive open world filled up with outposts you can ignore or clear while you are walking around carrying massive cargo; which makes it up to you, if you wish to risk to clear the outposts or not. 

[h1] Lots of walking awaits you - or driving [/h1]

The map is clustered with tough terrains, cliffs, rivers, streams and rocks to make your journey hard and make your boots rip apart - until your feet are sticking out (literally). 
I'm currently playing on normal difficulty and I must admit, the game can be slightly too easy when it comes to combat (and yes, there is also combat). Melee and guns, among other stuff. Is it the best combat? Far from it, but it is fun and impactful. 

[h1] Not a spectator game [/h1]

I'm not going to go into full details and say you need 1000IQ to understand or like the game or story; you don't. Concept is unique, but it is still inspired. Story so far is good, albeit confusing, just like in Kojima style. I know I'm only 10H in, so I suppose it all gets explained over time. From a gameplay perspective though, this game is really good and really fun. It is a fun, interesting and interactive walking simulator. You will just have to play it to know if it's something you like or not - it is not a spectator game. Watching someone play it can be boring and not a good way to judge the game. It's not a good way to judge if the game is for you. 

[h1] CONNECT THE WORLD [/h1]

And the online part of it is really nice and feels rewarding and makes you feel as if you are contributing selflessly and making other player's trips easier. If you put down a ladder to use to cross over a small canyon, or climb over a cliff - that ladder, if you leave it, will be there for another player to use. If they are kind, they will award you likes.
Tools you use to help yourself, can help others.

[h1] TL:DR WHY SHOULD I PLAY THIS WALKING SIMULATOR? [/h1]

1. Good story so far
2. Depth in the gameplay (traversing tough terrain, managing cargo, balancing yourself, combat while shallow, is still fun and feels impactful)
3. It is fun to use all the tools at your disposal to traverse tough terrain (ladders to cross rivers or climb up cliffs, ropes to climb/descent a cliff/obstacle, or use vehicles to carry more cargo and faster)
4. Good atmosphere.

You won't like it if you dislike slower gameplay and story pacing, which takes a while until it pops off. This is game for a patient gamer, who enjoys peaceful strolls with occasional challenges.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Highly recommend this game if you're looking for something different, and by different I mean much different. To sum this game up, it's an innovation on the Open World genre and is definitely worth a play. I think Death Stranding is one of those [b]pivotal[/b] releases that does certain things so well that it will have lasting effects on the genre and gaming as a whole. If you're not convinced by the rest of these reviews who took this game for what it is instead of playing for 5 hours and whined because it's not MGS, I suggest you read on.

First, some background. I've been tired of the Open World formula for a long time mostly because it didn't leave me with any sense of accomplishment. In theory the idea of a Open World is great, an alternate reality where you can really sink your teeth into it's content and grow the world through your own effort. But most of the time they prove to be dull empty stretches of land with little reason to explore or ability to improve the game play experience. They tend to be very much of a grind which can be okay if the reward is great enough, however these games often don't have much of an endgame which means all your hard work just goes away once your done.

In come Death Stranding, where the beginning of the game is arguably the hardest part. You start off alone, in a barren landscape with little to help you on your journey from point A to point B. But as you play you unlock equipment which help make your travel easier, more efficient and downright more fun. You grow the world around you with lasting improvements to traverse the hostile terrain. And not only that, while you help improve your world with bridges, zip-lines, vehicles, etc; your structures bleed through into other players worlds and theirs the same. This by far is the selling point of this game and one of the key innovations that make it so great. I'll talk about this feature in detail in the next section.

[h1]Scratch their back by scratching your own[/h1]
Why is it so common for people to be toxic in a multiplayer game? Well it's fairly simple, it's fun to fuck with people. It's not always fun to be on the receiving end of the stick but oh boy can it be fun to be the one doing the fucking. But what happens when you create a game that, as a premise, is fucking you? Is fucking the entire player base by putting them on hostile terrain with demanding controls (demanding meaning you literally have to grip your controller to balance yourself and hold things in your hands). You would think that this would create a player base of annoyed, toxic children who just get mad at the game and make the experience worse from everyone around them. Quite the opposite, this player base has banded together as if the game itself is the boss. Not that playing the game is that bad, but just that it requires cooperation and community to do the best. 

Plus the game has zero competition at all, you could easily speedrun if you wanted but you know that you'll be crossing that same canyon again so might as well take the time to build a bridge instead of just putting down a ladder to cross. And then after building that bridge you get notifications when other players use it and those others players may put a generator next to it or help provide materials to upgrade it. It's amazing the amount of real interaction you get just by playing this game, without the chaos of having other players actually in it. There isn't any room for griefing and abuse, just a group of people trying to make the world a better place. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
Not gonna get into spoilers here but don't have much to note on the story. I'm at the very end of the game and from my understanding it's almost all cutscenes and story going forward. I'll update this once I finish but overall just wanted to give some general thoughts.

The world and lore is cool. There's a lot of interesting concepts this game presents and does it well with it's top notch graphics. The game is just beautiful and pairs really well with the story. I especially like the balance between Sci Fi elements and the Natural beauty in the world. Mountains and Canyons look like something I would have as my wallpaper. 

When I first typed wrote my opinion on the main character, I said he was boring. And while he definitely is pretty dull he has his moments and I couldn't think of someone else playing as Sam. I just wish that he took his performance to another level, it seems like he's just the exact same character from The Walking Dead.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Death Stranding is a game you won't be beating anytime soon. It's something that sticks with you like a clicker or animal crossing. If you don't play for a week next time you login you'll see all the people who indirectly interacted with you while you were gone. You have a really interesting concept to follow along with and some pretty big questions that get answered along the way. The characters overall I think are well acted and tell their stories well. Even if some of the side one's are just flat out stupid: [spoiler]I'm looking at you Junk Dealer and the Chiral Artist's Daughter. Y'all are straight up whack together and I'm happy you split up.[/spoiler]
