title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This very much exceeded my expectations. I am not typically someone who enjoys all of Mr. Kojima's over-the-top gratuitous style. This is... different, and a really welcome departure from MGS.

If you want to play something that will repeatedly surprise you and not be similar to any other game you have played, you will enjoy this game.
If you enjoy hiking or mountaineering, you will enjoy this game.
If you enjoy crazy *** Kojima stuff, you will enjoy this game

The online features are also great, it's like if Dark Souls style features were all positive and an online hug instead of someone about to stab you in the face.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is one of the best games of this generation but for a certain kind of people. If you like stuff like immersive sims or simulator games (with heavy gameplay components) you will probably love this. The main game loop is about planning routes, your plans going absolutely wrong and then trying to salvage your cargo.

What I found awesome:
[list]
[*] The coop aspects are really fleshed out, you can collaborate creating structures, delivering the packages of fallen players and sharing your equipment.
[*] The environments are breath taking, even if you don't like this kind of game, i recommend you to look up some screenshots.
[*] The cast is 10/10,  at first I wasn't really feeling it, but they really deliver. I cried more than once.
[*] The combat, yes this game HAS COMBAT and quite a lot actually. The more unconventional weapons are really fun to use.
[/list]

What I didn't found awesome:
[list]
[*] Some pretty important aspects of the history are hidden in written interviews, considering that you are more than 70% of this game walking it's a wasted opportunity to not use audiologs.
[*] The menus are stylized but are really slow and convoluted, you get used to them but they can be streamlined. You can at least skip every cutscene/animation.
[*] The game doesn't let you play the OST like in MGSV, that's huge wasted opportunity.
[*] Every difficulty lower than hard is just game journalist mode, i would love more difficulty settings.
[/list]

What I hated (Pls fix):
[list]
[*] The vehicles, the physics are really really bad, I don't understand how this game was released with these vehicles, they are serviceable, but you will encounter problems soon enough. This entire aspect of the game should be revamped.
[*] The songs, the game has a bad habit of just cutting songs if you get in an encounter and then not resume playback, this completely kills this moments. It's specially bad beacuse this system is implemented for when you rest.
[*] There is a serious bug in the ending chapter, that can completely kill the delivery of some pretty emotional moment. [spoiler] The BB Theme doesn't starts sometimes, i had to load the last checkpoint.[/spoiler]
[/list]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I really enjoyed this game.  I see a lot of people saying it sucks ... and if what you want is a fast paced shoot-em-up game, this ain't it.  You do get to shoot people later in the game, so there is some combat, but it's a lot more of a game of exploration and a crazy story.  It really is a cross between a video game and a movie.  There are some parts where you really should just pause the game and go make some popcorn.  :)
So no, it's not like a lot of other action games ... but in the end, I really enjoyed it, and really wanted to hear the rest of the story.  It was worth it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: When I first saw the trailers I was pretty disappointed when it looked like a walking simulator with a pretentious story. I am not really a Kojima fan either since I had only played Phantom Pain and Metal Gear Rising: Revengence. So my expectations were low but I thought I would give the game a try, surprisingly I actually really enjoyed it. I would call it a hiking simulator since you have to plan optimal routes, pack cargo efficiently and keep an eye out for risky terrain you should avoid. When you  are a few hours in you are able to build roads and other structures like zip-lines in mid-late game which made the game really fun for me. Planning zip-line placements or building road networks to let me get from A to B as fast and safely as possible with minimal effort was very satisfying as someone who is very lazy and the effort to make these systems was enough to make it feel earned but not frustrating. I personally liked the story too as the world building was very well thought out and consistent, making it one of the better sci-fi plots. There are some parts which are about as subtle as being hit by a train involving Trump and the wall (which still hasn't happened yet) but I can generally forgive this because its mostly in optional reading material lore. Soundtrack is good too but you are not able to listen to it when outside your room, which feels like a missed opportunity but it makes the times when the music does kick in during certain parts of the story more special I suppose. Overall its a good game and if you can get it for 25% off or less I would

review:
This is not a game, it's a frustration engine shoehorned into a weird, disjointed sci-fi short to make it obnoxiously long.

If you're enough of a masochist Kojima fanboy to enjoy this, you can probably get a friend to kick you between the legs repeatedly while you watch the cut-scenes on YouTube for half the price.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Unlike what the reviewers and many people have to say about this game, I really like the direction Kojima chose with this one. Its definitely a unique experience with a refreshing set of gameplay mechanics. It really is a walking simulator, but a darn good one which takes into account the laws of physics very well and in a realistic manner. It is not for the faintest of heart and definitely requires a lot of patience as you will be making quite a lot of deliveries before the action starts (Episode 7 I think). For me personally, I didn't mind making the deliveries as the game blesses us with gorgeous visuals, amazing views/draw distances and a soundtrack which complements all of the above. My only complaint is that, right from the start the game just throws random terms from the lore at you (like DOOMS, BTs, Chiralium etc.,) and expects you to understand and know what all of this means. The least that could have been done, was an intro cutscene explaining the world/lore, instead of us googling every single thing. Overall, I would recommend everyone to at least give this game a try (try it out at a friend's place or something) and then buy it if they like it. I also recommend Kojima to release a demo for this game consisting of the first one or two episodes as not everyone would want to buy it without giving the gameplay a trial.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
You play as Norman Reedus, delivering Amazon Packages during the Coronavirus epidemic.
Throw your poop at ghosts, pee on Conan O'Brien's house, and build structures that everyone will use without thanking you.Feel connected and disconnected all that same time with Kojima's conveniently confusing plot line about dead people, time, and i dunno... Norman Reedus's bodily fluids? Doesn't matter Daddy Kojima says time is convoluted anyways.


Nah but for real this games great, surprisingly relaxing for a game about spooky ghosts. It can be repetitive delivering packages constantly just for imaginary game points. but if you enjoy that sort of thing it's done really well. 
Finding another players structures and messages is a great mechanic, very dark souls like in that way - you feel like you're going the right way, seeing the same things, and sharing the same jokes without ever seeing the players. Just be sure to leave a like!

Currently on Act 5 about 60 hours in (did a lot of side deliveries) and I don't think I'll stop anytime soon.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I think this game is polarizing. I mean, obviously. That said. If you like it you like it. This game is about planning, plotting and executing. It is NOT an action game, and if you try to play it like one you will feel disappointed. The controls are fiddly and sluggish. A core element of this game is figuring out how to finesse the controls to make it easily over terrain, because the moment you panic, you're toasted. Dropping equipment, captured by enemies, voided out, game over.

If that sounds fun to you great! If not, well, don't say I didn't warn you.

Unfortunately, I was wrong. I've rarely been this bored by a videogame. There's so much useless clutter in the menus and UI. The frequent BT encounters grow old really quickly. 

I hate to say this, but I would prefer this game if it really was just a fancy walking simulator. Where the entire focus was traversal with none of this other stuff.

Avoid if you don't want a story-driven experience about defeating Trumpism by being a post-apocalyptic  mail-man delivering narcotics and broadband internet to the dregs of humanity who are left over following the rapture.
The game itself is extremely polished, and looks amazing in 4k/60 on my Core i9 and RTX 2080Ti.....as for the gameplay......if you don't like walking with cargo, probs best to avoid...but if you like Kojima cringe and weirdness, it's a safe bet.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If USPS was still around during an apocalypse; this is how they would function. 

Solid 8/10 experience so far. I would go as far as to say if the game had slightly better mechanics and wasn't based so heavily on the premise of "fetching" it would have been a smash hit. 

Landscape: 9/10
Soundtrack: 9/10
mechanics: 7/10
fun: 8/10
makes me want to invent hydraulic electric vehicles: 10/10 

Would highly recommend for those looking for a very compelling, story driven game with an infinite amount of strategic choices for how you complete your tasks. 

Its just really neat and there really is not a lot of games out on the market at the moment that Death Stranding can be compared to. The originality of it is pretty captivating, and will make you grind away for the fun of it.

Then came the 505 games sale and the game was forty bucks. I watched some youtube let's play footage and decided to go for it. Man, i'm having such a good time. Who would've thought a game about delivering stuff would be so much fun?

If you've played Kojima games before (metal gear solid to be specific), then you'll definitely enjoy this game. It's very story heavy and it's not all action though. title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
ABSOLUTELY UNPLAYABLE

I want to start by saying that I was very excited for this game, but was worried it'd be disappointing, so I avoided all reviews, spoilers, walk-thrus, and internet talk about it until I actually had time to play it and form my own opinion. What I expected: beautiful walking simulator with scary spooky ghosts I had to avoid and could not combat. What it is: trucking simulator where you can (and often do) shoot everything you see moving. So, not much different than a Florida highway.

This game is absolutely unplayable, and I don't just mean the god awful controls, tedious story, and repetitive tasks, but it also crashes randomly anywhere from 10 seconds to 1 hour into playing. You could be standing still, driving, or in the middle of a cut-scene and then it crashes with the same 0x887a0005 code. 

Uninstall and reinstall game (takes over 2 days for me to do this due to its massive download size), clean install all drivers, and even on a fresh Windows 10 install. Same issue every single time. System is greater than "minimum" and and slightly better than "recommended", but every single time the game starts, my graphics settings are returned to default and I'm warned that my system "does not meet  requirements". Go back into settings, set correct resolution and switch from "windowed" to "full-screen", set graphics back to medium, and try to get more than 10 minutes of game play in at a time.

But that doesn't even matter because you find yourself trying so hard not to scream at just how clunky, awful, and all-around horrible the gameplay is. It seems that they spent a ton of effort designing the terrain of the first level, and then just gave up on everything else. Story? Bland, short, and not nearly as engaging as something you'd expect from Kojima. Controls? Worse than any MGS game ever. Driving? Holy potatoes, driving is just... I cannot express how BAD driving is in this game. And since 99.9999999999999999999999999999% of the game is driving on a highway back and forth between the same few places, it's so hard to put up with it.

The game also has a HUGE issue with double-, triple-, or just repeatedly pressing the same buttons that you've pressed only once. Different controller? Same issue. Keyboard and mouse? Same issue. Trying to open the menu? Well be prepared for it to open and close and open and close and open and close and...... You get the idea. Another massive issue is that it won't recognize you've STOPPED pressing a button, or pressed a different button. Driving straight and trying to stop, there's about a 10% chance that not only does the vehicle not stop, but it continues accelerating forward. Trying to stop Sam while he's running? About a 10% chance that he won't stop and just continue running. Sometimes the button to open a menu at a structure is "X", sometimes it's "START", sometimes it's "Y". Sometimes the button to pick up an item is "Y", sometimes it's "X". Some cut-scenes can be skipped with "B", but it's pretty much random which and when that works. You watch the same exact cut scenes dozens and dozens of times every time you sit down to play. Donate materials to a facility? Here's a cut-scene. Recycle materials? Here's an UNSKIPPABLE cut-scene. Set out on a delivery (which is all you do), here's a cut-scene. Want to rest in your room? Here's FIVE cut-scenes!!! Want to get in your vehicle? Here's a unskippable, unstoppable cut-scene where the NPC continue to move/attack you!!!!!! It's madness. It's stupidity. It's awful!

I have never in my life ever played a game that has controls as awful and clunky and massively irritating as this, and that's including Sekiro and MGSV.

The most fun I had in this game was the first 30 minutes, walking and navigating my way over rocks and mountains and streams using ladders and ropes and with the help of others. After that, you get vehicles, and you never walk anywhere ever again. Really? I thought this was a walking simulator? Not an unforgivably bad pizza hut delivery driving sim.

There's also combat?? In this game???? Why? It's such an afterthought. There's 0 effort put into the system (like literally every other system in the game). Combat had me ready to chuck my $60 controller across the room because it's just.... It's......... I'm running out of superlatives to describe just how poorly this game was made! And when your game crashes randomly multiple times every time you play... There's no point to even trying!

You spend your time building highways through "enemy" territory where groups of marauders will actively try to kill you (despite a death causing a "void out" which kills everyone within miles). Killing anyone would also result in the death of everyone there, so why the F^#& are they trying to kill me??? And WHY THE EVER-LOVING F^#& WOULD YOU PUT A HIGHWAY STRAIGHT INTO THEIR TERRITORY WHEN IT COULD BE PLACED AROUND THEM? Unfortunately you don't control WHERE the roads go when you construct them, it's all pre-set. Mind-numbing stupidity!

I do want to say that the first level is gorgeous. Probably the best looking level/area of any game I've personally played. I was in awe of the work and detail put into it. Great music to accompany the slow walking and navigating. Unfortunately this doesn't continue, and the subsequent areas are bland and boring and all you do is drive back and forth... back and forth... back and forth.... 

I am not a "gamer". I play a few games occasionally and suck at all of them. I just want to take my mind off of my day/work and enjoy something. So when the game IS work, and that work is even more irritating than customer service.... It's just no fun. This "game" is exhausting, broken, not fun, not interesting, and it's not worth your money.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Loving every moment. Please don't let gameplay videos fool you, when you actually experience this beautiful game yourself you get sucked in and find it hard to turn off. It's atmosphere just absorbs you in and this is Kojima at his finest. Can't wait to play more.

Yes there is a lot of walking, but please ignore the 'its a walking simulator' cliches coming from people who are even barely an hour in. There's so much more than that, and even the travelling segments are impressive and can be both relaxing and stressful when BT's get involved..

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I wasn't sure what to expect heading into this... it looks weird, and that impression only gets stronger in the first 10 hours. Yeah, this game is really different. But that's what makes it great, and ultimately its my favorite game since the first Mass Effect all the way back in 2007.

Performance wise, the game is incredibly well optimized. I ran it on max settings at 1080P with an RX590.  I've had a couple crash-to-desktops in 100 hours, but that might be more to blame on me running loads of other stuff in the background.

In terms of the gameplay... you know how in games like Skyrim, half the fun is just trying to find your way to where your going, and sometimes that means trying to glitch your way up a mountain, or find some aspect of the terrain you can exploit to make a shortcut. Death Stranding is like if you took that activity, refined the hell out of it, and made a full fledged game unto itself. There is very little combat in this game. 95% of it is trying to figure out how to safely get from point A to point B, or figuring out where you can build infrastructure to make trips between point A and point B faster and easier.

The main story can be completed in 30-40 hours if you stick to it, but you can easily spend twice that long if you do a lot of side content, or spend time building infrastructure. The story itself is also just lovely. Really something different and unique. It is very weird of course, as are all of Kojima's games. And while the story is especially strange in the beginning, Kojima actually does a much better job of bringing this in for a landing than any of the Metal Gear games. It makes sense in the end, in a way that most of the Metal Gear games never did. And all of the actors in this game are just fantastic too.

I can't guarantee everyone will like this game as much as I did, but I do suggest at least giving it a shot.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is a hard game to recommend since it will leave you with either mixed emotions, dislike, or "Amazing, Kojima did it again!!"

A very unique game and a pioneer of its genre. Calling it a 'Walking sim' is almost unfair, since the depth of the mechanics and gameplay is way bigger than any previous games in the category. The delivery mechanics are well thought out, the various tools made available to you to help with your traversal, plotting your route taking into account various terrain obstacles and areas crawling with enemies, make it really satisfying once you reach your destination and looking back at the path you've taken, trying to make it even more efficient the next time you'll take it, especially with the multiplayer mechanic.

The soundtrack is great, coupled with amazing acting performances and great visuals and interesting characters. The story is very interesting and makes you think, however falls short in some areas and almost bashes you over the head with it's deep, metaphorical monologues which could be summarised as "This is really [b]DEEP[/b], do you get it ?!".

The game has big pacing issues, some areas of the game feel dragged out just for the sake of it, and make the game feel very repetitive and like a chore in a bad way (if you're a completionist good luck). Same can be said with some parts of the story that drag on with no real new information learned.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death stranding is a game that stand as an example to how a simple idea can develop and become something that is strangely enjoyable and moving.

Without saying to much about the game, the basic premise is you are delivery man walking simulator. Except there are ghosts that you have to avoid, and cliffs you have to climb. the story elements are woven into these deliveries, each main delivery furthering the overall plot. there are also the standard (side) quests that you would expect. These side quests are there so you can flex on everyone else by getting stars for each one fully completed, as well as getting equipment upgrades that are honestly amazing.

Aside from just completing quests there is also making such quests easier to do by building structures, this can go two ways. Either one, you have played minecr*** and enjoy getting materials and constructing things that make your life easier or path prettier, or you don't. Though it can be time consuming i would recommend actually doing this, is it needed? No, not at all, however the sense of fulfilment that you get after completing such things is genuinely pleasing. Once again, i recommend playing this game to it's fullest as both completing deliveries in and of themselves, as well as making such deliveries easier are a big part of having fun with the game.
Aside from basic gameplay you can expect a sizeable amount of lore and in game communications from npc that make from some great in game reading (if you're into that).

In conclusion i believe that if you are looking to get this game you should be expecting a story that's hard to follow but pays off at the end, missions that truly give satisfaction at the end, and obviously a really well made action-horror walking simulator.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Firstly, I want to start by giving my System Specs. 

i9-9900k 

NVIDIA 2080 Super 8gb VRAM

32 GB DDR4 Hyper X

running the game on the highest settings at 1440p on a ASUS 31.5 in Curve ROG Strix 
XG32VQ

using a RAZER Nari Ultimate for Headset and a XBox One Elite Controller.



	Some of the positives of this game as well some of the story line. 
The games visuals are absolutely stunning! I mean ill just stop and take screen shots to use later on for background pictures. Also, normally i do not leave the music in games on, this soundtrack though has been very enjoyable. I dont even mind that the walk will be tedious and long because the music and the visuals are so amazing. There have been a few times I climb a big mountain and I'll look over the edge and I'll get that falling feeling for a second in my stomach. I love it!
	
                    So, you play the game as Sam Port Bridges (Norman Reedus) and you're a courier of sorts in the apocalypse. Earth was consumed by what they call "The Death Stranding" which somehow merges the world of the dead with the world of the living. Your characher Sam is altered somehow and is able to sense what they call "BT's" which are the dead. You eventually acquire whats called a "BB" or "Bridge Baby" which is the creepiest thing ever but its basically a baby in a metal enclosure to simulate the baby still being in the mothers stomach. The "BB" helps you plug into "the other side" so you can see the "BT's". The "Bridge Baby" does need to be coddled and if you fall it will start screaming. Basically the "BB's" are typically not in service more than 1 year. They are pull from whats called a "Still Mother" which from what i gather is someone whos in a hospital bed. They have to make the "BB" think they are inside the "Still Mothers" womb for it to have the abilities it does. The "Bridge Baby" was totally a creepy idea but oddly enough it works for the story.
	
          You also realize really quickly that the rain is toxic somehow. They call the rain "Time Fall" and I assume its because if you dont find shelter or cover up, itll age you when it touches your skin so you lose "time"  hense "Time Fall" really cool concept. 
	
          Upon delivering your first set of goods which just so happens to be where the president of the UCA (United Cities of America) is, which just so happens to be your MOM!
You find out the President is sick and she wants you to find your sister and then BAM! President dies. You're then tasked with bringing the President's body to the incinerator at the top of a Mountain. The reason it's at the top of a mountain is because when they burn a body they dont want this stuff called "Chiral Matter" to get in the air where people can breath it in as its toxic. Chrial Matter has something to do with the "Death Stranding" on the planet. 
	
          It doesn't take you long to find your sister as she shows up right after you bring your moms body to the incinerator and return back to Capital Knot City. Upon your return you are told the "President" needs to speak with you which is weird because you just brought her body to the incinerator. So of course I'm originally thinking "these mother fuckers I do not trust them they staged a Coup d'etat but it ended up being my sister. Which I was like oh shit that was easy. But, she ends up being a hologram and you're told she is stuck on the west coast of the UCA by the enemy. You are stuck on the East Coast and must get to her. Her captors know she is talking to you and is allowed to have as much time to be with her people as a hologram as she wants which is really weird. Also, weird everyone for the most part are all holograms. Everyone seems to be somewhere else. 
	
You're goal so far is find your sister and start rebuilding America! 

____________________________________________________________________

Will Update Review once I finish the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: People talk, and then you have to walk for a bit. Then some more talking. And more walking. And a lot of walking. More talking. Walking. Walking. Walking. Then suddenly you think like "ooooh, that's a bike", and yes it is. Doesn't work though, cause Tesla won the fistfight against Vin Diesel, so now everything is electric, and that bike has no power, so it's about as useful as an iPhone 6 in the winter. Then some more walkies. All the walking might be interupted by rain, and in the rain lives the people that don't like you much. or maybe they like you too much, cause they try to hug you all the time. And babies. Both hugging babies, and the other one, known for a long time as BB. And then suddenly, you can build stuff, and bike works again. At least QI charging has come a long way. Then bikeriding. Oh, and a sudden boatride shows up. Blond chick uses confuse. It is very effective. Then talking. And more walking. Lots more walking. In between eating floaty bugs and drinking magical product placement, there will be a lot of walking. sometimes up, sometimes down. Backwards and forwards until paths appear. Ah yes, the walking, it's great tbh. If I could walk this much in real life, I'd be in such a good shape, I'd no longer be in the shape of a potato, although that is also a shape, and potatoes are good. Especially when fried. Or baked. Or steamed. Or mashed. I want mashed potatoes with gravy and meatballs or something now. Don't forget the walking though, because there is a slight amount of walking in this game. And poof, trucks. Trucks are neat, because then you can carry stuff without walking. I think that is how trucks work at least. Mmm, mashed potatoes with gravy and meatballs. Anyhow, Kojima is probably crazy, but at least the game is fun. For me that is. I't kinda like mashed potatoes. Not for everyone, but if you enjoy it, then you might find the gravy and the meatballs as well.

An honest to god work of art, in my opinion. 

10 out of 10

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hideo Kojima is a nutcase. A beautiful, intangible mind. But I feel like going into detail for this review because this is the kind of game people won't understand "why" it's good or bad unless you lay out the specifics.

This story is wild and barely makes sense even after having finished it, but it was immersive and feels analogous to our current COVID-induced isolation and distancing from one another. As Sam Bridges, your job is trying to connect the people of America back together via the Chiral Network (a.k.a. "The Internet") after a mass extinction event tries to wipe out humanity and decimates almost all infrastructure. On the way to linking everybody together, you also deliver many (MANY) packages to those in need. It's well acted, well shot, and the music is well composed. Certain scenes could've used better writing though.

The gameplay loop is probably where most people will take issue with Death Stranding. You traverse a variety of difficult terrain on foot or via vehicle. As the story progresses, you also unlock a bunch of useful personal utility and infrastructure schematics to make your job easier. When an area is connected to the Chiral Network, you'll start to see other players' built structures crop up, once again meaning less work for you. I enjoyed the feel of conquering a tough area knowing it's only going to get easier to backtrack it from then on, and the scenery is certainly something to gawk at while you're completing your tasks. But, it is what you could consider an action-focused "walking simulator" going from various point A's to various point B's.

Combat and movement/sneaking has remnants of Metal Gear Solid V in it, but you lack a prone feature and a lot of enemy encampments are mostly flat earth so sneaking into a densely populated area proves particularly challenging aside from the occasional patch of tall grass to hide in. There is also no such thing as a day/night cycle in the open world so usually they see you from a mile away. I personally preferred to avoid conflict as Sam just doesn't feel adequately badass in those situations. You're very weak, ammo is limited, takedowns/melee feels like it whiffs half the time, and in the heat of the moment it's annoying navigating a multi-page emporium of weapons and contraptions to figure out what toy you should be using to best get out of your predicament. There's no more concise way to describe it all besides "clunky" in my opinion.

Avoiding BT's (the monsters of this game) can be fun and intense but other times made me roll my eyes when I'd waltz into a BT-infested area that was mischievously placed right before my goal destination, slowing down my traversal considerably. If you're caught by a BT, you're dragged over to a mini-boss and have to fight your way out (or literally just run outside the combat area and it disappears). Said mini-bosses are boring, repetitive, and I think they should've figured out a less wasteful punishment for being caught.

So why a positive review after so much "eh"?

Memorability. Uniqueness. Impression. The open world was carefully thought out, the characters were quirky and lovingly brought to life by their A-tier actors, Kojima's zany vision for how the future looks and what advancements in technology may come are always a treat to see, and to top it all off for the PC version it not only looks jaw-dropping at unlocked FPS but we also get a great photo mode that I personally enjoy utilizing for games with a lot of eye candy like this.

There just isn't anything like Death Stranding on the market, and while I wouldn't go as far as to say it's its own genre like Kojima himself has infamously stated, I'd say we're not going to see something like this again for a very long time. If you see gameplay online and feel you're suddenly on the fence about a purchase rather than a hard "no", pick it up on a sale some time. You're in for something special.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding isn't for everyone, but it's definitely for me.

Performance on this game is fantastic for a start, I only meet the minimum requirements for it which had me worried at first but I have had ZERO issues running this game, I booted it up, started playing half expecting to need to fiddle with settings to get a smooth frame rate etc, but no. It runs like a dream 10/10 performance.

The story is a typical Kojima story meaning its not typical at all, The world he has crafted here is fascinating and deep with concepts that it may take some time to wrap your head around, but fantastic none the less. If you're aware of SCP's the enemies/lore in this game gives me expertly written SCP vibes and I just want to learn more at every stage. 

The Gameplay is the thing that may make or break the game for you though. There has been a lot of memes about how this game is a UPS simulator, and they're not completely wrong, but they do sell the game short. Personally I love simulation games, I like the struggle to push through a long and medial task to receive a reward at the end, but even then I wouldn't call the tasks in Death Stranding "Medial". There is always something to keep you on your feet, whether its the possibility of a BT encounter and the tension that can bring, or an interesting formation of land that you think could use a structure to help traverse, then you have various useful items scattered around, packages dropped by other players that you might have cargo space to pick up and claim their reward for your own.

The multiplayer aspect is great too! Its a great feeling logging on the next day and having notifications telling you other players made use of and liked that ladder you left or the rope you put down to traverse a rock face. 

In summary Death Stranding is a great game if you're looking for this unique experience. If you are looking for something more like Far Cry, Assasins Creed or GTA, you won't find it here but if you're looking for something different, something unlike anything else, and delivering packages to unite a post apocalyptic world. It might be the game for you!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: FIRST OFF: THIS IS AN IMMERSION TYPE GAME.  I really enjoy games like these.  Yes there's a lot of walking and building.  A LOT.  I get it, the majority of gamers nowadays want royals and action packed stuff.  But you have to remember that we wont get games like Witcher 3 where you get a mix of both Action and Immersion all in one big package.....its just not going to happen.  The one big fall back for me is that devs are no longer making games like these Co-Op.  Given that the majority of the game is just a walk and enjoy what you see.....id love to play with my friend and enjoy what these devs have created together.  I mean hell, there's enough space for 2 players in your world come on guys!!!  So if I say anything to these devs in the more encouraging way, MAKE IT CO-OP PLEASE!!!!  And by Co-Op i mean actually doing this whole game including cut scenes and activities in the same world.  NOT these so called "co-ops" that require you to go to a mission area and "play together against time" which is not co-op.  But over all for an immersive type game, I give it two thumbs up!!

When you start getting deeper into the game the mechanics come naturally and feel amazing. The soundtrack comes on right on time and the beauty of the game alone keeps you coming back for more. LOL, it was good enough make me write my first review.

I Recommend this game for a gamer looking for something new for a change. This is not a fast paced arcade shooter, not really for kids. ENJOY!!!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I struggle to properly convey in words the feelings evoked by this game. I thought when I played Nier Automata this year that it would be YEARS before a game came even close to knocking it off the top of my favorites, but this game has taken that spot.

The idea of a game where online strangers help each other with random acts of kindness isn't brand new but it's done in such a way that it really hits you hard. It's unfortunate that with the massive amount of technology we have put into the internet, it seems we've accidentally created an environment where receiving hate from online strangers is normal. Facing a direct opposition to that feels almost wrong at first, helping others without any benefit for yourself, and receiving help from others without any expectation of a return.

The characters in this game are so unique and are introduced and built on so complexly and strongly that they've instantly become the most memorable video game characters I've seen. Heartman, Deadman, Mama, Lockne, Higgs, Fragile, SAM. every single one of them I enjoyed almost every scene they were in and they're so unique that scenes fit together so perfectly.

My only complaint? Not enough Lockne, hands down.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
5 star. epic.
now i normally get bored of all games at aged 45, been there done that years before.
or they get too hard and i just cant be bothered with the effort.. too much of a challenge.

but this, even though everyone said its a walking simulator really caught me.
its not a simulator, it is an adventure and an epic story almost a sci fi movie.

tip was to avoid some of the missions and concentrate on Sam's orders.  yes there was still walking to be done but then when you think of other games, you always have to do this sort of walking about.


but anyway.. the story is just up there with the greatest of all.
i have now completed at 75 hrs. not interested in completionism... but i may pop back just for a chilled walk across some mountains and rememeber how the story finished.

was well worth the full price

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is my first Hideo Kojima game and hopefully not my last.  This was the game I didn't know I needed.

For way too long, I've been looking for that "something different" game.  It seems that most developers are stuck in battle royal mode, re-master mode, hardcore survival, etc, none being particular great or catching.  "Let's just regurgitate the same tired stuff that most churn money through".

As I've stated in other reviews, there are many reviews here that explain the technical aspects and other such detail.  Most are decent and I don't see the point in giving my $0.02 worth on those topics.

With 25 hours invested at the time of this review, DS has been an experience, not just a play-through.  Complete immersion.  Given the uniqueness of "an experience", it IS something to experience and I don't think reviews, in general, do that justice.  I don't think they can.  For me, the experience has been elevated from that which one gets from reading (or listening to) a great book... to the experience of being in that book with all the colors and ambiance.  Words are too shallow to describe that experience and do it justice.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I had a lot of doubts about the game because of the general feedback that the game is "boring". I am glad I took the dive and gave the game a try because its an absolute MASTERPIECE of a game. If you're only interested in action its not the game for you. But if you're into masterful storytelling, exploration and open to trying a new experience, it WILL change your life. I've my share of gaming experience over 3 decades from playing FPS, RPGs, watching Hollywood movies the lot and this game is refreshing and new.

You have to praise Kojima for trying something new and while I agree this isn't going to be a game for everyone. For the ones that do play through it, it'll be a life changing experience

There was so much feeling put into this and it shows through, I haven't ever had a game that made me feel so drawn to the story, and every character, Wanting to know the backgrounds and secrets to everything I was so moved.
I don't think anything can top this for me, It helped me get though alot too and i'm glad to be able to play this masterpiece.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Do not play this game if you prefer games where things happen.  This is not that kind of game.  This game is all about strictly linear gameplay, cutscenes, and keeping the player upright.  I'll admit, if you're into watching cutscenes, and hitting the left and right buttons to keep from falling over, you'll probably have a good time.  If you're looking for problem solving, puzzles, intrigue, or even just choosing between multiple outcomes, you might want to look elsewhere.

It's very pretty, though.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Maximum comfy. Pinnacle of walking sim with real gameplay and a world that piques curiosity.

After finishing the story ~65 hours in, I can say this will be one of my all time favorite games. Honestly, Kojima's best work since MGS3. A journey that rewards planning, diligence, and ingenuity and at the same time being a blast all the same if you lack any of those. Calling it a walking sim is of course a bit of a joke, but regardless, to actually think it is one is such a disservice. Its fun to play, the story is interesting, and you would be hard pressed to not form a strong emotional bond with Sam and BB. 

Get this game. Be prepared to immerse yourself in it, though. It demands nothing less.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I can see why this game is liked by so many. There is this certain relaxing feeling and also exciting feeling when playing this game. I think they did a good job with this one. Plus I get to play as Norman Reedus so that's a plus.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death stranding is a unique game that combines many different elements from different game genres into a unique masterpiece.  While it is somewhat of a walking game, it has a flexability and purpose in the paths/actions you take which give meaning to the long tedious trips you take across world.  The story is rich and the world lore is deep and weird at first, but Hideo Kojima does a great job of explaining the world and making it all fit together throughout the process of the game, often teasing bits of story making the players  want to seek out and discover the hidden truths while still being apart of the main plot.  The world never truly feels alone with other players structures and the likes you give/receive for the efforts in making paths more efficient using roads and bridges that you/other players make. It is one of those games that leaves an impression which you will remember for a while after playing, at least I know it will for me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Extremely recognizable character from 'The Walking Dead' TV show, Daryl, goes around delivering boxes. Have you ever been wondering around your favorite video game map, grinding out tedious side-quests, and thought to yourself:  "I wish there was a game just about this!" Well here you have it. 

Here's how game-play goes: watch cut-scene movie for a while, then wander around for a few minutes; scan area, go pick up boxes. Careful not to trip and fall, or you could break a box! Excitement! Sometimes the screen will auto-zoom out, crank up some hipster music, and you get a full-blown perspective of what it looks like when a game designer gets WAY excited about himself. Usually those kinds of moments are built into a scene to help develop dramatic tension, or to emphasize some important event like the climax or big ordeal. Instead we get to experience an awkwardly forced, full-blown dramatic reveal of what might make a nice screenshot about every 4 minutes, complete with a screen tilt to reveal the "Death Stranding" title... again, and again... like a series of commercial trailers slapped together. I realize that not every game has to be about explosions and fighting all the time, but honestly, playing this game feels like an over-produced interactive advertisement. 

It just tries as HARD AS IT CAN to be some transcendental amazing experience, and really wants you to warship this Koji guy as some visionary, game-creating genius, and shoves it in your face every chance it gets. Here's a tip for everybody: The product should speak for the brand. If a brand spends more time trying to sell itself instead of the product, don't trust the product.


TLDR:
So here's what $40 gets you here:
-Daryl delivers boxes
-Pretty graphics
-Emo/Tween music, with no volume controls
and my fav:
-Don't trip and fall!


I REALLY want my money back, but the game was left running in the background for a while after it finished downloading, so it counted that as play-time. I feel like I've been scammed.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
excellent mailman-mildy-inconvenienced-by-the-post-apocalyptic-world simulator. 

death stranding is basically just a Walking Sim But Better. its fun to run from point to point while you force sam to fumble over the slippery landscape. its fun to drive your truck over a mountain and listen to sam OOF and AUGH as you smash into rocks on the way down. getting the messages that other people have used your roads and interacted with your signs makes the game feel less lonely, without ever taking away your peaceful solo wandering. its also pretty funny to see the desolate spots other people have *weewee'd in.

very interesting to see how sams' relationships with the other characters in the game changes as you progress, and i think as a whole sam is a good character. he starts as a gruff idiot surrounded by people smarter than him, trying to help him understand their new world Stranded world---and he ends as a gruff idiot surrounded by smart people, but now he's begrudgingly fond of them.

for the negatives... the story is a bit of a *poopshow, but its not bad. you do have to wait until the last few chapters for things to be completely cleared up---the worst part about THAT, is that in the last couple chapters there is a part where it tells you what happens and makes you sit through a long sequence where credits play. then a chapter later it tells you what happens and forces you again to sit through a long sequence where credits play. unfortunately if you want to know all the story there's no real way to skip through any of the repeated shit without losing the little bits of clarifying information, and there's no option to skip through either set of credits---which is EXTREMELY annoying as they're spaced maybe 20 minutes apart and as far as i could tell it's the entire credits, both times. i'm all for handholding if your story is a bit convoluted, but this felt like the game was beating the story into me. twice.

the only other major failing of death stranding was the music. the music choice is DELICIOUS! but the music is constantly cut off and there's no way to play it on your own WITHOUT sitting in your private room and doing nothing. if you get too close to a landmark, the music stops. if you open a menu, the music stops---it'll start back up when you unpause, but for *fricks sake theres no reason it needs to pause unless there's dialogue. if sam can have a music player in his room, there is no reason he can't take a portable one with him. being able to play music on your own time would make the game 10000x better.


i'd still absolutely give the game a 10/10 as my enjoyment of it far outweighs my annoyances.
(also good to mention that outside of the few boss / beach fights, you do NOT have to engage in any combat. :) you can just be a sneaky widdle postman)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I really liked this game, but I know it's definitely not for everybody. Most of the game is incredibly peaceful and relaxing package delivery, broken up occasionally by the odd bandit camp or "ghost minefeild," which is higher tension but still feels like a natural transition. The story is pretty understandable, and the story setup is really interesting. I do have two major gripes about the game though.

1) The story based combat sections are insane difficulty spikes. I love a hard challenge, but 90% of the game has you cleverly avoiding enemies, and using the terrain to your advantage. Even if you do fight something, the enemies are complete pushovers and pose little challenge. Then out of nowhere at multiple points in the story, it tosses you an assault rifle and proceeds to kick your teeth in. I actually would have really enjoyed the difficulty as the sequences really feel like epic showdowns, it's just that these sequences are really long with no checkpoints. This means every time you die you have to repeat the last 10-15 minutes of stealth/combat/inventory management gameplay. The more "supernatural," boss fights don't have this problem, and feel really natural and fun, even while being high energy and exciting.

2) The "ending sequence," went on for about 10 hours. This is a Kojima game after all. From the time I went "Ok, this is the final epic showdown," to the actual end, I went through 2 different (long) play sessions, 4 boss fights (including one of the aforementioned hard combat sequences), and 2 completely separate credit sequences. There's nothing bad about any of the individual parts and they could each stand on their own, but around the 8hr mark it's hard to keep your energy up and I just kind of wanted it to be over. It's also during this section that the story starts to fall apart a little, and raises more questions than answers, and not in a good way.

Would I buy this game again knowing what I know now? Definitely. Would I recommend it to anybody else? Probably very few people, but there are definitely some.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Roughly 30% of playtime is actually gameplay. The rest is clicking though ridiculously long menus and sequences, over and over again, for every ever-so-small action. Want to recycle a piece of metal you found? Navigate through the menu. Confirm a couple of times. Watch that video sequence where Sam puts a box into a shelf — you've seen in a thousand times before —, then watch that thankyou-animation. I even stopped takeing on missions or collecting items on the go, just because I hate how long it will take to deal with the menus. I won't finish that game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: It is one of the most shocking games I ever thought I would pick up when playing video games since its the polar opposite of what I play normally. However, even with those limitations the game is one of the most fantastic stunning games you can play. I won't speak about graphics since games are going through enough of an arms race right now but it has a beautiful story that does make you wanna charge back into it in order to see what will happen next.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This isn't a game, it's 2 games. An epic journey west where Sam's physical struggle to bear his load across the continent punctuates the emotive hits of the story. And a delivery game, where the player creates and improves infrastructure to more efficiently  move cargo around the world. They're both great games but they don't always marry to each other perfectly. Gameplay-wise the 2 come together well enough. But the latter is too grindy to allow the former to move forward fast enough. Despite this criticism it's a great game worth playing which I thoroughly enjoyed and could even be the heralding of a new genre.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Gameplay is clunky, vehicle mechanics/movement mechnics are atrocious. The UI is extremely unintuitive, clunky layout with frustrating menus you have to cycle through (no quicksave option???) I do love how atmospheric and beautiful it is, and I'm ok with a slower-paced game. However, this game alternates from long cutscenes (like watching a movie) to long periods of walking around. Then wandering into BT territory is especially annoying if you have a vehicle; the BT's are attracted to fast movement, but it's just not a viable option to abandon your vehicle (that also stores your cargo). Storyline is muddled and lacking.

I do enjoy some parts of the game, but it is not worth the price (even got it on sale), and honestly I have no idea how this thing got a AAA rating. This is the most frustrating game I have ever played. I would recommend it IF it was closer to the $25-$30 range, however this is the most frustrating game I have ever played.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The story is very strange, but that isn't a bad thing.  The game-play however, I just can't get past.  I don't particularly like games where you must sneak and hide, and there is a fair amount of that.  I don't mind grinding, but this game forces grinding in the least fun way I have ever experienced.  I will stick to Elite Dangerous or Diablo type of grinding. Walking up mountains and wading through water was just too boring for me.

The story is interesting enough that I will watch a play-through on Youtube or twitch.  I only wish I would have come to that conclusion before 8 hrs of game-play, so that I could get my refund.  Oh, well, not the first time I felt that I completely wasted money on a video game, probably won't be the last.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is not a game for everyone, hell it's for practically no-one.

I'm a Kojima fanboy, I'll admit it, but I review games unbiased.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[b]Great Music[/b]: Orchestrated by Ludvig Forssell, an incredible score that really fills in the silence of walking hundreds of miles.
[b]Intriguing World and Story[/b]: An incredible and interesting take on Post-apocalism and a lawless America.
[b]Unique Characters[/b]: Every character has their own unique motives, packages and interactions.
[b]Unique Online System that makes the game excruciatingly painful without[/b]: Seriously, don't play without an internet connection, it's pretty much hardmode.

[h2]Cons[/h2]
[b]Combat is Lackluster[/b]: This I can give a pass on personally, as it's a story game not a fighting game, books don't exactly have the most incredible fight scenes now do the?
[b]Movement is Jank[/b]: The movement can be quite infuriating at times, but you can adjust to it eventually
[b]Non-stop tedious tasks and repetition[/b]: This is not a game for someone who wants a million different mechanics that are constantly changing 24/7. It is Tedious and Monotonous. That's the point.
[b]Lots of Talking[/b]: When Kojima makes a story game, he makes a story game, period. This is not a point to even argue about, as you should always expect talking in a story game.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
[b]Death Stranding is a game for people who just want to kill time.[/b] If you have nothing else to do but want a story that'll keep you invested, Death Stranding's for you. In the beginning the game can be stressful, but once you unlock Anti-BT weapons, the game is much calmer and you can be much more relaxed than before.

9/10
Even for a dedicated Kojima fan such as myself, there's a few things here and there that grind my gears. But overall, this is a fantastic game that iis a [i]real[/i] story game. If you wanna complain about too much talking, don't play Undertale and set your standards, people.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
At first i was skeptical about getting it, but eventually i wanted to see what it was all about.
Currently i'm only halfway through the game so this inst a full review, but based on my experience so far. 
Death Stranding is like Skyrim, but with barley any fast travel, and its not terrible. The environment is beautiful and almost every time i enter a new area the view just gets more breathtaking, and their is alot of things to see, explore and do. While the online feature is really cool being able to team up with other "porters" to build bridges, roads, and even safehouses where the player can stay. Even though you cant see other players you can still feel like working together twords an objective. The story may be confusing at first but a deeper glance reveals all the lore that sets in a backstory for what happened to the world and the characters. The characters may start off bland and will make you want to skip every cutscene but eventually the turn into more interesting characters with compelling backstories. The game so far is long with also long cutscenes and many character building moments with alot of side-quest style missions which have the player going back and fourth between distribution centers. And while these missions can get very repetitve and lose grip of the player, they do build up the setting and plot. 

So far my opinion is that while the game is fun and a explorer's sandbox, the game starts off rough but settles into a compelling plot with interesting characters and lore. SO FAR i rate it a 3.5/5 for amazing artwork, scenery, Characters, and gameplay. 

Dm me if you have any questions.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is a huge wasted opportunity. The core gameplay, which is essentially a hiking simulator through a bleak, post-apocalyptic landscape, is also fascinating. I love the idea of a nice, slow game where exploration and atmosphere are more important than run-and-gun combat. Death Stranding provides an open world whose physical contours are more fully realized than any other game I have played. You spend a great deal of time traversing this world on foot while balancing an enormous pile of things on your back which need to be delivered. There is an element of "The Postman" in all of this, as the act of carrying goods from one city to another bonds people together who have been isolated by a...well...unnatural disaster of epic proportions. The setting, which is supposed to be the United States, looks more like Iceland than anything else. It is also much, much smaller than you would think. Fortunately, the landscape is quite haunting and lovingly rendered. It is strangely satisfying to navigate, as long as you aren't looking for any actual connection to the good ol' US of A. 

There are just too many aspects of this game, however, which irritated me to no end. The story is bonkers. It is a turgid mix of puns, third-rate philosphy, surrealism, spirituality, furrowed-brow artistic ambition, and icy science-fiction. There were several times, during the many, many cutscenes that I had flashbacks to the starting screen from "Bad Dudes" on the NES...you know, where the President was kidnapped by ninjas. That's the wavelength this game is on. It makes Luc Besson's movie "The Fifth Element" look restrained by comparison. 

This could all be forgiven if the ridiculous cutscenes would get out of the game's way, but they constantly elbow their way in and spoil the fun. I found myself spending far too much time frantically trying to skip through one cutscene only to jump right into another one...and then another one. I never made it to the end of the game where, according to what I've heard, the cutscene orgy gets spectacularly overblown. 

I love open world games. SubNautica, Green Hell, and others have proven that solitary explorations can be compelling without explosions and combat. Death Stranding, however, takes a novel and enjoyable central concept and smothers it in a giant pile of self-indulgent hooey. It's a shame.

[h1] *Me, talking to a friend before playing Death Stranding* [/h1]

Me: Have you seen that new Death Stranding game? it looks like a fucking Uber Eats simulator.

[h1] *Me, talking to that same friend after playing Death Stranding* [/h1]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
(No Major Spoilers)

Story: 
(Disclaimer I haven't fully finished the game) but if you're interested in mind bending Sci-Fi then this is a good one for you. Much of the time you're thrown into the fray without much context and you have to dive into the world to put pieces together for yourself. You will be asking more questions about what is going on then there are answers. I am hesitant to divulge much because part of why I've enjoyed it was because I didn't know what it was truly about. But that's what makes the game so special in a sense; it's refreshing to be so confused in a crazy narrative. In a basic sense the world, in this setting America, has been brought to near extinction from an event. Your character is tasked with helping the fractured country come together, dealing with a terrorist organization that doesn't want you to succeed, and navigating the horrors of what the event has done to the world. In typical Kojima style the cutscenes can be both breathtaking and engaging as they can be boring and bloated. Some cutscenes I really enjoyed but other times I was losing patience and just wanted to play. But I feel like if you've enjoyed the Metal Gear Solid franchise then this isn't too far off from those kinds of vibes. Kojima definitely has a "Kojima" feel in his games and you can tell he's involved from a mile away. He can get a bit over the top in what I might consider needless complexity but that's just the way he makes games. Overall Kojima is a mastermind of complex weird ideas and it really shines here. 

Gameplay: 
This is where the game gets into its unique niche. You're mainly going to be tasked with delivering various things from outpost to outpost, traversing difficult terrain on both foot and vehicles. In theory it's fairly straightforward and in practice it can be quite repetitive. But you are offered limited freedom on how exactly you want to get to your destination. You have access to craft a variety of tools like ladders, bridges, towers, ropes, etc, to utilize where you see fit in the world. There are dozens of routes you can create on your own to complete your journey in whatever way you like. You have to be careful with your cargo as it can get damaged and part of the challenge of the game is to safely get from point A to B cresting mountains, rocks, and cliffs. If you overload your carrying capacity you'll be prone to falling and if you neglect your footing you can fall off a cliff in an instant. Part of the gameplay is to balance your cargo as you walk and make sure you don't tip over. You will be tasked with special requirements for certain deliveries; some being dependent on low damage and some being timed. There are story objectives but plenty of sidequests to keep you busy. You get different rewards from different outposts that can help make life easier for future deliveries. As odd as that all sounds it's pretty fun to just sit back and enjoy the lonely peaceful treks. Occasionally somber music will accompany you and the rain will start falling to set the mood for the struggles you'll face. There are multiple maps that offer some variety and room to breathe in a new location every now and then. The game offers harsh environments and there is little comfort apart from the help provided by other players (more on that below) 

Combat:
The game doesn't have much combat in the traditional gaming sense but during your deliveries you will run across "mule" territories. These guys are basically out to steal your stuff and part of the challenge is either avoiding them, taking them out with stealth, running, or punching them in the face. You do get tools like smoke grenades for escaping and a bola gun to help take them down with non lethal finesse. They do have loot you can steal but if they take you down you'll have to sneak back into their camp to get your stuff. You will also encounter "BTs" and without spoiling much they are essentially ghost-like creatures that you will need to sneak past or deal with in other ways. They can offer tense moments between deliveries where you have to sneak by several while holding your breath. You use a baby to help detect them (I know it's odd) and this baby will accompany you throughout your journey. There are other tools I haven't mentioned here that you will be able to use in combat situations; the main point being you have some freedom on how to approach every combat situation and plan ahead. You'll have to make conscious decisions on whether or not to sacrifice delivery cargo space or bring along additional weapons to deal with threats. Part of the gameplay is weighing your risks and prepping how you see fit. There are also bosses that you'll face but again without spoiling much I can't say much more. The last comments I have is that combat does get rather repetitive after the first few instances in one location. I think it loses its charm after you eventually backtrack through an area after your 20th delivery. 

Multiplayer Element:
In my opinion this is where the game really shines in a humble way. Equipment that is placed by you can potentially be used by other players to their advantage while they are pursuing their own journeys. If you place a ladder across a river it helps not only you but any other players who need to cross there can get across safely as well. Additionally, over time, you can see the paths that players have created that can give you a good idea of the best ways forward. Players can also leave markers that show up in the world that can provide warnings of danger ahead, helpful hints, and even encouraging words. You can leave "likes" on facilities that you've used or markers that you've found helpful. Overall this aspect of the game creates a positive bonding experience with complete strangers in a way that few games have done. It's a great feeling knowing that your equipment or signs have helped others. 

Graphics/UI:
This one is fairly evident but the game looks stunning. The landscapes, characters, items, and everything in-between has intense detail that keeps you super immersed. I would wager they used Iceland as a reference for the landscapes that are seen in the game as they managed to capture the bleak, lonely, and beautiful scenery portrayed there perfectly. The animations are all buttery smooth and speak well of the time that went into development. The UI and menus are complicated/overwhelming at first but you eventually familiarize yourself and can navigate them well enough. The maps and menus offer a host of tools that help you traverse the game and gain intel on whatever you might need. In my time playing I have seen no glitches or errors of any kind; they really did well here. For a PC port it runs perfectly.

Conclusion:
It's a weird game that tries to go against the norm and I believe it has succeeded in several ways. Kojima has a fantastic mind and has come up with some unique ideas that I haven't seen before. It's a refreshing Sci-Fi story that keeps me interested as I press on to make sense of things. They definitely took some risks and I'm sure many people will be bored or alienated from the game. There are a lot of repetitive aspects that bring the game down as a whole and it's unfortunate they weren't able to add more variety in the gameplay loop. Without nitpicking too much the game does suffer from a tediousness that can get old very quick. I think most of the issues are not game breaking but you can get burned out and bored very quick if this game isn't for you. The involvement of other players in your own singleplayer story was a fantastic touch that uplifted the game without really affecting the story, without it I think the game would have suffered greatly. It's an imperfect but unique experience I'm glad to have played.

9/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: this game is unlike any other    if you have played metal gear or fallout you will love this game

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] Presentation [/h1]
Death Stranding will surprise you with a very deep and cinematic experience that shows you exactly what type of world and game you're gonna get into.
The beginning hours may feel too overwhelming for the average gamer, throwing at you too many concepts about life, death, sci-fi, supernatural and survival elements right away in a seemly post-apocalyptic America.

[h1] Story [/h1]
Probably the strongest feature in the game is the story. It is slow and part of it being told through flashbacks, but once you start to link all the pieces you'll discover a great, well-crafted story that is worth the wait.
It will always keep you wondering what's gonna happen next, as you learn more about the world of Death Stranding, its characters, past incidents and other pieces of information only discovered via interviews and emails.
Narrative-wise, the story is divided by episodes, providing long cutscenes specially at the end of each episode, building more tension and unfolding a journey until it reaches its climax ending that's not easy to forget any time soon.
The only downside to this is the vast open world and gameplay that break the immersion and distract you from the main plot.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
By far the weakest aspect of Death Stranding is the gameplay. The story itself can be really interesting and unique, but it all boils down to walking/driving long distances to make deliveries, it's really all the game has to offer and while it can get addicting as you'll always try to take on the next order, there's no denying how poorly designed the gameplay actually is, almost abusive even as you constantly stumble, tip and fall over basically easy to walk grounds.
When it comes to the game physics and collisions, it's probably one of the worst in recent years for a game of this caliber, with the main character, objects and vehicles moving in a very strange fashion and having almost over exaggerated animations.
There's absolutely no quality content except for the main orders and maybe a few standard orders, the progression system is always the same, consisting on gaining trust for different facilities and preppers by making deliveries to get new equipment or leveling up certain equipment or weapons.
Engaging in combat is totally optional, there's no reward by doing so unless it's related to certain retrieving item orders from hostile territories, although it's acceptable, it's not a game about killing, bur rather connecting and striving as one.

[h1] Visuals [/h1]
The game looks beautiful, with absolute stunning areas and a decent photo mode. The Decima Engine stands as one of the most advanced game engines graphically-wise speaking. The water simulation, character models, grassland and draw distances are actually pretty nice.

[h1] Sound Design and OST [/h1]
The music and sound design is really on point. From vehicle sounds to basic actions such as footsteps, ghostly voices, combat music, you name it, it all sounds great.
The game features a very sad, ambient, romantic and even nostalgic feeling OST by Low Roar, Silent Poets, Chvrches, Alan Walker, Khalid, Bring Me The Horizon, and many other artists which did great with tracks that offered value to the story.
Once again composer Ludvig Forssell did an amazing job with the music score.

[h1] Technical Issues [/h1]
This game suffers form Access Violations on multiple threads, also having memory and GPU leaks. Access Violations errors (which causes the game to crash and losing your progress) may have been caused by running scripts from the Decima Engine itself and as of version v1.02 they have not been fixed.

[h1] Overall [/h1]
[b] Story: [/b] ★★★
[b] Gameplay: [/b] ✰✰✰
[b] Visuals: [/b] ★★★
[b] Memorable: [/b] ✮
7/10

I don't understand why is everyone saying this game is not for everybody. In fact it's a game everyone should experience at least once, if only because of its story, world, lore and visuals. Not everything has to be a shooter, action or RPG to be a great game that everyone must play or just a great piece of art in general.
With Death Stranding, however, if you can put up with its ridiculously repetitive gameplay and funky physics, you can find a really memorable journey, one that will not be forgotten for a long while.

Pushing the gaming industry boundries, creating something artistically unique and translating your vision into the videogame medium for other players to interact with is always appreciated and should always be welcomed.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I've got a very mixed opinion on Death Stranding. I do recommend it, but probably get it on a discount, I recommend the game but maybe not at full price, I'll explain my reasons.  
So, down to it. Death Stranding's world and lore is very interesting, though very weird. You can tell its a Kojima game, simply because the story is really... well, vague and kinda boring. I loved the voice acting, and they chose some really great actors for that, so that's a plus, but it all falls apart when the story they're trying to push along barely makes any sense or completely loses you halfway. Most of my time in the cutscenes was trying to understand and figure out wtf was going on.  
I'll admit, the gameplay in Death Stranding is barely there. There's packages that you deliver from point A to point B, and maybe you avoid some invisible monsters on the way, and a cutscene every now and then. That's literally the entirety of the game, even to advance the story. BUT the little gameplay mechanics it has, it does [i]extremely[/i] well, which I can commend them for, they didn't try adding in 5 billion different mechanics and end up half-assing them all. Buuut it could've done with something more.  
Graphics are stunning, though the landscape is super bland, empty, and dead. Settlements are (almost) all underground bunkers so all you see are the same delivery warehouse assets for each location. Would've liked to at least see what the inside of these are like.  
Performance is phenomenal, though at release there was big stutters, freezes and frame-skips (can't confirm if that's been fixed recently). A big plus if you've got an Nvidia RTX card is DLSS 2.0 drastically improves performance and even makes the game look better. Probably the best console port I've seen to date.  
You can tell Kojima's proud of his work because he plasters his name all over the credits. I gotta admit though, guy's no professional movie director, and it shows. I've seen better directing in small-budget indie films or no-budget indie shorts. The story kept me intrigued, simply because I love weird stuff, but its not a point id praise the game over.  
IF you want to give it a try, be warned that it starts to get interesting well after the 2hr mark (in my experience, though I didn't rush through either).

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Kojima is still way ahead of his time. A truly unique game, one of a kind.

Let me start by saying: Don't listen to people who say it's just a walking simulator...IT'S NOT.

The story is gripping and keeps you thinking constantly. 
The acting is great. 
The soundtrack is pleasant. 
The gameplay is engaging, makes you think and plan while also being very rewarding with lots of different styles of playing to choose from.

BUT, let me just give a slight warning: Try not to grind too much, don't focus on side stuff too much, continue the story here and there. I've played the game quite a bit and focused too much on 100% everything, so I got a bit fed up with the gameplay towards the end. BUT that was my own damn fault.

Just take it slow, enjoy. Soak in the environment, the music, the story the game tells. It's brilliant.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
As of writing this review, I have not finished the game yet, but I've come to my conclusion.  There will be spoilers so read at your own risk.


Death Stranding is by no means a typical game.  When it was originally released many called it "boring" or "intentionally frustrating".  I think that these are both lies.  At first, this may feel like the case, but slowly the game's ever increasing difficulty creeps up on you.  First you start out simply walking through a valley between two stations to deliver some documents, then later you're forced to scale entire mountains in the middle of a blizzard to deliver fragile lifesaving medicine all within a time limit.  Each area of the map feels meticulously crafted to provide a challenge to you.  There's no one "right" solution to get around each problem.  The fastest methods can mean multiple trips and leaving your cargo behind to degrade in bad weather, but at the same time, slower yet higher-volume methods can mean trekking through BT territory with a full load of cargo and risking losing it in a deadly fight.  Achieving S rank on all your deliveries, especially on higher difficulties, becomes a major challenge that pays off so well when you fully max out stars on a prepper.

The gameplay, however, is not the best part of Death Stranding.  What makes Death Stranding art to me is the masterfully written plot and characters.  Each and every character feels like it was given hours of writing and development before the game was released, even the minor side characters.  Every single character in this game has their own unique struggles, trauma, and backstory that explains why they act the way they do.  Some see Fragile Express and Bridges as terrorists, coming to take away their liberty, and some eagerly join the UCA, hoping to save others from the same suffering that they've endured.  Watching Mama send her BT child into the "other side" and thus sacrificing herself to help Sam expand UCA was one of the first time I have ever had a game make me cry.  The acting is world-class, making every character feel so real.  Heartman's story of losing his family and going into cardiac arrest every 20 minutes just so he can have even the slightest chance of seeing them one more time is truly painful.  Reedus and the rest of the cast bring the characters from being characters to real people who all struggle just the same as we do.

There are times in this game when you feel truly alone, walking a lonely path, simply a porter living just to transport cargo.  The fucking fantastic soundtrack hammers this feeling in so well, kicking in on long stretches.  However, for each of these moments, there are so many more times where you are reminded that you are not the only one who struggles.  Other players' structures can save your cargo and your life at times.  Together with everyone else you can build you own infrastructure that allows players to get around safely.

The ultimate message of Death Stranding is that we are in this together.  Despite every characters differences they can all come together to save America.  I often stop to think that, despite likely never interacting with any of the people who's building I use or who use mine, we have connected ourselves through this online game.  In uniting players in one grand struggle, Kojima reminds us how important unity and community is.  Every single person who plays this game is connected and relies on one another to survive and "save America".

So, if you want an action-packed bloody mess like Ghost of Tsushima (which looks fucking amazing btw) or Call of Duty, I don't blame you in the slightest.  This game will [b]NOT[/b] be everyone's cup of tea, but if you like Kojima or don't mind a slower paced story oriented game, I beg you to give Death Stranding a play.  As the game's tagline says, "Tomorrow is in your hands".
