title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Kojima really kept us waiting for the PC release

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I really enjoy all of Kojima's games. Especially his last game MGS V: The Phantom Pain. When I first started DS it felt really slow and I really just wanted to play another MGS. But like many of his games, there is a slow start up, because you're about to have to learn and utilize a whole lot. The slow trickle of new mechanics and gadgets would be WAY too much up front. Similarly to how MGS fully blooms after about 50 hours, I feel like this game really begins to shine after about the same amount of hours and I am happy for that. 

What makes me mad is that originally I intended to buy a ps4 to play this game when it launched. But all the reviews said this game was "its own genre" and "we dont know what to call this game other than a walking simulator." which is complete bullshit. Its just as much an action RPG as any except Kojima has a clever reason not to murder people. Let it be known, this is an action RPG through and through, and if that's your flavor, pick this up. 

While this isn't another metal gear solid, its certainly another vehicle for Kojima to share his stories with the world. We as humans are better for it.

Edit2: Upgraded to Ryzen5 3600 and nvme SSD. Game doesn't drop bellow 110fps

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
7/10

The game if definitely over-hyped and over-praised, but is still on the good side.

The story while not phenomenal is innovative and decently interesting (if you can overlook some of  the new age mishmash it is based upon) and it is definitely the best part. It is mostly well told and most importantly, although confusing at times, is presented in sufficient detail. The main characters are fantastically well acted, beautifully animated and the main cutscenes are masterfully directed.

All the main characters are well designed and each has his/hers unique story and place in the grand scheme of things. The support characters though range from bland to cringy to fairly annoying. All characters names are puns of some sort - Barbara Strand, Die-Hardman, Heartman.... I personally find that quite irritating.

Also most of the characters are designed with some form of shock value intended to force an emotional response out of you. And when it has served it's punch, they're usually discarded. (even some of the main cast)

The story suffers from some pacing issues. It starts well with the right mix of exposition and gameplay. Then it drags a bit in the middle when you travel across the country connecting stuff. Then it picks up again , then races through by the end, dumping huge amounts of exposition. And while the main storyline is fairly conclusive, some of the supporting stories are either underdeveloped or left unresolved.

The gameplay is exceptionally narrow. The entire game you do one thing and one thing only - carry packages form A to B. Literally all missions consist of this, except one or two tutorials and a few action sequences. The monotony is only broken by a few stipulations. The packages you'll have to deliver will sometimes have to be wrestled from bandits and sometimes collected from a remote area. Also there are various types of packages, some with restrictions on how to be handled. And sometimes you're tasked with carrying a live bomb which has to be meticulously babysat.

Thankfully you have a lot of tools at your disposal to get the job done. There are various climbing gear, boots , exoskeletons and vehicles that help you carry the packages over the roughest of terrains. There is also a set of buildings to be built. Some of them help immensely on the way.

One very cool feature is the passive interaction with other players. You can use buildings , vehicles and equipment left by others to help you on your way and you can also leave stuff for others to find. One annoying part of this though is that the game takes every opportunity to bombard you with communist propaganda urging you to do so.

Controls mostly logical and satisfying and keep the flow going. UI is mostly sensible. Although there are a lot of menus, once you get used to them, you can navigate easily. One minor annoyance is whenever you unlock new equipment, it is usually presented to you in a cutscene. Then a large text box appears, explaining how to use it. Then somebody calls you - Hey, by the way, did you know that you can now do ... whatever was already explained twice.

The game overall looks great. The character models are meticulously detailed and the colors are very true to life which I love. The world design though leaves mixed feelings. It definitely has  it's fair share of beautiful vistas and scenic spots, but most of the time you're looking at just mosses and rocks. There are mostly three types of terrain - green mossy fields , snowy mountains and something that faithfully resembles the surface of Mars.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The game engine is quite nice and awesome looking, as the characters.

The overall idea of having a porter linking stranded cities, nice. Good.

Now, the details of the scenarios and ideas just don't make senses, bordering silliness and full of illogicality. You'll have your 'suspension of disbelief' killed once per cut scene or dialog, at the very least. It's just so weird, inconsistent and outright idiot at time. 

I don't want to spoil the storyline, so I'll just give a few examples: a person held hostage but with full access to telecommunications and radio. Holograms with weapons at the ready guarding bridges (even at the distance, you clearly see they are only projected images). Marauders which are made crazy not because of the undead or a virus, but because they became too frustrated of not being delivery men (really!). 

Clearly the man in charge is smoking too much weed or illegal substances... Too bad, the graphics and several game mechanisms are nice. For the rest, I'm wondering if I should not try to finish the game with all cutscenes disabled for starter.

The game crashes frequently, about once every hour, very irregularly. Sometimes I can play for 5 hours without crash, sometimes it crashes after 30 minutes. It seems that these crashes are common, when you web search you find many people reporting similar issues.

My recommendation would be to wait until they improve the game's stability.

Update 2020-09-06. After playing for some more time, the crashes have gotten less frequent.
Update 2020-09-06 15:00. Forget what I said earlier. I now reached a point in the game where it consistently crashes. I can no longer progress.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I just wish to start by saying that I have over 200 hours on the game on PS4, even though it says I only have around 9 Hours as of writing this review. 

I've seen many people say that the game is nothing but a movie, with no gameplay and only cutscenes, and while there are long cutscenes in the game, it's wrong to say that this is just a "60 Dollar Movie" and not a "60 Dollar Game" I'll be going into spoiler territory so for those who wish to experience the game themselves can stick to the TL:DR at the bottom.

You start off the game as Sam (Played by Norman Reedus). You are a porter, a person whom handles packages and deliveries in a post apocalyptic america. Your primary objective is to deliver packages to people who need it and connect them to the Chiral Network (Basically the Internet but cooler). In the beginning, you can only carry the packages on your back and walk to the destinations. You have access to ladders, ropes etc to help you traverse the land covered by rivers that can wash you away, rocks that can make you slip and fall and so on. As you progress through the game, you get items that can help you with your package deliveries. 

You will unlock cars, bikes, zip lines etc to make your life easier. I've seen people complain that the zip line makes the game trivial because it takes away all the challenge to climb mountains and stuff, but I have to disagree, is it's just a tool in your disposal that allows you to tackle challenges in different ways. Does it become a lot easier to climb mountains with it? Yes it does, but that shouldn't be a negative thing. You're rewarded for setting up and maintaining these zip lines that allow you to complete deliveries faster and safer, just like how a Truck driver gets his job done faster and safer because he's driving a truck. 

As you continue through the game, you come to realize that most of the gameplay loop revolves around you picking up packages, and delivering these packages. This might not be for everyone, but saying that there is no "gameplay" at all because of this is plain wrong. 

You have enemies that you must fight, enemies you must hide from and different environmental mechanics like slipping, getting washed away, losing balance etc. This game revolves heavily on taking smart paths, while not losing and destroying your cargo that people so desperately need. You also build structures to help other players in the game, something that is my favourite part. 

TL:DR: Is this game for you? Well, that depends entirely on the person who's looking to buy. For me, this is the best game I've played in a very long time. I find it very chill to just do deliveries and traversing the beautiful landscape. If you find games like Euro Truck Simulator fun, then this game could be very much for you. I get that this game isn't for everyone, but there are plenty of stuff in this game that says that it IS a game, and not just a movie, but people cannot see past that because they would rather hate on stuff that are good, then go back to their fortnite or call of duty.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] SPOILER FREE REVIEW [/h1]

At the time of this review, I am 31 hours in. Will update when finished the campaign.

[h1] Story [/h1]

If I had to ratio this game's appeal, it'd be 80% story and 20% gameplay mechanics. Let me explain. Inside of the first half hour, you already begin to feel a gleaming sense of familiarity as [i] Death Stranding [/i] has that classic Kojima touch we've all come to love. The way it almost feels you're playing a large budget film at times with tracking shots, close ups, overhead shots of the world. Talk about big on presentation. Over the course of this long journey, we're developing unique relationships with those we come across. [i] Death Stranding [/i] takes its time fleshing out the world, dispensing information at an infrequent yet rewarding rate. Should you be patient enough between each story beat, it certainly unloads enough to compel you to move forward and unlock more of the confusing yet fascinating story. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

So let's address the elephant in the room. [b] Yes, this is a niche game. No, not everyone will enjoy it. [/b] When it comes to the gameplay, [i] Death Stranding [/i] revolves almost entirely around delivering packages. You are, in fact, a porter. It isn't just a title. The entire world surrounding you has been constructed in such a way to provide challenging ways for you to traverse it. Elements like weight, movement speed, package location and various tools at your disposal all play a part in your success of getting a package from Point A to Point B. Some may joke this game is considered a [b] Walking Simulation. [/b] You're free to view it that way. 

This is not [i] Metal Gear Solid. [/i] If you come in expecting massive bouts of action and shooty shooty gun kill EXPLOSIONS!!!! ... You'll be sorely mistaken. Yes, there are ELEMENTS of combat, but it certainly is not the main focal point in any way, shape or form. Though if you come in with an open mind, you'll find that the 'way of play' you're encouraged to try can be quite enthralling, too. Devising careful paths and approaches to overcome the dangerous obstacles standing in your way and executing them flawlessly, or failing miserably and improvising a way to get yourself out of a mess can make for exhilarating moments.

[h1] Fidelity/Fluidity [/h1]

Simply put, this game was meant to be played on PC. What a flawless port. The world as you step out into it is vast and colorful, with gorgeous terrain scattered all around you. Easy on the eyes when you're engaged in playing or taking a break to just admire. The character models, especially in cutscenes, are bar none some of the most impressive I've seen in ages. That IS Norman Reedus. That IS Mads Mikkelsen. Down to the spottiness of Norman's facial hair to the creases in Mads' face. Truly impressive stuff. Running the game at a consistent 60 frames per second or more absolutely makes for a fluid play experience. Couldn't go back to the hard 30 on console, personally. Many of the encounters you'll come to face can partially rely on the sounds emitted and my goodness, does it do it well. In certain scenarios, the noises made by certain... THINGS have absolutely creeped me out. That's a good thing. Sound good. 

[h1] Overview [/h1]

It's no secret that [i] Death Stranding [/i] isn't for everyone. Your main player base here are proper Kojima fans, story-rich lovers and appreciators of new experiences. That's exactly what this new IP from Kojima Productions provides you with- an experience unlike any other you've ever had. Is the game perfect? Of course not, none is without their shortcomings. But I'd be remiss to give any other impression than my honest one, which is solely that the pros FULLY outweigh the cons. If you can stand or prefer long play experiences, compelling story, unique gameplay and thinking you know what's going on only to be dead wrong over and over again, look no further. THIS is what a sixty dollar game feels like. Absolute major props to Hideo Kojima and his whole studio for putting together such a remarkable experience in such a relatively short window of time. I have full faith in their next project.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]Overall impressions[/h1]
Delivering packages and building infrastructure is unexpectedly satisfying but may turn off some as being a bit grindy when it comes to resource gathering.  I had reservations before release upon hearing the early details of the mechanics, it did not exactly sound engaging on paper as glorified fetch-questing.  This was unfounded though, as the general process of getting from one place to another has plenty of nuanced mechanics that reward attention to detail and planning.  Aside from that, the narrative and characters all line up with expectations for a Hideo Kojima game - a bit over-the-top in a way that tends to be very memorable.

[h1]Nitty-Gritty[/h1]
The main loop is simple - chose packages to deliver from point a to point b.  The underlining mechanics though encourage the player to consider terrain, prepare by choosing a route either from other players or their own, optimize their load and orders and pick out tools for the job.  When out in the environment, the topography of the trail can be scanned in-game to give visual indications of bad footing.  It also helps highlight other packages that are may be picked up along the way.  Most of the time when progressing through the story they are for previous areas and would require back-tracking to complete but can be worthwhile to stock up in a private locker or to pass off to other players to finish for a reduced rating.  Walking in those areas tend to make it harder to balance and can easily lead to tripping when running.  If you fall, packages get scattered and potentially damaged, which will lower your rating for the delivery.  Most of the time this is easy to avoid though unless you purposely load up too many items.

The online elements provide indirect co-operation in three main forms: signs, buildings and tools.  The signs can be placed in order to provide boosts or warnings to other players.  Tools like ladders and ropes that are used in the environment can be seen and by other players or may appear in your game.  Buildings act similarly but have more specific utility such as storage containers in which packages can be stored for later delivery or left for other players to finish.  These are all related to the overall progress that has been made on an area - as when you first enter, very few tools or buildings appear.  As you gain more reputation (in the form of likes) from the area's inhabitants via the main terminal, the more other players items appear.  You can also add likes to the items form other players and receive them - resulting in bonuses for stats.  Using them often will reward one like for the player who left and item, but you can button-mash to add a lot of likes for those that you really appreciate.

Those concerned with having some actiony-bits will be pleased to know that there are two other main aspects to deliveries - mules and BT's.  Without getting into the details of the story, BT's provide the main stealth portion of the game and mules the gun-play.  Granted, either can be approached interchangeably as you get access to more tools.  Your engagement with them can vary, as sometimes it is often required in order to get into new areas but later can be beneficial to seek them out for resource gathering.  Each generally are only found in certain areas, so they can at times be avoided entirely if you know where to go or pay attention to the community signs.

Aside from that, there are enough smaller-scale mechanics that make it difficult to get into them all.  As an example, you can make Sam pee – which I would normally expect to be a throw-away addition but instead has varied affects.  Doing so in the environment results in mushrooms and has a cumulative size based on the efforts of player contributions.  On the PS4, the community decided to do so in one specific spot in front of a character’s home [spoiler]Conan O’Brian’s[/spoiler], which in response I naturally marked with a Deep River sign.

[h1]Some Strategy[/h1]
Most seem to recommend not worrying too much about ratings until you get at least into chapter 3 mainly due to new items you receive later in the game: roads and eventually zip-lines.
Throughout the central region there are road drop points that require a lot of resources - ceramics, metal and crystals.  The total amount required can be alleviated by contributions from other players though.  The precise nature of this is not very clear, but the result is that for the most part you can be the sole provider of all the materials mainly in areas which have not yet been connected to the network.  Once an area is connected, the higher the rating and connections made, the more will appear to be added from other players to the various road build points.  You potentially avoid spending much (or at all) on completed road sections in this manner but they are also a massive source of likes.  Often completing a few sections of road can lead to getting enough likes to hit the soft cap on the player-related stat.  Other than that, they also provide constant power for vehicles on the central line and relative safety from mules and BT's.  Keep in mind though that mules can hit you from unexpected places if you are not traveling at high speeds.

Zip-lines on the other hand provide quick transportation form one area to the next.  The main catch though is that they are very network-intensive per node, and usually require some finessing.  Based on your current ratings in each area, the network determines how many structures you can build based on a bandwidth point value.  Zip-Lines themselves take up quite a bit at 500 a pop.  They also have limits to length (300 regular, 350 level 2) and require line-of-sight.  These can be used to easily connect areas that otherwise do not connect directly to roads, making speed deliveries for S+ ranks much easier to complete - or possible at all for those that are speed-based.  Additionally, the eastern region can be networked with zip-lines to the point in which all terminals are connected.

[h1]Some Dark Souls[/h1]
As much as I probably should avoid it - a lot of things I like in Death Stranding are comparable to Dark Souls.  The online features build upon the foundation of Dark Souls and Demon's Souls use of World Tendency and player notes as a sort of multiplayer-but-not-directly-multiplayer approach to building a community.  The commitment to atmosphere in both is strong and includes aspects of the lore into gameplay in a way that many games do not.  Death provides more of an inconvenience, not a hard-stop, allowing players to maintain immersion even when they fail.  There are some game-over screens but they tend to be limited to boss-battles and specific story missions.

[h1]Something Personal[/h1]
The themes of the game resonated in a way that I really did not anticipate, but probably should have guessed.  My wife is home-bound due to illness (MCS), and so much of my time not working as an early father was spent gathering things we needed from the outside world while carrying my daughter in a wrap.  The similarities obviously stop there, but in the playing of the game it endeared me more and more to Sam and BB as characters.  Throughout the story there are moments that made me even wonder if the director was a father himself - which apparently, he is.  Fatherhood as a theme is one of those things that appears to be coming up more commonly in games these days, but despite all of the sci-fi and horror elements, Death Stranding has been for me the most relatable.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The best example of a console port I've ever played. Genuinely loved every second of this game. Very happy it finally came to PC where it can really shine. Great world building, story, and characters. Graphics are top tier, which is impressive considering it was originally on a console. This is the first game in a long time that I felt relaxed and could actually take my time. Some of the cut scenes are a bit long, but what do you expect from a Kojima game? Seriously, just kick back and enjoy.

Only other thing I would call out it the exceptional soundtrack. Very impressed.

review: Wow.  All I can say is wow.  I took my time - 125 hours - to play through the game.  Amazing creation.  Impossible ideas.  Fast-action combat periodically punctuated with much time exploring, playing around, different environments.  Game is a work of art.  Such beauty.  Not a Doom FPS (which I love) but an awesome way to enjoy someone's story.  Kojima Productions and Hideo are awesome.  Well worth the price.  Only small criticism is ending takes its time and is a little convoluted.  But I'd still give this 99 out of 100.  Brilliant.  And you get to keep playing after the end (though not sure if the bosses still show up - I am off to find out).

review:
Loved it. Drop-dead gorgeous and great music. The world and story were quite interesting to me, and while some people might dislike the gameplay, I enjoyed it quite a bit. It's very different from what everyone is used to, and sometimes it does feel like a chore, which I guess is why a lot of players critique it in the way they do. It's not for everyone. I'll admit though, I was on the verge of rage quitting a couple of times because of the gameplay. Especially my first quests in the mountain area, but every time I did, my patience was rewarded with another chunk of the game story, and some new equipment that helped make the next deliveries much easier. 
Overall I really like this game, to the point that I keep on playing it even after finishing the main story.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]A Walking Simulator?[/h1]
Death Stranding is definitely not a game for everyone. You have probably heard that its a "walking simulator". While I wouldn't agree, it is accurate to say you're the 'FEDEX guy' which is mainly walking from point A to point B. 
"Wait!" I hear you say "That sounds like a walking simulator to me!" I would agree. However, Death Stranding was made with this in mind, and is built around it. Just like how a good stealth game is fully built around stealth. If you shoehorn stealth into a game that is not built around it, it often comes off as contrived and unenjoyable. When many people hear about what you do in Death Stranding they imagine the equivalent of a whole game of shoehorned stealth sections. 

Death Stranding is built around the idea of carrying a package from point A to point B, and I have never seen a game do a better job at it. Something that sounds so dull as planning a path through some rocky hills is actually a pleasurable experience. 

The world of Death Stranding is so grounded as well. There are a few fantasy elements put into the world, not a lot. However, each element is taken to its limit. The world is shaped by these elements down to the minute details. 

It is great seeing Kojima make the game that he wanted to make with no restrictions. This isn't a big action game, this isn't a big stealth game. This isn't one big hero pulling America together. This is everyone chipping in to do their part. This isn't a game for everyone, and it might not be a game for you, but I would love to have another porter out there to walk with. 

"The paths we walk become roads"

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Oh my god. I am unable to express my approval for this game well enough. I'm a picky gamer, and I'm always looking for something different, this is it. I can't even do a pros and cons, because everything so far are pro's. I am writing this review after playing for 14.3 hours, and that is all in one sitting. I installed it, kind of tired, figured i'd try it out for a bit, and go to sleep. I've now been up for 28-29 hours, and I regret nothing.

The Story is totally unique, the gameplay itself, is also totally unique. Everything about Death Stranding is a gem. I will not spoil anything, but I will give you a little description of what kind of gameplay is involved.

Delivery: Everyone sees this part. You run cargo from a city/outpost to another city, settlement, waystation, etc. You will also find cargo littered across the landscape from previous dead couriers, and deliver that as well. You'll have to manage your weight and how it's stacked however, if you get too top heavy, you'll be falling all over the place.

Dark Souls style help: Dark souls is the closest explanation to it, remember the tips you'd get in messages through darksouls that could be upvoted? The same type of system exists here, except it's picturesque holograms to tell you where it's safe to wait out the rain, where a nearby bridge is, and where enemies are. The biggest difference however is, Objects transfer over as well. You may be scaling a cliff, and find a ladder not far from you, from where a previous courier traveled, or some of the cargo you find may have been theirs, but they had to leave it behind, or it got knocked into a canyon.

Combat is a thing: It's not a pacifist game. You'll be fighting all sorts of interesting and unique enemies.

Stealth is a must: Sneaking and even holding your breath to reduce the sound you make is a very important feature in this game at certain times. Do you need stealth? Absolutely not. It's much easier by sneaking through some places, but if you want to walk through like you own the world, it's still quite possible.

Many different ways to play: As I said above, it's not a "You must do this to get through here." type of game, there are endless ways to do everything.

and finally, the Massive World: I do not feel constrained at all. I have found no borders, I have not hit any "out of bounds" barriers. Any hill, any mountain I've wanted to climb, I have. Thing is however, some mountains you'll simply look at and think: Nah, it's a pain in the ass. I COULD, but I choose not to. and that's how the barriers work.

I recommend this game. It is worth full price without a shadow of a doubt. If you can get it on sale, go for it, but even if it's not... If you need a GOOD game, this is it. If you're stuck between this, and another game, choose this.

Oh, and Norman Reedus is the voice actor, that's kinda cool too.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
在玩这个游戏之前，我完全无法理解送快递竟是一件令人如此沉浸并快乐的事情。

       虽然你从表皮上看，这也许会是个欧美风格的游戏，比如精美的画面，精致的细节，枪械，开车，还有欧美的演员，但它的内核确是十分偏向东方文化的。
       游戏的背景看似在铺陈着生与死的边界，末世的氛围，但其所突出的主题却是一个人心灵上的成长还有人与人之间的情感联系，它所意图讲述的是人不可能孤立地活着，人之作为人的本质是要依存于他人的联系而能存在的。
       明线上是山姆奔走各方，几乎孤身一人充当起了联系作为一个个孤岛的个人的桥梁；在暗线上，旅途中支离的线索慢慢地拼凑出一段感人至深的往事，它是最为触动人内心深处不断悸动着的渴望的情感，在剧中以一种悲壮而充满希望的方式呈现在游戏剧情的最后几小时中。
       也许有很多人没能耐下性子坚持到这一切的结束，但若你能乐在其中的话，也许能收获其它作品难以满足你的感动。

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Currently 60+ hours in

Generally enjoying the weirdness of the game.
Slow to start off in the first area, you lose you bike and have to walk/run around for a bit but still interesting enough to keep you occupied, your introduced to characters and game mechanics. slowly making you way around the map on foot and eventually move onto area 2.
Area 2 is where the issue start, but not until your over half way though.

You start off on foot and have to run everywhere again to start opening things up.
You come across MULES, which after a while you realise just how little threat they actually are and are easy enough to beat even if they come as a group.
You get your bike back and things start to get easier...yay, except for the really rough terrain at times
You get a van, which makes things interesting, just how bad the handling is for a "delivery" vehicle and just how useful it can be when you start to get the bigger deliveries.
You start to get the road network rebuilt, takes a while but makes things so much better, magical floating roads...yay
Then...you reach the mountain...OMG...which then turns the game into an even slowly slog than the first area.
Crawling thought the snow to open up areas, so you can build ziplines at least.
Going to BT areas makes things even more slower...found i preferred just to agro them and defeat the mini boss just to clear the area out and move on far easier.
Wind and snow storms every 2 mins so you have even more trouble moving and seeing just where your suppose to be getting too. 
Delivery orders to collect stuff from certain areas of the mountain, so again having to slog thought the snow to retrieve as there is no easy method to really get about.
First part of the 2nd area, was enjoyable and in a way relaxing...this is just ...ugh....people want to take shelter on a mountain....don't expect anyone to deliver....just let them DIE....
And when clearly the roads are floating in some places cant you just continue to build roads to these remote areas.
Ziplines are pretty cool but sometimes you just would prefer a road.

Prolly edit when i finally get around to finishing it, but for now...back to the ruddy snow :(

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This is a refreshingly unique and interesting game at first, but ultimately it does nothing well. For a cargo-based game the inventory management is clunky and shallow. For a walking sim the controls are superficial, the terrain clipping is odd, and interaction with context-sensitive objects demands a controller precision that the game mechanics can't reliably provide. For a hybrid cine/sim game the cut scenes are sloggy, repetitive, and the dialogue is a case study in the obvious. I've been a Mads Mikkelsen fan since Pusher but I couldn't skip his scenes fast enough. Stealth-based game play is disengaging, driving mechanics have no basis in physical law,  the menu system is an abortion. I liked that combat is a low-priority in the game, but it certainly doesn't add to the experience either.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Alright, perhaps this is my first review where [b]I'm not sure if I recommend it or not.[/b] It was incredibly hard really. Perhaps this would be the case where a scoring system would be appropriate. If such system would exist, I'd give it 3/5, being generous. IS a good game, but there's a few fundamental flaws.

Okay, so, this game is done by Mr. Kojima and such, which we all love and all. [b]But let's all be honest: Is not a game for everyone, BUT going from point A to point B, for the millionth time could be still fun[/b]. Might be fun, in some cases. To get it out of my system, here's a few cons, then the pros, to end in a positive note.

[h1] Cons [/h1] 
[list]
 [*] [b]Controls/Movement. [/b]
Animations are great, but there's this very annoying issue about momentum. Yes, could be nice to be aware of your surroundings to avoid tripping, but sometimes, because of weight or whatever, your character will continue its movement, and this could get very annoying, specially on combat. If you are on PC try this: run to your right or left, and then press the key in the opposite direction: your character will slow down, stop dead for a second, then will turn towards the camera direction for a split second, and then it will run where you want to. This is extremely annoying and can't say the times I got killed because I went for cover, or wanted to avoid this fall or catch a ladder, etc.
Other games solves this by going into "combat" mode, where your input is favoured, instead of waiting for the animation to end. If there's Death Stranding 2, I think it could benefit from this.
Also, soothing BB, which is done on a regular basis, takes multiple key interactions
 [*] [b]Combat. [/b]
Where there's lots of weapon options, combat is clunky. Most of the weapons, if not all, are projectile based, even fire guns. [i]You can outrun bullets.[/i] That's super silly because you can't cover in those moments where the game forces you to combat, so, a valid approach is run side to side, so you don't get shot. And it goes both ways. Also, enemies can shoot you through tall grass, meaning you can not see them, but they will still shoot you.
Your cargo and your weapons are pretty much the same, so managing them is really clunky. And when your weapons are empty they stay on your back, which increases weight, which makes you tired/unstable. So you quickly get into a big issue. Why do I need to open a menu, go through my list of weapons, picking the one I want, press "drop" or "offload" and having to wait for the character to do the 'unload' animation? IN COMBAT? What's the reason to carry empty guns you can't get ammo for?
 [*] [b]Story.[/b]
[spoiler]The first ending, where the credits pops up, drags on and on and on. Come on, finish already![/spoiler]
I feel like they were afraid of the player not understanding, so they explained bits at any chance they could get. Over and over again. This takes away the mystery. The general rule would be to give the player A and B, so they can figure out C by themselves. In this game, a few interesting things should be explained more, but didn't happen.
Also, Higgs (the golden mask dude) is the most silly character I've ever met. Pretty much one-dimensional. No real purpose, no real sense of danger or urgency to defeat him.
[spoiler]Defeating some antagonists could get tiresome, because seems like you kill it/him for good, you are happy etc, then they reappear multiple times. This is bad, because you defeat it already and because gives a poor sense of accomplishment. "This thing will appear again, why do I even bother", was my thought at the time. And it did, for different characters.[/spoiler]
 [*] [b]BTs.[/b]
These are the most annoying enemies I've ever met, ever. Is not only them being invisible, but them catching you when you are being silent (yes, by walking, holding your breath, etc). I feel like they always get in the way, but in a very very frustrating, not fun way. If they grab you, they force you to do a mini-boss multiple times, and your cargo will be severely damaged. There's not a single approach, that could be reliable, to counter them. If you shoot them, they hear you. You can't out-run them.[spoiler]Cutting the umbilical cords works, but at that moment, chances of screwing things up are high.[/spoiler] All I wanted to do is deliver a package. They are time-wasters.
 [*] [b]Visual Interface[/b]
At first glance, animations for the UI seems fast and responsive, but between interactions, these millisecond of moving/fading, etc they all add up. Also, a few interactions requires unneeded extra steps (like recycling items from shared containers). In your private room, instead of moving your character to interact, you need to wait for the camera to fly to where you want. Is not nit picking: in 50 hs of gameplay, all of these add up, trust me. You'll end up clicking "skip" like a mad man.
Also, is really hard to see your markers when you are in snowy areas. White against white is quite impossible to see.
 [*] [b]World[/b]
The world looks like one of these tech demos you download from the NVIDIA page, to see what your new fancy card is capable of. Is mountains here, terrain there, a stream of water there, more grass, less grass. and that's it.
[/list]


[h1] Pros [/h1] 
[list]
[*] While perhaps repetitive, [b]delivering packages feels rewarding.[/b] It gives you a sense of purpose for yourself and makes you care about what you actually delivering. They took their time to let the player know why certain packages are important. That's great.
[*] [b]Immersion is great.[/b] Is you versus the world itself, and MULES and BTs are another layer on top. Preparing yourself for terrain challenges and actually conquering them, gives you a feeling no other game will give you. Is really that rewarding.
[*] [b]Everything surrounding BB is fantastic.[/b] Specially Mads Mikkelsen.
[*] Knowing that you can connect with other players, and using their structures feels fantastic, in different layers. On a emotional level, knowing they are helping to create a path so they got your back, and on a gameplay level they are incredibly useful.
[*] Animation is top notch. You won't find a better animation technology and acting like this, in a video game, for probably years (except for Naugthy Dog games, of course).
[*] While walking through that black tar is awful, the buildings/car/structures coming in and out of it, are great. Really cool concept. Also, water technology is probably the best in the industry. Fluids are incredibly well done.
[*] Raiding MULE bases and the melee system is quite fun.
[/list]

My suggestion for anyone who's interested in this game is [b]wait for it to be on sale, play it a bit and see if you like it.[/b] This is one of these games that looks boring on gameplay videos, but the experience is different if you play it yourself.

So, there you have it. Why my recommended review them? Because I want more games like this. They took a high risk and it does pay off in certain areas. [b]We need more games like this to push the medium forward, onto new ideas and unexplored territories.[/b] Ventures like this will always get my thumbs up.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: amazing game, truly an experience no other game has given me

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: A masterpiece. Very immersive and unique game. Soundtracks are absolutely amazing. If you are PVP players do not bother with this game though. It is refreshing to see new genres of game like that. One of the best games in 2020.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It has combat.
It has graphics.
It has psychological thrills (not jump scares, unless you include the cosplayer)

This is a one-of-a-kind game, tailored to keep you guessing until the very end.
Worth every penny.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Prettiest movie I've ever played.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A wonderfully well-crafted experience. The story and lore of the game are fascinating, and the gameplay is an excellent exercise in self-improvement, perseverance, and incremental progression. You get a real sense of connection to the characters, and to all of the fellow players who help you along the way.

Early game can be brutal, delivering through enemy territory, with no equipment, no shelter, across jagged rocky terrain, all the while being chased by ghosts. The game drip feeds you a large variety of new tools, gear, weapons, and vehicles to help you overcome obstacles in the world and overcome the world itself. The strategy is all in managing encumbrance and preparing the right equipment to complete your deliveries. 

You will spend time building up infrastructure in areas to help you navigate and avoid hazards, maintaining old infrastructure, creating paths that make traversal more easy, and clearing out bandit camps, all to deliver an old man 500 pairs of high-performance underpants.

The game is visually stunning. There are some great moments of solitude while walking around alone in the beautifully-crafted world. Cutscenes are very cinematic and I never felt bored watching them. 

You can pee on ghosts and throw your poop at terrorists. 10/10.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Honestly not my cup of tea, was a complete waste of money. If you are interested in being a single parent while having no traction as you walk down a mountain as you breast feed with black ghouls chasing you... Wait... you don't even get a gun instead you have to make the baby stop crying and hide like a homeless man running from his dealer.... 0/10.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: masterpiece

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: One of a kind.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Probbably the most original and creative game i've ever played

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Keep On Keeping On!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Ever wanted Truck Simulator but like...made by Kojima? This is it. God damn this game is good.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I was on the fence about trying this but I'm so glad I did. The gameplay is really meditative, the story is great and the online aspects make you feel genuinely connected to other players. It's refreshing to play a game and actually feel like I'm playing something entirely new rather than just another re-skin.

update: after playing for 40 hours I'm ready for this to be over... it was enjoyable and interesting to begin with but it's firmly over-stayed it's welcome.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: 5/10: Dork strolling costs so much coz they have to pay the actors fees and pentions. The devs are having great laughs messing with us, with this game, unless it was ment for kids.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: People in the future will be playing this game and calling it the "Life in 2020 Simulator"

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The Story Line is very good, it is like as you play a game and at the same time watch a movie of Death Stranding which is the main character is yourself. I hope there will be next new episode of Death Stranding.

Really like the game difficulty for normal level, not so hard, not so easy. If you like more challenging, than you can increase the level of difficulty in the game option.

If this game can be improve on how the weather changes occur in the game, it would be nice, as example, you know in front of you the weather is raining by looking at it, not the weather changes when you come into the area. This is more realistic and appreciate it if can be done on next chapter or in feature game.

I don't mine if there is chapter continued by DLC, I would buy it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Amazing.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The controls are difficult to get used to. They're too different from other games as far as button mapping is concerned. It's also too easy to get lost in trying to figure out what to do next.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The joke is that this game is a walking simulator... and it is, but that's only a small part of it.  It has an engaging storyline, and there's a certain relaxation to it, to travelling the desolate landscape and bringing people things they need to make their life, and the world better.  If you're looking for a looter-shooter, this ain't it.  Its a challenge, but in a different way.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is probably the 80th time you've seen this, but I really wanted to like this game. There are parts that I really like and parts that I really don't. Some of this you'll really agree with and other parts you'll just want to punch me for if you've played the game. I'm going to start with the old sandwich model of structuring with good, bad, then good again at the end to lighten the blow a bit. Fair warning for those who haven't played the game I will be including light spoilers for a section of the game that's not the main story, but nevertheless the game makes you go through it.

Pros:
_I love the delivery sim and navigating some of the obstacles they really make you think hard about how you are supposed to stack things on your pack (until 16 hours in you notice there's an auto stack and spam that fucker like no one's business) while traversing this unusually rocky ground.

_I found myself sinking what felt like hours and hours into making deliveries that were (at first) really cool because they genuinely got my adrenaline going and reminded me of my favorite game in the whole world, Subnautica. The BTs are there and they're doing their own thing and you can avoid them if you play your cards right and manage your distance properly. They feel the right amount of fair, but difficult and something that you can learn how to get around with a bit of knowledge. More about this later.

_There seems to be a B plot with the BB that Sam carries around between the baby and its father. And it's alright when it's actually telling a story, but eventually it felt like it was repeating the same scenes over and over. So I just started skipping it.

I kind of left this part out of my introduction, but every one of the pros has an asterisk of *until it's not. So here's the asterisks. Also this is the section with the most spoilers.

Cons:
_The delivery sim never changes. There's progress made, but the three times I moved to a new area they reset my progress. I started with a bike then I went across a lake and they gave me the ability to build a bike out of materials then they took that away and I had to steal a truck from the MULES, but that can't be housed in the garage, which repairs your vehicles (that take damage over time due to the timefall rain, which rapidly ages things). Instead of increasing difficulty naturally they just take your progress away, and that's the most infuriating thing for me in games. It's actually why I quit playing.

_Every story in this game is so melodramatic. I saw a commercial for this game when it was first being promoted where this big city was underwater and it looked interesting then the water drains and you see it going up the stairs and back into this apartment. Inside there's a dude crying at how emotional the game is. This is peak melodrama folks. There's a story in this game where this random couple (early to mid 20s) is separated by the attack on middle knot city. She (an asian woman with some asian accent I'm not that knowledgeable about where specifically) went with her European descended mom with no accent whatsoever who told her daughter that the daughter's boyfriend was dead. Your mission is to get the boyfriend's help with your missions. He hates your guts because of the Bridges Company's lack of anything to do with what was going on or the aftermath, but he says if you can find my girl (I thought he meant his daughter because the asian woman appears really young in the holograms he shows) then I'll help. So you go do a mission for him while Bridges searches for the woman. You find where she is and you have to go get her and her back in the least interesting series of cutscenes I think I've ever seen. They expected me to care about these people and their situation when I couldn't remember their names, I don't think the mom even has a name. It was played up as the happiest moment in the world, but zero buildup. I didn't know who these people were and what's more I didn't care.

_The BTs were enemies that were interesting and slowed your progress until you got your handle on them a few hours in, but the game started using them as a roadblock anytime it didn't want you to do something. There's a point where you find a dead motorcycle on the side of the road that belonged to one of the NPCs. He says if you can get it charged you can take it. So I did. Immediately after they put in a section where you encounter the biggest set of BTs you've encountered in the game so far in the craggiest parts of the game yet. My natural reaction was to gun it through them. Huge mistake. If you bring a vehicle in these areas every BT in a few feet will land and start to chase you down which will result in you being dragged in front of the whale BT to try and escape. This is made little more than a nuisance by the time you start to get weapons. So the enemies go from admittedly terrifying to the literal reason I dislike this game. At one point I lost my cool on a stream (https://youtu.be/Jkff_jrr_cc If you care to watch my reaction in person) after encountering two BTs in a row on the same path.

_Every bit of the BB storyline is just boring. You start off meeting his dad and you seem to have some sort of working relationship with the guy and he dies to your first voidout, death, which you can come back from. Every so often you will leave your private room and a scene will play of the BB and his father, but it's shot from the same angle every time and there's always this pod with the mother in it. The dad always talks about how much he loves his wife and wants to bring her out of the (coma? I think because the BB needs a live womb sync back up with to level out after getting stressed) condition she's in. He dances and sings and I'm guessing you're supposed to feel some type of way about this, but I felt nothing because he's dead in the first hour. I never knew the guy, Sam did, but we didn't know much about the dude.

_There's a scene where the deuteragonist, Fragile, is stripped down to her underwear (white tank top and white panties) and made to walk through the rain. I get the story significance of that and you can definitely do that type of scene well. In this case I don't feel it was used a bad thing to do in this story. They are trying to set up the bad guy as the bad guy. But I felt the game lingered uncomfortably on her body in certain areas. The ones generally used for fan service. I'm all for fan service, but there's a place for it. At this spot in the story the woman is completely being dominated and forced to be in a vulnerable position by the closest thing to a god this story has setup as of now. Giving me fan service isn't what I need now. It counterbalances the message of the scene. Am I supposed to be horrified or aroused by this? This made me quit playing the game after that cut scene and delete it from my computer.

Conclusion:
There is a lot to like about this game. It really has some great aspects and when the story is good it's great. I liked the voice acting everyone seemed to be on point. The character models seemed to move like a real person would other than a few graphical glitches, which could be explained by a less than optimized PC port. I while I was engaged it was a great game to experience, just had more than a few issues that made me not like it. I definitely see why other people love the game, but It's just not my bag man. If you've stuck it out this long thanks for reading you're a genuinely awesome person for giving me your attention for a few moments. Keep being awesome.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game, oh man oh man, I knew going in this game wasn't going to have much action but god damn it takes a few hours to get to the first fight, then another 15 hours or so to get to the next one. At the time of writing this it says 24 hours but it has been far more(don't know why some games' timers stop/glitch). Don't buy it, the people saying it's a masterpiece are lying, the story is as mundane as it gets. Oh but don't worry "SaM wE hAvE aNoThEr DeLiVeRy fOR YoU, cHeCk ThE tErMiNaL wHeN yOu GeT a ChAnCe". All there was left was for Preston to come out and say another settlement needs my help.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The world in Death Stranding will pull you in if you let it. Kojima's fingerprints are all over the complex lore that builds the foundation of the game. What is essentially a UPS simulator becomes a journey to understand the cosmic significance of death, and I love it for that. The gameplay loop of making deliveries and taking on new orders becomes more and more satisfying as you reconnect the world. It becomes easier and easier to traverse unforgiving landscapes thanks to utilities, vehicles, and the amazing zip-line. It really gives you a feeling of earned power. I can't recommend this game enough.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game reminds me of what it felt like to play the pokemon games as a kid. Everything feels huge, and the game feels like it goes on forever. It's a dream.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's hard for me to push thumbs down on this game, because in some way it is brilliant but then in others it is so  abysmally bad that all the brilliant parts are overshadowed.

Yes, it is a Kojima oddity, and I knew that going in. Yes, it is a walking simulator (and later riding simulator and trucking simulator) and the story is propelled almost exclusively by the player completing fetch quests. 

Technically Death Stranding is brilliant. On highest specs, the environment is so beautiful that it makes even Red Dead Redemption 2 look a bit dated. Gameplay mechanics work very well when you are traveling on foot - Sam Porter Bridges isn't a superman, he moves like a normal human would while burdened by a stack of boxes on his back. You NEED to consider the terrain you are crossing, and the obstacles in your path, and the creatures and characters that seek to stop you.

The setting is typical Kojima, and it lays on weird and spooky very heavily and very quickly. For the first hour or so, you will very much wonder just what the hell is going on; when the game's monsters, the BTs, make their first showing, it is quite  suspenseful and terrifying. And then comes the first stumble: a rapid-fire exposition dump from the second NPC you meet in person. It does a decent job giving you an overall idea of the setting you are in, but it is delivered rather awkwardly, and is symptomatic of what's to come. 

After the game gets in gear in subsequent chapters, for a while it maintains the spooky atmosphere. The BTs are a force of nature that cannot be fought, they can only be detected and avoided, and you feel like a proper BIG DAMN HERO for daring to cross the areas infested with them to deliver the supplies to the needy when everyone else cowers in shelters. Unfortunately, this does not last: the game quickly hands you weapons that allow you first to disperse the monsters, and then to kill them outright. By the time you cross into the second area, the terrifying force of nature becomes first an annoyance, and shortly after a prey to be hunted and farmed for a certain type of resource.

Which brings me to one of the worst mechanics ever invented in a game. In order to detect the BTs and make them visible, you are given the infamous "baby in a jar" that is seen in the trailers. This constant companion is invaluable for keeping yourself alive and out of trouble. However, it behaves exactly as a baby would. That is, it cries, whines, and cries some more. Stumble and take a fall, and it whines. Take a punch in a fight, and it bawls. Get close enough to a monster, which is necessary at times, and - you guessed it - it cries. It's a source of constant annoyance that pops up at the worst possible time and it is about as easy to ignore as nails on a chalkboard (ain't biology fun?). According to the story, your character gradually bonds with the baby and begins to view it as more than just a piece of equipment, but in reality, I wanted nothing more than to be rid of it.

The other major problem with the game and perhaps the main reason for the thumbs-down is the way the story is handled. It is very easy to get lost in deliveries, improving relationships with the inhabitants of the map, and building stuff. But eventually you need to move the story along, and it happens in the form of "take this VERY SPECIAL box to this one shelter, and be rewarded with a feature-length cutscene where an NPC spouts exposition at you and your character nods along." It all culminates in a massive infodump at the end, where through multiple sequential cutscenes all questions are answered, all i's are dotted and all t's are crossed. Overall, the story is very weird, heavy on metaphor and absolutely fascinating - I would expect no less from Kojima - but the presentation via one massive endgame infodump was exhausting and spoiled the impression. It didn't help that after what FELT like the final boss fight of the game (and was emotionally satisfying) the game decided to throw a sequence of boss fights at you afterwards, culminating with a colossal monster that put the original "final boss" to utter shame. It served no purpose other than just to be there and present one final speed bump before the endgame exposition vomit began.

To sum it up, Death Stranding is brilliant in both technical execution and the story, but it is HOW the story is presented that severely undermines the entire thing. That, and the damn crying baby. Even if you didn't hate children before, I'm pretty certain Death Stranding will make you hate them.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This was an unexpected treat, after hearing mixed reviews, (Both incredibly positive and blisteringly negative that is), I finally decided to break down and buy the game, and the game can be miserable at times, I wont lie, BTs and Mules that refuse to give up the chase, and BB that for some reason just cant stay mentally healthy.  But as the game progresses, and you not only uncover more of the story, but you are able to figure out just what kind of courier you want to be, and what kind of bridges you want to make.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[b] WAIT UNTIL THIS IS SUFFICIENTLY PATCHED OR ON STEEP SALE. ETA - PROBABLY 1.5+ YEARS [/b]

I'll start by saying I recommend the game itself. It's a relaxing walk sim made by an artsy Kojima you can slap on when you look at your library and go "I don't have anything to play".

 The program the game runs on, however, I do not recommend at all.

People with high-spec systems are stuck at <60 fps. The game will freeze and crash if you test it even a little bit. It's no exaggeration when I say 10-15 out of the 40 hours of my time has been lost due to crashes. Saving frequently is required.

I'd say it's worth, in its current state, about $30. When drunk, $45.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Satisfying delivery simulator in the apocalypse with an epic story

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Does the sound of travelling across a rugged, hostile, and ultimately gorgeous American landscape to connect various people and locations to an expanding network sound interesting to you? Do you often fantasize about getting lost in a Hideo Kojima inspired nightmare? If you answered "yes" to either of those questions, you will probably find enough here to enjoy despite the flaws. In short, this is a walking/delivery simulator posing as Art (with a capital "A"), full of self-important storytelling and melancholic characters crying lamentations and lullabies about death and extinction (for a game as experimental as Death Stranding is when it comes to the gameplay, it's a shame the story itself is so dull). In the end, Death Stranding rewards patience and perseverance, while providing an open-world experience like no other.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Daryl Walking Simulator? Maybe. More like Metal Gear Amazon. You still get to kill some wily enemies but now you can also earn likes for helping players that you can't see! Make sense yet? Look, all you need where I'm at in the game is a bola, blood grenades, and leg supports. I don't know how it could get any cooler than this, so if you're still wondering if you'll like it, just buy it and set a two hour timer and hope that you get enough of a taste of the game in before then. Refund it then if you must. It's a Kojima game, so the reviews stating that there's too much story are probably from people not familiar with Kojima games and this is coming from someone who's only played Metal Gear Solid 4 (waaaay late to that party). It is in no way a bad game, not even close, but it could definitely not be to your taste.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: If you like Elite Dangerous, you'll easily like this too.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The game is written off by people saying it's a walking simulator and a boring delivery man game, but I say there's nothing wrong with challenging the conventions of what you expect a video game to be. Regardless of that, there is plenty of action and complex game mechanics that kept me playing this game longer than I expected. This game makes me feel like i'm part of a community that only wants the best for each other and to help out your fellow man. If you want a game you can play at your own pace with no pressure, with an engaging and creative narrative, then I would definitely recommend.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I didn't expect to like it that much but after 144 hours playtime.. it's brilliant! Playing in your own instance while giving you the opportunity to help every other player with the things you do is genius. A very very slow burner story that unfolds a chink at a time and mostly confuses more than enlightens along the way but keeps you wanting more,  then slaps you around the face in the last few hours.. well worth the time invested imo.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Beautiful game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
What a weird place to be in. I just finished one of my favorite games I've played to date in the last 5 years, and yet I couldn't recommend it to anyone I know without a ton of caveats. I found it fun to play, but I could see why it would be so easy to just be frustrated with the game play loop. The story/soundtrack/characters/world building, is fucking fantastic. But will you enjoy the whole 60 hours? I couldn't easily say. 

It's worth pointing out I played this in 2020, during covid-19 in NYC, where we arn't going out and America really really needs some re-building.

Roll the dice on this one at you own risk. Down the line when it's on sale, if you have the time to invest, I do suggest.

Also thanks Kojima. Damn.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is not a standard game. Though it may have the trappings of a Third Person Shooter, set in an open world, that is merely the cover of the book. What lies within that cover is a truly fascinating title. A game where the journey becomes the primary gameplay. Taking cues from Breath of the Wild, mountains can be scaled (with the right tools), rivers crossed, and the interplay of systems allow you to forge your own path through this Volcanic Permian Post-America.

The story is thoroughly twisted and cliche, but in the most wonderful ways. The way Hideo Kojima tells a story is like no other, and seeing his vision for this brand new IP is a delight. Every actor delivers their strange, film-inspired dialogue with true earnestness. The performances in this game (from the primary cast) are pitch perfect and pull you into the abstract structure of Kojima's mind.

This is easily one of the best performing titles I've ever played. The gorgeous graphics only dipped below 60fps during particular cut scenes. It is surely a glitch, as it would not happen upon reloading the same scene. 

Though you can play this game Offline, I would highly recommend playing while connected. Much like Dark Souls, this game provides a whole different experience online. However, it's best to experience all that this game can offer whilst connected.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This isn't a game for everyone, I would do a bit of research to see if this title is right for you.

But I love it, having a blast doing postal delivery while stuck indoors due to the global pandemic :)

Almost 100 hours and 100% on achievements, still like the game :)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The story is intriguing and is what kept me going, but the game play is very repetitive and the way the story is presented is also feels a bit in your face, with characters monologues going on for ages. In the end it felt like literally walking from one cut-scene to the next with the game being a nuisance in between. 
This was exasperated by the fact that there was also no real choice in your actions. You can decide how to bring the delivery from A to B, but none of that changes anything in the story and even when you know that something isn't a good idea you are forced to go through with it anyway, because it is the only way to progress the game.
While the story was interesting, the payoff at the end was not enough for me to really recommend the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Now that i have actualy completed the story of Death Stranding. Let me update my review.

A yes Death Stranding. The walking simulator. And either some very high quility sh*tpost. Or one of those DEEP things.
Now that i completed the story. And barly remembered any of it or understood any off it. Becus im a low IQ dumbbrain i must say it was......a interesting experience. One filled with a lot of tar. Walking and.....Very interesting dialoge... But i do like meny of the concepts. I find the beaches, BB's, BT's, Time fall, a lot of it quite interesting. Just a shame i do a lot of walking...or well driving between it all. but let me get to some main points

The Story : Like i said it's wierd. Not that that isen't to be expected. Basicaly this huge cataclysmic event happend that caused the dead to come to the world of the living and if the dead capture a live person and eat them it causes a explosion. and then there is this one super BT called a EE (extinction entity) who aperantly will cause a big bang.....and then there is this dumb mario and peach pun later on in the game that i still hate. its.....yea. I do somewhat like the caracters. tough. mainly higgs.

Gameplay : Like i said. its a walking simulator. Or a driving simulator depending on how mutch you like cars. Its all about bringing item 1 from A to B. Sometimes there is a timer. Sometimes you must not submerge the package in water, Sometimes its is even extra fragile so you have to carry it by hand, Sometimes its a pizza that you must only carry horizontaly on you backpack or else it gets destroyed (And if you do the pizza delievery missions without putting the Spiderman pizza time theme in the background troughout the entire delivery YOU ARE DOING THE ENTIRE DELIVERY VERY WRONG) So there is some veriaty in the delievery missions. You can also build a lot of structures to make delivering easyer like roads. zip lines. generators to recharge your exo legs and trucks. all that jaz. + You don't just have to do missions to deliver packages. You can just find lost packages dotted around the place. There is also the Time fall. witch rapadly ages anything it comes into contact with. including your buildings and packages. if the package gets to aged. And you get a exidental bump. Or fall of a cliff. It will rilly damage the item inside it. so carefull of time fall. Take some Cargo repair sprays or hang out under a Time fall shelter. 
 
MULE Combat : combat is Probably the weakest part of Death stranding imo. Lets first talk about MULE combat. MULEs are some of the random terrorists you find around the place. There are 2 types. The ones with pocky shock sticks that only wan't your cargo. They can moostly do only melee combat. And there sticks do nothing but lower your conciousness meter. And you can for the most part just drive past em. But these guys have a mean throwing arm. And if the stick they trew hits your car. It will make it undrivable for a couple seconds. Then there is the big MULEs. the actualy big terrorists. These guys juse guns. thats pretty mutch the main diffrence. and melee combat is not the best idea so get a gun. SPEAKING OF GUNS. HERE IS THE RILLY DUMB PART ABOUT COMBAT. In the world of Death Stranding. Dead people have this thing called ''Going neckro'' Witch means there body is about to turn into a BT. And becus of that. You have to haul any bodys you make to a incinerator. Now i have never killed anyone. and even if i did it was jusualy only one that i had to bring to the incinerator. So idk what happens if you just leave a body to go neckro. But for all ik. Its a insta game over. So do yourself a favor and just juse non-lethal weapons and watch out that you don't run anyone over. Saves a lot of trouble

BT combat : 2 Sides on this coin. One is stealth and avoid. The other is fighting. You will jusualy find BT terriroty in Time fall zones. If you are in a car/on a bike. it will stop for a view seconds When your rilly close to the BT zone. If you get closer. You get stopped agian for your BB to activate the wierd detector on your shoulder and spot the BT's. So. BT stealth. plain and simple. Watch your scanner and avoid where its pointing at. If you get to close to a BT. press and hold ALT or whatever button you juse on controller to hold your breath. If you have succesfully avoided all BTs and exited the BT zone. BB will make the scanner give you a thumbs up or wave the BTs goodbye. 
Now for BT combat. You juse special weapons and ammo for this called hematic grenades/ammo. There is also the EX grenades from 0-2 Witch are Sams shower water, pee, and shit. but i never jused those. Hematic grenades and rounds juse up Sams blood. Becus Sam is infected with DOOMs and a repatriate or something. His blood has damaging effects on BTs. Becus of this. The special Hematic grenades and rounds where created. When you trow/shoot them. They drain your health. If you have blood bags on you. They drain those first instead. Normal BTs are generaly easy to kill. dying jusualy from just one hematic grenade. There is also a special upgrade you get to your com link later in the game. A chiral crystal knife or something along those lines. You sneak up to a BT and cut of there ambilical cords. Releasing them back to the land of the dead. dusent have mutch juse in combat tough. But. If BT's manage to catch you. They will drag you over to the BT mini boss's main arena

the bosses have a special arena. its a massive tar lake that slows you down. however. random buildings and cars will emerge from this lake. Giving you places you can climb on and hide from the boss. You can also skip the intire fight by exiting the tar lake radius. There will also be random Sam ghost that apear (specters of other players) Who will trow you extra gear to defeat the boss. If you defeat the boss. The tar lake disapears. The time fall stops pooring down. And left over BT's disapear. making the area completely save to loot. But. the BT precense can quickly return

Driving : cars and motorbikes. In all honesty. cars......kinda suck imo. Ik there kinda supposed to be not all that viable. Becus in a game about delivering it may make em super OP. But i...I rilly don't know about em. Sometimes they respond just fine but other times they just either respond to mutch to my imputs. Or to little. And don't try to skyrim pysicks up a mountain with them. I have done many a time and oooooh boy. Cars and mountains don't get along. Also. Despite most of the land bing a rocky wasteland. Cars have a habit of getting stuck on rock formations....Rocks are there Achilles heel. Bikes are a bit more resistend to getting stuck on rocks and going up mountains. But i feel like they controll worse. Idk.

So thats death stranding. or etleest how mutch i care to tell about it. Me? I somewhat like it. A game i can play when i have nothing better to do. Or just had a bad day and wanne look at some nice scenery. You? Well. If like me your looking for a game to play when you need to be calmed. go for it. If your looking for anything else that Isen't a walking sim with a wierd story. Look somewhere else

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Absolutely loved it! The gameplay was highly addicting for me, and in Kojima fashion the cutscenes/story was masterfully made. Mads Mikkelsen didnt get that award for nothing.
Pros:
- Amazing acting and characters
- Addicting gameplay
- Great OST (happily its up on Spotify)
- Looks breathtaking (especially if you got the hardver for it) 
- Gripping story
- Great and fun to watch cutscenes (can be a con if you're not used to/dont like long cutscenes. They can always be skipped tho.)
Cons:
- Bulletsponge bossfights
- Motorcycle moves terribly on any kind of terrain that isnt 100% smooth
- Sam's physics can be odd sometimes. This is mostly frustrating if that makes you fall from a high place
- Around mid-game I got Access Violation crashes from time to time which were depending on circumstances were really infuriating. Some people have them, some dont. Could be in my case cuz I was really pushing my pc to its limits to run the game well.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's a different kind of game. Kojima-style story (but not so over the top as Metal Gear), long cutscenes, and a very cinematic approach to storytelling. Situations and actions in-game add to the  interconnectedness of the story, characters and most importantly, players.

 The challenge of walking to 'that hill over there', the challenge of carrying too much weight. Of coming back through that rocky mountain or that bandit-infested zone.

 I wouldn't call it a masterpiece but it's very interesting author piece; both as a game and as a storytelling medium. Must play.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
播片有点好看，但游戏体验真的极差。。。。。
大家修路送快递方面的想法真的很不错，从东边连到西边最后一章从城里出来看到满地的告示牌搭上BB‘s Theme真的鸡皮疙瘩都出来了，小岛选歌他一直可以的。播片丝滑，拔叔每次上场都湿了，剧情总体来说还可以。（但中规中矩，讲了个不错的故事）
一切都被拉稀的叙事框架和跑路体验整塌了，开车在泥地跑的体验简直就是拉稀，过场和快递的比例分配也是拉稀，整个剧情节奏乱成一锅粥，2小时快递2小时片，冥滩部分就一迷惑行为大赏，战斗部分更是浪费时间，全部的boss战都是泼水流，游戏体验和播片分配彻底拉跨把整个游戏水准拉低了。。。。
个人综合起来感觉7/10不能再多了(但推荐），不能说全都不如MGSV，但这几个短板跟MGSV比简直不是一个次元的。
所以小岛什么时候拍电影，到时候肯定支持

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: We never understood this game until COVID hit us

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Copy pasta from Steam review

Have you ever heard the phrase, as wide as an ocean but as deep as a puddle? You could describe No Mans Sky like that. It's got millions of planets to explore but there is nothing to do when there. I feel like Death Stranding is the opposite. When looking at trailers or gameplay, it looks so simple. You take packages from here to there. You are a post-apocalyptic Amazon delivery dude. And while that's a decent summary, the gameplay is so much more engaging than it sounds. There are systems that feed off of everything you do. And the story, my god. Who thinks of this shiz?

GAMEPLAY is deeper than you think. For instance, taking a package from point A to point B sounds simple. First you'll want to auto sort your packages for better weight distribution otherwise you are going to fall... a lot. During your journey you will constantly be surveying the land to find the safest route through the rough terrain. When turning with a lot of cargo you with have to actively shift your weight with left and right triggers or mouse buttons. The world is full of environmental puzzles like; Coming upon a river that you don't want to deal with? Plop a ladder down to cross it faster. There's a ravine stopping you from moving forward? Construct a bridge to get your vehicle across (yes you will unlock vehicles but there is no perfect way to traverse. Some terrain requires you to travel caveman style). Oh but wait, during your travel you have to pass though MULE (people who want your stuff) territory, so now you need to either fight them head on or stealth your way around them. Adding to your journeys already thoughtful execution are delivery objectives. Such as delivery time, package condition, package orientation, or so much cargo you need a vehicle to help carry it all. There are so many systems feeding off one another that one journey can become a bit of a strategy game. Don't worry, after a couple missions everything starts to flow so well together that planning becomes second nature and doesn't stretch into tedious or daunting territory. Each delivery is an adventure worth taking.

STORY is weird af. It's way more cohesive than MGS in my opinion. This really feels like a passion project that Hideo had thought about quite a bit. And with seemingly no interference from publishers or anyone else , it's a miracle this game even exists. Still mothers, babies linked to another dimension through their dead mom, tar people, time altering rain, nukes caused from dead people, giant lovecraftian monsters than eat people, crystal hands growing out of the ground that power electronics. Who thinks of this stuff but also makes a somewhat cohesive story out of it. AND WHO FUNDS THIS? Either way, I'm genuinely happy it exists. This has been some of the best gaming experiences I've had in a while.

PERFORMANCE. Everyone's system is different. MY PERSONAL EXPERIENCE with Death Stranding has been very good. I have an AMD (8core-16thread) r7 1700, 32gb of ram and a gtx 1080ti. I play at 1440p and I'm getting over 60fps 90% of the time. Some dips below that and it's 100% my CPU's fault. The 1700 does not have great single core performance and IPC so I think that's letting me down. If you have an i7 3770k or higher, you should probably be fine. But I haven't tested that. It's just a guess. The game uses about 7-8 cores. And would probably benefit from 16gb of system ram. 505 did a great job porting it. I do wish we had more graphics options though. But this game already looks stunning.

THIS GAME IS GORGEOUS. Everything about it screams quality. Most of the scenery is photo-realistic. The human models are also fantastic but the facial animations leave some room for improvement. Sometimes emotions don't shown enough through the performances. A little stiff looking. When moving through the world there are contextual animations for so many things like stumbling, walking over rocks, pushing grass away as you move through it. It's all beautiful and smoothly blends between one another. And it runs really well while being a graphics power house. Only complaint is Anisotropic Filtering will not go above what looks like x4. Others can get x16 AF. Mine might be bugged. But that's my only real complaint. Most everything in the game is high quality assets.

OVERALL. I suggest trying this game. Very unique gameplay with some fantastic graphics and world building.

UPDATE: Finished the game. Everything above still stands. BUT this game suffers from horrible game direction towards the end of the game. The story is told to you multiple times over the span of playing the game with it recapping everything you just learned 2 times in the last 4 hours of the game. It's insulting and annoying. During that time your gameplay options are EXTREMELY limited adding to the frustration. Brings my overall score of the game from an 9/10 right before the last 4 hours, to a final 7/10 for that garbage ending. Story was good. Ending was not.
