title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] DEATH STRANDING [/h1]
This review will contain ZERO spoilers for DEATH STRANDING, this is a review for players who are thinking about buything DEATH STRANDING.

This game is one of the kind, a game with an experience that you have never witness before. Both the gameplay and the story is something new no game has never done before. The main characters in this game are also complety unique and loveable. The game is almost perfect but sadly it has a BIG problem, the gameplay.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
I and many others are not a fan of the gameplay, the controlls are extremly weird and also extremly frustrating. The gameplay is EXTREMLY repetitive, all you do is go from point A to point B. There are problems on the way such as BTS (Ghosts) and Mules (Bandits that steal your cargos) however these two enemies doesn't make the game funnier but instead they are just extremly frustating. The combat system in this game is dumb and I would just recommand running away from the Mules because it's simply not fun to fight in this game. The BTS are dead people or ghosts that you can't kill early in the game so instead you just sneak past them in hope of them not noticing you, fun and scary the first three times but after the thirtieth time it's not fun anymore and instead just a frustating way to make the game slower and harder.

While you're playing you will notice that your character Sam will start to trip every second. You can prevent this from happneing by simply clicking right, left or both clicks on your mouse. Although I only fell around seven times in my 60 hours playthough, repeatly clicking on left and right click is extremly annoying and it almost pervents you from enjoying the beautiful world in DEATH STRANDING. And if you're to fall then your cargos will be damaged which makes everyone extremly pissed of because the more damaged your cargos are, the worse grade/reward you will get. Something else that is a big problem just like the tripping one are the climbing mechanics in the game. It's extremly broken and not enjoyable, they tried to do something that Legend of Zelda Breath of the Wild did but sadly failed.

You will learn early in the game that you can drive vehicles, driving these vehicles are almost complety impossible and extremly frustrating. No matter where on the map you're driving, you will probably end up driving into someone every tenth second and although crashing with vechicles can be fun in some games, it's not fun in this game. The whole driving mechanics is just extremly unenjoyable and complety ruins the flow. You will get updates for the vechicles futher in the game but this isn't fixing the problem. You also have to worry about the fuel in the vechicles which I can see why they added but I personally isn't a fan of it.

I know it says on steam that this game is single-player however there are other Porters in the game that can build structures such as bridges or ladders for you which will make it easier for you on your path. By thanking them for the help you can give them a like. Although the likes doesn't do much it's still fun to grind likes and help other people, DEATH STRANDING simply have their own social media which is a really cool and fun idea.

Although walking around on you feet all the time can be extremly boring over time atleast you're not often visting old places and are almost always heading forwards new beautiful environments. Walking though this beautiful world is truly magical and are probably the highlights of the gameplay. DEATH STRANDING also have PLENTY of amazing songs made for this game and listening to these songs while climbing the beautiful mountains really feels amazing. Hideo Kojima is really a genius for this.

The game always gives you new weapons, tools, clothes and updates to old mechanics  which really makes the gameplay less repetitive. Some of these new items you get futher into the game also makes the gameplay a lot more easy and less frustrating. Finishing these game without these updates would simply not be possible.

[h1] Story [/h1]
I can not say much about the story because this is a spoiler free review however I will talk about things you learn early in the game that wouldn't be seen as spoiler but instead as your goals. Something else I can say is that the story is AMAZING, ALMOST PERFECT! The gameplay may be a big problem however the story and the characters in this game really makes up for it. The beginning and ending when the game focus more on the story and not as much of the gameplay is magical and you can't stop youself to loving the game while playing though these parts. The game as a lot of plot twists can that be confusing but other than that the story parts are almost perfects and I doesn't have much to complain about that.

Your goal as Sam Porter Bridges is to rebuild the nation America by going into every state and reconnecting the chiral network, inviting them to Bridges which is a company that was formed to reconnect the fractured society of United States of America.

Every character you meet in this game has their own story, it could be all from losing family members to getting betrayed by their group. It's really worth listening to these stories and every character has their unique story and their unique powers. Sometimes you can feel that the game could be a really good movie.

[h1] Worth Buying? [/h1]
This isn't a game for everyone and if you can't handle boring or repeative games and like action games that this probably isn't a game for you. If you're a person that enjoy a good story game that this is probably a game for you. I personally enjoyed the game.

Is it worth buying the game? Yes, if you have the money and have the feeling that you wanna play a good story game and I think you should buy it, just expect that you're gonna go though a 40-60 hours journey.

Rating of the game? I will give the game a 7.5/10, the gameplay is a complete mess with not many positive sides however everything else with the game is amazing and it mostly makes up for it. The game also has a complete new experience which is always fun to witness.

"Being a father... didn't make me scared. It made me brave."

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I love this game.

The mechanics and gameplay that is.

As someone who greatly enjoyed Euro Truck Simulator and Elite: Dangerous, I love the games where you can sit back, relax, avoid some dangerous areas, and enjoy the scenery while listening to some nice music. The soundtrack, both the original score and the licensed music, are amazing. music player when. The environment and ambiance throughout the parts where I have reached we're stunning to look at. The walking mechanics (that's new to me) are clearly the most realistic, yet easy to grasp, that I've ever seen.

However, i'm not able to enjoy this game because every 20-30 minutes, if i'm lucky, an hour, I get either a bluescreen, or a crash. Every fix that I tried on the official 505 website did not work or did not apply to me, and even the steam support forums and Reddit didn't prove very useful. I was able to solve one crash related to DSLL, however another appeared in it's place. It's not related to graphics card or CPU temperatures, or even RAM and SSD temperatures.

Specs:
ASUS ROG STRIX B450-F
AMD Ryzen 2700X @3.7GHz
Gigabyte RTX 2060 (5GB)
G.Skill Trident Z 32GB-3200MHz (4x8) (clocked 2866 because of CPU)

It's unique, it's beautiful, it's relaxing, it's deep, and it's contemplative. It is not "fun," though. The pacing is extremely slow most of the time, and then there are surprise boss battles that do not coincide with the rest of the gameplay at all. There is a certain mood that justifies playing Death Stranding, and for me, it's a rare one. Nonetheless, I do not regret pre-ordering the game, and I think more people should play it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]I Walked So You Could Run[/h1]

[i]A glorified fetch quest post-apocalyptic open world straying off the beaten path[/i]

[h1]What I Like:- [/h1]
[list]
[*]Intricate traversal game mechanics which highly engaging in the world's complex terrain
[*]Variety of tools at your disposal to strategically complete delivery trips in your own way
[*]Unique inventory micromanagement system complements the decision making for trips
[*]Kojima's delicate craftsmanship of DS world building with high discipline making it feel believable and immersive
[*]Asynchronous multiplayer social system making the world feel organic, natural & relatable
[*]Wonderful overall visuals while also being highly optimized especially with DLSS 2.0
[*]Weird & believable cast of characters with memorable moments throughout the game
[*]Amazing songs & soundtracks during beautiful journey moments with also a thrilling suspense for BT encounter
[*]Semi-addicting sound effects providing some good ol' Oxytocin to the brain
[/list]

[h1]What I Dislike:- [/h1]
[list]
[*]Despite the whole gameplay mechanics resolve around player agency/decision making, none of it being offered at all during story moments
[*]After the first few deliveries for preppers, their dialog felt generic, was excited I got to deliver a Sony Playstation System but without any customized dialogs
[*]BT encounters felt a tad bit scripted and hinders as an annoyance instead of horrifying
[*]Some uninspired bullet sponge BT Boss Fights later in the game
[/list]

[b]Final Verdict: [spoiler]8/10[/spoiler] [/b]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I must admit that Kojima really did blast it out of the park with this one. The story is absolutely amazing; labyrinthine and convoluted (as always), yet an absolute masterpiece when it all comes together. The way the story is told is simply flawless. As for the game-play, this interactive piece of art is clearly not for everyone. People who love cinematographic storytelling will love the game; tuning in to walk from A to B, carrying cargo and leaving items behind to aid others in their travels (just as they help you in yours later on in the game) is extremely satisfying. Knowing that you have facilitated the rough ways you have traversed for others is lovely.

If you don't mind a "walking simulator" to which you can hook up and disconnect your brain for a while, then this game is definitely for you, not only during the story, but after you beat it as well. Some segments of the game, like when you make it into new areas, will trigger music that will go along with a zoomed out shot of you traversing the new landscape; those parts of the game are the absolute best.

Later on in the game, vehicles will be unlocked, which takes me to my only issue: vehicle control. The way that the bike controls is absolutely unpolished and requires clear improvements. It really breaks the immersion by making the movements look unrealistic and abrupt (especially after getting a great deal of very detailed walking motions). Even at later stages, when vehicles might seem indispensable, I chose to walk; not only was it more fun for me, but it helped restore the aforementioned immersion that was mercilessly broken by the bike. 

TL;DR:
All in all, it is a lovely game, but clearly not for everyone. If there should exist any proof that video-games are pieces of art, is would be this. If you like to look at scenery, enjoy the feeling of progression and aiding other players in their travels, then consider buying this game. If you're a fan of Kojima's stories and his amazing plot twists, then don't hesitate. There is plenty to experience. If you are keen only on fast-paced games, then this is definitely not the pick for you, but still an experience that should be played, so I'd recommend to buy it on sale at a later date. Either way, this is irrefutable proof of how right it can go in the game industry when developers don't stick to the mainstream casual players, but to a certain type of people. The sells might be lesser, but the experience (for that smaller few) will be absolutely amazing and unforgettable. I believe Kojima wants to send a message, not only to the players, encouraging them to be more connected and compassionate, but to the industry and how it is possible to break out of the mainstream trends, worrying only about sales figures instead of content.

Takes some time to get used to, due to the fact that mr Kojima clearly wanted to make a game that does NOT revolve around killing stuff.. which we are so accustomed to! There are combat elements.. but they are not the focus, and again effort is made to refrain from killing but instead subduing or banishing. 

Give the game time as it starts slow.. but it just keeps on giving.. improving and growing and constantly throwing new bits n pieces at you. The story is a mindfuck but deep and thought provoking.. the graphics are amazing.. technically very polished. i play on steam controller with zero issues.

Its a special game... extremely well done, a masterpiece in its own right. Thankyou and hats off to Mr Kojima for really thinking out of the usual box and having the rep and balls to create something so different.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Reedus and the fetus: a tale of being tied to a crying baby. I really tried to like it. I really did. I stepped away a few times to try to regain perspective. First off, I will say that the concept was interesting and it really could have had potential. But really that's where it ends.

This game is more than a walking simulator, it's a crawling simulator. It's tedious. This could have been a game about the Rug Rats. The struggle to keep your balance and stay upright throughout the game is more of a curse than an additional layer. Oh and let's make a game where you have to drudge through tar pits. But wait, let's make them ethereal tar pits. 

The bottlenecks make you want to never progress through the lackluster plot. The death eaters are everywhere you expect them to be. The vehicles cannot travel to the locations you need them to.  You absolutely get a feeling of “here we go again”. Seriously, if anyone is a die hard fanboy of this game, I fear they are lying to themselves. The plot sucks. The plot sucks. Also the plot sucks. 

This game is not fun. I bought the game based on the fact that Reedus was in it. His character is a ghost of a player. Seriously. Its uninspiring. It reminds me of the Japanese concept of Seppuku. Seppuku was used voluntarily by samurai to die with honor rather than fall into the hands of their enemies. Except here there is no honor and you voluntarily have fallen on your enemies sword hoping for a swift death but let me reassure you, you will find none. So its actually nothing like Seppuku but more like Aokigahara (known as "the Suicide Forest"), because at least here, you are willingly torturing yourself for the low price of $60. $60 dollars you will never get back unless you never spend it. 

Here is the most stupid part of the game. If you crawl or walk slow and hold your breath, you can walk past the death eaters. Seriously, with all this technology that is a part of the plot of the game, no one would have thought to make a mask with a rebreather built in. dumb. Dumb dumb dumb dumb.

This game is a perfect example of how you see really good actors in a terrible movie. The plot sounds good. The script is ok. But the execution is terrible.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
So, steam just ate my 3 page detailed review and I am not going to retype it. This is my first and possibly only review here and it is more of a frustration vent and an obituary for the wasted $60. I am about three hours in. I might play for another hour or two and try to find some redeeming qualities in this game. After all, this is the first time in about a decade that I paid full price for an AAA title.

The good:

* Graphics are pretty good.
* The goo monsters are pretty scary.
* The dreamlike, illogical setting feels refreshingly original

The bad:

* The acting and the writing are abysmal. There  are stupid expositions, unnatural dialogues and nobody seems to behave like an actual living human.
* In the first two hours of the game, I had about 15-20 minutes of actual gameplay. The rest were cut scenes. If this game was not released on consoles before it came to PCs I would have thought it was an intentional trick to prevent Steam refunds.
* For a walking simulator, walking does not feel natural. Like the guy clutches his chest to catch his balance instead of spreading his hands out like every other human does. And apparently if you are climbing a steep hill with a heavy load and try to stop, inertia will keep you going for like half a dozen steps upwards. I wish I knew that when I was doing backpacking.
* The game UI/UX is abysmal. Like really, read a damn book on UI/UX design before you make your next game. I spent like 10-15 minutes trying to figure out why the guy drops the stupid briefcase after a couple of seconds. The game doesn't tell you anything, it just prompts that you can pick up the case and carry it in your right hand, your left hand or on your back. But turns out that if you carry it in either hand the guy will drop it. And nobody tells you why. The map interface is super cluttered and not helpful. Key assignments are weird. Even WASD doesn't behave like in every other game.
* For a game centered around carrying weight, carrying weight is weird and unnatural. The reason he drops the briefcase is because he doesn't like carrying things in one hand if he is not carrying things in his other hand. The two seconds delay gives you a chance to pick something else with your other hand. And you, the player, go like "Just carry the damn case, you idiot, you are a fully grown man who can kill zombies with his crossbow, but you are too chicken to carry 10 pound briefcase in your hand for a few minutes?!"

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is all about unity.  Working with fellow players and coming together to do things you can't [easily] do on your own.  Griefing is not possible and the way this is implemented is fantastic.  The game can be challenging at times, but the rewards for succeeding are great and each NPC story is a interesting and compelling.  That is the real winner here - a fantastic story line.  Probably the best I can remember in 40 years of game playing.  The story was deep, heart felt, emotional, and extremely well acted by cinematic greats.

The graphics are awesome.  The characters especially emote like few other games.  The characters look and act exactly like their real-world actor counterparts.  The environment is beautiful and challenging with varied landscapes and logistical problems to solve.  Even at the end of the game I was still in awe of the visuals.

There is no one way to solve a given problem although most quests are fairly linear and straight forward.  Solving the side quests can be equally important to the main line and all of them have interesting plots.  Some rewards provide special capabilities that become very useful towards the end of the game.  Hint - don't ignore Peter.

The only downside was the often whonky Xbox control on the PC.  It was at times hard to control the character which resulted in near death experiences.  Some combat situations were equally frustrating as the player character kept putting the weapon away instead of shooting it.  In this game, you learn to nudge the character instead of directing the character through the controls.  Vehicle control is also kind of difficult at times but all in all it was manageable. 

While the game can seem tedious at times, the last hour of the game is well worth it.  There is a sense of community not found in most other games and it is done very well.  The 7+ hours of cut scenes are all fantastic and the way the story is woven together will keep you flipping your opinions and conclusions until the very end.   If there was one game to buy, this would be it.  Absolutely 10 our of 10 for me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
There are a lot of Mixed opinions swirling around this game some consider it to be a masterpiece other say that you’re nothing more than a delivery boy the entirety of the game. 

With all these opinions put aside my clean-cut opinion about this game thus far not knowing what I was walking into is that it’s absolutely fascinating. From the start of the game I was drawn into the storyline wanting to figure out more of what was happening to the world and why it is the way it is. Aside from the story line driving me to progress in the game building structures to help other play became overwhelming exciting and sidetracked me so far for hours on end. I am currently about halfway through the game but have spent many hours just bettering the surrounding terrain to possibly help a fellow player.  I highly suggest playing this game if multiplayer experiences are the only reason you play games. This game also offers a lot of freedom as far as completing missions goes. You can really go about completing them any way you see fit leaving lots of room for creativity making for high playability for nearly anyone. 

Buy the game and immerse your self in Death Stranding your probably wont regret it!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I played through the game and enjoyed the progression and the story. Once again I note that Kojima and his team have created a world where it's structure is explained by the story when it is actually the limitations of modern day game-making technology that define the world: The reason there are no friendly NPC characters you can meaningfully interact with is because the Death Stranding has almost completely wiped out humanity. In truth though, populating the waystations, distribution centres and 'cities' in the game with Varied NPCs with unique dialogue, interactability, furnished places of work/residence etcetera would be impossible. Only the illusion of that can be attained now, unconvincingly and frustratingly short of interactability by the likes of Ubisoft in their latest AC games. 
I prefer though how Kojima explained the structure of his world in MGSV through the context of the game. You cannot interact meaningfully with people because you are trying to remain undetected behind enemy lines. I found MGSV to be altogether a better and cooler game. I feel Kojima succeeded in his project to have people 'work together' in an oblique fashion over the internet though, but then in MGSV he had the same sort of set up with your Forward Operating Bases which would be randomly broken into and raided by other players as you would break into theirs. Loved that idea, really added to the game.
The story and acting is great, even when the plot gets ridiculous. I believe plot and context in video games should be defined by the limitations of, or the conditions set by 'video games'. Not enough pixels to make a mouth? Give him a moustache and make him Italian. Can't render more than 2 bullets on screen at one time? Make it a stealth game. Got the best actors on earth who can be rendered into photo-realistic million-polygon 3D avatars that can be seen on screen, but still no way to convincingly communicate with an artificial intelligence in games in 2020? Wipe out the world and make all communication essentially one-way. Your game character will be able to take a piss and wash his face but no dialogue system. 
Anyway, its a fun game to play through but less to stick around for than MGSV in my opinion. Can't wait to see what his next project will be.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Would I recommend it, heck yes. Would other players enjoy it - Maybe not.

The game is very much "Game light", and what I mean by that is the game play elements are not what makes the whole of this game. The most enjoyment I got from it is the theme and character development, it's a highly engaging and extremely interesting story that grows in the telling, constantly making you think. Admittedly like the intro to Skyrim, in the first 10 - 30 mins it does not showcase what the game is about in theme or gameplay well, it's all very serious and po-faced. But as you progress you start to notice subtle things that genuinely put a smile on my face, especially Lou and Heartman.

I need to stress how incredible the multiplayer element of this game is, other games creators need to start doing this sort of "passive co-operative" in other games as well, the way it accentuates the theme and makes you feel not to alone is fantastic.

And finally: Kojima is renowned for creating experience that push gaming as a medium and creating believable stories and characters, and frankly i'd chalk this up as another great.
Apart from Conan o'Brien - What a terrible out of place and unfunny cameo.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's a fantastic game. But honestly you should buy it on PS4 instead (if you can), cuz on PC the game keeps crashing despite my system meeting the recommended specs. It runs fine most of the time, but then sometimes it'll just randomly crash. Updating Windows and all your drivers and such helps reduce the frequency of these crashes, but you can still count on them happening (I can still reliably play for several hours at a time without encountering a crash, but they do still happen from time to time). So if you have a PS4 you're better off buying the game for that system rather than PC.

As for the game itself, I really love the story and honestly just everything about this game (except for the crashes). If you like games that aren't combat heavy then this game is for you.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
One of the biggest questions I’ve seen is, is it worth it?

YES, this game is an experience, might be boring for you, might be incredible for others, regardless it is an experience that should not be missed. 

DEATH STRANDING is not an easy pill to swallow, it has plenty of exposition, good AND bad. Sometimes the story diverges for technobabble and other times it grips you for an emotional rollercoaster. It has action, it has consequences of just that action, it rewards you for thinking outside the box, it punishes you when you avoid making connections. If anything, making sense of the bones of the story in our era of the pandemic should create a personal connection to the story Kojima wanted to tell.

The gameplay doesn’t need to be explained, it is a unique blend of a 3rd person action game as well as a walking simulator with a purpose. The gameplay has enough variety to not become mundane and the world is formed by YOU and other porters making a lasting impression throughout the entirety of its course.

now to some personal nitpicks.
The game is structured as a long feature movie and in that narrative structure there are weird things you have to accept, for one, the game world is supposed to symbolize the entirety of North America, yet traversing it you feel a sense of freedom but not variety in this post-apocalyptic world. Characters are nuanced but also suffer from being behind holograms in bunkers or locked to cutscenes. This world is truly empty and desolate, you can meet porters on the road, Beached Things, Terrorists, and mules but never normal civilians trying to survive in this world.

Some of the plot points can be tedious and overbearing, causing a disjointed narrative that makes up “special plots” to just be special. It is when the human elements of the story are allowed some breathing room that DEATH STRANDING truly shines, the facial animation, the dialogues and emotion you can see in the characters. Those small nuanced expressions that define each character are absolutely the most impressive achievement in gaming I’ve witnessed in a long time.

In the end this game had a story to tell, and in the end, it achieved it. I just wished we had gotten a more fleshed out IN-GAME world for us to connect with, to create bonds in.

8/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
When I saw the teaser trailer for this game back at E32016, it had me scratching ever since. We all didn't know what this game was. All we knew is that there's Norman Reedus, who in my opinion is a fantastic actor. We also knew it had Kojima's name on it, so we all expected this to be a really weird one and it is. 

The environment is amazing to look at. Having the game on max settings makes it look even better. It's one of those games where you just take in all the scenery. Appreciate it for what it is. It reminds me of seeing images online of untouched land in places like Northern Canada or Iceland/the rest of Scandinavia. If the locations were not modeled after those places, then the devs have great imaginations. 

I'm not far into the story so far, but it's so far got me thinking and predicting what will happen. 

Oh what am I saying? Norman Reedus is fantastic and so is this game. Totally worth it

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
What exactly draws me towards eerie themed video games, is it the fact that the fiction elements are so far from our present reality that I find pleasure in the discovery of an eccentric world? Whatever the case may be, Death Stranding was no exception in terms of peculiarities. 
  
Death Stranding has a great way of delivering its narrative through high production cut scenes and through the in game interview logs. I soaked in every bit of information I could for the game. I haven't had a game appeal to me this greatly in a while, so I took pleasure in the discovery.
  
While some may say that the game play is "lackluster", I enjoyed every bit of it. Your task is to transport cargo and you are given the freedom to deliver your packages however you wish through the various tools they provide. I should mention that you can choose any route you like also, the possibilities are endless! The combat was engaging though nothing to difficult. Your best friend is stealth, and if caught then accuracy. Make sure to be prepared! 
 
 Overall I enjoyed my time with Death Stranding. The atmosphere, dialogue and music compliment each other very well, and if you're like me it'll suck you right in. I do recommend for everyone to experience the game at least once!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Not gonna lie it is very hard to review a game like this, and I can't help but think that I would probably feel a little bit differently about it if we were living in different times. I like fast paced combat that is challenging and really don't care too too much about story. This one is....different. 

For the two of you reading.....I'll start with this: This is the perfect game to play during a time like this. Photo-realistic landscapes really help to immerse the player even further into this bleak, unforgiving world. And with DLSS 2.0 my 2080 had zero problems playing this game at 4k 60 HDR with the settings cranked all the way up. 

Violence / needless killing is heavily penalized in this game, which I thought would be a bummer since it's a game and I need to blow some steam (pun?) but with how the story i set up it makes perfect sense, and to be honest it was a breath of fresh air. Combat is spaced out and in lots of cases can be avoided altogether, but when it is inevitable it is so incredibly thrilling (especially that first time encountering BT's). 

Story - 10/10 (still stuck with me after closing the game for the last time. Incredible story and, as importantly, incredible story-telling. This was a pleasant surprise.)
Combat - 9/10 (thrilling as HELL but you are very limited in what you can do / bring and the boss fights, while really cool to watch, are not exactly unique from one another)
Traversal - ehhhhhhh 9.0/10 (this one is hard because on the one hand the landscape is the best I've ever seen in a game. Hands down. However, the reluctancy to give it 10/10 is rooted in the traversal itself. While I understand and massively respect the attention to detail when it comes to portraying realistic traversal through difficult landscape....randomly tripping on a rock or mis-timing a jump and destroying my fragile cargo (thus resulting in a failed delivery) in the middle of a boss fight is incredibly frustrating. I found myself at times randomly yelling at my controller when Sam decides that it's time to go from slow walking while crouched in a BT area to popping a cartwheel to show the floaty folks that he is down to party)

Overall - 9/10. Thought-provoking title with limited but thrilling combat that takes place in such a beautiful, lonely setting. Too bad Sam went into delivering cargo instead of fulfilling his lifelong dream of becoming a gymnast.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is simply put absolutely beautiful. I was as sad when I finished it as when I finish an excellent book. The mechanics are great, intuitive and well-developed. The dynamics of those with the environment are perfectly fluid and then there's THE ENVIRONMENT. Non-stop landscape p0rn how you have never seen. I've read someone on the Verge or Ars talking about how Death Stranding and Breath of The Wild can give you part of the aesthetic experience of climbing and exploring the natural world. I remember thinking that "ah, ok. I think this guy is also a climber is over-romanticizing things a little here, I mean, I clocked 400+ hours of BoTW and I do get giddy with the climbing and the exploration, and I love getting lost but..." And then I ate my butts for breakfast after playing this game. This game SERVED my butt to myself for breakfast. Hello. I remember all the crap that went on when it was first released on PS4 and jesus H D M I christ we ate all that bulls**t we talked FOR SURE. And I'm glad we ate. I would eat it all again. I hope I get to clock 500+ hours of this crazy, beautiful extreme postman simulator.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1][b]One of the best games released in 2020. Definitely worth buying👏[/b][/h1]

I'm level 2, meaning I can sense masterpieces. This one right here, it's one of them.
Just started the game, and it doesn't feel like the review is going to change even after I finish the game. 

[b]Let's start with the pros. Tons of them:[/b]

✅Great Atmosphere
✅Great Soundtrack
✅Graphics are impressive 
✅Original idea and interesting lore
✅Great technical performance, even better than expected from the official source.
✅Top-notch actor performance
✅Oscar-tier cinematics
✅Excellent actor selection
✅Enjoyable gameplay
✅Perfect save system
✅Absolutely unique multiplayer coop, you can't see other players, but you can have an impact in them and they on you

[b]Neutral thoughts:[/b]

🔸This game might not be suitable for everyone, as some might have mentioned, it's a walking simulator. Well, Kojima stated long before releasing that this is "another type of game". So if you expect some RPG shooter with constant action and spawning enemies and headshots, don't expect that.
🔸The interface might look a little bit hard to understand, as some minor aspects of the game. But in time you're going to understand it.
🔸For some the lore might be too complicated, and the big amount of text in the received emails
🔸Shame we don't receive trading cards for this 
🔸Maybe some stated, but I'll mention again. There's no way to control the sound settings, just the general sound volume. Maybe that's a design decision, but for some this may be inconvenient. For me it's not, the sound synchronization is great. But nevertheless, this option should have been included.

[b]Over 100 hours in this game and I'm still not finished with 100% everything.
Kojima never disappoints💕[/b]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Personally, I love this game. Not my all time favorite or anything, but regardless a fantastic game. Don't listen to dumb-ass IGN who gave this work of art a 6/10.  Yes, there is walking, but this is far from just a "walking-simulator". The game harbors a great depth of vehicles and equipment to trail blaze, and provides you with the challenges of overcoming BTs and MULES. The game's first couple hours of game-play are definitely a little slow, but it quickly picks up once you get to the central region. Death Stranding is most definitely worth a buy!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[i][b]I'm not sure that right words to describe the experience of Death Stranding do even exist...
This is inimitably well combined with each other when we're talking about game mechanics and gameplay in general, utterly well made when we're talking about animations and graphic, and oh damn... infinitely spectacular and deafening when we're talking about the story and the lore. The most lively game ever.[/b][/i]

[i][h1]In a nutshell - Breathtaking![/h1][/i]

[i][b]This game isn't about eternally running guy with a tremendous backpack, but about torn world full of people obsessed with their own fears, about adventure that leads through all types of trials. This game is about life reaching out to the sky, about what does it mean to have connections between people, how we could rise and how we could fall, what's death and what's life, what does it mean to live especially.[/b][/i]

[i][h1]You must play this through and out, there's no way you don't.[/h1][/i]

[i][h1]UPD:[/h1][/i]
[i][b]Sorry, how I could've forgotten about mentioning the incredible work have done about Steam version - the BEST PC port EVER. Optimization, control adaptation are perfectly done! Feels like this game meant to be for PC from the beginning)[/b][/i]

[i][h1]UPD 2.0:[/h1][/i]
[i][b]Why, why I forgot to mention the soundtrack?! You would die to play this game only for the sake of its musical accompaniment! Every single music artist that work on this game is a GENIUS! Ludvig Forssell did an amazing job, just as whole Kojima Production team, and music bands which participated in the development. 
Thank you.[/b][/i]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
As a Hideo Kojima fan, I tried to like this game, I really did. I gave the game 60 hours of my time before throwing in the towel and deleting it. 

I read the reviews (the good and the bad) and knew what I was in for. I wanted to listen to some audiobooks while giving my hands something to do, maybe experience some avant garde gaming while I'm at it, so this seemed perfect. However this game fails even at that.  

This game occupies an uncanny valley between tedium and engagement. It's long periods of boredom peppered with frustrating interactions, cutscenes, and fights. The controls are clunky to a fault, going beyond a form of expression as some believe it to be, and the interactions (i.e. the non-hiking parts) are best described as annoying chores--yes, chores compared to trudging across repetitive scenery at a slow pace. Vehicle physics are abysmal. The narrative and cutscenes are self-indulgent, disjointed, unsubtle, and puerile, yet also preachy and self-righteous--a combination that reminds me of the schizophrenic. However, this is merely an exaggeration of Kojima's writing style, so I'm not going to hold this against this game, since this is about par for the course and aren't game-breaking. The other issues are much more severe.

This is an artistically and technologically pretty game that is a joy to look at, until it opens its mouth. No doubt the technical aspects of the game is laying the groundwork for something far greater, but this game as it stands is a highly-polished, over-marketed, AAA turd. I've been on Steam for about fifteen years (since Counter Strike 1.6), yet it is this game that brought me out to write my first and probably only review.  This has significantly dampened my mood for any more AAA games.

Whoever you are, this game is not for you.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is the latest from Hideo Kojima.  He’s best known for his Metal Gear Solid franchise while working at Konami.  Death Stranding is the first game after leaving that series and the question is can he still deliver on the style he’s known for. 

Death Stranding is two different games.  There’s the gameplay which focuses on the main character, Sam Porter, delivering packages, and the story that focuses on the world of Death Stranding. I’ll be breaking this up because the game also breaks up these two topics as we’ll see. 

The core of the gameplay is Sam delivers packages, and while that sounds quite simplistic, that is ultimately what Death Stranding has the player do for gameplay.  It’s very much a Doordash Simulator 2020 edition.  There are several systems to assist with that or make it more interesting, but nothing that changes the base action. 

Players will traverse a vast wasteland to visit different outposts, distribution centers, or prepper houses and while it sounds like there might be something interesting in each of those locations there’s not.  Every location feels like a cold sterile mess and so much more could be done with these different sites.

There are multiple levels of gameplay when players are walking between the various locations.  Without a large load, Death Stranding feels like a very chill and relaxed walk in an unknown land.  The world of Death Stranding is beautiful at times, and yet it’s also sterile.  There’s a very peaceful feeling of being the only person for miles around. 

If Sam starts to carry a larger load, Death Stranding starts to challenge the player to keep his cargo balanced to avoid falling over, and in this, the game starts to take on minor aspects of QWOP by Bennett Foddy.

Both of these systems work well and are quite interesting.  The problem that Death Stranding runs into is when it wants to make the experience have more action.  There are two major threats to Sam, other humans, who want Sam’s Cargo, and BTs, the unknown terror.  The problem is that Death Stranding never really makes either of these threats threatening.  Players can just run past most encounters and get away with almost no danger to themselves or their cargo.  

Death Stranding has some interesting systems that work with the delivery game, such as power armor and vehicles, but all that does is change the speed that Sam can move or how the weight is distributed  Ultimately the gameplay of Death Stranding is a walking simulator where the player is just getting between points

The one part of Death Stranding that can be interesting is the inclusion of other player’s items.  A player might leave a ladder on a cliff face, and later on, you might come across it.  Another player might leave a sign warning you about something dangerous ahead of you.  But the player interaction between these systems is a bit limited, and while players will receive likes from other players for doing a good job, these likes feel like a simplistic version of experience points so players can level up through artificial systems.  

Death Stranding reminds me a lot of Metal Gear Solid V, in that it has some large systems that players can safely ignore.  There are systems such as the dangerous and damaging system of Timefall, a story element that talks about the rain that ages humans and cargo.  Timefall sounds like it’s going to be a major problem but I never once had to even consider it.  Most of the time, Timefall just warned me BTs were in the area, and all that made me do is start to sprint through it, rather than worry about the damage it could do to me or my cargo. 

There’s also the ability to create transportation systems such as a zipline but even these don’t feel that interesting and after building out a couple of pieces, I found it was a better use of my time to just move quickly between two locations then creating a new transportation system that I rarely used. 

On the other hand, the story is every type of Kojima weirdness together and the fact is Death Stranding has a compelling story.  There’s a lot to talk about with the story but with 90 percent of the story being choke-full of spoilers. I hesitate to dive in. 

I will say that story would rival an early Metal Gear Solid.  There’s a lot of interesting characters, themes, concepts, and stories.  A few moments in the game are wonderful and the game keeps revealing more and more of its story in the final moments and somehow makes the large narrative very accessible. 

The only real issue with the actual story in Death Stranding is that the game is needlessly silent on a majority of topics early on.  What the BTs are, what Death Stranding means, and what is going on with the world is not explained to the player.  While many of these topics have spoilers that Sam will find out as the game goes on, there’s a base understanding that Sam has at the beginning of the game that isn’t well conveyed to the player. 

Death Stranding’s story is a great rollercoaster ride of emotion and filled with multiple interesting and unique experiences that players will enjoy.  Every major character has an interesting level of exposition and almost every character was a joy to meet after talking to them virtually for a decent amount of time. 

The real problem with Death Stranding’s story and thus Death Stranding as a whole is not how it’s told or what is said, but rather than have a tight 10-20 hour story, Death Stranding strings the gameplay out for 60 hours, and ultimately will stretch the story out over that time.  

The delivery of the scenes are good, but when there can be between two to eight hours between critical dialogue scenes that should be connected, it’s hard to have a cohesive narrative. 

Sadly this is a critical issue for Death Stranding.  It’s a fun and interesting game, but with so much time between scenes, the story struggles to remain relevant.  The gameplay is interesting but it’s a vessel for the story. I wouldn’t mind playing the gameplay by itself as it does produce a calming and interesting experience but at 60 dollars players deserve a better experience.  

I give Death Stranding a 

6/10  

though add a couple of points if you will mostly focus on just the story because it’s one of the most interesting stories being told right now. 

At the same time, I would probably wait until the game is priced between 20 and 40 as that feels like a better price.

If you want to know more about my opinions on the gameplay as well as the idea of it being a walking simulator or further information on the story, or faces of Death Stranding I recommend checking out my video that can be seen here: 

https://youtu.be/GPyEUPEduio

It ran flawlessly, and really pulls you in. I don't want to rant, but I have to add that everyone saying this game "isn't for everyone" is a ridiculous point. No game is "for everyone" I feel by saying that, you are signaling in a pretentious way that you ARE the target audience, and that most people wont grasp the game. Which just is not true. I think most people will enjoy Death Stranding. Just look at the overall rating above. That said, I recommend this to anyone who finds the concept and visuals interesting.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is one of the best games Ive ever played, across every category. 

Graphics are off the charts, super well optimized and runs like butter at 4k. The story is interesting and engaging and keeps you wanting to learn more, the world is huge and filled with gorgeous organic textures and forms, and the exploration/porter game is 80% better than I expected any game with these mechanics to be. The increasing challenge of traversing while carrying 100s of kg of deliveries actually turns out to be deep and fun, your abilities to do with carrying and balancing have actual interesting progression, and somehow Kojima has made a totally original masterpiece out of this concept. 

 I really didnt understand how Kojima would pull off a non-PvP oriented game where people support one another and succeed together, but on release day...I got it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
When I had originally started this on launch day, I was going into this optimistically as I was a great fan of Hideo Kojima. Unfortunately, around the same time I had gotten into this, I had made the heart shattering discovery that a woman I had held in a romantic regard for twelve years had came out to be aromantic- someone who doesn't seek a romantic partner because they cannot personally feel those sensations. I was left broken and lost, and this game eventually came to become a coping mechanism that helped shape my way toward moving on not only as a person, but how I saw other people as whole. I understand this game may not be for everyone, but it is something I now consider to be very near and dear to me because of how positive everything and everyone is in this game. There are good people in this world. Love your fellow neighbor. Please consider giving this game a chance and see it to the end. Thank you Hideo Kojima, for such a masterpiece.

p.s.
To the dude who put a safehouse up near Edge Knot City, you're a goddamn hero.

title: DEATH STRANDING

To sum it up, you are playing as a post man delivering things and linking stations to others and bringing America back together. The game itself is beautiful. Very unique choice of biome. The story is interesting and unique. The attention to detail is also very impressive. As a original PS4 port, this plays really well on PC.
Some downs I encountered would be is that the map is massive. A little too big unless you are in a vehicle. But on foot it can come to a pain in the ass. So get a bike or suv as fast as possible. Game stutters did happen for me don't know if others did.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The gameplay is mostly conquering numerous environment types with as much gear as you can carry, with the intent of delivering packages to numerous locations.  It could have been a disastrous concept, but it's saved by throwing a mixture of enemies both human and supernatural, combined with harsh environmental conditions. The feeling of beating bigger challenges to deliver even more packages is highly gratifying. It's further benefited from the overall visual and audio design that creates a world oddly familiar, beautiful, and desolate at the same time.

The story's initial simplicity and camp gradually give way to something surprisingly compelling and emotional at its end. The entire cast does an excellent job, with Norman Reedus providing some of his best work as an actor.

I look forward to playing it again.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
You know that meditative flow state you get into while hiking where you mentally map out a path in the terrain and then traverse it in an endless loop?

You know when you decide to bring all the groceries in one trip, plan it out, and then barely make it?

You know when you are packing for a trip and fit everything into one bag by Tetris-ing it all perfectly?

You know that part in [i]Red Dead Redemption[/i] when you get to Mexico and the music starts playing?

You know when you help out a random stranger and feel a momentary connection?

[i]Death Stranding[/i] is kind of like all those things. 

It's a beautiful and wholly unique experience about bringing people together. The craftsmanship on it's own is something to behold from the animations striking the exact balance between impact and speed to the absolutely stunning facial capture and detailed photogrammetry of the world.

But it's the level of engagement in the inventive gameplay loop and how it involves both mechanics and thematic ideas that is so refreshing and arresting. This is a truly unique game that is almost difficult to understand why it works as well as it does. 

In contrast to the gameplay being almost laconic in the delivery of the ideas, the narrative elements are verbose, self indulgent and lacking in any subtly. But if that's the price to pay for this weird and one of a kind experience, I'm down with it. 

I absolutely loved the journey of [i]Death Stranding[/i] and it's one of my favorite games of this generation. 

Keep on, keeping on!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Meaningful asynchronous multiplayer is an astounding achievement. The game itself is a little on the easy side, I played on the hardest difficulty at all times. There are gameplay moments that really surprised me, for example the first time another 'player' helped in the middle of a heated battle by throwing helpful items was really an astonishing moment, a moment I didn't expect to be able to 'share' (this wasn't a literal multiplayer aspect).

Overall a very zen-like game with not much difficulty. For example, once you unlock zip lines and construct them at a new location the first time you reach it any difficulty related to delivering items there is completely gone.

Combat is serviceable but not deep or complex.

World building and its resource gathering aspects in tandem with the multiplayer elements were the best and most enjoyable parts of the game play and experience.

The story was a bit silly for me. I found myself not being able to suspend my disbelief and invest into the meat of the theme due to the overly eccentric style of the story's presentation. 

One absolute negative is the baby you're required to take with you for 99% of the game. I had to use the in game audio options to set BB's audio output to an unused audio channel so I didn't have to hear the thing cry and then I could ignore it during game play. Other than that it was an enjoyable game.

Its more of a go from point a to point b but we are going to add a geography puzzle and some weird Kojima story in a beautifully crafted world. I encourage anyone who wants a weird and different type of game then the shooter after shooter kill everything type of game. If i were to rate this game I would give it an 8/10. 

It gave me a great single player experience that I was looking for to take a break from multiplayer games.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The game is, essentially, delivering cargo from one area to another. Yet, there is a strong focus on the journey to and fro.  

Delivering requires a lot of preparation, in order to deal with the obstacles in your way—including your carrying capacity, condition, the elements, terrain, enemies, etc. Walking and scaling are a core part of the gameplay and feel very satisfying when done correctly. Combat and driving however feel very unsatisfying, even if they do make your journey(s) more convenient.

This is also an ‘always online’ experience. Although you don’t physically meet other players, you do interact with the paths and objects they have left behind. This can greatly help the unprepared or (at worst) be an annoyance.  

The story can be divisive for some. This is one of the few games where its gameplay and narrative don’t feel disconnected from each other. There are also a lot of amusing moments that break the fourth-wall. Admittedly, there are also some moments that do come off as contrived, confusing and/or verbose.

The default graphical settings are up to par with console quality. I’ve had no problems with this PC port, but there have been many who have reported troubles with this port.

Death Stranding is a slow and steady grind, but each successful delivery feels rewarding and satisfying.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I discovered this game through Youtube autoplay finding a song in the soundtrack, I was already hooked from there. I went into it without reading any criticisms or reviews. This game is essentially a story delivery vehicle for the most part. The gameplay isn't too thrilling except when you are dealing with BTs. There is a lot of walking, which can be tedious, but isn't too bad. Although for a game which relies so heavily on movement, the movement itself is pretty lackluster. Walking down slopes and driving in general is janky. Combat is entertaining enough, but this isn't really a shooter. 

I feel like the BT battles weren't hard enough. I had the game set on the second highest difficulty, and while early encounters without a proper counter to BTs were thrilling, once you have weapons it lost its edge. I felt challenged only 3 times. Leaving the incinerator for the first time, the one sided battle with higgs on the beach, and the LAST BT encounter before the end of the game: getting ambushed by 4 anus monsters simultaneously.

The community mechanic is interesting, helpful most of the time, with a troll or two tossed in there.

If you are younger, I wouldn't recommend this game, as it won't really effect someone the same way as if they are older. As you age, you 'get' things better, understand them. 

That being said, the story is truly epic, and makes up for a lot of the game's other downfalls. As mentioned above, I found this game because of its music, and its music is very good. Overall, I would rate 8/10.

-Don't buy if you are easily bored/impatient (I finished this in 50 hours)
-Don't buy if you are expecting action the entire time
-Don't buy if you are young and haven't addressed "the question" for yourself yet.
-Don't buy if you are expecting a super polished game

-Don't buy if you don't have decent hardware. I have a GTX 1650 Super. Playing at 1080P I can maintain 60 FPS for the most part, but during rain it can stutter and drop to 40 FPS. I would recommend a graphics card with at least 6 GB of memory. I tried a GTX 1660 Super and was able to maintain 60 FPS comfortably without any stuttering whatsoever. For reference, the 1650 super has 4 GB memory, and the 1660 super has 6 GB.


-Do buy if you enjoy solid story
-Do buy if you enjoy exploration/adventure
-Do buy if you appreciate excellent level design and aesthetics
-Do buy if you enjoy ambient scary

title: DEATH STRANDING

I enjoey this game, but a couple of things that really annoyed me to the point that almost blinded me with rage where the bullet sponge BT's, the Junker and Amelie scenes, I loved the "community" aspect of the game, the fact that you could use highways built by other players and create your own fast travel ziplines were pretty cool, the ammo the other players gave you fixed a problem MGS peace walker had, due to the bullet sponge enemies

there are issues with the controller where double inputs happen randomly (menus open and close) and you can loose control of your vehicle and many thins can happen due to that, like your vehicle been destroyed and having most of the packages damaged, also walking even more, or worse when you are in rocky terrain and your character randomly jumps into a cliff, it happened to me several times and I almost gave up, hope this is fixed some day, but for me I just finished the story and I got enough, maybe some day I'll replay it in a couple of years

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is game not meant for everyone for sure. there is a couple i will say in this review and i recommend you read them before buying this game.

1.) This is Def just a game about delivery packages and reuniting the country after chaos. you must enjoy a game that is soley on story and thats about it. if you enjoyed the Products of Hideo at all like old school Metal Gear games, then you will enjoy this amazing story.

2.) Game tends to have control issues where its weird to ride the bike around so you will be walking and i mean lots of climbing and walking around. You can make this game easier by just using the online features to help guide you and let you use other players ladders, ropes, etc.

So do i recommend this game, If you love story games and get invested in the story all the way thru and like what Hideo is now doing outside of the Metal Gear, then i say get this game, but if your more into better controls and more than just story, then avoid at all costs

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a somewhat controversial game; its slower-paced with minimal combat and the majority of the gameplay is delivering packages. Despite this, I still enjoyed my time with Death Stranding and never really got bored. The game starts off slow with most deliveries being done on foot, however, it begins introduces many structures throughout the story to make your life easier. Part of the fun is figuring out where to build ziplines or bridges in order to make future deliveries easier. 

There is some combat and stealth in the game, but nothing too major. Human enemies are mostly in camps and can be dealt with fairly easily during the cargo-recovery deliveries. The BTs (supernatural enemies) appear all over the map and are best dealt with a stealth-based approach. There are also a couple of boss battles, but they aren't too challenging and mostly rely on good inventory/health management. 

The story was amazing. Hideo Kojima incorporates a lot of original ideas that I haven't seen before in any other games or movies. My only complaint is that certain cutscenes are quite long. They aren't boring by any means, but it can be annoying if you want to save the game and pick it up another time. [spoiler] In particular, the ending lasted over 2 hours during which the credits played twice... [/spoiler] The graphics are also pretty, and enabling DLSS 2.0 can give you a significant bump in performance with no quality loss.

Overall, I would recommend Death Stranding if you like slower-paced games with incredible stories. It took me about 90 hours to complete the story, get all deliver locations to 5 stars, and gather all the collectibles.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I played 90.3 Hours. This review represents my personal views only. 

Final Rating: 2.6 - 5 (This is based on the average ratings of the below ratings): 
* Story: 0 - 5 
* Graphics: 4 - 5 
* Sound: 4 - 5 
* Game Play: 2 - 5 
* Fun: 3 – 5 
* Comments/Hint 
* Knowing what I know now, would I buy it again. 

* Story: 0 / 5 
The story is simply garbage. I understand that this is a "Hideo Kojima" game and he likes to do things a bit different than other games. which is why i bought it thinking it might be similar to Metal Gear story which was amazing. 

But Deathstranding story is so bad it is on another level of garbage. It is as if he had no other stories or ideas, and wanted to make a game so bad that he said ok I will bring more celebrities and add a ton of emotions and add freaky stuff and mix it all up it will be a master piece!.... 

The answer is no... the story is garbage to a level that i was skipping cut scenes and was literally not interested in the characters or what do they have to say... 

To make it even worse... The game is almost 60% cut scenes! and you know it... every time they pop up and try to explain the story (Which I'm sure they think is amazing) I find myself trying to skip it... because it is simply boring and not fun... I was connected to the story in the beginning of the game and then slowly started hating it slowly until I reached a point where I was skipping cut scenes and just wanted to end it... 

What is funny is that as if the game knew that the story was garbage... because the closer you are to the end the more cut scenes it throws at you! As if the game is trying to say wait let me explain.. Just want let me explina... I was like NO Enough garbage just give me the credits already! 

* Graphics: 4 / 5 
Graphics are simply amazing. The open world and nature is simply amazing. Not as good as Withcer 3 but close. 

* Sound: 4 / 5 
Sound was beautiful. Captures the surroundings and on point. 

* Game play: 2 / 5 
Meh, there are a lot of small issues that makes you want to rage quit. 

Example, when you are reversing with a car and then want to go forward, it takes some time for the car to shift into gear and go forward which will ultimately end up with you sliding the car and then falling off a cliff. Hard to explain but trust me when you play the game and run into this situation you will understand. 

There are some areas of the game which the game suddenly wants you to get killed because it forces you to use some mechanics which needless to say was not fun. 

* Fun: 3 / 5 
Amazingly I found the Transporting cargo part Fun! 

Remove the garbage story. 
Remove the garbage mechanics. 
Remove the garbage game logic. 

It was fun meeting new people and delivering what they need and bringing them what they need. It was fun making my first car and hauling everything I found on the road and transporting stuff from one location to the other. It was fun building those roads so I can get to my customers quickly while building more reputations and gaining more tools as rewards. Anything else was garbage. 

Wish they would make a game which is JUST that and maybe add more options for cars. Now that would be a fun game. 

* End Comments/Hint: 
Second screen and your Phone are MANDATORY! 

This way you can watch Youtube or Netflix or check your phone or anything. Because the game has a lot of garbage cutscenes and you need something else to keep you awake otherwise you will end up rage quitting. 

* Knowing what I know now, would I buy it again: 
Yes... The delivery part and graphics are fun as I mentioned above. Just ignore the story and you will be fine.


(Blood Angel)
If you truly do hail from the realm that men once called hell, when you return there, tell your kindred it was Sanguinius who threw you back - Sanguinius .

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The only true walking simulator. multiplayer for introverts, breathtaking Icelandic landscape, Kojima's usual goofiness in dialogue, interactions and cheesy characters nicknames, mostly non-violent approach to gameplay, detailed and cryptic lore with the usual weirdness. All that.

From a regular Kojima hater, it hurts me to say this but somehow he created a very unique and coherent (which is not usually the case with him) story about reuniting humans at the brink of extinction. Yes, all you do is deliver stuff, however, at the same time your connection to the in-game (and "online") characters grows, constantly revealing new aspects of the game. For me seeing Sam, all of the main characters and the overall community you unite was the best thing about this game. Heartwarming stuff.

I did not even get to the weird stuff which most Kojima fans expected from this game. Not to spoil anything, it is all there but integrated into much more subtle game. Overall, if you search for more story-rich games, for me, this one is the best AAA games released ever. Plot resolution hit me hard with that bittersweet feeling and I was shocked that in a Kojima game basically every aspect of it was explained and purposefully connected to the overall story in a major way. No random bullshit just to leave ominous impression on a player. Best casting, acting and VA too. The amount of quotable, cheesy one-liners dropped in the most serious scenes was the most Kojima thing ever. 

Loved it. Everyone should play it. Still, most people will probably say that all you do is walk for hours with barely any gameplay (nearly no gunplay) until the next pretentious 1 h cutscene that is not even that clever:) Requires slightly longer attention span for sure. For me a single playthrough took ~72 h doing some side-quest deliveries.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding Review

It's a great game, however, the story is typical Kojima nonsense. The story is convoluted and just as hard to follow or get immersed in as any Metal Gear Solid game, just thinly veiled subtle nods to our current lives and what not, but despite the annoyance of trying to follow the story the game is solid. 

HOWEVER THE VEHICLES ARE THE WORST IN ANY GAME I HAVE EVER PLAYED! Seriously for a game that is all about deliveries and moving goods between points, the vehicles couldn't handle worse, be more annoyingly designed to get hung up on every single rock, or high center, randomly boost in the opposite direction, or just generally be a frustrating aspect to the game.

Despite the annoying ass vehicles and the weird convoluted story, the actual Gameplay is super addictive and incredibly fun when you finally drop off that cargo and GET THEM LIKES SON!

Also the Music is probably the best atmospheric music I have ever enjoyed, and they aren't typical songs or genres I would like, but in the context of the game's setting, they are phenomenal!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is one of the most unique experiences in a game that I've played. It is a wholly Kojima game with many Kojima-isms (4th wall breaking, celebrity cameos, callbacks to Metal Gear Solid).

The gameplay is centered around taking packages from one location to another. That's it. However, the way that you plan your routes and utilize the structures that you can build in the game are where the fun is to be had. I often found myself becoming the road builder of the game in order to make taking packages between some of the main facilities an easy task.

The game also has a pseudo-online feature (reminiscent of Dark Souls). Other players that are a part of your world instance (you won't see them in the game) are able to build and leave behind structures and equipment that will also show up in your world. You are able to reward these players with virtual likes (does nothing, but is a cool mechanic to show how beloved you are by the community).

Another great aspect about this game in particular is the port. Along with Kojima's previous entry on Steam (Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain), this game got the A+ treatment on its PC port. I encountered no glitches, frame rate stuttering, or any other performance related issues. This game runs especially well if you have a RTX GPU with DLSS enabled.

If you're looking for a relaxing game to play with unique, fleshed out characters, a desolate and depressing yet beautiful world, absolutely fantastic soundtrack, and a thought provoking story that is very well written, executed, and explained, then look no further.

Vehicle controls are awful though.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
In a video gaming world where gameplay reigns supreme and story is more of an afterthought, it's refreshing to have a game that's the other way around. The gameplay is there, and the combat is pretty smooth, but the story is definitely the focal point.

Good game.

[spoiler]Plus the cast is stellar. Mads Mikkelsen and Margaret Qualley are standouts, in this nerd's opinion.[/spoiler]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Well, I finally got to play Death Stranding.

So I actually enjoyed my first 3 hours in the game, even if my PC still can't handle it in its best settings, still looks pretty good to me. Hopefully, once I have the budget for my upgrade I would be gladly play this game in High Settings.

In terms of gameplay, I kinda get it why some people don't like this WALKING SIMULATOR but for me the gameplay is freaking creative and I highly suggest that Death Stranding should be played using a controller because you can feel the weight of the cargo you're carrying. I can really relate to this because during my days in Tarlac, I had to make deliveries to various people in Capas and I always love the journey of carrying heavy things and delivering it to various people who needs Water, Cooking Oil, Money,Soy Sauce, etc. I can totally agree tho, this is a FoodPanda Simulator, not a Walking Simulator. I also love the Photomode, it's pretty obvious I'm gonna spend a lot of time in Photomode while saving America from destruction.

10/10 IGN
Will continue this Review once I play the game twice

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Masterpiece is the only adjective for this game. Kojima's first independent production immediately demonstrates his artistry. The plot consistently evolves and does so until the very end of the game providing a satisfying conclusion to the story. Every piece of the story played a role in developing the characters with jaw-dropping revelations down the line. I fully recommend this game at full price. Take your time while playing it. Enjoy every step, quite literally.

Of all the masterpieces that I have played, which I have sought out through Steam and top recommended games, this is by far the best of all of them. Completely worth the wait as I have been following the development from Kojima's creation of his own company to the console release to the PC release (placing my wait at several years).

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
-I'm at awe on how the game runs and feels, I'm so excited to play this game.

About 25 hours in, still on Chapter 3:

I'm still making the most out of the side jobs and deliveries as I can and I love how much love was put into this game. HOWEVER, the only problem I've had with this game is the controller input. For some strange reason, the controller input repeats itself... EX: I press X to hop on the motorcycle, and 4 seconds later I randomly jump out of it damaging all my cargo. It's annoying and frustrating to deal with, especially going against enemies that are chasing after you. I know the simple solution is to change to KBM but it's a big issue for people who want a controller experience. 

This game is incredible and should not just be dismissed as a "walking simulator". The story is very enticing with characters that makes you want to learn about their backstory (Fragile, Higgs, Cliff, etc.) I'm still not super deep into the game but it's been an amazing experience by far and highly recommend it for people who want an immersive, slow-paced, adventure game.

FINISHED-
Words can't describe how amazing this game really is, purely... amazing. This is one of those games where you can't help but appreciate all the effort that was put into it, truly one of it's kind and in my opinion, a masterpiece. This game does not deserve the hate it gets, not a single bit of it. I will never forget this experience.
"Keep on keeping up."

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm so happy that I ignored all hype (both positive and negative) around the game, and went in with an open mind. Within the first hour, it was clear how special this game is. Having not been a fan of the Metal Gear series, I wasn't sure what to expect. 

I found it an incredibly beautiful and innovative gaming experience along with a story that is a fascinating example of science fiction world building with humor and heart. 

The story can be very difficult to follow at times, given it's the scale and how and when game decides to insert exposition (piecemeal, often out of order, and some times deceptive). 

It's a game that I feel is important and will be talked about for sometime. If you appreciate the unorthodox and the eccentric, you owe it to yourself to experience it first hand.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Not gonna lie is hard to like it at first, but when the gameplay clicks on the second map is hard to forget an experience like this. This is my modern "Mario", and that game started all for me when I was a kid. The gameplay is the traversal walking itself with all the tools you have and discover along the story. title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't need to mention already what other's have posted.  Yes, at the core you are making deliveries between different points either on foot or a truck/motorcycle.  You can either plow through the story and complete the game in 30ish hours or take your time and not even be halfway done while spending 145 hours in it.

It comes down to this: You need an imagination. You need an imagination to appreciate the story and the off-world/spiritual occurrences in it.  You need an imagination to appreciate the level of insanity placed into the beauty of the abnormal in the game.

You are Sam.  Your job is to connect the inhabitants of a continent together through the game's "internet."  And most of them give you perks the more deliveries you make.  It is what happens between these deliveries.  You have mildly annoying humans who want to steal your cargo and you have the supernatural trying to take your soul.

Why have I spent 145 hours in it and am not even halfway done?  I enjoy the scouting.  I would look at a mission and its route, not accept it, go towards where I need to make this trip and scout for the best route. Sounds simple enough, but you are dealing with areas vehicles do not always fit through, streams/rivers, avoiding the supernatural, making sure your electric vehicle doesn't run out of charge, etc. It is a real threat to have driven and not have reached your destination, your vehicle's charge is half gone, and you are unable to carry all the cargo on your back.  Do you turn back or do continue forward to your destination?

The grinding in the game is fully optional.  Will you build your highway systems to make your future orders far easier to deal with?  Or will you just deal with off roading it the entire game?

Playing the game with DLSS makes it pure eye candy.  Even 145 hours in I still find myself looking at the scenery and marveling at how amazing it all looks.

If you like plowing through games and not even putting any thought into the wildly imaginative story and think the supernatural is something silly, then the game is probably not for you.  But if you love building, connecting NPCs, seeing insanely looking beings, and have an affinity for appreciating landscape, then you just might enjoy the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Say what you like but Death stranding is a work of art.  The sort of art you can't drag your gaze away from.  After a while you are walking in Sam's boots and you really get to feel your surroundings as if you were really there.  Magical.
Most games you play start to get a bit boring mid-game.  Death Stranding is different in that it just keeps on getting better until you can't put it down, you even start dreaming about it.
A bucket list game that everyone should try.
I can't exactly tell you why I recommend this game, but I can say there is something amazing about it what ever your personal choice of game may be.

UPDATE: over 49 hours in and the game just keeps on surprising me on it's quality.  There is nothing really you can compare it with.  It's unique as it is brilliant.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I can see the reason of polarized comments, this gameplay is boring and punishing for beginners, you have to make your way through harsh terrains, BT territories, or MULE/DEMON  territories carefully, the BTs and MULE/DEMON will not make it easy for you, even a mere bump may cause you to fall to the ground, the story telling is slow paced, got loads of text to read,too.
However, after overcoming the difficulties, the touching moment of meeting other characters, the excitement of fighting dead socom operatives, mood-fitting music or simply a funny face of the BB, all of these moments make the game worth-buying.
The only downside i would say to be the post-gameplay, there isn't much you can do except complete achievements or doing additional orders.
28/10 Lou is real.
