title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Score: 9.8

Positives: Unique gameplay, beautiful visuals, interesting story and world, low minimum specs.

Negatives: Third person shooting mechanics feel dated.

In terms of world building, characters, story it is my favorite Kojima game. It has very experimental gameplay. It takes some getting used to, but I enjoy it a great deal. It's very addictive too. Walking simulator just doesn't do it justice. Planning the best route to make your delivery is an important aspect of gameplay. What hazards are on the path to your destination and would it be better to take an easier, but longer route? The combat mechanics need work, but it's a very small aspect of the gameplay. Nonetheless, it is important to mention that the combat is awkward. Compared to other third-person shooter, it just doesn't hold up. It ins't bad, it just feels dated. There are many things in the gameplay that has potential. A sequel would definitely have things to improve. The most significant innovation this game features is the 'Social Strand System'. This is the passive multiplayer feature which allows you to interact with other players in unique ways. Giving someone an item they need in a remote area. Building a helpful structure that appears in other players world. Everyone loves to see the numbers go up in games. Without a money system, this game uses 'likes' that you get for helping others. The visuals are unbelievably stunning! 4K, High framerate, Ultra-Widescreen and DLSS support gives Death Stranding some great high end PC visuals. It isn't a particularly difficult game to run and relatively low end PCs should have no trouble running it. The game offers lots of content. I have 100% the game in a little over 100 hours. I had played it on PS4 already though. People playing it for the first time could potentially put 200 hours into. Keep on keeping on!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A friend once quoted an article to me "PC is coming to Death Stranding"

Jokes aside, I love this game, But for many people, this game is a walking simulator. And it is, but if anything, This game should be played by aspiring dame designers, as this game introduces new gameplay mechanics I think should be in new AAA games.

My taste in video games is weird, I love moving, I love it when a game has really interesting movement mechanics, N++ introduced momentum so that you can launch yourself across the room, Celeste has a sharp, but fair, movement set like wall jumps, climbs, etc. and Team Fortress 2 is all about movement, where you place yourself against the enemy will almost always dictate the winning player. So what makes Death Stranding interesting to me? Its all about walking, so there is alot of mechanics here. The terrain will make your progress fast or slow, the graphics of rocks on the floor may look like its safe to traverse, but reality, you have to hop rock from rock to make it past what looks like a safe passage. if you were climbing a hill, and you find yourself falling over, crouching will lower your center of gravity, making it easier to traverse hills. Going down a snowy slope can prove diffucult since snow cant support all the weight at one time, it will give, so you have to make diaganal movements, just like going down a sand dune.

Of all of this, I think designers can learn here, they can learn how to make walking fun. instead of some boring walk to point B, why dont you make designs that make walking more fun, like walking on a path will make you move faster, or make the terrain interact with the player, decreased defense or attack power. I imagine alot of people fast travel in Skyrim because walking is boring, but you might meet people on the roads of Skyrim, Walking is boring, and Hideo has taught the game industry that walking can be fun.

for all future games, If walking is a major thing you do, I expect walking to be fun, Im looking at you, Elder Scrolls VI

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is consummate videogame. Brilliant story with novel ideas to ponder. Completely rewarding gameplay that reinforces the story's point.

It's all about human connection. Death Stranding uses its medium to full effect to explore human connection from several different angles to give the gamer an extremely rich perspective.

Real connection. Fake connection. Absent connection. Severed connection. These are the four main angles that slapped me in the face while I took the experience in.

God damn, it's good. Like holy shit. One of my favorite games of all time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Don't fall for that nonsense of not looking into anything of this game before playing so that is doesn't "spoil the story". That was a clever excuse to just hide the fact that you are basically a delivery guy and that's about it.
It is not a bad game, but it isn't a great one. This game feels a lot like Metal Gear Solid V: a really empty open world with almost to no reward for exploration.
It is really simple to summarize it. You are a delivery boy that keeps coming from point A to point B and so on if, and only if, you decide to mainly just do the "Main Quests" which are basically the same as the optional ones, with the exception that you don't usually keep coming back to the same places over and over again.

There is combat, but it was clearly not the focus on the game due to the focus of the story and of the character, although it is kinda sad because those mechanics work really well.

The ONLY reason to buy this game is just the story which is actually really good, but this is what you AT LEAST expect from Hideo Kojima.
There is some really lazy explanation that this game is actually for you to "feel like you are helping the world" and that you have to enjoy the trip and not the destination itself. This could be true if you didn't have to simply keep coming back through the same damn way over and over again.

I wasted more than 100 hours on this game expecting that something would eventually happen on a gameplay perspective, but nope it is as boring as it seems.

Conclusion: Do not even think on buying this for full price and MAYBE consider it if eventually half price, but even then I think pac-man would be a lot more fun

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't write regular reviews but i feel i might start, I'm a gamer and a dad, being a gamer dad is hard alot harder than i thought it would ever be. I only tend to get about 4 hours a weekend to play a game which a far less than i am used to even on a busy week. I first put my feelers out on the discussions board because with what little time i have to game i don't want to waste it all as i've got 4 other games on my list at the moment that i want to work through and i'm glad i did. Further down you will find a "For gamer dads" score/list hopefully it will help fellow gamer dads like me.
When i first head about this game i thought what a joke, Kojima has finally lost his little mind. But the joke is on me, this is one of the best games i've played, my total play time is all in the first map! This game is pure Kojima, arty, deep and full of documents and audio logs. 

Let’s start with the mechanics, the main mechanic of the game is delivering orders carrying boxes from one place to another at first I thought how can that be engrossing enough to carry a whole game it turns out it is very engrossing. The satisfaction comes from making it to a new delivery spot as the environments are full of slopes, lumps, bumps, rivers (which can make you fall over and damage your cargo, you can regain balance if you are quick enough and plan accordingly) and hostile life forms human and other worldly which keep each delivery engaging from start from start to finish. You get tools to help you along your way (what I’ve used): A massive ladder that extends to climb cliff edges, across rivers and gaps, a climbing rope that you stick into the ground to get down slopes and cliff faces forging your own path for deliveries was so satisfying for me I find my self looking for ways to go just to use these tools. Once you’ve added the delivery spot to the network other players items appear in the word; like placed ladders and ropes which you can use at will (all helpfully on your map in green whilst your items are blue) which can help with future deliveries.
Other mechanics, We’ve got shooting (which I’ve not managed to unlock yet only just made it to the 3rd chapter), stealth thanks to mules who are a group of people who are addicted to amazo… packages and will stop at nothing to steal deliveries, driving is also a thing which is very helpful for delivering items quickly (you do unlock a bike early on but can’t take it with you off the 1st map) because they can carry some of the weight for you, allows you to easily out run most on enemies except for the BTs (not sure why they are called BTs not dived into the flavour text, will explore in the dad gamer section) if you run into them they will drag you kicking and screaming to a mini boss encounter if they can drag you down to the ground, signs work like Dark souls by leaving hints, requests and encouagements that can replenish your stamina which after a long haul though BT land is much needed (looking at you wind farm), lastly building, you can build structures like (what I’ve come across) watch towers to get a better view of an area, postboxes to drop off packages you can’t deliver for other players to drop off for extra likes (which rase your rating), power generators to recharge things and bridges, these structures will appear in other players games for them to use.

More mechanics, this the other USP when you add someone to the network other players items and structures appear because you don’t help other players directly or even see other players but you feel their presence by what has been left behind and you can leave a like or few hundred to rate the item. This is all fits together so well none of if feels like it’s been put in there just because, everything has been done for a reason and it shows.

Artistic merit, This game is choc full of symbolism there is a lot of talk about strands which is to symbolise connections and bridge gaps between people/different societies, you know typical Kojima fair but this is pure Kojima it all culminates in happy marriage between art and gameplay, all the little details from story to game mechanics make it an experience that just needs to be seen.

Gamer Dad plus points
+Generous auto saves (which can be triggered when safe by just resting)
+Saves start exactly where you save 
+Can pause any story videos and codec conversations
+Can be relaxing and fulfilling
+Emails highlight important information for you
+Not overly gory, more intense horror scares than gore
+Not much swearing
+Feel good vibes through out

Meaning that should you need to stop you can without any major loss in progession (or any at all) and is just a great game to turn on, listen to a podcast whilst you walk across some of the best in game scenery I have seen, I love looking at the environment and soaking it up

Gamer Dad Negitives
-LOTS to read if you want to flesh out the rest of the universe and story, my data page has over 99 entries to read and the emails do tend to waffle on a little much for my taste.
-Cinematics although infrequent but when they do happen take time (I had to skip 2 cinematics at the start of chapter 3 because my son was trying to turn off my PC after his nap and I needed to save)
Overall Gamer Dad recommendation: Good fit for dads

Anything i've not mentioned is fine or didn't leave an impression, i won't comment on graphics because it doesn't bother me, i've been gaming since the spectrum. I will only ever mention it should it be truely awful and ruin the game.

Thanks for reading, this is my first gamer dad review so hopefully they will get better with time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A very pretty game, filled with silence and beauty and rapey scenes with old ladies. The gameplay by itself is like a mechanically complex on foot delivery game with bits of action and horror, while the story takes a small amount of characters and makes you like all of them.
I would highly recommend.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
"Keep on Keeping on"
Yeah. "A Hideo Kojima Game." It's no Metal Gear Solid, but it ticks all his boxes. The focus is absolutely on the story; Gameplay will be either hate it or get used to it and take in the little things; primary mechanic is movement and balance of cargo, occasionaly, you knock out crazy unemployed delivery guys, sneak by ghosts, fight big ghost bosses. The Gameplay isn't that special, unique as it is.

The story is insane, absolutely. I won't bother to try to explain, you'll either love the bonkers creativity or get lost and confused too much - don't skip cutscenes, read the lore entries. The theme that Kojima goes for in this outing is all about the connections and bonds you make with others, no man is an Island, re-uniting divided people, death, Extinction, that sort of thing.

If you just want to walk around and enjoy the scenery or pass time being a mailman, this is a decent enough itch to scratch. If you're the kind to pour over story and lore, or just enjoy a game with a message, this is absolutely something to check out. But if you're looking for a more typical action game, you're not gonna find it here...think this thing has more cutscenes than MGS4. Keep some popcorn on hand, play it with a controller, lean back and relax, get sucked into another of Kojima's crazy prophetic experiences.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't quite know how to explain how a game about delivering packages across an Iceland-esque landscape is one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had. It takes would should be tedium and makes it incredibly gripping and compelling - I never wanted to stop playing. The story is standard Kojima - somehow coherent through being a complete mess.

I can't recommend this enough - I went in expecting to hate it and have fallen in love.

Finished the Game:

Started playing this mainly because the graphic looked very impressive and yea they do, one of the most detailed and clean looking games I have played for a while.  Found the gameplay so so, enough to keep you going but missions were bit repetitive. I really enjoy the usual storyline, definitely one of the best I have seen a game for a long time. I would have like to see the music tracks you collect been able to be play in the background e.g in vehicle, those long walks lol. Can make you feel a bit lonely sometime. Sorry it this review is a bit wordy, I don’t normally write reviews.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Alright so you're on the fence about this game ..... Ok you're a UPS/FEDEX delivery guy that eats bugs, drinks Monster energy in a post apocalyptic world who's worst nightmares came true with flying whales and a super villian with a terror network as well as a teleporting chic. Now mix that scenario with The Transporter, a delivery guy in a hostel world with some weapons and high tech devices also vehicles trying to reconnect the world VIA a network and you have Death Stranding. 

                  Game plays well on my ultrawide in 1440p, well optimized and a great port.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Great game with great soundtrack. Despite what the negative reviewers says, this is a unique game with unique game mechanics. If you are planning to buy this game, you should check all reviews and official videos and not base it on the developer. Checking those out are enough to say what the game is all about:[i] [u] [b] DELIVERING not gun fights and action,[/b] [/u] [/i] yes there some gun fights and action but not unlike the other Hideo Kojima games. Even when I first saw gameplay videos it look pretty boring until I played it myself.

Finished the game with all [spoiler] roads rebuilt, zipline network all throughout the areas on both eastern and central region, maxed the connection levels, and completed all standard orders on very hard. [/spoiler]

To those who want tips (also contains spoiler, i think):
[list]
    [*] [spoiler] First connect all preppers and distro centers to allow structure building and allow the game to add materials to roads from other players. [/spoiler]
    [*] [spoiler] If short on materials do materials standard order or hit the mules/terrorist camps. [/spoiler]
    [*] [spoiler] Before maxing out the connection level, wait for at least the zipline to become available to you and all will be much easier. That or unlock the truck from junk dealer and rebuild the roads. [/spoiler]
    [*] [spoiler] Thermals will destroy chilled deliveries. [/spoiler]
    [*] [spoiler] And last since most players don't know this, you can boost the speed of a vehicle by pressing the sprint button. Boost and roads are blessings especially when heavy loads of delivery. [/spoiler]
[/list]

KEEP ON KEEPING ON!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The first two hours were a drag, but I am absolutely loving it thus far. That being said, I understand and would agree this is not a game for everyone. With a hard-to-follow story, repetitive walking-simulator style gameplay, and very long and arguous quests that you need to plan-ahead for, this game has a fairly niche audience. However, if you are into slow-burn games of that nature with incredible attention to detail and introspective journeys, this games story and overall experience will encapsulate you.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is really something else when you try it hand-on. It is not a game you could appreciate just by reading review, and frankly, the early review this game got was going to be bad precisely because the game's mechanism was not meant for "early review". I came playing this game after already reading and watching the story of it, and I have to say, it was the gameplay that got me hooked and made me stick around. It is easy to label this game as walking simulator for people that have not tried it out, but it is such an understatement and disservice to this game's actual mechanisms. I don't even need to praise the story as it was apparently the "only good thing" that came out of this game according to critics, but you should really give it a shot now that it is out on steam. If the gameplay genuinely feels boring to you, just refund the game, you really just have to give it a try before casting judgement. Also, tips for more engaging action sequences and overall challenges, play on hard or very hard, you will be rewarded with a lot of satisfying battle out of it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Disclaimer: This is a game where you deliver packages.

If you go into this game with that bit of knowledge, and no other expectations, you are likely to enjoy it.

Gameplay: The gameplay is FANTASTIC. This is the first game that I have been able to play in 4K at 60FPS, because the game was built for it! The mechanics are smooth, and once you learn how to walk and run and keep your balance, it is actually very intuitive.

Story: The story is convoluted. Convoluted does not mean bad. I actually had my own theories while playing through the storyline, because the storytelling purposefully leaves blanks to be filled in later. Hideo Kojima tells the story that he wants to tell, and you can either decide to have an open mind about it and let the story unfold before you, or you can decide that you don't like that kind of storytelling.

Audio: I was able to play this game in full surround sound with my 5.1.2 system, no problems.

Verdict: I dunno. I liked it. That's my verdict.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hideo did it again, such a masterpiece.

Pros: 

1- Gameplay: Excellent gameplay. I became addicted with the delivering of the packages. Sam moves very smoothly, driving a vehicle is fun as well.
2- Action: There are moments when the game becomes a third person shooter and it is really fun and frenetic.
3- Story: One of the best story in a video game. Hideo makes this kind of things like no one else.
4- Duration: A lot to do, long game, a lot things to deliver.
5- Graphics: Awesome graphics impressive scenery 
6- Music: Great gloomy trip music. It really matched the atmosphere of the game
7- Difficulty: moderate, i played in normal difficulty and the game was enjoyed accordingly.
8- Replayable: I will wait some time to re play it. But I will definitely play it again. 

Cons

1- For some reason, in chapter 3 I had a lot of errors and crashes. For example i had the "Error violation" that is supposed to be related to the GPU drivers. But i had everything in place. I have checked everything that is related to. I have also re - downloaded the game but the error was  random
2-. Again in chapter three infinite loading times when I arrived in Every Terminal in that chapter. Specially when i  was riding a vehicle. Maybe this would need a fix.
3- Maybe it is done on purpose, but i would  have expected some fauna in the game o dead fauna at least. 
 
In conclusion, it is a 9.75/10 because this is a port of the PS4 game. Some errors needs to be fixed. But it does not change the fact that this game is a masterpiece. There is no game like this one in the industry. If you expect an action game like gears of war or call duty go and grab those games and forget about death stranding. This game, will reach you like no other game.

More than 29 years of gaming, so i would say i have some experience in it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Hands down the best game i have EVER played. Now before you think "oh another fan boy" I have NEVER played anything by Kojima. Not metal gear solid or anything. People like to say its a "walking simulator" i truly believe that those who said that never finished the game. Amazing boss fights, THE BEST STORY OF ANY GAME/MOVIE/OR TV SHOW I HAVE EVER SEEN, Amazing visuals, scary/sad/angry moments, fantastic voice acting/acting in general, and beautiful music. Highly would recommend anyone to play this. If you do for some reason feel bored (which i highly doubt you will.) Stick with it. The story is so good. I felt more like i was watching an fantastic movie rather than playing. Which isnt a bad thing. You still play 80% of the game, with the remaining 20% are the most spectacular cut scenes. Worth buying. glad i took the plunge.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A cult classic right out of the gate. Games have gotten to the point where great graphics are no longer the pinnacle of the whole enterprise, but a workhorse to evoke a certain mood or sentiment that plays to the story the creator wants to tell. Death Stranding is a prime example of how the graphics look great but I find myself immersed in this world that Kojima has created, with one crazy plot device introduced after another, but told with such sincerity and acted (mo-cap'd?) with such intensity that it really assaults not just eyeballs but the mind as well.

Astounding achievement, and even if you are not particularly impressed by the story or the gameplay, this experience deserves praise for just existing the way it does.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Super immersive game play, amazing graphics! Love every second of it

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: So, first and foremost, this game will confuse you when you go into it blind. As well you should be confused because piecing together this weird, twisted world is what a lot of the fun is. I can see a lot of people playing this for a couple hours and ditching it because they're confused and don't seem to like the idea of a delivery simulator. There really isn't much I, or any other reviewer, can say that can do this game justice. Seriously, find the time to actually sit down and play this game. It runs wonderfully on PC and the controls on Keyboard dont feel clunky at all. I have seen too many reviews from people who just play the first hour and base the whole game off that, this is a game that deserves all the love and praise Kojima has earned through the years.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's Kojima, need I say more?

if you don't like games that are a slower burn or sandbox-esque games then this one probably wont be for you. If you like fast twitch based combat and shooting games were there is action constantly then this game probably wont be for you. You can try and maybe you'll find something here for you but this game is what people would call a walking simulator (gets better later on with vehicles, ziplines, and speed exo-skeleton) and it's very unique in the AAA game genre and I would see this as a love it or hate it type game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I wanted to post a review, because I'd like to see more games like these.
I'm sure the gameplay is not something for everyone, and you should check before buying this.

What is important for me, is the spirit of the game, It's one of the first game where I felt so much connected with other, you use tools left behind, you contract other player to help, and you see your surrounding grow and morph. Everyone is contributing and not competing. This makes me feel really great.

Death is always a tragedy in this game and it's quite easy to empathize with the characters.

Great experience overall and I look forward to games axing the gameplay on something as hopeful and positive as this one !

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A fantastic game. The visuals, music, gameplay, and story telling are absolutely wonderful.

That being said, it isn't a game for everyone. This game is not combat based, but there are a few bits with combat.
This game is tagged "Walking Simulator" for a reason. It's about balance, carrying what you can, being cautious, planning ahead, and most importantly; patience.
To be more specific (With NO spoilers):

[h1]Story.[/h1]
This game is placed fairly modern day. The technology is boosted by the event this game is about, but other than that everything is standard. Science fiction for sure, but no flying cars or jetpacks.
The story is told mostly in cutscenes, with a few exceptions during a boss fight or exposition during gameplay. Not all the exposition is necessary and therefore some of it is tucked into seemingly regular delivery missions for mundane people.
Again, it's not required to understand the story, but more for the player that wants to dig deep. Or a completionist.
The story is told from the main characters perspective. He is neither ordinary or extraordinary. It's hard to explain without giving away spoilers.
Overall the story is excellent. It's more unique with a heavy focus on life, death, and limbo. It wants to tell you a story and that's that.

[h1]Storytelling.[/h1]
It does a good job getting the complicated world across. There are so many ways for lack of clarity in any topic in this game to result in confusion and an incoherent story/universe.
They take care to give you every bit of help along the way. While I'm 100% on board for stories that aren't always explained, this game didn't want to leave it open ended. There's no "1,000,000 possibilities" or questions unanswered. The game will show you the world, pose the questions, and answer all necessary questions.
If I were to compare the way they told this story I would say it's far more like a Quantic Dream game, like Detroit: Become Human. As opposed to God of War. The gameplay has some story, but it's 95% cutscenes.
But, to be clear, there are NO multiple paths to the end. There are NO multiple endings.
This game has one singular story. One beginning, middle, and end.
Quality story, world, and characters.

[h1]Visuals.[/h1]
Just ridiculously beautiful. I've run this game on max settings with 140fps easy. I run a GTX 1080. Nothing special hardware wise, but this game has wonderful optimization and runs smoothly.
There are reports that a few people have issues with the game crashing on loading up or fails to load up at all. I do not know how widespread that issue is. I have heard of it, seen it, and have seen a few solutions for those afflicted.
However, the support appears to be excellent and whomever is handling customer support is on the case. They have responded quickly and offered numerous potential fixes for a variety of problems.
The game has a lovingly crafted world. This game is screenshot heaven. With plenty of vantage points to appreciate scenery or boss fights that give fantastic shots of tension.

[h1]Gameplay.[/h1]
It's solid across the board. With very little focus on combat.
Your point is to deliver, not to fight. So the gameplay difficulty is almost entirely geared around how challenging it is to deliver your packages with minimal damage. There are many ways to achieve this. Use of vehicles for long distance, gear that help you traverse rough terrain, tools to assist in overcoming various obstacles. Your careful selection and balancing the weight of tools and packages, as well as the path you take to your destination; those sum up the difficulty of the game.
Combat is a part for sure and most people like more combat in games. Death Stranding doesn't really break new ground with combat. It's pretty simple. There are guns, your fists, and vehicles. You can use stealth (recommended), but when stealth isn't an option you can engage in decent combat.
The combat in the world like with MULES and some unsavory types really isn't anything special. Shoot them or not. Kill them or not. Killing results in a greater number of BTs in the area, which makes life more difficult. So you should be careful of that.
The combat the game puts you in, like in a boss fight, isn't unique. Once more you have common weapons like a handgun, assault rifle, rocket launcher, etc. You aim, you shoot, the boss gets hurt.
Combat is smooth, but definitely nothing ground breaking. Once more, with feeling; this game doesn't focus on combat.

[h1]Dialogue/Characters.[/h1]
This area gets some flak at times. Some people love the characters, some people hate them.
Personally, I adore them. I had my healthy suspicions at first of their intent or, outside of the game, their writing and design. But as I played more I found myself growing fond of the characters and their strangeness.
The dialogue could definitely be worked on in a few areas. Certain conversations feel forced or lacking in sincereity. It can feel awkward or, for me, sometimes cringey.
Not that it detracts from the game really. After playing it and getting deeper into the story I had adjusted quickly to how awkward some things were. Some people were strange and there were rational reasons for it. A few rare moments where I wanted to take the script to Kojima Productions, lay it out in front of them, and ask what were they thinking.
At the end of the day, having completed the story in this game, I can now say I care for these characters. Their awkwardness, their unusual behaviors. At the end of it all it kind of just came together for me and all I wanted to see is what happens to them now.
So a lot of the strange issues with dialogue or writing did not detract from the story itself.

There are a few characters that utter puns in this game and they know who they are.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
I'm trying not to give any spoilers at all so the review is safe to read. It is hard trying to give criticism to something I cannot explain.
I'm not a professional reviewer and I very rarely review anything at all. So my thoughts are not as organized or as well put as others. I would definitely look through a good number of reviews before making a decision to buy.

This game is unique. It is its own kind and I love it. I want to see another Death Stranding or more games like it.
I think this is a rare game that belongs up there with the great games of the last few decades.

I do not believe this game "has a little something for everyone" as IGN likes to list in all their reviews.

This game has a lot for the right players and absolutely nothing for others.
People who prefer a game to drop you in and say "Go play!" This is not that kind of game.
People who prefer a game to tell you a story subtly. This is not that kind of game.
People who like fast paced games, combat oriented games, or games that turn you loose with a thousand different options.
This is not that kind of game.

You have one goal and only one way to get it done. The path is rough and riddled with rocks, mountains, rivers, and frustration. You have to build the road to cross it and even then you are forced to traverse the worst terrain with the most delicate cargo. You have a task that must be repeated a hundred times.
This game is tedious and slow. Patience really is a virtue here.

But I love this game. Despite the hours I spent walking from city to city or to the small prepper shelters out and about, I never listened to music, watched a video on my other monitor, or had anything playing in the background while I traveled. I was always in the moment.

Not a lot of people will pay $60 to trip on a rock and destroy all your fragile cargo you just spent the last 15 minutes struggling your way up a mountain to deliver.

Also, the more I play this game the more I realize no one at Kojima Productions has ever either driven a vehicle or been in one being driven.

I highly recommend this game. But if it's not your style, than wait for Horizon: Zero Dawn. That game is fantastic too.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I came into the game thinking it might get mindlessly boring... however after 126 hours of playing the game and nearly pulling off a 100% Completion... I utterly miss playing this game. 

It's something about the 'Work Together' attitude that this game breathes. Doing the deliveries and shaping the world with other unknown people was just remarkable. Watching paths open up and form right as you're playing the game is brilliant. I haven't even mentioned the fantastic story line and acting. 

I honestly wish there was more drive (ha) to keep playing the game. So far I jump back into it to see how the roads are doing and do some repair runs.

To everyone else that was playing around the same time I was... Thank You. Thank you for the bridges, the shelters, the roads, the vehicles, the clues.... everything. No raging from attempting to be competitive, or frustrations because I was having an off day. Just me, other friendly people, and the road. 

Thank you. This game was a pleasure to play and I hope anyone reading this give it a go.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: To call Death Stranding a bad game is a courtesy that it does not deserve. Death Stranding is an offensive assault on your intelligence. Those who say otherwise are merely pandering to the Kojima hype surrounding this title. This game is so lacking in content that it is decades behind a modern open world AAA title. A perfect metaphor for the enjoyable content found in this game can be seen in the screenshots above this comment. What do you see in the vast majority of those screenshots? Rocks? Grass? And not much more. This game is hollow. It is empty. There's just nothing there. The story is so overly complicated that it is constantly tripping over itself. The textures are good, but the graphics are terrible. How can that be? Density. This game has nice AAA textures with the density of a game that came out 20 years ago. And finally, the game-play. If the game-play were good, I could forgive any other offense, but it's not. It's the worst part of the game. Take a moment to think about other open world games. The Witcher 3, Skyrim, Fallout, Red Dead 2, hell, even GTA V and Assassin's Creed. There are things to do. You may run into an interesting NPC, find a location worthy of exploration, discover some interesting treasure, a unique vehicle or weapon, you may be impressed by the animals you see and how they interact with one another, or a random event taking place, there are many ways to breath life into a sandbox game. Death Stranding employs none of these techniques. It's you, a copy and pasted terrain, and some crates walking A to B, A to B, A to B. THAT'S IT. To summarize, Death Stranding is 10 minutes of genuinely interesting game-play diluted over 45 hours, a game that is so inferior  and lacking in content compared to other titles available that it is baffling that a studio would actually produce it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is one of the best videogames I've played in my lifetime. The setting and the creative imagination of this game is simply astounding and the story is both intriguing and has a powerful emotional finale at the end.

Also, you really don't need me to describe how gorgeous this game looks. The performances of the actors are excellent as well - specially Tommie Earl Jenkins (Die-hardman) and Mads Mikkelsen (Cliff). Some of these scenes just blew me away.

The PC port is also excellent and the extra smoothness due to the increased framerate makes for a much better experience on PC. The game also has excellent controller support including DualShock 4 and even uses the impulse triggers found on the Xbox One controller! Very cool.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Pros:
Story and everything about it. No spoilers, but trust me it was amazing.
Runs well FPS wise
Hands down the best visuals for any game I've personally played
Has the distinct Kojima charm


Cons:
The gameplay got boring for me about half way through the game. It was novel at first to try and pick up as much stuff as possible, but in the latter half I found myself rushing through missions just to see the next cutscene. I wont go into too much detail, but know that if you're playing Death Stranding for the gameplay you might be disappointed.
I encountered a few performance issues. My game crashed about 10 times throughout my playthrough. Nothing too crazy, but still worth noting. Also, if you go too far too fast on a vehicle, expect to spend some time loading. It may have been my system(somehow, even though I'm running an NVME SSD???), but I would sometimes spend over a minute loading smack dab in the middle of gameplay. It really broke the immersion a few times.


I personally loved the game in the end, but to each their own. TLDR, if you like story based games, buy this right now. If you don't give a shit about story, definitely pass.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I recommend it because I'm glad I played it, BUT you should read my review and decide for yourself because the gameplay really is focused on walking or driving on rough, uneven ground without damaging cargo.

The graphics are great and everyone seems to agree that it's ported very well. I was very surprised I could run it in 4k with (I think) everything set to the max setting with my 1060.

The story is unique and interesting and as weird as you could hope for (you poop at bases and then get poop grenades to throw at enemies because yOu hAvE sPeCiAl DnA), it has famous people in it like a movie.

The gameplay is slow-paced but kind of soothing because you travel through environments and really pay attention to them. In all honesty, before I finished the game I had gotten tired of navigating environments. It's rocky everywhere so you're either walking or driving around or over rocks, or slowwwwly walking in snow, etc.

I really enjoyed the online aspect, and it's rewarding to see that you built a bridge and hundreds of people gave you likes because it helped them too. Plus you'll come across ladders or recharging stations or helpful signs that other people placed, and you appreciate them doing it.

Honestly it's pretty easy unless you go for high difficulty. It rewards you for doing extra side missions, and you could put a lot more time in than I did.

The bottom line is this is a AAA game that's based around traversing environments. There is shooty stuff but it's NOT the focus. I don't regret paying full price but also I rushed through the last 4 or 5 hours because I was tired of the traversal.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game fills a niche that I think a lot of people have been longing for, a game where the challenge lies not in twitch reactions or precise aiming, but the adventure itself. 

Where going from A to B in most open world games is at best a nice disconnect from the action and at worst a tedious chore, in Death Stranding it is the challenge, the experience. It allows for players to approach the problem of getting somewhere in their own fashion and pace, and does so with a wonderful pacing. Even though a route may seem nearly insurmountable at first, it gives a great feeling of accomplishment and relief when you arrive, goods safely in hand. This is coupled with a great story that unfolds slowly at first, but becomes more intense the deeper you get. 

Rest assured that, story-wise, this is one of those games that challenges you with a lot of mysteries, but answers them all by the time you are done, in a way that I'd wager very few would find predictable.

The only downside sticking out for me would be the actual fights that occur a few times. The nature of the controls make battles seem unnecessarily clunky, and bosses sometimes have way higher health pools than what is necessary. Luckily, such fights are few and far between.

Important to note, I would recommend going as high as you are comfortable with in difficulty, as it really does improve the experience, and immersion into the story by making it more challenging. 

All in all I'd say, on a scale where 1 is trash and 10 is a must play, it's a solid 9/10 if not actually 10, only being hampered by somewhat lackluster boss fights. This score is however assuming that you are not looking for yet another MGS, or yet another Assassins Creed. This is miles from being either, the memes about it being a walking simulator are not far off, but it does what it does with great conviction and a very obviously large amount of heart and soul poured into it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
you think this is a nice game with cool graphics and a story like from a movie or a book.
but I gotta tell you, its not as nice as it seems.
but lets talk about the good things first:

+ graphics are good, just as good as they are in any ubisoft game (division2/ac odyssey)

+ mvp of the game was the audio designer, such a genius!!!!

+ the implemented songs that were added on certain triggered spots are nice, but they're not very different to eachother. maybe cause most of them are by the same band

+ the visual design of the fonts the interface the scanner, looks beautiful

+ dynamic effects like weather switching from sunny to rain/snow or even give u a total whiteout or bossfights and just everything that moves looks excellent

+ scanning multiple celebrities into a game isnt always a good thing but some were lovely to see, such as "margaret qualley" who plays Lockne and Mama or "Tommie Earl Jenkins" as Die-Hardman. Also Mads Mikkelsen was pretty fitting at some scenes

+ the movement feels real, the combat the step-by-step walking felt very nice

lets hop to the negative parts of the game:

- it takes 3hrs with maybe 30min of actual gameplay to get into the game and you're already 100% confused what all this is supposed to mean

- once theres no cutscene to watch you just grind yourself thru delivery missions doing kind of the same over and over again. you can upgrade structures you build or just do nothing cause u dont have to to complete the game. half of the structures are already placed by other players and thats enough to reach your targets most of the time

- as soon as u end up in an npc conversation it just never seem to end quickly enough. their chatting is extended to the maximum and another point why this game might make u sleepy af

- the first bossfight on "normal" difficulty wasnt doing anything at all, way too easy, the other bossfights are kinda easy too cause the game doesn't want you to die I guess. and with that being said, there's the option to donate gear which then might appear in other players bossfights. as far as I know is that once you use your "5" key to yell for other players like "hello I'm sam" or whatsoever turns into "I need help" during a bossfight which then lets grey figures appear that throw weapons and medkits at you to just pick it up and continue fighting. so you can just be unprepared as usual. 

- for 9 episodes you been chasing an evil guy that you finally beat in episode 9, but the game isnt over yet... it couldve been done but there are 6 more episodes to play. therefore the dramatical ending was a bit useless. as if they added more and more content to the game cause they had a bit more time to invest.

- the ending of the game is sooo stretched out ... I stopped counting how many creditrolls I noticed, it just keeps going on and on..  and within the last 3 hrs theres no actual gameplay ( zzzZZZ )

- the acting looks awful sometimes, not sure what rigs they used to scan those people but ninja theory did it way better. if you like those games where they scanned actual people into a game, u gotta check out hellblade. thats pure perfection which blends from game to cutscene with such a nice transition that you won't even notice it. 

- the interface of death stranding is an absolute mess. the cargo management and mission / item windows are a pain to scroll through. and after each mission you're just skipping for your life...  entering a vehicle, dropping items, doing things in a terminal.. takes way too long for a game thats focused on cargo delivery.

- is there even a way to die in this game? or is it just trying to scare you and thats it ? cause once you see a bt, you can just act like being caught and then run out of the area with ease instead of sneaking around for hours.

- the story kept being confusing til the very end, and still then it has lots of things that don't make any sense.

result:

if you still want to play this game.. get it somewhere cheaper , maybe with a voucher discount or something like that.
40hrs were enough, the rest was just work to finally uninstall it.

but it was worth the money just to see margaret qualley ♥

A Hideo Kojima Game = Poorly Written Story with "fun" gameplay

Mama? I got pissed off how bad he did her.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Oh, boy, where do I start. 
Do I recommend this game? 100% Yes. Once in a life time experience. But I want to tell you, that you HAVE to be in a mood for something more than a game. 
This game is about death, obviously; about inevitable end of everything and your choice to accept it or to fight it; about love of a father - aggressive, defensive, warrior-like love; about love of a mother - caring and protecting; about family; about conflict negotiating; about coping with fear; about searching for something good when everything feels like falling apart; about revenge; about sacrifice.
But in the end - this game is about life, with all the obstacles, people, connections, deaths. 
This game rises so many questions - for 1 answered there's 5 unanswered, yet, it's awesome to turn on your imagination to try to understand what's this all about. 
You might feel like burnt out at some point - just make a pause and return. Or just continue the story which unlocks you all the possibilities to overcome the challenges. 
It's all about journey. 

My review might looks confusing, but this is what I feel right now, a confusion. And deep sorrow for finishing the game, because if I could - I would delete my memories of it just to play it again. 

Definitely - this is the game 100% WORTH of your support. And we need to see more such original AAA projects.  

P.S.: If you want to stay in the mood - try to read Haruki Murakami's "Kafka on the shore" ;)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm currently on chapter three of Death Stranding, and I have 30+ hours played. 

Is DS an action game? Not really. Is it MGS? No. Is it perfect? Not quite. Is it immersive? Absolutely. Is it unlike anything I've played. Without a doubt. Is it worth a buy? There is no question. 

From the unbelievable visual detail to the unforgettable soundtrack, Death Stranding draws players in and securely holds their attention like precious cargo. It carries that attention across spanning landscapes, thought provoking dialogue, and immensely tense encounters with the other side. 

There are a certainly things Death Stranding doesn't do right, but if nothing else this game masterfully delivers its message.

Kojima set out to build a game that pushed players towards connection; Death Stranding connected with me as one of the most engaging, rewarding, and meditative experiences I've enjoyed in a long time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: An absolute masterpiece.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If you think it's going to be a walking simulator, you're getting filtered. 

It reminds me of MGS4, where the focus is on telling a complete story. The game is not heavy on action. You can go into camps where you can fight, but the story only has a handful of action sequences. It is a bit convoluted, which you might expect if you played other Kojima games.

The best thing about the game is its uniqueness. So many new games today are just remakes or remasters just the same game with a different paint job. This is something completely different. It's a game for the sake of a game not making money. You can feel a lot of love went into it. I love it for that reason.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is a simulator. 

If you've ever been hiking, and had to decide what to take & how much, considering the total weight and terrain, and then going on that hike, this game is very similar to that sort of experience. But how is that fun in a game? Without spoiling Death Stranding, the game constantly rewards you for each successful "hike" most often by giving you a new feature, items, vehicle types, weapon types, and tool types for the player to increasingly consider which items to take on the NEXT hike. For example, if your path goes through an enemy camp or through a ghost-zone, you'll have to take items accordingly. A smoke-emitting decoy cargo box is much more interesting to the enemy camp than it would be for the ghosts, who only care about how close you get to them. If you get too close, then you'll need to do some damage. They're not difficult fights, but they're there to distract you from the rest of the game.

What you're NOT doing is calculating and remembering the weight of each individual item, constantly fretting over it's position on your back or if you've carried too much. Instead, you simply accept the delivery order, use the "auto-arrange" button, and carefully consider what you can take on your next hike within the clearly defined "load limit" which is actually quite generous. 

For the Online structures, I found them to be an optional but very neat part of the game. Someone else built a bridge over a river that saved you the trouble from trying to find a rocky spot to make a makeshift ladder bridge. Someone else placed a convenient rope down a mountainside or put a generator just before the next unconnected zone. You're not always spoiled by these luxuries, and plenty of times you place them yourself. Your first time into each "zone" will not have any player-built structures in them, they'll only appear after you satisfy the requirement to "connect" that area (which most often is easily done by finishing story quests). 

Story is classic Kojima. It doesn't make much sense, and tries very hard to make broad philosophical pokes but it really just wax and wanes. It does its job by keeping you interested in the world of Death Stranding itself.

Excellent game if you enjoy simulators.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
so personally i love the game. however it's not a game that i would recommend it to (most) other people. if you're fan of Metal Gear series than i dont think this is the game for you. Just because this game is not a  shooter game  like previous games made by Hideo Kojima.  (there is a little bit of third-person shooting gameplay)

so the game starts off by going through a cutscenes (btw theres LOTS of cutscenes) and intorduce you to the cargo carrying mechanics and deliver packages in a open world. You might get bored really quickly because the story takes off very slowly and weird at beginning. it starts to get good from about 10 hours in. but around the end it becomes all worth it. 

this is also a punishing game when you're going though a tough terrains and one mistake causes your packages to be destroyed or lost. you might scream in rage or cry. That's when you place some equipment. so not only can you get yourself out of tough situations but also for the other players. and that's the whole point of this game. you connect by helping others and being helped by stuff left by other players. I remember someone left a "all terrain skeleton" in the random postbox while i was stuck in the snowy mountain. i was so happy to find it and climb the rest of the mountain to my destination. its kind of a wholesome game of helping each others out even though we don't see each other in the game. you can "like" the stuff people built as in 'nice' or 'thank you'


here's some main things in game that i didn't like. 

-ads. theres few ads in game like:  the tv show Norman Reedus is in. i just don't like this because its breaking the forth wall and cuts away from the immersion of playing the game and also for the main character Sam. 

-cutscenes. like i mentioned above, there's few too many unnecessary cutscenes. i find myself also clicking the skip button all the time when Sam is in private room. (safe house) 
 
-inventory management. its made by Hideo Kojima and you know he loves those crazy inventory management mechanics like MGS5. 

also the price. its a really hard choice to make for a game that you're not too sure about. if money is the problem then i recommend PS4 version. its on sale for $30CAD on amazon at the time I'm typing this. I just chose to pay full price on steam because of the fps and graphics setting that can be offered for the PC version. i heard that console version's fps is capped at 30 fps (you might wanna look it up) but honestly didnt look that bad on youtube review i saw. 


if you're looking for a weird + beautiful game to experience, this is it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Solid game. Time consuming, but engaging. Feels like you arent really doing anything for a long time, but it helps with the muscle memory of the extremely detailed menus and completion routines.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: More games need to have a new and exciting story like this. Yes some areas will get a little slow but well worth it in the end.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'll have to wait for the afterglow to fade, before I can decide if this is truly my all-time favorite game. I can say without a doubt that it has the best story and best acting out of any game I've ever played.

The gameplay isn't perfect, but it's close. It's the same with the pacing of the game. 

It is without a doubt Hideo Kojima's crowning masterpiece, and really unlike anything I've played before. Perhaps the closest game I can link it to is Shadow of the Colossus, in that I feel both game transcend into the realm of legitimate art.

At the very least I feel that everyone should give this game a shot. It's certainly not for everyone, but for me it was an absolute treasure.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Not really sure what i liked about this game, I should NOT like this game. But i do. 
It is a walking simulator. It wakes you work to build roads, and it makes you work to obtain vehicles. You can fight, and you can shoot, but killing isn't the object. If you do kill, (which, im not sure you can) you get a massive crater. Puzzling game. Interesting story.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game evoked many feelings for me, and not all of them were pleasant. In fact, while I enjoyed most this game, and even loved some of it, there are a few glaring issues that are impossible to ignore and did take away some level of enjoyment I had. But, it's art. It's experimental and pushes the boundries. So those things can be overlooked right?

Let's start with the good. 

I'm reminded of some of my enjoyment from Zelda: BotW. You travel across the land, except now the game mechanics are built around that traversal. Lately, the most boring thing you can tell me to do, is to kill a room full of enemies, especially if killing them means shooting them. Majority of video games ask you to kill something, over and over again. This game, how ever, asks you to cross a river, and it's tense. You're brain has to work out all these different possibilities of what could happen. You could get swept away, you could trip on a rock, maybe you should build a ladder, but you might need that ladder later, so maybe if you look further down the stream you'll find a smaller gap you can jump over, or maybe another player will have built something that aided you. It's like using muscles my brain has never really gotten to work out in a video game. Early game is cross river, towards the end you'll be climbing deadly mountain passes and clifffaces, all whilst hauling around tons and tons of packages and there's real tension when you trip and watch your packages start floating down a river or rolling down a hill. It brings out a lot of the same feelings I have when playing a game like Animal Crossing or Harvest Moon. 

While your going from point A to point B, your greeted with beautiful, otherworldly vistas. They are mostly barren and without life, yet each area you come across has the touch of having been meticulously hand-painted by someone. Every rock placement, and figuration, and deformation looks stunning and I swear that someone went over every area of this damn place with the amount care and detail that a landscape artist spends on a painting. Every time I looked up, my jaw dropped. The colors are surreal and alien, you feel like your on another planet so often that I'd have to slow my pace and just walk slowly, taking it all in. The sci-fi elements are outstanding, from the design to the implications in the world you explore amazing. Here's where the first issue comes up.

Kojima spills soooo many beans within the first several hours, that it makes it feel like so much of what he put in the trailers was just for hype. All the lore slaps you in the face with about two books full of theories and emails from people you do not care about. I don't know if I've ever been less interested in NPC's wants and needs. Most the people you meet, you never actually meet! You just get a hologram of them telling you thanks for the delivery, by the way, here's my opinions and theories on everything. Even the main cast of characters that the game is like this, they tell you should care about them an why. Most characters only one or two moments where they actually do anything, and most of this happens in the later half. Even more important moments happen in the last 10%. It's a shame too, because some of the actors really fucking sell their performances. There's two at the very end that are nearly Oscar worthy.

It's jarring because the whole game is about connection with other people. Yet so many of these connections are emails, emails are people who never are willing to leave there homes to say hi to you. It's a little to real to the current state of the world (even before covid-19) where most people spend more time on their cellphones than with actual people, and again, MAYBE that was the point. There's even a metaphor by making what is basically your cellphone into a handcuff. I can't tell how much of this was intentional, avent garde stuff that Kojima likes to try to pull off with MGS2 and Phantom Pain, or if it's just actually bad and Kojima's ego has just gotten to him a bit to where he assumes anything he comes up will be genius. Or he's gotten tired, he's already made plenty of games with iconic characters, maybe he just didnt wanna try and prove himself again. Probably a bit of both. 

Honestly, that's okay. I came here for a lonely trek across strange lands doing weird Kojima things like taking a bath in hotsprings while singing to a baby in a jar whilst a parellel universe version of myself joins in from afar.

That being said, the trek sometimes disappointed me too. The game does not reward exploration. Any time I strode off the beaten path and went where the game didn't want to me to go, I returned back the that lonesome road in tears. Either what I found wasn't suppose to be found yet and could only be accessed later in the story, or just had no real relevance despite looking important. On the latter for example, there's this huge crater that's there because of story reasons, and there's this little narrow passageway seemingly off the map, being a noticable part the game will allow you to explore. Yet the moment you get to the top of the crater, you hit an invisible wall. The area is shaped in a way that is BEGGING me to explore it, but I go there and, nothing? Really? Are you kidding? I'm still mad about this. I'm mad how many times I dared explore only to find I had wasted my time. Even if there was nothing to physically obtain, just let me look inside the crater! I wanna see it! That's why we go on hikes right? I still can't understand why its programmed this way.

One more thing I loved about this game. The action, when it hits, hits hard. Some set pieces blew me [spoiler]haha pun[/spoiler] away. For those of you wondering if there's more to do than just haul packages, you do get weapons, and there are enemies. They are far and few in between, but I found that made their encounters more meaningful and more tense. I didn't defeat these men cuz the game told me that's what I should do, I defeated them to protect my precious cargo. [spoiler] The boss fights are some of the best I've seen in any game ever. I'm making this a spoiler because I didn't even know there were bosses in this game and I was pleasantly surprised. [/spoiler]

Oh yeah, the music in this game is also great. It fits the tone of the game so well and anytime a track came on I felt great.

Final thoughts, there is also some outstanding imagery the game uses. If you've seen any of the trailers or images you probably know what I am talking about. There's some stuff in cut scenes that looks fantastic, but doesn't ever give you a good enough reason for why it's happening, and stumbles over itself trying to make sure you get why it's important. 

TL;DR. This game is a clusterfuck of amazing moments, music, vistas, refreshing gameplay, solid performances from both voice and motion capped actors, art design, and epic high-octane action. But they all sort of feel like they exist within a vacuum, floating around, and having no real connection to each other. I imagine Kojima sitting there, bless his heart, coming up with these fantastic ideas, seeing all these cool things happen in his mind, and saying "Wouldn't it be cool if this also happened?" And his staff is like "Ahh! Yes Kojima-san, excellent idea. But, what does that have to do with the story?" To which he paid no mind, he merely wanted to see all these things in his game. I actually really admire that. I feel like it's the type of game you would have gotten if you had given a few million dollars to a child, right down to the green army figures you collect, and the monster energy drink.

You know if you'll enjoy this game or not. If you like walking sims, and new takes on the video game medium as a whole, then you'll enjoy this. If it looks boring, then it will probably bore you. This game is art. It's why there are so many polarizing opinions on it, because it breaks the mold. And in that sense, it's worth experiencing.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: dX

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Lets get one thing straight, this game was seriously misunderstood at launch, didn't help that all the media and early reviews of this game deemed it a 'walking simulator' or 'no gameplay'. Its a shame because this is truely a gem of a game that more people should play. Yes you deliver packages from point A to B 90% of the game, and you might ask, 'whats the appeal of that?'. Well let me tell you, as cliche as it sounds, its not about the packages themselves but the journey you had. This game is all about making connections, time and time again Sam is reminded he brings people together and thats what you do in this game. You connect a broken american together by essentially hooking up their internet so they can use their 3D printers lol.

This game is beautiful, its captivating, it has amazing story telling, and top notch voice acting. Not to mention it has an addictive game loop. Its hard to understand the draw of this game if all you have seen from others is the frustrations and inconveniences set by the games mechanics. However, once you make it about 3 hours in and the game opens up its gorgeous open world, you really can appreciate the grind of this game. I would hardly call it a grind, as i look at all the hours i've accumulated, i can remember so many instances where i told myself 'just one hour today', only to see the next moment i checked the time, 4 hours had gone by. 

Its the satisfaction you get from delivering these packages to the NPCs, the fact that every path you take makes it easier for the person to come after you. This open world of broken america feels so empty and daunting at first, but once you unlock zip lines and you're wizzing past previous stretches of land you once trecked and see all those blue lights of the watch towers, bridges, roads, generators, vehicles, the world seems so much more inviting and developed. 

Now i understand the criticisms of this game, yes the story is long, yes you're walking, and absolutely YES is the UI the weakest link in this game, but if you already think the previous work of Kojima in the MGS series was not your taste, maybe this isnt for you as this is really peak kojima. Still, i implore you to at least try this game, if not for the story, then for the world, if not for that, then how about the enemies in this game.

About those, i feel like thats an entirely different game. You've probably seen some boss fights online and thought 'wtf is this' well its bat sh*t crazy let me tell you. Theres really two different games in Death Stranding,  you deliver packages in one game and then fight BTs in the second layer of it. Now the gun play is a little janky at time, its definitely no shooter, and i dont think its trying to be. I played this game on Very hard and i actually had a difficult time in SOME parts. Most the time you can just put this game on easy and enjoy the story and cut scenes unbothered, however it would do it injustice if you didnt at least try to fight the enemies in this game. The boss fights are a spectical in itself and you might find yourself in awe looking before you die and get pulled into the seam. You should really push through to the end of this game and ACTUALLY finished it around the 45 hour mark to see, just some incredible battles that make you think 'how did anyone think of this?'.

Some things that really stand out in this game that make the gameplay even better is the sound design. I played MGSV on console and PC and thats probably one if not the best stealth game ever. This game is no MGS game BUT its still pretty good. Everything makes a sound in this game and everything rewards the player, like the sound of likes you get from pretty much everything you do in the game. The guns sound great, the rain, the noise your little spinny thing make, the BTs are quite scary at times early on, BB even when crying still sounds good. 

In conclusion, this game is amazing. Its truely a masterpiece in my opinion and deserves all the praise it gets. Its story is moving, its combat enticing, its game mechanics are tricky but rewarding, its greater meaning and metaphors will have me ponder this game for some time long past this games prime. Its worth every penny and you should absolutely give this game a chance. Theres so many things i want to bring up, but at the end of the day, you'll play it and see how it all clicks and then you'll be smiling on your face when you reach the top of that mountain, or cross that river, or build that road.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Edit after some consideration: So I feel like I've taken off Sam's Gold Sunglasses and starting to see some issues with DS. Mainly in the difficulty balance. I feel like DS did a really bad job of minimizing spoilers (I had the no spoilers option enabled). I was seeing Safe Houses before I could build them myself (for example). There was WAY too much help. I never came close to running out of ammo and never needed to eat a cryptobiote until the fight with Higgs. I always had some extra blood. There were always way too many player structures, I never needed to place anything other than a few zip lines after I opened up a place because there was an abundance of player structures. I also 5 starred every place, which may have contributed to this, but I just with there was about half as much help.

If a higher difficulty would have fixed this issue, that's my fault I guess, but I remember having the impression that all difficulty was based on combat.

I never died on Normal difficulty. Because I was warned not to kill anyone, I never got to see what happened when someone died. That is kinda my fault, but I just had no clue what would happen and didn't want to screw up my playthrough.

This game is great, I would play it again if there was a major expansion. However it wasn't without some big flaws that I needed to overlook.

Final Review after 130+ hours: Finally completed the game (not 100%) and I can say that I enjoyed 99% of it. The end cutscenes were extremely overkill. The over acting and repeated scenes really started to kill the epicness they were trying to achieve. However, in the end, I was fine with it. I get that they wanted to tie up all loose ends and they definately did so. I'll tell you what though, I guessed every twist from the very beginning, not exactly, but for the most part everytime a new character or concept was introduced, I started to puzzle everything together and the end only confirmed my suspicions. Again, I loved this game so much and endured what I didn't enjoy because I know that the devs put their soul into it.

However, after getting to the end and having the option to 100% it. After 131 hours, I'm done. Time to move on to the next epic game. I'll always remember how great this game is and would always recommend it to anyone. Probably one of the best games I've played in maybe 10 years.

Edit after 100 hours: This game still has me entranced. I just can't get away from it. Although I do have the occasional crash, I never lose too much progress due to its great autosave and manual save system. However, I do wish that it would autosave when leaving a safe house/private room.

My only real complaint is that the only place you can customize your backpack and apply a backpack cover is in a private room. It should really be something you do at a kiosk, as forgetting to do so and then having to go back into the private room is such a pain in the ass.

Other than that, and the desire to be able to listen to music in a vehicle, this game is 9/10 for me even after 100 hours. As much as I want to play HZD, I'm happy waiting until I 100% this game. In fact, I'm now so enticed by Kojima that I might even play MGSV before HZD.

WOOOT! A game so great I bought it twice! I like how they made the PC version with lots of configuration options, can't wait to try it out with keyboard mouse. Though I suspect it will still be better via controller.

FYI, I have this game on PS4, but just don't care for the console. I probably put 30-40 hours before deciding to wait for the PC port.

The story makes no sense from the beginning and can be quite confusing for a while, but once it clicks, it's super cool.

It looks like this game is a mailman sim in a dystopian future, and it is, but there is way more to it. The acting is superb, the atmosphere is amazing. At first I didn't like the emoji holograms everywhere, but you kind of understand why they did this. Either way, you can just turn them off if you don't like them.

A lot mention that this game is repetitive and it is, but the game is all about the story, and the progression. It's a relaxing, casual game that can become very tense at times. It can be frustrating as well, but once you get the hang of everything, it gets easier.

It's probably not for everyone, but no game is. I immensely enjoyed it and it was certainly my game of the year in 2019.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm not much of a gamer, but DS looked interesting so I gave it a go. For me, the game had two main problems:
- First it seemed full of missed opportunities.
- Second, it couldn't decide what it wanted to be and consequently didn't do any one thing as well as it could have.

The setting is beautiful, and it's great to explore. The problem is the exploring doesn't yield anything interesting. No deep hidden secrets at the top of a mountain, or interesting Easter eggs. The datachips you find are mostly unimportant and don't reveal anything interesting - in fact they just appear to be a few factoids about the game designers favorite things - and seem incredibly egotistical.

I like the premise of being a porter that has to overcome difficult obstacles - trouble is, once you have access to bikes, every delivery is easy! It then becomes a driving game, and the trouble with that is the driving mechanics are f**king abysmal, and easily the worst aspect.

The game then morphs into a building game briefly, but again there's no real reward for building roads, unless you're one of those Facebook types that live for likes. Building structures that can be used by other players, also makes the game easier for everyone, which is silly. So it becomes a little MMO with weakly interacting players for a while. But this feels mostly unrewarding too and often annoying with all the signs and structures dotted EVERYWHERE! It destroys the sense of being remote that the game starts with.

BTs can all be circumvented or killed with exactly the same tactics with a couple of exceptions. They are certainly interesting and spooky though, they add a real sense of dread.

The sudden morphing into a FPS game is done well, but too brief and it doesn't fit super well with the backpack mechanics of the game. It's stunning scenery, but the FPS game sections are repetitive.

The cut scenes are interesting, but yes they are WAY too long at times.

The game really suffers from an identity crisis, it's a jack of all trades and a master of none. These also seems to be true of the character Sam, his personality seems entirely inconsistent. He goes from being peaceful, lovable, and whimsical, to gruff, belligerent, and antisocial - with no seeming cause for his personality changes. The message the game is trying to portray seems equally inconstant, just for the sake of it.

The design, theme, and setting is amazing, and at moments it really shines. But overall it's tripping over itself trying to be everything and trying way too hard to be clever.

The UI is extremely cluttered too.

Overall, definitely worth a play, a thinking persons game that just fails to deliver on it's promises. I think it would have been better focusing more an the isolation, desolation, mystery, travel and adventure aspect, mixed in with the deliveries.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Was looking forward on playing this game but all I came across was a variety of bugs throughout my 2 hours of playing the game. In the prologue, a cutscene came up where Sam(The main character) has to burn this body but Sams body just disappeared for me and all you saw was a floating head. Then where he goes and sees the president and little bit after that, Sams eyeballs start shooting out of his head. Then after when im trying to get away from the BT's, his arms disappeared. I do not recommend this game at all for $60 unless there is a sale or these bugs get fixed.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I played through the first few episodes on PS4, but for whatever reason, life happened and I didn't jump back on it until I bought it for my PC. The game is DAZZLING even on mid end specs that I've seen, and even more so on high/enthusiast level builds. The story is amazingly well thought out, with characters that are well written, with some giving performances (Mads's Character as well as Die Hardman) that are absolutely OSCAR WORTHY IMO.  Gameplay is great but not without hiccups, the physics are a bit janky, and vehicles are rough to control, sometimes they contradict what you think they should do. Combat while fun in certain situations is sort of an after thought here, this is mainly a critique toward enemy AI and not toward Sam's combat options, abilities or weaponry.  The last two real highlights of the game are honest to god, the meta game of delivering packages and managing yourself and inventory of items for your journeys, and the SOUNDTRACK. Most of this soundtrack, has so much emotion and drags you in so far, that its actually made me shed tears because of how beautiful it is. This game brought out emotions I didn't know I was capable of and makes me want to come back for more. Kojima made a masterpiece, and if not, it's damn close. Buy the game, you won't regret it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a weird game, and I absolutely adore it and am so happy to experience it again. 
It's definitely not for everyone, it forces you to take your time and take in the atmosphere and world building, overall to just pace yourself. 
The game story itself is also a meta-narrative. About a man bridging a broken America back together, and the gameplay itself mirrors that. At the beginning, and on your own specifically, the world design is broken and difficult by design. But once you start working with others, and helping OTHERS, people you'll never see in game, that's where you truly start to experience all Death Stranding has to offer.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I just signed up to deliver some parcels and Kojima sent me for an absolute trip. I don't know what the heck is the story about, but I'm happy I got to experience it in my lifetime.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Simply engrossing but definitely not for everyone. Death Stranding has quickly become one of my favorite gaming experiences despite the seemingly mundane and tedious gameplay loop that makes up the core of the game. It's a wonder how Kojima and Kojipro created a game that makes the act of delivering packages in a sci-fi dystopian world so appealing, while interweaving Kojima's signature plotlines, world-building and characterizations with his uniquely cinematic eye. Moreover, it's a graphical sight to behold, interspersed with high-production music and the ever-present "Strand System" that allows you to interact with the cargo, structures and traversal information left behind by other players in a sort of dark-souls style pseudo multiplayer system (without the invading and co-op). 

As there is no other game quite like it to compare the gameplay to, I would recommend watching some playthroughs of it to get a gauge of how into the mechanics you would be before buying, just be aware that there will be a good amount of dialogue and cutscenes that take up the long span of the game. But if you can get into all the intrinsic complexities that make up the core gameplay loop and really enjoy it, this game will be an incredible time.
