title: DEATH STRANDING
review: It's different than other games I have played.  The interactions with those that you usually don't makes it that much more interesting.  The scenery is amazing and the twist and turns keeps you on your toes.  Even though its single player you still get to glimpses into other players worlds. But dont be one of the losers that looks at 3 minutes of gameplay and has a nuclear heart attack because its not something that appeals to them so it MUST be trash. title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Check the critical reviews, then the Steam user reviews, then the Metacritic user reviews--it's overwhelmingly obvious that Metacritic was review-bombed, as is so often the case. Clearly, the vast majority of people who have actually played the game love it. If there were any technical issues at launch, there don't appear to be any now--I've had nothing but rock solid performance with no bugs or crashes. I can't say the game's perfect, so I can't call it a 10, but it's undoubtedly a 9. It probably deserves a bonus point for being an amazing game *while also being a delivery simulator*, of all things. It's worth noting that I've never even actually played a Kojima game before, so I approached this one with almost no expectations.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
One the one hand, I really like this game and a lot of what it is doing and saying. I also feel that the current world situation makes this game extra resonant. It's not just that this is a game about the importance of delivery people in a disconnected world of social distancing, but also that it is a game about the importance of all our connections, even or especially the most ephemeral.

But on the other hand, after finishing the game I was filled with the impulse to find Hideo Kojima and repeatedly hit him over the head with a comically oversized rubber mallet.

I do recommend it, but it isn't for everyone. Still, if you should be able to tell if it is for you or not: this game is a lot of things, but it's not actually obtuse in its appeal (or lack thereof, depending on your tastes),

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Like EuroTruck Simulator, but without the truck, until you get the truck.

Death Stranding is very much enjoyable despite the 'Walking Simulator' moniker this game has received.
One hell of a story layered over a delivery game.  Though the walking may be tedious to some, I believe the world is filled with enough to make traversing interesting enough.  It begins with just boots but you quickly unlock alternative methods for transportation; all of which remain relevant throughout the game.  The truck doesn't entirely render the reverse-trike motorcycle obsolete.  I found myself using the hovering carriers in the beginning, stopped using them during the middle, then using them almost the entire last third of the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This isn't very complex. If somehow you are reading this and DON'T already know the core gameplay loop here, it's this:
- you get deliveries from one place, you take them to another. Sometimes with a vehicle, sometimes on foot. Terrain varies from rocky plains to mountains. Flat, hilly, treacherous.
- Sometimes bad people are on the way.
- Sometimes scary ghosts are on the way.
- You are given the means to deal with these.
- While you make your deliveries, you reconnect people living in the boonies, and disconnected bases. You also build helpful infrastructure. Sometimes the infrastructure that other people have built in their games will show up in yours.
- You do this for many hours, play through a 5 hour end game, then watch credits twice.
- It's Kojima crazy for the duration.
If any of that sounded fun? You should probably play this. If it sounded stupid? You should probably not play this. For me, I read all the reviews and what sounded good to me was a game around making deliveries. I can get behind that. I had a blast for about 95 hours making deliveries, and was annoyed for 3 of the final 5 hours, and watching cut scenes for the other 2 hours.
10/10 would buy again.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Probably the best Kojima story to date; it ended perfectly and it left a lasting impact on me.

I really love stories that leave a mark. Just perfect.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I put about 80 hours into the PS4 version and then immediately bought it here to finish off and %100.
It's like MGS5, Silent Hills, and a delivery simulator crammed into a beautiful Kojima mess.
I would recommend it to anyone who is ready to hunker down and enjoy some longer cutscenes and bit of a slow build

Cons:  not enough to affect my recommendation but worth mentioning, driving collision feels weird sometimes but once you get used to it, it's not bad. and that's mainly just bikes.
Replayability could be better, not much in the way of choices or weird alternate story paths. but again, this game is robust and not an RPG so that's fine.
and I'm pretty sure I'm a MULE now.

EDIT I'm playing on hard this time and I would probably recommend starting on hard if you are comfortable with planning your routes and supplies more. And it makes the timefall feel like an actual threat

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The positives.
The whole atmosphere in the game, from its narrative to the way how it expresses the story, how it let you feel  through your character, how you accept an hour long traversing the mountains, which is not making you bored but rather curious what new horizons you will see IS ABSOLUTELY STUNNING. From this perspective, this game is unbelievably original and its own kind of experience. This experience was finally the reason to finish the game.

---

The negatives.
AMERICA FIRST. Why the he11 the whole story is about absurd American exceptionalism? Time to time the characters talk about the world but the whole story is that the "world" you have to save is actually America. It's boring and it's what is exactly not cool on America. 

YOU ARE A HERO. All the dialogues you have after all deliveries need to ensure you that you are absolutetly the best porter on this world. The NPCs are surprised in what condition you have delivered the cargo. Why? Do we really need to be ensured that we are the best all the time? It's annoying.

GUI. The game interface and its animations is so annoying that I had to close my eyes time to time. I had to go through unbelievable senseless statistics that have nothing to do with RPG-kind of a game. You need to see all the shining glowing graphics and texts with final statistics after delivery that have little sense for your progress through the game. In the end, everytime you take an order you cannot make the decision what equipment you want to take with your. E.g. you can't recycle in this moment, so you must finish this part of preparations and go back to the terminal. This is something every player must experienced but such a bug was kept in the game not by mistake but by game design.

---

Finally I was able to ignore these parts of the game and pursue the story and the whole experince was fantastic. Yes, I do recomend you to play it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
My Review is mostly a quick review and a suggestion on how to play the game so you get the most out of it.   A lot of people seem to get the process bass ackwards and end up only really enjoying the post game.  I'm here to help!

Graphics, Story, Gameplay loops.    All bloody fun.  It's a Kojima game.  The first areas and early game are a slog,  if only to emphasize just how important the help from your fellow porters can be.  Once an area is on the network, your fellow porters have placed items to help you.   (I myself created a transportation system that lets you get anywhere on the mountain in less than two minutes)

YOU WILL PROBABLY NOT ENJOY THIS GAME IF YOU FOCUS ONLY ON OR PRIORITIZE STORY MISSIONS.

Build roads as you go,  in fact build roads before you move forward.  Use any city or distro center as a base to unlock the stuff in the area before moving on.     That means unlock any prepper shelters and max them.  The game generally gives you great upgrade item's that make life easier for the upcoming part of the game.   

Don't move on in the story til you've five starred every shelter in the area you're in. 

 The upgrades are valuable.

Build.  Make life easier. Come back, repair structures that still help, even other player's stuff.     Leaving behind a solid infrastructure to come back to means when you do return to an area, it's not a slog, and your fellow powers will like your stuff, which gives you stamina bumps when they tally it.  

BTW UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES PLAY THIS GAME OFFLINE.

You need the stuff your fellow porters build.    This is emphasized by the chiral bandwidth that limits your own building.   I found it helped to delete structures people weren't using and focus on a couple types.   For instance I relied on my other porters to build shelters.

I can't emphasize enough, build roads.   Roads make your life easier.

Make it a point to seek out those preppers tho.  Their items drive you forward,  and the extra chiral bandwidth and supply store is nice.     

Oh one last thing.... don't be afraid to pull materials you need from shelters and centers.... that's what they're there for.  Load that dang truck up.     

ANY MISSION MARKED MATERIALS WILL GIVE YOUR VARIOUS PREPPERS/CENTERS FREE MATERIALS OF THAT KIND.

So (Spoiler for a feature but it's a minor non-story spoiler) send your autodeliver bots to deliver materials when you can and then when you end up going back to an area or needing supplies, your preppers and centers are stocked.

Every shelter/prepper place you unlock passively generates chiralium crystals, so snag em when you can.   

Do these things and you're gonna have a better time.  Don't and this game is gonna be miserable for ya.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is an immersive story telling experience.

You play as Sam Bridges (Norman Reedus) and go on an journey with BB in an effort to reconnect America.
This definitely isn't a game for everyone but if you want a chill yet engaging game it may be worth checking out, its definitely very high budget (as expected from a Hideo Kojima game).

The Gameplay:
Sam's main mechanic is his backpack which is used to store the majority of cargo when travelling, at the start this is what you'll be using the most until you unlock vehicles and carriers.
The enemies in the game that you will encounter are MULE's/Terrorists and BT's.
The mules attempt to steal your cargo if you enter their territory and the BT's are these ghost type creatures that rely on hearing so you need to slow and careful through BT territory

The Soundtrack:
Absolutely amazing put simply. Kojima's choice of both licensed and original music is beautiful and carefully placed in key moments throughout the game.

As a bonus exclusive to PC there's an added difficulty and a collaboration with Half-Life and Portal which by completing quests you can unlock unique accessories for Sam.

The game also offers a lot of replayability through the amount of deliveries you can accept and each facility has a relationship meter to fill up to unlock new items and such which increases by deliveries made.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding has a completely unique story, beautiful scenery and graphics, and compelling world-building. But true to form, Kojima prefers to "tell" instead of "show." It's always been a flaw of his storytelling, where he explains to you how you should feel about things instead of letting you feel out and figure out the world around you on your own. He gives you the illusion of a sandbox, but it's very much his sandbox. The result is, if you actually want an open world, you come away feeling railroaded; and if you want pure story, you come away feeling overwhelmed and talked at. The game gets bogged down by constant interruptions, making me cringe every time I hear the crackling ringtone and a certain someone going, "Sam, you might have noticed that..." And after a while, the game starts to feel incredibly hamfisted in how it decides to force-feed you its narrative and insist that you care.

My other criticism is that the terror and threat that the story establishes early on quickly disappears. The game becomes very easy, very quickly. It's really no big deal to tromp into bad-guy territory, knock everyone out with a Bola Gun, and steal a truck. At that point, the primary threat is almost completely negated because you can simply drive through it fast enough. I hope this continues to become more difficult - and I have some indication that it might - but it also feels like I'm nearing the end of the game. 

Anyway - great idea, unique worldbuilding, but underwhelming story and action.

Last thought - "walking simulator" is a tired criticism. I actually love how challenging it is to roam across the landscape and how much strategy is involved in just staying upright. It's kind of amazing. But I'm also obsessive, and I've probably spent hours just building roads... "road building simulator" feels better to me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
"This is not a game.

This is a Goddamn work of art."

That is what I said on release, less than an hour into the game. This is still what I say 52 hours later.

I guess to be a "review" I should give you more info, but I'm not going to go into the story at all.

What everyone says about it (Walking simulator, errand boy simulator, etc.) is pretty much true. The "gameplay" isn't really there. It's seeing what others build, what you build alongside them. Watching the world change around you as you play. It's not "fun" like "action" games (First person shooters, ARPG's) because you don't DO anything. You don't fight people for money or better gear. You don't fight in armies or kill people by the score. You just have a job, and you do your job.

The missions you take on are literally just "Take this pile of cargo a couple kilometers down to that place with so-and-so and see if they want to ally with us or something. Oh, and try not to break it."

Then "These guys left some pretty cool tech that will build roads for you. Help out and supply the materials if you can." 

That's the gist of the "gameplay." If it doesn't sound fun to you, it's because it's NOT "fun." It's a means of continuing the story, of exploring the world, and it just feels "satisfying" to complete these missions. It's experiencing the feeling of utter terror the first few times you encounter the primary enemy of the game turn to absolutely demolishing them (if you come prepared!). The elation and absolute satisfaction when, after the hopelessness you feel when you turn around and see a truck load of your valuable cargo stolen while you were climbing down a hill to retrieve another piece getting further and further away, you chase it down on foot to the base it was taken to and manage to get everything back before delivering it all to your destination successfully.

It's seeing a destination you have never been to in the distance and feeling hopeless about trying to get there. As you get closer, you see ways others have made it and then it's time to figure out the best path to take, or perhaps forge your own way: "I've got a vehicle, but would it be smarter to go on foot? Would it be easier to go around a little further to make it up that hill? Would a few ladders placed here and there be worth it or should I just grit my teeth and trudge up this hill?"

It's cliched, but I have to agree with many others: It's not a game, it's an experience, and it's frankly not for everyone. No hard feelings to any who hate it and don't see the point. It's a beautiful experience regardless.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Addictive logistics-satisfying gameplay mechanics drive what is otherwise numbing gameplay through a compelling and surreal narrative. The mechanics can get their hooks in you while the story will pull you along.

The graphics are excellent, delivering a vividly realized photoreal experience.

The music both sets the beyond-grimdark mood while delivering some music worthy of a listen outside the game.

Recommended to those with even the slightest inclination toward obsessive goal accomplishment, and certainly those that are interested by dark surreal stories.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
One of the "secrets" of storytelling is: make your readers/viewers/players care about your main character/s, and the world they're in, within the first sentence/minute if you can, and certainly don't take more than 10 sentences/minutes.

After 90 minutes of carefully following directions, I've discovered the characters in this -- what? 8-year-old-on-painkillers nightmare? -- are all pretentious idiots, and I hope they die and their world ends.

[spoiler]We're supposed to believe they have all that advanced technology, and no way to put corpses on an underground conveyor belt / drone / f****g catapult!? to get them to the incinerator? Nope. Gotta carry them by hand. Is there a *highway* to this vital incineration facility? Nope. Just rugged terrain where no-one has been before, yet the incinerator has dozens of burn chambers...[/spoiler]

It simply makes no sense whatsoever. Things that are obvious to the character who cannot walk in a straight line without my intervening literally every step are complete mysteries to me. Forget it. Rage quit. Don't care about these people, and hope their illogical world is put out of its misery ASAP.

Maybe this could all be forgiven if the main gameplay loop wasn't "falling to the left!" tap tap tap tap, "falling to the right!" tap tap tap. Repeat endlessly.

Years ago there was a certain audience who went to 2001: A Space Odyssey not for the plot or the special effects, but because they were stoned and the looooooong flashing light sequence at one point was, I am told, a real trip.

That's this game. I *strongly* suspect those who are all like "BeST gAmE EVaR!!!" are simply high.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Quick: I really wanted to finish the game before writing this review, but I just can't force myself to play it any longer. The game is very unique and I understand why many would recommend it. But ultimately it is painfully boring/redundant. 

Details: At its core, the game is a delivery sim. The unique spin is that you are delivering goods in a post-apocalyptic future across untamed and often "haunted" environments (trade invisible poltergeists for undead). You can also craft structures as you travel to help with return trips. You start with basics like ropes and ladders and the tech improves as the game progresses.

There are plenty of games that offer similar empire building experiences, but what makes this one unique is that it has massive-multiplayer elements quietly included. By default, the game will show you the structures and signs other recent players have created dotting the landscape. Conversely, the things you do will be shared with a small group of randomly selected players who have unlocked the same tech as yourself. You don't actually see the other players, but you share a common infrastructure.

Some positives: 

- The graphics are amazing. The universe lends itself to some physics defying visuals and vistas that are hands down the best part of the game. I am particularly impressed by the games water effects. Rain, rivers, streams, beaches, etc... Extremely well done.

- The story is Okay. Probably even "good" by video game standards.  Fortunately, the voice acting is great. It turns what would be an unremarkable story into a memorable experience. Props to all the actors and actresses involved in the making of the game. 

- The game poses some interesting philosophical questions, at least for those who believe in an afterlife. 

For some, the positives above are worth playing the game. And I would agree if the game were $20 or less. But not at the $60 price point. At that price point, I expect choices that matter, multiple endings, traveling companions, romance opportunities, mini-games, inventory management, good enemy AI... A day/night cycle. For $60 you are better off playing something like The Outer Worlds.

Negatives. 

- The game is nothing like the trailers make it out to be. Does the game have a story in the background? Sure. Go find a youtube video and watch it. But as a game, 99% of the time is taking and delivering items. Transporting goods from point A to point B by yourself. The pickup and drop off sequence is exactly the same everywhere you go. The scenery may be great, but you spend most the time staring at the ground/road, trying not to fall or keep your vehicle on the power strip. 50 hours staring at a road. Might as well be playing American Truck Simulator.

- I like games that make me feel like I am surrounded by or traveling with people, especially during a pandemic. This game actually managed to make me feel more alone than I actually am. It is the most empty game I have ever played. There are no animals, no birds. not even the sound of insects. Just the sound of wind and rain. The handful of NPC interactions are mostly in cut-scenes. When the cut-scene ends, you are back to standing in the world by yourself again. Even your primary enemy, the poltergeists, are (wait for it)... invisible.

- Enemy AI is non existent. I mean, at least zombies and undead have to still walk towards you. These enemies just float in the air. They are glorified land-mines. And the bosses are not challenging. They walk slowly towards you, giving you plenty of time to ready your grenade and throw it at them. They probably had to water combat down for console users, but as a result, combat is a joke on PC. 

- If I had known the game had MMO elements, I wouldn't have bought it. While some will claim you can turn it off, the reality is there are projects in the game like roads that are too big to do on your own.  When you are 60 hours in, ask yourself... are you still playing because you like the game... or are you simply building things in hopes of getting some likes from other random people you don't know and will never meet. It feels like this game uses the online component as a crutch to keep it interesting, but without that component, it is a beautiful but ultimately boring experience.

- While new tech is one of the few things to look forward to in this game, often times it also negates any infrastructure work you did. This game likes to slap completionists in the face repeatedly. IE: When bikes and trucks come along, it basically negates all that time you spent placing ladders and ropes. Then later, rail lines come along, letting you fly through the air between cities. This negates all the time you spent building roads and bridges. Word of advice for those who are going to buy it anyway: Don't get caught up building infrastructure for other people because it all quickly becomes obsolete. Only build what you personally want/need, not what you think others might need.

- Sam has a baby in a bottle (called a BB) that he travels with. BB is hooked up some to some tech that allows Sam to "see" ghosts. The relationship between Sam and BB is cute, but the baby starts crying when Sam falls or gets in deep water. I don't know if you have ever tried to play video games with a kid crying in the room, but this really irritates me to no end. If you deal with babies crying in real life, be it your younger brother/sister, at work or with your own children, this may make the game unplayable for you.  

- There is no day/night cycle and the sky is always cloudy. This may seem minor, but a $60 open world game released in 2020 that has no day/night cycle? Really? 

- The game doesn't PAY you for deliveries. You get "likes" and reputation increases for doing a good job, but you can't buy things with likes. I prefer games that offer a store model. You know... where you get paid and you can see items  that you can't initially afford. Gives you motivation to make money. As is, this game really lacks motivation both for Sam's character's perspective and for you as the player. 

- Sam supposedly knows his own history and thus why he is so withdrawn and reclusive. Yet you have to play the game to learn about his past. And sometimes his own reactions are like he doesn't know what is going on. "What... you mean I am a middle aged Man? I had no idea!". I wish the game had officially given him amnesia at the beginning so that he was discovering the world and his own backstory along with the player. I had to mentally pretend this was the case when I played because otherwise it is just too unbelievable/stupid for me to handle.

Anyway Its the Best game I've played in Years and I can't wait to see what comes next from Kojima Productions.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I love this game, but it's a VERY "Acquired taste". I dumped a bunch of hours into the PS4 version and this is definitely the best way to play, but it's a super slow burn. Game runs well, looks gorgeous, seems to be well optimized for PC. Cutscenes are capped to 60fps, though they are running in engine, so if your framerate dips you will be able to tell. I think I've hard crashed once with this game, and my framerates are consistently in the area that I would call really good - never dropped below 60fps on my rig with everything pinned to max settings (2080ti, 3700x, 1440p).

I don't think that everyone is likely to enjoy this game, though. (hell, I'm a sucker for Jim Sterling and totally understood his take on the game). The story is definitely one by Kojima - it's deep, crazy and heart wrenching all at once, though it can be a bit difficult to follow.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
An apocalyptic plague splintering the world where you must unite America by delivering packages. 
*shakes fist*
Kojima, you've done it again! Somebody tell me he isn't a prophet. God bless this man.

tl;dr Death Stranding is a high quality story and universe placed within a tech demo for literally every type of game that Kojima is known to make from tactical espionage to horror. All of these elements and more are put to the limits thanks to the creative vision of Kojima. I can't wait to see upcoming titles using this as a jumping point.
-----------------------------------------------

This game is very similar to MGSV: Ground Zeroes in that it's more of a tech demo than it is a game. When I classify it as a tech demo it no way means it's any less of a game but rather they are trying to innovate new gameplay mechanics more than rehashing older mechanics to create a "safe" game for people to enjoy. This new system has a plethora of calculations that needed to be inputted to determine the physics of weight distribution, character models interactions with the environment and structures, open-world boss fights (and the effects that come with that), and last but not least optimizing an online experience without harassing the player with online connectivity and the ability to backtrack progress made in an online game (this is probably the most consumer friendly online mechanics that people are undervaluing.)

Kojima was bold to call this a strand-style game which people are still debating on what that means. My theory is that he is describing an indirect interaction online gaming experience. Similar to Dark Souls messaging system, Kojima takes a step further and makes it even more interactive without having the player directly be there (i.e. each player's gameplay is a "strand" that can be "knotted" into other "strands" with the moral of this system being that advancement is amplified through cooperation.) It must not be forgotten the nuance required in programming an indirect online experience but also allow players to backtrack on save progression. Something no other strand-type game has done before.

The fact that Kojima was able to pull off all these mechanics near perfectly is deserving of the $60 but the story and graphical quality cement it's place as an iconic game. After seeing Death Stranding I am so excited to see how these mechanics will work in Kojima's next tactical espionage game. I can already imagine a loadout screen similar to Phantom Pain and Death Stranding where each gear can be placed in a certain area to minimize noise, visibility, and speed. Mechanics like this would make the skill system that Phantom Pain offers for some their mercenary soldiers a more meta/viable option. 

To summarize: Kojima is a prophetic genius, this game is the foundation we'll see in future games for years to come, and finally Konami is a despicable company that endorses profiting off gambling as well as scummy practices such as preventing Kojima to get health insurance for his employees. #Fuc-Konami (had to add the "-" to make it uncensored because I hate Konami that much.)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I find it implausible that mechanical skull masks are everyday attire for businessmen/politicians or that motorcycles are still a popular form of transportation in a world where getting rained on is a fate worse than death. However, I didn't find that either detracted from my enjoyment of the game. 

World building and atmosphere: Fantastic. Writing and Plot: Highly questionable. Graphics: Amazing. Gameplay and control: Interesting but not groundbreaking. More conventional than has been reported. You wont see many "strand-like" games. Sound and Music: Excellent but you should be able to turn it off. Soul: The game has soul. 

Overall this is a unique and worthy game that I'm glad exists. It's impressive that Kojima took this massive risk and I hope it pays off for him, partly just to encourage other developers to take more risks. I'd say the replay value is pretty low and the game will almost certainly appear in bargain bins once it becomes ubiquitous. I personally don't regret buying it at full price if only to reward the brilliant marketing campaign. In reality it deserves 3 out of 4 stars since my ultimate criteria is how long I want to spend playing but I feel compelled to give it 4 out of 4 on the basis of that soul. Someone, a lot of someones, obviously put everything they had into this project and despite being pretentious, overwrought, ham-fisted in its symbolism, and somewhat goofy what really shines through is Kojima's vision of the modern world: a profoundly lonely place where no one has any privacy.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is a great new look at a post-apocalyptic game, and truly feels like an inhospitable planet. The short term goals are avoiding rocks, crossing rivers, and traversing steep hills. Long term goals are generally moving cargo, building infrastructure, and obtaining new technology. Achieving these goals introduces new ways to make the treks easier and faster. This game is not for people with short attention spans though, there is a lot of quiet walking. 
All in all, it's a very artistically fresh game with extremely satisfying game mechanics. Keep on keeping on!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The first two hours of the game had me wondering if it was all entirely cut-scenes, though after what I would call a slow burn this game lets you explore an absolutely gorgeous world. "Walking simulator" as I heard early on does it no justice, seeing as you get vehicles later on. As things progress I've already felt hints of Metal Gear Solid in the delivery structure, seeing as there is absolutely so much optional content to be had that's layered under the actual meat of the main story.

If you want a truly original game by the master himself Hideo Kojima, give it a damn try. I know I haven't regretted it once I got the handle of things, and at this point the utterly deranged, out of this world story is slowly pulling me in and not letting me go.

Love it.


x--- /Edit ---x

After finishing the main story, and still wanting to play, I can easily say this is one of my Games of the Year! Not only was the ending confusing as hell (helps to record, and watch again), the very end almost had me in tears. AND IM A MAN, DAMNIT.

Hideo Kojima has proven with this game that he is still one of the best (and one of my favorite) writers for a game's story, and fleshing it out by producing a game like this.

My only gripe? I wish you could edit certain sounds in the game to make them quieter (Accelerating on a bike, wandering into a Timefall Storm, etc) as the noise can get downright repetitive.

Other than that 11/10, will be one I get to 100% completion.

x--- /Edit ---x

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I have played computer games more than 30 years now and have seen my share of the good, the bad and the ugly ones. I have from the beginning loved good story driven games because in my opinion game without a story is like human without a soul. One of my first games that I played was the original Monkey Island which gave me a unforgettable impression.

With all that said, Death Stranding is by far the best game until this day I have ever played. The story was just amazing with its all twist and turns. The whole game is very well polished and executed. This is a amazing example how to make a good RPG.

So if you love good story driven games this is just must play. If you usually skip all the cutscenes when playing games then just forget this one, it is not for you.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: One of the most important games you will play.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If you dismiss this game as a "walking simulator" I implore you to still play it. 

Even the walking part is exceptional. Jaw-dropping landscapes, atmosphere and wonderful moments of music bring life and hope to an otherwise desolate existence. I can't tell you how good it feels to endure the journeys this game takes you on and then make it out the other side. 

This game is all about reaching out and building connections, even though you don't want to; even though it can hurt. 
But those connections make everyone stronger. Players have such a special impact on each other without ever being able to see or know the other. A bridge built here, a ladder there, all small moments of hope that kept me going, made me feel so grateful and far less alone. This is just one element that made me fall head-over-heels for this game (and not just because it was slippery).

I loved the characters, especially Sam, and although I went into the game thinking BB was just a creepy gimmick- I was so wrong. Their story drives the game and underpins it with so much emotion, that I would play this game just for them alone. 

DS is full of signature Kojima oddities but they do not detract at all from the emotive narrative; it only helps cement this game as a masterpiece of this generation with a distinct style and ethos; Alone We Have No Future. 

In this time of corona, this game has honestly brought me so much comfort, hope and plenty of laughter too- although get the tissues ready; I absolutely cried my eyes out for the entire finale.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Even though I am over 11 hours into the game, I feel like I am just starting. The only problem I am having is too many keys to remember. I am an older player and used to less that 20 keys to memorize. Don't get me wrong, I really like the game and am starting to get the hang of it. I feel it is a different kind of game. I love the story and video cut scenes. It would be nice to have a few less keys to remember. I am many times going into my help menu to trigger my recollection of which key to use for which function. I haven't gotten to real combat yet and hope it won't be too complicated. But the game is great and as long as I take it slow I can get through it. Much of the time I spend always trying centering my cargo as I walk. Quite a few fingers involved at one time on the keyboard. If I had any advice it would be to simplify all the keys we need to use but other than that I am enjoying the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: AMAZING!!!!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[b]This is by far the best game I've played and that I probably will ever play.[/b]
Hidea Kojima finally breaks free from Metal Gear Solid franchise and shows us what he is truly capable of. In this very unique game, he blends all of his doubts, fears, thoughts and hopes in order to provide us a story as breathtaking as heart taking. Death Stranding offers an original and refreshing way to progress in the story, a story that might seems austere at first glance but once reached his full potential, delights you with some of the most magnificent set pieces and treats you with absolutely brilliant cinematics. It is beautiful and hipnotic as well as insightful and heady at the same time, but if you actually make the effort and embrace the story Kojima and his teams are sharing with you, at the end, you would have lived a real journey that even days after it's done, will make you think about it. The ending is as heartrending as uplifting and if you don't cry the first time you will probably do the second.
To sum up, while it might not be the game that necessarily pleases everyone, I can only wholeheartedly recommend this experience that in my opinion, if you have a strand of sensibility, you'll be glad that you lived it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The game's beginning is a bit confusing and hauling stuff seems like it would be boring. However, once you keep going and gain an understanding of the world and mechanics, game play is addicting. I'm currently in Episode 11 and am amazed at the depth of this story. So much so, I've been playing now for 86 hours and look forward to playing more each day. This is an incredible accomplishment in story and game play. Well done and highly recommended for explorers and people who always play in story mode. You won't be disappointed.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's been a long time since I experienced a game as relevant, interesting, refreshing and new as Hideo Kojima's Death Stranding. This is a AAA budget game mixed with unchained creativity, eluding common cliches and other tropes.

This is not a game for everybody. You will find yourself arranging and rearranging equipment and managing your inventory for a good portion of your playthrough. You will sit through complex dialogue and long exposition dumps in the form of cutscenes. You will be walking, climbing, running and rappeling your way from point A to point B, and you will be doing it a lot. And you will fail. But, for me, this is what made the game so great and unique.

On the gameplay level, this is a slow paced walking/delivery simulator that takes you through harsh terrain while carrying cargo. You have to find the best possible ways to make your way. And yes, there are enemies, and yes you can shoot them and they can shoot you back, but that's just a secondary gameplay mechanic. 

There is no multiplayer / singleplayer division, but I'm not gonna spoil that amazingly interesting side of the game. Just let me tell you that you won't find someone else on the game, but you will never feel alone.

You can experience similar moods on some David Lynch works.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
To start, the performance was phenomenal and it's probably the first time I've every loaded up a AAA game and didn't have to spend a bunch of time tweaking settings to get a stable framerate. I only have a 1080p display and a GTX1070, so I wasn't able to take advantage of the DLSS 2.0, but I was still able to keep framerates at my monitor's max refresh rate of 75Hz for most of the game, with only occasional dips below 60fps that weren't particularly troublesome due to the excellent frame timing. My only complaint would be that they probably could have pushed the visuals a bit further to take advantage of higher-end hardware.

The gameplay was incredibly unique and I enjoyed it thoroughly. I wish more games would take risks like this to create something new, even if some people won't enjoy it. It wasn't particularly difficult on the normal setting but all the systems felt like they created meaningful and enjoyable challenges to overcome without becoming tedious or punishing you greatly for being a little lazy. I really enjoyed how the game introduced new challenges and let you feel the problems it creates for your traversal, then provides you with new equipment to allow you to overcome some of that difficulty, but then later there may be an order that takes away the ability to use those tools so that you have to find new ways to overcome that obstacle. This kept the game fresh for the nearly 60 hours I played it and it never felt like any particular obstacle or system (like snowy terrain, boot degradation, BTs, stamina, balance, etc.) became trivial but they also didn't become tedious. This is actually really hard to do in a game. I've recently played games like RDR2 and Kingdom Come: Deliverance, which were both great, but in they didn't strike this balance of not-trivial but not-tedious that Death Stranding did. In RDR2 I felt like many of the systems and mechanics they introduced were more there for role-playing purposes and you could mostly ignore eating, sleeping, wearing weather-appropriate clothes, etc. while in Kingdom Come: Deliverance the survival mechanics are very important in the beginning but you can get perks that make them mostly trivial by the middle of the game.

As for the story, I won't say much other than it had probably the best acted and delivered cutscenes of any game I've played and the story and lore were intriguing enough to provide motivation to progress. It gets weird and at some points I thought it was trying a little too hard, but overall I wasn't disappointed.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Disclaimer: At the time of writing this, I have not completed the game.
Tl;dr: This is not a game for everyone. It is however something that is worth the time if you take to it. It definitely is worth full price.

Death Stranding is an experience. There's *much* more to it than "Norman Reedus and the Funky Fetus" or "haha postman go stippy step"

On the surface, yes. It's about delivering things to people across the worst possible landscape for travel on foot, even worse for vehicles. It's a slog. However the *point* of the game is to make connections. Whether that be via connecting the various waystations and other facilities, or the more subtle way of helping other players by building useful infrastructure or giving your materials to someone else's construction. 

Now you might say, "wait this game has player interaction?"
It does. However, not directly. When you connect a facility to the rest, the surrounding area also becomes connected to the network. This allows you to see the buildings that other players have placed for you to use and upgrade. You can interact with these structures by "liking" them, which increases the builder's stats as well as letting them know that their work is appreciated. The game gets easier (to an extent) the more you try to help your fellow player moreso than yourself. The more you like other players' efforts, the stronger the connections you have, which means you get more structures to use as you see fit.
Something else that I find pleasantly intriguing about this system of interaction is that there are no negative ways to communicate. If you don't like the place someone has put something, you can dismantle it without consequence, however you will not gain anything from it besides the space it took up.

On a completely subjective note: The environment is stunning. I find myself taking "time off" in-game just to explore. It's legitimately relaxing to just go for a walk.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Thoughts after finishing this game:
Amazing cinematography. Story is interesting. Gameplay can be boring, but for me at first it was interesting. It's not just walking simulator. Building is so much fun. I recommend building roads and wait with standard missions after you can do premium deliveries.

First impression:

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
From my experience, this is a nice game to play alone. Even though I'm only 13 hours in, I can tell I'll be putting much more time into this game. While you're traversing beautiful landscapes, you take into account what gear you should bring with you depending on the route: one that you get to set out on your own. Though, your route might be susceptible to change in either good ways, such as coming across other structures built by players in their worlds into yours (which you can do yourself to help others along their travels); or in bad ways, such as timefall suddenly raining down, slowly deteriorating your containers and/or equipment and potentially bringing enemies known as BTs. With a mix of basic stealth and combat mechanics, enemies are certainly a threat to acknowledge, and whether or not you've come prepared to face them, they provide a decent challenge along with the environment for a relaxing game such as this. I will say that some of the lore was confusing at first, but once I stopped overthinking about it, I became more focused on the plot given to me. The themes on hope and the importance of reconnecting people stand out, using the setting on what seems to be on the surface: a desolate world but with thousands of people separated, most staying within shelters underground, in what used to be the United States. And I'm glad to have the opportunity to dive into this world every time I launch it. I almost thought I'd miss another quality game with exclusivity on the ps4, but fortunately it's here on PC on Steam. And it runs amazing! While I do have a pretty good rig, I wasn't expecting it to look AND run this good at a consistent frame rate no matter how intense my encounters in-game got. DLSS 2.0 must be doing a lot behind the scenes, but this game just feels and looks amazing. If you have the chance to try the game, give it a shot. It's definitely worth checking out, but be aware that it can be time consuming in a good way, depending on whether or not that's your thing. For me, the game feels alive enough with it's player structures, messages, and lost cargo and secluded enough with my own journey in the world to feel like I'm making a difference as a lone porter, taking cargo condition, quantity, and time to deliver to account for. Thanks, Kojima Productions.
UPDATE: I just finished the game, and the story did get a little interesting until it tried doing its plot twists. I don't have a clue what's going on, and I know if I try to understand it, it's pointless because it's a mess. It's sort of like MGS where you have to wonder why there's so many versions of Snake and the supernatural behind that story, and Kingdom Hearts where it's best to just enjoy the game rather than understand what the hell's going on and why. That's what I did in Death Stranding: I enjoyed the gameplay for a little while, but as soon as I wanted to finish the story I was disappointed. I still recommend it for how laid back and enticing the gameplay was for letting me explore a vast, beautiful open world and for putting me on a journey. But, I've learned that trying to understand the details of games like this isn't worth it and that it'll only bring more questions, ones that aren't thought provoking but rather questions that are often answered with, "Because that's the way it is." With games like MGS or Kingdom Hearts, I played them for the gameplay and I did the same here, and I enjoyed it. The themes of connection are still heavily implied and I appreciate that, that's the most I'll make out of this too.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
***NOW***

I would 10/10 buy, great game needs a second. 

Play at 1440p at 66fps for great results.




****EARLIER****  I would except it is 100$ and I have found to major issues with gameplay that will be obvious to anyone who gets invested in this game.

That is.

Now I play it at 75fps and still the jitters of in game rendering persist. Along with all the other problems. Fix this, look to other similar games for how this should be. 

So I have found two issues with the game In the game at 60fps 1080p. 

1. [Is present with dlss and without] 
- That is that when panning the objects being rendered within the game will at some point in the acceleration curve of the panning movement jump. That is they move there position In space back or forward (it is hard to discern) from where they should be. I.e. the mountains In the background when panning will occasionally seem to jump. Frame pacing and frame rate are perfect, this is consistent across a range of variable changes such as camera speed and acceleration as well as fps vs refresh rate with output at 60 fps.

2. [DLSS problem] 
When panning you can see on the outside of the screen a number of borders manifest. That is it looks like you are seeing a frame in a frame in a frame in a frame. The spacing varies with speed of camera panning. Possibly the actuation of this also correlates with the jump found in in game rendered objects described above.

I would very much like to see these issues fixed as when compared to the overall polish this game has it is very non immersive.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game has 'move it from point A to B' gameplay style placed into a complex story based world with painstakingly designed terrain, social media inspired likes for finishing missions and aiding other players, and structure building to help not only yourself, but other players progress in an interconnected world, all with a Kojima flare for gameplay and story. Enjoyed MGSV? Give this a shot. Like Elite Dangerous, Euro Truck Sim, or any other Delivery styled game? This will likely be just your cup of tea. Just be prepared to sit and watch a Kojima directed movie for a while. But anyone with experience playing a Hideo game before should know what they're getting into :)

However, if you're someone who wants fast-paced, moment to moment involved gameplay, this is not the game for you. This is no shooter and combat is best avoided, even more so than in the MGS series. The world and your preparation are your main enemies and if you rush in head first without planning, you're gonna have a bad time. This game rewards methodical thought first and raw execution second. That's not to say that you won't have to think on your feet and get out of tight situations, especially on the harder of the 5 difficulty settings that you can change during gameplay, but you'll know when you're about to get into some trouble before it happens and can avoid it, or failing that escape, with skill and careful maneuvering.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Has a classic Kojima + Shinkawa vibe that MGS fans will be familiar with, but right now you're playing deathless US Postal Service set in the apocalyptic future. Expect classic Kojima stealth gameplay.

If you don't enjoy organizing your inventory and opening menus countless times to make sure you've done everything before leaving a "station"...    then this game ain't for you. All you're doing is delivering packages with a decent story to go along with it.

PC Port not that bad, especially given the quality that the devs could give us at these frame rates, but it can always be better.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The build quality of the game is amazing - it is truly an another Hideo Kojima masterpiece.

Although marketing seems have been wrong.

In it's heart it is a logistics simulator - You start as a postman in nowhere and from that point it goes on and on with more game mechanics to play and more experiences. New features are introduced gradually which helps a lot in learning the game. It is not overwhelming as You start and it does not become boring as You continue. As You progress You get more and more toys to play with, which is amazing design concept. 

For example - as You walk, You notice You are leaving paths around You.

Then You notice there are new buildings left by other players but they do not appear instantly - it seems that building mechanic is tied to the mission system so that You get stuff from other players who are around the same point in the game as You are. Later in the game You get vehicles to drive, roads and bridges to build, etc.

I call it simulator because the detail that goes in to the simulation is real and huge. To the point that You have to keep spare pair of boots to change if something goes wrong. Also pathways that You keep making help You navigate a lot.

Game seems to me been wrongly marketed as a "horror walking simulator" which does not give the game full credit for what it is.

Sure there are few things that might get You scared when You meet them at first but after that - it's just an another game mechanic with a bit of drama added.

I am emphasizing that because wrong assumptions about what the game is actually about, was one of the reasons that kept me from buying the game instantly, as I do not often buy a game that's not on 30 - 60% sales.

I think the game should appeal for player who like games like American Truck Simulator, Farming Simulator, Oregon Trail, etc. Also the game focus is a lot more on cooperation not so much about competition either.

Oh, and the cut scenes are really really nice. Because it is Hideo Kojima game after all :)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: An amazing game which I struggle to describe in a single sentence. The story is extremely creative and entertaining, punctuated throughout with clever storytelling and amazing cinematography. It is one of the rare games which creates scenes only possible in video games, and they are truly delightful to watch and interact with. And that is to say nothing of the gameplay itself, which I admittedly loved a lot more than I thought I would.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: If you liked Mad Max or Fallout, you'll probably like this game and I think is a must-buy.  It's a lot of fun with fun activities to build stuff.  I felt unsatisfied after finishing it though.  I felt like I spent a lot of time gathering resources to build stuff, but never really got to enjoy the fruits of my labors.  I also hated that after I cleared an area of BTs, I'd go back later and they were there again.  That got pretty old.  Also really annoyed at not being able to skip BB's warning every time I went in a BT area, and the too-long cut scenes.  And even though it has open-world play, in reality it has an awful lot of linear play - also annoying.  Also found the ending unsatisfying and I don't want to play again.  But is worth buying and playing.

The choice how you play this game is yours, and your performance is noticed all the time and it reflects on your actions.

This is an experience where one should testify themselves, give it a thought and immerse into the world of the unknown while it all unfolds in front of you.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Played on PS4 when it came out.  Bought it again for elevated experience.
The Good - 
Unique story.  
Very MGS style character development, may seem unusual to people not used to kojima games.  
Gameplay loop is mostly optional however for those with efficiency will be rewarded and those who are risk takers can also be rewarded.
Has a very cool online mode in regards to construction projects. 
The Bad -
Some very key lore is sometimes easily missed.  The story can do without it, however it's strange they where not made more obvious.  I guess though that is the reward for finding them.
You don't get the headcrab hat on steam edition until like chapter 8, that sucked.  I wanted headcrab for most of the early cutscenes.  Almost refunded because of that but then i realized that was petty.  

Other than that, it's in my top 10.  Very memorable game for me, i enjoy most of Kojimas work and this is one of his best works so far.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
One of the most brilliant games to come out in recent times. So I have always been a huge fan of Hideo Kojima. I have played almost all of the metal gear solid games. So when I got to know about this game, I was disappointed to say the least. A walking simulator is what it was being called when we got to know more about this game. I thought the same. 'How can this game be fun? How can anyone enjoy this? Don't people remember the first assassin's creed game?'. 

I couldn't have been more wrong. 

This game is a masterpiece. Not a perfect game. But definitely a masterpiece. 

Yes. you have to deliver goods from one point to another point in this game. But this is a very shallow way to look at this game. In fact, that is the best part of this game. I can't tell you how happy I was the first time when I found a couple of ladders and ropes placed by other players just to make my travel easy. See the thing is, this isnt just about reaching point B from point A. Much of the fun comes from what happens in between. You have total freedom upon the path you want to choose. Along with that, come a lot of challenges in the game. The terrain, for example, is a key element here. Unlike other games, just because you are pressing a button, doesnt mean that the dude will oblige. a lot depends on the weight that he is carrying, the kind of terrain, the speed at which you were running. One wrong step on the danger spots will make you fall. Along with that, all of your luggage. The rain plays a key role in this game. Anything that it touches, will age in a short span of time. So your luggage is bound to get damaged if you spend a lot of time out in the rain. Along with that you have to deal with the BTs (ghost like figures which can be a pain in the ass but their encounters are fun and intense) and humans who are bad. have forgotten what they are called. 


Slowly as you progress in the game, you are given tools which make the journey a little bit easy. You can build roads, bridges etc. You can place ladders and ropes. You can also place markers. The best part is that you get to use items of other players as well. For example, in the first mission, you are supposed to carry a body to a place. While on my journey, while managing the weight of the body with the two mouse buttons, i came across a mountain. I couldn't have scaled up the mountain if i wouldn't have found a couple of ladders and a rope placed by other players. I can't tell you how satisfied i was when i found that. Once I finally got to the place, I was feeling tired. Not in a bad way. but for the character. Because I was there with him throughout his journey. I could feel the weight of sam. 

See, the fun in this game are those little intense moments. I consider this as a masterpiece because, unlike other games, this game isn't trying to feed you these moments after every 5 seconds. This game provides them at the perfect times. And those moments make your journey special. That moment when you scale down a cliff with the help of a rope placed by someone else. That moment when you successfully avoid the BT zone when you notice a warning placed by someone else. That moment when place the ladder at the perfect place for yourself, and once you are across the river, you leave it. So that others can use it. That perfect moment when you find your private room after a long journey with tons of stuff on your back. That perfect moment when you sneak up behind an enemy and strangle him with your rope. That perfect moment when you see your character stumbling down and watch his luggage fall on the ground, one by one. 

In this game, you just don't travel from point A to point B. You have to earn it.

Another beauty about this game is just the chilled nature of this game. Trust me, you will look forward to your next journey. You will want to step out and carve your own way towards your next destination. This game is very therapeutic. You feel the wind. You feel the rain. You feel SAM's pain as he walks towards his destination. You feel his happiness when he finds a ladder or a rope. 

Long story short, games like this one come rarely. This is a bold, and i might add, a very successful attempt at breaking the format of a video game. Of what we perceive video games to be. This one isn't playing by the rules. 

This game isn't perfect though. The clunky UI is there like a thorn which you have to touch every time you play this game. I wish someone at the company would have realised that no one wants to read all of this over and over and over again. 

I am just 7 hours in at the moment so I can't really say a lot about the story. But it is a hit and miss when it comes to characters. Some fall flat. Some (sam included), are interesting. The scenario is just what one can imagine if his name is Hideo Kojima. 

But, according to me, this shouldn't distract you from the true beauty of this game. A game, that perhaps, that will stand the test of time. A true next gen game that is not playing by the rules. 

If you get this game, thinking of it as just another third person shooter where you kill any moving object, you will be disappointed. If you buy this game with an open mind, you will fall in love with it. 

You feel this game.  I highly recommend this game to anyone who is ready to take that chance.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Its amazing how much detail was put into this world. This is a game for the sightseer.  Someone who enjoys seeing large scale world building. Fighting in this game isn't terribly difficult. The music makes the enemies seem more threatening.  This is a game that discourages taking life and more to using none lethal weapons but will not stop you from making your own choices.  Vehicles are plentiful.  Construction is a cool mechanic that helps you and your creations will appear in other players worlds. You can choose to spend allot of time building roads. across america. Which will make traveling on missions much easier and feel rewarding.  Each person you meet in the game also supplies you with little gadgets that will help you along your journey. So it is worth doing side quests once you reach episode 3.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Pros:
      1. Great Story:  At first you may not understand but in the end you will.
      2. Amazing Graphics: Everything from people to environment are so well done and optimized.
      3. Game Play: Played on Very Hard Mode and the game through everything at me.
      4. Sound: The music tracks and sounds are amazing.
Cons:
      1. Vehicles: I don't know if it was just mouse and keyboard but this was not the best. Turning was like driving a semi-truck on any vehicle. Grip was bad too trying to move sideways on a slop. Rocks, sometimes even the smallest one, was like a brick wall when you hit it.
      2. Character movement: Like above I didn't play with joystick but this got me in trouble most of the time. Trying to upgrade something on a cliff or slop having to face it made me face right off the cliff; falling and all my cargo rolling down. Same with some combat or throwing cargo I just couldn't get myself to face the way I needed too. 

Summary: 
       I got 200+ in a 60$ game so it has payed for itself. Even though I beat the game there is more to do. Replay value is high even though I know how everything ends. I think this is a great game and you would be missing out on a great story if you did pick it up and play it at least once through. Helping and bringing people together is what this game is about.

This is a unique and fun game. 5/5

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
To get the obvious out: a masterpiece.
Aside from city building simulators, combat has been the main course at the restaurant of gaming for 30 years now. I am not a fan of stealth games in general, but Kojima et al expanded on the stealth formula to make it rewarding. The amount of avenues one could  approach Metal Gear Solid V missions is a trait that carries onward with Death Stranding. I never felt limited as a player to approach a mission the way I wanted to approach it. 

And my god- the rewarding way terrain navigation was handled in game. This game is a 10/10 for the sole reason the team managed to create a system in which the player ENJOYS navigating the terrain- a series of mini puzzles. And then gives the tools to make those paths easier on the repeat- and to other players.
This strand type gameplay, I hope to see in the future- true cooperation.
I beat the game about 10 hours ago at review time, and still am coming back, I believe it may be the first game I 100%.
If you are on the fence about buying, I am jealous, I would love to play this game for the first time again.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I don't usually write reviews for games, but Death Stranding deserves it. This game I feel was too bagged on in the beginning. Yes the game start with just taking packages from point A to B. It then start to open up giving a beautifully crafted world jam packed with lovable deep characters. The mechanics get deeper action gets better and the adventure always seems worth it. Hideo Kojima knocked it out of the park with this game and it makes me excited for what he has in the future. It is not for everyone but if you want a game to get lost in with deep lore give this game a try.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: An interesting Progressive Freak Show with Puzzle solving and optimization tests versus other users online. Those users also enter into your gameplay to leave you reminants of their play. An interwoven multiplayer shared experience.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The second playthrough is when this game's story really shines. One of the best games I've ever played. The graphics are the best I've ever seen (to date). The music selection is spot on. The controls are very, very, smooth and every aspect of this game is "mostly" very polished to that of a Nintendo Mario game. The motion capture and acting and voice overs are done well. This game is much than a "walking simulator" and its very lazy to label this game as that term seeing that players get access to vehicles very early on. 

Having one linear profile is my biggest gripe of this game. I would have like to have had the ability to make at least two profiles, one OFFLINE and one ONLINE. 

[spoilers] Tommie Earl Jenkins, WOW, did he steal the show at the end. His character of Die-HardMan was very captivating.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The visuals and audio on this game are beautiful, and the story is strangely entrancing, though it is pretty bizarre. If you play through the main game without going into the side-quests, then it is a brisk cinematic experience, with plenty of content to fill 20 hours or more of playtime. If you begin to obsess over completing every non-story grind-quest to level up your relationships, you might find it repetitive.

Some people, though, will also love the grind. It is very beautiful delivering packages and finding new ways to use your tools, and there is a real sense of connection, both with the AI and with other players through the online feature. It's really nice when someone helps you out for no reason, and there is basically no way to grief or harass other players. It's a lonely world with these increasingly frequent shout-outs and boosts from strangers, and it's really nice to be able to help them too.

I think this is the game the world needs right now.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Finished God Kojima's Death Stranding. Man I never thought this game is gonna deliver so satisfying ending. Yeah the game starts off slow it won't make sense at all in the beginning but it blew me off at the end. Loved the experience.A very decent game by Kojima. I hope this game doesn't get fucking cracked any day just like red dead. I played the entire game on 4k ultra settings and it was a WILD experience. Must play game.
I rate this game 10/10 for its uniqueness.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is like if MGS5 and Silent Hill had a bastard child and then Euro Truck Simulator adopted it and raised it as his own.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
EDIT: Real review

* It says walking simulator, but most of my time was spent in a bike/truck/zip lines. Infact you only need to walk once to get to your next destination, then you can setup infrastructure like roads, bridges and zip lines to make the trip a 10-15 second commute. 
* Combat is not just there but expected. You have to raid MULE camps (bandit camps) to get resources to build infrastructure. Chiral Crystals are scarce unless you fight BT bosses then you get like 1k-2k in one shot.
* The story starts slow and then dumps everything in the last few hours. Almost as if Kojima was running out of time/budget and cramped the last parts in. Some cut scenes are just cringey. 
* The actual walking simulator part is varied enough to not get repetitive, there are enough new unlocks and toys to play with to keep things fresh. 
* Optional deliveries is how you upgrade your weapons and armour. 
* Online play is strongly recommended as the infrastructure of other players randomly show up in your game. Which helps a lot.
* Inventory management during boss fights are annoying. You have to go into menu to throw away empty guns/magazines, otherwise it weighs you down.
* One of the best looking games out there. Great optimisation.

All in all, I think we should appreciate Kojima to taking a risk and making a game which is unique. Only Kojima can make a walking simulator fun.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't think you'll ever see another AAA game in whatever odd genre this is for a long time. To top it off it does whatever this is well. 

You start off like a mailman in the old west, hiking great distances to deliver stuff, that's interesting for a while, but right as it gets a little tired, bam an easier way to traverse with a bunch of drawback so you still gotta do walking here and there. Then eventually you get the ability to upgrade things that makes travel easier and you feel like you're flying high. 

However you run into a lot of new challenges that require you to mix up your approach until you eventually find a new tech, which changes the game to be all about logistics and easy supply chains, mixing in a bit of the previous stuff you learned. Also new challenges.

Then it all comes together, you get a ton of Kojima plot and bam. Weird fun awesome game. I tried not to spoil anything.

Also there's a bunch of side stuff to do. The game can go from a bit short if you rush the story to quite long if you take your time and jump into the side content. Up to you, interesting either way.

Also sometimes you get to shoot a gun, as like a mini-game here and there to break up the usual. It's far from the best gunplay, faaar, but it's done well enough to be an enoyable diversion.

I liked this a lot.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game isn't balls to the wall action, but it's an amazing story with a great soundtrack. I highly recommend it, so long as you are someone who is okay with slightly slower games with great story and atmosphere.

This game isn't super challenging, but that's not the point of it either. It's somewhat challenging, but not ridiculously hard, so keep that in mind. It takes quite a while for the real action to start picking up, but I found the in-between parts to be just as fun personally. Once again, I highly recommend it if you are someone who can enjoy a slower experience.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I've just finished the game. When I bought this I was a bit affraid, since MGS V got monotone after a while and got bored of. Well, luckyli this isn't the case in Death Stranding! The gamplay vids and reviews can not transfer you the whole feeling that this game is have. Belive me, it has a very have atmosphere, and wtih those movie type flawless cut scenes that are integrated into the game, man... thats something - and interactive movie, or mini series. 
The cast, the story, the music, it got me already in the prolouge, and that scene when walking down on the hill to reach Port Knot City with Low Roar music in the backround, it is so well directed that not so many games have the same, just only a few, and they are among the all time besties. 
The story still keeps me wondering after my first playtrough, there is a lot into it, with so many life reference about our everydays. I like, that the writeres explored the full potential of this story, but still left some open space to make my own thougts about it. 
Only thing that is not so well played in the story side is that some times some specific key moments are so implentary and repeating, that makes me feel like I am a 5 year old child that needs explanation from everything even if it straight before my eyes.
The gameplay is not ordinary, it has the challanege like any other games but with other mechanics. Death Stranding is really about to be a post man and make deliveries, but how you make it is just only up to you. The game gives you a well edited map, region, with several enviroment hazards and other terrain challenges that makes you wonder how to get trough. For me tha map for the first time felt like empty or boring, but thats not the thing, its a very clever design that gives you the oppourtunity to build delivery routes with items gained later in the game. The route building and searching for the best route is some kind of '90 or early 2000's game thing, its the same when in your child you played the game and tried to pass trough the low poly levels jumping cliff by cliff. With that deliveries almost made me a MULE just like they mentioned in the game, its addictive, and well rewarding, but still not overwhelming.
In total Death Stranding is not just a game, its a feeling, and also a social feeling with its semi multiplayer, an experience that worth the 60 euro price and the ~70 hour gameplay. The story is a whole just don't forget that the game has 15 chapters, the end credits means nothing ;)!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: If you love slow burn entertainment with complex, meaningful and emotional story with compelling characters and long, cinematic cutscenes, Death Stranding is a must play for you. The techinal aspects of the game is also fantastic. The graphics, cinematography, the soundtrack are brilliant. The gameplay can be repetetive and frustrating at times, especially in the first 20 hours bur once you get through that part, it will pay off wonderfully. Death Stranding has become one of my all time favourite game and it is an easy 10/10.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]Death Stranding PC review[/h1]

I've played the PC port of Death Stranding for about 70 hours as of writing, and have played for over 150 hours on PlayStation 4. I can say with honesty that Death Stranding is one of my favorite games of all time. I've been a subscriber to Kojima-san's brand of storytelling since Metal Gear Solid on the original PlayStation all those years ago, so I thought I had some idea of what I was getting myself into...

I had [u][b]no idea[/b][/u] what was coming when I first played Death Stranding.

Between Kojima-san's storytelling and vision, and Shinkawa-san's environmental design, the world immediately captured my attention with its futuristic yet plausible design. I've always enjoyed Shinkawa-san's mechanical designs since I first played the Metal Gear Solid and Zone of the Enders games. If you enjoyed the open world experimentation of MGSV and want to play a game where Kojima-san was able to fully realize his vision, check this game out. It's various difficulty levels allow access by nearly any player, from super easy to incredibly punishing. It has something for everyone.

Death Stranding is an amazing experience, and has a story that both excited me and caused me to cry. This game has caused me to feel things no other video game has. It gives you a true sense of satisfaction and accomplishment, and I never felt bored once in all my playtime. It is one of those "once in a generation" types of video games that truly bridges the gap between a video game and a movie, and in my opinion is a work of art. 

You feel the emotions right alongside the characters, and you experience their trials and tribulations in ways that few other games have accomplished. At the end of one of the hardest deliveries in the game, the evaluation screen began to scroll and I realized I had traveled over 84 kilometers on a single delivery. I let out a astounded gasp and thought: [i]"Did I actually just walk 84 kilometers for a mission in a video game?" [/i]I got an achievement for that one, and I'll always be proud of it. This game has a way of dragging you in, it's nothing for you to think [i]"Ah, I'll sit down and play a bit..."[/i] and next thing you know it's 3 a.m. and you're delivering a mountain-top pizza...

The PC port is nothing short of well executed. There were some hiccups at first that have all been patched out at this point for me. I have only experienced one crash in my entire playthrough of the game, and that was determined to be my fault. (driver update) And on a 2070 Super and Ryzen 3700X system while utilizing DLSS 2.0 I have zero issues playing the game at a nearly locked 120 FPS at most times.

[b]TL;DR;[/b] If you enjoy the hauntingly beautiful worlds full of lore that Kojima-san and his team create, then I highly recommend you check this game out. 

Also, crying baby in a bottle you have to shake like a snow globe to calm them down...
[b](PLEASE DO NOT ACTUALLY SHAKE BABIES LIKE SNOW GLOBES)[/b]
