title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Another masterpiece by Hideo Kojima. This game is kinda unique, its slow, dont expect any fancy crazy action here, its kinda courier simulator at some point. Its perfect game to chill out with beer and have fun. Hiring real actors to game really did the job, Mads Mikkelsen was scary af, Jesse Corti/Guillermo del Toro was funny one, Norman Reedus was kinda meh but rest of the crew really did the great work too, story is really good but at first confusing af, the more u play the more u know. Graphic looks just outstanding, and it runs well even on old pcs, optimilisation is very well made. Connecting whole world with zip line system was satisfying, I really liked how the online mode worked in game, cool idea, sharing everything with other players. Theres just one thing i didnt liked - collectibles. Dont put them into the game when theres no chance to find them without a interactive map or an guide, the world in the game is just too big for stupid small 56 memory chips to find (+most of them are invisible till u get a enugh reputaion for a faction). Getting collectibles was the last thing i did in this game, not rewarding expierence at all. I recommend this game, its solid 50/80h+ of solid gameplay by just doing Story mode. It was fun expierence. :)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Eu nem sei como começar a falar sobre este jogo de tão incrível que ele está sendo até o momento para mim, mas vou tentar expressar algumas coisas nessa análise, que eu espero que ajude outras pessoas a tomarem a sua decisão de compra.
   O jogo certamente não é para todo mundo, visto que a história e o gameplay são únicos e desafiadores. A história é cativante e faz com que cada minuto faça com que o jogador mergulhe ainda mais na profundidade do universo criado pelo Kojima. Já o gameplay, no início pode parecer meio monótono e chato como um walking simulator, mas tudo vai depender de como você experiencia as coisas. Na minha experiência, o gameplay me entregou um momento único, um momento de desafios pelo terreno devastado de Death Stranding e com certeza um momento para refletir e admirar a beleza da paisagem. Uma das grandes surpresas que esse jogo me proporcionou foi com toda certeza a trilha sonora que é espetacular e sensacional! Um outro ponto que preciso comentar da gameplay é o fato do mundo ser construído em conjunto com outros jogadores. Uma ponte que um outro jogador constrói, uma escada, uma corda ou até mesmo placas de informações, facilitam e muito a experiência, uma vez que você poupa muito tempo durante suas entregas, esse elemento faz com que todos se ajudem, cumprindo a promessa do jogo que é "reconectar os humanos no mundo caótico de Death Stranding". Isso me parece uma mensagem clara do Kojima que reflete nossa realidade de hoje, onde estamos desconectados e que precisamos nos reconectar novamente neste mundo caótico que vivemos.
   Eu definitivamente não costumo fazer análises de jogos, mas este jogo mereceu cada palavra que escrevi. Recomendo fortemente este jogo para jogadores que gostam de uma história diferente e que gostam de uma jornada solitária. Nós, jogadores, merecemos mais jogos deste estilo e espero ver mais propostas parecidas em um futuro próximo. Eu tenho muito mais coisas para escrever sobre o jogo, mas não quero me aprofundar muito nessa análise para não ficar chato.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: A weird, but oddly satisfying game that takes what is frequently most boring part of other open world games, traversing the open world, and makes it an engaging fun experience. There is an interesting story in Death Stranding, but you'll find it wrapped in a iffy metaphors, poorly written characters and a rushed presentation.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I love this game! I'm not finished, but the overall story, style and game play is excellent. 

I'm only giving this a negative review because I have been experiencing controller issues. (Not the stuttering/FPS drop which got fixed in this recent patch). My game/controller (XBOX 360, corded) will input commands I'm not doing. The game will "press" buttons when I'm not. Examples: Mounting and dismounting bike, opening up my cuff links (menu), punching for no reason, etc. I use the controller in other games and do not experience "phantom buttons," if you will, so I don't believe it's the controller itself and have heard of others experience this on Reddit with this game.

This can be extremely frustrating in situations against BT's and Mules or just general game play trying to work through menus to have it constantly close and open. I'm really hoping this will get noticed and patched at some point, but until then the game is not currently enjoyable for me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I've really enjoyed this game so far. It feels like a mixture of american/euro truck simulator with assassins creed. Most of the tasks are deliveries, then they have little bits of stealth or combat stuff sprinkled in. The way the character walks and the way the ground and little rocks on it act as obstacles makes for a more interesting and stimulating experience than the truck simulators ive played. 
Also the story feels like a movie level story to me, good acting from all the main characters imo. 
Not sure if this game would be as enjoyable for people who aren't into delivery games

I like the acting of the characters. But I also find them kind of empty shells. I wonder what all the surviving people do, when the stage is mostly filled with a hand full of characters. Some of them are so powerful that they take the spotlight from all the other people living in this game world. The world for me feels empty and meaningless (like nobody is actually alive sort of meaningless). Why am I the only guy, who kind of does something like building structures and roads? Why does nobody from the cities use them once they are build?

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It started with a really attractive experiences, the combination between graphics and musics are just awesome. 
The first few CG really lured you into the game, and I must say even though the game play mechanic is about delivery, it is still way better than some action games. The story behind is great, got you think and even wondering a lot of things. The main idea of connecting people is just unique, and couldn't wish more games learns from it.
However!! 
So here are some downsides you must keep in mind if you really wish to buy this game:
There are TONS of CG in the first hour, like, 70-80% of the time. 
The story telling at the beginning is, well, unclear. It spends a lot of effort to create the feelings, but if you didn't see some Youtuber play it or read the story, you will definitely get lost. You might feel this after watch like 20 mins CG "aha, it's a great cinematic, but what does it tell?"
You CAN'T enter menu and close the game sometimes. Yes, you can't. if you started CG, you might need to skip like 6-7 times before you could take control your character. And remember in the private room, your system menu button does not work. 
Overall it's a legendary game, with great story, awesome idea behind it. But just, be prepared for the first few hours.....

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game started with great promise - performed and behaved well although graphics rendering would start messing up after a few hours overall little problem Some functions cannot have keys remapped on PC (middle mouse button on my PC is allocated a system function but I have to remove that because it is used int he game and cannot be remapped) Skip scene is stupid using different buttons at different times, and clearly during porting nobody bothered to think how having a keyboard might make the interactions better that on a console. 
Story starts well although got a little tired of such a long introductory learning and set of cut scenes (including repeating everything about 4 times), but that improved later.  This in fact kept me playing, but more later...  Focus on construction, improvement and sharing with NPCs and other players was good and well executed for about the first 6 chapters, until the inconsistencies and limitations of the story started impacting. 

While the story started well, the deliveries and collections needed to progress it are entirely linear, just do what you are told one at a time and the next bit is explained, not even a pretence of having any influence - and here the problems start - it starts well but becomes drawn out and contrived,  the main twists of the story are obvious mainly from clues left throughout and the tiny cast of characters, but you have to watch your player constantly ignore the blindingly obvious make stupid choices just to give you challenges at each stage.  Equipment needs to be usable properly -  consider this if you have two locations joined by a road, a truck parked outside with 2 seats, and have to take a person from your location to the other - is there a reason you have to strap them to your back and carry them by foot - just exactly what do we get from that particularly since we had to do it before we were allowed to drive trucks (why can't you use the trucks parked outside every Bridges location).  How inconsistent is it that I can steal a truck but no drive my own company trucks for a large portion of the game.

Overall a game with lots of promise that seemed to deliver to begin with but became tiresome and annoying -  yes of course I want to leave my equipment behind (that I just put together) when I go up against may main enemy - so I can play out the fight scene how someone wants me to, instead of how I want to.  And of course I'll just trust everyone who is obviously using me.    Overall disappointing and falls short of what it could have achieved.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[i] I haven't had a game make me cry like this in a long time. [/i]

[b] Let me just get this out of the way: [/b]

Is this a walking simulator? Yes it is, but with mechanics that make the walking aspect a game in itself. You have to plan and be smart about how you traverse the world. The terrain you walk on is an enemy in itself. 

Gameplay is unique, in a sense that you deliver packages. There is a lot more to it than that, but its best to leave it to the player to find that out. 

Presentation in this game is phenomenal. Cinematography, graphics, audio design, musical score, acting, etc. Its all amazingly well done. 

---

[h1] Personal Thoughts [/h1]

I was really skeptical with this game at first, even after enjoying all of Kojima's previous works, I heard of all the backlash it was getting. I just thought it was a game trying to be different by having a lot of "weird" elements to it.

[i] Boy... was I wrong... [/i]

I won't go into the story as I believe this game is best experienced with having absolutely no prior knowledge.

Mental health is something I have been struggling with the past few years. Games I would pick up and play would just lose me with the traditional game mechanics being recycled and reused. Just felt like I was playing the same Ubisoft open world clone with all these open world games. Death Stranding has been the only game in recent mind to have me come back again and again just to explore the world and "take it all in". It has put my mind in a positive space mentally whenever I'd pick up the game. 

This game relaxes my mind, I feel safe whenever I play this game as cheesy as it sounds. Kojima has crafted a world that has had me emotionally invested in the time I played leading up to its grand finale. I told myself I wouldn't cry, I was actively testing to see if this game would make me cry. Whenever I do that with any other sort of media, I end up not actually crying... but Kojima broke me. I still think about this game's story and characters and still come back playing so I can get my fix on it. 

Kojima... you bastard, the last game I cried to that you made was MGS3 and was wondering if you'd ever be able to get that reaction from me again. 

Thank you, for this once in a lifetime experience, it truly has changed the way I look at the world.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Probably one of my favorite games thus far. Hideo Kojima did an amazing job (as usual). I was introduced to Metal Gear Solid 4 and then backtracked and played 2, 3, and Peacewalker. When MGSV came out I was stoked and while I still think it was a great game, it felt unfinished. When Kojima had full reigns with this game, I am just astounded. While there isnt direct coop, the idea that other players can contribute to you world and vice versa is amazing. The story was confusing at first but then started making sense, in Kojima fashion of course. Finally the ambiance and soundtrack, I get absolutely lost in it. I can play for hours just doing random deliveries on roads that I and other players built together, and when the story queues a song to play and zooms the camera out, its just a masterpiece.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I was a bit skeptical about buying the game. After watching lots of review videos and read articles, I decided to give it a try and I think it is one of the best games I have ever played. I am only at 10 hrs of gameplay and I am totally impressed by vast regions, game mechanics, music(it'e best), detailed terrain, graphics and every aspect. Again it is not everyone's cup of tea. Game essentially doesn't encourage much combat but the deep story and massive and unique multiplayer support is totally something else. First you might get bored a little but eventually you will start appreciating gameplay, you will fall in love with it and it will make you think about the connections we make with people in real life. You will start appreciating life around you. That's the depth of this game.


Edit: 11/08/2020

So, I have completed the game just today with 70+ hours of gameplay and still there are side missions(Standard deliveries) pending but as I have completed the story I wanted to share my experience. Though story seems somewhat weird in starting and you might not be able to connect to dots but eventually you will start understanding what's happening. Story will unfold and new plots and government secrets will be revealed and I liked the plot twists. Kojima showed credits 3 times( YES, THREE times) and still I watched it third time too... Just because of the amazing music. I loved every aspect of game and you are sure for an emotional roller-coaster ride in last few chapters. Though game is bit costly right now but it's worth every penny.

I was so frustrate in bosses fight especially at the final boss, so angry and then joyful after finally beat that thing.
And then there's the end... I cried, it hit me hard. Story is so touching and very well done, it not hard to understand as I thought it would be.
Thank god I did not watch all the trailer out there, step into the game with blind knowledge is recommend.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'd like to preface my review by sharing this feeling of satisfaction I get whenever I approach a destination or see a view.
[spoiler]
First time I remember experiencing this was when I was on my way to Port Knot City. It was going smoothly till you have to take this arduous path through the rocky mountains full of BTs. The path was so difficult, got my cargo damaged, depleted my ammos and blood bags.
The BTs and the timefall were gone when I got to the mountaintop, and Port Knot City was within my field of view. As I trudged down the mountain feeling exhausted, "Asylums for the Feeling" by Silent Poets starts playing. 
The tiresome feeling from the BTs (and BB crying lol), the wonderful sight of Port Knot City, and the chilly music constituted to a deep and beautiful experience. From that point on I knew that [b]Death Standing is a very special game[/b].
[/spoiler]

[h1] "It's an open world game, meaning I'm going to take up so much of these players' precious time. But I don't want the players to just feel like, 'Oh, that was fun.' I want them to feel something more."[/h1]
- Kojima in an interview by Washington Post (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fe7l2MI7ozo)
Right after finishing the game I was just blankly staring at my screen with thoughts in my head in complete disarray. The game was fun as much as it is innovative, but with that I also felt very happy and sad, all the while thinking of [i]what's the meaning of my life[/i].

Here's three main points as to why I think Death Stranding is a great game:

[h1]Story[/h1]

Every character Sam meets in this game has a story to tell that's worth listening to. Most of them had something terrible happen to them in the past, including Sam himself, yet they still choose to keep on fighting for a greater purpose. Sam Bridges' character arc was quite interesting as much as it was relatable to some us - he's a careless man who's just "living a lie, hung up on past regrets", who slowly grows into someone who actually cares for people. Perhaps most of us haven't reached that point yet where we can trust other people, but it gives us hope that we someday we can, too! I'd like to highlight two things about the story that I really liked:

- About Cliff
[spoiler]
The part where Cliff and Sam met as father and son for the first and last time was a beautiful yet sad moment of revalation.
At this part of the game it was shown that the visions Sam was seeing while connecting to Lou was his own memories, and that Clifford Unger was his father all along. 
Cliff gave Sam the baby (which is also Sam), then hugged him. Cliff was then (regretfully) shot by a comrade of his who loves and respects him a lot.
[/spoiler]

- About Amelie
[spoiler]
This was the part that got me the most. Halfway through the game, when Heartman was explaining things to Sam, I thought to myself, why would someone (at that point, I was thinking of Higgs) want to get it all over with, make the sixth extinction happen when there could still be a lot of time before it happens? Was he a nihilist of some sort? Later on in the game it was revealed that Amelie/Bridget was behind it all along. She is an Extinction Entity (EE) whose task is to make sure that the next extinction will happen.

Whether the next extinction shall happen in the next 1 or 100,000 years, Amelie is stuck on her beach, waiting for it to happen. Given the fact that the next extinction is inevitable, she chooses to conjure up a story to convince everyone to speed up the extinction, so as to end her agony. I'm not saying that her means and ends are justified, but, knowing her suffering as an EE, I now understand why she did those things. But since Sam and his friends were able to "unite" America, she's willing to wait for another lifetime.

To quote her words, "The extinction isn't just an ending. It's an opportunity. And if I have to pay the price for that - to be the sacrifice - then so be it."
[/spoiler]


[h1]Lore[/h1]
Almost Everything about this game is so intriguing yet so fascinating! The beaches in the game somewhat represent what most people believe as purgatories - a final place where people go to when they die, before going to the afterlife. And BTs (Beached Things) are the spirits from the Beach who can't move on to the afterlife due to some attachment to the world of the living. Does this mean that the BBs are shamans? 

In the game, every people in America has isolated themselves inside their homes, due to the fear of endangering their lives - timefall, BTs, and the possibility of a voidout is right outside of their doorsteps. They ask for Porters like Sam to deliver things to them such as documents, food, medicine, and other stuff. It's interesting how Death Stranding is uncannily similar to what's happening now to the world due to the Coronavirus pandemic.

And most importantly, about the 
[spoiler]
Five Major Extinctions, and the Inevitable Sixth. For some of you who don't know, The Five Major Extinctions did happen, though, not caused by Extinction Entities! 
There's two conflicting ideas in the game that's explained to the character: You either just make the extinction happen 'cause it'll happen anyways, or you work your ass out to evade it in order to enjoy life more. Of course, the latter is more emphasized by the game.
I wouldn't want to shed more light on this, except for the fact that I'm being brought back to a time where I was contemplating about life and its purpose - It's all in a good way, of course!
[/spoiler]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
On a lower level of abstraction, it is a game where you're tasked to deliver things, and in order to do so, you should manage your cargo, plan your route, and build structures/vehicles to make your journey easier. As you continue with the game, you'll unlock more stuff to use, which makes the travel fun! It'll feel so damn rewarding when you get the skeletons, the carriers, and all those things for convenience. Hell yeah this is a delivery-man/truck/walking simulator, and [b]I am having fun[/b]!

On a higher level, and as all of you may know, the game is all about connection, and thinking [i]what connection truly means[/i]. The true definition of "connection" is all about caring for someone else (at least that's what Kojima says in one of his interviews). This resonates strongly as you progress through the game. You're not allowed to hurt other players, all you can give to them are positive things such as giving them likes, building them a structure, or leaving them a tool to use.

Your task as a porter is to connect with people, whether with the NPCs in the game or with other players online. I suppose the deliveries were meant to be hard at first, so that when you're able to use other player's structures, you would realize how easy it is with other's help. You would go through a path, then think how it could've been easier, then you build structures for others to use. As you expand the chiral network and see other players' structures, as you build your own structures for other porters' sake, you'll find out that you'll stand stronger in solidarity with other players. 

Kojima said in an interview that he is making a game in a time where everyone's so disconnected and detached from one another in spite of all the technologies that make it easy to reach out to people. He said that through this game he hopes that everyone will [i]cherish the relationships that we so strongly had[/i] a few years/decades ago. Now if that isn't amazing, I don't know what is.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I've seriously began to appreciate the mail workers delivering my packages after playing through this game. [strike]Mail Simulator[/strike] Death Stranding is a beautiful game where [strike]Norman Reedus[/strike] Sam Bridges is employed as [strike]a delivery guy[/strike] an agent of BRIDGES to reunite America [strike]by dealing with whiny NPCs, getting hunted by exploding soulsuckers, babysitting, and a door mat for practically everyone[/strike] by completing the chiral network and rescue a certain someone and it couldn't be anymore tedious.

It is a beautiful world with definitely-not-garbage-Fragile-dialog("I'm Fragile but not that [i]fragile[/i]") and I am pleased it runs smoothly on both my laptop and my main rig with a bit more graphical improvements over the PS4 version. Do please play this game especially when you don't like killing people (like you secretly like to do in GTA) since they tend to turn into soulsuckers(**cough BTs) who eats some poor schmuck somewhere and explode to shove a game over up your ass. Otherwise, feel free to experience balancing poor Sam when you've punished him by stacking several Norman-tall worth of stuff on his back or, of course, fall asleep on your desk.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Peak Kojima, for good and ill. If you don't like Kojima's style of storytelling and presentation, or the concept behind Death Stranding's gameplay, you won't like the game.

BUT, if you are open to the type of game Death Stranding is, it will not disappoint. This is a top 5 game of the decade for me. An utterly stunning, unique and masterful experience that made me feel emotions almost no other game has been able to. This is what gaming as high art looks like.

Besides the masterpiece of a game Death Stranding is, the PC port is one the best I have ever seen for a former console exclusive. Everything worked flawlessly and the game runs like a dream, especially if you have RTX and can take advantage of DLSS. Given the recent atrocity of a port Horizon Zero Dawn has proven to be, this shows that Kojima cares about the PC platform and the studio put a lot of time and effort into giving us the premium experience.

10/10 Will not forget anytime soon

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Despite some errors that this game has, such as DX12-ErrorCode: 0x887a0005, that 30%-40% of the players (myself included) are experiencing.

This is truly a Kojima game, and sadly is not for everyone.
Just like many people didn't like the Metal Gear saga because it was too long with so many cutscenes, there are many people that won't like this game... but at this point, as seen in Steam reviews, 94% of the people that bought this game, already knew what they were buying, it was a Play Station exclusive in 2019 so some of those got a lot of time to watch some videos and trailers.

I will not spoil anything about the plot here.

This game has like 10-12 hours of cutscenes which are the best I've ever seen in a videogame, using photogrammetry with awesome actors, was just an amazing idea.
The plot is just immersive, well explained and it feels complete, once you finish the game, you don't end up waiting for answers, or going to youtube searching "Death Stranding Ending Explained", all your questions and doubts are answered at the time they need to be answered.

If you've played Euro Truck Simulator you will find out that this game will give you the same kind of satisfaction once you deliver a cargo that is big and that was far away, lucky, the second area makes everything more interesting, pushing your limits as a single delivery man with more enemies, more BT's areas, bautiful landscapes and access to build roads.

On my first playthrough I finished the game on Very Hard difficulty. Which it didn't feel quite hard after all, once you know how to fight back or avoid the enemies and how to walk on certain terrain, everything becomes easier.

The music in this game... I don't really like it, 90% of the time I found myself lowering the volume so I can hear my own music which is kinda frustrating because you lose the immersion on the game.

This game starts to get repetitive once you reach the second area, but just like Euro Truck Simulator, there are other ways, because you will find yourself going to new parts of the map, searching for lost cargo or finding new NPCs to fill the emptiness on the map that sometimes the main plot doesn't require you to go in some areas. So after all, there is always something new to discover, as in my 100hrs in this game, I still finding new areas.

To finish this review...
I really love this game, I finished it within 80 hrs of gameplay, which 40 of them I spent building roads to make my deliveries safe and faster.
The Premium Order is just an obsession to get the highest recognition from other porters which I gotta admit, it makes the game longer.
You can give likes to other porters trough their buildings and as I can see on the scoreboard, some guys from china already have 5-6 millions likes, so once the game introduces you the scoreboard, you don't get any obsession just like the Premium Order.

This game is at its best when you play it offline, without the help of everyone else on the map. It's like Extreme difficulty, which I will play again once I finish this game at 100%

As I said before, this game is not for everyone, but since I've been waiting too long to finally play it on PC (because I never played it on PS4), I really loved it.

Is just perfect. 10/10

PD. Let's hope you don't get inside of the 40% of the players that are experiencing game crashes. If you have bad luck, the only solution at the moment that have worked is limiting your fps, if you run the game at 121-135fps limit the fps to 120, 61-110fps limit it to 60, 31-50fps limit it to 30 (It's not that bad, you are not playing a fast first person shooter game) and so on.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This is a hard game to recommend. If you like the idea of Euro Truck Simulator with ghosts, then this might be your thing. That being said, for a "walking sim" the sim part is pretty laughable. Glitchy controls and character animations, and Excitebike levels of vehicle physics. The horse in Skyrim obeys more Newtonian laws. Then sprinkle in 20-30 minute cutscenes with awkward dialogue exposition which thoroughly explain character motives, while glossing over the whole WTF IS THIS GAME ABOUT!? And yet, I keep coming back to play it. I normally have long abandoned games that put me through this much frustration. The chiral network grows on you, so play at your own risk.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Mild Spoilers. Probably the most chill game I ever played in the past 10 years. The journey and tasks this game gives you really challenges how you approach each task. They give you moments of panic sure where you need to face off against BT's and such but you overtime start to get a habit of preperation and strategy like getting your self set up for fights and long runs. The whole online thing of being connected across games where you see other people's things in your own world and their equipment they drop while also providing and being provided retrieval of your own things you lost is great. But the best part is when you fight bosses and you have to think on your feet. I would definitely recommend to anyone who just wants to have a game they can chill on and see the beautiful scenery and story line.

title: DEATH STRANDING

It's a fantastic port that can run 4k well even with a 2060 and that is something I cannot say about any other game.

The graphics can be breathtaking but there could be a bit more variation in the environments. 

Even with the quite repetitive environments and seemingly simple and repetitive gameplay, the game has gotten me hooked and I've been enjoying it a lot. 

It's a relaxing and meditative work of art and masterpiece of sorts.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is an absolute gem. One of my favorite games of all time as it stands. I have a soft spot for games with unique game play loops and great stories and boy did this fit the bill. I could go on for hours about how weird and confusing it can get at times, but that's why I love it. The mystery, the suspense, the absurdity of it all is fantastic. At no point in the game did it feel repetitive to me, it was always engaging because I felt like I was working towards something. I felt like I was developing with Sam, and growing into a better person because of it. Even though there were a ton of situations that were just borderline insane, i felt as if i had a connection to it all. It's a game play experience and a story that will live with me, and I'm glad for it. The game looked amazing, navigating menus was intuitive, and planning routes and load outs was challenging and could be punishing. I would definitely visit the world of Death Stranding again given the opportunity.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Story

The story is a slow burn at the beginning, and the opening cutscenes are frustratingly long. At the beginning of the game, I felt very frustrated that I had to slog through cutscenes instead of actually playing a game. Once the story started coming together, though, I ended up loving the cutscenes and happily anticipated the next set of revelations. By the end of the game, I was fully engrossed. The story is trippy and weird and follows its own strange logic that is hard to digest at first, but becomes more clear as the game progresses. It's a lovely story full of well-rounded characters, with very convincing acting. My favorite character was Mads Mikkelsen's character, played with a lot of love and warmth. The only egregiously bad acting was done by Mala Morgan as the Chiral Artist.

Gameplay

The gameplay itself can be kinda samey at times, but I still find it fun to plot routes and power through difficult terrain while still keeping my cargo in tip-top shape. The way the game reveals new upgrades makes even nonessential deliveries feel rewarding, though sometimes they can be a bit of a slog if you have to travel far. Vehicles prove not to be as useful as you'd hope; however, once you start rebuilding roads, vehicles are a huge convenience, even if restricted to a specific set of roads. The sneak mechanics are a little annoying, and I find myself either outrunning MULEs or fighting them all 9 times out of 10. Sneaking is essential in BT territory, though, especially in the early game when fighting isn't a feasible option. In general, the gameplay itself is relaxing and meditative, and you get to navigate some truly breathtaking scenery.

Overall, I'd give it an 8.5/10 and I would recommend playing the game through to its epilogue.

One minor note: THE HIGGS PARTICLE DOESN'T GIVE THINGS MASS, THE HIGGS FIELD DOES. THE HIGGS PARTICLE IS JUST AN EXCITATION OF THE HIGGS FIELD! ARGH! Thank you for coming to my TED talk.

title: DEATH STRANDING

Descrever o jogo é muito difícil. Se você está na dúvida pra comprar porque viu gente por aí dizendo que o jogo é só andar pra lá e pra cá, ignore. A mecânica do jogo realmente é ir do ponto A ao ponto B, mas a atmosfera criada pelo jogo dá sentido a isso. Você se importa com o mundo, com as entregas, com as pessoas.
Existe uma sensação de comunidade com outros jogadores também, porque tudo que você faz no mundo afeta o jogo dos outros jogadores também.

Se você só procura ação, não compre.
Se procura uma experiência única, com certeza compre!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
There are a whole bunch of excellent reviews of this game already posted here and all over the interwebs, far better written than I can muster. I read them. Probably all of them. Thought it was a good idea because I just couldn't make up my mind. I happen to have a spanking PC totally overpowered for nearly any game out there and quite honestly I finally bought it for the test it would give my rig. That being said...I've hooked in to 15 hours on this so far and I don't see this slowing down anytime soon. 

Unlike anything I've ever played. Hard to describe without falling short of how well put together the whole experience actually is. Did I mention it's addictive? Wanna lose 5 hours in a game and know that it's just a pebble in the pond of time that you could spend if you didn't actually have to live in the real world? This is that game.

I don't expect this couple of paragraphs to convince you to get on board and it's fine if you don't, but if you do, I'll be sure to send you a like in-game. See you on the road less travelled.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
To be honest, I was rooting against this game last year during the game awards. I thought look at this pretentious Kojima game with celebrity cameos and "No gameplay". Maybe I was just salty about it being a PS exclusive. When I saw it was coming to PC/Steam and effort was being put into the port, or rather it had been designed for PC from the beginning I thought I need to give this game a chance. And I'm glad I did.

This is not just "Movie Game" or a "Walking Simulator" or "Kojima's Wild Ride". Well actually it is that last one but that's OK. But it's also more than all that. It involves many themes and many statements and yes the lore is silly and convoluted sometimes but it has a real structure and an emotional core worth experiencing. The soundtrack, the acting, all are insanely well-produced for a game and it makes a big difference. I cringed at the naming conventions and some of the characters initially but by the end of the game all were memorable and felt like real performances, not just voice acting. The soundtrack is phenomenal, one of the best with original songs and inserts.

The gameplay can basically be boiled down to "UPS delivery man simulator" if you wanted to but it's a bit like calling Sekiro a hack and slash or Halo a "run around and shoot things" game. It's hard not to make it sound pretentious, but it's a game that uses the medium of "the struggle" to draw you into the experience. Sometimes things are going to suck: you're going to trip and fall and damage cargo, get rained on, get attacked by terrorists or worse. But you keep on keeping on. This is where the social aspect of the game comes in, as you connect destinations to each other you'll see other players' structures and encouraging messages and they'll see yours. It's hard to explain really without breaking it down but the game really is about bridging connections between people.

So basically tl;dr go into the game with an open mind and a healthy suspension of disbelief in parts and you will have a good time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm trying to keep this real. I'm not going to give Kojima a pass on certain things just because he's the greatest game designer of all time.  Of course the story is just what I'd expect from a Hideo Kojima title- a deep experience that connects you to the greater human condition. I'm only 50+ hours into this game and have yet to complete the main story, but I'm guessing this will probably be up there with MGS 3 & 4 with a misty eyed you won't soon forget.
There are some elements of game play that I take issue with. If you're going for a walking simulator where real world physics are a real concern, please explain why all of your cargo and posessions in your vehicle are laying on the ground after fighting a super BT?  I wasn't even targeted. Played no role in the fight. I get that one of the themes of the game is suffering and overcoming adversity, but geez.  Also, the vehicles are almost not even worth the trouble. They are unresponsive at times and navigating rough terrain is a pain in the ass. I get that it would be that way in real life, but not when your vehicle has jumping capabilities.  They can be useful, but only in spurts, I'd argue. Maybe things will change when I've put more time into this game. I dunno.
A part of me knew that like a typical Kojima game, you WILL be penalized for killing. I just didn't know how badly. I appreciate the recurring non violent themes in Kojima's games, but sometimes they feel a little too forced.
Don't get it twisted. When it comes down to it, I'm splitting hairs, because this is a great game. Despite what I said about non violence feeling forced at times, it's also deeply rewarding putting MULES in their place wrapped up in cord or unconscious on the ground after a few well placed haymakers. lol  The terrorists are far more challenging because they have no problem killing you right out to take your stuff.  Be warned. Fighting them usually isn't worth the trouble unless you are carrying limited cargo and they have something you really want. Also, while at first I foung reading mail to be a chore, as I advanced through the game I started to get immersed in the Death Stranding universe. Maybe not to the degree of Mass Effect codex entrees, but close.

All in all, this game is very addicting.  It could be the validation you get from leveling up and being validated by the NPCs you're delivering to.  Metal Gear Solid is one of the greatest gaming franchises ever and it's not fair to judge this game based off Kojima's previous accomplishments.  Death Stranding isn't just a filler project. It's a great game with something unique to contribute.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Let me list down some bullet points of the good and bad I got from this game so far. I havent finished the game yet and Im on episode 8 currently but I have played enough to understand whats good and whats bad and what can be fixed about it.


[h1]The Good[/h1]
-The Visuals and atmosphere. can be very relaxing at times.

-The Music (although I am not a fan of vocals in any kind of music, since its my personal bias but I can appreciate most of the music here)

-The online aspect of the game. The main takeaway and why I'm still even playing this.

-Animations and Cutscenes are well done. 

-The story and lore. It is very interesting and the mystery is quite appealing. However...(Go to The Bad)

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-The non user friendly UI and the speed of navigating through it. Need better QOL changes for this.
[b]Suggestion:[/b] There are a couple of things like: 
faster way to saving, 
make it so that when you access a terminal you can access private locker, recycle, donate and shared locker on one menu instead of having to switch between each of them everytime. That way you can offload, donate, recycle or take cargo IN ONE GO.
-In Inventory UI make it so that you'reable to select all cargo to be offloaded with one click, making it so that equipping the power skeleton automatically puts the cargo on your hips to your back, 

-Unnecessary cutscenes/ Animations
[b]Suggestion:[/b] Make it so that the game has an option where it will remember what cutscene to be skipped automatically. (this will not affect any unique cutscene that comes across thouhg) If its a repeating cutscene that appears on a certain action, make it so that it's automatically skippable. No need for us to have to wait like a few seconds before manually skipping it. You think people want to watch everytime Sam drinks 1 monster energy drink in the private room? or do you think people want to watch the Bridget Poster Logo everytime they recycle something? Or do you think people want to watch Sam get on a truck for 

-Too much expository dialogue and too much dialogue where you are forced to pay attention without giving the player the ability to do anything while the dialogue plays out.
[b]Suggestion:[/b] make it so that you have them talk to the player while they are out doing missions. You do have many of this but you should incorporate more of it.

-The first few hours of the game gives such a slow burn and lacks the investment appeal and is hard to gain new players this way without at least frontloading something interesting to the player to make them look forward to the gameplay. 

-Some of the voice acting such as the Chiral Artist, Fragile and sometimes Deadman are pretty bad. All of them are trying too hard to speak in english and I feel its better for them to just use their native language or probably get someone else who can professionally dub them. And seriously...What is up with the Chiral Artist? I have to be blunt here but her voice acting is horrible. If she cant do the voice acting like this please let someone dub her or let her speak in her native language.

-The Villain. (although I cant say it yet since i havent finished the game but...) He's very one dimensional so far and his constant unexplained absence while Sam is reconnecting all the networks are yet to be revealed to me.

-The way the story is told throughout the game. The game suffers with pacing issues and the way the story is told is too much on the nose and kind of makes us as the players stupid instead of trying to tell the story in a way that it allowing us to understand the story on our own. Interview data, mails and memory chips do not help in this case.

-The lack of personality of the Delivery recipients. Their dialogue is boring at best and cringey at most. Make it so that they actually say something worthwhile whenever you deliver something at their terminal instead of waiting to get that star on the connection level to get some kind of physical reward. 

[b]Suggestion[/b] I would suggest putting off some of the mails and replacing them as dialogues for these NPCs. like each delivery instead of them just saying "thanks again, take care Sam" they tell a brief story on how they've improved or how they've gain back their confidence or something.

-Unexplained blatant advertising (monster energy drink, Ride trike and norman reedus flagrantly sponsoring his show while riding it)


All in all, I cant say I can recommend this a 100%. its more on 50/50.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I hesitated buying this remembering the initial reviews post launch at which point back then I immediately wrote it off but then I saw a stellar review score on steam.  So.....

My word what an amazing story.  Generally speaking I am the king of skipping cut scenes.  I genuinely hate most crappy gaming stories and look more at the actual game play for my entertainment.  This one not so.  Every aspect of the story I absorbed, wanting more the whole time, and the end.... ugh.  I haven't been this absorbed in a story maybe ever.  

Game play - I can see here why this may not have been for everyone but I like games where I get to decide what to do next so all the journeys were all or at least in part my own design and I enjoy that freedom.  Granted there is an overlaying progression for the story so there is some structure there.  The combat is not fleshed out or challenging enough to be honest and the AI design straight up sucks.  Pretty simple that even the most basic player can excel at.  I think that this is probably what motivated the past reviews by the bigger names upon release.  The real challenge here is deciding on a rout, getting to know the landscape and the hazards within it, and getting better at avoidance/navigating the terrain.  Here though I do think the game direction went a little mad - your basically a postman... the crappiest job in the entire world.... especially during the holidays and when people in large apartment complexes mail order large bags of dog food.  Considering the mail man thing and the real lack of potential with that I think they did a masterful job at making the unfun fun.  Prepare for a walking sim though with a lot of depth.

Unlocks and evolving your character - amazing.  a perfect work reward balance the entire way through the game and felt very rewarding as well as little and big items being game changers.  Yeah this was perfect.  Good job here!

All in all I find myself having completed the game just shy of 100 hours and wished there was more because I don't want to stop playing.  For a game, that finish is about as much as you can ask for.  Im not sure how profitable this game was but fingers crossed for DLC and a sequel.  I really really want more and am glad I bought the game.  For those on the fence just go for it!  People this story... Im telling you... the way its delivered, acted out by a masterful cast, the twists, the head scratching, the revelations... I went on a 26 mile bike ride today and meditated on that story the whole time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
---UPDATED REVIEW AS OF 8/9/2020---
I wanted to provide a cautionary tale, now that I am in the middle of Chapter 8. TDLR below...

My experience with Death Stranding has been a glorious roller coaster ride of sorts. Full disclosure, I was on the Death Stranding hype train; having missed out on the PS4 release I pre-ordered this as soon as humanly possible on Steam. I also went into this game without seeing any game play footage other than Digital Foundry's (PS4 release). 

After spending a few hours with the game, I was hooked on the story and the strange yet incredibly satisfying game play. At this point in time, I wrote my initial review of the game; basically saying the game was AMAZING...and it is!

However, after I spent a few hours with the game, my OCD kicked into overdrive and before long I found myself completely distracted from the main story line and focusing on two things: (1) 5-starring (ie. completionisting (I know it's not word)) all the delivery distro centers and (2) building/upgrading structures for others players. 

At this point, I was somewhere in Chapter 2 or Chapter 3, and I was asking questions such as (1) Does Norman Reedus actually have dialogue of ANY substance? (2) Do I seriously give a crap about my BB (the baby)?? As you might guess, at 35 years of age I was seriously questioning my abilities to make solid judgement calls on video game pre-orders.  

But, I had slapped down the $$$ for the title and I wasn't about to just walk away. And thank the good Lord I didn't because wow! For me, Chapter Four is where I got hooked. I can't explain why exactly because of spoilers, but for me this is where the game truly starts to pull the curtain back a bit...and it's amazing. Also, yes Norman Reedus does in fact talk (and for the most part) he's convincing. He's out shined by some other characters IMO like Die-hard Man, Mama and Heartman. And also, I did learn to love my BB for reasons that again I cannot share (spoilers). 

Needless to say, if you don't allow yourself to get overwhelmed and try to advance the story at least every 2 hours (unlike myself) I believe you will greatly enjoy Death Stranding!

During my playtime I have experienced phantom controller inputs as well as some odd frame rate dips during some (not all) cut scenes. Otherwise, from a technical standpoint the game runs beautifully on my system. 

TLDR: If the story appears to start off a bit slow, don't lose hope! Also, don't let (as I did) OCD take over; it's fine to stop and smell the roses once in a while, just remember to advance the main story every 1-2 hours if you can and you won't regret it. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
---Original Review---
Death Stranding has easily been the highlight of my Summer. The open-world is a thing of beauty and terror all at the same time. I'm loving the mystery and story-telling; the characters are incredibly fascinating to me and only make me want to deliver MORE packages for them! If only all package carriers were as reliable as Sam...

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: It is weird that I am about to utter the words that are about to come out of my mouth... this game is a walking simulator and this game is fun af. Reading about it does not do it justice. Not his best work but definitely a Hideo Kojima game. I love the overly long, surreal cut scenes, and story, so I see that as a positive. I honestly did not think this game would be as fun as it is, so I was pleasantly surprised at how much fun I actually had and the graphics with DLSS 2.0 is freaking amazing! This is a great game with some of the most fun game play I have had in a while and also has that novel Hideo Kojima experience that no one else can replicate!

title: DEATH STRANDING

"This game is so gorgeous on PC"

*cries in 1050ti*

I gotta say, despite having to set everything on the lowest setting possible, the game still looks really good and it runs decently on my end of things. The soundtrack is nice, slow, bombastic and the Low Roar playlist fits in this game's traveling occasions very well.

Initially a friend and I were, like every gamers beforehand, hyped for Hideo Kojima's epic return but as the post release happened, things looked pretty iffy. "Ewww it's a walking sim" "laaaaame and boring!" HOWEEEEVER--- By the time you start this game, you'll start to forget the somewhat negative feedback of it being a walking sim and undoubtedly embracing it for what it is. The world Kojima portrayed in this game is oddly compelling and the gameplay is so serene, to an extend. You'll know what I mean.

title: DEATH STRANDING

10/10 would find ghosts with a baby and pee on them too.

Jokes aside, I really like this game. It's a slow paced adventure where you are travelling from one point to another while braving various hazards. The graphics are great, the gameplay feels tight and there are tense moments where I was literally at the edge of my seat.

That being said, I would caution about the bugs and would recommend having my finger on the refund button. There are few bugs, but the ones that exist are devastating. I had an access violation bug that prevented the game from even starting, and others have reported something similar. Be careful!

review:
This game has left a lasting impact upon me and I hope it will do the same for you. I haven't connected a game this much since my younger Playstation days. The story, visuals, mechanics, characters and music all create an atmosphere that you will find hard to leave. Finishing the game felt like I was closing a book that I didn't want to stop reading. So go ahead and give it a shot or wait for a sale, either way you won't be dissatisfied. 

My advice is to take your time and enjoy the ride, I 5 Starred almost all distro centers at the time of writing this before I beat the game and a small part of me wishes I hadn't so that I'd be more inclined to repeat it. I hope Kojima Productions reads this review and seriously considers making a new game plus so that I keep my cosmetics for another play through.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a remarkable achievement. The innovative gameplay loop that serves as the foundation is simply unheard of and the way all areas of the game-online component, side quests, main quests, general exploration and the overarching story- are connected to this "Strand Gameplay" is a stroke of genius. There are some glaring flaws and Kojima seems to have a hard time creating satisfying bossfights when it comes to execution, but the positives completely outweigh the negatives. Beautiful scenery, excellent cinematography and the most impressive mo-cap performances I've seen in a videogame so far take an already impressive work to another level. It sure as hell isn't for everyone, but those who get into the gameplay loop will find themselves entranced by Hideo Kojima's surreal universe. 

Tomorrow is in your hands.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is a slow burn, artistic take on the current generation action genre. I highly recommend checking this masterpiece out especially if your looking for something fresh. The story is interesting and compelling as you follow along a fragmented plot piecing everything together as you go along. It;ll take you for a ride of emotions by the time you reach the end of your journey. The game play is lacking a little but honestly I didn't mind as I had much more fun taking up the shoes of a Porter thrlling to piece to gether my past and my future then I would have running and gunning as if I where an invincible Spec ops god. The graphics are next gen and nothing more needs to be said about how beatiful this game is and how pair with the sound track and audio will suck you in from the start.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[b]That's... quite astonishing.[/b]
You can't really grasp on what's even going on, especially in the beginning; just being thrown in this new world you don't have any understanding of. And as such it is really hard to tell why exactly I love this game.
Maybe it is the feeling of, again, being thrown in a place with everything so weird and conceptually new; having to learn everything as you go. Maybe the story, which believe me, is great and makes you invested in its characters, at some points sending shivers down your spine. Maaaaybe it is just me knowing that I've bought it for quite the price that makes me so invested...  alright, jokes, jokes.
Also, for this to not be your regular and vague review, I think I need to say this: Although I can see how from the outside perspective some people may find it, to put it simply, boring... and I can see some of my friends' interests not being exactly compatible with the plot or gameplay of this game overall, this game is really not about making deliveries. It's, at least for me, a duo of the storyline and the online segment:  While the storyline is obviously the main thing that pushes you forward making you experience all kinds of emotions, the other makes you go the extra mile trying to be helpful and useful to other players.  I'm, let's just say, very affectionate and every like on the things I build saying that players have found me helpful really gets me going. And just returning to the game after going to sleep, seeing something like "A player used the road you rebuilt" and a few thousand likes no kidding makes my day.
Not taking the price into account, I insist that everyone should at least try this piece for an hour or two and make up their own opinion.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]Pretty much the best postman simulator to date![/h1]

The core gameplay loop is probably not for everyone:

- mostly [b]overcoming terrain[/b] by different means to deliver stuff
- there is [b]combat[/b], but most of it is [b]strongly disadvised[/b] for the majority of the game

If you can get into it though, it is probably unlike everything you've played before (which I'd count as a positive, seeking something different from the norm). I'd not go as far as Kojima saying that he created a "completely new type of genre", but it is indeed a unique experience to be had.

The [b]really strong points of the game are the story, music, and the cinematography[/b] (there are really beautifully crafted shots and scenes in the game, any of which you could use as a wallpaper or literally hang as pictures on your wall, this is complemented by a pretty good photo mode in game).

The theme is solid sci-fi with some religious/fantasy elements strewn in.

[b]It is a Hideo Kojima game[/b] though, so it can get really strange at times, and it is littered with (sometimes more, sometimes less subtle) movie references, as well as some elements that are figuratively thrown in your face (I mean the main protagonist is named "Sam Porter Bridges" who is a Porter working for an organization named "Bridges", thanks for the hint Kojima).

Story wise it is a [b]mostly linear game, but it has strong open world elements to it[/b], especially if you want to get most of the equipment and upgrades, which you get mostly by doing side quests/optional stuff, which will in turn greatly ease your future (main- or side-) quests.
If you're like me and want to get most of it, you'll have to sink in a lot of hours to optimize the delivery routes, which in turn can lead to kind of a burnout at some point, where you just want to progress the story or finish the game altogether.

The [b]PC port of the Decima Engine is mostly OK[/b], it will certainly run better than on console, though as some people have pointed out it could probably run a lot better (you won't hit 144 FPS even on the best of machines, and during most in-game/in-engine scripted scenes or cutscenes it will lock to 60 FPS).
At some point in the game I started getting DX12 errors which hard crashed the game, and I found reports from other people online having the same issues. I've put my 1080TI to default clocks (it is watercooled and had a otherwise rock solid overclock in place), which got rid of most of the crashes (it seems to me that only some specific areas are prone to crashes, as I was playing the earlier as well as the later parts of the game with the usual overclock in place without problems).


All in all if you know Kojima and know what you're getting yourself into, or if you're not shy to try something different or more "artsy", this game definitely has a lot to it.

Despite becoming a bit burned out by the end trying to get the most out of the game, finishing the story gave me that good feeling you get when you finish a good movie, tv series or book, accompanied by a form of void or emptyness when you know that something grand is over.

Outstanding game - I love the highly original idea for this type of game! Graphics and sound are top notch! Highly recommended.

Late update (Aug. 9, 2020): I just finished the game, and let me tell you, it is worth it. It is almost like you are in a big movie but with a spectacular story - absolutely nothing is what it seems. Outstanding story and ending!

The good news is that after the "end," you can go back and keep playing. 

Overall, this is one of the best games I have played since Half-Life. I felt like I watched a movie or read a book afterwards and actually felt connected to the characters. 

Well done Hideo Kojima!!!

By the way I think the game is highly narrative from what I have seen so far but its all good movie scenes as you will see.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I find myself really struggling to recommend this game to anybody, even Hideo Kojima fans.

[b]Story[/b]
-The story is seriously convoluted and barely makes any real sense (and I say that as a Kingdom Hearts and Metal Gear Solid fan).
-The story feels like it's trying to be "2deep4u" and clever, but it's just not. The dialog is mostly groan-worthy, the exposition is insulting and treats you like an idiot (all while explaining jack shit) and the game throws all these terms at you like "DOOMS" and "Chirial" from the first 10 minutes without explaining anything.
-In retrospect, the character names are even groan-worthy too. "Mama" is called that because she has a ghost baby, "Deadman" is [spoiler]made up of dead people, so he's literately a DEAD MAN[/spoiler], "Die-Hardman's" [spoiler]real name is quite literately John McClane as in the protagonist of the Die Hard series[/spoiler] and vice versa
-At one point, a main character [spoiler]is killed off, only to be replaced by her identical twin sister who's soul she merges with. It's completely stupid and they hand wave it with a "twin-telepathy" excuse. It makes killing her off feels pointless and if it wasn't for Sam reminding the player about it, I would have completely forgotten about it. The whole moment falls flat anyway because I didn't care about this character, much like the rest of the cast.[/spoiler]
-While Kojima's previous games were filled with lovable and memorable characters, the entire cast of Death Stranding is just [b]bad[/b]. Spending what was probably millions on a cast of celebrity actors didn't pay off and I didn't care for any of them. Funnily enough, the one character I did enjoy watching was portrayed by Troy Baker; the famous video game voice actor, not any of the traditional, Hollywood actors.
-"Sam", the main character is fairly uninteresting and goes from being talkative and engaging to almost a silent protagonist. I can only imagine it was due to having cast Norman Reedus, a busy actor instead of a regular voice actor who's available. This was the same problem that plagued MGSV

[b]Gameplay[/b]
-Admittedly, the gameplay was interesting at first. It was interesting managing your cargo weight and finding the optimal way to travel to your destination. However, after a few hours of playing, I was burnt out. Sure, you get access to different modes of transport (trucks, bikes, ziplines) over the course of the game.
-In the end, this game is really just a walking simulator in which you do fetch quests. It's at least mechanically interesting compared to others I've seen (which isn't saying much), but you're not going to get anything more out of it than that.
-The game turns into a very mediocre third-person shooter halfway through with awful controls and a lack of a cover button. Not only that, ammo isn't stored separately, so you're forced to carry multiple copies of the same gun instead of just one that goes through the same pool of ammo. It turns firefights into this awkward game of running away and taking shots, emptying countless amounts of bullets into enemies, going into a menu to drop said gun and using a brand-new rifle with more ammo in it. It's a huge downgrade compared to MGS4/5.
-The game tries to chastise you for killing NPCs, but there's no real point of avoiding it. You're given non-lethal weapons like in Metal Gear, but I found it easier to just run down terrorists or the many enemies that will try to steal your cargo. There's no punishment for doing so and it's much more effective than wrestling the game's awful combat mechanics.
-The online component is well-implemented and helpful. If you build structures or leave tools like ladders in the open world, other players can use these and leave you "likes"; helping your in-game rank go up. This whole mechanic is the game's saving grace because I doubt I would have stuck around if not for the abundance of trucks and ladders around for me to use.

5.5/10. If you really feel like buying it, just buy it on sale. DON'T pay full-price.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The excellent Kojima Productions team take the next logical step with this new game, abandoning the familiar stealth-action game they invented long ago, along with most of its combative game play for a wholly new experience. 

It's inevitable that innovation pales in comparison to sophistication, but while the latter benefits from years (decades) of refinement, the former has the advantage of novelty. I loved MGSV's endless replayability, and after 85 hours, I'm finding package delivery a tad played out. But I wouldn't want KP to go back to stealth. I've been there, done that. I'd actually be more interested in seeing them find new ways to explore non-combative game play. 

But the real treat here is the surreal storyline. The closest I can compare is if David Lynch wrote a sci-fi game and Christopher Nolan directed it. I can't tell if it's good or bad that Kojima and his writing partners have no editor, leaving endless, often repetitive dialog to run unchecked. But if I had to choose, I'll take audaciously unique stories delivered sloppily over the same old story done to perfection. 

Because what a story! It's like living in a dream, following dream rules and dream logic, where the strangeness becomes the whole of reality in a way no game ever had before. The game's juxtaposition of hyper-realism and surreality leaves one permanently off-kilter, softening and eventually eliminating the line between the real and the unreal, the literal and the symbolic, just as it erases the line between life and death. It embraces the fact that in story, there's really no difference between these things. And yet it's the juxtaposition of opposites that evokes examination of what they mean in relation to one another. 

I think these days, we often hear loud, angry complaints from certain fans when they don't get what they were expecting. Plenty of people didn't enjoy Death Stranding at all, either because of its bizarre story, its experimental non-combative game play, or even the conspicuous self-awareness studio-head Hideo Kojima brings to it, inviting his friends and colleagues to play roles. 

For good or bad, the game is a unique artifact, making it hard to judge in terms of qualities and flaws. It is what it is, as awkward as it is graceful, as pretentious as it is brilliant, as clumsy as it is masterful. One can't fairly judge its failings without acknowledging that experimentation must include missteps. Without experimentation, we would get the same game over and over again, as boring as it is flawless.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Overall, I absolutely love this game. I have never racked up so many hours on a single video game. The story is detailed and beautiful. So is the environment. Those scary af BTs are soooo scary. Seriously. They can also get a little annoying at times, at least before I unlocked the BT killing cuffs. But the rest of the gameplay was satisfying for the most part. The dialogue was well thought out. The characters had emotions in their dialogues. I believe this is what Horizon Zero Dawn was lacking. Speaking of horizon, I like the fact that there were hzd easter eggs in the game in form of holograms. The soundtrack is also one of the best and I still can't stop listening to those songs, especially "ghost" by au/ra.

The single most annoying/boring thing is the cargo management and rebuilding all the roads. Also, the distance between cities and outposts is a little too much. Especially when you need to deliver cargo in order to unlock more bandwidth and resources. I needed them to rebuild the roads. I almost felt like giving up halfway into the game. But thankfully I didn't and that's when the story got much more interesting. Everything up to halfway was basically training and unlocking more stuff.
The jumping and stabilization thing also bugged me. I don't like the fact that I have to stabilize every single time. Mostly during heavy loads. I also think the jumping interface is a little buggy. I couldn't jump over rocks when I needed to and so I ended up falling several times during the start.

But enough negativity. The game itself is a masterpiece. I don't want to dive into the details at the risk of spoiling stuff, but all I can say is that it was well worth the $50 I spent.
Also, a word of advice... Always use trucks for cargo hauling on roads. They seemed to be slow at first, but the amount of cargo they can haul is just crazy and so you wouldn't need to make a hell lot of bike trips.

Overall: 8.5/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Came for the Norman Reedus, stayed for the literally everything else. I love it so much, it's overwhelming. The following is just a fan ramble. If you're considering buying it please don't read the hidden parts.

I desperately want more Mads. [spoiler]But like, in a situation where I don't have to shoot him. I'm actually sad I'm done with him -> maybe that's why the bday easter egg made me cry, lol that's hilarious (by far best bday content I've ever seen in a game). That whole part of the story where you're fed tiny pieces that make you grow to like him, then suddenly you're really terrified of him, then you're back to loving him again in overdrive. With his scariness being for a very relatable reason.[/spoiler] It's so well done. It's my fav part. I love Fragiles part of the story too. And Lea Seydoux was the perfect pick for that. I could listen to her talk for hours. Maybe we can work for her in the sequel? Idk. but I def need a sequel.

Gives an interesting take on why the dinosaurs went extinct. [spoiler] That part of the story, Sam being raised by an extinction entity is extremely imaginative. We're going about our business thinking Higgs is the scary part when all along it's Amelie singing london bridge.[/spoiler] Expert story telling. And perfect amount of horror sprinkled throughout.

Wouldn't mind the seam being expanded on somehow. Any time I end up there I always swim around and try to find people and wish there was something more there.

Hideo could've written a book but I'm glad he made a game instead. :)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Honestly a great experience. The game is well developed, and despite being highly exploration based, has very few issues with clipping or bad movement. The story is as incredible as it is unique, with some of the most in-depth and interesting world building I've seen in a long time. The actual gameplay ranges from extremely exciting to bordering on drudgery, but without both, the excitement wouldn't be as good. The only thing it's missing is music when you're driving on long hauls.
The graphics and cutscenes are beautiful, the animations are lifelike both in regular gameplay and, obviously, in the pre-rendered sections.
Sam as a main character takes the "show, don't tell" concept to an extreme, but it works well as a foil to all the other characters.

TLDR: if you want a slow burn game about overcoming depression and forging bonds with people, then this is a great game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Another meticulously crafted work by Kojima, best known for the Metal Gear series. 

But even if you like his previous works, this one might not be for you.

The story is in typical Kojima fashion filled with twists and turns where you truly don't understand everything until the very end. And that is not the problem this game faces. But the pacing of the gameplay. After watching through the first hour or so of cutscenes you get put into the game world. And here is where the initial frustrations can start. It seemingly takes forever to progress. Once you are somewhere in the middle of the game and are pretty much free to do as you wish the game really opens up and becomes quite enjoyable. Still, with downsides, however. The combat feels quite boring and repetitive, unlike the last Metal Gear. Towards the end, the game once again suffers pacing issues. Progressing feels once again very tedious and stretched out.

If you can overcome these hurdles however, the game can be a lot of fun.

And while only mentioned briefly, the story is an absolute blast to experience, expertly voiced and mo-capped by quite a few famous names and wonderfully rendered in the Decima Engine that most might know from Horizon Zero Dawn.

P.S. The game also has a Conan O'Brien cameo

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A unique experience, one that I can totally understand why people might not like.  For me though, this was an engaging story, a time-killer (in a good way) and a present for the eyes.  I've finished this game feeling like I've genuinely achieved something incredible with the help of others along the way.

The performance and optimization of this game has exceeded my expectations considerably, I've had no issues running 144FPS+ 1440p while other far worse looking games can sometimes struggle at similar settings.

The only issue I've had in my whole time playing is double-inputs from controller, which apparently is a Steam-side issue.  This doesn't significantly affect 95% of gameplay, so was something I could overlook, as I'm sure this will be fixed later.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
What a disappointment. The UI is confusing and needlessly complicated. Everything in this game is done for the sake of looking good. Game play is a glorified walking simulator. There might be some cool scenes and section of the game later, but right now I am too brain dead from all the walking to move forward. This is the only game I ever paid full price for because I enjoy mgsv so much that I am willing to gamble on Kojima on this game and ignore the negatives. I want a refund to be honest, but I already played more than 2 hours. O well, lessons learned, never buy anything at full price.

Edit: okay, now i am double mad about the game. I reinstalled the game again to give it another go for the hack of it, and i was disappointed yet again. 

After walking back and forth between the four posts, I still didn't get a quest to move forward to a new base, so I said flack it and i decided to walk towards west into the unknown and make my own discoveries. After about 40 mins or so I find myself enjoying it actually, just walking into the nothingness with only a direction and no quest mark. I finally found the next post (behind a path of rocks and shadow people), and I was so excited and for the first time since I began playing, I had fun. I thought maybe I finally became one of those people that enjoyed the game, that I discovered what death stranding is about, freedom of choice, and discovery on a lonely path.

So with my heart pumping like a little deer following mommy, I walked up to the post and was ready to be rest my character. GUESS WHAT?!? Nothing comes up. Nobody from that post came out to great, and I realized that the only way to unlock that post is to follow the quest marks. There is no freedom of choice. This game is a scam! I alt+4 a few seconds after that realization and I don't think I will give this game another go for a very long time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I feel like there is not much I can say that you probably haven't already read, and there are too many essay-long reviews that nobody reads anyway, so I'll be brief: Death Stranding is not just "ugh, a walking simulator". No. It's the king of walking simulators, and you better respect it for it shows it with pride and ingenuity. Walking in this game is a full system of mechanics that include elements such as movement, balance, center of gravity, terrain, and climate, to the point that the very act of moving becomes fairly technical and challenges the definition of gameplay. It also serves as a metaphor for the main theme of the game, an interesting example of storytelling through game mechanics.

As for the story, it lies in the thin edge between brilliance and ridicule, characterized by the typical Kojima-esque overexposition, awkward comedy and symbolism that notwithstanding hides a phenomenal lore of a Sci-Fi dystopian world in which the planes of the living and the dead collide, changing forever the very way people interact with each other. It tells the story of mankind regaining the upper hand against certain extinction, and it reminds us the values that make us human. It's an acquired taste. It's divisive. Don't let anybody fool you and try it for yourself.

Final advice: Don't be afraid of playing on Very Hard or in a high difficulty even if you don't usually do this with other games. It corrects the overall balance of the mechanics and make them shine. Playing on a difficulty too easy for you might affect the experience in a negative way.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Interesting would be an understatement.  There are so many facets to this game that I had to stop and reflect on the story line a few times to stay on track.  That being said, it has this very intriguing and complex story albeit married to a Facebook themed environment on achieving "likes", which in my opinion does not fit the overall theme of the game.  You basically have this expansive/creative map where you can venture from a pasture to mountain peaks all polluted with signs requesting likes for the 20 somethings.  It appears that the purpose of the game was to create synergy and sharing but the Facebook theme doesn't work.  It would be like providing Mario with a BFG!!!  I actually think many of the players are in it for the likes more than the story....most probably linked to their i-phones which provides notices when "likes" are received!!

As mentioned, the story line is good and makes you think.  However, if you think too much you begin to see where some of the parts don't fit together.  In the game there is an agent of doom surrounded by a transcending environment.   However, how does said agent become said role?...Tequila???

Another pet peeve is when engineers try to transition from a box controller to the keyboard and mouse.  Sometimes the commands and menu's are too complex for the PC environment and you just about require a foot pedal, this is one of those games.  At times the 3rd person movement doesn't function well and the weapons commands get mixed up, not good when facing a s.o.b......nope....you're done!!

Overall I recommend this game just to experience Hideo Kijomi's work, it is brilliant.  The engine used, the graphics, characters, theme, progression, etc.  I would give it an 9.2 out of ten if the likes crap was removed but I have to give it an 8.2 as is.
