title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I was very happy with this game and had no trouble playing it from start to finish but it might not be for everyone

Graphics 10/10 : This game is stupid gorgeous and can make even the beefiest of PC's chug at max settings. This game really makes you feel like you're playing a very buff Norman Reedus.

Game-play 4/10 to 9/10: Depending on how you feel about it the game-play can be very good. There is obviously a lot of running but it's mostly for the first part of the game as eventually you get lots of vehicles and an exoskeleton that lets you run at 30mph and jump like Spider-Man and basically become a super-athlete. The shooting and action sequences are similar to Metal Gear Solid 5 but with some changes to fit DS's mechanics. There is a ton of nuance and these mechanics are very complex and rewarding with a high skill ceiling. To be perfectly honest with how challenging the early game is you might consider giving up on the first map but please don't because the rest of the game is amazing.
 - This game utilizes online mechanics similar to Dark Souls except other players can only help you and you will need it due to the games unrelenting ruthlessness.

- The whole game isn't a walking a simulator, just the beginning which can drag a bit

Music/Sound 10/10: Soundtrack is perfect and sound is crisp, diverse, and very immersive.

Story 10/10: Complex and overarching like you would expect from the creator of Metal Gear with many twists and turns with great and memorable characters.

9/10 if you like the game-play and get past the unforgiving early game, and a 6/10 at the worst.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
At the two hour mark, i swear to all the gods you can think of I pressed the refund button, and then five minutes later undid it. I thought, give it a bit of time: kojima is weird but his other stuff is good. 

I waited and eventually it clicked. My problem with the game was that i hated the traversal mechanics. I somehow managed to find the core of the game (moving from point A to B) somehow simultaneously boring and so complex as to be annoying. The great problem is that you can rarely prevent Sam from, say, slipping on a mountain: he will slip, and when he does you must correct the mistake. When you are forced to make mistakes, mistakes that you believe you could prevent, it is infuriating. Breath of the Wild resolved this problem by a) letting you climb anything and b) limiting your climbing to your stamina. Thus the only true mistake you could make would be with your stamina management, and that was entirerly within your control.

This presented a great problem: how do you play a game that you hate playing? How do you play a game centred around bad traversal mechanics when you hate those same mechanics? Why its simple: you find a way to avoid the traversal mechanics. You get a trike or a van, some PCCs and you ram that vehicle to your destination. Thats it. It helps if you build roads and zip lines but I swear to goodness it works. I've seen some poor fools walking the whole game; imagine that!

Once i defeated the basic idea of the game (at one point i was literally driving a van through the mountain range you encounter around mountain knot city) , i could begin to enjoy the story. When i first encountered that story, i laughed so goddamn hard. There is something so fundamentally silly about some of the plot that they could only be the product of Kojima getting a blank check from Sony. 

I won't spoil the story because its so complex i would need to attach a link for a word document before the spoilers i provide began to make sense. In terms of characters, there are lots of big names but few good performances. Lea seydoux and guillermo del toro stand out in a bad way; mama and heartman range between dull and enjoyable; Reedus and Mikkelson are consistently good; tommie earl jenkins delivers a performance so good in one scene i would almost recommend the game solely so you can experience it. 

There are a couple burning problems i have with the game beside the above. The game has action elements in that you do some fighting at some points; the game gives you interesting, unconventional weapons to deal with those problems. Then, all of sudden, the game gives you assault rifles, shotguns and rocket launchers and never takes them away. Why? I'm sure it was a demand from Sony because its so utterly silly to have a game about hiking to deliver packages, telling this specific story, that then goes "also here's a assault rifle which is better than all the other tools you received to this point". Its especially disappoint given how deep the mechanics are that mean if they took out the COD guns, you could still have a good experience. 

SPOILER COMMENT FOR LAST 2hrs of game: [spoiler] you get to this point where to advance the plot and get the ending, you have to run around on a beach in order to get the credits to play. The credits only continue you when you run. this goes on for 15 minutes. Why? I almost quit the game there and then before i realised there was more stuff after. Its so stupid and it crowns this games consistent problem of being unable to communicate plot to beyond making you stand still and push a button to advance dialogue. [/spoiler]

I recommend Death Stranding despite my experience with it rather than because of it. This game obviously produces a lot of reactions, many of which i think reflect how comfortable someone is with the mechanics and gameplay loop; if you cannot develop a working strategy, the game is a chore; as a chore, the indulgent, sometimes laughable, occasionally gripping story becomes impossible to engage with. Death Stranding is a monetary risk, though one i do not regret taking.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]Poe's Courier Ltd.[/h1]

Death Stranding is an action/adventure—can only be described as a delivery simulator set in the ruins of post-America, following a mysterious event that crippled normalcy. You play Sam by the famed Norman Reedus, a porter and one of the few to have DOOMS, an ability to use the beach.

The gameplay is exceptionally different from the norm. You are essentially a courier sounds easy, doesn't it? It does actually, but there is common sense involved; even weight distribution and centre of gravity, momentum and, well, common sense. You deliver from point A to point B, dealing with obstacles and MULEs (Bandits), sneaking past or fighting BTs and babysitting your... baby or BB, an apparent human-tool that exists between life and death. DS plays a con-game making everyone believe it's a difficult game, but it's not, as I find it simple. I can't place [i]how I feel about gameplay[/i], it's different and extraordinary. There are combat and stealth bits as well. There are no revolutionary differences—a part used items stay in your inventory taking space and BTs are invisible. 

Landscapes are captivating and alive. One known factor for traversing these beautiful vistas is that they are especially dangerous. DS uses a terrain colour code system—variable data via the scanner, they are as follows; [b]blue[/b] is easy, [b]yellow[/b] is used with caution and [b]red[/b] is danger—ill-advised. Slowly over time, it can cause damage to your hiking boots and possibly damage/losing your cargo. Thankfully, there are items to use to save you on the pitch. Besides that, rain. Yes, seamlessly harmless drops of water can "deteriorate" your cargo and equipment. This is called time fall.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2190477272

The asynchronous multiplayer is not original by any means, it was first used in Demon's Souls (2009) and later for Journey (2012)—only ones I know of. In laymen's terms, players can/assist you in-game by leaving markers/or messages on the ground. While I get the idea of forming connections in DS, not everyone will be on board with the idea. In my opinion, it ruins surprises around every corner. I don't know about you; I don't need seven signs saying: [b]WARNING! THERE ARE BTS IN THE AREA! USE CAUTION![/b] Do wish it was optional.

The VA is incredible, with some of the finest actings I've seen in years, with many being renowned. I didn't found the OST that much impact on me, it wasn't bad or anything. Just didn't click.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2190477334

DS is an exceptionally weird and intense journey across America, while at first cosmic horror themes are hidden. They are gradually unveiled; the concept of the dead has changed—sorta Quasi-Poe, being dead is inherited dangerous. Time is sorta shattered as it rains in small pockets and crystallized to Chiral crystals. BTS is the by-product of the circumstances, but they're not like gods or aliens. They are the dead, misplace and disconnected. To say DS is fun or enjoyable is like saying "going to the dentist is enjoyable." I felt I was [i]along for the ride[/i]. DS isn't bad or good, it was a unique experience and only from Kojima's visionary mind can think of. I have one exception to recommend this game: Individual(s) must be a fan of Kojima's games and have a deep yearning for unique games—games that challenge the conventional norms. As I am, stuck in the middle between awe and alienated.

review:

The graphics are fantastic, and hardly trouble my GFX card (RTX2020s) in 3440x1440p UWide with DLSS2 turned on: 80fps constant with 60% GPU usage. And it's a really lovely world out there...

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't think I've played many games in my past where you immediately get the sense of tone within the first few minutes. Especially with games that are of such grand scale as Death Stranding. Granted I think this is achieved with the incredible intro that showcases the beautiful landscapes and music provided by the band Low Roar. 

Death Stranding is one of those games where having seen countless teasers and trailers for a couple of years prior, I couldn't grasp what the game was even about other than it starred Norman Reedus. There was actually a time before release where I thought the game seemed a bit convoluted. 

Its with great relief that I say that the game is anything but convoluted. It lets you into a world that is so fleshed out with detail and depth that it's actually refreshing. Over on the PS4 I spent so many game hours between objectives just exploring the world, getting a kick out of creating structures for other players to use and completing the more trickier deliveries. 

The graphics are beautiful, the music is gorgeous, the characters are interesting, the voice acting is excellent and I think the main important thing with this particular version of the game is that it really is an excellent port. I don't have the newest of rigs but the game managed to sustain a solid 60fps with ultra settings through most of my experience. 

In closing, this game deserves to be a part of your Library

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is, for sure, a pretty weird game, there's no point in denying it. It has a little bit of open world, a little bit of walking simulator, a little bit of third person shooter, but it's its own thing for sure. 
It can be slow-paced at first while the story gets going and you get used to the mechanics, but once you're there, it doesn't let you go. 
I really loved the world building and the weird story. It's a unique story of connection, and the fact that the mechanics of the game only help building towards that, is quite a feat; that gives the game a feeling of wholeness, not just some disconnected story vs. mechanics. 
The music is top notch and the acting and capturing of the actors just really immerses you. Sometimes it looks a little bit creepy because you know the actor's faces and something looks off. 

The only complaint is, sometimes, climbing is not that intuitive and Sam just crashes against rocks that don't let him move.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death Stranding is one of the best games that I'll probably never play again. A lot of the charm and experience would be lost after the first play through in my opinion. Not like that's a bad thing. I got 40 hours out of it and I'm sure others will get probably double that. It's a strange game that has that classic Kojima signature that you can't really articulate into an apt description. You just have to play it. Boiling it down to a simple UPS simulator doesn't do it justice. While on paper it would seem that way; Deliver package from point a to point b, adjust your weight, use equipment unlocked from delivering packages to allow you to transfer more packages at once. It's the experience however that elevates the game past this simple gameplay loop into something more.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Everyone should know this by now, but Death Stranding is by no means the next Metal Gear Solid. However, it provides a spectacular experience nobody was really expecting.

The game is essentially a package delivering simulator, but the game surrounds itself in one of the best stories I have experienced in my life. The characters are unique as well as well written, whilst being played by some well-known actors. You may need to do some research in order for you to fully understand the Death Stranding's tale, but it did blew me away with some of its surreal imagery and messages.

There is a lot of travelling (not just walking), but there is more action than I thought. On your journey, you will encounter short, but tense stealth segments as you try to evade the spirits of the dead. However, I was not expecting so much action as the game does throw in combat segments as well. 

I'd like to keep this review short, but DS is a fine game and a pretty good PC port. I did experience some random crashes, but I am able to run this game at 50-60 fps most of the time. I recommend you to run GeForce before playing this game. It may lower your settings, but it is handy in preventing issues.

9/10 Excellent game!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If somebody had told me few years back that I would enjoy a UPS simulator, I would say they are crazy. But it turns out, Kojima can make any mode of game fun and meaningful. In a society fractured by natural disasters and terrorism that reduced long distance interaction down to mail service, there is no better way to tell a story about human connection than in the shoes of a delivery man. Coincidentally, and maybe already envisioned by Kojima, our reality is becoming increasingly similar to the world of Death Stranding in a metaphorical sense. We are more and more entrenched in our niche subcultures, while the world outside our doors are being torn apart by climate change and geopolitical tension.

Perhaps, we all need to become some form of Sam Bridges.

Don't get me wrong, this is a great game but it's also a one-time experience because the game has no replayability.

It would have been better if instead of all those contracts with complete strangers, you could have made a few contracts with friends. Now you just have to hope that you ever bump into their objects and signs before you finished and get tired of the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is the definition of a niche game. If you play the first 2 hours and enjoy it, you will LOVE the game. If you think the first 2 hours are boring and feels like a chore, then you will dislike the game. 

The game starts off pretty dang good, but around 8 hours in is where the story starts its trend of getting better and better. By the end of the game, the story is one of the best in any AAA video game I have ever played. 

Steam says it took me around 44 hours to complete the game, and I am ready to invest another 50 just exploring and completing side quests. 

I know this review is kinda jumbled and such, but another thing that I felt I needed to praise was the photo mode. I would pay $30 for the photo mode alone. It is extremely fun to use.

title: DEATH STRANDING

It has a nice story, breathtaking scenery and sense of being connected while being disconnected from everyone.
To me it's a masterpiece, but it has its issues, it's a console port so limited settings because of that, it crashes in some areas way too often, hindering gameplay but it's still somewhat new so lets hope the issues get ironed out

I'm 50 hours in and halfway through the story and there's some really interesting places you wouldn't expect from a game about delivering packages and connecting with others

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
There's that quote about 10,000 hours in anything will make you an expert at it. Well when it comes to gaming I've surpassed that years ago. I have gone deep into every single genre of game there is from games like Dark Souls, to World of Warcraft and even many years in Call of Duty as well as Halo. I've beaten Resident evil 4 on the Gamecube 21 times. Mario Sunshine, Luigi's mansion. The portal games. Hell even League of Legends I've put time (and more money than I should have :< ) in. There's not many games I haven't played is my point.

Death Stranding has surprised me and made its way to be my favorite story game and game in general. Passing by Dark Souls 1 and previously Resident evil 4. An incredibly legendary gem of a game that I won't forget. This is the Hideo Kojima that made Metal Gear Solid and it shows that he has continued to grow throughout the years since.

A masterpiece 10/10.

For anyone thinking if it's worth trying and is discouraged by whatever stream they watched of it when it first came out should reconsider greatly. For those who have tried it and got bored before completing the 3rd episode will miss out greatly by what follows it. Push through it, porters.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Wow... What a load of pretentious, self-indulgent crap. A game that personifies the height of tedium and bad story-telling; Death Stranding not only fails to deliver compelling gameplay and immersion, but it also makes one feel pandered to and patronized by the "deep" philosophical undertones.

 In it's attempt to grasp the profound, it has instead only thinly veiled the mundane. 

The product placements and ad placements are completely immersion breaking, and signals to the player that the game can't even afford itself. 

The concept of walking across the united states in 100 km fails to realize the symbolism that it attempted, and instead makes you think that either the devs think you are stupid, or they think that America is roughly the size of Japan.

I hope my refund goes through, as I have never been more ashamed at a purchase I've made.

It was a great game, that turned amazing in the final stretch, with a very human tale that tucks at the heart, after this I can't wait for what Kojima Senpai delivers next.

9/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Overall I really enjoyed it. Parts of the game can be slow, but there are moments that also show Kojima at the top of his game.

The game is about making walking from point A to B as interesting and thoughtful as possible. In that sense, because of the way it treats the mechanics of walking, it is never not interesting and engaging. Every step and piece of the environment matters. So you are never not thinking about where you are going.

It isn't a game about exploring in the sense of "whats in this mountain?"  but it is about planning and executing specific runs. It is rarely boring because every movement requires thought and consideration. But it also isn't tedious. As a result, it is one of the few open world games where I didn't look at an "point A to B" mission and sigh because I thought it would just be a time suck to go there. As a side note, the multiplayer aspect is fun because it is genuinely rewarding to contribute to connecting the world in terms of building roads and ziplines. Building roads and planting ziplines is fun, especially because you know it will help others, and if you play you will appreciate the work others have done for you.

At the same time, a few short action missions aside, the pacing of the game doesn't change significantly, and honestly, if the first couple of hours don't impress you, you may not enjoy the game. In the end, it is what it is. You walk or drive from one place to the other while managing heavy cargo and trying to avoid rocks. By all accounts, it shouldn't have worked, but it did (for me at least). But if you don't like the first couple of hours, well, it won't really change significantly.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a highly subjective game. You will absolutely need to play it yourself in order to determine whether or not you will like it. No review of this game will be able to make that verdict for you, and almost every review that you read about it is going to sound like a personal memoir. That said, I loved it. 

I originally played Death Stranding on my PS4, and at first I was skeptical of the game. It felt like I was playing a glorified "walking simulator", as many would call it. But the thing is, walking simulator or not, there was no denying that I had an experience unlike any other with it. And after pouring over a hundred hours into this game and exploring everything that it had to offer, it wasn't just a walking simulator to me anymore. It became one of my top 3 favourite games of all time - next to Bloodborne (release a PC port already damnit) and Final Fantasy VII. An incredibly bold statement, I know. 

The reason for that is simple - it helped me. When Death Stranding came out, I was in a pretty tough spot. I was miserable and felt hopeless. It wasn't until I played through the game that I began to ease up. There was something so unusually relaxing about delivering packages across barren, unforgiving landscapes and it felt nice to help other players across worlds asynchronously - placing ladders, building roads, and returning their lost parcels. Being able to leave an indelible mark within someone else's game world was such a small yet meaningful gesture that really made me feel better, like I was worth something. And then it clicked. I realized that I was playing a game that was the antithesis to video game toxicity. In a world where many video games are so full of spiteful playerbases, I found myself playing a game where every single person was helping each other. This alone completely changed my perception towards so many things in life, and gave me hope that there is some kindness in our world. 

The story, too, was nothing short of beautiful. I loved it. In my opinion, Kojima-San once again knocked it out of the park with the narrative, which involves stellar performances, especially by Norman Reedus and Mads Mikkelsen. I won't spoil anything, but I'd like to mention that I found the main protagonist to be incredibly relatable. His journey is about connecting with others, which he has difficulty doing - much like myself. As a result, I found this to be one of the most touching stories I've ever experienced in a video game. How Kojima comes up with such original adventures with powerful characters when it seems like every plot has already been explored is astonishing to me, and I eagerly await whatever he and his team come up with next. 

Death Stranding quite possibly saved my life and it is a masterpiece in my eyes. I've only just begun my second playthrough of the game on PC, and I can't wait to continue re-experiencing it in greater fidelity. If you love this game like me, that's great. If you hate it, that's fine too. Just play it.

Update: Can't believe I forgot to mention the music. Using licensed music by Low Roar was a brilliant stylistic choice on Kojima's part, and I am forever thankful to him for introducing me to this group. Their work is simply magical, and the way in which their tracks are utilized to play at certain key moments during gameplay is genius. I was listening to their music in my car today and I knew I had to come back to edit my original review of this game to show my appreciation to them. This game truly has one of the best soundtracks I've ever listened to.

Update 2: After 108 hours of playtime, I've just completed my playthrough of Death Stranding on PC. Boy, was it worth it. This game runs like an absolute dream on the platform. Death Stranding is hands down the most beautiful game I've ever played, even on a standard PS4. And so to be able to replay this game on PC with crisper resolution and an uncapped framerate was a wonderful experience, especially considering how I had no technical issues whatsoever. I was running the game on an RTX 2070 and I experienced a grand total of 0 hiccups. There were a few dips here and there with the framerate, especially when driving on roads, but overall the PC port was very well optimized. I initially thought that my playthrough would feel like a humble return to a game I already know and love, but instead it felt like a brand new experience. The visuals are just that much better. In fact, playing the game on PC made me fall in love with something that I did not expect: Photo Mode. This is a relatively new feature that a lot of games have started implementing, and I'll admit that it's one that I've often overlooked. But with its photorealistic beauty and gorgeous cinematic storytelling, Death Stranding changed that for me. A solid chunk of my playtime went into taking as many screenshots of the game as I could, and I have to say that it was very easy for me to fall in love with photo mode. The UI of the feature is simple and gives you plenty of options to make virtually any frame in the game wallpaper-worthy. You can tweak various camera settings, add color filters, change character poses and expressions, and so much more. I had a lot of fun freezing in-game time to save and admire several instances of the game's beauty, and this was definitely one of the major highlights of my PC playthrough. I'm excited to continue using photo mode in games that offer it in the future, especially when their visuals are this appealing. Until then, I'm happy to say that the graphical upgrade of Death Stranding from PS4 to PC made me enjoy one of my favourite games even more, and I wouldn't trade the experience for anything.

Keep on keeping on!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is one of those game...where you really can't tell if you would like it just based off of what other people say. You really have to try it to see whether it is for you or not, I initially looked at all the reviews from the past year and thought it wasn't for me, it looks slow, boring...yet when i started playing I couldn't put it down and now 80+ hour later into the game i'm still engaged as I was initially. 

The phrase it's not for everyone fits. But the strange feeling when you play this game...despite it being a single player game, you feel other people around you playing the same game, doing the same thing you are. All working together to achieve a similar purpose via the online network. 

You have to try it for yourself to really see what it is like. I think it's an amazing game and concept despite the story being a bit wierd since it is from Kojima after all.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A glorified walking simulator with epic graphics and a story that with melt your brain. 

Death Stranding isn't the game we were hoping for but it is worth checking out. The gameplay can be extremely boring and you may get tired and have to hop on Doom or something every couple hours. but the story is interesting and well put together. Norman Reedus is amazing and so are all the other actors. It's a movie like game with an awesome soundtrack. 

Combat is rudimentary, it is strategic but simple and you will be sneaking around a lot hoping some invisible floating monsters don't melt you into the ground and make you explode. Honestly it is kinda scary and can be pretty fun. 

I did enjoy the walking sometimes, delivering towers of packages on Norman's back is quite amusing and stupid when you lose your balance and all your packages tumble to the ground. 

How the game connects you to other plays it cool, you can interact with other players structures from other sessions. It's interesting and refreshing. 

Overall Death Stranding is a odd masterpiece that is just plain boring.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I bought this on console when it came out, put more than 100 hours in, many spent building infrastructure such as roads. I bought it again because I'd rather play it on PC, and it's a significantly improved experience. Game is exceptional, but be warned. Nearly everyone I've talked to about this either loves Death Stranding, or hates it; primarily dependent on whether the core gameplay loop is enjoyable or not to them. If a walking simulator / resource management game puts you off, walk away. Otherwise I strongly recommend.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is a totally unique experience, that you can't easily compare to any other game on the market. There's combat, but it's not in any way the focus, and it'll make up maybe 10% of your total gameplay at most.

Death Stranding, mechanically, is chiefly about transpiration, logistics, and infrastructure. The primary gameplay loop revolves around you transporting cargo over long stretches of treacherous terrain to disparate locations, over and over, back and forth, while occasionally constructing upgrades to your gear and refitting the land to suit those means. On rare occasions you'll have to pass through or directly attack enemy encampments, but those situations are uncommon and infrequent. The large majority of the game you will be concerning yourself with how to best travel from point A to point B, while carrying your own body weight in cargo.

But that's not to speak against the game. The actual act of travel has been refined to a razor sharp edge, and subsumed with detail. There are constantly decisions to make as you travel: moment to moment, as you keep the cargo on your back balanced; minute to minute, as you plan your route ahead; hour to hour, as you design new infrastructure to benefit your future deliveries. You may happen upon lost cargo that you can choose to take with you to your destination; you may happen upon an unexpected challenge when your batteries run dry, or you tumble and lose your cargo off a cliff, or are assaulted by an enemy and have to fend them off. The game is designed to make sure that there is never a dull moment during your travels.

The story is just as refined. It's a story of connection, common understanding, and the bonds that we all share. It's a story about fostering trust between one another, and forging new connections such that everyone can benefit. It's a strong, poignant, consistent message that is constantly broadcast throughout the entire game. And it's a refreshing change from all the games today which are about conflict, competition, and good vs. evil. Death Stranding is not a game about division; it's a game about unison, about connection. And it does a damn good job at that.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: WOW just wow. If you give the game the time to get to know it. This is by far one of the best games I have ever played. It also has the best suspenseful story line I have ever seen, Every time I think I am figuring it out, CURVE BALL. Yes you may be doing go her do that go here do that but it keeps you wanting to do more and more. It is an outstanding game. Worth every penny. I am 30 hours in and feel like I have barely scratched the surface yet.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a one of a kind game. It is a game, an experience unlike anything you've ever played before. The game is about connection. Connecting with other people, other NPCs, changing a broken down post-apocalyptic country set in a sci-fi setting and bringing it back up and running...society, humanity, culture making the country whole, You are Sam Porter Bridges, a one man team selected to do just that. You do that by delivering cargo to other NPCs and people, some mundane, some critical to sustaining life and humanity, all of which has meaning and value to every individual. 

For your every actions, you will not only be rewarded by NPCs in the game but also by real players too in many ways. Be it via likes, via items, weapons, resources etc. Throughout your journey, you will find help from both NPCs and actual other players alike too. Yes, even though the game is single player, there's asynchronous multiplayer in the game from start to finish where you won't see the players but will see the help they've chosen to provide you via weapons, items, structures and many others things to make the journey more convenient for you. In this game, the journey is just as important and rewarding as the destination.

You will face many obstacles along the way too, not just the enemies and bosses, which you will encounter a lot but also the seemingly beautiful and hostile environment itself. There are both human and supernatural enemies in the game. The environments are nice and varied...from huge grassy green fields to rocky plains to volcanic crevices to snowy mountain peaks. The game has unique challenges and overcoming said challenges, especially when you're helped by other players, is immensely rewarding.

Visually this one of the best, most photo-realistic game you'll ever come across. Some of the other strong points of this game are the story, character build-up and interaction, gameplay, unique combat encounters and soundtrack. Hideo Kojima and his team at Kojima has directed / crafted this game masterfully and meticulously with the finest details from start to finish and it really shows in the game.

The game is also extremely well optimized and runs beautifully on decent hardware while looking stunning. I ran the game on my I7 4790K CPU paired with a GTX 1070 GPU and 16GB ram. Maxing out the game, I had anywhere from 60 to 120+ FPS. Depending on the location and how intense the visual spectacles were.

I've spent 133 hours finishing the game even though there were still quite a handful of side missions left. I played it non-stop since launch on Steam as the game was highly addictive and rewarding. Yes, it is THAT good and I don't praise a game to this high caliber lightly. I'm telling you, this is a game you MUST experience at least once in your life as it is a one of kind unique game that is so well made, you won't believe until you've experienced it yourself.

Overall, I give Death Stranding my highest score which is a 10/10. I'm seriously hoping there be a sequel as this game has a great potential to become the next big franchise.

Keep on keeping on, Porters

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYBODY


Death Stranding scratches a very niche itch of Post-Apocalyptic Delivery Service Walking Simulator. However the most care put into this game was in the talking mechanics and story. Yes Walking has it's own complex mechanics, you have to think about your center of gravity, where you place each step, and the amount of weight you're carrying. If this all sounds super boring and repetitious then this game might not be for you. For me all of these mechanics clicked perfectly in place and made for a calm and also stressful experience.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I can highly recommend this game, but with a big qualifier: it's not for everyone. 

I think most people will already know if this is a game that suits their preferences already, but here are 2 things I think would help determine if you'd like this game: 

Kojima Story Telling. The story is bonkers. Characters have stupid names that lack all subtly. Proper nouns are used that can be very confusing ("Beach" being a term for the limbo between life and death?), Dialogue can range from high school creative writing to class to very moving within a conversation. If those things don't turn you off or you find Kojima's brand of story telling charming, then I think you'll like this story. 

Non-Traditional Gameplay Loop: This game has much more in common with something like Euro Truck Simulator than Kojima's previous work. If you are expecting a big action romp like the Metal Gear series you will be sadly dissapointed. There are action-packed moments, but they are few and far between, acting as contrast between the banality of delivering packages across mountains. I view this game more as a "zen" game. Put on a podcast or some relaxing music and enjoy the beautifully built and recognized world. 

If you can appreciate a infrastructure building/delivery simulator set in a world created by the mind of Hideo Kojima, you will probably love this game. The story can be cheesy, the dialogue hammy, but everything is so sincere that it brings a certain charm with it. The game is amazingly polished. It looks and runs beautifully. The lore creates a very unique world that is fun to explore. I'm greatly enjoying my time with the game. 

My only complaint with the game is that by it's very nature there is a lot of down time. And there's a lot of lore-rich documents you can collect. I wish Kojima would've had the lore-interviews voiced acted so you could listen to them as you make deliveries. It is kind of strange that this isn't the case as The Phantom Pain supplied players with cassette tapes they could listen to as they traversed to add more the story. 

All in all, I love this game. Not for everyone. But it's an entirely unique game that will stick with me. Currently my GOTY is between Death Stranding and Outer Wilds, that's how much I'm enjoying it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm not finished playing the game yet, but I do have some thoughts.

First, I hope you like cut scenes (and a lot of them) because Death Stranding is overflowing with very long (albeit well done) cut scenes. While some of them are short and simply for flavor, some of them last quite a while and hold a ton of story elements. If you just want game play, keep this in mind.

That being said, the game play is pretty engaging! The 'Strand' element to the game is pretty interesting. From what I understand, a 'Strand' is your connection to someone else playing the game. In terms of game play, as you progress throughout an area strands will start to appear. This can show up as pathways that other's have traveled down or even bridges that other's have built allowing you to use them. The buildings and paths you create in your game will likely show up in someone else's! It's a fun concept.

Enjoy the game and for god sake someone help me build these roads!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If you haven't got this already and you see it on sale its a no brainer.

Gameplay is doing something really interesting, increasing the depth of mechanics outside of combat for once. That alone is worth a $30 price of admission. Its not going to be for everyone. I find the character models a little uncannyvalleyesque but the Decima engine makes landscapes look phenominal.

For the rest of the price, if you're not familiar with Kojima you're probably not going to get much out of the story. It has some interesting things to say but does so in a mostly poorly constructed way with way too much exposition, and the lore ultimately undermines itself. However it does have some really strong performances and the cinematic language is sublime in some areas which elevates it beyond its issues, at least in my opinion. But again thats the opinion of one who is familiar with Kojima's previous work.

I also think Trump derrangement syndrome has rubbed off on Kojima a little bit and it shows within the themes, which is really weird coming from the guy who wrote MGS2 and pretty much laid out how information manipulation works in the internet age 15 years before it came into full effect, but I digress.

Bridget deserved nothing but the stick.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] Keep on keeping on! [/h1]

From the mastermind of the Metal Gear Solid series, Death Stranding is a visual and story-driven experience which attempts to relay a message of isolation and connection; as Sam Bridges (a.k.a. Norman Reedus) forges across a post-apocalyptic America to re-connect its people. At it's core, the gameplay is exactly how you've probably heard described; a glorified walking-simulator wherein you as the player is tasked with handling deliveries as you travel from coast-to-coast. Its biggest appeal -and inevitably to some its biggest flaw- is the portrayal of characters and story spread throughout the 35-50 hour main questline. 

Traversal of the multiple region zones which encompass the map is at first barren and daunting, as you are not able to interact with or see other players' constructions as well as having little in the way of equipment. You do receive more benefits as you venture further into both the story and map. However this is the aspect in which I believe Kojima focuses in building the Death Stranding world, as a metaphor to the evolution of social and technological interconnection. The map opens up as you progress and with it, the ease and advantages of having other players support your own gameplay experience via useful constructions like bridges, shelters, zip-lines, or the occasional vehicle and supplies.

The area where Death Stranding really shines is its story-telling elements. From amazing acting from the likes of Mads Mikkelsen, Tommie Earl Jenkins and Troy Baker to name a few, to the insanely creative visual direction, you get the feeling that you are partaking in an interactive movie, and while to some that is not what they expect out of a video-game, it brings into question the idea that games are not only a means to experience entertainment, but also an artistic platform. The audio is sparse throughout, with music only playing during certain moments, but when it does grace you with a song it is not only impactful, but implies the introspection of the journey as a whole.

All in all, this game is not for everyone but for those that appreciate creativity and something different, Death Stranding is one of the most unique experiences out there. The type of story that, at the end of it all, makes you sit and contemplate the glorious absurdity, all the while relishing the moments that brought it together. [spoiler] YEAH BOYEE [/spoiler]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Some games are great because they have good game play, some games are great because they have an interesting story, some games make you question who you are in this reality while showing you that anything is possible with a length of bloody rope. This is another true-to-form Masterpiece from Hideo that involves package delivery as a core mechanic.  Much like MGSV, creativity generally pays off with often extremely satisfying results.  No bullets? No problem.  Just throw a smol package into the enemies gut while you sprint up and high-five their faces with your boot.

My only gripe is the game doesn't really start until chapter 3 (i.e. vehicle building).  Not really a negative, but I just spent way too much time in chapters 1 and 2 not knowing this.

Tl;dr
You can send illegal ghosts back to where they came from with your poop.  10/10 would pee on tar people to again.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If I'm going to recommend this game for others, I would give mainly 2 reasons but this IMO also rhyme with the game itself, which seemingly consisted of 2 parts.

the first part of the game is a game like Spintires, yes it's weird and not many people know Spintires, it's a game where you drive trucks to transport goods throughout natural landscape, it is the same with this game with the major difference being here you're controlling a human, and the character is the emphasis, in here your character is the one carrying the cargo, here the character is the one getting upgrades and gears etc. Then there's also building gameplay in this game where you build or lay infrastructures so you can have easier time playing the game like putting in ladders, building bridges etc.

The game is also open world where you're being presented with vast open terrain to traverse, pretty standard open world game today with one major difference, here you are in a shared multiplayer world where you may see infrastructures that other players built in their own game, it can certainly come in handy at times so it may encourage you to share your own stuffs too.

that's in general summed up one half or one part of the game, that in itself already offers you a pretty unique game, especially in  AAA landscape... and honestly judging from that alone would make this game on par with other AAA open world titles.

But that's only half of the game, the other half of the game metal gear solid series, with some of the downside, you get get the scifi and supra natural elements to deal with, both in the story and in the gameplay itself, you would get slowly introduced with combat and firearms, you would get some stealth gameplay in this game, the difference with MGS would be that all of this stuffs would not be the focus in this game, it would not be as refined as MGSV but it would still be a nice addition for this game and also give you some unique take on that area.

Now with that being said, the MGS series is legendary because of the story, and I tell you this, death stranding story is better than the best story in any single MGS game story ever had. The story here doesn't get bog down that much by the open world nature of the game unlike say like MGSV, this is also why I said about the game being 2 parts thing, you have to play through it and see it yourself.

To be honest, the story impressed me more than the gameplay, it's HIdeo Kojima at his best here as a such unique artist with little to no equal because almost no one do the same like he does (doing significant works on and resulted in both unique gameplay and unique story at the same time), Kojima deserve an Oscar award for this game, as ridiculous as it sound, IMO it is an Oscar worthy story that hooks you with such intriguing world building and unique characters and their stories filled with metaphors and present you with intriguing story twists over and over again to the end... and you have to see it through the end, you have to experience this story unfolding through the end. If you can, don't spoil yourself by watching the story without playing XD

Because athe very least, no... other... games... have such a story, and I dare say that no other books and movies have such story too.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If you're willing to play it through and play it patiently, it's one of the best experiences out there. I've played for dozens of hours and only had a bad fall a few times (the game records it, it's a fact), so I have no idea what people who constantly fall over are doing other than making obvious mistakes. Don't overload yourself, don't sprint wildly across rough terrain, stabilize your load when necessary, etc. It's not that hard.

Storywise I adore Kojima's works and this is more of the same for him. Heavily thought-through characters and themes,  compelling plot, though confusing and maybe not entirely consistent. Still, probably my game of the year 2019 on PS4 and a great performer on PC.

review: Really unique game that builds on itself as you go along. Making investments in delivery infrastructure pays off down the road, so you can be a bit strategic. Combat is okay enough but not incredible. It's not the main focus but endgame weapons, etc, make common encounters/threats less tedious which is nice. Some clunky encounters and typical Kojima "quirks" that can be very annoying. Overall very reminiscent of MGS in both style and flow, but very different mechanics. Excellent motion capture and acting. The overarching plot is very strong and it feels exciting to discover the backstory.  I do recommend this game to anyone, it really is unique and beautifully made.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I like this game for its atmosphere and world-building. The game takes place, oh, maybe 30 - 50 years in the future, but a cataclysmic event has wiped out most of humanity. All this crazy stuff happened and no one knows why, and to make matters worse, seemingly unkillable monsters and an atmosphere full of a new, strange from of matter makes travel (especially by air) difficult. As you progress in the game, your character helps recover information about the past, assist in experiments/initiatives to overcome these new and deadly challenges facing humanity, and yes, deliver pizza. 
(My friends jokingly told me that the game is called "The Pizza Delivery" game and the next time I played, mind you this was like 15 hours into the game, I did get an order to deliver a pizza 😄)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game isn't for everyone. There's little action to speak of, it's easy, and you are mostly doing the same thing over and over again in a new place. I spent most of my time raising connection levels, building the roads, making zipline networks in the mountains, and such.

This game is for getting likes from other players. That dopamine hit when someone appreciates something you did. I built all the roads and pretty much every time the game syncs up, it tells me someone used it. People used my ladders and my zip lines. Such an innovative take on an "online" component to a game that I want to see more of.

As far as the story goes, it is pretty good, if you just disregard the corniest dialogue in history. Just try not to take it seriously. Every minute I spent with Amelie and Fragile was horrible, but the other characters are great. And I would say this game had the most climatic ending in video game history. Kojima definitely wrote a movie at the end there, and watching everything come together did make the whole thing seem worth it,

And finally, it's very chill. If you're in a dark place, this game puts you in long periods of isolation, talking to only holograms really, and it has felt intensely relatable as many people were or still are trapped in their homes during the pandemic. But, that doesn't make you anxious. Sam likes being on his own, he likes the good deeds he does for other people, even if he doesn't admit it. It makes the negative feelings of isolation wash away, because we are all still connected. And we can work on these connections, even if we don't see each other for a while.

tl;dr it's a good game if you go into it without expecting a stealth/action game. It's an interactive story, and it's about farming likes from anonymous strangers.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is easily one of the best action games on the PlayStation 4 ecosystem and I'm glad to have finally played it without any spoilers. Walking and delivering packages is a quintessential part of the unique gameplay which I'll add might not be for everyone, but I love it. Hideo Kojima created an odd yet very entertaining story that unfolds well with an ending that was as emotional as Metal Gear Solid 4 Guns of the Patriots. The acting in Death Stranding is on a whole other level and has so much heart that it'll probably stick with you. I cannot speak for everyone, but I can say on the RTX 2060 Super with DLSS Quality never expect to drop below 60 fps. Highly recommend, but know what you're getting into before buying it blindly and not liking what is otherwise a great title!

4K TAA vs 4K DLSS:
All RTX 20 Series GPUs can run this game at 4K 60 frames per second with DLSS 2.0 in either Performance or the higher tier Quality Mode. Even if you can get 60 fps on the 2080 Ti using 4K TAA, Quality Mode looks better and runs way better so you might as well use it. Update to the latest graphics driver otherwise you might experience major performance and graphics related bugs.

My Specs:
・HP Omen 15 (dc0030nr)
・Intel Core i7-8750H 3.9GHz
・RTX 2060 SUPER (via eGPU)
・Samsung 32GB RAM 2667MHz
・Samsung 970 Evo 1TB M.2 NVMe
・Samsung 860 Evo 1TB SATA SSD

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] Introduction [/h1] 

I just want to preface this entire review with the knowledge that I originally played this on the PS4. I am not yet complete with the game on PC but I am far enough into it to know how it handles and I know the entire story from my previous time playing through the game. 

[h1] The Review [/h1]

Before I originally bought Death Stranding, I was nervous. I heard the controversies and I was worried I would find the game too repetitive and boring. I can’t quite remember what changed, but something in me snapped because I went in to Gamestop a week before launch and was able to switch my pre-order to the Collector’s Edition of Death Stranding. 

I will start by saying the opening area of the game (roughly 5-7 hours, can be longer if you try to 100% it at the beginning, which I would say wait until the end [spoiler] because ziplines. [/spoiler] Once the game opens up, and you reach the main area, the game finds it stride. You start unlocking new things that make the game easier, and overall, the game becomes more enjoyable. I think one thing everyone needs to understand when going into this game is that it is not Single Player. If you are not connected to the Internet this game will suffer dramatically. The premise of the game is working together with other people you have never met and never will meet to help achieve a common goal, which is making deliveries. When you first enter an area, you have to suffer through it alone, but once you complete one (sometimes a few more) mission you bring that place “onto the chiral network” which allows you to see what other people have done and use their different items (such as bridges, towers, vehicles, etc.) Playing this game and not trying to work with other people is going to make this game miserable. 

As for the story, From the beginning it is great Kojima, as usual, tells a magnificent story from start to finish. It has twists, some you see coming and some you don’t, and overall a star-studded cast that surprisingly doesn’t hurt it. I was worried that all these actors and directors in real movies would potentially hinder this game because acting for a video game is definitely different than acting in a movie. Alas, the story is one of the best I have experienced, and Kojima sprinkling in music from different bands (Mostly Low Roar) always hits at the right points. 

Speaking of music, the music in this game is some of the best I have ever heard. I instantly fell in love with Silent Poets and Low Roar, two bands I never heard of before this game, and I will always thank Kojima for that. 

All of these praises said, the game is not perfect. I have played most of my time on PC with Mouse and Keyboard, only rebinding a few things to my mouse for ease. I think a controller is much better suited for this game and makes it handle much better. I have decided for the remainder of my playthrough I will be using my PS4 controller, which at times can make your fingers hurt from having to hold L2 and R2 all the time. Another complaint some people may have but wasn’t an issue for me was the fact that the game is repetitive. You are basically a UPS Delivery Man. The whole premise of the game is you delivering packages and if that seems boring, wait for a sale or watch gameplay. 

[h1] Verdict [/h1]

I think this game is hard to say whether you should play it or not. Some people will hate it, while personally it was my Game of the Year for 2019. For me it was one of the best games I have played and the story was thought provoking and felt well written, much like a Tarantino film. I personally find this game to be a 9/10 but if you are iffy watch gameplay. Gameplay is always my go-to on games I am unsure about and if you are unsure watch people playing it. I would recommend Dansgaming or even CohhCarnage. I am sure Cohh’s vods are on Youtube and I believe Dan uploads his to Youtube as well. Dan has actually been playing through the game on PC while Cohh I don’t believe did.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'd love to recommend this game, I really would. It's a wonderfully ambient world with lots of storytelling potential clearly visible. That said: a game needs to be more than a good story. At the least, gameplay should be a fluid conduit for the story, something which makes the story work. But here, the gameplay is weirdly grueling in a way that reminds me of old-school boss battles (which I absolutely hate). And that I think that's they key, sort of: the gameplay design is an evolution of the old boss-battle-styled game, with a real story, open world, and rich graphics -- but ultimately it's still that "mash your button until you escape from the nameless thing trying to eat you" experience. And that's just not very fun. 

There are also issues with how the plot is structured, too, though, and with how the world is built through the dialogue. Sometimes there are infodumps and sometimes there's no info. There are sequences where the responses of characters are contradictory to what the plot reveals through elaborate cut scenes just a few minutes later. I can see that a great world has been built, that an interesting story exists... but I just don't want to have to fight to experience it. 

Now, in order to get this game back in time for Steam's stupid 2-hour limit I also need to mention: that I had about thirty minutes, total, of actual gameplay in that two hours. The rest is cut scenes or menus. Now, I love rich cut scenes, but this is pushing it -- especially considering some of the issues I've already mentioned. 

This is a neat pointer on the road to new game designs, but it's not the next stage, not yet. I might even be willing to stick it out and purchase again some day if the price drops to, like, $20. But for the current price I'd rather just buy a good book series and leave it at that.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: You think you're just going to be a FedEx or UPS delivery person during the Corona Time Quarantine, but you end up being able to throw your piss and shit on monsters and helping people find love and loss. Bring an old man 20 briefcases full of sleeping pills EVERY DAY. Deliver pizza to a man who's never there. Learn that all mountains were once pyramids. Definitely a game that shows you the meaning of both Ha and Ka.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
You might be thinking, "Wait, it's just a walking simulator?" Well, yes. It differs from your usual Gone Home or Everybody's Gone to the Rapture because it sets out to be an actual game rather than a sandbox with some voice clips strewn about. It's all about the challenges that come with carrying heavy, fragile, and/or priceless items across hazardous terrains, coupled with the inevitable gang of thieves seeking out your cargo, or even the oil ghosts that want to cause explosions. You have so much to manage as you roam around from shelter to shelter that you won't even notice that three hours have passed, by the time you're done with a big delivery route. It is so much more than just your usual no-effort, pretentious, bland walking simulator, because this makes you WORK for a good result.

I won't bother getting into the story, that's a thing to be experienced for itself. If your computer can run this, and you're looking for something to fill the year-long void that will be 2020, this is a good start.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Can't explain it but there is something magical about this game.  There is some annoying and eye-rolling aspects about how popular modern Japanese media approaches storytelling, but it does little to diminish the brilliant moments that can be found in the game.  I also grew to really care about some of the characters and their silly names and METAPHORS.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is fantastic, although certainly not for everyone but maybe not as out there as some think. The gameplay loop whilst simple is addicting and the world is so interesting it's surprisingly compelling.
I would akin this game closest to real life hiking, or a long drive, or ride, the gameplay is all in the journey and each step it takes rather than being hand fed a story like a walking sim. Supper Bunnyhop has a great video on this exact feeling, highly recommend watching that before picking this up as it may not be for you, but certainly worth a try. Also as SkillUp says, this is peak Kojima, so it has all those querks. 
Finally I'd recommend playing at least 5hrs before deciding if you dislike it or not, as the first 2hrs is 50% cutscenes, but after that it is vast majority gameplay until the end.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Let me start by saying, this game is unique.

The style, the story, the atmosphere, the acting, etc. It has been a blast to interact with something like this. Elements that you genuinely have never seen before in a game. The themes touched by the story although ridiculous at times are genuinly deep.

The game play however is the main spot light when staring into this new frontier... It's not for everyone, it's chill and grindy 80% of the time delivering packages from point A to Point B. The other 20% is kind of an additional blend of third person shooter and some interesting boss fights, That overall didn't feel as great to myself... more of something I wanted to finish to get back to the core gameplay. However the multiplayer factor of item and structure sharing is phenominal. Most of the game you never really feel alone, you feel that you are a part of the community, you wanna help it cause it also benefits you in character stats reaching an amazing mutual benefit between all players.

To keep this short. In my mind, if you feel like playing a chill delivery simulator with some really unique and interesting elements this is the game for you. Just think before you buy, ALOT of the people that complained bought this game without knowing what they were signing up for.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I really liked it. 
The story was confusing, weird, and good, you'll figure it out in the end. It's about life, death, and limbo, so it's intentionally vague a lot.
The gameplay is good, lots of exploring trying to find or build the best path. The exploration is really good, make sure to bring a ladder and rope wherever you go! Combat is nothing new or special but still good, you sneak around enemies, or try to non lethal KO them, so you don't create any more ghosts. It feels like a combo of MGS and Red Dead. 
The sound track is amazingly well done, and if I were to add anything I'd give the main character an mp3 player for the road.

title: DEATH STRANDING

Death Stranding is the epitome of everything Hideo Kojima experienced creating videogames.

It has similarities to Metal Gear because Hideo took everything he knew from Metal Gear and applied it to Death Stranding. He said he wanted to get away from Metal Gear... because he wanted to use all that experience to create something new. 

An emotional Journey Metal Gear couldn't have replicated. His child.

This was a beautiful, confusing love story. 

Written and Directed by Hideo Kojima.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
As a huge Kojima/Metal Gear/Zone of the Enders fan it pains me to say that this game is incredibly bad. Like, I'm mortified that people manage to look past all of the bad traits it possesses long enough to enjoy the game and give it 9's and 10's. It is getting a pass because Hideo Kojima has a stellar reputation as a game designer and people treat it as sacrilege to outwardly imply that he can make a mistake, whether purposefully or not. I'm only playing it as much as I am because I'm gathering footage for a YouTube video in which I explain why I hate this game so much. Very interesting way to spend my time, I know.

In Death Stranding, you deliver packages, which isn't inherently bad and could be done interestingly, but the entirety of the game is layers and layers of frustrating, punishing game design.

You manage the durability of your shoes. If your shoes break, you gradually bleed and die. You manage the durability of your packages, if you fall too many times your packages break and can't be used, and if they're a story-relevant package you simply gameover. You have a baby called BB (Bridge Baby) who cries if he's submerged in water or if you spend too much time around BTs (Beached Things; very clever acronym). BTs will often be in your way when trying to get to a plot-relevant destination, and unless you just rush through it and risk getting attacked by the BTs (I'm going to call them ghosts) your BB WILL "die," which the game tries to make you think is a big deal because you won't be able to see ghosts, but it has no bearing on gameplay because you just crouch and hold your breath and the ghosts won't bother you, especially since your scanner/radar thing can point them out anyway and you have 90% as much intel about ghosts whether BB is alive or not. He cries a lot, and you're meant to cradle him to calm him down and restore his health, which can take a minute or two depending on how low his health is. The game consistently and frequently manipulates you to think BB is adorable despite giving Sam multiple nightmares (one of which involves him BASHING his head into his glass tank and breaking the glass before reaching for Sam, and another involves him turning around suddenly before it's revealed that he has Guillermo Del Toro's face) and being a giant pain in the ass.

Enemies known as MULEs (deranged Amazon postal workers who attack you and steal your packages) will obstruct your progress and swarm you with electronic spears (?) but won't actually kill you. They'll just knock your packages off of your back and attempt to steal them. If they hit you enough times they'll knock you out and you'll wake up with no packages. Ghosts will grab you with tar ghosts that emerge from the ground and drag you a mile away and force you to fight a ghost whale which can charge you and kill you, thus triggering a "voidout" which destroys all of your packages and leaves a gigantic 500-foot crater (but clears out BTs which is actually a good thing, since BTs will harass you every time you pass through that area and a voidout gives you a straight path). There's a lot of emphasis on packages being EXTREMELY important, but since you can re-deploy quest packages and material resources are extremely common, it simply serves as an opportunity cost, aka you just waste time as you have to go back and do it again. There is no tension aside from the feeling of "I really don't wanna run all the way back to the base again."

The game encourages you to build drop boxes, generators (everything is battery-operated, so your motorcycle dies if you don't recharge it soon enough and you have to abandon it), ziplines, and most commonly, bridges. These require you to lug material like metal, resin, ceramic, and special alloy back and forth to build and upgrade them. Bridges let you traverse over the terribly-designed terrain (which is just rocks, dirt and rivers that make using vehicles an absolute nightmare to the point where you're forced to abandon them and go on-foot) and effectively let you circumvent the core gameplay. You hate navigating a giant field of rocks with 1 foot of space between each individual rock? Build a bridge and just avoid them! You hate slowly climbing up snowy mountains? Just build a zipline and fly over them!

Instead of making a fun game, they decide to make a really obnoxious and tedious game and later give you tools to mitigate the tedium. These are not mutually exclusive design templates.

Every time you find something fun, it punishes you. You decide to kill enemies? Too bad, we don't want you to do that. You have to now go on an errand to cremate the bodies because if you don't they'll cause a giant explosion that literally ends the game. You enjoy going fast on your bike and launching off of ramps? Sorry, your bike has durability and if you do it too much your bike will break and you'll have to continue on foot.

There's a lot of time wasted. If you spend too much time out in the world (~30 minutes) your maximum stamina reduces. It would be one thing if your stamina simply affected your ability to sprint, but Sam will literally stop everything and kneel over if you get down to 1 Stamina Bar (there are 4 total by default) even if enemies are nearby. You can restore your stamina (but not your max stamina) by drinking Monster Energy or by sitting down and stretching/sleeping. This takes about 3 minutes of real life time on average, which was probably a design decision made by Hideo Kojima who suffers from motion sickness and constantly prompts players to take a break from the game ever since Metal Gear Solid 4 reminded players to play in short bursts with tips during loading screens. He made it a punishment if you decide to play for long stretches of time without returning to a rest base.

The entire cast is unlikeable. Norman Reedus plays Sam "Porter" Bridges who is a Repatriate (a person who revives after death and whose poop/pee/blood can be used as weapons against ghosts) and has a symptom called "DOOMS" which means he has allergies and cries when he senses chiralium (which is a thing in the air I guess). DOOMS also makes people sensitive to touch, apparently, because Kojima made Death Stranding to be all about connecting people and breaking down barriers and rebuilding society. He literally doesn't try to be subtle with his political message, as "The Elder," an old man you help who lives in a mountain, will send you an email talking about old America where he talks about "a black man and a woman were given the chance to be president,” and mentions "a man who wanted to build a literal wall around America." Bruh.

Solid Snake and Big Boss were interesting, cool, complex characters with an extensive backstory. Sam Bridges is a grump who tells everyone to f*ck off and mumbles and refuses to open himself up to anyone so he can eventually experience an "arc" where he opens up and makes friends with people (building bridges: get it?).

A man named Heartman uses a defibrillator to stop his heart every 21 minutes so he can visit his dead wife and daughter on the "beach," an artsy metaphor for limbo, confusingly referred to as a "multiverse." He does this 60 times a day. He lives on a lake in the shape of a heart. Sam's middle name is Porter because he's a transporter of packages. His last name is Bridges because he builds bridges (literally within the context of the game mechanics and figuratively in the sense of re-unifying society).

Kojima is a goofball and it's part of the charm of his often silly games, but this time around we get to see what he's capable of when he has no one standing behind him to slap the keyboard out of his hand. He’s a man who has seen nothing but immense success over the last 20 years and this game is the end-product designed by a man who VERY clearly forgot that it's possible for him to fail.

Do not buy it. It is bad and you're stupid if you think it's anything higher than a 6/10.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't even know where to start with this game. It's so incredibly unique in so many ways, I contemplated buying it for so long because I couldn't figure out what kind of game this was. When I started playing I was instantly blown away by the visuals and graphics. Everything else just got so much better from there. It's exactly what I want in an open world game. Survival, horror, mystery, emotion, RPG mechanics, guns and other useful weapons and equipment , an insanely massive world you'll find yourself immersed in the scenery and monstrous rocks and mountains and long streams and rivers that run across your entire screen, taking you upwards of multiple hours to get to your final destination.

Multiplayer, seen in a way I have never seen it, other players can entirely share and contribute equipment, paths you've walked through deliveries and mountains, where to cross rivers, and warnings about where to stay away from, ladders, bridges, climbing ropes, vehicles, ammo, weapons, and building projects to your game and your world and vice-versa.

I've had so many terrifying, even more satisfying, and extremely fun times in the small 20 hours I have put in so far but I'm very stoked to see what the rest of the game has to offer.

Its very confusing at times, but just play it till the end, deliver some packages for fun and raid a few camps. I especially love the rating system it allows for huge replayability. The controls can be a little wonky a times, but thats part of the system its built around and you get used to it (and frustrated sometimes!). But overall I'd give it a solid 9/10, just pure fun and imaginative, Hideo has a really strange mind and I absolutely love it.

The story is also paced well if I say so. The endgame is where it lacks. After the story there isn't much to do but finish off deliveries. I still found myself coming back to it after I finished all i wanted to because it's relaxing. The atmosphere and visuals are amazing and never ceased to amaze me.

Very weird story that will probably received as "cutting edge cool" by reddit but really just feels like pretentious BS to me. If Hideo Kojima wants to make a "cool" high budget film, he should go do that. This game doesn't feel like a game moreso than it feels like a cleverly cut series of sequence shots followed by oddly subliminal leftist propaganda. That said, I can tell a shit ton of money was poured into creating this (and there's plenty of in-game advertisements to prove it).

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This review is not for the actual game of DEATH STRANDING, as a game I love it-- but my problems are with the PC port.

Depending on the hardware you have, even if you meet or exceed the minimum requirements you will have frequent crashes randomly, causing you to potentially lose hours of game time. I've tried every fix every website has suggested, I've done the blanket statement fixes 505 Games has on their support page, and nothing has worked. 

I've been emailing 505 Games support back and forth since the game's launch, and they haven't given me a solution to the issue, only repeatedly asking me to submit the error.txt I receive. 

I understand we are in the middle of a pandemic and as a result they are probably patching the game slowly, but they never should've released it in this state to begin with; I would've much rather there been a few month delay than a broken game on launch. 

Please fix the game I wanna play it

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is most certainly not for everyone, but to me it certainly was a relaxing, and positive experience.

It may be repetitive, but so are the Doom games. You just go about killing demons over and over again. Doesn't mean its not fun though. You can always find new strategies to kill them, and conversely they may do the same to you.

The same goes for death stranding except its much slower paced (may be a turn off for some), and rather than killing demons (although you can somewhat do that in death stranding as well) you deliver packages.
You discover new paths, strategies, uses of items, and much more. You should always experiment and mix up how you go about deliveries. 

A very disagreeable criticism about the game is that the world is not detailed enough. The world is packed with interesting and unique geographical features, camps/shelters, and all manner of distinctive areas. The game is intentionally vast and at times seemingly empty. One, because you're supposed to travel long distances, and long untrodden paths and feel it. And two, because the world is dynamic and changes with your own actions and those of your fellow players. Changes can certainly be witnessed, and if they are not you can be the change that you want to be.

I must reiterate though, that this game is not for everyone and disliking it is understandable even for Kojima fans as it isn't like his other games in most aspects. Especially the pacing and focus of the game. It may be repetitive and perhaps even boring at times to some, but overall it is a good, enjoyable, and generally fun game, at least to me. But you should make your own mind about it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
An absolute masterpiece.

Let me preface this with, if you think the gameplay itself doesn't look like something you will like you will most likely have a hard time getting through the game. I really think this game is either a love it or hate it type of game which is why there are very mixed reviews.

I found the gameplay to be relaxing and very enjoyable. The graphics were some of the prettiest i have seen in any game period. The way you unlock additional tools/weapons as you do main story and side missions felt like really good progression as well. Working together with other players and being able to benefit from their created structures, help construct them, and construct your own structures for yourself and others to use was a very cool concept as well and worked well in conjunction with the story of "connecting America" again. 

The story was amazing. I am not one who usually is super interested in stories but this one had me absolutely hooked. Usually i cant wait for cut scenes to be done or skip them but in Death Stranding i was excited to get to my next checkpoint so i could see the next scene. Keeps you guessing the whole way through and then they tie everything together in the end. A very unique game both in gameplay and story. Very original and one of a kind. 

Between the gameplay that i quite enjoyed and the story itself which was one of the best i have experienced i would venture to say this is my most favorite game i have ever played. Sure there have been other greats in the past for their time but for current time and the feels this game gave me i would have to put it right up there at the top.
