The rest is relaxing, atmospheric, and overall a fantastic story I highly recommend.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Great game with an engaging story. Took some weird turns but one of the most emotionally invested games I have ever played.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I would definitely commend playing this game if you are into the experience. It's not heavy on action outside of dedicated sequences where you are forced to fight. The story could have been spaced out more instead of having all of the plot lines resolved at the very end of the game. Overall I would recommend playing through at least once as the story is really good and ties everything you see from the beginning to the end. Best FedEx Simulator on steam!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: i kept waiting for it to get better... its so repetitive. Deliver package, talk for EVER then, go deliver a package.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
In order for you to enjoy this game you have to take your time through it. If you can't do that then skip it, this game is not for you. The story is melodramatic and obtuse, but I enjoyed it. The game is like a bunch of different games that are snapped together, that should make a cohesive sense, but oddly it does. It has possibly the longest ending I have experienced in a game.

Also Mads Mikkelsen brought me flowers on my birthday.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Played this to it's conclusion as far as the story goes. The story is good and has many twists and turns and surprises and keeps you wanting to know the truth about the characters, it's good to share with other players even if you never see them. Norman Reedus, Mads Mikkelsen  and the other voice actors bring the game to life glad I hung in there it was touch and go for a while lol.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I really wasn't sure about the game mechanics before starting this game, I mainly wanted to play for the story.

And holy shit, two things:

(1) I said what the fuck at the beginning of this game for 15 minutes straight. And I loved it.

(2) I actually f'in love building bridges and ziplines and hauling cargo. I had no idea transport could be so captivating.

Highly recommend playing on very hard. I started on normal, but I think very hard is where it is at.

Also, photo mode is a lovely addition.  It's almost like a second game to see all the unique photos you can create and I love looking at everyone else's photos on Steam.

I am not rushing my game play so I am still not done with the main story, but still loving it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The story is burdened by fictional jargon with Deepak Chopra metaphysics nonsense. The absurd story is portentous but entertaining. In the future, I hope Kojima hires a professional writing staff, with experience outside of the Metal Gear franchise, and he allows them to tighten his story ideas.

Model detail and movement animations are fantastic. The low-key sound design is nice. Combat is barely passable, and the driving mechanics are weak. The boss designs are nicely presented but become repetitive.

Death Stranding is a mixed bag of bizarre design choices, but this makes it a unique experience that I can appreciate.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Very pretentious, very fun, very unique. Every single trailer for this game is a depiction of something that actually occurs, which continually shocks me as I play through it. Because those trailers were wack.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: After a few hours, the tedious gameplay of DEATH STRANDING eventually felt meditative and profound. It’s been a long time since I’ve played anything that was remarkably strange and complex.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
First of all, this game is not for everyone, this is for specific type of player only.
If you're looking for action, this is not a game for you.
If you're looking for a gorgeous landscape, atmosphere or good story telling, then this might be your game.

[b] Pros [/b]
+ Good story telling, Kojima's story telling method is one of the best out there in the world.
+ There's always a new stuff/mechanic along the way for the player to discover while playing till the end of the game.
+ Photo mode for those who love to take a picture in the game
+ Multiple experience when playing. When facing BT(S), the game become survival horror game until later on the game. 
   When facing human enemies, the game become action game.
+ The music!

[b] Cons [/b]
- Repetitive gameplay. In case you hate doing the same thing all over the game
- The fighting mechanic in this game is... bad. Well the main focus of this game is the delivering mechanic so that's the most refine part of the game but the fighting mechanic when engaging against human enemy is like normal TPS game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is awesome. It`s certainly not for all because of its rather melancholic gameplay and very long completion time even if you're doing only story missions, but that's what makes this games such a original product, giving everyone who decides to try it out a breathe of fresh air.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: EPIC! The graphics in this stunning mind bender of an open world RPG are incredible! If you have a decent enough build and want the best experience of a lifetime you should definitely immerse yourself in the Death Stranding world!

TLDR: Make sure your video card drivers are up to date before launching, and you'll have a great time in a beautifully designed world with an engaging story.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game has great graphics thanks to photoscan assets and good modeling. But it is far from a perfect game.
It has great entertainment value. You can get around 40h of gameplay at least. And much more if you wish to continue after the end.

The environment design is great, with nice landscape and original terrain to parkour through. You are given small challenges to overcome the environment while trying to preserve your cargo in good shape or not to loose it.

The graphics of the game are not that heavy, the game runs smoothly, can be a bit taxing for a quadcore CPU.
Do use an SSD it help a lot for load times.

The sound design is excellent, but beware if you decide to stream the game or put playthrough. All of them are copyrighted and it is easy to get a claim or a strike. Better mute all of them or replace them with some copyright free ones.
The sound convey really well the mood of the game, the situation.

It doesn't feature better higher graphics then the console, but features better frame rate. There is no support for true 4k graphics, nor raytracing features but that isn't a big loss as the game is well crafted to not need it and not suffer a performance hit. But it would have been an added value to have it for better visual to enhance the horror of the BTs and flashbacks.
The motion capture and facial expressions feels very stiff and still lack life in it. Sam porter emotion at least are superbe. The rest of the crew is a pass. You won't see much NPC, the world when playing offline feels tremendously empty. Connecting to the internet really adds a value to the open world concept. seeing path and environment change or assets left by other players make you feel less alone when doing your task. This concept of sharing same assets and worlds is really an amazing and well executed concept.

Story wise, nothing was mindblowing for me as the game progress in a linear way, there is no alternative endings. But one well done ending that doesn't leave you with a bad taste (MGTPP). Metaphores and analogy are really blatant and put into your face (see my joke?). But nothing mind blowing and concept breaking in story telling. I did find it a bit annoying how sometimes it had a pretentious tone to it. Anyway, you will surely enjoy it as a good movie but it wont be for me an unforgettable experience.
Some cringe worthy moment and dragging moment can be tiring during cinematic. Like some nonsensical, illogical, irrational behavior from the character narrative. I sometimes got really bored from those antics and how blatant they were.

You play as a porter, concept that actually exist in multiple countries but quite frankly unknown by many western countries.
It is like a porter simulator, micro managing your cargo, your delivery priority, your weights, your tools that you will bring with you. You are given some minor obstacle that can be easily overcome. All depends how you decide to tackle a problem. Do you go through a Mule/terrorist territory or BT territory or decide to take a slightly longer path or more challenging one.
If you focus early on the game with deliveries you will get spoil as it will make the game easier. If you speed run you will not get any bonuses and wont be able to get items that makes your life easier (until you find them on the floor left by other players)

It is easy to get knocked out in game, but hard to die. You will have to try hard to fail a delivery, to die or screw up completely.
This game like many Kojima games is against killing, and will penalize you heavily for doing so. So avoid at all cost from going on a killing spree.
AI is very predictable and its actually good for those having a hard time to learn a pattern. This is plainly obvious and easy.
It can be seen as helpful for those having difficulties or very easy and lacking challenge for those hard player mode people.

Do note that the game suffer some input lag sometimes and car physics are a bit on the weightless side. easy to tumble your car. Beware on switching from running to walking on mountains slopes as the input lag can send you flying.

All in all, if you are in search of an excellent visual and sound design porter simulator with a minor horror twist. This game is for you. You choose whether you deliver packages like Feded, UPS, IMS or whatever.
The story is a good movie but not a mindblowing story.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I played this game before when it came out on the PS4 Pro and it impressed me a lot then. But it pales in comparison to how impressed I am now that it's on PC.

Tremendous improvements in the details which takes this game to an entirely different level visually. It also runs very smoothly on my system compared to other visually demanding games, my CPU and GPU load remain very manageable.

I was totally stoked when I heard Death Stranding was being ported to the PC and Kojima Productions certainly delivered on this one. Hoping to see their future games here in PC as well. Cheers to your team Kojima-san for a great job!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: YEAH! I'MMA DELIVERY BOY! WHOO!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
As of this moment i have played the game for 114 hours and i am close to 100%. I truly experienced everything this game has to offer. Anyone that is familiar with Kojima knows what to expect from this, its a very similar game to The phantom pain. It uses a lot of similar systems that TPP had and you can say that the way the story is delivered is the same. 

First of all graphicly the game looks great, it wont blow your mind with the visuals but it looks nice and has nice scenery to acompany that. The port is great you can play the game with both a controller and a k&m, personally i used a controler and i did encounter some bugs with it. Sometimes it would register the latest action i did onto the movement stick. So for example you decide to exit the bike and you instantly press forward to move but instead of moving it jumps on the bike again, that happened a lot, and i am not sure if its a controler issue or a game bug. Personally i would say its the game, it seemed too specific and happened with different buttons to be a controller thing. WIth that said even if it was annoying it was easy to avoid it so it didnt ruin the game for me. Now perfomance wise it run well on, i have an i5 6600 and a gtx 970, the game run at 60fps at 1080p with occasional frame drops but nothing major or annoying. The graphic options were a mix of very high and medium, i saw the digitalfoundry video and decided with what to tweek, but i would say even if you were to play this on all low options it would still look good.

Now secondly we are going to talk about the gameplay. A lot of people will label this as a walking simulator but its farm from it, the gameplay consists of 3 aspects combat, delivery missions and stealth. There some combat sequances and some enemy camps you can go and clear out, it feels good but its clear that this wasnt the focus of the game. The stealth is a step down from TPP and is there to help the story and world building more than it is as a gameplay mechanic. And lastly the transfers, this is were you gonna spend most of your time. The game basicly is this, getting cargo and delivering it from A to B, you choose the route, the medium and your equipement. It starts slow and clanky but once you get used to it and get some equipement it changes completly, suprisingly its rather addictive and fun, i dont know why but it feels that way. This deliveries dont remain the same, as i said once you unlock new tools the game changes. At the start you walk its slow and can be annoying, the you get a bike and you see the light. Delieveries that would have taken you 20min take you 3. Then you get the car and from speed you go to cargo load, you were transfering 100kilos with your feet now you carry 1 ton. Then you get a drone to help you out and you can carry on foot even more. And lastly you get a zipline and build your own system of fast transportation. Each of those items changes the gameplay drasticly, add that along with the change of scenery the game feels fresh and interesting through the ride. I would say the gameplay is the strongest part of the game. Also you would spend some of your time in your private room, you can avoid this completly.

Thirdly we have the world building, its done by 4 means. Now this is the part of the game i have the most issues with. The story gives you hints about what happened but its so rare and small that if you were to ignore all other aspects you would be completly lost. The emails are what people you help sent you, 99% of them are completly useless, and if you said to me they were writen by the same person i would believe you. You see this game is about connecting people, but every person you interact with and connect is a robot, with no personality or story. Out of all the npcs you meat the one with the most character is Connan o'brien, imagine that. All of them are definied by what they are, for example, one of them is a film director, what is his character? He likes films, thats all there is to it. So they send you all those emails talking about 3 things, they just love being alone in their shetler( not major differences in this part, they just chose to), they hate USA, they dont hate USA. Its insane, i would make a few deliveries and recieve 2 emails from one of them. So i go and check them and it would be like this, email 1 : Oh i hate america i would never join you, email 2 : I will join you, i will give america a try. And then after they join the send you a third email saying that america rules, thats all there is to it. And its basicly done withing 30minutes of gameplay. It felt so stupid, so by the mid game i just didnt give a fuck about anyone of them, they had nothing to offer. Even if you were to remove them from the game nothing would change. Its a huge missed oportunity to have some actually story there to make feel like you want to connect with them, but there isnt one. Personaly i would read only the yellow parts in emails, everything else is garbage. Then you have the interviews, the interviews are basicly the casette tapes from TPP, but not voice acted, so thats a step down for no reason other than to save budge i would say. Here you get the most character and world building, you should read these since they contain critical information. I find really stupid that this is the way the try to pass on story, i will give you an example. The protagonist is a blank slate, you dont know shit for him. At some point you get some interviews about his family and you read them and it gives you some context. Those interviews would have been much better if it was a cutscene mid game showing what the character went throught... On top of that you dont get all the interviews for this particular subject unless you complete some specific deliveries that dont appear unless you do something else specific. I havent figured out what that is, and youtube didnt help. So the story is intentionaly impossible to get, i dont know why they put so many walls to hide it but its a terrible idea. The game would have been much better if they showed some stuff in cutscenes or even in tapes... You also get some world building from the scenery but not much, its empy mostly.

The fourth part of this review is about they story. The story is interesting i wont say much to avoid spoilers, but its a unique concept that i personally thing has a few plot holes and can be a bit pretentious at times. The main cast of the story is mostly amazing, great perfomances and animation all around. And some character specific storylines are great. Now the main issue with the story is the pacing, now as i mentioned i played this game for 110 hours, i actually did whatever they asked you to do. But if you play the game like that you ruin the pacing. You see the story is split like this, you see 10% at the start of the game, 15% during the gameplay and 75% at the end. So out of the 110 hours i playd, the 85 hours had minimal story, so i felt completly blind for the majority of the game, only to get everything together at the end. This would have been easily fixed with what i mentioned about the npc and the interviews. That also creates another problem, since you dont see those characters often you dont create a connection with them, so you saw a character and their story at the first episode and then dont hear about them until the end. There is only one exception to this, and thats mads character, because you get glimmpses of his story through out the game.

Lastly the conclusion about the game, i would say its worth playing and its a game with unique enough game that i doubt you will ever get another similar experience. I am glad he was able to make a game like this. But it has many issues, issues that were part of TPP. I believe that hideo hasnt figure out yet how to implement his stories in an open world game, both his attempts at it have pacing issues, even tho both games were great gameplay wise and with interesting characters, i cant say its well executed.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm conflicted about this game as a whole, I'm going to give it a thumbs up only because the following reasons. The game has a fascinating story set in a post-apocalyptic world, with intriguing characters and enemy concept. The music selection is top notch, the cinematics were all beautifully put together and the voice acting superb. 

The quests however are repetitive and for the most part boring. Some of the quests were completely ridiculous towards the end of the game. Traverse for hours to reach your destination, only to pick up another quest at the final location which tells you to return to the same location you originally started from. Boring, absurd, and at times infuriating. The BT's (enemies) carried mystique and were interesting foes at the beginning of the game. Similar to the quest design of the game, these enemies that you would encounter throughout the world became more of an annoying nuisance than anything and encountering them just became irritating. 

I'm not a Kojima fanboy, but I didn't hate the game either. Just giving my honest review. Overall, I'd rate this game a 5/10.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a truly bizarre game that feels like a triple-A title from a different dimension.
The story is interesting and engaging, the gameplay is fun and relaxing.

+ Complex story that motivates to keep playing.
+ Almost photo-realistic landscape graphics.
+ Magnificent, perfectly timed background music.
+ Great actors and voice actors.

- Game is a bit easy so play on hard mode.
- Overwhelmed by content and hidden combat features.

As of now Kojima could release a 60 euro farting compilation and I would still buy it.

Edit:
My gf described this game as WALL-E the videogame. This is quite accurate.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm not one to write reviews, but the sheer variety of emotions I've felt since starting this game have compelled me to share my thoughts.

I'll begin with my major criticism: the game's narrative is terrible. Now, I don't mean the story itself, melodramatic and indulgent though it consistently is; there's more than enough imagination in this story's construction to find reasons to forgive some of the more egregious Kojima-isms. However, the actual delivery of the plot is appalling. I'm a patient guy who'll wilfully sit through 5+ hour-long pretentious arthouse movies, but Death Stranding broke me. The dialogue was interminable. Every aspect of the story was overlaid with three times as much detail as it needed, mostly through tedious, unskippable monologues. I began to literally groan when a character would declare "Wait - I need to tell you something". What should have been the game's most climactic moments I experienced through a minimised tab - I'd just got so bored of the overwrought exposition that any emotional impact had long since been lost. 

It's a real shame as the early hours found me excited to unpick the mystery of the world that I'd found myself in. By the end, I simply had enough of it; I wanted the mystery to be over and done with so I could go back to actually having fun. Prior to Episode 9, I was having a blast. I loved the core gameplay mechanic of the actual delivering, and had been very impressed with how the game subtly increased the challenge as you progressed. Just as I started getting cocky with my level 3 trucks and shiny new super-highway, the game's focus shifted to the mountains where I was taught an abrupt lesson in humility by the elements. It was fantastic, and I really hadn't played anything like it before. There was an authentic sense of adventure to the missions, a goal so easily missed in other open world games.

But as the story got heavier, the game became less and less fun to play. I want to avoid spoilers, so I'll just say this: reaching the West Coast was a huge disappointment and things never really picked up again from that point on. Any other gripes that I have pale in comparison to this: the game's script needs some brutal editing. There is really no excuse for a story to be told this badly.

Despite all of the above, I do recommend it. The early game strikes a perfect blend of wonder and horror and I'll forever remember my first time getting caught by a BT as one of the most thrillingly horrible experiences I've had in a video game. As you learn the ropes the game transforms into something genuinely original, at times exhilarating and at others entrancing. I did not find the delivering aspect of the game boring at all, although this seems to be a common criticism. The game can be frustrating, but more often than not the player brings those frustrations on themselves due to bad decisions - as irritating as it was to lose a truckload of ceramics, I had to admit that trying to drive top speed across a deep, fast flowing river may not have been my best-laid plan.

Flawed is an understatement, but there is something excellent at the heart of Death Stranding. You just have to remind yourself of that as you wade through the atrocious storytelling.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Have you ever played a game which made you question everything about life and your existence?

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
When this game first came out reviews seemed to be bad.  They called it a walking simulator, all you do is deliver packages, they all wanted another Metal Gear.  It came out on PS4 and fans seemed to not get it, Dunkey gave it a bad review.  Months later when it came out on pc, I was very curious about the game. 
 Were the reviews right, was it actually boring, did Kojima fail his fans.  I nervously bought the game since I loved MG5 so much and waited with baited breath.  After about 40 hours of play so far I'll say I really enjoy this game.  Yes its a walking simulator but that's the point.  This game breaks down modern gaming into its most fundamental form.  Most adventure games today are essentially walking around on a map collecting and delivering packages in one way or another.  They cut the bullshit and serve that straight up and execute at an extremely high level.  Itemization is fun, planning routes is fun, encountering new obstacles is fun, and the innovative online concept is fun.  The online concept is that other players can leave objects on the map that will help you complete missions, you can also leave objects, you can also like other players' objects and they collect those likes which gives them titles and upgrades, you also collect the likes for upgrades.  Its a really fun and engaging progression that is clearly well thought out.  The mechanic itself is poetic and artful which you never see in gaming today or in culture at large.  The game feels lonely but the online element makes simple abstract social interactions that much more intimate.  I find myself wondering what the guy who liked my ladder is like, who walked over those roads I rebuilt, and if anyone ever will use the first rope I ever put out.  I would recommend to people who like to take it easy when they play, who doesn't mind a few butt clenching moments, and who enjoy a psychedelic mind fuck.  The story and setting are poetic and abstract.  Its like playing a game designed by David Lynch.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I would recommend this game. The graphics are phenomenal, the game play is very well done. This isn't a shooter type game what so ever, so if that's the kind of game you like, avoid this one. Hideo Kojima has really come up with a unique game this time around and should be in the running for game of the year for sure!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I tried to get past the naysayers and the negative reviews (even though I read and appreciated them). I bought it anyway and started playing, really appreciated the visuals...

But the game is boring. It truly is boring. It is a walking simulator. Now, if I was desiring of that, perhaps my opinions would be better, and some aspects of the story line seem pretty rad, but there's just not a lot to keep me attached to the characters. The only character I even remotely became attached to in the time I played it was [spoiler] the baby in the container that was supposed to be eliminated [/spoiler]. Otherwise, it felt pretty hollow.

For those able to enjoy walking simulators, perhaps wait until this is at least 50% off, then buy it. There's no way in good conscience I can recommend this game at full price.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Nice

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Really cool game, very story based.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: An incredibly unique experience. This goes for both story, design and gameplay.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: It isn't for everyone, but it's definitely for someone. I gotta say at first it was really boring and tedious. I didn't see myself getting into it at all. Yet after playing for what I thought was maybe 45 minutes, realized It was for over 3 hours. Needless to say I've been hooked ever since. I cant recommend this game to everyone. Some will see this entire game as a waste of time. The main objective through the whole game is literally to deliver things, but it's a lot more than that too. You'll just have to see for yourself. So far I think im gonna give this game a 9/10. Dropped one point for a variety of small reasons. It isnt a perfect game, but it's a damn good one.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Graphics: The Best of All time. Not just how real everything looks, but all the little details of this world's environment tells you different little stories, it's absolutely breathtaking and very easy to get lost in. You will spend hours in photo mode capturing incredible moments and gorgeous scenery.

Gameplay: Very relaxing for the most part, but still enough challenge to never be boring. It feels like Journey and Metal Gear had a baby.  Nothing else is really like it so it's hard to explain, but it is fun and addicting as you constantly get new gear and the pacing is very good.

Story:  If you enjoy mind boggling stories like The Matrix, Inception, Or Metal Gear this will be right up your ally, very science fictiony also, but it is extremely deep and will take some brain thinking and extra digging through game emails and documents to fully understand everything. Although even if you do get lost, the cut scenes are very fun to watch.

I feel this title is easily accessible to anyone, and feel like anyone can enjoy this game. Definitely more so than any Metal Gear Game although Metal Gear Fans will also enjoy it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: A great truck/delivery sim (e.g. ETS2 or ATS) with a story developed while dropping acid.

review: Fantastic game! One of my all-time favorites, and well worth the money. title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding reminds me very much of Peter Jackson's LotR Trilogy and, like the movies, it all depends on one's taste. 
There are those who only watch the epic fighting scenes (like Battle for Helm's Deep and Pelennor Fields etc) and just scroll on their phones for the rest of the movies. Then there's us, who get a hard-on every time we see a wide shot of the New Zealand's stunning landscape, with one of Howard Shore's masterpieces blasting in to our ears and pushing us to the climax, as the fellowship marches on with their epic journey... 
It really helps if you belong to the latter group.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:

Not perfect but a masterpiece.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
First note:  Play this on the hardest difficulty setting.  The movement engine isnt' perfect but it's truly sort of next level in design and worth it for the immersion you gain from it and the tactical challenge and tension it provides.

I just finished playing it and I have that depression feeling after you finish a great tv show you love or something like that because you know it's over and you're not going to get something of this quality again because it's super rare.  This game is a work of art.    The story is amazing and the performances are academy award quality.  A perfectionist made this.   

I played this on a i9-9900, 2080ti with DLSS on quality  (which made an insane difference in quality) on a 3440x1440x120hz monitor.  If you're on the fence about playing this and might upgrade soon I would wait to play it - it's breath taking how pretty it is.  It just raised the industry bar on terrain graphics layering at all distances.  I've never seen a landscape so huge and open with so much detail and it all looks real on the eyes, no differences in layers or textures loading in or anything like that.   Seamless perfection.   

The sci-fi story is extremely creative and involves the meta physical and I feel like I just watched the best sci-fi mini series I'm going to get for the next decade.    No injected politics, just real human characters with a very japanese philsophical background as the foundation.  It was outstanding.

People talk about this being repetitve and I've been gaming since Wolfenstein 3d/OG doom and I was nearly completionist on this.   I will definitely play this game a second time in the future, maybe when I'm on 4k or higher.  This definitely deserves the master piece tag.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm the type of guy who plays a space combat simulator just to end up spending hundreds of hours transporting goods between space stations. I find it very relaxing!

If that sounds like you, this game will be right up your alley.

Don't get me wrong, has much more than that - drama, suspense, mystery, and exactly one Kojima of cut-scenes (which is a lot). That being said, if fetch quests aren't your thing - prepare to gird your loins.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
An unique game in a world of mediocre AAA titles. Hideo Kojima did right by this one, bringing back excellent storytelling and refreshing - or entirely new - gameplay mechanics. 

If you like stories, science fiction, puzzles, open worlds, beautiful scenery and some good old shitting bricks, then i suggest you really should give it a try.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Story is one of the best I have ever experienced in gaming and is only let down by the midgame where I felt very restricted with many exposition delivering compulsory missions that made me sigh when I had to do many back to back.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game isn't for everyone, but I love this game.

The core loop of this game is just a bunch of fetch quests. That's not very appealing now is it? But the thing about these fetch quests is there's a bunch of obstacles and ways to go about completing these fetch quests! You come into contact with various types of terrain, enemies and environmental hazards; each to be tackled differently with a multitude of ways! It's really up to you how you'd like to go about it.

All in all, the game has a simple core game-play loop paired with a riveting story. Once you start and reach a flow state, you just can't get enough!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: An addictive trucking simulator set in a post-apocalypse where every human death has terrifying consequences and the best combat strategy is to fight without fighting. The online features mean that you'll always be grateful for the resourcefulness of those who came before you and those who come after you will benefit from your own.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
After playing this game on PS4 and getting to chapter 6, I had to throw in the towel after the OG PS4's loading times and 30 fps got to me. I just finished the game again for real on PC, and it's so much more of an... experience than I could have imagined.

[b] Walking Simulator? [/b]
First, let's address the idea that it's a "walking simulator". The core gameplay element is deliveries. This is irrefutable. Many people get an hour or two into the first area and throw in the towel there. At this point, Sam struggles to carry 50kg and every step can feel like a balancing act. BTs feel like these insurmountable obstacles and even MULEs are this overwhelming threat.

However, as Sam does deliveries, he gets stronger. He can carry more, has better endurance, better balance, etc. On top of this, he gets more gadgets. Floating carriers, exoskeletons bolstering his strength (immensely), speed, and balancing abilities. Vehicles, the ability to build roads, and even crazier abilities.

The delivery aspect becomes less of a "walking simulator" and more of an optimizer. If you put forth the effort, you will reach a point where deliveries are somewhat of an auto-pilot and only as difficult as you want them to be.  There is an excellent sense of progression in Sam's arsenal and abilities.

[b] More than a walking simulator, combat [/b]
But the game is MORE than just a walking/delivery simulator. BTs and MULEs are your main threat. Early on (the first area), your focus is on avoiding BTs and MULEs. But as you go on, your arsenal expands... considerably. My math isn't perfect, but you get at least 9 weapons to combat BTs and MULEs. This is not counting different levels or the distinction between non-lethal and lethal. If you do that, it ends up being somewhere around 25-30. The point is, you get options to fight.

One of the first real combat encounters is experienced towards the end of the first area. It is a beautiful cinematic experience that I won't spoil. The problem is that most people get put off by the tutorial of the first area that they never make it this far, and are left saying "oh it's just a walking simulator". The game has multiple mandatory (most of which are very cool) combat sequences, and you are decently rewarded for clearing out MULE camps or fighting BT areas. While this doesn't have incredibly polished combat, it works for the most part and is satisfying.

[b] The visuals and aesthetics are beyond insane [/b]
I won't go into details here, because it's some spoilers, but the world is beautifully designed. Most of the encounters and locales are beautiful, and there are a few... interesting areas you wouldn't expect.

[b] The story, cutscenes, and acting are Kojima at his finest, and breathtaking [/b]
Kojima spared no expense for this game. The story is nuts, but not arbitrarily so. It all makes sense once you get there. It isn't left permanently shrouded, but you won't understand it until the end. And the cutscenes along the way put movies to shame. All of the actors/tresses get into their roles. The scanning and acting are absurdly high quality. Tommy Earl Jenkins and Mads Mikkelson have absolutely stellar points. I always thought it was a shame that Konami cut Phantom Pain short. It's beautiful to see Kojima actually having freedom to do what he wants.

[b] The OST is perfect [/b]
Occasionally, a scripted song will play as you are on a mandatory delivery. I can't say anything other than it's always perfection.

[b] The "multiplayer" exists, but it doesn't really make or break much [/b]
You'll frequently come across things other people have built. They generally don't fit in your agenda or plan for the world, but it's nice when they do. It's more of a nice touch than a huge pull to the game.

[b] Overall, this game is like a 9.8/10for me [/b]
The only real issue being some occasionally wonky controls, but they don't do much to diminish the game even then.

I highly recommend this game. But if you do play it, make sure you at least make it to the second area.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: They did an amazing job capturing Normon Reedus's personality. This is an extremely beautiful project and has an amazing story so far. If you enjoyed other story intensive games, you will enjoy this one for sure. Highly recommended!!!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Great freerunner game. The storyline is something if David Lynch would write a Japanese scifi post apocalyptic family drama. Other than that, I DID NOT SEE THAT COMING! Or that. And that..
Also, don't play this game if you're creeped out by creepy babies.
Or ghosts.
Or heights.
Or interdimensional shamblers.
Or fish.

No spoilers:
It's about this guy (you - also Norman Reedus) that can't die. Which comes in handy when you're running around as the only courier delivering EVERYTHING in post apocalyptic America.
Once you agree to be the only one that can save (this part of) the world by hooking everyone up to the internet from outer space, you get to run around delivering stuff to .. yeah well just about everyone you meet. Which makes people like you and they give you stuff to help you get around. Like a new backpack, better shoes, the plans for constructing powered ziplines, a death-navigating baby or a cool motorcycle. You know. Regular stuff. 

As you progress through the game you'll unlock more stuff, more vehicles, more zones to run around in and more monsties. The monsties are a kind of ghosts that are tethered to this world and want to hook up. But not in a good way. They're kind of clingy and once they get a hold of you they drag you away to a tarry pit with more bigger monsties. 
Don't. Die. Here. 
The thing is when you die from falling off a cliff or drowning or getting shot or whatever, you float back to your body and get to go again. No harm done. Just some lost cargo and a lot of time. But if you get eaten by the big monsties... KABOOM. Crater time! Anyway, try (not) to find out.

The only downside for me are the cutscenes. Not the storyline movies those are great. But every time you enter your room or get something from a warehouse or deliver a package it's the same cutscene. Sure you can skip it afer the first couple times but still. I find them annoying. 

About the storyline movies: there's tons of them. All with famous people and they're great. There's an entire movie waiting in between deliveries. 

In short: great graphics, simple controls, enough difficulty settings from "laughable" to "what the hell why god why", and did i mention the storyline? no? ok. 
PLAY IT.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Just play it and enjoy. Peace. Harmony. BB :)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
In the pantheon of video games, Death Stranding is with no exaggeration one of the greatest game I've ever played.

+ 999,999,999,999,999,999,999,999,999,999 Likes to:  Kojima Productions

This is by far one of my all time favorite games. 10/10. Had me laughing, angry, and crying the entire play through.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It crashes. ALL. THE. TIME.

It is the prettiest, most entertaining UPS simulator ever made. While it's running, I love it.

Then it crashes. And crashes. And crashes again.

The save system is such that will find all my progess undone by a crash. I've delivered the same cargo over and over and over again.

Its more like ground hog day than anything else for me right now.

I'm ten hours in and still in the starting zone. FFS.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Masterpiece.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
You can't play this game. You can merely suffer though it.

Delivery is boring and non-rewarding.
Clients are laughing in my face rewarding me with a hat (a hat!) for completing the most arduous task.
There are buildings, but most of them are uselesess and they deteriorate over time.

The worst bane is the UX: you have to navigate through numerous menus and watch the same cut-scene a plethora of times. I feel like 10% of play time was spent on these.

The plot was promising at the beginning though: it had those cool invisible creatures, weird weather mechanic etc, but in the end everything turns out to be total boloney. The ideas they put into the game make no sense. I don't sympathise the characters at all; they are constantly crying for some reason; in this cruel world they behave like 14year old teenage girls; all they care about is some useless emotional and esoteric stuff. This is definitely not the world I would like to save.

I want this diehardman dude to go fuck himself. He is so friggin' annoying.

I reached the scene were I had to fist-figh a demigod and I decided that I had enough of this bullshit.

32 hours of my life down the drain.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
You play as a glorified delivery boy in a world that seems boring and not very immersive. Delivering stuff to hologram after hologram. You dont even get to go inside their bunkers, The devs must have saved alot of time by copying and pasting their building models.
The names of the characters lack imagination "die hardman, deadman, fragile" etc. 
The storyline is bland and not engaging in the slightest. 
Some boss battles are not challenging enough (played on very hard mode) sometimes I found myself able to simply evade the giant BT's by walking until I reached the edge of the arena and they disappeared.
Other boss battles are utterly boring, giant health bar, the same movement pattern, all you must do is collect ammo and attack. The fact that you can come back to life after dying (in most encounters) takes away any tenseness these battles could have had.
Some weapons/items have next to no use, the sticky gun, smoke grenade, decoy cargo etc
Chiralium is a completely useless material except for building roads/powering the floating cart. What is the point of even collecting it?
Sometimes I found myself saving the game next to a online player created bridge/vehicle, only to reload the save a minute later for the bridge/vehicle to be gone.
The soundtrack of the game (the actual soundtrack, not the music that the game forces you to listen to in order to try to instil some kind of ambient feeling to your journey) is instantly forgettable and didn't grab me in the way that metal gear solid or zone of the enders OST's did.
The ending of the game was a bit drawn out. The unnecessary plot twists don't add anything and feel like they were done just for a bit of extra shock value.

All in all, I found this game to be a waste of time and money. Kojima should have stuck with what he does best (metal gear solid style) instead of making death stranding.
Sadly, because of this game, I will think long and hard before I buy another game made by Kojima productions.

Save your money and just replay Metal Gear Solid V. 
(Metal Gear Solid V > Death Stranding) --- and thats saying something!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I like weird characters, weird story and anything weird. And this game is weird enough

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: It's unlike anything I've ever played before. The game is just as mysterious as the Trailers make it seem, which makes playing through the story (to find out what the heck is going on) even more fun.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game makes me appreciate the difficulty of real life delivery man, especially if it's on some remote area where terrain makes transportation difficult.

On another note, this is different from the usual Kojima game, but it feels like Kojima game. So i'm actually surprised, well done.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Only 4.5 hours in(I had to force myself to quit the  game) but so far it is one of the most interesting games I've played. You see traces of MGS but make no mistake this is an entirely different game wtih a unique setting and  interesting gameplay elements.  Seems like it can only get better as the story expands. 
Hold off if you are expecting MGS. If you do like exploration, slow progress and a story driven game, then it might be for you.

edit : 

I thought I'd add my final input after 56 hours of gameplay. 
I mostly stand behind what I said. I had only two major issues through out the game :
1 - The final chapters are way too linear and filled with almost an hour  worth of cutscenes. So you kind of watch more than you play which is never a good thing for any game. You have to play the game. Considering how amazing the gameplay itself is, it was a huge downer for me. 
2 - The exploration is story driven. Meaning if you stumble upon a node/terminal the chances are you won't be able to interract with it unless the story has taken you there. So at times I felt like my exploration efforts were not rewarded, and almost punished. It is not something that happens frequently because the story forces you to explore, so it isn't a huge deal but still worth mentioning. 

Overall it is an 8.5/10 for me. I cut down 1.5 points for the reasons I mentioned above.
Everything else is phenomenal.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is another Kojima's masterpiece. I can't believe what I just played. Out of this world storytelling, enhanced by the best motion capture I've ever seen. Ended up crying at the end. I wouldn't recommend this to the average gAmEr though. For most cases it will be like giving a $100.000 wine bottle to someone who doesn't drink wine. They won't know how to appreciate it, or what things they should be looking at.
Thank you 505 games, thank you Hideo.

review: Marvelous!

review: What a weird, special and beautiful game.

review: not for everyone my ass, the game is beautiful

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Gorgeous. Captivating story (so far).

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: You basically work for DHL.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Truly a phenomenal game, except for the 2+ hours cutscene at the end.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
First and foremost: This game won't appeal to everyone.

Of course, that's a true statement for any game, but this one will be more divisive than most. I'll try to explain:

This isn't an action game. There are action elements, with new approaches to battle unlocked as the game progresses, but you can avoid most conflicts to the point where they do not occur often at all. Some have described the game as a "walking simulator." I feel you have to ignore a lot of what the game has to offer if that's your takeaway, but it's not -too- far from the truth.

So what do you do? You walk. A lot. At least, you do at first. You make deliveries by getting from point A to point B. That, essentially, is the core of the game. Should you choose to do so, you can try to unlock and use vehicles. Build roads to make the journeys easier. Meet and learn the stories behind a number of characters, and read a deep and sometimes confusing backstory as to how the world got to be the wasteland it currently is.

You could take on the most basic missions and rush through the game, or you can relax and take your time and learn more about what's going on around you.

It's weird. It's sometimes confusing. For me, though, I kept wanting to find out more. It felt rewarding to finally get the necessary materials to build a structure in a key location, and watch as other players leave "likes" (which you then use to "level up") on any that they find useful. It was interesting to see each puzzle piece of the story fit together and things began to make sense.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: good

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Humping boxes through rivers, over mountains and the like has never been so absorbing. Not suitable for those with short attention spans.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This isn't the game you thought it'd be I'm sure. It's not a fast paced, intense, action based game. It's a story that slowly unfolds as you make your journey. This game makes a real effort to bring small details that make the story that much more rich and engaging. In order to appreciate this game, you have to appreciate the story and message. In my opinion, this game does an amazing job at making you feel connected to others that are currently at the same point in Sam's journey as you are. The graphics are beautiful, music is great and thoughtfully placed, and the voice acting is top notch. 

This game is in a category all it's own and in order to appreciate it, you gotta be up for the long, drawn out, beautifully written ride :)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Amazing game that pushes the idea of what game entertainment can be... but - you're either gonna LOVE it or HATE it. Not sure there's an in between.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I legitimately cannot tell you whether I liked the game or I'm suffering from stockholm syndrome.

The reality is that this game has a bunch of fun parts and a bunch of dumb parts. I loved delivering packages and exploring the open world. I hated the bullet sponge directionless boss battles. I loved building structures and making viable delivery routes. I hated the overacted and tediously long cutscenes. I loved the environment design and the visual fidelity. I hated how much focus there is on pausing every second to look at your UI. I loved avoiding/fighting the 2 main enemies in the game. I hated how cheesy the dialogue was. I loved the atomsphere the game built in certain scenes. I hated the stupidly long ending/credits scenes.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
*H I G H L Y R E C O M M E N D*

The most original game I've played in decades, nothing is quite like it. Hideo has let his creativity run wild and has turned up his trademark weirdness to 11! 

This game is not for everyone, it's a love it or hate it situation. I highly encourage you to try it and experience the amazing world and experience that is the first "Strand type game."

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Play as Norman Reedus portraying a postal worker in scenic post apocalyptic America, which looks like Iceland for no discernible reason. Trip over rocks and hide from ghosts as you try and sign everyone up for AOL, guzzling Monster all the way. Conan O'Brien tells you about otters.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
pros
+ excellent ps4 port. almost no graphical glitches. latest steam and graphic driver update improved performance even further. constant 60+ fps on 1080p ultra, except on some areas with heavy rain and long draw distance. (my spec is ryzen 3600 + rx 580 8gb)
+ gorgeous landscapes with excellent graphics.
+ story is a bit weird but i like it, excellent, almost prophetic social critique on modern american society.
+ gameplay is good, realistic walking and climbing mechanics, great passive online structure sharing system.
+ good soundtrack

cons
- pacing issues. they need to not infodump it all at the end
- some balance issues, eg:
    - mules are very easy. terrorists are better but they are nothing compared to bt's
    - oxygen mask is needed for just one mission and has no practical use on regular missions
    - watchtower is not that useful, while ziplines are incredibly useful
- why is western region is so short

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
God, this game is amazing. Many people approach it as a walking simulator, but its more than that. Ill admit, maybe the first 2 hours are, but thats before they give you vehicles to use and drive, which really isnt long. Theres 3 things that make this game just... so great

The Graphics/Physics/Mechanics
Theres was maybe 2 times something weird happened... a truck got stuck on a rock, and my game crashed loading a boss. Other than that, the game is BEAUTIFUL and runs smooth, just look online and find a cutscene. The tripping/stability mechanic for rocks, and slants works wonders, and its pretty reasonable when it comes to balance. Carrying a lot and turn around quickly? You stumble. Carrying a lot of stuff? Hit a roof and it falls off. Its the small stuff that gets you, cause it all just runs perfectly together


The Story
Man.. this game isnt as easy as "go across the US, kill bad guy, yay you did it!" the entire last 2 chapters (of 13) are almost all cutscenes, just DETAILING and EXPLAINING stuff, connecting and making sense of the 40 (in my case) hours you put playing this game, why this person did this or why they are how they are. Plus the twists all the way inbetween, I'd sit here and gasp at some stuff, like "oh my god thats him!" or just be shocked at what I was presented

The Music
Now, this seems minor, but the soundtrack for this game is unique. Of course anything made has its use, but the music in this just.... hits; it knows just when to kick on, and complete the scene. Whether emerging after a nap in your room, driving through a desolate valley, sneaking past BTs or that final delivery, people who played know what I mean. It just creeps on you and gives that extra bump or tension needed to make the feeling alive


Overall... this game makes me sad. I've completed the story, and I'm sad I cant experience it again with the same level of mysticism, but I'm glad I was able to experience it to begin with. 1000 likes to Kojima and the wonderful people who put this together!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Everyone lives holed up inside their homes because there are scary invisible ghosts out there. If someone gets exposed to the ghosts without the right protective equipment, thousands could die. The only thing that keeps people sane and functional is getting stuff in the mail. 
This post-apocalyptic hiking simulator feels like if STALKER and Dark Souls were holding hands. There are guns, but the game is at its best when you're not using them. I've you ever been hiking with a considerably heavy backpack, you'll empathize with Sam harder than with any other game protagonist.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The story gets more bizarre as it goes on, in the tradition of Kojima games. I really enjoyed the gameplay, although it won't be for everybody. If you've played Red Dead Redemption 2 and disliked the downtime while traveling between point A and B, you will not like this game. If you didn't mind or even enjoyed that transit time, you'll probably like Death Stranding.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
There are only 2 games that managed to make me cry by the end and I am happy to say this is one of them. A deep story, lots of emotions, a big threat and (mostly) relaxing gameplay with some action and horror moments thrown in to shake up things.

This game is a masterpiece visually, gameplay-wise and story-wise. Combined with Soundtrack from Low Roar and other musicians the travels through rough terrain are very enjoyable, which I initially was skeptical about if I would enjoy the whole delivery aspect of the game.

The game itself has "connections" or "strands" as a overall theme. Connecting people, players and npcs alike, to build up a broken society. On the note of players, I love how you can encounter other player structures and use them to traverse through the world as well as make your own structures to help other players (I spent an embarrassing amount on building roads, but in the end it was very worth it).

And then, there is the end. Without spoiling anything, it is one of the greatest endings in a video game I have experienced in a long time. If you are curious what the other game was that made me cry, it was Mother 3... yes it's on that level.

Oh and to any new players: Don't stay in Chapter 2 for too long! You can return to that area at any given time, just play Chapter 3 for a bit before returning as the things you get will make deliveries much easier.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[i]See the sun set….. the day is ending…… Let that yawn out…….. there’s no pretending….. [/i]

[b]What. A. Game.[/b]

[h1]Story: 10/10[/h1]
The story is absolute class, which is something I’ve already come to expect from a Kojima Game. Having played Metal Gear and really liking the settings and stories used there, I knew this would be no different and I was not wrong. Kojima always manages to create story’s which start with the player gaining about 100 different questions in the space of 20-30 minuets and then slowly unravel as you progress which is always immensely satisfying at the end, once everything is revealed and the puzzle pieces start fitting together. This game has exactly that, which was already evident from the trailer. I loved all of it, from the premise of the Death Stranding to the people who you meet in the world. Of particular importance was Mads Mikkelsen’s character and story arc which I thought was phenomenal throughout and loved every scene he was in. I also enjoyed Heartman and thought his story and input were great, quirky, and added some light humour which I thought worked well.

[h1]Gameplay: 10/10[/h1]
Well, this one was always going to be hit and miss depending on the player. The deliveries never felt like boring fetch quests for me which was brilliant as it kept me immersed and a big part of that was the environmental setting which amazing. I loved evading or even fighting the BT’s which always added a sense of fear to the gameplay and was very welcome. Having the correct loadout and weight distribution for making trips also added to the sense of achievement I felt when I made a delivery and therefore, I never felt the task was boring or worthless. The MULES were also another great addition, providing a human NPC for me to either evade or attack and helped mix up gameplay and kept things fresh.

[h1]Soundtrack: 10/10[/h1]
Again, Kojima has a great taste in music and always manages to fit the right tune in at the right moment. Music always has the chance to really make or break game and for this, it worked perfectly. From action scenes to the cut scenes I really rated it and it adds to everything.

[h1]Graphics: 10/10[/h1]
Pretty outstanding graphics and I was able to run this at a solid frame rate (120-130fps) on max settings (Spec in profile). You have the option of enabling DLSS 2.0 if you own a Nvidia RTX card, but I did not need to enable it. I encountered no graphical glitches and no crashes so full points here.

[h1]Overall Score (in my own opinion): 10/10[/h1]
 I liked every scene in this game and had no complaints. Again, to reiterate, this is my opinion. We are all different and, in my case, I loved making deliveries and I especially loved the story and its cutscenes. I really cannot wait to see what game Kojima comes out with next.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
People will paint this game as a "walking simulator" without ever having played it. To call it such is pretty much painting every other open world game as such from the Elder Scrolls to Far Cry to the Zelda series as a "walking simulator". Your goal can be simple but the journey to complete it is monumental. By grounding itself in realistic expectations of how you traverse mountains and hills actually become just that, an endeavor and a challenge instead of just a set piece that you jump to the top of.

The threat of the world isn't just the terrain as you can soon find out in this new messed up world, but steadily, piece by piece you get more tools at your disposal. Small buildings can be erected by you as well as other players, forging a support network that can make the harsh reality a bit more hospitable.

Personally this game reminds me of playing The N64 Zelda games for the first time, the feeling of changing the world one step at a time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding - full disclosure; this is NOT a game for everyone. A lot of people would call it a "Walking Simulator", but in all honesty that is a very shallow description. There are stealth elements, there are battles/fights, there are Boss Battles against the BTs and the Stranded Monsters, BUT, Primarily - Yes - there is a lot of walking. This is more of a relaxing type of game with reflection being a major part. So, if youre looking for a Metal Gear Solid-Like game, keep walking -- Pun Intended. 

If youre looking for a more chill, relaxed, but bat-shit crazy storied game - You're found your game

title: DEATH STRANDING

Let Death Stranding take you on a ride and enjoy, see it through to the end and you won't be disappointed. Beautiful game with amazing actors and a well executed idea.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Bought this on its PC release date after waiting way too long for it to finally come out. 54 hours in and I don't feel I am too close to completion, the game has lived up to its hype, and I never tire of finding new ways to traverse terrain more quickly or efficiently. The way the game is designed and paced allows you to never feel like you're progressing too fast, as there is always something to be accomplished whether it's building up loyalty with remotely located Preppers, collecting materials for rebuilding roads, or making your own network of ziplines, bridges, ladders, climbing ropes, etc. People say it's a walking simulator but I think it's more of an post-apocalyptic delivery expedition simulator. The gameplay reminds me of the old stories of Lewis and Clark, the Pony Express, and dogsled drivers delivering vaccines to remote towns/villages, except with a sci-fi futuristic atmospheric horror spin on it. It's an incredibly gratifying game and I recommend anyone try it. If you're not sure if it will be your cup of tea, maybe wait for it to go on sale. But if you're a fan of previous Hideo Kojima titles, I doubt this will disappoint.

The gameplay is basically inventory management, walking/driving/balancing your cargo and yourself as you traverse rough terrain, a little bit of standard 3rd person shooter and thats basically it. You know that feeling when you just want to skip the cutscene to get to the gameplay? Well this game makes you wish you could skip both. I played through it to see if the story got any better at the end, it did'nt.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The fact that this game came before a global pandemic was really amazing. Now more than ever, it seems our actual world is devided. This game's story is one I am still unfolding 30 hours in, however, there are major themes that combat apathy and division. It uplifts and encourages the value in a human life. 

Gameplay is very unique. I really enjoy taking long missions/orders to find that someone out there laid a road or a ladder to help me out. It uplifts the story of 'connecting america" and "making us whole'. Very thoughtful and is a MUST PLAY. DO NOT WATCH CUT-SCENES ON YOUTUBE.

Thanks Kojima!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] The Strangest Game I've Played... [/h1]

TL;DR - It is entertaining, and it can get a little tedious/repetative, but the story - atmosphere - art direction make it all worth it. I fully recommend picking up this title, even more so if you see it on sale.

[b] My Experience [/b]

So, I have not played this game for too long, nor did I really hear too much about it before hand. This gave me the rare opportunity to be able to start this bad boy up without any expectations, and with a sense of wonder that has been missing since the overwhelming amount of information that is usually spoiled by social media and other platforms. Now, many people know about the man, Hideo Kojima. What [i] I knew [/i] about him was that he worked primarily on the Metal Gear series - before all the hub ub went down with Konami. Regardless of what or how you may feel about that whole [i] thing [/i], the man is damn talented, and a great writer.

For the entire time I played (I know, not very long) I was completely immersed. It played less like a video game, and more like a hybrid between a game and movie. The cut scenes, story - all had me thinking that I was literally another person tagging along for the ride on Sam's journey.

It pains me to say, but obviously there is no such thing as a "perfect" video game - due to individual tastes, failed programming, poor engines, bad designs, and subjective perspectives, but I dare say this title comes just about as close to perfect as you can get.

[u] The Nitty Gritty [/u]

The Good;
- Great design.
- Awesome graphics - even my potato made it look good.
- Almost zero lag/hang ups - usually only when I'd rocket into a settlement too fast.
- Story is completely immersive.
- Music suits the moods offered by the game.
- Just the right amount of RPG elements.
- Makes time just whizz right by.
- Most important of all - it's damn fun.

The Meh;
- Can become tedious
- Something other than delivery quests would be nice, like go eradicate a BT territory, for example.
- Equipment interface and switching is a bit clunky.

The Bad;
- Controls are a little wonky, not unplayable, just feels like Sam is drunk.
- Vehicle controls, namely steering, is friggin hard to get used to.
- A pebble beside a stream can bring your reverse trike to a dead stop...

[b] Overall Impressions and Analysis [/b]

A very good game, worthy of being called a triple A title. The small things that made up my "Meh" and "Bad" lists are quite minor - really only annoyances, and not game breaking at all. As I continue to play, and unlock more of the game, I will update this review. I know that there is a whole lot that I haven't uncovered just yet, but I was so impressed by the first 5 hours of play that I had to put this review up.

[b] My Patented and Infallible Score Process Results [/b]

At 5 hrs game time - 90%, ezpz.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Honestly one of the best games I've ever played in my entire life. It's such an immersive experience and such an atypical game that I instantly fell in love with it. It's basically Hideo's take on society. It's an actual metaphorical essay on society, and life itself. Our relation to the past, how we connect with others, and so on. I'm truly saddened by the fact that people didn't take this game well, because I think it's truly a mesmerizing piece of art. Incredible acting, incredible direction, superb soundtrack, and absolutely stunning game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I am a gameplay-first kind of guy. It's very rare I'll continue to play a game for the story or plot if I do not enjoy the moment to moment gameplay and mechanics of a game... and that's why I'm so confident in my recommendation of this glorious game. I've put nearly 40 hours into this game, yet from what I can gather I'm around a quarter through the main story. Why? Because this game is beautifully nuanced in its systems, mechanically deep in its gameplay, and thoroughly enjoyable regardless of how menial the task is I'm completing in the game, because it's so enjoyable to play.

It may not be for everyone, but if you come into it with an open mind and some patience to understand the deeper layers of gameplay hidden within, it's an extremely rewarding game. I can't wait to spend another 40 hours with the game... weather the story goes anywhere or not (and so far that's really good too :-) ).

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I try to be as critical as possible when I review games nowadays, but for Death Stranding, I simply don't have the ability to put in to words what this game is or what it makes me feel.

The lore of Death Stranding is based on the real world, but in that regard, it makes almost no sense, its full of holes and it needlessly rewrites history for some reason, just for... what even? It's unnecessary and feels like an excuse to spout utter nonsense exposition at the player, through characters who seem like they're just Hideo Kojima wearing a mask, and not a believable human character. The story, though.. when the game isn't expositing garbage, is amazing, and surprisingly compelling. Its what ties the game together, and the game is trying to contextualise is so unusual and different, so the story HAD to be good. Sam is believable, and the people the game surrounds him with are believable as well, almost to a fault. They're so real, that just like real people, you'll only ever want to watch their cutscenes once. They're so awkward. They're uncomfortably real. Whenever the characters aren't... talking like they're reading a script it really is like they're just real people and i love/hate it? it's compliated. Except for Clifford, he's beautiful and I wanna watch him over and over again.

But the story is good and that's all there really is to say, so what about the game? Well, from my point of view, its incredible. Aside from a moment at the end of the game, on a beach, you know the one. but that's like 20 excruciating minutes on a beach among a 40 hour sea of utterly compelling environments, gameplay and systems. The story? I had to watch a 7 hour analysis/commentary to understand it. But the gameplay? I understood it the moment i took the first step. I want to say more, but I'm no critic, this is a game you have to experience. if you don't feel good within the first two hours, you can refund it knowing the game isnt for you. But if you enjoy those first hours like I did, stick with it, 40, 50, a hundred hours, whatever. I plan to go back and play more of this game, just spend time in it's world in it's never ending end game, to help other porters through their adventures, to give likes, to make deliveries..yeah, I think I like this game.
I discussed lore and other nonsense for hours after the credits rolled with my girlfriend, the only other games which have really compelled me to do that are Final Fantasy 14, Xenoblade and Fire Emblem.

Oh yeah, and Sam named his daughter the same I named mine. My daughter is canon. I'm a proud Mama. 10/10, literally perfect game, masterpiece, would play again, etc

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is not for everyone. There is some action here and there, but you will spend most of your time traversing various beautiful landscapes while managing deliveries. Going in to it as a fan of Kojima and not watching any footage of it beforehand, I honestly didn't know what to expect. But this was one of the best experiences I've had in a long time. If you decide to give it a shot, I highly recommend playing the story to completion. It starts off a little slow, but the ending was one of the most powerful and emotional things I've ever seen in a video game. Thank you Kojima and Kojima Productions.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Note: I played the game start to finish on "Very Hard" difficulty. 

This game is one of a kind. The main gameplay is fun, delivering packages sounds boring, but when you actually get into it and play it, the numerous threats that oppose you add for a challenging, yet fun, experience. It is extremely rewarding and satisfying to take on a delivery with a massive capacity that you can just barely carry to its destination. You start off as just a person in an unfair environment, but as the game progresses, you begin to unlock new items and tools to make the game just a little bit easier to traverse. This pacing makes upgrades seem very valuable. Although it was on the highest difficulty, I still found myself racking up S - rated scores for deliveries.

What really helps the gameplay set in is the graphics. This game is absolutely gorgeous. The game will also play certain tracks of music during specific times in the game which leads to very emotional moments. One of my biggest moments of pure awe was at the very beginning, and that set the tone for the rest of the game

The story is phenomenal, if confusing at times. However, there are numerous pieces of lore available to the player that they can view at any time to help fill them in. I played the whole game without looking at any bonus lore and I still understood the story. The characters are likable and show a different viewpoint on the world as a whole. The game remains very self aware of its mechanics, and characters can be seen following the rules of mechanics in the game in cutscenes, adding to overall world building.

My only gripe with this game is the combat. The combat is very bad. The combat is so bad, that I avoided it whenever I could. The main character moves too slow and reacts too slowly to inputs to make high stakes combat fun. To add on to this, some enemies in the game create an area that slows the character's movements down, which makes fighting in these areas even more tedious. There are tools that help mitigate this, but they are not available until later in the game Weapons do not pull their ammo for one pool, they pull from their own pools of ammo, so if you are not paying attention, you could end up holding a few assault rifles with no ammo, just clogging up carrying capacity because each assault rifle has its own unique ammo count.

Also, they stopped giving me Monster Energy about halfway through the game. Gave me some knock off stuff. Worst moment in the whole game by far.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is awful. The worst thing about it? There is so many cut scenes in the first few hours that by the time you figure out the gameplay sucks you have gone past Steam's two hour return point. 

Where to start... the monsters you fight are annoying. You like... throw you shit at them I guess? Why? And when you are fighting them you CAN"T QUIT THE STUPID #@#$@#$ game. You actually have to wait until you die if you are annoyed and want to quit.

The UI is ridiculously unintuitive and clunky. 5 hours into this game I still only sort of get how the UI works, nothing about it is intuitive or makes any kind of logical sense. I once spend (I shit you not) like 20 minutes trying to navigate the conveluted UI system to accept a specific mission.

The "gameplay" basically just involves walking... and falling over. and walking some more. And falling over. It's #@$@# annoying. The entire game is annoying. I don't understand why Death Stranding has so many positive reviews on Stream. I very much regret buying this and don't even think it would be worth picking up at like... $20. It's just bad. All of it is bad.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'll just flag this as not recommended, so you people should heed the reviews more carefully. This game is NOT for everyone, so make sure you do your research before buying this game.

It's essentially a walking simulator with a lot of frustrations on every little things that come up like falling over when you are trying to scratch your nose after playing for hours. When there's a boss fight (plot points), it just become more of a boiling point for frustration to boil over after dealing with so many mundane craps in the game. After playing for hours and setting up roads for various players, I just come to a point where I just say it just... wasn't fun. I butchered the MULE camps and the only thing I have to watch out for is BT and that's about it, majority of the game is watching unskippable cutscenes and simulating amazon deliveries.

I don't think I'll be buying anymore Kojima's game, because I've given him a chance and he kind of blew it for me. If this game is for you, great, go and enjoy it. This is just my opinion and my experience after playing Death Stranding.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This is one of my top games of the year, but I struggled to decide whether or not I could, in good conscience, recommend it to others as I can easily see how it could be a very polarizing experience. If you go in without the expectation that this is any kind of Metal Gear Solid title or even MGS-adjacent, I think you will have a better shot of enjoying it. The setting is wild and inventive while the dialogue is corny and frequent but serviceable. The overall narrative is compelling, and I found myself enjoying the traversal game-play loop. The story also hits a lot harder from the perspective of a parent. It's not going to be everyone's cup of tea, but for the people who allow themselves to be immersed by Death Stranding, it'll probably wind up being one of your favorite titles.

It's essentially "digital errands" do over and over as a player.  Unless you FULLY connect with the story (which I didn't, I just found it too strange to get into) then you're not going to love this game.  By chaptor 10, I just started skipping every single cutscene so I could get this game over with and be done with it. I would have just walked away but when you drop $60 on a game you definitely owe it to yourself to finish it.  I ended up finishing in 35 hours but I bet if you watch the cutscenes then you're in for 40 plus and if you have the difficulty high and do a lot of the optional errands then, heck, you may get 60 hours in it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
An amazing beautiful game! The game-play might not be for everyone, but if you enjoy it, you REALLY enjoy it. The amazing world that comes along with it and the wild ride you're taken on makes it all the better. In terms of performance I am astonished at how well it performs while maintaining some truly amazing visuals. This is probably one of the best looking games that released recently and it runs like a dream. There are very rare dips in frame rate. I'm running it on a GTX 1080ti and R7 1800X. I am able to maintain about 71 fps on average.

In my entire play through I only encountered one bug. This bug tended to show up when playing a single session for upwards of 5 hours and would cause objects to stop loading in. Can be fixed by restarting the game. 

Regarding ultrawide support. The game does support 21:9 in the literal sense. You will need to hex edit for 3440x1440 or 2560x1080. With the edit the experience is completely flawless
