title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
To keep things brief, Death Standing is a weird game in that I feel like it's a simulator game with far more money and effort put in than you see normally. Imagine if something like Signal Simulator or Thief Simulator had the kind of resources put into it as a yearly Call of Duty. 

On it's own it's a very good cargo management and transportation simulator, mixed with stealth and combat sections that actually play rather well when you understand the nooks and crannies of the system. The first starting section of the game is rough since you lack the gear to handle things, and none of the bosses are anything spectacular. Most of the fun arrives when you have the tools to deal with problems and it all becomes a cost-benefit analysis of managing cargo, tools to bring with you, routes, and hazards along the way.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
One of the best gaming experiences I've had, but remains a tough title to recommend, particularly to players seeking a fun escape from work/school/life's stresses.

I felt the game actively sought to frustrate, impede, and exhaust the player. 
Yet Kojima was able to utilize these hardships to convey a positive message. 
When you set out on your current quest, the journey is difficult and exhausting. 
Completing this trek, the game enables you to see and interact with how others ahead of you tackled their journeys, instilling the idea that you are not the first to experience these hardships, nor will you be the last. Like the predecessors before you, you are given the opportunity, will you act to ameliorate suffering in the life journey of others? By building shortcuts and donating vehicles/items to nameless strangers, you could make a thankless gesture to help others on their journeys and relieve overall suffering in the world. 
It is a unique and emotional experience that I've only seen successfully done in [spoiler]Nier[/spoiler]. 

There is much more to say, but instead I'll choose to wrap this up. 
Death Stranding is a wholly unique experience, weaving messaging, setting, story, and player emotions to deeply explore concepts like the double-edged nature of connections, the perennial impact of the dearly departed, and finding a personal reason to endure the hard road of life or succumb to the nature of a fatalistic and dying world. 

Death Stranding has left a lasting impression on me, and I hope the initial reviews of the game as "boring" don't dissuade him from continuing to take risks in developing games that are not traditionally considered fun to explore and convey his take on complex topics and messages. It is an experience like no other and I hope interested players will give Death Stranding a chance when they are ready.

title: DEATH STRANDING

There is a deep philosophical story where you may find answers for your (specifically your) questions. It took me around 40 hours to complete the game and I don't remember any boring or dull moment. Every challenge, every cut-scene, every delivery is special.  
This game is a brilliant masterpiece.
Definitely recommend

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The good 
- Graphics: The environment and its rendering in Death Stranding is stunning and I think I could enjoy strolling around in there just for the point of exploration (but at this stage i get a bit frustrated trying to sneak around invincible enemies).
- Audio: The soundtrack is great
- The "semi-cooperative" multiplayer where improvement of the game world are shared with the online community is a really great idea, you have the feeling that you're sharing stuff for the greater good when you build something.
- I like the story and setting, it is creepy and well though out.
- The game seems well optimized and I run it just fine on an older high end PC (Core i7 4790 with a GTX970) 

The bad (in my opinion)
The dialogues get pretty long, and are mostly with the player talking to a hologram or two. After just a few hours playing I got so frustrated them that I started skipping them altogether to get into the action faster (all things are relative), probably missing out on some of the story. 10-15 minutes dialogue with a couple of holograms in one go is too long and stale for me. Maybe not for you.

When you use your "private room" in the game to recover and organize yourself, there is an animation for every single action, some of which cannot be skipped. And between the actions the player HAS to go through the animations where he returns to his default position on his bed, staring contemplatively at the floor. What if I want to go from the toilet to the shower without sitting on the bed staring at the floor in between? It just makes it a drag to do this stuff (and it is required at some stages of the game).

My biggest gripe is that the game is mostly consisting of "fetch quests", travel to point A, talk to a hologram, get some cargo, take it to point B, unload cargo, talk to a hologram, get new cargo, go back to point A, talk to a hologram...
I am not a fan of these kind of missions in other open world games. Fetch quests are the worst kind of tasks in the Assassins Creed series IMO, and unfortunately I am not a fan of them here. In fact, dialogue with only holograms while standing still seems to make it worse. 

I only have 7 hours of game time so far, and I will try a bit more, mainly because I want to see different landscapes, and because it is too late to return this game. However I struggle to stay entertained already, and I doubt I will be able to motivate myself to finish the game.

Obviously from the reviews here there are lots of people who like this game. I hope I change my mind. In that case I will update my review. 

I do urge potential buyers to find some videos showing longer game play before buying.
I hope this helps.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: One of my favorite games of all time.  At face value I never thought I would enjoy, what essentially boils down to a delivery simulator.  However, I think the reason I liked it so much is that he game is so much more than that.  It's all about the atmosphere of being out in the natural environment on your own and the challenges of traversing difficult terrain.  The graphics are incredible and the feeling of being up on the side of a mountain, with the wind smashing you or traversing some alien looking rocky desert, having to pace your steps, can't be matched.  The story is also pretty interesting too if you like weird, artsy, sci-fi stuff but progresses pretty slowly and some of the side-stories (Moma) are can be silly.  Otherwise though great game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I tried....
But, sorry, I feel that a 'movie version' would've been better than what artist extraordinaire H.Kojima calls a "game" nowadays.
Correction: it is "a game", in the most passive and latent sense.
I know, I know: many will laud this as 'the greatest story ever told', conflating the emotion of the tale with ACTUAL GAMEPLAY, which unfortunately, it's dismally void of: 'travel for an unbearably long distance; hide; run; delivery mail - rinse and repeat'. 
The "combat" is more of the Alien: Isolation variety - so if that's your cup of tea, you'll probably get your fill here.
Optimization-wise, the game is first class, hands down; and for it to be running Denuvo, I'm extremely impressed.
With all that said, I don't think this is worth full price; if one wanted to experience a near true to form post-apocalyptic walking simulator, then wait for the sale.
But my Verdict: PAUPS Man: Post-Apocalyptic United Parcel Service Man! 'Coming Soon to a Theater Near You'
(EDIT: [Damn you, Kojima... "Going To Work: The Game" grew on me]:
Delivery after delivery, while attempting to get to a point in which the game became fun and interesting, I suddenly realized that "The Delivery" itself had become "the action" I found fun and interesting.... What a mindf***! Kudos, Kojima - another well-played Psycho Mantis gambit.)
Thumbs Up, all the way!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This is not your typical MMO. Its more a game of experiencing a life after a tragic situation.  You need to have a mind of strategy and patience in addressing situations in the game that aren't predictable. It has its action moments but action in respect to combat isn't its thrust, its about decision making to enable connections to occur from building bridges, roads, places to sleep and other constructs that not only benefit you but others. Its a different game which requires a different thought process and game play.  Give it a try I really like it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
With the PC release this game has solidified it's spot in my top 10 games of all time. This game is an absolute masterpiece in my honest opinion. I have so much to say about this one, and I really don't even care if no one ends up seeing it.

The story of Death Stranding focuses on themes of depression, isolation, connections with people and what comes with them, and what comes with losing those connections we have with people. It's a very important topic, especially with the situation going on in the world right now that almost perfectly encapsulates what Death Stranding is all about.

The writing is superb. I've read every email I've received, and every interview I obtained and I don't regret a second of it. Clients email you praising your efforts on deliveries, reminding you that you really are helping these people (whether the game shows that or not) the sense of accomplishment is unmatched. Interviews are chocked FULL with tiny details you would never know about if you didn't read them. Documents explaining timefall, BB's, BT's, Chiral Density and tons of other things that you could VERY easily just pass right by without ever finding out. A lot of these fully explain things that I was confused about the game (eg. Timefall and how it worked - why we can't use planes etc. etc.) the sense of discovery in this game is absolutely incredible.

The voice acting and acting efforts put forth by everyone involved in this game is unbelievable. You FEEL the pain of these characters. You see it in their faces and hear it in their voices. They feel like real people, real friends. Every actor involved put their A game forward and you can 100% tell. Fragile had a couple of weak parts but it by no means effects the game negatively. And of course Mads Mikkelson and Norman put on amazing performances. Probably some of the best I've ever seen in video games.

The graphics are incredible. The massive snowcapped mountains, deep valleys, dense forests and rivers dotting the horizon - it's spectacular. I don't think I've stopped this many times in a game just to take in the view. (aside from Ghost of Tsushima) It's a gorgeous game, and the cutscenes are only even more gorgeous and masterfully directed. The amount of detail in the character models, from the threading of Sams backpack straps and clips to the ominous carbon fiber skull mask that Die-Hardman wears, the level of detail is mind boggeling (Which I'll touch on later as well)

Where this game shines in my opinion is its game mechanics. Throughout the game it will introduce you to new tools that will help you on your journey. You'll also receive new tools from Preppers for raising your connection with them. These tools include things like Floating Carriers, Spike Gloves, Heat Pads, Battery packs, gas masks, multiple different exoskeletons and so much more that I can't even list here. It's all given to you at a pace which keeps you expirimenting with the different tools you're getting, and as you get further through the game you'll have a much more robust toolset for whatever your mission is. A lot of the game is delivering packages yes, but a majority of it is all about planning, and the satisfaction that comes from making it from point A to point B through whatever conditions may apply after said meticulous planning. I also need to mention the sense of discovery in this game. Finding new things you've never seen before (trying to stay as non-spoilery as I can) is so incredibly satisfying and downright cool. I found MANY things in my PC playthrough that I never knew were even a thing from my console playthrough. That includes tools I didn't know existed, and entire GAME MECHANICS I had no idea about. It's amazing!

The multiplayer mechanics are VERY unique and SO much fun to play with. The game has a soft multiplayer mechanic, so buildings and tools that you place in the world (even packages you have to leave behind) will show up in other players worlds, allowing them to use those tools to their advantage, like zip-lines, ladders, bridges and climbing ropes. Players can also put down signs (akin to Dark Souls) these can be warnings, greetings, or just plain motivation to "Keep on keeping on" you can receive likes from these players AND NPC's, raising your courier level and allowing you to carry more cargo, keep your balance more easily, and so on. You can also sign Bridges Contracts with other players or friends allowing more of their items and yours to be placed in eachothers worlds, eventually you'll have 30+ bridges contracts signed and you'll be helping so many players with every little thing you do.

I have so much more to say about this game, but I'll leave it at this - if you know what you're getting into and you're still interested, BUY IT. This game is absolutely incredible and will forever be up there with some of my favorite games of all time, solely based on how unique, mind bending, rewarding and gratifying this game was.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
After spent quite some time on this game, I decide putting my silly jokes aside, giving a serious review of it, ‘serious’ I mean, I will critise this game strictly based on the true feelings I had along the journey through BT infested America.

I think Kojima chan messed up this time. Despite the next-gen cinematic Graphics and ‘not a usual day you would listen to’ soundtracks, Death Stranding’s highlights are finished. I admitted the graphics of this game is a real next-leveled model even comparing the other titles within the triple A game industry’s standard, however, how long will it keep your eyes-open in the game? Sorry, but not for too long. The length of DS is around 40-60 hours in average. After 4-5 hours, you will be off the graphics hook probably like I did. Then what else will it be to keep you continually playing this game for the next 35-55 hours? 

The gameplay.

DS follows the tradition Kojima chan often does: everything progresses in detail SLOWLY. It isn’t a bad thing being honest, only means the game will be long. Long or short isn’t the problem here either, plus, I am not saying the idea of ‘delivery’ should never be used in the first place, but the real matter is: this idea doesn’t last long and wears off your interests pretty quickly. If it is the only problem in the long run, it might just catch the falling grade, unfortunately, the other matter comes along killed the gameplay completely and left me can’t give DS a pass.

It’s very repetitive.

If you’re an experienced gamer like me, you probably already noticed the gameplay structure of DS is very simple and repetitive. To sum it up in detail: you start in Point A delivering a cargo to Point B, on the way enter Mules’  territory and encounter them, fight them off your road, then reach Point B, from there to Point C, delivering another parcel while going through Timefall areas which means sneaking pass BTs stealthy. Lastly, go on delivering another cargo from Point C to Point A in a long distance while encountering Mules or BTs, or both. Repeat this process until you meet the chapter boss. 
DS might looks new to you, but it still gets lots of references from Metal Gear Solid mechanics regarding the gameplay. Like game consistently suggests you to play ‘stealthy’, or add some TPS elements to shoot your way out. I don’t know wether you get what I mean or not  here: Kojima studio doesn’t really get very far by creating new things in DS, instead, the major part of it felt like familiar, even in the story, I don’t want spoil anything here, but you will notice them once you’re set to play yourself. In my opinion, their next project should seriously take some deep thoughts, learn and break this mind cycle, otherwise, they never gonna make something truly amazing that could surpass MGS franchise. And we all know that the longer a franchise is, the less idea you could have coming up to work it around.  

The idea to build facilities to help the other players is one of the few standing-outs and also happens to be original, I speak it highly and wholeheartedly think the team should be proud of themselves. It added a lot of fun to a single-player campaign. What’s more? It now becomes the sole reason I still playing this game because I found building structure in order to help the others and appreciated by him/her is way more fun than delivering cargos to the NPCs in the main missions. I personally have no doubts that the story will meet my expectations but the gameplay just barely could hold me reaching that far end. I honestly could drop this game at any point now if any new more interesting titles comes to my lab. This online feature is a small good catch but still can’t make up for the entire game, even I counted graphics and soundtracks within too.
Some players might enjoy the Iceland-America  landscapes, but for a player like me, I found it hard to enjoy them while Mules and Timefalls are consistently chasing my back. 

Tripe A games now like to use very complicated controls as the trend I say? DS is not an exception. Despite the cargo delivery is repetitive and dull, the control you need to learn are more than you can think of. The tutorial section of this game is like a thick book, well, I only say one sentence: you do need to enjoy reading otherwise you may not going to like DS. Because there are many things to read in the game and the controls takes a lot of time to read too. Once tips vanish into the ocean of the tutorial book, you will have a hard time to find it again.

Anyways, spending $60 for a game only for its cinematic graphics and beautiful soundtracks definitely are not my recommendation. I also happened to have a mix feeling about DS regarding its attachments. In one hand, I really appreciate it make its way to PC. If it stuck to PS4, I would have missed this title probably like forever. Even though I don’t recommend this game, whether to have a choice to try it or not is entirely a different matter. I’d like one and I am very grateful for it on PC. In the other hand, DS came to PC with half a year delayed, full priced no less, planting Denuvo inside it. Feeling like a back slap to my face with no joke. Well, don’t chase Kojima chan with your $60 or more while he chased his favorite actors and actresses in this one, the relationship blooms no result for you. Besides, there are many big titles lining up until the end of the 2020. Wouldn’t it be better to spend your money for the FIRST PC released titles(if proves being good ones of course) like Halo Infinite, Cyberpunk 2077, The Medium, Tell Me Why, if you’re not Steam Only Members, then also Starwars: Squadron, Watchdogs: Legion and the new Assassin’s Creed and so on? Meanwhile this parcel delivery simulator can wait a year or 2 being exactly the same with a price drop. Then, if you still insist being Uncle Sam to save the Ice-landed Unite States, go ahead and grab it, the loss would seemly be fairly low. 

If you still skeptical about what I’ve said here, go and watch a DS gameplay video, it also helps for my statements Ive listed above. Well you may still have a final question left: why the hell I had it in the first place then? 

Nah, it was a gift.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
In a world of similar concepts being repeated year after year, Death Stranding takes "questing" to a whole new level. Although, the concept is simple (pick up a package and deliver it to a town you've probably already visited), the game keeps you intrigued and on your toes as you're progressing through the ranks. Each new delivery adds a new element of danger and gives you multiple ways to solve (taking a new route, facing enemies head on, being sneaky). 

The story draws you in with it's dark and ominous tones, and the gameplay mechanics are balancing caro and using different vehicles keep the game feeling fresh. I highly suggest this for anyone looking for a fresh take on a video game that requires hours to "grind" to complete.

This universe henceforth without a master seems to him neither sterile nor futile. Each atom of that stone, each mineral flake of that night filled mountain, in itself forms a world. title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I would like to preface this review by saying this is the first instance of me playing a Hideo Kojima game, and while I have had no prior experience with his works, Kojima's stentorian reputation of making unique and impactful pieces of art has duly been maintained with Death Stranding.

Death Stranding's mien is just that: a piece of art. This descriptor is not necessarily that of praise, but rather something to be experienced and digested. Not everyone wants to sit and tacitly absorb a game, but rather get into the action right away, and that's fine. But Death Stranding is at the aphelion of that. In fact, Death Stranding's gameplay is largely secondary to the plot and story, and Hideo Kojima could have easily indited the plot as a novel, and the experience and sentiments I had at the end of the game would have largely been the same.

I don't want to turn this review into a full-on harangue, so I'll now surmise my thoughts: Death Stranding is a slow burn, giving the player gratification through their own arguably herculean efforts of hauling freight across a conspicuously small America. If you enjoy games like Subnautica, where you progressively acquire minute augmentations and slowly unravel plot, you will most likely enjoy Death Stranding. Beware that there are stints of the game where I would recommend a podcast or video to listen to.

Overall, this game receives accolades from me and an emphatic recommendation. The forty-five hours of gameplay to eighty dollars Canadian I spent was well worth it, and I look forward to further games Hideo Kojima has in store.

The graphics are beautiful and helps bring the realistically rendered characters to life and the landscape itself is another beautifully rendered character that you learn to navigate and explore, always seeking more efficient routes between zones.

If you loved the MGS games because of all the quirks, huge plot heavy cinematics and unusual gameplay then definitely pick this up, everyone else might be best waiting for a sale.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
F I N A L  __ T H O U G H T S
Finished the game just now, updating my review. It is so gooood. Just the best thing ever. Zip-lines are cool.

P L A Y   __W I T H__   C O N T R O L L E R !
Inventory MGMT could be a bit tedious with keyboard and mouse. The game seams to be designed with controller in mind. You absolutely can play it on the keyboard and get used to it, but I feel like controller would be better because things like "Hold Left/Right triggers to balance feel more intuitive".

R E A L I S M
So, imagine if you didn't have infinite pockets. Every single thing needs to be somewhere on your body. Now imagine that you play with other people, but you can't see them. You can only see things they put in the world for you. A "Speed Up" on a road to boost your bike, a "Cheer-Up" to restore your stamina, etc. You can sleep, rest, massage your shoulders, take a shower, pee, poop, drink and it affects game is a way - nothing critical, nothing to force you to do any of it, but everything feels very comprehensive and though-trough. In a way it reminded me playing an RPG, where I would collect all of the missions in a city and then plan a route and grind trough all of the tasks as fast a possible in a line. Except in this game that planning is a big part of it since you don't want to overload yourself. 

T H E  S T O R Y
The story is great so far. It has a Japanese approach to structuring of the gameplay. They are careful with surprises so taking a mission you can be almost sure that you will not be interrupted by some story event. And I like that very much. I want to relax and know that I'm in a sandbox, I understand the rules and the mechanics. As opposite to having some surprise behind every door because developers are worried that I'll get bored. I must say, many things in the game are scripted, but very subtly: a camera can zoom out a bit and a nice music starts playing. Also, I wish I could zoom out manually.

E M O T I O N S
There is something... off about how emotions are usually presented in modern and classical games/movies. Something sad happens and we watch people crying or looking depressed. I know for a fact that I'm not the only one who feels uncomfortable during those moments and don't understand why we need them. And for me games like Death Stranding and Persona are a breath of fresh air - they deal with it just right. Every moment is there for a good reason and not just "Well, the person died so let's show all the other characters show emotions to make it believable".

G A M E P L A Y
I was worried about the pacing of it all, how will it feel. And it is alright. Legs are fast enough. Getting somewhere isn't hard. The balancing challenge only happens when you overload yourself and it doesn't seem to be required. You get plenty of tools to deal with everything. It is easy to get things done and you probably will not be dying or failing a lot. In general I feel like the game loves me, it does everything to let me have a great time. One thing, it is probably good to go trough main missions first with taking additional ones only when it is in the same direction. 

G R A P H I C S
Wow. Just wow. Clearly Kojima made sure that every detail is just right. It is probably the best looking open world. There are plenty of good looking games out there, but this terrain feels more organic. Not artificially shaped to facilitate gameplay. It is, but with care.

C O N C L U S I O N
There are so many things I haven't mentioned but all of them come together in a single vision. There is also so many fun things that happens left and right. Doing various animations with Sam. I never did any side activities in GTA, it was always meh, in here everything has an animation that attracts attention and delivers.

title: DEATH STRANDING

review:
Ya know, i'm gonne be real honest with you guys.  Streaming this game on twitch was a blast for me. Not many people were interested in it,  but those who sticked around saw its MORE than just a walking sim. its MUCH more than that.  Emotionally investing story, the music is insanely good.  the voice acting and the facial animations were superb. best i've seen so far personally.  the gameplay yeah..well i'd give that a 6/10. its a simple loop. not that interesting but the story pushes you. and then you suddenly get that ingame music and you're spirits been revived.  If you dont care much about a simple gameplay loop. i heavily recommend it.

Story: 9/10
Gameplay: 6/10
Music: 10/10
Graphics: 8/10
Lenght: Depending if u do side missions, story took me 33 hrs.
Worth full price?: Yes. on sale? HELL YES.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]"It's about the journey, not the destination."[/h1]

Calling this game a "walking simulator" is like calling Metal Gear Solid V a "shooter".
True, you do a lot of it in the game, but it's also so, so much more.

MGSV is also the best comparison point here, as Death Stranding is definitely "A Hideo Kojima game."

Is it also a brand new, revolutionary "Strand-type game" genre? 
No, that's just Kojima and marketing pushing it a bit too much.
Still, it takes some ideas from other games, repacks and improves them in a way that provide a fresh perspective.
Describing them all in a review would ruin it, as finding them out yourself is half the fun.

[h1]Gameplay: (8.5/10)[/h1]
Kojima again provides a sandbox world for you to play around in, explore, and master, giving you more and more toys to choose your preferred way to achieve your objectives as you progress through the game.
The vast majority of the missions are about moving items from point A to point B, however what matters more is what happens on the road and how you deal with it with the tools at your disposal.
Grades and scores after each mission return as well, giving you that extra incentive to push yourself to perfection.
The worldbuilding is done in a way that perfectly fits the gameplay mechanics such as death and respawning.
There is also this great dynamic where if a main mission proves too challenging, spending some time on optional side content is very likely to make it easier, and it's truly up to the player and their choices as to HOW to make it easier as their choices visibly change the game's world.
[i]Note: I recommend playing on Very Hard difficulty, as otherwise the gameplay mechanics are underutilized and the game becomes a bit too easy. [b]Yes, that includes walking as a game mechanic.[/b][/i]

[h1]Story: (8/10)[/h1]
In a true "Hideo Kojima game" fashion this story about "Connections" (in all the meanings of the word you can possibly think of) requires your full attention as it presents a world, characters and events filled with strong metaphores, social commentary and themes that make you think and reflect on our own world and your own life.
This effect is strong, stronger than MGSV. So strong that I would risk saying it's more important than the actual story of the game taken at face value, which, even more so than MGSV, is hard to keep track of and truly understand unless you go full detective.
Also in a pure Kojima fashion, the game contains some fourth-wall-breaking moments, characters and items. This is just something you have to get used to.

[h1]Graphics/Audio: (9/10)[/h1]
I mean, just take a look at the top screenshots. 
This game is beautiful, with photorealistic environments, fantastic lighting, insanely detailed character models and great animations.
Performance capture is a bit uneven, sometimes reaching uncanny valley (Fragile, Mama) but mostly great, really capturing the emotions (Sam, Die-Hardman).
Audio effects are great and the music really pushes the atmosphere higher, when it manages to "get it right" (although sometimes it doesn't quite align)

[h1]Performance/Bugs (9/10)[/h1]
My GTX 1060 was holding 45-60 FPS on high-ish settings and I could probably stabilize it to a constant 60 by dropping some settings down, however with the pace of the game I didn't feel a need to do this as I only noticed the framedrops on the frame counter and not in the game itself.
The only real bug I ran into was a potential memory leak after REALLY long (8h+) sessions that resulted in disappearing textures, but it was very rare and a restart fixed it.
I heard other people ran into some issues though, so YMMV.

[h1]Length:[/h1]
A bit over 100 hours in I completed the main story, unlocked all of the unlockables and mastered ~170 out of... 400-500 side missions (not sure exactly how many exist) playing mostly on the hardest difficulty.
I wasn't rushing to completion but I haven't been super slow either.
It feels a bit smaller in scope than MGSV, but at the same time it's a more complete experience.

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
Just like Nier: Automata, it's an unusual game that does things differently and does it well. Despite not doing everything perfectly, it's worth to be experienced.
If you enjoy Kojima games and are open to experience something new in terms of gameplay, you will like it.
If you've never heard of Hideo Kojima and/or are just looking for an universally liked, triple-A game to enjoy, MGSV might be a better starting point, as it's definitely closer to mainstream games while still introducing Kojima's signature style.

[i]If you're still looking for more info I recommend the youtube review by SkillUp, as it's what convinced me to buy the game and contains some more in-depth explanations I didn't want to to include nor had the proper words to describe.[/i]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]I will be waiting for you on the beach[/h1]

Death Stranding is a very singular game, the first game from Kojima Productions as an stand-alone studio after the departure from Konami, it’s also the first new IP from this creator for a very long time, when it was confirmed excitement was the general feeling and while people didn’t really know back then what the game was about trailer after trailer, the excitement was brutal and then the game released and reception was, well, mixed, what happened?

The game is something completely different when it comes to the AAA scene, the premise is very unique, the core idea of the gameplay is traversing a map from A to B while connecting stations one with each other, sounds boring, right? Well, that’s because this is a very common simplification of what Death Stranding is, while a true simplification it doesn’t make justice to what the game truly feels. Thankfully it looks like after the excitement settled, the fan theories stopped and the PC version arrived, the game is getting a more positive reception in general, why? Well, that will have to wait until later in this review, so let’s get this thing started, shall we? 

In the future, Humanity has discovered the afterlife and the existence of the “Beaches”, places that work as bridges between our world and the world of the dead, at the same time Earth experiences an apocalyptic event called the Death Stranding which made both worlds to collide breaking the process of dying and letting in some creatures called BTs in the process, entities which only purpose is to drag the living to the world of the death, when this happens it creates a Voidout, for that reason communities across all the old United States hide themselves in subterranean bunkers.

As people hide themselves the only way of getting resources and having any contact with the outside is thanks to the Porters, people that cross all the land with packages, we will be controlling Sam Porter Bridges, a lonely worker of bridges that will get dragged into an impossible task, reconnect all the continent alongside other members of Bridges, it won’t take long until your mission becomes something bigger and deeper. 

Story is extensive, deep and involves a lot of characters that will not only helps us accomplish our objective but also open their feelings to us in a variety of ways, at first things won’t make that much sense as a lot of information is thrown at you very quickly but the more you unlock, the more connections you make, the more sense makes the story. 
It’s pure Kojima style, tons of military, social, political and humanistic topics mixed with a great layer of obscure post-apocalyptic science fiction, make no mistake, it’s deep and very interested but it’s presented at a very slow pace, keep in mind the game wants you to be intrigued with the story but at the same time wants you to enjoy the journey.

It’s really interesting at all levels, the world is completely gone, most characters are broken one way or the other and all actions have consequences in the long term, I would say everything is well connected and while not everything makes sense, it works pretty well.

And with that we come to the divisive part of this game, gameplay, as I pointed out before, if simplified this game sounds boring and maybe even stupid, we all know the “Amazon deliver” joke from when it was shown for the first time and let me tell you, it is not boring and it’s not stupid, on the contrary, it is quite addictive, it is challenging and the progression feels natural and not forced to the point in which you have so many tools that the traversal process becomes something quite cool, at least for me after playing it for almost 40 hours. 

Let’s start with the map's progression, the game is divided in 2 maps, the first area is the one you will be playing in chapters 1 and 2 while the second area (which is bigger) will be your playground from chapter 3 up to the very end of the game, what’s with this? Well, you will notice how the game throws at you a very stable but crescent challenge, from not so difficult hills, little rivers and a bit rocky slopes and then comes the next part of the challenge, big rocky hills, desertic areas, big rivers and mountains but by the time you need to pass this challenges you already got used to the traversal controls and fundamentals, your equipment is better than when you first started this journey and the progressions feels always like something you have accomplished, even with other players objects and/or interactions, never feels like something game breaking and always as something complementary to your own equipment. 

The movement, the balance, climbing, all the systems work amazingly well making the experience of traveling a very pleasant one and as you are enjoying your journey, why not pick up some lost cargo? Yes, this happens, a lot and almost without realizing it by yourself, deviating from your route just to pick another piece of cargo because you want more upgrades and better level, I didn’t feel like this was boring but a really great and challenging gameplay, sure, it’s not for everyone but if it catches your attention at first, you will surely enjoy it. 

Speaking of levels, keep an eye on those stars, Sam will improve his skills the more cargo you deliver here and there. 

There’s combat too against BTs, MULES and “special encounters” but I felt like this wasn’t the best part of the game, those 3 elements will go up in difficulty the further you go, from simple enemies to better armed or more challenging monsters, however you always have to options here, fight or run, if you decide to run then that’s it, you will just not face them and you will be able to continue your journey but if you decide you want to fight you will probably face a combat system that, while it works, it doesn’t feel like the main core of this game, it has some benefits to sometimes face the combat but most of the time is not worthy.

For such combats you will be unlocking both lethal and non-lethal weapons too, the first group for the BTs and the second one for human enemies.

Something very interesting from the technical perspective is the shifting area effect that will happen once BTs get you, imagine a complete transformation of the environment due to the chiral energy of the zone, once the combat starts a very interesting effect will happen that will change your area completely, I won’t spoil it cause’ I think it’s amazing but it’s visually stunning.

And speaking of visual elements, graphically this game is top tier, let’s keep in mind that the game is very nature focused and they nailed it, each natural perspective and scene gives you the opportunity to take a good picture. Seriously, this game is one of the best looking games I have seen in a very long time in terms of nature representation and biome integration, plus character models are superb, really expressive and detailed, each acting moment is amazing and the same could be said about the assets, high visual quality in this game everywhere. 

Of course we are talking about a PC version of a previous console exclusive and made with a console exclusive engine, the Decima, so it’s one of those cases in which the port itself is interesting enough to compare against it’s console counterpart and I’m happy to say that it’s a world of difference. The higher framerate makes this experience to go really smooth, the general performance is absolutely great with a great scalability with a wide variety of systems.

In general I have a very positive vision of this game, as you can see, I wasn’t really expecting anything from this and I found a really pleasant experience that I loved every single minute, it can be cheesy, it can be repetitive at times but story, characters and their performances, the world, everything in general really caught my attention and after spending almost 40 hours on it I can safely say that it’s a game that I absolutely recommend.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is not made for everyone. Im enjoying it but its very slow moving, but there are some amazing graphics. In steam its called a walking simulator. THEY ARE NOT WRONG.  Its not the i would not recommend to a friend but i would make sure they know exactly what they are spending $60 on. Some may like the type of game(im sure USPS or Fedex workers love it but to me delivering packages gets old). Beautiful graphics but having to walk every where the first half of the game seemed like it took forever. im only 5 chapters into the game but ive put 37 hours in. There is 10+ chapters ;[ . I will be finishing the game just so i can keep up with the story line but in all, you might just want to walk around the neighborhood for free instead of spending $60 to walk around in rain that burns you and also being attacked by BT's as Kojima calls them!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Kojima's return brings a new universe dripping with his signature style and social/political commentary, as well as fantastic art direction from Yoji Shinkawa. 
While not the artsy-fartsy genre-creating experience it was advertised as, it definitely brings a new twist on open world action-adventure games, making the act of traversing the map into much more than just walking from A to B. It's definitely a lot more fun than I would ever expect a game about delivering packages to be. The convoluted lore and futuristic aesthetic will make you feel right at home if you're a fan of Kojima's other games. If not, however, I imagine it'd be a little bit much in terms of how cheesy it can get.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I went into this game knowing fully what it was and what it offered. I watched many people play the game when it came out on console, thinking it was never coming to PC. I knew what the story was and what was going to happen. But damn is playing this game for yourself a whole different story. The story was still just as emotional and impactful as it would have been if i never watched what happens.
(Oh boy will BB's theme song be stuck in my head for ever and i love that)

I really never thought that i would become so addicted to delivering packages or building roads in this game. I really thought that i would just do what is necessary for completing the absolutely amazing story and just that, i was so wrong. Quickly after starting the game i began to really, and oddly, enjoy grabbing multiple orders and doing deliveries all over the map.
It got to the point where i was doing deliveries and not progressing the story for like 3 days as i was completely dedicated to getting 100% completion for achievements, and boy was that a struggle that was rewarding and enjoyable.

The music in this game is just simply amazing, i even started listening to a spotify playlist of the soundtrack ever since the game originally came out and i still love it.

I completely understand why some people will never enjoy this game as it is completely not for everyone, but if you are even slightly interested i highly believe you should try it. It is so worth it

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Still playing through, but extremely addicted to the immersion and anticipate another satisfying cinematic experience as Hideo Kojima would always deliver in every masterpiece.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is beautiful. The story is amazing, and it is the primary reason I had for playing. The settings are great, the characters are well written, and, for me at least, it was a lot of fun to play. I can't say that this game is for everyone, because it honestly isn't. But if you like a good story, like sinking a lot of time into something, or if you like to keep pushing forward against the odds, maybe you could give this one a try.

I for one, recommend this game 10 outta 10 from my own, albeit subjective, experiences.

title: DEATH STRANDING

now i listen to 'low roar' when  i am free, and i think of sam when i am carrying  anything heavy or receiving deliveries. 
'keep on, keeping on'

finished the main storyline, and the story is much better than i expected.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I have well over 75 hours on the Playstation 4 version, but was so beyond hyped to be able to purchase it again for PC. I'm in no way a diehard Kojima fan, frankly I think he's overrated, but this game is honestly a hidden gem. A lot of people brushed it off when they saw "walking simulator" and I think a lot of them are missing out. 

Is this game for everyone? No. Does it break the mold on traditional AAA games that just copy/paste the same thing with some changes (looking at you Ubisoft)? Yeah it does, and it does it well. Is it perfect? No. 

It's a unique story that no one except Kojima would create, but it's interesting, touching, and worth experiencing. Experiencing the landscape while helping to reunite a bunch of closed of settlements while these creatures from beyond, the BT's are waiting to get their hands on you, and if they're not after you a bunch of deliverers-gone-mad known as MULEs will try to tase you and steal your shit. 

Seriously though, it's a unique experience and absolutely worth it. I bought it, bought the Collector's Edition, then bought it a third time on PC (hoping for mods). If you're thinking about getting it, play it through to Chapter 2 before you brush it off and scream refund from the rooftops.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I have over 300 hours in game on the PS4 and 3 hours PC. I love this game. It is such a unique game that has a fantastic story. Hideo Kojima does not disappoint with this game, at least to me.
Performance: i9, 1080 Ti....I hold 60 frames constant at max settings. I can't do 4k because of my monitors but even under 4k this game is beautiful.
Story: as stated above the story is so great and is a great take on modern society
Controls: Take some getting used to on the PC since I came from PS4 land with it but they mesh well nicely
Sound: the soundtrack for this game is just amazing and it still sounds great being ported to PC

Cons: this game is not for everyone. I've played the game for a year and I've seen the hate it gets in the forums. People call it a "walking simulator" but so is any game you play if you want to break it down that far. The deliveries can get repetitive but so is shooting people in COD, building in Subnautica, or Conquest on Smite.

All in all, hands down one of my favorite games due to how beautiful the game world is in it and the amazing story it has.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm not one to be moved by video games or cry often but Death Stranding is an excellent game that discusses many struggles that we all will face throughout life. 

I would recommend this game wholeheartedly. However, you will have a hard time enjoying the experience if you have no patience or a desire for story-driven games. In my opinion, people who really like the lore behind their favorite games & movies as well as people who enjoy grindy games will love their experience. I would not recommend this game to people who only play action-multiplayer games such as Battle Royale or other PvP exclusive titles.

 Hideo Kojima you are a master of storytelling, video game design, and entertainment.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:

We'll be waiting for you, on the beach.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Played on Very hard without changing difficulty. If I didn't have time to kill during a global pandemic I would have deleted this game after about 5 hours since I believe in giving bad games a chance. Overall this game is pretty bad. its tedious. the terrain programming and vehicle handling is low quality you can tell they cut corners everywhere. you have to hold down buttons constantly you can toggle run on keyboard and mouse but they really made this game as painful to play as possible. its cool how other players stuff and your stuff can exist in the same world and people like the things you build. I spent a lot of time building roads and helping people. the combat on very hard, is basically avoid/run its dumb. the acting is bad, the storyline is bad. overall its like all hideo kojima games I have played, trash tier, lots of time killing stuff, but really just garbage. It might be just what you need though during a pandemic to kill a lot of time though....

Mocap 10/10
casting 10/10
story and writing 2/10
engine and mechanics 1/10
quest design 1/10
combat 1/10
end of game is garbage

if there is an opposite game to witcher 3 this is it. a ton of time put into just trash, this is a huge win for indie games and startup companies because it shows on a hardcore level that money does not translate into a good production.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: One of a kind. Extraordinary experience. I am looking for words to describe it nicely, which is not easy. In simple terms - graphics photorealistic, humans so detailed and pretty, the landscapes, weather, everything stunning and immersive, sound great, music special and fits so well, the core gameplay loop fun, exciting, challenging, very difficult to get bored with it, while there is still more to discover, to build, to help others and so on. The plot, the story - captivating, intriguing, well told, keeping You wanting to dig deeper, know more, see it thru to the end even if it means not going to sleep at usual time. Actors' performances great, love all the characters really, from main cast to all the NPCs - everyone has a soul of his own and adds to overall immersion and good experience. Now I know there are people, who do not like this game. It is really hard for me to really understand that. Maybe it is because there is not enough destruction here? Some people just like destruction and building, connecting, is not their thing. Hard for me to judge. As it is for me - as a creative person, an artist, a craftsman, builder at heart - this game was one of the very best games I was able to experience and really would wish there were more ambitious projects like this made. So yeah - I liked this game a lot and want to give my thanks to all, who made it come to life <3. Totally recommend playing.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
BUY ON SALE

It has some cool innovative elements, but is very grindy and repetitive. Main story line is OK, but the secondary quests and dialogues are TERRIBLE. 

Core gameplay is trying to find a glitch on map to avoid danger or trying to unstuck your vehicle from an obstacle. The whole time you are just delivering stuff from point A to point B.

I am only continuing to play because I want to know where the main story lines goes.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I honestly knew very little about this game, but due to the year long hype of the release on console's first I figured what the heck, I'll give it a try. 

Absolutely have not been disappointed. I have never played a Kojima game before but I truly love the story play throughout the game. You have goals at every single turn and all play right along with the stories. Very well written and produced and while it's really just a game about being a human freighter delivery cargo, the game mechanics progress and keep adding depth and complexity that really make it a lot of fun.

I highly recommend it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This has the potential to be a great game but in its current state is virtually unplayable due to random crashes and errors.  There is no help on Steam and the developers offer only anodyne solutions.  I have managed to play for twenty hours and enjoyed the game even though I had to replay chapters due to random crashes.  The controls with a controller are somewhat "janky".  The learning curve is steep and the control system complex.
I have a high end rig and the video is outstanding with an excellent frame rate.  My advice would to delay your purchase for a couple of months during which time the developers will hopefully patch the game and who knows...maybe drop the price.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Norman Reedus begged me to go to the bathroom, where he then proceeded to take a stinking dump while an advertisement for his AMC show about bikes played in the foreground. When he was done doing his business, he winked at me and drank a full can of Monster Energy™ drink.
If you want to see acclaimed Mexican filmmaker Guillermo del Toro take a bath with Norman Reedus while hiding from the glare of a black man, this game was tailor-made for you. If that's not going to sell you on it, I don't know what will.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Let me start off by saying that this game is not for everyone in the slightest. There are many repetitive feeling deliveries and aspects about the game. On the other hand though this game is absolutely flawless. The game looks incredible with a beautiful unique environment across the areas of the game. The music that plays throughout the game is in a word perfect. All of the music that plays coincide very well with the point of the game you are at. Now on to the game play, there are certain aspects of the game play that I find to be a little buggy, the vehicles being probably the most buggy. I'm not saying that the vehicles are unusable in the slightest, there are just times were you get your vehicle stuck and the jump feature won't work or occasionally the vehicle will hit a rock or something that just doesn't exist. Enough about the bad stuff. I feel that this game runs super smooth and everything works like a well oiled machine. The gun play in the game I find to be very good and it is really enjoyable to be able to have gunfights in a game you wouldn't think would have any. There are countless little things that just enhance the game and coincide with the lore of the game and just make sense. Now we are finally on to the story. Death Stranding is by far the best story game I have ever played. It keeps you thinking about what everything means and throws curveballs at you constantly throughout the game. There is never a dull moment in the story because you are always doing something that directly has a purpose to the main story. The ending of the game is flawless, it answers every remaining unanswered question you might have and still surprises you with plot twists even when you think you have it all figured out. I strongly suggest that everyone gives this game a try and pays attention to the story, it is an amazing story on how one man came to be and how he in the end helps save the world from mass extinction.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Do not take any of the memes about this game's core design as legitimate criticisms. Yes - you deliver things, but there's enough depth and challenge simply in doing this that it's rewarding and entertaining to accomplish. Death Stranding is as much a pioneering simulator as a delivery simulator, there is a ton of exploration depth and it can take some real thought to navigate difficult terrain. Made a new path you like more than the ones other players have come up with? Lay some equipment down to make traversing it easier. 

I took three hours to make a path tracing the tips of each of the big mountains in a range, then laid equipment down to make traveling that route easier. On the way back, it only took about one hour. Imagine my surprise when I was notified other players had started following my route. With ziplines laid along that path by myself and other players, it now takes less than five minutes to cross that mountain range. There's a real sense of progression in the world, and lots of incentive for exploration and cooperation between players.

Given this is a Kojima game, your enjoyment of the story will improve immensely if you just accept the premise as face value and not question it. The story is esoteric, but a high degree of effort has gone into the writing and it shows. 

I'd say it was worth the full sixty dollars I paid for it at release, and I almost never buy games full price, let alone without first 'demoing' them by less reputable means.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
As Norman Reedus, you must trek the land with your Funky Fetus as a post apocalyptic USP delivery boy, linking the remaining American cities together with all the abandoned packages you find ranging from action figures for a man modelled after a games journalist crates of emergency fuel and emergency wine for a bunch of guys at a wind farm in a forest. The only thing stopping me are oily creatures that are suppose to be the souls of dead people and Troy Baker with a skull face mask.

Out of the 11 hours, I barely made it out of the first area as I was too busy delivering all the fallen and abandoned packages that make me wonder how much of the bunker of the Luden's Fan is filled with toys from before the Death Stranding. A few hours later and now I'm just busy delivering medication to an old man whose only visitors are porters. BT's are still annoying as ever and I wish Kojima would just give us a dedicated "pee your pants" button just to get the stupid BT's to back off.

Also, thanks for every player along the way that helped my journey by building structures so I could rest, cross hard terrains, waters, BTs areas, get cover from Timefall and stay safe and away from the Seam.

I've heard the game was pretty easy so I went Very Hard for my first experience, its not "very hard" but it wasn't so easy for a first playthrough either, a nice challenge that not once left me frustrated.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: One of the best games I've ever played. Amazing soundtrack perfectly accompanies a story rich game that's sure to have you thinking about the next time you can play! The game runs well, even with its incredible graphics. The delivery aspect is downright addicting, that feeling when you finally deposit your 220 lb haul to the wind farm, or when you successfully deposit a body in the incinerator without falling prey to the BT's or MULES, is like no other. The incorporation of likes and the ability to interact with other players structures is just a genius way to connect us, and to keep things fun and interesting. I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants a truly unforgettable experience. Join the global phenomena that is Hideo Kojima's Death Stranding!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Me when this game first came out for PS4 in Nov 2019: "What? This game is just a walking simulator? Haha no way I'll be playing this hot garbage"

Me, months later playing it on PC and actually grasping its concept: Woah! Truly a fantastic experience! Personal GOTY 2020.

The story, the concept, the gameplay, OST and the cutscenes are one experience of a kind! It's true the story starts slow at first but if you're patient, the story will unfold and you'll realize how rich this story is. Heck, I even enjoy the side missions and the very mechanics of being a postman amid an extinction-level event. If you consider yourself a patient person and have played any sims before, then I thoroughly recommend this game. Thank you Kojima for this absolutely great game.

My only, albeit very minor, complaint is that when connected to the chiral network (the game's multiplayer), some player structures already built save you the time of creating your own, making the game a bit too easy at some points.

Now I'm scared of the idea of upside down rainbows.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: It's definitely a different kind of game, but I would still say it's a very good one with fresh story. The gameplay itself can be a tad sluggish, which I understand some people do not prefer, but I realize that it's just part of the challenge the game imposes on the player and I think that it's done very well. The story at times may be difficult to follow but rest assured, like most Kojima written games, answers will reveal themselves with time, patience, and a little bit of brain power. Overall I thoroughly enjoyed all 70+ hours sunk into this experience and I felt that it was money well spent.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game sure is divisive, I'm even fighting internally about my full opinion of the game. I love Hideo Kojima, his previous works are amazing, story, and gameplaywise (talking about the MGS franchise) and after his departure from Konami, in collaboration with Sony, having absolute freedom and some funding into making a game he always envisioned, I thought it could be one of the best games to date, or perhaps reveal Konami's restrains on Kojima was a necessity for the games own good. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

imma be real, it is kinda a walking sim, but not really. It's not fair to the game to just disregard it as such, because there is a lot more to it than just holding down your stick or W key. Navigating through the landscape, the equipment you'll probably need to get to B safely and the most efficiently, do you use a vehicle and potentially having to leave it when you come across an area where it's just impossible to take it with you, dangers, such as MUELS and BTs, the equipment and countermeasures against them, timefall, which will degrade the container that protects the contents inside (the cargo) so unless you prepared against that (which is a total must) you'll be on a timer to get to your location before it starts damaging the cargo. It all plays into getting to B with your cargo in a condition as pristine as possible. It's quite nice for the first 10-20 hours... until you realize you'll be repeating this if you greatly care about potential rewards and getting 5-star ratings, and I've never been a person to care about side stuff. So after a while, I just solely focused on the story.

And I guess I'm just that damn good at the game, but it was just so fucking easy?? Never once in my 40 hours of playtime did I get caught by the BTs or knocked out by the MULES, tho the MULES were the biggest challenge overall, able to immobilize your vehicle and chasing you around until you get out of their territory. But that threat ended momentarily when you unlock nonlethal weapons. As you progress the game and connect the bunkers to the chiral network you'll start unlocking new equipment and weapons. Leveling your rating from bunkers will give you better versions of your stuff. But again, it'll require you to deliver the cargo back and forth, and it gets tedious.

Oh yea, those boss battles... yea, never encountered them unless it was scripted... You see, to go against a "hunter" you have to get caught by a BT, dragging you into the Tar, which is hard to move in and they're trying to drag you into it, if they're successful, they'll drag you around for a bit and a hunter will appear, big motherfuckers. But again, I never encountered them. BTs are insanely easy (at least for me) to avoid, just sneak and hold your breath when too close. Quite disappointing. Something else that was disappointing, the boss battles. Out of 3 times I got up against the Hunters only 1 of them was a good battle, there was more times when I encountered them, but as easy as they are to beat, they're even easier to escape. Can't go into it as it's spoiler territory. I played the game on normal difficulty, perhaps that was the big mistake. But no way am I gonna replay all of it again.

[h1] Story [/h1]

It's decently good. Has a lot of problems, but it's nonetheless good. Going through the game, you have a good handful of characters in the story, all there helping you reconnect America. They're all written well, but as you're a porter out on the field, so you'll be communicating with them through the coms. There'll be very few times where you meet them in person and that's where the character interactions shrine, because that's when Sam finally really talks. As you play the game, you realize Sam is partly, Sam, but also a silent protagonist when you're in control. But you soon come to learn, that's just the character of Sam, a quiet guy. You also learn how the cast are all affected by the Death Stranding in their own unique ways, being a theme in the story.

A reason, if not the only reason we bought this game was because of the man behind it all, Hideo Kojima. Getting this game, that's what I wanted, a Hideo Kojima game, and we certainly got it. Through his career, he's known for Metal Gear Solid, a franchise about soldiers and special operations. Action and stealth, violence, but also philosophy, patriotism and loyalty, a lot of themes and messages tucked in the story of his games, and that's the shit I love, so for Kojima to totally 180, making a game about just walking and avoiding violence was unexpected, but understandable. I understand if Kojima was tired of making games about War when violence it isn't his entire being. This game really did demonstrate who he really is.


So there are some of the thoughts on the game I wanted to put into words. The game really isn't me, it was an interesting experience, but no eye-opener. The game wasn't really able to carry itself in the long run before I just wanted to get to the story's conclusion so I didn't have to carry any more cargo. But you should totally buy it, for what Kojima goodness it has in it, and it does, it's good game, a Hideo Kojima game.

But for the love of god Kojima, as a mega-fan, a dedicated cocksucker of yours, make your next title resemble a more traditional videogame next time around

[h1] 20 likes from Sayobaka <3 [/h1]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
There are a lot of negative reviews for this game out there, is this a bad game? In my opinion, it's not, but I'm also the target audience for this game.

If you are looking for a high intensity game without story do yourself a favour and move on, you won't like this game. This game is touted as a walking simulator because for the most part you'll be delivering packages to various outposts around the world. Most of the challenge here comes from how to get there, whether you walk there, ride a motorcycle or load up a truck. The terrain can be pretty janky to get around and with the rain that damages your stuff, invisible monster fields (BTs), and balancing huge loads on your back which you have to control the tilt of manually it can actually be pretty tricky to get where you need to go initially. I say initially because eventually you can rebuild the road network with some of those materials you are hauling which makes it much easier to get to most areas on the map, reducing the grind considerably. 

One of the shining areas the game has is the story. If you skip through the many cutscenes and story elements of the game it's understandable you likely wouldn't like the game. The world and the characters in it are very well done and the story is interesting, I'm 34 hours in and the game is only now starting to answer many of the questions that have built up from playing the game. Overall I am quite impressed with the game but I can understand why it hasn't done super well because you need a little patience to play this game and it's not all action all the time.

TL;DR Buy if you enjoy story rich games with only minimal action in between.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
What can i say about this game? Is it good? I guess that depends on your point of view. Is it mediocre? I think so. To me, it's one of the most boring games I've played. The story is fragmented, like it came from the mind of a heroin addicted robot with no sense of humanity. I can tell that Kojima really needed Konami to round out his games, because left to his own devices, this mastermind falls flat. From the boring landscapes, the 30 minute long cut-scenes, right down to the GOD awful niche music that for some reason he decided he would make you suffer through instead of allowing you to turn it off. Whomever that band is...it has to be friends with Hideo, because no one else on earth would play that garbage.
I mean...I hate to rip on it like this. I did like the Metal Gear series, ( for the most part). I hate to get all the Kojima fans feeling hurt, but come on guys. This game was thrown at us like a spider monkey throwing his crap at your face. That's exactly what this is though isn't it? It's a pile of after Taco Bell poops. The actors have no real expression on their faces. The dialogue was written by jellyfish it seems. It almost makes me wonder if the development team has ever even met humans at all. Do i recommend this game? Sure...if you absolutely have zero excitement in your life. Maybe if there were literally no other games to choose from. I'm not entirely sure why this game is getting Very Positive on Steam. Maybe they got payed off? Maybe it's a Steam/Kojima collusion? Who knows. I will say this though. Hideo Kojima is know for his akward, nonsensical stories, and over the top characters and mech. In this game however, if this is his true personality, deep doen inside he must have the soul of a wooden plank. This game is lifeless.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's an interesting experience of fetching things for guys you don't really care about. Building roads and ziplines are especially satisfying. But I would recommend you wait for discounts, if possible.

Music is good. Scenery is good. Game rewarding mechanism is satisfying. Battle is enjoyable. Stealth=0, why go stealth? Fight them head on! You get tons of precious resources! (If you get precious cargo on your back and don't want to fight just walk/drive on the road. BTs won't bother you on the road.)

Then the biggest disappointment, story. TBH, the story is Okay, but the story telling is the worst I've seen in a while. I don't feel connected to any of these NPCs and feel quite awkward every time I hear them saying "connect"-ish things. No wonder Sam doesn't want any connection with these guys.

Lockne is cute but you don't get much interaction with her. 

Why? Kojima, Why? You have ONE cute girl but every other NPC gets more cutscences/interactions!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The graphics are amazing. It really lets my video card shine.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
i love games that allow you to wander off into the environment and do your own thing and i recommend this game but maybe once the price has dropped a bit.

it's not true exploration as there is not a great amount to see or find if you are not completing a delivery mission in the story. the environment looks amazing but you are always quite close to a base and it just doesn't feel like the scale is right for a journey across the entire US.

and while the story is very interesting, it's only in the last 10% of the game where so much is finally revealed, and i mean a LOT of connections are finally defined. it would have been much better to have big reveals all along the journey so you could in fact mistake what was happening until the next reveal.

Playing online is both fun and also makes the world seem less post-disaster. there are too many interactions with other players in terms of likes and structures. they needed to make it more sparse so that when you do find a player bridge or storage unit, it feels more important.

but it's a great game. now we need DLC with Fragile as the protagonist.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
An incredible game that I thought would just be delivery simulator, but there's so many components and details that complete this game. I bought this thinking it would be relaxing, but it turns out to be pretty stress inducing. The gunfights, sneaking, cutscenes, the atmosphere, the freedom, and the main characters are amazing.  Only one or two minor characters are kind of weird or awkward. Great game, and refreshingly innovative among all the new, same games.

Completed the game at 80 hours, and wow the finale is absolutely beautiful. I think this masterpiece truly shines at the very end.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: A work of art deserving of Game of the Year.  An absolute masterpiece in my book.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
At first, I didn't think this would be a game for me. I've seen gameplay from when it first came out on PS4, and it was rather different from my usual preference (JRPG, Classic RPG, etc). Despite this, I decided to give it a shot and I've been hooked ever since. The story, while confusing, is leaving me with enough intrigue to want to see it through. The controls, albeit frustrating at times, are engaging and keep me focused. 

I am still playing through the game, but it's already something I'd recommend. It's different, but worth a try.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I was ready to give this a chance. When this came out there were come collision issues, especially with vehicles, and I thought they weeded them out before bringing them to PC after almost a year. Not only are the issues not fixed, you're paying a new game price, for an old game that's buggy as all get out. What drew the line in the sand for me was I finally got my first vehicle, loaded it all up, got to the first river crossing, was a short cross in very shallow water. started crossing it, apparently hit a tiny rock under the water, beached it and immediately ran out of battery. Its walking simulator for a reason. even if it dangles vehicles in your face, they will take them right away with shotty hit boxes and garbage controls. Do not recommend.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This might be my new favourite game. I don't remember the last time a game got me so hooked on the story like Death Stranding did, so much so that everyday I would be like "just one more delivery" and would end up playing for two more hours, then rinse and repeat the next day.
Now, even with a brilliant narrative like this, I don't think I would be this invested if the gameplay was lacking or barely ok. That's so not the case with this game. At first sight it might look repetitive and it might be at some points, but you have so much to work around with like vehicles and structures and upgrades, so much you can pause deliveries to pursue instead like creating better routing for navigating the terrain, that nothing ever makes you feel like you're wasting time. Everything in this game is rewarding. (Except driving bikes. Curse the man who programmed those.)

Do yourself a favour and play Death Stranding if you can. I promise you've never seen anything like it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Great gameplay if you enjoy exploring. Amazing acting and a really interesting story. When i first started playing it felt weird to carry a BB on my chest but even tho nor Sam or BB are the talking type you really see the connection growing.

The gameplay loop is basically an hour or more of you delivering orders and contributing to the world and then there's usually a good 5 to 10 minutes of story/cutscene's. There's also story being told to you as your moving sometimes but those are here and there.

Either you're gonna love it or hate it. It's a long game and slow moving game but it unravels itself beautifully and because it's not super fast you really get to enjoy and experience everything to the fullest.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
FedEx in Haunted Iceland, the game.

Definitely not a game for everyone, but it's the most unique and rewarding gaming experience I've had in years. Stick through the first 10 hours. The game forces you to walk before you can run, but the heights you'll reach later make it worth it.

The story and dialogue at times felt like a bad movie that takes itself a little too seriously, but still in an enjoyable way as long as you're willing to laugh it off. The world building, however, is excellent. Really great setting. And the gameplay is amazing. I've spent so many extra hours with the game after I beat it, just improving my infrastructure and helping out other porters by upgrading their stuff. It feels like an asynchronous minecraft server.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
STORY - Long story short, you're a UPS delivery man in a post apocalyptic setting. The story is by far the best thing about this game, though the pacing could be better in the beginning where it feels like its dropping too much information on the player at once, however, all questions you may have are answered by the time you complete this 25+ hour story (or longer if you dont rush main missions like me). Either way it makes the experience worth it for the story alone.

GAMEPLAY - The gameplay itself is a little tedious and can become very monotonous at certain points in the story. The building concept is a great idea, allowing you to build your own bridges, ladders, vehicles, etc. to allow you to roam the massive landscape easier, even allowing some structures from other players to end up in your session for you to enjoy. Other concepts such as "the weight you carry" vs. the landscape are interesting at first, but just annoying in the long run. It essentially forces you to take some areas slow in a world that is already expansive enough as is. 

PROS - 
My personal favorite thing about this game are the random music cues that can happen during deliveries. You are strolling along on a mountain carrying goods to the next delivery area and suddenly you have one of many fantastic songs from this games soundtrack play to make your journey even better. 

The story is one of the best in recent years

The soundtrack is absolutely amazing, I only wish it played songs more often during deliveries

The combat (later on in the game anyways) is fun and adds a new layer to your delivery strategies

Buildings and other player structures add to the monotony of the gameplay

CONS - 
The gameplay, they don't call this game "walking simulator" for nothing. Its what you do for 75% of the game and the other 25% is watching the story unfold through several hours worth of cutscenes

The pacing at the beginning of the game can be duanting for some, as the game gives lots of information within a short time span
 
The vehicles are a bit rough to handle off the roads and especially in the mountains where they're borderline undrivable

Enemy encounters, mainly a ghost-like enemy called a "BT", are interesting and creepy at first, but the effect wears thin after the first five encounters

VERDICT - 8/10 overall, with most of the points coming from the story and soundtrack alone

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Pros:

Tightly woven story for the most part, great mocap and acting from all the cast, satisfying ending

One of the better looking games with excellent worldbuilding and landscapes

Something new in gaming, not just the same old copy pasted Ubisoft / Bethesda / Rockstar BS

Cons:

Gameplay feels bland after 20h, ziplines way too cheap and OP

Game drags on for far too long in the middle

A fairly pretentious game that thinks too smartly of itself, with ads plastered all over and Kojima's name slapped all around from the cover to the credits

Not everyone cup of tea, since it's pretty much a glorified walking simulator for 30h of the game, with two feature films at the beginning and end. I think the only appeal of the game in the post-COVID world is the concept of a world ravaged by an unknown force, with deliverymen being hailed as heroes in society for delivering packages. Story was decent enough to make me want to finish it at the very least, but much balancing is needed between the ziplines, lategame weapons, and roads. I respect Kojima for having made this game into existence as a niche pick for those of us tired of getting yelled at by randoms in online games, and just want to build bridges to help unknown strangers, 4/5
