review:
Super smooth and fluid gameplay, graphics are top notch, soundtrack is great, story seems full of wtf moments but very solid so far.... And while it's not Metal Gear, you certainly get some moments to practice the basics of CQC by roping up some MULEs and sneaking around some camps to steal back some stuff. It's not a combat focused game, but honestly...? That's a nice change of pace. It's very nice to kick back and chill, smash that like button on literally every structure another player has left for you, and just vibe with the music and make some deliveries.

Tl:dr- If you like Hideo Kojima's work and don't expect Metal Gear, this is a game for you.

review: Starting off this game was interesting and seemed cool. I am playing this on a pc and I like the story but, man I tell you idk how many times the game has showed an error and kicked me out then I lost all my progress since my last auto save. Then don't even get started on how Horrible it is trying to drive a truck or motorcycle  around the map especially mountain area or snow. I get it that its not sopose to be great but man it is so aggravating when you make it half way up a mountain or rocky area then you try to turn and the vehicle just hauls ass in a different direction or wont go the way you trying to go. I like the game but small things add up so I would not recommend for that reason. Needs to be worked on.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Honestly I was rather nervous and almost didn't buy it despite being a Kojima fan over the ages. Some of the reviews I'd read prior to the steam launch left me wondering if we even played the same game. Or rather, it felt like they barely even finished the tutorial before writing about it. The game is kinda long, either that or I just took the scenic route every trip I made. Just doing the primary missions with 0 cutscene skips outside of run of the mill tasks was nearly 40+ hours of content. 

Before we continue, I'll just stop and say that yes: You deliver. That's your job, that's the premise of the game, if you're expecting to not be apocalypse amazon prime I'd imagine you didn't look into Death Stranding very much prior to reading this. It has atmosphere and story, the quests are not the meat of the world but rather the world itself. Funnily enough, just getting from A to B has more substance than most things on market these days though; So quit whining, pick up your shit and get moving.

Controlling the character and the mechanics take some getting used to, but the balance mechanic has both boons and banes to it in terms of use vs risk. Once you get the hang of it you'll be scaling cliffs like a goat and doing things with the vehicles your beginner self would have thought impossible.

Combat is interesting and feels rather responsive, often times I was able to switch up strategies and weapon types without feeling too outgunned. {Besides, Sam has fists of iron.} Weapons have enough variety to cover every situation I encountered and left me satisfied, expecially in the mix of all the useful terrain gear and fun gadgets.

I liked the story, had great fun with the gameplay and wonderful scenery, loved the characters and actors, and genuinely will be revisiting it often over the years I'm sure.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] Post-Apocalyptic US Postal Service Simulator [/h1]
[b] I would say all the pros and cons you hear of the game are very correct but I found the game very enjoyable and this was my experience [/b]
I played on normal and will say it took me a while to get use to the mechanics and combat of the game especially when you don't start out with pretty much nothing in the means of offense or buildings. I found myself exploring more in the initial area and found it interesting to see how people played based off of the buildings and signs they left behind. once you start unlocking more items and buildings then the game gets relatively easier to progress. when I moved on to the next area and unlocked roads that was my time and resource sink early game. I will say it took time but completing it before moving on in the story was very helpful and progressing thru the story a breeze. I completed at least 80% of the road by myself and the rest with other players but everyone seemed to enjoy the trail left behind from following the road instead of the road itself. even tho my goal was the road and progressing thru the story I still took time to listen to the music playing when going thru scenic areas, making runs to go floating carrier boarding, helping out NPC porters by stalking them and laying down buildings to make their life easier for fun. my tip for the road especially for resource gathering is resource deliveries helps but channeling your inner solid snake and raiding mule/terrorist camps helps a whole lot also fighting BTS for those crys-tals when I unlocked the grenade launcher that was my favorite weapon to use for those purposes. As for the story goes it pays off at the very end where everything comes to light and I will say its an investment of your time but to me it feel like a good investment and rewarding to see it to the very end but that is my own opinion.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]Obligatory Joke About Being Able To Fight Your Enemies By Pis*ing On Them[/h1]
I ran out of blood grenades, so I p*ssed on a giant oily squid monster to try and kill it but I ended up dying because I couldn't stop laughing.

Kojima you beautiful b*stard.

[h1]A Brief Review[/h1]
Pis* jokes aside, Death Stranding is fun and it kept me hooked until the very end. It's got a fantastic story, amazing world building, and beautiful motion-capture graphics. The characters are animated beautifully by their respective actors with Mads Mikkelsen as Cliff demonstrating what is in my opinion, one of the best portrayals of a villain in all of gaming (You'll really wanna see where his story goes). 

The gameplay may be boring to some but if you have Spotify open and put on your favorite playlist you'll enjoy it much more. There is a system where you manage your cargo and how it affects your balance but there's a function that has the game auto-arrange it for you to lessen your cargo's effect on your balance. If you keep losing your balance and falling just hold down the right and left mouse buttons as you walk and you won't fall (It's slower but much more efficient). You can get over encumbered as well but it gets nullified pretty early on with a certain item that you get. If you want to get around the world faster, then you can always take a bike (I highly recommend this in the [spoiler]Mountain[/spoiler] Region). 

There are also a few stealth sections with BTs (Beached Things), invisible ghosts that you can spot with your BB (Bridge Baby). You have to hold your breath when you're near them and you can get through them with some patience. They get much easier later on when you get better weapons though.

The big feature of Death Stranding is the Chiral Network, a mechanic which allows you to see other player's structures (ladders, climbing anchors, bridges, roads, etc...) and also allows them to see your structures. You can like people's structures to appreciate them and give them points which increase their level and give them extra abilities as they play. It also feels very gratifying when you see that other people used your structures and liked them as well. You also have the ability to entrust some cargo that you need to deliver to other players so that they can finish the job (they can do the same to you), however, this feature is entirely optional, so you're not obligated to deliver anyone else's lost or entrusted cargo.

The game has got a great soundtrack as well which unfortunately only plays at specific moments throughout your journey with you not being able to listen to it while travelling, however, when you rest in your private room you are given the choice to listen to music. This isn't much of a problem though since the whole soundtrack is on Spotify (see link below):

505 games did an excellent job optimizing the game because I didn't encounter any bugs and had only a few FPS dips throughout the game. Bravo.

Overall, the game is really solid and I highly recommend checking it out. If you're not having fun at first, wait until you get to the [spoiler]Central[/spoiler] Region which is when the game really picks up (it's about 8 hours in). I applaud both Kojima Productions and 505 Games for bringing an excellent game to life, and I also applaud Sony for allowing Hideo Kojima to make the game he wanted without any interference on their part, something unfortunately rare in this industry.

[h1]Spotify Soundtracks:[/h1]
[b]Death Stranding (Original Score)[/b] 
[b](Songs made specifically for the game):[/b]
https://open.spotify.com/album/5e4LO7QzLLN6sSs9RlaawU?si=WIkb86W5Rcq5zJGdntEkqQ

[b]Death Stranding (Songs from the Video Game)[/b] 
[b](Licensed songs included in the game):[/b]
https://open.spotify.com/album/1H5k5QgsFjnMPzlXfWq8QH?si=Kxqdk9jNTi6qoe_oIR8kRw

I get the "worker access violation" error at random which crashes the game to desktop losing ALL your progress since the last save. And when the game doesn't crash you get these random ghost double presses if you are using an xbox one wireless controller.
I have tried everything suggested (under-clocking GPU, clean driver, vc++ and game installs etc)  nothing helps, seems like 505 doesn't know how to code on PC since they can't fix these bugs.

9900k
1080ti
96GB RAM

Game installed on NVME SSD

I think I should try to play this again when and IF they update it to see if it's fixed. For now I feel like I wasted my money.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Loved the game. It's unique gameplay, great visual style and gripping story and atmosphere absorbed me so much, that I pretty much only stopped playing for sleep, food and work.

I'm not a huge kojima fan (MGS V was his only game I really played) and not that much of a story fan in games. Usually I play multiplayer or games with little story. But death stranding combined gameplay and story really good. And if there was a huge dump of cutscenes and story it felt like you earned it and wanted to finally get to know the world better.

It's... different. Keeps you invested. Every time you come close to getting bored by the gameplay loop it introduced something new. Every time you had enough of sidequests and delivering it pulled you back in with story and action. And when you felt like chilling you made a hike across the mountains and watched the snowflakes fall.

It's not perfect. But I'll be damned if it's not close to it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Can't believe how awful this game is, I really don't understand all the positive review. Maybe the game gets better? I've played for about 5 hours and am sad I missed the refund window. The story is completely nonsensical (again, maybe things get better later) and is explained through very long cutscenes. These look good, but since you have no idea what's going on, you'll be hard pressed to pay attention. I like narrative-based games, but this just felt like absolute nonsense, that wasn't going anywhere in the first 5 hours. 

Then the gameplay... honestly there almost isn't any. This game is about walking and moving random packages from point a to point b. There is no real danger or challenge, and before you know it the walking part is over and you're looking at a long random cutscene again. 

I liked two things about this game: the graphics are great (faces, animations and environment all look good) and I liked the community aspect, where players can leave messages or helpful artifacts in the world for other (random) players. This is a singleplayer game though. 

Ultimately those few strong points don't save this game. After even 30 minutes I was asking myself "why am I doing this and wasting my time?". I persevered for a few more hours but things did not get better (they got much worse) and I decided to give up. Probably I "just don't get it" but this game is a total waste of time and money.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
You know...I laughed at the E3 trailer when it was revealed, I thought Hideo had finally lost his marbles. I thought who wants a game where you walk around delivering packages. However I was bored, so I bought it, thought it'll be a good laugh and maybe a benchmark.

I didn't know what I was in for.

Well, I'm not laughing now. The game was nothing, I repeat, NOTHING like I thought it was going to be just from watching trailers. In a good way.

I did have 3-4 bugs over the entire course of the game where I would load in wrong, I would be walking in purgatory instead of floating to find my body, or I'd get a crash to desktop, but the auto-save is pretty aggressive so I never found myself in an overwhelming setback.

8/10 for the bugs making me reload and break my immersion. I'd personally say a perfect price point all considered is right around $45, but I'd pay $60 again.

I look forward to revisiting this for a second play-through.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Such a beautiful, well-written story from Kojima and his team. The conclusion is extremely satisfying and as the credits rolled I was happy knowing all of my questions and then some were answered. DS also boasts a strong cast of main characters with equally strong performances from some great actors. Gameplay is fun and addicting and the constant evolution of the methods you use to deliver packages works really well. Through my 90 hour playthrough it really only started to get a bit tedious towards the end.

Phenomenal experience and one that I highly recommend you try. Videos of gameplay do not do it justice; it's a boring watch but a very addicting play.

9/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Great Graphics, Hideo Kojima game, quite Unique

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Here it goes

Pro's
The overall game is absolutely stunning. Over 120 hours played. Graphics are amazing (RTX 2070super)
Story is 100% Kojima and a breath of fresh air although his recurrent use of the deathmask (metal gear) is a bit cheap.

Con's
While people say it's a walking simulator, which it is not, it's definitaly not a driving simulator. The bike is kinda ok, but the car is a disaster. Doesn't break, doesn't do slopes well, wheels not spinning when you throttle, wheels still spinning when you break. Jumping the car is bad, when stuck with the front wheels it should jump the front wheels, etc.. So, stay away from cars. Use ziplines.

Likes.
If you are unlucky as I was being on a server with too many chinese, they will ruin the game. They don't work at building roads or zip lines but focus on likes. I have found a chinese bridge near every location which serves no function at all. Some of these useless bridges have over 200.000 likes while strategically placed bridges, generators etc barely reach 1.000.
They start building the pavers by putting half the amount of materials in it so their name show up. I practically have build the entire road on the map.
I have seen ziplines built just outside of range or not reachable due to an obstacle. A lonely zipline had over 100.000 likes and was absolutely unusable.
After one day playing after launch there was one guy with 225 legendary deliveries. Just like on the ark servers, they cheat and ruin games.
I can go on for hours but that wouldn't be fair to the game designers.

I still had fun and hope Kojima makes a space game next. With no Chinese if possible.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Played for 80 minutes, almost every one of those was a cutscene, very boring ones at that with only a few that stood out. The celebrities cameos are grating and the travel, while gorgeous and somewhat interesting quickly gets old and I have a funny feeling the exposition dumps and janky movement will only become more annoying as I go.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I've played this game on PS4 for about 200 hours and I bought it for PC on the day it came out. Another one of my favourite games, mainly due to the storyline. The storyline and cutscenes are time consuming but a masterpiece nonetheless, in typical Hideo Kojima fashion. If you're a fan of Hideo Kojima games, such as the Metal Gear Solid Series then this game should be of interest to you.

[b] Pros: [/b]
 - Amazing Storyline (not for everyone though)
 - Online Aspect of the game encourages you to help others in their games and in turn others may help you in very beneficial ways, such as building structures to help you traverse the environment.
 - Progression throughout the game is rewarding and hard jobs are worth doing in most cases.
 - Realistic Postman simulation

[b] Cons: [/b]
 - Walking Simulator (yet somehow still interested)
 - Long cutscenes and a lot of information to take in that can go over your head.
 - Missions definitely become tedious at times, going back and forth between places.

I can't think of many pros and cons for the game to be completely honest but I enjoyed the game and I found myself binging it quite often. My favourite thing about the game is probably the fact that as Hideo intended, the game is an attempt to reunite players all around the world to reconnect and help each other, whilst not physically or verbally interacting with such players, the game gives me a positive feeling and even a sense of purpose at times.

All in all, good game, I'm a massive fan of Hideo Kojima and I think he's pretty brave for making a game such as this considering Silent Hills was cancelled to make this. A lot of people scrutinise this game and find it lacklustre but it's not everyone's cup of tea and if they aren't familiar with Hideo Kojima's work then I'm not too surprised.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I wholeheartedly recommend this game with the reservation to know what you are getting into. The game is slow, it takes around 10 hours to really get going (though it did capture me from the start).

The main gameplay loop is trying to get cargo from point a to point b safe and sound. You have to traverse rough terrain and the game simulates center of gravity, momentum and you can slip on uneven terrain. You have to make it through areas with people who wanna take your cargo and areas of spooky ghosts. You can use ladders, ropes and vehicles and build structures and roads to help you on your way. All structures, equipment and cargo you build and/or leave behind will appear in other people's games and their stuff shows up on yours.

The story is very Kojima. It's weird, complicated and at times campy. Some of the names and lines are really cheesy. Despite that, I found the story and the characters really captivating.

Now the pc port does have some issues:
- I experienced some major graphical glitches first time playing, I managed to fix this with just updating my GPU drivers.
- The game requires a CPU with AVX, so make sure your CPU supports that.
- The graphics options for the game are quite limited for a pc game.

TL;DR:
Walking sim with mechanics to make walking interesting. Help others help you help us all. Weird, cheesy and wonderful story. Make sure your cpu supports AVX. Do your research before buying. I love this game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Pros: 
~you're always playing with other people, getting items and structures, even if you can't see them you can say hello with 5. 
~Story made me cry.
~Soundtrack and visuals were amazing .
~Zip-Lines, even thought they would never connect when I would find one. 
~This game looks amazing even on a GTX 970.
~When this game has a scene, you're dropped into it and the only thing that exists at that moment is you and the scene. I got that feeling a lot and it's really hard to find that in a video game. 
~Every boss fight was amazing and I loved every one of them. 
~Game-play is amazing and every time I get out of a stupid BT field and the music cuts in I would just take in the scenery and enjoy the moment, you get a lot of that in this game. 
~The first couple hours are a roller coaster of fun scenes and visuals and introduction. 
~This is PC, there will be mods.

Cons:
~Fuck the Junk Collector and his story-line, the acting was the worst and the only time I was pulled out of the game.
~I had a lighting graphical issue but i'm on a 970.
~Story was kinda long but well worth it by the end. 
~It dumps a lot of exposition at the end so be prepared to stick through after you go to the beach for the final time for like 2 hours. 
~vehicles are kinda bad but they can also be really good at times. you could fix this with a mod. 

Even with those cons I would give this game a 5/5 the story carried too hard.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
When I initially wrote my review I was only a few hours in.  The 1/2 of the game is kind of entertaining in an OCD kind of way.  Wanting to get 5 stars, or at least 4, so you can get the upgraded items.  The story is the best part of the game.  Too bad there aren't more of them.  The 1/3 of the game is slow, the 2/3 of the game picks up in story and in action,  but the final third of the game is where the game shines.  And the way they make it an "online" game but never seeing others in unique.  The "walking simulator" is only a small portion of the game.  You get a bike and a truck relatively soon into the game.  

The fights with BTs are easy but fun.  The gun fights can be challenging til you realize all you have to do is hit and run.   I still really enjoyed the battles though, especially when there is 2-4 BTs popping up all over the place.  

The story is great, though a bit confusing.  Its kind of on some Inception type ****.  Nothing makes sense until the end.  I'm watching the credits roll and still scratching my head on some stuff though.  One of those things I will have to google to see what everything I didn't catch means.  

There is some good music in the game, but you will never hear it.  I don't understanding why they have all these tunes in the game but never play them except for like 3 seconds when you're on a mountain 30 seconds from a city where it will stop.

Overall I really liked this game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is a strange experience that's for sure that. It's definitely a walking simulator. There is no question that the majority of this game is exploring the post apocalyptic USA by foot. However, if you chose to this game can be so much more than a walking simulator with a decent story attached. You can dedicate hours into building structures creating a network of roads bridges recharge stations and pit stops to help other players through the game. You can attempt to infiltrate MULE territory to reclaim lost cargo steal their vehicles and get out with more than what you came in with. You can go BT hunting filling your inventory with blood bags and guns to or just go out there with sneaking around with your cufflinks.
The boss fights are pretty good, being caught by a BT when you are unprepared or under prepared is a punishing and devastating experience. And when you load up too much you are punished for your hubris. 
The Vehicles a good way to get around but you can go more places by foot and until you build enough structures vehicles can be a pain to lug around. 
The walking around and shifting your weight mechanic is a little jank and doesn't feel like it works all the time but maybe that's what I get for stacking a tower of cargo on my back.

It starts off slow but man when you get in the action it's really something else and the landscape is just stunning and between being chased by Bts and tripping over a rock and loose all of my cargo if I'm not careful enough it gives a hard but fun challenge. I recommend this game if you want a good time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is not for everyone.  If you enjoy a methodical but relaxing and intriguing game this is for you.  I find myself constantly amazed at the small detail and nuance of the game mechanics but it's not always a pro.  The game is very much enjoyable but small cut-scenes tend to slowly erode your sanity after you see the again and again.  The first time you watch Sam (Norman Reedus) take shower or drink a Monster it's cool; the fifteenth time? not so much.  The game does a exceptional job at making you feel apart of something bigger while also making you feel small in the grand scheme.  You are rebuilding America quite literally and due to the current political climate/global pandemic this message feels more potent.  Whether you are from America or and other nation there is something powerful about humans coming together to surmount something so monumental.  You are just a cog but, the wheels would not turn without you,

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm just going to share my honest opinions about this game.

I love the story, characters, visuals, UI, the game is smooth as butter. I have 0 performance issues and overall this is an extremely well done port from what I can see, if you have already played and enjoyed this game then it's worth picking up on PC if that's what you're into. 

That being said, this game feels like a chore, because I play it to get to the story and the characters and learn more about the world. The setting is so interesting and you want to know more, that it keeps you somewhat motivated to play the game. If not for that, I feel that this game would be a total failure. The gameplay loop does not captivate me or keep me even remotely interested. You feel pretty helpless against the enemies, even though you can dispatch enemies pretty easily most of the time. They are not super hard, even the BT's don't stand a chance if you just run away from them. Not saying that's the optimal strategy, but it works. So you're walking nearly everywhere, delivering packages on foot. That's the game, and if you're expecting more than that, I would say don't play this game, because at it's core this is a walking simulator. It's a damn good walking simulator, but a walking simulator. 

Another thing that I just personally get annoyed with in this game, is when I actually am in the mood to deliver packages and mellow out for a while, it constantly interrupts your play with tutorials, messages, guys talking to you, guys warning you, when you get a new item everyone has to explain what it does. Sometimes they are incredibly lengthy in their explanation of a mission, even though it's really not that complicated what you're doing most of the time. Sometimes characters will literally have nearly the same conversations that you just had with a previous character about a mission or item. It can actually be very annoying. 

And at the end of the day, your goal is to deliver packages safely to their location, and build roads and other items to assist others and yourself for the next journey. It's not for me. I feel like this game is missing something very important that would make it much more interesting for me, I don't think it's combat.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]Great Game so far ( Currently trying to 100 percent the game)[/h1]
[b]!Warning This game is not for everyone![/b] 
(Don't buy the game if your gonna whine like a ***** about the Gameplay and how the game is a walking simulator)

[list][b]Pro's[/b]
 [*]Progression feels good and exciting especially when you get new gear or equipment
 [*]Story Is great so far
 [*]Acting is 10/10
 [*]Game is very Immersive
 [*]Always something new to discover
 [*]Nice little valve Easter eggs
 [*]It has nice pacing and can be a pretty chill game ,but  can have exciting moments in the game that get your heart racing(No Spoilers)
 [*]Love the monster sponsorship
 [*]Love the dark souls like soap stone multiplayer that adds depth and cooperation to the game
 [*]Love the fact you use your feces, urine and blood as weapons against the BT's
 [*]I love my BB unit
 [*] Graphics are pretty great except when they're not(See below for what I'm talking about)
 [*] Boss battle's are amazing and cool
 [*]Music is great
 [*]Love the fourth wall breaking by Norman Reedus in Shelter
 [*]Characters are well written 
 [*]World is great
[/list]
[list][b]Con's[/b]
 [*]You have to  immerse yourself to the enjoy game 
 [*]Game is kinda of buggy
 [*] texture glitches happen to me all the time which break my game and force me to restart my game to fix any texture glitches(Only way to save is inside a shelter)
 [*]Too many Cut Scenes and gets repetitive after a while (You can skip them)
 [*]Game runs fine and all but for my rig it's kinda disappointing that it can't run my native resolution with it capped at 120 fps (I have 2080 ti and i7 8700k)
 [*]Mules are a little lack luster and suck except in super large droves 
 [*] Game gets repetitive
 [*]Weird ad placement can break immersion
 [*]Linear Story
 [*]Game can get grindy

[/list]

review:
Definitely not for everyone, but i have found significant enjoyment out of it. If you like unique-esoteric/kind-of-boring game play similar to what is seen in walking simulators and difficult uncompromising titles like pathologic and pathologic 2, then you may enjoy this experience as well. 

Of course, looking at the other steam reviews is leading me to believe that although initial perception was rather divided, the people who would actually like this type game have gradually been drawn to it over time. The hype train leading up to this game's release was probably its biggest source of negative press. With what people expected it to be, i can't say that they were necessarily wrong to criticize in the ways they did.

review:
Having spent 40 hours in this game, I decided to give it a thumb down.

For the first 10 hours of the game, I liked it. The graphic is good, and the control is kinda like Metal Gear.

But the missions started becoming repetitive right after that (all missions are basically carrying xxx from A to B.) 
The maps are large, but there is little reward exploring them.
The storytelling is also flawed. The NPCs in the game talk way too much (there is a NPC called "Deadman" in this game, he is supposed to be a friend, but his meaningless blabbering just makes me want to punch him in the face.)

In summary, I bought this game expecting an involving adventure. I'm disappointed.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Positves =

- Graphics are fantastic

- The game runs very well, great PC version (High fps and no crashes)

- The atmosphere is awesome

- The gameplay is relaxing to me (Finding the best way up big mountains, doing deliveries, etc.)

- Online aspects are great, you can build ladders, ropes, bridges and all kinds of things for others to use!

- Good voice acting

- Love the vehicles



Negatives =

- Combat that is here is not that great (Thankfully you don't have to do a crazy amount if you don't want)

-The game might just not be for some people, what I find relaxing others might find boring 

- Writing is a mixed bag, the overall idea for the story is very good and there are some great characters but Kojima stumbles overall in this department, trying to be David Lynch a little to much (Who is one of my favorite directors ever), but in the end some of the strange Lynchian style stuff feels forced at times.


A unique game that at times reminds me of ripping around in the forest and mountains of BC as a youngster. The missions to drop off stuff is very relaxing, building things to help other players feels very satisfying, the graphics are great and it runs very well. Give this game a go if the positives sound good to you, now I have some mountains to climb, stuff to deliver and some bridges/ladders to build for other players! I actually enjoy it more than Kojima's last MGS game!

Some are reporting performance issues but at least in my case everything ran without a hitch on a gaming laptop a few years old with a mobile GTX 1070. YMMV

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I had almost no expectations for this game when I started but it has honestly turned out to be one of my favorite games.

This game is definitely like no other game I have ever seen at a AAA level. The soundtrack is amazing and I'm really annoyed that you do not hear it enough. You should have a music player for when you are out in the world. the gameplay is repetitive but is strangely addictive. From the surface it may look like an "amazon delivery" the game but that is not the whole truth. The game has elements of combat, stealth, cargo management and also small glimpses of "horror".

Everything fits so well and the atmosphere in the world feels convincing. The game looks very good but what new game does not? However, I have never taken this many screenshots in a game I played. the included Photomode is pretty good and fun to play around with

The story and characters are very interesting and make the game fun to play. You are always curious about what will happen next. The large group of actors does a great job of being a part of the world. Also some fun easter eggs.

The fact that you exist in the same world as other players and see how they affect your world by building equipment, buildings or leaving vehicles for you is very cool. You get the feeling that you belong to something bigger in the world.

But no game is perfect. Even though the game runs very well, especially with DLSS, it has crashed a number of times. You have no music player in the world and the threat from BTs disappears quite quickly.

This is definitely a game that is not for everyone but I think everyone should at least try it. The first 2 hours do not give the game a real chance. But when the story starts to get started and the world opens up, it gets better.

This game on this scale would not have existed without kojima and no one can take that away from him!

Overall 9/10 would play again.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game isn't for everyone granted, and Kojima's stories and name translations are always a little odd.  but at the core, this game is actually really impressive and fun.  Those calling it a walking simulator probably haven't given it enough time to open up, the game allows you to solve the issues of deliver any number of ways.  Want to put a couple hundred pounds on your back, and slog through rough terrain, that's up to you.  Or do you want to build a truck, and the roads, bridges, and power system to do that, or build a series of zip-lines, that take you 300 meters a hop, all are valid.  But its hardly a walking simulator.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A surreal futuristic science fiction spiritual experience about the connections we all have as human beings and the infinite ways we strive to our benefit and extreme detriment to keep them to the point of illusions being as real as our flesh and blood lives bringing the question where do things end. Is life visual and do the dead hunger for this in their darkness absolute?

Graphics are a photo realistic dreamy masterpiece. Its as if I could reach out and actually touch the gorgeous lush landscape and the firm softness and the muscular physiques living, moving before me. Animations are detailed matching up with the miraculous ultra realistic physics where I have to balance my character to keep him from falling over where his delivery packages will take different degrees of damage effecting his pay.

User interface is intricate with many layers of depth. From the fantastic quality of life camera views which allow one to experience the game from a first person view in compass mode to the very flexible third person view which feels very natural and enhances the realism of the physics to the scanners which allow me to detect resources, abandoned lost cargo deliveries, enemies in the environment etc along with the different maps everything is done in a very professional high level of function respecting the intelligence of the player to explore and figure it all out while giving a tight comforting grip of hand holding guidance which makes all these intricate systems a joy to use and experiment with where I never felt lost or frustrated.

Music and sound effects are beyond description in their excellence. All I can is when playing DEATH STRANDING I am not in my room but in another world familiar yet alien like a glimpse into a future not quite here. A deja vu moment in reverse.

Story is thus far very enjoyable where I am feeling emotionally invested in the outcome of things from making deliveries which can be very peaceful and tranquil traveling along the uncanny valley of realism that is the mountains and nature of DEATH STRANDING to terrifying throbbing with tension encounters with threats I come across where reality becomes transfigured into a disjointed jumbled nightmare of unleashed insanity to talking with inspiring charismatic characters one feels a certain bond with almost right away as they communicate with a natural lifelike authenticity not seen in many games. 

DEATH STRANDING, BUY IT! PLAY IT! Enter a mystical futuristic game world where reality and fantasy fuse into a indistinguishable oneness of creative gaming artistic excellence pulsing with passionate craftsmanship flowing with the breathe of life!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Amazing presentation, very unique I must say. A very well rewarding game, no hand holding, gives you tools to make your life in-game easier as a "Deliverer", for you and for other porters. Its all up to you how you want traverse from point A to B. 

Point of advise - Don't rush thru the main game story. Try to invest little time and create your own unique way to traverse, whether its contributing on creating Highways or Ziplines or ploting easy routes .

Climbing mechanics felt off, some times I felt buggy like standing on a platform in air, and in some areas you  get stuck behind a 1 feet boulder, making AI of the player dumb unable to step up and move thru.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I understand that this is a sort of divisive game to people, but I'll try and explain why I enjoy it so much in the most succinct way I can.

If you really wanted to reduce this game down to a snappy descriptor then "walking simulator" would make sense, but I don't think that term does it enough justice. A lot of walking simulators, leaving out how good/not good they are, are extremely passive experiences: The Vanishing of Ethan Carter for instance, or Dear Esther - both games that I absolutely adore and have revisited many times, consist of a gameplay loop where, for the most part, you can hold "W" from start to finish to get this gist of the story and experience most of what there is to do. Death Stranding really diverges from this in an important way in that, since the game is first and foremost about traversal, the ACT of traversal has been made integral to the experience of the game. As you move shipments and materials across the broken American landscape you aren't just holding "W" to go from point A to point B... you're having to put a lot of thought into how you want to get from point A to point B, and not in the same that you might consider traversal in other open world games - there's a group of bandits here, an enemy encampment there, etc, though all of those things ARE factors in Death Stranding - it comes down "oh there's a rock field this way that'll make it really hard to maintain my balance, and the rough terrian might lead my shoes to degrade too rapidly, maybe I should take another path thats a big longer but easier to navigate." In this way I think that the America represented in Death Stranding is one of the more purposefully thoughtout game worlds in recent memory, because every gameplay instance requires you to consider in depth the terrain you will encounter, the rivers, the estuaries, the mountain ranges, the cliffs, the muddy river banks, etc, as you determine how you want to reach your destination. I haven't had to think about traversal in an open world game this way... probably ever. In Skyrim you can pretty much walk in a straight line to any given point as long as you're willing to deal with a couple of steep inclines. Same with Fallout, same with Grand Theft Auto, etc. I think if there wasn't the balancing mechanic in this game I wouldn't enjoy this nearly as much. Each delivery is a puzzle that can be approached multiple ways based on your equipment, gear, exoskeleton, and perserverance. 

DOOM Eternal is one of my favorite games this year in how satisfying it is to sit back and fall into a blissful state of running around, ripping and tearing, jumping and grapplehooking, etc, but Death Stranding is a close runner up in how blissful it is to just trek across the midwest with a bunch of metal and resin strapped to my back as I make deliveries for people at the top of mountains and at the bottom of gorges. I'm still rather early in the story because I've been taking my time with it but the gameplay has me hooked. 

If you want a game to sit down with and just relax to, I can't recommend this highly enough. Absolute bliss.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I'm not going to recommend this, not for the full price I paid for this "experience" nor when it's on sale. This product deserves an old-school Spoony review, God bless his soul. You should really at least watch Dunkey's review on Youtube, as he outlines the biggest issues with Death Stranding. I endured, God knows I endured, cringy dialog, repetitive and mundane gameplay, unintuitive GUI, but the plot, the PLOT BROKE ME. I’m pretty sure, that all the people, who give this title a positive review never played past Episode 4 (there are 14 Episodes total, plus the Freeroam episode 15). Because no human being can praise this convoluted mess. Death Stranding is the air in your bag of Lays. The story doesn’t make sense, the delivery is awful, the characters are bland, and pointless, there is large cast that exists purely for decoration and exposition. The biggest issue is that characters don’t have any motivation for any of their actions. I’ve spent 66 hours on this piece of media, and all I could think about during lengthy “story cutscenes” is – What the hell is going on? Why? Why should I care about what I see on the screen? The characters don’t have ANY chemistry, yet the narrative thinks that you care deeply for them. This is an art-house “movie” that is devoid of any entertainment value, it’s an elaborate joke that exists only to waste your time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: First off, this isn't Metal Gear Solid.  I feel like a lot of people are judging this game because they are expecting a tactical game of some sort and this just isn't it.  However, this is an excellent game in its own right and is very slowly becoming one of my favorite games I've ever played.  The social interactions are so unique in this game, and not only do you see other people's influence on your world, the profound thing for me is I get to see my influence on other people's worlds as well.  There's nothing like getting a message that someone used a piece of equipment you set up!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Really enjoying this one.  Visionary sci-fi, great graphics with some downright beautiful landscapes and the best character animations I've seen this side of LA Noire, challenging and methodical gameplay and traversal, and the asynchronous multiplayer features add to the theme of the game and give you a great feeling of camraderie with your fellow gamer.  Using the tools you have to come up with your own routes around obstacles and then seeing other players use your route feels really rewarding.  Runs great on a 1070 at 1440p.  My favorite PC game of 2020 so far.

Update: Beat the game, what a ride but the story kind of eats itself/gets up its own ass towards the end. Make sure you have several hours to spend on cutscenes before you get to the endgame, it's almost as bad as MGS4 as far as indulgent Kojima stuff but for me it does hit more often than it misses, really good performances, and I struggle to think of a more creatively and thematically ambitious game that I've played lately.  It hits tons of different notes and game styles; action, shooter, rpg, walking simulator, puzzler, light MMO elements too. I don't think I will replay it but I got my money's worth.  I'd love to see the multiplayer stuff expanded on in the next game from this studio, that's what held my interest the most.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Really unique. Gorgeous graphics. Trippy, bizarre storyline. The core game mechanic is fetch-quest, yes -- but it's really about traversal of of challenging terrain. People have called it a "walking simulator," and that's misleading; it's a walking, hiking, mountaineering, motorcycling, trucking, road-building, zip-lining simulator. And the asynchronous multiplayer-ish aspect of it is interesting and well-executed. Sound design is brilliant. 

Cons? The writing is sometimes REALLY soap-operatic. But a) that's a matter of taste, and b) it's a very minor component of the overall game experience. And c) you can skip it. 

Conclusion? If you like open-world sandbox games, DS is a fascinating, unique take on the genre.

This game, in my opinion, is one of the very few games where I can truly enjoy myself, immerse myself in the environment, and not feeling exhausted, angry or frustrated after playing it, The story, the mechanics, the MUSIC, everything just makes the game so so so good.

It is a very beautiful game. I truly hope everyone would give themselves a chance to appreciate this absolute fantastic masterpiece.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
We have been blessed yet again by Lord Kojima giving us this masterpiece. Pure art in digital format. One of the best games I have ever played. 主の年に二千二十

It's got in-depth characters and lore as well as world building. Gameplay is smooth and can be almost meditative in its style. I love the extensive list of top-tier actors alongside Norman Reedus XD ウォーキング・デッド、ボンドック・セイント、ブレード・セカンド、ライド

There's very few games I can even compare this to. I guess at times it gives me a Metal Gear Solid vibe mixed with the survival genre, walking sims, MMOs (Deliveries similar to fetch quests and lots of walking, driving, etc...) and supernatural / sci-fi horror set in an expansive post apocalyptic, cyberpunk, dystopian open world (Probably the best I've ever seen). There is potentially 100+ hours worth of content with just the side missions alone not counting the main quest line. This truly is GOD material.

This is one of those games where you can take your time and enjoy every moment. The visuals are crisp and some of the best I've ever gazed upon (Damn near photorealistic). The picture mode feature is also really fun to use and adds to the overall replayability. 

This title is way ahead of its time and is even more relevant now than ever drawing parallels to the real world (Isolation, Divided people, Divided states, Deliveries as an essential way of life, trying to help one another) as well the many layers of deep themes and pop cultural references. This is the perfect game to play without having to worry about anything. The cutscenes themselves are better than most films and shows much like the MGS games. 

This is an easy 10/10 for me and I highly recommend getting it even at full price as it is definately worth it. I hope someday Kojima gives us a full MGS remastered collection on Steam as well as Silent Hills and MGSVenom: The Director's Demon Cut. コレクターズヴェノムスーパーデラックスエディション

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If you've ever wanted to live in a film made by Andrei Tarkovsky, this is the game for you.

57 hours played on PC (Very Hard Mode); already beat it on PS$ on hard.

Difficult learning  curve, but once you get it, there's nothing else like it on the market. A walking simulator with combat, asymmetric multiplayer, horror, absurd comedy, narrative gymnastics, gorgeously rendered environments, a wealth of vehicles, and near infinite ways to solve any particular "delivery", DEATH STRANDING earns its place in video game history. You might love it. You might hate it. But Hideo Kojima has made something unique and truly special here.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I love this game. It's environments are beautiful, the soundtrack is phenomenal, and I found myself often just wandering. I'd take a delivery job and just walk my way there and take my time and just take in the sights. It was almost meditative for me. The gameplay takes a bit getting used to and it takes a couple of hours for things to finally click, but once you're past the initial sense of overwhelm, everything becomes clearer. The same applied to the story. I found myself intrigued and emotionally invested in the story. Great fucking game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is not the boring "walking simulator" critics like to call it.  Yes there is a lot of walking and it is the main thing you do.  Walking is boring in most games, but this one adds so much more to it.  You have to plan your route, equip yourself for the trek, decide whether or not grabbing that extra piece of cargo is worth being over encumbered.  There is a lot of story and lore to follow.  The pacing is a little slow for the first 3 hours or so.  Once you get to the next region, things get way more interesting.  Personally, even the beginning wasn't boring imo.  As you progress, the terrain gets more difficult to navigate, but you get better equipment to combat it.  Speaking of combat, this game does not have the best combat mechanics out there.  That said, that's not the point of the game.  There are vehicles and roads and zip lines to build at a certain point, all make the going a little more forgiving, however you do need to save up a lot of materials for these things.  Not to mention everything you build is shared with other players and vice versa.  Everybody's world looks a little different and we all help each other with every little thing we do.

As of writing this review I have only logged 25 hours and am on Episode 3.  Still have a long way to go but I'm already writing this review because more people need to consider this game.  Don't listen to the critics.  Obviously if you like FPS titles this wouldn't be for you.  But if your into exploration, large maps, RPGs, anything that is just a little different than the norm, check this one out.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Very good game. Story is deep and the Graphics are amazing. There is a lot of delivery's to make if you wish to 5 star everything and sometimes can get repetitive however it is rare and not too annoying. The game also runs very smoothly on highest settings system specs will be posted below with  73-110 fps, and it normally hovers around the 90 fps range. The only thing which I always got annoyed about throughout most of the game is the Bike and Truck Physics they are just horrible the bike stops dead on tiny bumps in the road/grass and the truck wishes to just drive directly sideways sometimes (not joking) seen better in some old source engine games. Other than that I am very surprised with how good this game is and very happy I bought it. [spoiler] I will be replaying this and also I do like the headcrab hat :) [/spoiler]

System Specs:
Ryzen 3900X stock speeds (CPU max usage was 40% and normally hovered around 30%)
EVGA GTX 1070TI FTW2
32GB DDR4 RAM @3600Mhz
Game installed on a NVME 2000MB/s Read/Write

Story is great for the most part other than some nitpicks to a few subplots, but the main story is quite consistent in of itself. As long as you realize this game idealizes the setting it takes place in and that it isn't meant to be taken extremely seriously, you'll probably love that part of it. 

Recommended if you enjoy pre-planning your courses of action and seeing your plan through as the main loop. It's a slow burn that asks for your attention a bit longer than a lot of other games.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I wanted to love Death Stranding, I had seen it hyped for more than a year as a groundbreaker title.  I liked the concept, I like the backstory of Kojima struggling with those pricks at Konami and finally getting to craft his swan song game.  I jumped immediately into Very Hard difficulty and tried to immerse myself in this thing.

And struggled...and struggled...and began to hate the game.  It has terrible menus, very confusing concepts that aren't well explained, and the controls are the purest jank.  But it looked amazing, felt amazing when I was succeeding, and I could see the potential as I pushed forward.  

So there is a learning curve, less so with the core mechanics of the game and more so with the controls and menus.  In time I've learned to love this game so I'm going to just throw a couple non spoiler help for anyone like me out there (as this game is about helping others through the slog of the journey).  
You are ridiculously underpowered and incapable in the beginning, deal with it, the main threats that face you nearly destroyed humanity...so think of it like that.  Do not concern yourself with trying to 'boost up' or do anything than walk the main plot path till act 3 (after the boat), you will gain advantages after that that will make you capable enough not to feel like a punching bag.  Also use F in the cargo menu to auto balance your gear unless you are trying to create a specific weight effect, its a huge time saver.  The rain wears everything evenly so don't bother with placement tricks. The speed of the container wear is about 10x time of the item wear, so don't stress.  Once the container is toast...you can bring the container back from zero.  The restorative can is area of affect cloud so place containers smart, and don't do it in the rain unless you have to....that percentage damage score at the end of the run is nothing to worry about.
The 'yellow' grenades disperse BTs from an area but cause no harm, it make take them a second to leave.  The 'red' grenades are direct damage but one may not be enough.  When you throw a grenade, you right click to get the arc, but then you left and hold to get a different more direct arc that is 1000% a superior throw.  Anything that affects a BT will cause other BTs in the area to aggressively search the area where the 'ruckus' took place.  Use this to manipulate them out of your path.  DO NOT face the evil tentacle dolphins without superior killing firepower, but if you do take one out that local storm will be gone for a while.
Give to other players like you are Mother Teresa.  There are an excess of materials for what you need to do, and being generous with equipment and materials to their structures, and relying on other players to handle things for you pays off.  The like system is a social currency that boosts everyone dynamically.  Reward other players with glorious thumbs and your character will grow as theirs do.  There is a time window where you can rapidly give likes before it closes out, you hit the button rapidly.
Saving can be finicky, basically if you are not in harms way you can save, though there is a buffer around what is obviously 'harm's way'.  There are two types of rain storms, moving and static, early on all of them are static...deal with them as a hazard not something to wait out.  The menu system is...horrible...it will make you crazy, get used to it.  The game will throw a ton of terms and concepts at you without explaining it.  A lot of the acting is terrible, even what is handled by the Hollywood b-listers and there are so so many cut scenes (which you can mostly skip).  The plot is um...I mean the core concept is freaky and cool but...yeah it's really dumb.  Also there is a lot of male partial nudity which is...uh...I don't know, ask Hideo Kojima.  

Just be patient with the 1st two chapters (which is like 10+ hours) and the game will open up and the fun will be there.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Great game

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
As a big, big MGS fan and Kojima defender, I really wanted to love this game and patiently avoided spoilers and gameplay until the PC release. I knew the game drew mixed reviews but I had enough faith in Kojima as an auteur that I was pretty confident it would be well worth my while. Even with MGSV burning me a bit story-wise after failing to deliver on the incredible trailers, it still provided a fantastic gameplay experience and I could blame Konami for rushing the game out. 

Unfortunately this is the first game directed by Kojima that I won't be finishing, and the second game of his in a row where I felt the trailers overall were a greater artistic achievement than the game itself. Dude should just become a film director like he clearly aspires to be.

The game started with a bang, and I was quite hooked albeit it felt awkward to handle, moreso because my controller had problems with the triggers in this game and M+KB isn't ideal in this one. About 10 hours in the gameplay started to feel like work albeit satisfying work. 20 hours in, I felt like I was having to force myself to continue. The breaking point was when I made the longest and most difficult trek yet from A to B, only to immediately be told to go back from B to A, and then immediately back from A to B. At this point I really just wanted to advance the story, so in my carelessness I Game Over'd twice on my way back to B, sending me back to A, at which point I had to admit defeat and put the game down.

While the gameplay is original and not-uninteresting, it's just not very good either. It gives you a bunch of tools to figure out novel ways to transit around the terrain, but I found myself not excited by the possibilities, and just tried to build roads and use vehicles whenever I could (this in spite of the fact that the vehicles handle TERRIBLY - there is no excuse for this in 2020). The enemies I mostly zoomed past as it was a viable option, and there didn't seem much incentive to interact with them. And exploration revealed very little interesting to discover - yes a side effect of the game's setting, but bleh. Boss fights up to the point I played were highly underwhelming, little sense of peril or agency.

The environments are beautiful but I've been to Iceland so I've seen all the types of terrain in this game in real life, and walked among them, so the game loses a bit of its glamour in that regard. And there's almost never any bloody music when you're traveling around! Terrible design choice.

The premise and themes of the game are fascinating, and the earlier cutscenes start you off with a bang (heh), but the pacing gets sooooo wack as you progress in the game. You'll go hours where you get nothing other than holograms giving you generic "Golly Sam, thanks for the delivery!" messages which are completely soulless. Then every few hours there's a side-story that tries to give you a little burst of emotional involvement but they tended to feel flat and awkward to me, moreso because so much of the character interactions were bland, and even many of the main-story cutscenes are just two people talking in a grey room. I am still quite interested to finish seeing the main story, because I LOVE the themes about disconnection, social media, individualism vs collectivism etc, but I am content to experience it by watching the cutscenes on YouTube instead of completing the slog.

The online elements were quite cool, it was fun sightlessly co-operating with other players and felt rewarding to build structures that other players got use out of. Not enough to compel me to keep playing though.

I would only recommend this game if it goes on sale for $20 or so. And I have lost quite a bit of faith in Kojima as a game director.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is definitely a slow burn. I almost got bored of it a few hours in, but I am really digging being a delivery Reedus now! The more tools, vehicles and gear you unlock the more fun it becomes to plan your route effectively and try to accept orders in a way that you can hit multiple stations while picking up even more orders on the way. Even evading BT's and other enemies makes for some fun change up's enough to not get bored of just delivering. The cinematography and visuals in this game are amazing. I've sat in aw with my controller drooping out of my hands more then once. Just beautiful. And I'm only on a 1070, only 1080p just a rock solid 60fps almost maxed out. Very well optimized.

The building and sharing of the waste land is so clever. Even tho you never see an actual player, you feel like your helping people out and getting help in return. I just spent 3 hours today starting to build the highway system, and every once in a while I will get notifications that someone used my part of the highway or sent me a like for another structure I built that may have helped them out at a rough time. It's a very unusual sense of community, you never see or talk to anyone but you don't feel alone.

The story is so messed up, half the time I don't know what's going on, but I love every second of it. The more you actually start to understand the more interesting this world becomes. It definitely drives me to get to the next cut scene. The cast is amazing and the performances are cinema quality. Hard to talk about any story beats without spoiling, every little unveil is a treat.

If your even thinking about getting this game, just do it. There's nothing like this on the market and there may not ever be for quite some time. Kojima is a genius and this kind of out of the box triple A game development should be encouraged as much as possible. We need to break this industry out of the cookie cutter crap we get most of the time. Give him all your money so he may deliver us with another work of art.

Head out and deliver bro!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Like his prior works, auteurist Hideo Kojima has rain-soaked his latest masterpiece in deep spiritual and philosophical symbolism. The game itself is a meditation on koyaanisqatsi (Hopi for "life out of balance") and this theme can be found as immediately as the introduction to gameplay. From the grassy, desolate fields broken up by craggy hills, to the moody and melancholy sounds of Low Roar and Silent Poets, this piece exudes craftsmanship and pines for the deep consideration of the player.

In a world where humankind believed itself to nearly solve the problem of death through science, the bodies of the living now decay into invisible, restless horrors that stalk the rain-stormed plains. Those familiar with Japanese spiritualism will note that night is never shown to fall, and thus symbolically the spirit world no longer draws close to the living, stranding the souls of the dead in our reality. So also, the ocean serves as a classic motif for life while the shore can be thought of as a passage into the next realm or a barrier to it. A trip to the bay is itself a confrontation with the reality of death and life.

Many questionable aspects of modernity are unpacked throughout, much like the warning essays of Junichiro Tanizaki. The player must decide what habits are worth building up or automating away; craft against convenience. Cellular devices are depicted as shackles clipped to the wrist to feed you numbers, while the superficial networks that connect them and other installations slowly kill the environment surrounding, shown by shale plants shaped like hands reaching up through the dirt. Infants themselves are reduced to hardware commodities, necessary to better the conditions of the already living. The very footsteps of the BTs fill with oil, leaving dead earth in their wake.

Kojima continues his laudable dialog on reconciling the strengths of the American Dream against the moors of nuclear proliferation that continue to hold the natural fate of humanity hostage. He leaves it up to the player to decide whether the convenience of taking a life will outweigh the resulting "voidout."

While extending both the physical and information highways, players have the opportunity to form deeper connections with other characters, to juxtapose the superficial against the substantial, for a far deeper contemplation on the social aspects of media. Myself, I am only three chapters in and already I feel welcomingly confronted by the many questions being asked of me. In particular, is death something to flee, or is it a part of life?

Kojima and his team have once again produced a masterpiece worthy of consideration by any fan of philosophy and culture.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a very good game.  Sure it's got some flaws, as most games do, but nonetheless, none of them were major and I really enjoyed playing it.  
Post apocalypse deliveries is the fundamental task you will be performing when you play Death Stranding. For this reason alone, this is a game that is not for everyone.  On the up side, there are very few games like it, which makes it a good title if you are tired of playing the same old types of games over and over or just want to try something different.  Additionally, I feel it's worth your while for the freaky deaky story if nothing else.   
The story of the Death Stranding is a weird one, and it is fed to you throughout playing the game.   Advance a little, and you are exposed to a little about the history and lore of the Death Stranding and the slew of other terms used in the game.  

What exactly is this game about?  Well, at some point in our future, something happened and a lot of people died as a result, this is the Death Stranding (DS).  Many years after the DS, you are working as a delivery man, living the good life, doing what you want to do, answering to no one.  Very early in the game you are convinced by the last president of the US to attempt to help bring the former United States back together in a new nation called the United Cities of America.  Your task, when making your deliveries, is to connect these cities to a network spanning coast to coast, which allows the rapid sharing of information and other resources.
The world of DS is freaking gorgeous!  The environments you encounter are a variety of natural environments and ruins of man-made ones look amazing.  But don't let the pretty mountain fool you, what may seem pretty easy to navigate from afar can turn south when you get up close and see the path is actually pretty treacherous.  You will need to use your wits and tools to navigate these environments in order to make your deliveries on-time.  Thank heavens there is no night time, you would fall off a cliff and die so hard many, many times. 

The controls can be aggravating and clunky at times, it takes a while to get a genuine feel for them.  Just when you master the controls of one aspect of the game, they throw something new at you, but the learning curve gets shorter with each new aspect.

Combat is different, not the strongest aspect of the game.  It just doesn't have a responsive FPS feel when in combat.  However, the combat system seems to work given that combat is not really your primary role in the game, delivering stuff is.  Still, some better or more responsive controls would be nice to have.
Sometimes the menus ask for different button presses when exiting a menu.  This is kind of annoying, but not a game breaker.

As you are moving through the world of DS, it would seem some nice motion mechanics have been built using some real world physics, which adds to the sense of immersion you feel while playing.  But those physics seem to be set on random at times when weird stumbles, or when vehicle speed and direction go all bizzaro on you for no apparent reason... so be prepared for that, especially in inclement weather.

Driving is even more frustrating than stumbling and falling on your face with a big load of cargo on foot.  You will curse a lot behind the wheel.

Interactions with other people are a welcome event, until it becomes repetitive and they say nothing new on repeat visits.  Conan O'Brien is in it. 

The only glitch I experienced while playing was what seemed to be an internal memory leak, which caused some issues with gameplay after 5 or so hours some of the time.

Many have said this game is too repetitive, and they are right, it is.  In conclusion I counter with this; Even though you seem to be doing the same missions and mission types over and over, your character and the resources available are always evolving in the game.  Each new discovery, or enhancement you uncover gives you a chance to take on repeating missions in new and improved ways, often much faster than before.  The game seems to have a good pace for me, one where things will get changed up right at the onset of being tired with the current way of doing things... This seems to happen all the way up until the end of the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is a form of meditation. 
If I was to compare it to another title I've played this year, it would be Animal Crossing.
Not in their themes, but in their pacing, however, to me, Animal Crossing is much more painful to play (I got 320 hours deep into that game, just to figure out there was an 8 incline limit). 
The two games rake you up out of your socially desperate, entertainment addicted mind state, and allow you to breath for a moment. They pluck at your nano-thin attention span, and if you play them for just long enough, it snaps, and regenerates in the form of the Bonneville Salt Flats.
I've spent 47 hours so far just playing the main story of the game and I now feel like that's just the beginning.

Worst excuse for a game I have played in ages. It's kind of pretty in places. that's about all.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is my first Kojima game... And I am hooked. If you want to play something completely different, this is your game.

The graphics of this game are amazing. The rocky landscapes just pop, and if you have a recent RTX GPU you can take advantage of DLSS 2.0 for some ridiculous performance. The game holds your hand a little bit in the beginning but if you push through it you are rewarded with this gorgeous world. There are alot of cutscenes to sit through but that doesnt really bother me. The story of this game is a little confusing at first but if you pay attention, the world is so rich. There is lore everywhere to immerse yourself in. 

Alot of people describe this as a walking simulator and say that they do not like the driving mechanics, I cant disagree more. Yes, you do alot of walking, but if you work at it, you can also traverse the landscape in a motorcycle and a truck. 

Give it a try, this might be your pick for best game of 2020, so far its mine.

title: DEATH STRANDING

10/10, will probably not play anything alike it for several years.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This ‘game’ is very pretty. It is very unique. It is very different from other games. The unique part is that all you do in this game is load heavy packages on your back and then walk for 10-15 minutes from point A to point B and deliver the packages. Yes there are ghosts, which the baby you carry in a bottle on your chest (yes a baby) allows you to see. You don’t really fight the ghosts, you try to hide from them by holding your breath, but since they don’t then go away you have to eventually walk past them and when they see you, the game allows you to spam a key to ‘shake them off’. If you succeed you get to go walk some more, if you fail you die, and then get to come back to life and go find the packages you dropped so you can pick them up and walk some more. It is as though someone watched people play video games and thought, “They spend a lot of time walking around the map and trying to climb over obstacles, that must be what they like about games”  Once you deliver things you get to go to your room and rest, and go to the bathroom.  Going to the bathroom is an important mechanic in the game.  Really.  It is.

I am being harsh here because I really wanted to like the game and suffered through the extensive cut scenes and confusing conversations figuring the game just had a long and slow tutorial and would get more interesting once I was through that, but it didn't.  I have requested a refund, which is not a thing I usually do.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Well where do I even start with this? 

The game is definitely something unique and it'll take you on quite the journey.
It's a pretty lengthy game that takes place in a big rich world filled with all kinds of details and hazards,
It does a great job at building an emotional connection to the main character and his companions and sometimes even a few villains but and that's a big but, there are parts of the game that do drag on at times, if you are prone to getting bored easily then this might not be the game for you, if on the other hand you enjoy a well crafted world with an interesting deep twisted complicated story that's gradually taught to the player then I can't recommend this game enough.

A word of warning, if you are like me and wanna do the side objectives as in getting all preppers on 5 stars then I can only urge you to think about for a good while, there ain't a massive payoff to it and it damn well nearly drove me insane at times, I recommend only doing so if you are really determined and wanna see every little bit of content in the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game won't be for everyone. It's as simple as that. If you like combat games more than anything, then you probably won't like it. But if you're more into games like Subnautica or exploration/survival games, this is for you. The game is high concept and isn't made to be 100% exciting all the time. It's meant to feel like work at times because it wants to demonstrate how difficult this would be if it were to take place in real time. But part of the benefit of that is when you DO complete missions or tasks, you feel a great sense of reward and accomplishment from what you've done. You actually have to progress your way through the game on your own without the story driving it. 

That being said, if you have a crappy laptop like me, this game will murder your laptop and run horribly. But even then, I still really enjoy playing it so that must mean something.

So that's how delivey men feels during a pandemic...
(Review after finishing chapter 7)

Jokes aside... it's bad. It's a mix between fetch quests and radiant quests. The map is open but it's not open world! Meaning that if you stumble upon a building, unless you have a main quest delivery there, you can't interact with it.
The game use every tricks in the book to make its playtime longer.

Also, don't listen to the people saying "you'll see after X amount of time" or "After X chapters"... No. You watched the trailers? good because that's more than half the good stuff! 
With no spoilers, there is 2 maybe 3 "action scenes" . After that it's delivery time in an empty world. The "Wow it's wonderful!" dies very quickly.

Story wise, you know how you felt watching the show "Lost", started good then got worse because it made no senses? well, here you go!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Okay, this is complicated. Game's unique, culturally significant and it's important that it exists. But it's also a proof that giving creator full artistic freedom with no oversight isn't always a good thing, In movie industry it's producer's job to hold the leash of director.
So yeah Kojima's out of control here, we have breathtaking visuals, we have setting like no other. But all together it does little sense, game tries very hard to be deep and thought provoking but all it does is dropping 15 anvils a minute,

The standart block of the game goes like this:
1) Hey sam porter BRIDGES, it's important to build BRIDGES, here's your STRAND help us all get CONNECTED.
2) You built a BRDIGE THANKS that will help us all be CONNECTED, you are like STRAND holding us all together.
3) In a world that revolves around delivering cargo where everyone's a courier you were the first one to deliver my stained comicbook 300 meters across in literally decade. THANKS SAM.
4) Some movie with Mads/Some talk on the beach mixed in.
5) You feel very clever and getting likes in the process.

At some point I had a feeling that game is consious about it's shallow overuse of CONNECTION theme and thanking protagonist for every smallest step taken and even ironic about it. But I was wrong, and it's horrifying that the game is dead serious about it.

Verdict: This game is unique and presents genuinely new experience, but Kojima is not in on the joke he's telling us.
