title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I tried to give this game a fair shot (70 hours as of writing this), but several things really put me off of this game, which is why I don't recommend it.

1) It would've been better if you weren't so limited on how much you can build, by the small amount of bandwidth they give you in the game. The building aspect opened up some really cool options for progressing in the game, but you have to be very discerning on which options to pursue, because there's no way you'll be able to accomplish more than a fraction of what you'd like to do. I really wish they didn't have a bandwidth limit in this single-player game.

2) There is so much time, effort, and resources required to rebuild the roads, reconnect the Knots, and do all the things you'd like to do, if you're the completionist type; yet so very little payoff. By the end of the game, you can have all the tools you need to conquer the terrain and the BTs, but you have to progress too far in the main story, to unlock everything. While I don't think they should give you everything at the start, I feel I had to work too hard and too long for the next item in my toolkit. This is an open world, not a linear one, so the excessive wait for the next upgrade felt too unreasonable.

3) I still have a lot of questions about the story and the world. A lot of people like to joke about, or even praise, how abstract the lore is, but I just find it to be an unnecessary pain in the ♥♥♥. I still don't have a solid understanding of how the original catastrophe took place, and that's something that most other games would explain early on, so that you can feel a connection to the past, and make sense of the present. I'm definitely not impressed with Kojima's rambling abstraction.

4) You are CONSTANTLY backtracking in this game. I really feel like games which rely on a lot of backtracking to pad out their content, are lazy. And this game compounds the non-stop (that's not an exaggeration) backtracking with frustratingly-difficult terrain, which must be overcome to get from point A to point B. You have the option to fabricate tools to help you with this, to an extent, but you can't just build bridges over everything, because your bandwidth is limited. You can lay down ladders, but the rain causes everything to degrade over time (including structures you had to spend resources on to build), and the vehicles you unlock are only useful when you don't have to constantly fight the same terrain over the same routes.

5) Quest design in this game is simply lazy. It is apparent that very little effort went into making running cargo fun and interesting. It's always the same copy/paste mission where you load up on packages from the north city, move them to the east city, then move packages from the east city to the north city. Over the same terrain obstacles. Over and over. Then eventually, you'll unlock the west city. Will the method to transport packages to the west city be different? lol, nah. The terrain might change, and you may need to use a different set of tools to get there, but you'll stop being impressed after the 15th run there and back, in order to get enough stars to unlock the next upgrade.

6) Interacting with the NPCs outside the main plot is pointless. You usually don't ever get to meet them in person (except for a couple notable exceptions), instead just communicating with their hologram. And their reaction can be boiled down to, "Oh wow; you're the chosen one! It's such an honor to get a package from you, and it's in such good condition too. And the next 20 times you deliver something to me, in order to unlock my next upgrade, I will deliver the exact same dialogue."

In conclusion, if the game had been more generous with the frequency at which you unlock the next upgrade, removed the unreasonably-strict building bandwidth limitations, and not lazily relied so heavily on non-stop backtracking over the same frustrating terrain obstacles, I could've enjoyed it a lot more. Or perhaps if I just focused on the main story and skipped the side content (I tend to try and complete as much as I can), I wouldn't have felt so frustrated and bored. But at the end of the day, it all just left me feeling a bit tired and poorly rewarded for all my effort.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: First off, this isn't going to be for everyone. Honestly, I'm not sure what the type is yet that would tend towards this game. I myself have always loved fast paced shooters, occasional racing games, RPGs, and aRPGs. This game may be extremely boring to watch, but I'm finding it inexplicably fun and satisfying. The world is unlike anything I've ever seen and the characters are just plain intriguing. I'm always looking forward to somebody speaking because it gives you more of the story, and you get to see just how well each character is portrayed. At it's core, the gameplay loop is; pick up packages, traverse terrain, deliver packages, rinse and repeat. But there's something fun in going about doing that in this. The graphics look good and make one of the first solid uses of DLSS I've seen that doesn't look like everything turned to mud, while giving you way better performance. To keep from droning on, and on about every little tid-bit I've experienced so far, all I can say is if you have an ounce of curiosity for this game, try it. If it's not your cup of tea, return it before the 2 hours, but you just might be surprised. I definitely was. I expected nothing more than hating the game within the first few minutes, yet here I am recommending it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Warning: My GTX 1050ti with 4GB vRAM was not enough to run this game. I actually bought a RTX 2080 Super with 8GB vRAM just to play it, plus a total of 40GB of RAM sticks DDR4, needed an upgrade in general.

That said, with some high quality hardware this game is amazing. Graphics are beautiful, the physics are amazing, and the gameplay is exactly what I expected. This is just the sort of game I can stay inside on a hot or rainy day and waste away the hours, following story, making deliveries, planning and crafting. This is not an action game, yet it is. It's not a thriller, but it is. It's not a survival game, but it is. It's none of those things yet all of them, all at once. I'm blown away by it, and obviously a huge fan of Kojima. Highly recommend if you can run it.

One of the best games I've played, period.

Before, I was not a fan of Kojima-san games, but I am now.

The story seems weak at first, but it gets stronger and stronger, the more you play, the more you live and become familiar with this strange world, and the final moments hit you like a heavy truck, no pun intended.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Rented and beat this game on the PS4 when it first came out. Bought it for the PC on day one, I don't regret it.

This game is great but I wont lie the story can kind of drag and repeat itself quite a bit. I keep this game on very hard mode and find it relaxing. The constant upkeep of gear, the travelling around, the good and emotional music, and the occasional action. 

I enjoy apocalyptic stories and I find the sci-fi in this game really immersive. I recommend this  game to anyone, at least to try. If you're not sure and not really into it I recommend at least buying it cheap to try.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I hated this game for the first 20 hours.  I felt it was empty and devoid of any purpose.  In my last 14 hours though I have come to see it for what it is.  At it's heart it is a message about society and how we have all become very disconnected from one another, and why we should be working to reconnect.  I've heard many reviewers say that the best part of the game is being able to skip large parts of the game via building highways and such.  If you keep playing, you realize that IS the game.  The more connected you become and the more you do to help humanity the easier your own "life" becomes.  

This is not a game for most, but if you have ever read a book that you could not get into only to find out that it gets really good about halfway in, you will like this game.  It requires patience and will appeal to those who find themselves obsessed with grinding in games.  This is more a work of art than a "fun" game, though it is very fun and rewarding.  Honestly, I think not liking this game and being unwilling to give it a 30+ hour try is evidence that you need this games message most of all.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Dude, I dont even know where to even try to start describing this game.  Basically, its the most gorgeous UPS-on-foot simulator ever made, with the game world, story and narative birthed from the mind of Hideo Kojima, and characters portrayed by honest to gahd real, talented actors.  The visuals are absolutly stunning, photo mode is gorgeous, if youre at all familiar with Metal Gear series and its, shall we say, interesting quirks and unique flavor of storytelling/ character development, then youll be on-board for guys with ridiculous names like 'DieHardMan' lol.  And being just thrown into this world without very much exposition or explination of what all exactly is going on, why the world is the way it is, etc.  But if you can get into the story, its deeply facinating, and the Kojima -standard long-ass cutscenes will be a joy.  Just don't dwell on the notion that you're essentially playing a walking simulator with balance mechanics in between the good, beautiful story bits, haha.  Oh, and having to find and retrieve apparently every other lazy bum's undelivered items, its like poor Norman Reedus is the only porter who actually tries to do his job, lol.

10/10, needs more David Hayter tho.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] Let me start out by saying 2 things, one this game is not meant for everyone, and two this is probably the greatest game I've ever played (and I really mean that).[/h1]
I was completely hooked from the start. The first couple of hours were packed with a story I could get into it. It sets the tone of the game, and is the reason that makes wanting to come back to the game. After around 5 hours the story starts to show a little less, and the main game-play loop starts. For me I enjoyed the game-play. I felt it to be satisfying and actually enjoyable. I know some find it to be a drag, but I am a fan of the delivery sim style of game-play. Anyway, after the opening of the story and the end of the game you decided what pace you go at to complete the game. I have seen people say they spent the first 30+ hours in just chapter 3! Personally I was so interested in the story that I didn't do many of the side missions, but instead powered through the story. The last couple of hours are just like the start, a lot of story told through many fantastic cutscenes. Honestly the animation and voice acting in this game is 100% some of gaming's greatest. As I continue to write this review I realize I want to say so much, but I'm not trying to write an essay. I start to close it up now. Honestly I loved every second of this game. The story, game play, voice acting, animation, environments are some of the best I've ever seen. For someone who is interested in the game, please buy it. If you aren't drawn to the game by the media thats already out there, I'm not sure if this is for you, but for those who have an interest, I bet you'll love it. Also this is my first Kojima game. I am most certainly going to check out his other work now.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is not for everyone. It's a slow game, with a story that for the first 20-30 hours of the game, is confusing as hell. The latter is of course to be expected from a Hideo Kojima game.
The story all in all, is pretty good, but not as amazing as you'd might expect from Kojima. 
The game itself is really enjoyable though. The tie-in with Half-life and Portal, is a funny little distraction. 

When you haul packages from one city, to the next, you'll enjoy some amazing scenery, with some carefully curated music, which just makes you want to stop and enjoy the view, time and time again. 
It's also this however, which might keep some people from playing the game. The vast majority of the game, is just you, delivering packages, walking or driving from city to city. 
This might sound boring, and I'll admit, I had to get used to the very different gameplay. But once I got used to it, I thoroughly enjoyed it. 

I'll enjoy this game to anyone, with the asterisk of it being a slow game, meant to be enjoyed, and not rushed through.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I hated this game to start with. 
It starts all arty, like the devs were auditioning for perfume adverts. 
Everyone cries, the acting is awful, the dialogue is stupid, the story makes no sense (it gets no better) but worst of all...you hardly get to play a game for ages. 
I was this >< close to getting a refund. 
Then you get let loose to do your own thing and make your way in the world and it gets interesting. 
It was probably helped by me being a hiker who very often is in almost exactly the wet upland environment of the early game. It felt very recognisable. 
Then I spent a couple of RL days wandering lost in snow in the game. The snow visuals and mechanisms are really well done. The experience was immersive in a way that I've not felt in a game for a long time.
When looking for a new game on Steam I have a thought in mind: “I want to go on an adventure”. This is very rarely fulfilled but, just for once, it was with Death Stranding. 
The story is still a ridiculous eco/pseudo-intellectual crack-dream. But never mind that, DS is an adventure.   

Update:
Just finished it. Including the 2 hours of  "cut" scene ending that had the credits twice!
At any point I expected a voice-over of “Obsession by Calvin Klein”. 
What a self-indulgent load of tosh by the developers. 
The story made no sense and was full of inconsistencies, plot holes and sheer nonsense. 
Spoiler/tip: When you’ve killed the giant just quit the game there. Everything after that is a complete waste of your life.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is weird. It shouldn't be fun based on the core gameplay loop of gopher quests, but for some reason it really just works for me. If you enjoy the experience of a long drive or hike and wouldn't mind a bit of a gamification of that experience I recommend this. You are constantly getting upgrades to let you move more weight more efficiently, and going from struggling to stay balanced with like 60 kg of cargo, to literally tearing across the landscape with 200+kg feels pretty good. I highly recommend listening to podcasts and to treat this game more like elite dangerous or euro truck simulator, you'll get plenty of enjoyment out of it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
See that mountain?! You can climb it!

Opinion after these hours of gameplay?
Menu are horrible you don't understand what is your destination cause everything looks the same, im used to skip all the menus after delivery something cause they are hard only to look at and to read.

When you enter the game everytimes and you forgot what you were doing, You go to your orders and it's just a mess to look at the map, full of indicators and weird simbles.

Why every menu must be blue in the game? They could have added different colors for different waypoints, everything is blue even sam clothes are Blue.

Another thing that bothers me are the waypoint paths that disappears everytimes and it's pressing G or Tab everytime to recalibrate your path to show it. If you get too far away from the path you won't see it again, and everytimes you have to press G to locate your destinations, but it's hard cause you got so many waypoints that you loose yourself, so you have to erase all your waypoints and recreate the path you have to follow... the solution was simply to have a specific key that shows you the position of your path and a compass would have been so useful...they are so advanced but they don't use a compass.

Also it's a game of Kojima you will hate it and love it for his complicated mechanics. 

You are Sam...You are a porter...You are part of the "Bridges Company" and you deliver packages.

Artistically is 10/10
Gameplay is 7/10
Graphics is 10/10
Story until now is 8/10 


9/10 is my final vote...

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I love Kojima. He's a great developer and I've played almost all his games.

That being said I have to be honest and say that Death Stranding is one of the most frustrating games I ever played. It's an absolute chore. For someone who works in construction for a living, I just don't have the patients for something like this. This is NOT a game, it's a JOB.

It's slow, boring and convoluted. The gameplay mechanics are questionable and make me think that Kojima maybe smoking the frog glue or something. 

It has great visuals, voice acing and the story is very interesting... but after 11 hours I couldn't go any longer, even though I really wanted to see what happened - I just couldn't put myself through that kind of stress.

I applaud Kojima for the writing and visuals in this game because it's very theatrical but the gameplay is just too BORING and frustrating. Not Fun.

4/10 below average score from me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Its fucking weird.  Expected from Hideo Kojima but i've actually been able o follow the plot which is a first for me in one of his titles.  At its core the game is about making it to your destination with your cargo.  Sounds boring at first but you come to find that it contains a fair bit of heart pounding stealth, a bit of horror game and some instances of combat. As you progress in the game you unlock a ton of options on how you can attempt and execute each delivery.  It is refreshing to play something of such quality on this scale that is so far removed from the usual AAA rehashed game ideas.  That last bit alone has been worth it for me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Every story beat in Death Stranding has hit twice as hard on replay-- it was difficult for me to believe, but it really is the sort of thing which reveals mile-deep reservoirs when mirrored back its own vocabulary. It’s his best work, and a fantastic, authentically weird story and cast. Games like this ruin you for any other medium while somehow simultaneously bending over backwards to resurrect narrative. Deliriously good. 5/5 on the video game scale.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Great game if you want to look outside of regular old shooters. This game is well polished and has a robust feel to the game play. 

Pros: Visually lit, spectacular cut-scenes, action packed, requires piecing together info at times (nothing complicated), good boss fights 

Cons: After you get over the initial excitement and the Awe of this detailed apocalyptic world, nearing middle of the story it starts to feel repetitive and boring at times. The plot could have been better, all the build up to climax went over my head as I just wanted to finish the story as soon as possible. Too many twists and turns and vague origin story that it felt disoriented. Would have been nice if they were able to keep me engaged till the end. 

 Verdict: Awesome game, story telling no good.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Absolute masterpiece and work of art. This game will not be for everyone, but if you want to see excellence in cinematography and storytelling, you're in for a FANTASTIC journey. The gameplay itself is decent for what it is. On foot, the game shines. It has its janky moments but there was something oddly satisfying about conquering the worst terrain "post Death Stranding" America had to offer. Vehicular travel left much to be desired, if they had tuned it more towards GTA levels of fidelity, it would have been a lot better, but its not too huge of a deal. (Because ziplines are king) 

A lot of people ask in my long hours of gameplay if I would recommend Death Stranding... and thats honestly hard for me to answer... because the answer is different based on the person asking. Are you someone who only cares about gameplay, hates cutscenes and dialogue? Don't get it. Its not for you. 

Do you love deep and intricate storytelling with beautiful landscapes and scenery? Then I would recommend this game for  you. This game is more like watching a movie. If you've played Metal Gear Solid.. you're already in tune with what to expect from a Hideo Kojima game. You'll get the quirkiness, the humor, and the little oddities. But if you're not the patient type or you do not want to try anything new and out of the ordinary, just skip.. I would rather hear you say you did not try it because you're not into it, rather than listen to another dunkey review of it. Just know what you're getting into and the type of person you are. 

Its much like people who don't like sushi or only like cheese pizza. If you'd just try something new, you might find a whole world of experiences you never knew you'd enjoy, but instead you settle for cheese fucking pizza for your entire existence... sad. 

As for me, I appreciated everything and I feel Death Stranding puts a LOT of movies and TV shows to shame. It told a complete story, no loose ends, no questions, no sequel baiting in and of itself. The stars who lent their talent to the game are amazing. Having characters modeled after actual people does wonders for immersion. It was a brilliant move, it made the strange world of Death Stranding actually believable. 

Anyways, full disclosure I am a Hideo Kojima fan if you didn't guess so already, but I would not spend the time to write a review if I did not enjoy the game. This game is truly a sum of all its parts. Experience everything in it together, or you probably wont like it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
There is nothing new I can say about Death Stranding that you haven't already been told if you're looking at reviews.

This is definitely not a game for everyone, it's a game where the core gameplay is literally walking from point A to point B and delivering packages. You have various places to pick up packages from, the packages are different size and weight. Some are fragile (but not that fragile), some can't be placed placed vertically or they will be ruined. You take these packages where they need to go, and then you get points for how good condition the packages are, how fast you got there, how much you carried or things like that you had to travel into the mountains or something.

The idea of the gameplay is terrible. It does sound absolutely awful. But it isn't. The gameplay is really engaging. You see, walking isn't usually something that you get gameplay from. Walking is what you do between gameplay moments. In World of Warcraft, you walk between areas where you kill enemies, gather rocks or whatever else. In Minecraft you walk to get to resources or your home or whatever.

In Death Stranding walking isn't something you do to get to gameplay. Walking IS the gameplay. Picking up packages, choosing equipment, planning routes is all part of the preparation for the walking, the gameplay.

The walking isn't simply holding forward on the left stick or holding down W. If you have packages that are heavy, you might start to sway from side to side, you might start to trip over rocks or get swept away in rivers. It requires you to pay attention to what you are doing. There is a geographical scanner called an odradek, which scans the landscape and tells you of potential hazards. You get to a river, you scan to see where you can cross without falling over.

The map isn't flat. There are mountains and cliffs, which means you can't just walk straight to your goal. You can bring ladders with you, climbing ropes too. You can construct bridges to get over rivers. The ladders and machines to construct things take up space on your back though, meaning you have to choose how much to bring with you.

The structures you build can also be put into another players world. Sometimes you'll find a ladder built by another player, with a sign next to it with a happy face. If you want to say thank you to the player, you can like the structure. This shows a message in the other players world, showing them that their ladder was useful to someone else.

This extends to the entire game and almost everything in it. You can't see other players, but there are ladders built in places. You can't do anything else but like them if they are useful. Seeing a massive river that you can't cross, but seeing a bridge someone built for you further up the river is a blessing.

There is progression. I will not spoil gear progression, which there is. The progression that is most important is the feeling of quality of life. Walking through a snowstorm ruins your packages, so does rain. Someone putting up a roof over a place or showing you a way to a small cave where you can wait out the rain makes your journey slightly easier. This is the progression. In the beginning, you walk slowly from place to place, while later gameplay allows you to traverse areas faster and more easily.

The important thing is that the game doesn't allow you to have it easy to begin with, but that it slowly makes it easier with time. Allowing you to have all quality of life improvements to begin with wouldn't make you appreciate them. Spending multiple hours setting up bridges over areas and them using them to deliver packages really does it for me. Then seeing that people have liked the bridges, and seeing outlines of their footprints on them is the cherry on top. Knowing that you helped not only yourself but others too is the true endgame.

All of this is wrapped up in a confusing story. If you have played any Hideo Kojima games before, you know to expect strange stories. If you haven't played any games he's been working with, get ready for some confusion. 

There are NO story spoilers in this review.

The story is told through cutscenes, calls on the phone and hologram meeting. There are also lore texts to read, in the form of shorter "interviews" with characters in the game, which basically translates to shorter texts expanding the world and ideas around it.

The story is confusing, as I said. No details will be discussed. The story does not stay confusing forever. There are answers that make sense in the lore. There is an ending. There are characters with actual personalities and motivations. There are ACTUAL character-arcs if you can believe it.

The graphics are really nice. The implementation of Anti-Aliasing is not perfect, there is some noise around thinner details, like necklaces. This can be improved if you turn off sharpening. The game runs well. I ran the game on highest settings, in 1080p, on a 6700k at 4,5GHz and a 1080ti with no overclock. The game ran at over 120fps for the most part.

All of the cutscenes are at 60fps, which is a strange choice, as they seem to be in-engine, and not pre-rendered. This change of fps can be jarring if you are running a high refresh-rate monitor, but it is not a problem for the most part.

Controls on keyboard and mouse are completely fine. There are some moments when you want to hold down a few too many buttons at the same time, and there are some overly complicated situations, like having to click G, then 2, then F, then W to do a thing. There were a couple moments when I needed to press W and ALT and SPACE, left click and right click at the same time. No input lag, no mouse acc or smooth. 

Took me about 60 hours to beat the story. There is gameplay after the story is finished if you wanna keep delivering. Don't worry about how it fits into the story, it will make sense when you get there.

I did cry a couple times. If you know the game, you will know towards the end when the walk happens, with the music about seeing the sun setting. There was some real loud sobs, some real shaking ugly crying. A couple moments left me crying, saying "it's not fair" repeatedly, so that's a testament to storytelling.

A word of caution, many reviews show spoilers they don't deem spoilers. So does a lot of videos about tips and tricks. Let's say you buy the game and start playing it. Let's say you meet character A. Then you meet character B. In a video you watch on the Steam-page you see character A and B meeting. In the game you then see character A in a bad spot where they might die. You then remember that A and B haven't met yet, or that you haven't seen A do a specific thing in a cutscene yet. This makes you realize that A isn't going to die. Only watch as much as you need to before choosing to buy the game, especially if you get invested in the story.

All in all, as I said, this is not a game for everyone, but it is a game for me. If you wanna discuss this at all, my comments are open just for you.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Here's the thing with this game... I don't know whether to recommend it or not, but this is my second playthrough(first was on PS4) and I feel like the genius of Death Stranding unravels at a kind of glacial pace, but it does indeed reveal itself. Playing this game amidst the lockdown has really helped me out, as Death Stranding requires a bit of planning and endurance. You identify where you're going, and as the game progresses, the trips get a lot longer. The gameplay requires that you pay attention whilst on these treks across the landscape, but much of that time isn't particularly stressful or action packed. Death Stranding evolves into a kind of meditative experience, choosing routes and changing them on the fly as you encounter the realities of the terrain, staying balanced and pushing forward. It was no slouch on PS4, but on PC the game is breathtaking. It just seems like the landscape stretches forever, and it is hauntingly beautiful with the world being almost entirely void of humanity for much of the game. When battles do happen, they serve as a nice distraction from the travel, though the BT encounters can become a bit annoying at times, as they are less challenging than their disturbing presence initially suggests, and they can scatter your equipment around the landscape, making them a nuisance when you want to get your packages safely to their destination. I know this game will not be for everyone, but you know, the more I play it the more I see this as a kind of breakthrough for Kojima. Something like Death Stranding could only be done in a video game, demanding both patience and commitment, and rewarding you infrequently with exposition and narrative elements. It is a game that is unique in the sense that it stays true to its message of forging connections, and you will do this much more frequently than you beat up bad guys, which is why I believe the game is so divisive. In the end however, I've really never played a game like Death Stranding, and I think Kojima is to be applauded for that. It's a game that I believe grows on you the more time you put into it, and I think, given how unique the game is, everyone should give it a real shot and commit a bit of time, as the complete image of Death Stranding will not be revealed by playing it for a couple of hours.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: After all of the negative press about this being a walking simulator, I was reluctant. But, seeing as how I love everything put out by Kojima I wanted to give my support. Aside from the facial animation and the political undertones, this is a masterpiece.  Normally I dislike political statements in my entertainment but Kojima presents multiple points of view based on modern concepts and I appreciate this---this is more akin to the original Deus Ex in that they explored all theories and points of view even though the director clearly has a guiding philosophy. Very inventive in every way. The game play to the way players interact with one another as a single player game tied to the internet, to the way this multiplayer experience ties to the story line, to the twists and turns of the story... everything is polished. Yes, you are a delivery person but not like any other. The story is fun and imaginative. I recommend the game. Especially in the wake of the disappointment that is The Last of Us 2. Sorry to all my friends and colleagues who worked on the game. LOU2 is beautiful and the game play is smooth, but the story killed it and the games legacy. Anyhoo, you will enjoy Death Stranding if you even partially enjoyed the modern MGS games.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The most fun I have had with a new game in AGES. I cant stress enough how well Hideo Kojima polishes a game. This is a different experience, he didnt do the same tired formula over again, and there are a few whiners that wanted mindless shoot and loot , but this is about a story and an experience.

Gameplay: 10/10  so many wants to get the missions done
Story : 10/10  Strange, and compelling, thought provoking. After a play session the content stays with you
Graphics: 10/10 Soooo gorgeous , the landscape the environment that changes with the rain and your paths
Sound/Music: 10/10 , the sound track is beyond amazing, nothing more relaxing than being on a long walk and a low roar song comes on. The ambiance is spot on, the rainfall the snow. I loved it.

Over all this is a new type of gameplay for most people and if you keep an openmind I think you will enjoy this game as much as I did. I can see how its not for everyone, if you dont care about story and you enjoy shooting games more, this probably isnt for you, but that doesnt mean this game isnt great.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I played Death Stranding on the PS4 when it launched, it  has become one of my all time favorite games and the most unique and memorable game in the last years.

The game is beautiful and so is the story, the gameplay contrary to what you may think, is fun and sometimes challenging, from planing a route and choosing equipment to going through some hard terrain and overcome it. This is the type of game that has you so hooked up that you lost the time sense. 

The online aspect of the game is a big part of the experience where you connect with fellow porters and even if you are playing by yourself you will never feel alone, make sure to be connected to it when you play the game.

Edit: After finishing the game again, I can only say it's awesome, very well made port, not a single crash or bug and the performance is flawless, had no trouble in my 100% completion journey.

The Half-Life rewards are cool and helpful, don't forget to grab them.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Exactly what I expected from a Hideo Kojima game: an artistic masterpiece.

The theme of the game is about connecting people in a world where selfishness and isolation is what most people adhere to. This theme is present on the main protagonist, the game story, gameplay and multiplayer mechanics. At first you won't notice it. You will be overwhelmed by the hardship of traversing uneven grasslands, stones, mountains... the mere act of walking will be a challenge. Slowly this idea will sink in your mind. The idea that loneliness makes everything a challenge. Then the game connects you to other players. And you find yourself relying on people you haven't ever seen to cover tough ground.

This game breaks the 4th wall in so many ways. It is the kind of game you can just enjoy playing for the experience. You get attached to many characters and, sometimes, even to some cargo you're carrying on your back.

An experience you should consider going through!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I waited a year to play this game. Almost re-purchased a PS4 just to do so, but I'm glad I waiting for the PC release.

I can say without a shadow of a doubt, this game is a masterpiece, yet it's also for a certain type of player.

If you enjoy slow burns, rich gameplay, a truly passionate game dev team and director, a collection of familiar faces who are all friends, then you'll love this game.  

I feel this game is more relevant now than ever before given America's current situation. 

This game has one of the best digital performances I've ever seen in a video game by Tommie Earl Jenkins, Oscar worthy in my opinion. 

Truly an original story, new concepts and a feel train all the way to the end. I want more. 

I can't wait to see what Kojima Productions does next.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
9/10

I originally got this game on PS4 but only played to Mountain Knot city-which is only halfway or less through the game-but then stopped as I had other things come up. I decided to pick this game up on PC and was met with AMAZING performance increases and even better visuals.

The story and moments in between made me fall in love with the game. It is a refreshing open-world to play in as you must carefully consider what you take with you and where you go, and one which has rekindled my favor for open-worlds.
But it isn't perfect.
I find the controls clunky for combat, which made some encounters tricky, but did not ruin the experience for me. Sometimes Sam controls in a way I feel clunky too, even when I am not carrying a lot.

But other than that? I beat the story in 45 hours, and plan on continuing on Very Hard mode. Buy this game if you want a strong story and MMO's have made you used to fetch quests.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's not the worst game I've ever played.

Death Stranding feels like someone wanted to make a post apocalyptic game but all of the good ideas were taken so they made up a whole bunch of really weird stuff that doesn't make a lot of sense.  I don't mind a good walking simulator type game (Gone Home is one of my favorites) but if that's what it is, then just make it that.  Instead, there's a ton of filler content where you have to pick up random boxes that are scattered around and drop them in postboxes while trying to not lose your balance, while running from point A to B.  And the deliveries, even the main quests, feel very tacked on - like you have to take some morphine to an important person early on.  They even tell you they probably already have morphine there - it's a high tech facility.  They should just scrap the delivery stuff and make the quest just to travel there and speak to the person.

Maybe it gets better but after completing the first 4-5 quests the story still seemed kind of uninspired and illogical (they can secure all of these underground locations with super high tech but above ground is just too dangerous for anyone?) and I was already tired of delivering random boxes.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
My Official Verdict On Death Stranding: BUY IT

This review will be split into 5 SECTIONS: Gameplay, Story, Combat, Experience, Opinions

[GAMEPLAY]
Lets get the basics out of the way. This game [On PC] is optimized extremely well for most graphics cards and can push decent to great frames. Keyboard and Mouse are so easily integrated it DOES NOT feel like a console port, it feels like it was made for PC, and I respect Kojima for accomplishing that. AI in this game is very different and varies for sure. BT's will attack you if your loud enough (Example is if you fast crouch instead of slow crouching you make a decent amount of noise compared to slow crouching and holding your breathe makes a HUGE difference if you go for stealth kills). Mules get progressively harder once they aquire weapons they will do a lot more damage, but the weapons they use affect their skill and aim, so be careful when near their hideouts and areas (People say combat in this game isn't that good but for a Story driven game its on par with other games like LOUII and ghost of tsushima). Walking in this game DOES NOT take up as much time as people truly say if you are only playing to finish the story (about 10 hours of walking for 60 hours of gameplay, you'll be crouching, hiding, running, ect more than actually walking and doing nothing). Lastly multiplayer in this game functions very strangely but I think that's a good thing. So If you enjoy helping people by providing resources for others, building bunkers for everyone, bridges to making traveling a LOT easier, and get a TON of likes from real people for helping make their lives easier, I promise you'll enjoy it way past its story, if your into that sorta thing.

[STORY] [NO SPOILERS]
This is hands down a better story than 90% of games that have ever been made. This is not debatable. Its on the level of Halo, LOU, and RDR2. This story (If you can handle a little bit of walking) will take you on a emotional roller coaster and provide a very realistic sci-fi plot that is extremely creative and well thought out (Kojima is great with plots). The Begging, The middle, The End ALL reveal different ideas, entrances, moments, and gameplay. You never feel like your repeating anything (Yes walking is repeated all the way through, but honestly its like saying Riding a horse in ghost of tsushima takes up too much times and its annoying). The Characters are extremely developed in this game (Better than most TV Shows and Movies). Sam (Main Character) was the easiest to bond with because of how similar he is to you, the character, and Kojima knows how to take advantage of that. Every surprise, every choice had an impact to an extent, and the ending was breathtaking. If your not sure about buying this game, because someone told you its boring, they are dead wrong. This game has one of the greatest stories, plots, and development ever thought of. If you love a good story, this one will keep you thinking.

[COMBAT]
This game isn't exactly revolutionary when it comes to PvE, but it does it decently, enough to offer you a challenge. In the begging the game doesn't give you many weapons, most are non-lethal (Don't kill anyone = NO Voidouts). But once you start getting weapons, the games intensity goes up different stages. With new weapons unlocking, you'll also unlock new enemies and boss's to fight. For those who want a challenge HARD mode is required, as Normal mode might feel to easy and boring, trust me it makes many PvE scenerio's much harder and require much more skill (If your crazy and want a challenge start your first game in Hard Mode). Boss's Battles are mostly the same except three different strategies of boss battles (I won't spoil them because people should find out for themselves), there are 5+ boss's but some approach the player similarly, and you can fight some boss's repeatedly, and there are mini boss's (Red BT's).

[Experience]
This game isn't like other games, in fact its one of a kind, and that's a fact. This game adds realism, depth, progression, skill, tactics, multiplayer, combat, and development like no other before, in a very unique way of course. Kojima did something very different with this game, and it WILL require you to be able to accept the difference right at the BEGGINING, if you don't accept that, you wont enjoy it. Most people are used to the re-released products Game Companies sell every year, and by nature, we get used to them being the same, and this game is something you need to get used to very differently, because in essence its not a game, its a little bit of everything (Movies, Game, and Simulator). I do believe that the experience depends on a person's taste bud's, so if you only like a specific category of game, you might not like this, But if you like a wide variety of categories you might like it, you might not care. So the experience really depends on how willingly you are to embrace it, cause this is definetly a masterpiece, on a story level.

[Opinions]
Of course this is now my own idea and opinion on the approach the director and company decided to take with this game. I would also like to state I have played almost every category of game. Simulator's, FPS Shooters, Campaign's, Survival, City Builders, Horror, Multiplayer, Sports, etc. This game fits a lot into just one game, and it can be overwhelming if your not ready, since most people I know did not enjoy the game because of the walking it started to develop over time. That is the problem though, most gamers when they first start playing don't look at the bigger picture so they dismiss it instantly. That's why it upsets me that people are willing to stop playing a game because of something they are not even fully aware of. I know this might sound generic, but if your three hours into a game and you still don't know if you like it, question every part of the game and see if there is a chance you'r missing something, or not looking at it like the developer designed it to be enjoyed (It's like buying a Honda Civic when what you want is the most Fancy Sedan money can buy, and ruin your expectations of the civic). People need to stop thinking ahead of the game, but think about whats happening and whats being presented to you, thats' when you can start appreciating the game for what it is (Whether you like it or not). The story was TOP 3 in all of gaming history (I truly mean this, as I've poured thousands of hours into hundreds of games). The experience is something you will have NEVER experienced in any other games (Thats a fact). A lot of little details; High Detail in the Terrain (Looks like real life), Customizing your buildings and items, connecting bridges with online people, Sharing your resources with friends, walking through different types of terrain, and different types of encounters. This game is truly a masterpiece, I have never played anything like it, and I don't think I ever will again.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Easily - 9/10 (1 point lost on how the ending was planned, it could've been better; more on this at the bottom of the review)

Where do I begin with? I mean you obviously know how it looks and how everyone calls it a walking simulator. Then there are reviews who calls it a masterpiece by Hideo Kojima. And that is true.

To summarize my experience (finished the storyline in 29 hours, including the cutscenes): 
- It IS a masterpiece. 
- It is not much of a walking simulator. [spoiler] You get the bike in about an hour in the game and based on how you manage, you can pretty much have a ride throughout the game, except a few parts. Yes there are BTs, but you can always just nade them into oblivion, and keep riding on. Saves you a lot of time.[/spoiler]
- Sometimes terrain makes you feel like it'd be just easier walking but then you learn ways to ride through them anyway, by spamming boost + jump. 
- Visuals are stunning, story is also brilliant.
- It is nice to see that some eastern friends of ours have deployed bridges for you in the places you least expect it and you just have to appreciate the bridge being there, so you don't have to take a detour (if you don't have stuff to create the bridge, which often, you don't)

It's worth it, overall.

Now the only thing that I think that was mildly annoying was, how it ends. I believe at the 23-24th hour I was at a point where I thought, "Ah, the ending boss fight", and then there was some more little gameplay inside and outside of the "BEACH", and I believe this happened for the next few hours until it actually ended. They try to explain everything in the end, which kind of makes sense but it would've been better if it was much better spread across in-between the game, than just throwing it all on us at the end.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Pretty awesome and unique storyline this game has. Honestly pretty decent in length as well. I 100% recommend this game, especially if you are into single player story games.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: if you're looking for a shooty action game, this ain't it. if you're looking for an original game that takes risks and nails what it's trying to do, this is it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a stunning game with great mechanics that I really enjoyed. The story was incredible and at times found myself racing through the game just to get to the next cinematic portion of the story. Walking through the wasteland and listening to the well picked music for the game was also just another bonus. I hope that other developers use the frame work from this game and create a great open world survival game. For new players the beginning of the game was very annoying specially when you find out your really just a delivery boy. I promise it gets better, the beginning is like a very long tutorial and eventually opens up.

Some things I did find annoying was the animations of getting in and out of vehicles though it looked great, it became very annoying when you need to get out and pick up the next lost cargo. speaking of vehicles, the truck will make you want to break your monitor when trying to navigate through uphill rocky terrain, hitting one of the million rocks and turning your truck just to watch it slide all the way back down to the bottom. I also ran into my vehicles acting crazy and going forward quickly and not being able to stop it.

With that being said I very much recommend this game. Now a days its not often that you pay $60 for a game and feel like you got your moneys worth out of it. I have no regrets paying for this game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I have been a long time fan of the Metal Gear Solid games and the creators behind it, and I can say that this gives me goosebumps to see the amount of detail put into the landscapes. The words "Walking Simulator" could not be more accurate. Before you purchase this game, just know that if you are in the market for a fast paced, run-and-gun shooter, this is NOT the game for you. Gameplay can almost resemble a movie, where if you do not watch the cut scenes, you leave much of the depth of the game behind. 
So, to wrap up my review:
If you are a gamer that prefers visuals over anything, this is the game for you. Long deliveries can take up to half an hour to accomplish, and if you do not care much about the landscape around you, the game can seem a bit 'boring' to say the least. 9/10

Use left/right mouse button to balance.

i5 8500 3.0Ghz
Ram 16GB
GTX 1070 8GB
Installed on SSD

P/S 2: My suggestions for beginners, after you reach Chapter 3, then start doing Standard Delivery for everyone in East Region (The map from beginning) and Central Region (The second map when you reach Chapter 3). The reason to do Standard Delivery in Chapter 3 is:

- In Chapter 3 you have unlocked a lot of new stuff that make your delivery trip more easier.
- Some NPC will unlock new stuff for you when they reach 3 4 5 stars. Stuff will make your delivery trip more and more easier.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is really pretty, although very bland. The "gameplay" consists of walking. That's it. you walk from one settlement to another, playing on "very hard" in the search for any form of difficulty just means more micromanaging of your footsteps, because that's their way of making a walking simulator any fun, QTE's while walking across flat ground and the occasional slope. The story to this game is so obtuse and off the rails (Yeah, Kojima made this, his name pops up many many times throughout the first few hours) and the cutscenes are 20 minutes long each because they honestly need to be, but they don't even use that time appropiately to explain how this utterly insane world came to be or how anything works. You're just along for the ride after you run some errands... I won't spoil it the story and that's half because i don't have any clue what's going on lmao. The "gameplay" is what leads me to give this a thumbs down, my god is it boring AND a chore

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death Stranding is a bit difficult to get into, but after the first few hours you're able to get a grasp on the controls, but also the story, which honestly is pretty weird at the beginning. I stopped playing after the first two hours and wrote it off as a boring walking simulator like most people, but there was something about it that made me pick it up again. i'm very glad I did. After breaking through those two barriers, I found it pretty fun to navigate the map and plan deliveries while also unfolding the stories of the different people you meet along the way.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This is my first review ever on Steam even though my library consists of more than 500 titles. But i had to write review about this game! First of all i am not a Kojima fanboy whatsoever but this game is piece of art. Among hunders of games that come out each year this is a first fresh breath that i have seen in a long time. This game is simply amazing and a must for anyone who loves story driven games. Also its originality is something i havent seen in gaming industry in a long time. A must play game for sure.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Okay I 100% Death Stranding after 107 hr, here are my thoughts:

Overall I liked the game, it's a good game but I don't think it's amazing or a masterpiece. The game has some phenomenal concept but it stumbles a lot in execution. 
The games visuals looks amazing 👌. The cinematography, the direction and performances are top notch.
The gameplay is a mixed bag. I liked the delivery mechanics and controls but the combat and vehicle handling are horrible.
As far as story goes I liked the story, lore, world, it was interesting and unique but the pacing was way off, Way too much exposition dump and lot word but saying nothing, sometimes dialogues are soo bad. Sometimes serious moments are ruined by corky things. Using weird names making things harder to understand than they are.
The characters are also a mixed bag. I didn't care for most of the characters, I liked Cliff, Deadman and the relationship between Sam and baby. 
With that being said I still applaud Kojima's team for coming up with a unique new IP in the age sequels and reboots. I hope in the future they iron out these issues with the sequel or the next game.

OVERALL RATING: 7/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Bizarrely amazing game. A lot of walking. A fair amount of sneaking. Rebuilding a whole goddamn highway from coast to coast. And it'll draw you in into this cycle of building and extending structures to ease the travel from A to B as well as employing other players' structures. 
The multiplayer aspect is indirect and gives a sense of hundreds of invisible players through the marks they leave on your game. 
The story itself is quite interesting with many unique sci-fi elements and some cliches but that needn't necessarily be a bad thing. The acting and voice acting is fantastic. The world itself is gorgeous. 
A singularly unique experience that I hope more games would strive for.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Honestly I can't explain to any worthy amount of justice why I enjoyed this game so goddamn much but I will try, it is such a one of a kind Hideo Kojima experience that will leave you confused out of your goddamn mind more often than you could possibly expect. It has been a long time since I have bought a game and only played that game without other games in between until I finished it. I bought it on a Saturday night and played it straight through the weekend and for every week day I played it with all of my free time after work until I beat it today on Friday. I came into it thinking I was going to experience a bad story, shitty gameplay, non-immersive atmosphere, and basically a glorified walking simulator with the full intentions to refund it after the 2 hour mark. But I put 9 straight hours into it first go, didn't even get up to get a water, something about it just enthralled me and I experienced none of the fears I expected. I constantly felt motivated and interested in pushing forward through the game to understand that little bit more the game teases you with and left satisfied. If you want the type of game that you haven't experienced that will blow you away and you got the patience to burn about 40 hours of time, for most people this might just be it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Amazing story. Possibly the most stable port I've played. Gameplay-wise...yea, you are a delivery man. The real magic though is the fact that you get to build the world to make your and other player's life easier. Surprisingly I found myself gathering materials to build roads (some of which were contributions by other players). Seeing how the worlds changes is a big reason (for me) to come to the game even after I finished it and keep playing. Graphics are stunning also. It's not perfect by any means (boss battles are abit meh, bt's mech0nix are more annoying than interesting) but overall I can say that I enjoyed the experience. Overall rating: 7/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Don't buy this unless you want to play something that takes risks and has a ps1 era feel when it comes to how nonsensical the world is. Most of its appeal to me is piecing together lore and trying to understand what is going on. There is a lot to unpack and definitely is confusing since most of it is abstract. An excessive use of metaphors and symbolism may lead to you getting bored or annoyed. 

Most of your time will be in cut-scenes and walking. combat exists and can be difficult if you are too wreckless or play on the higher difficulties, which I recommend if you want the tension to stick throughout the game. Normal is just to make it as accessible as possible by default. Most gameplay is traversing the environments and overcoming obstacles. There is not constant action but when action occurs it can be intense but once you learn how these sections work they can be easy, which is why I recommend playing on Hard or Very Hard difficulty. Learning Sam's (Norman Reedus) limitations is key to not flubbing deliveries, and these limitations improve as you take on different types of deliveries,

As for the PC port itself, I have only had one issue. A bug from my gpu driver not being up to date, caused models to not render properly, which was fixed when updated. A common issue seems to be a frame rate stutter for others, but I'm not having that issue. I don't think it's hardware limitations since people that have better hardware are having the issue. I'm not sure what quality of life improvements where made for the port specifically, but a lot of the time wasting functions like the sensor activating when entering BT areas can be altered to not stop and do a small cut-scene every time. which I agree got annoying when going in and out of them constantly.

The visual presentation is very impressive. It's what makes the long treks more bearable if you appreciate that kind of thing, which I do. Character models have some ridiculous detail, like Normie Reedus' armpit hair. 

In conclusion, If you aren't sure about it, wait until a sale price you are more comfortable wasting in case you don't enjoy it. However, if you want to enjoy some dumb nonsense and a game that is exactly as intended by the minds behind it then go for it. A certain mindset is required to enjoy it. Don't take it too seriously, but analyzing it can be part of the enjoyment.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
To call this game a walking sim might be a fair assessment. It got a lot of flack when it was released on playstation for that fact, people called it "boring"! oh no! Well, with the tag on Steam you know exactly what to expect. But the walking is the game. There is even strategy in the walking, in navigating the subtle undulations in the ground or setting your desired course, there is plenty of gameplay in the act of walking. 
Bottom line is, I have fun with this game. Navigating the land is fun. Sneaking around BT's is fun. Holding a package in my hand and smacking someone in the face is fun. Finding structures made by other players, building bridges other players can use, yes, it is all fun for me.

The only thing I don't really like is fighting the BT's. Maybe I haven't mastered the system yet, as fighting the human enemies became fun after a little practice. Maybe it's not supposed to be fun but if I trigger a fight I'll reload a checkpoint and try to sneak better which is fun.

All in all, if you know what to expect, you should do alright with this game

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Another amazing story by Hideo Kojima with amazing graphics! I don't normally do reviews, but was so thankful this was ported to PC and not just on console. I have spent nearly 100 hours in game. 

Like I said the story is amazing and the graphics are fantastic. There are new mechanics in this game that I hadn't experience before and actually enjoy, I do realize that the game mechanics of being a courier in a post apocalyptic world may not be for everyone. However, there are lots of opportunity for combat with enemies with use of all types of weapons and I like the possible consequences of using lethal force.

You have the option of quickly running through the story or spend time in the world and help reconnect/rebuild it.

Thank you Mr. Kojima and Kojima Productions for a great game!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is quite possibly the best video game I've ever played, and I've been playing video games avidly since I got an NES for my 5th birthday in 1988.

It's very hard to do the game justice in words. Put it this way, this game is more than the sum of its parts, and the parts (individual mechanics -- everything from managing cargo weight/distribution to stealth invasions of enemy camps to a resident evil style literal bloodbath that will often pop up and continued to scare the s*** out of me after many encounters) are all perfect. 

The reason for that is the online/community aspect and the way that fits into the themes of the story, which starts out seeming very convoluted and frankly sort of dumb and, as you work your way through the game, it feels like you are filling in the gaps with your own actions. And your actions are comprised mostly of just delivering things to people! Anyway, the story starts to really click and make sense, and the way you kind of discover that along the way is worth the price alone, but the online part is really what makes it stand out as a potential GOAT.

I love that you can share items and resources with other players, create buildings and structures with multiple players all pitching in materials, and find cargo other players lost and deliver it for them. It inspires a sense of hope. It's a timely thing to experience right now, and it honestly ends up feeling great that you've helped other people - pretty ingenious the way the creators kind of harnessed the Facebook/social media positive feedback loop and managed to make it work in the game. But after climbing a really tough mountain or getting stuck in a crazy river that badly damaged your cargo, building a bridge or a zipline, etc., that other players (and you) can use to make it easier next time, it feels like all the hard work was worth it. I really don't think it'd be near as satisfying if this were a single player offline game and you only had access to structures you'd built and nothing else. 

10/10 would burn my mother in an incinerator again (I realized every line in this review has probably been written in prior reviews so ending it with something i feel almost certain appears in reviews posted before mine)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If you enjoy Kojima's all-around weirdness, this game may be for you.
If you enjoy hiking through a post-apocalyptic wasteland, this game may be for you.
If you enjoy medium resource management with a low grind, this game may be for you.
If you enjoy reinforcement-only multiplayer mechanics, this game may be for you.

If you're looking for action-packed or clear-cut, this game may not be for you.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I was skeptical to leap at a game I'm unsure about, I have never been so glad that I took the leap.
Lets break it down into Pro's and Con's

Pro's
     - A refreshing game inside a very stagnant industry, the gaming industry is stagnant with tons of the 
        "same" game, Death Stranding is not like any other game.
     - Very story Rich. 
     - This game makes you cry in all the right ways

Con's
     - Very long cinematic's (Not exactly a con as the story is amazing, but it creates a sort of get to the game 
         anxiety)
     - Combat mechanic felt clunky at times, To add to that some enemies are laughable as combat felt more 
          like a three stooges skit.
     - Vehicle Physics, my constant complaint throughout the entire game was how vehicle collision's would 
          cause hilarious flying car/bike incidents.

Overview:
      This game was absolutely fantastic, I laughed, I cried, but more importantly i had an absolutely great time traversing the broken UCA. This game is a refreshing breath of air in a relatively cookie cutter gaming industry, It is not only just unique, it is a Masterpiece. 
If you're debating on buying this game, DO IT. Death Stranding is a well lengthened game with tons of turns and surprises that will keep you enthralled by its mystery.

Overall: 9/10, would purchase again, will play over and over

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Unlike any game I've played before. It's like a cross between a AAA game and a studio film. If for no other reason, I'd recommend playing it simply for how unique it is.

Edit: Having played this game for 20 hours now, it's clear just how generous it is with content. It takes about 15 hours to really open up. Some may say that 15 hours is too long of a wait, but I'd argue that if the creators jammed all of the different systems and nuances this game has into a shorter amount of time that the player would be overwhelmed. It's a slow burn, but very worthwhile.

Wasn't sure if that was me or just the games I was playing. But this game had me so invested constantly. During deliveries its not as simple as some might call a "walking simulator". There are so many things to watch out for and you constantly have to plot your course and make adjustments where necessary so your brain never has a chance to turn off while making them. And the story, man. I just remember crying for the last 30 minutes of the last segment of the game. Great acting and great work from the entire development team. In my opinion this is the most important game made since 2000 at least.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Game with some interesting concepts. The story, atmosphere, and landscape are the primary selling points of this game. So, if you are into that, you may enjoy this game. But for me personally, the game play is not appealing enough. Perhaps the makers should have just made a movie or tv series instead? My concerns about the game play are three-fold. First, the movie like cut scenes are nice at first, but eventually they just felts repetitive and some rather unnecessary. The first couple of hours in, you basically spend watching cut scene to cut scene. After playing a little, there are many less engaging cut scenes that take way too long for my taste. Second, the game play comprises of the game throwing annoying obstacles on the player's path. I see that developers tried their best to make the game not feel 'annoying.' However, its main premise is overcoming difficult and hostile territory. I am not sure how appealing such game play is for a broad audience in the long run. Lastly, some things can be explained or designed better. I.e., how some controls and mechanics work and what some items do. Even after playing a few hours, I struggled to use important items and understand how some things work even after the game has repeatedly instructed me about it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't review games as much, so long as the're getting their rightful praises and recognition. However, this game, no, this masterpiece has been so controversial, being called a walking simulator, a huge disappointment from kojima and so on, that I had to write a full review as soon as i finished it! 

To begin with, i always expect the most out of kojima's work, following metal gear solid v: the phantom pain being a tremendous accomplishment even though it was never fully completed and had alot of missing parts, while just because it granted the player freedom, making it a masterpiece among pc games. Death stranding also grants the player freedom in a variety of ways, from controlling how they'll be getting from point A to point B to how many packages are you willing to challenge yourself to handle. I never seemed to feel the sense of repetition, as different deliveries required management of different terrains and the vast amount of devices and tools you'll be granted will never cease the excitement of heading out on a fresh new journey. 

The game's graphics and optimisation is one of the few you'd see nowadays in new games, mostly they just want you to own top of the line hardware, on the other hand, kojima is like HELL NAW, everyone's getting a chance to play this game at 60 fps and definitely have same beautiful experience. The music is out of this world, and captures memorable moments strongly as you journey across america (fictional & based on Icelandic landscapes). The gameplay is surprisingly smooth, and i felt super comfortable with keyboard and mouse as my main controls, although the vehicles are somehow stuck to the ground and it's physics are terrible, but still manageable after getting used to, on the contrary it encourages walking, climbing and running through the amazing landscapes, or stealth through a mule's camp or terrorist occupied land, and only not missing on a single experience or to using roads. Roads which you'll be required to rebuild with materials & ofc. with the online social experience of players helping out, we repaired all roads leading around the map, makin' it easier for players to grind at a faster pace to complete achievements and connect america again

Lastly, the story and OMFG it is a masterpiece, it's how i want next generation line of games to inspire to be. The innovation behind it is absolutely stunning, while konami took metal gear and turned into a zombie game that no one was interested in, kojima just straight up invented new type of paranormal monsters that will make you feel more intense and legit sometimes freaked out. I'm not gonna give out any details, as being curious and figuring stuff out as you play along is what sold the game for me. 

So to summarise like every other person here on steam

Positives:
+++ story
+++ ending 
+++ graphics
+++ music
+++ Boss fights
++ gameplay


Negatives:
- vehicles
- no option to play music as you free roam

I've never thought i'd say this, but im glad silent hills was cancelled for this game.

9.5/10 - god damn it kojima, you've done it again. Worth every penny i paid at full price!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If you can get past the "walking simulator" memes, and aren't one of the morons who expected MGS6, this game is tight. A lot of people have said "just wait until Episode 3, it gets better," but imo, if you aren't in by then, you probably won't ever be. It's more or less the same gameplay from beginning to end, you just get access to more tools as the game goes on. You're still just delivering things for people, though. It had me hooked within the first few hours, and it only got better from there, for me, personally.

Anyway, it's basically an overworld travel game. If you've ever played D&D, overworld travel there is basically always ignored. You might get some random battles, but most likely you'll just get narrated from town to the dungeon entrance. The gameplay in Death Stranding is completely centered around traveling between destinations, to an extent that I don't think I've ever seen before. As you overcome obstacles, the game provides you with new tools to help deal with them the next time. It comes up with new challenges, you get new tools, and this cycle goes all the way through the end of the game.

I played the game on Hard, but honestly, most of the game was still kind of easy. I'd recommend Very Hard, honestly. You can change the difficulty up or down mid-game, so definitely try it out on a lower difficulty, but bump it up if you realize you're enjoying it. Very Hard also adds at least one new mechanic, so there's that, too.

The plot is your usual Kojima fare. It's wildly confusing for pretty much the whole game, as it basically doesn't explain anything for quite a while. It does start making more sense, and the "interview" data the game periodically gives you helps a lot with understanding what's going on (you do have to read it, though). You can also unlock some interviews from doing some of the "Standard Orders", aka sidequests, which I wish I'd known from the start, since the game otherwise leaves a few mysteries unexplained.

Honestly, if I didn't have other games that I wanted to play, I'd probably keep playing it past the ending. There's a lot of extra stuff to unlock and discover, like new customization options, equipment, and probably more that I don't know about. And honestly, I was having a lot of fun.

I would talk more about specific things, but honestly, I feel like the game benefits from discovering those things as it goes on. You'll experience a good amount of what I really liked about it within the first 5-6 hours. It does not take until Episode 3 (about 10ish hours in). I [i]highly[/i] recommend it, so long as you expect it to be a game about traveling, and NOT a game about stealth action.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Awesome game! Just make sure you know what you're buying. 

This is a walking simulator. You walk through a desolate wasteland carrying cargo. The challenges are optimizing what you carry, optimizing your route, navigating difficult territory, and avoiding or fighting enemies. Fighting is easy if you have the right equipment, but every piece of equipment you carry is less room for cargo. The more you carry the harder it is to navigate too. There are vehicles but they're of limited use. All of this stuff is all executed perfectly and the game is a blast to play, but if that didn't sound like fun you probably shouldn't buy it

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hmm? I am absolutely in love with this game, the story the feel of the thing. I wasn't really sure if they would be able to pull it off but they have really made something different here, something special. I guess if you are looking for something with a lacklustre story and no end of pointless shooting? Then this is not the game for you. Like a good book, if you allow yourself to slow down and become engrossed in the characters and story this game comes alive, it really does. 

If there are any negatives, it's the scale of the States which is off, I am a quarter the way across the States and I feel like I've run, ridden 4 or 5 miles in game, that is clearly not right, (little disappointing) but hey its a game right? My real world hiking experience is playing tricks with my brain whilst playing it unfortunately. Still, as someone who long distance hikes the terrain in the game is absolutely beautiful just to look at, the screen camera option is going to be used and hammered way too much for 3440 x 1440 screen grabs for my desktop.     

No, it's a beautiful game and I am glad i didn't listen to some of the naysayers posting here about it being just "a walking simulator", it's so much more than that, It's a beautiful game and it's unique.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I finished this game last night and now I've had time to ruminate on it a bit I reckon that's one of the most satisfying gaming experiences I've ever had. It's not necessarily the best game in any specific area but as a whole package it's really, properly good. 

I expected at least a vaguely interesting (if baffling) story from Hideo Kojima but what I got was an absolutely insane yet incredibly creative supernatural/sci-fi story where the supremely  camp and the genuinely horrific were mixed to perfection, where every thread and arc was concluded in a satisfying way and with every element of gameplay + mechanics tying in to reinforce the themes the story was presenting. Absolute masterclass on games as art.

The main gameplay loop probably isn't for everyone (Deliver this cargo from point A to point B, repeat for 40-50 hours) but I found it engaging and deeply satisfying. 

I strongly recommend playing this game through to the end if you're even slightly interested in seeing how games can offer unique story experiences that you can't get in any other medium. Also to anyone who is intrigued by the idea of a game in which you throw bottles of your own piss at angry ghosts.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Love it ,
Highly recommend playing on 'very hard' difficulty. - Be the true Legend of Legends of Legends!
The game has lots of mechanics that unfortunately get underutilized on normal and even hard difficulty, you'll find you'll hardly ever need to replenish your stamina, take a rest at a shelter, change your boots that much, or have to care about repairing your cargo all that much - it's only ever just enough to make it not simply "walk from place to place". It actually feels like this is how the game is meant to be played - you actually feel the impact and care of each delivery in a more meaningful way with greater challenge and having Sam be completely exhausted. Plus the game gives you more credit and awards for doing so, which is also nice.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
POST FINISHING THE STORY: I still think this game is pretty great :) I didnt like the story all that much and thought it was too cliche and predictable but the gameplay was enjoyable for me and made up for it

Let me start off by saying that the fact that this game is made by "Hideo Kojima" means almost nothing to me, I am not a fan boy, I have played one maybe two games made by this creator in the past and mostly I just find them to be okay. (not saying they are bad games they just aren't my thing)

THIS GAME. However, this game takes so many risks its absolutely CRAZY when it comes to creativity. It is extremely weird but quite damn engaging. The story telling and dialogue can still be a bit cheesy and a bit weird at times but if you can look past that (with the help of some fantastic acting and character animation this is not that hard to do which is why Im still enjoying the story) this game offers something not many other games companies or even indie game companies would DARE to do. Deliver something SOOOOO outrageous it makes you think the writers need to see some kind of psych because of the stuff going on in there head, having game developers and planners that come up with ways to make walking and engaging as hell experience for people that would rather play a game with mechanics of walking than do it ourselves and then graphic designers that make a bunch of rocks, rivers and grass turn into beautiful landscapes whilst not turning your computer into the sun and melting it through the floor of your house.

IT IS VERY well made and whilst it does have some flaws I cannot think of a single game like it and although I may not be done or close to done and thus I have no idea how well the story evolves, one thing is for sure it is a story I will never forget having you dumbfounded and amazed all at the same time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Gameplay is diversified from transporting, traversing, co-op construction to help one another, and combat. The writing, meanings, concept, etc, is top notch and very deep. Think MGS in terms of deepness, but rather than twists and turns, it's more about correlations to societies collective sentiments and the state of the modern human's general quality of life, and being detached yet attached. The parallels that are drawn are what get me the most... on top of the MULE-esque construction addiction.
