review: Perfect game from Kojima. Yeah You are a Courier, but not only that. Story of this game is just breathtaking, unbelievable. Everyone must see this. Not everyone will like game mechanics and bringing packages all the time, but if You do... You will be suprised how the story is a masterpiece. Waiting for Death Stranding 2.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A game where you are a UPS delivery driver and your goal is to deliver peoples packages. However, there are some inaccuracies to real life UPS delivery that I think are worth mentioning.

-The game world is completely unrealistic and there are ghosts, magic crystals and terrorists.
-People turn into bombs when they die.
-Everyone has a private beach.
-Everyone you deliver a package to is incredibly polite and always thanks you and cares about you, even if you do a bad job.

Despite this, the game is very high quality with very few things that ruin the game. I wouldnt say its perfect and combat is generally a bit unfun, but the game is still fun overall and very enjoyable. Its a very long game, the 57 hours I put into the game were on one playthrough that I did not 100%, but worked here and there to complete certain aspects.

Highly recommended if you dont know anything about it, going in completely blind is preferable for the experience.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's a Meditation experience through and trough.
In this game the story doesn't matter that much as the gameplay is the main focus of the game.
So before buying consider this : This is the "DHL simulator". You will be walking, running, falling, delivering packages, fighting paranormal beings and normal humans.

However the game is Centered around package delivery and the goal to "Unite America".
In order for you to deliver packages more efficiently and more safely you will be building bridges, ladders, ropes, Safe stations,Generators, zip-lines, roadways, Bikes,trucks, Exoskeletons (to help you carry more weight). These however degrade over time, especially under the effect of rain (Timefall) as the rain is abnormal and it ages anything it touches, this mechanic will force you to re-think your delivery route as the rain damages your Parcels and vehicles alike: will you wait inside in a cave for the rain, snow to pass ? Are you going to go around the storm and all the "baddies" that are present in the storm ? Or are you going to go Rambo on the rain and paranormal beings and push through the storm ?

In any case, the game might not be for everyone as it is not your usual action packed Shooter.
As this game was directed by one and only Hideo Kojima, people who liked his metal gear series should feel right at home when playing his newest masterpiece. 
So the Evaluation of things separately :
Gameplay and it's mechanics :  8.5

Story : 6.0
Hideo Kojima game with weird Story, not understandable for mere mortals, usually has a deeper meaning hidden inside of it, Even Norma Reedus main actor who plays the main character in the game Doesn't fully understand the story

PC Port optimization and Graphical aspect : 9.0

 As for 2020 the game runs smooth on old generation GTX Cards 1060-1080 should handle the game no problem on 1080p 60 FPS
 (On my specific rig I could get a stable 100 FPS)
Asus Nvidia GTX 1080 Strix
Intel I7-4790K
DDR3 2133HZ 16GB Ram

The game is advised to be played on a controller, as it really immerses you more with the Vibration feedback from your controller, helping you balance the packages, detect enemies and other.
Also controller will assist with the sneaking sections as there might be a few.
One grind on my side is the shooting itself, as I'm not used to play shooters on controller that part was kind of hard, so on full action shooting sections i Would switch to PC controls, that however only applies to people who are not used to controllers, so if you are cod or halo junkie on a console you shouldn't have a problem.
Hopefully the review gave you at least some insight on the game if not my apologies(This is my first review after all ;) )

review: Only a few hours in and I love this game. The graphics are incredible, probably the best of any game I've played. Yes the core mechanic of the game 'deliver cargo from place A to place B' could be described as repetitive, but for me it was never boring. The ever present threat of BTs or Mules (which, certainly so far for me in the game, You are going to encounter one or the other, or both on every delivery) keeps the gameplay loop quite exhilarating. Trying to be stealthy and dodging invisible enemies that are only visible while stationary is fantastic. If you're unfortunate enough to get caught by Bts, the ensuing struggle is a stress enducing and frantic. I definitely think this game is far from boring.

No basic, rudimentary understanding. It is THAT insane. Quite honestly...It ruins it. Its like meeting a really hot girl at a bar but she cant speak english - she can only communicate by drooling and poking herself in the eyeball - you can get past that...but then you find out she is also a man who has a fetish for tentacles. Also she doesnt live close by, she lives in a another dimension that consumes their own bodily excrement for nutrition. And before sex she makes you watch 20 minutes of cut scenes about a beach with dead whales on it and a dream catcher. It sounds insane but that makes more sense than the story in this game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] You don't have to be a Kojima fanboy to love this game. [/h1]

I've never been a massive fan of Kojima, ever. I played the MGSV demo thingy way back in 2014 (?) and that's the only real piece of content I've consumed from Kojima.

Even so, I love Death Stranding so far. Of course, the game isn't for everyone, but I am thoroughly enjoying my time with it. The way you have to think about everywhere you go, having to plan around MULE territory, BT territory, Timefall patterns, etc. You have to think about every step, as one foot in the wrong place can send you barreling down a massive hill. The systems put in place make something as mundane as walking into something engaging and fun. Crouching and holding my breath while I make my way around BTs, being careful of where my feet land in order not to fall and create noise was truly engaging and scary. The music is also incredible, with an indie track slowly creeping in as you make your way up a hill and are awarded with a beautiful view of the landscape. And those graphics.. absolutely incredible, and on top of all that it runs amazing even though I barely meet the recommended specs.

I wouldn't recommend this game to everyone, but if you're looking for something relaxing and engaging, I'd recommend picking this game up at full price. 100% worth it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
As a gamer of the past 20 years I've developed a 6th sense about what games are worth purchasing.  I was hesitant to buy this game at first based on the trailers I saw a while ago but knowing Hideo Kojima and the bar he sets for the games he's developed I decided to take a plunge on this game.  

After pouring in so many hours into this game I can say without a doubt it's exceeded my expectations in delivering an experience I wasn't expecting at first.  This is probably one of the most memorable games I have ever played since I was a child.  It was absolutely worth the $60 I paid and it's a crying shame this game hasn't sold as well as Hideo expected it too because it deserves it.  I would go as far as to say this is probably a better game than any of the Metal Gear games he's produced.

Story - 10/10
Game play - 10/10
Graphics - 10/10
Sound - 10/10
Longevity - 10/10

If you are looking for a gaming experience that's different and will leave a lasting impression this is the game for you.  The game play is repetitive for the majority of the game cause you are doing deliveries most of the time but the beauty of it is you can approach each delivery however you want.  Also there are weapons later into the game that makes it more fun.  Everything else about the game is AAA can't get better than this.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The joke is that this is a walking simulator.  And to a degree that is correct, the same way GTA is a driving simulator. 
What this game really is: All of Hideo Kojima's crazy ideas as a game director put into an intricate physics based movement system (you need to keep your weight and weight distribution in mind as you are ascending and descending different terrain types, thankfully there is a very easy auto-distribution in the cargo screen). 

You get a very interesting and weird world that you are dumped into, stealth elements where you are trying to avoid invisible creatures that can hear you breath, and some action-stealth elements in fighting or sneaking past the MULEs (crazy people who want to steal your cargo and equipment to get an endorphin hit off "delivering" something)

And on top of it, as you expand the game features you built into the environment (like ropes and ladders to navigate cliffs, or more permanent structures like bridges) become shared online, and you also suddenly have access to other peoples work.  Even pathways forming in the dirt from people traveling the same path repeatedly.

Is this game for everyone?  No.  
Is this game MGS?  A little but not really? 
However if you like the stealth elements of MGS, the incredible level of detail Kojima drives for, and a weird  plot about invisible soul monsters in post-apocalyptic America; give it a shot.

Now if only I could figure out why I'm so thirsty for Monster Energy Drinks.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Bit of an essay below, but there's a tl;dr at the end :)

After managing to avoid any and all spoilers since the game was released on PS4, I finally got to experience it for myself on PC. I'll start this review by saying what many others have already said - this game is not for everyone. If you aren't the kind of person to get invested in a long, singleplayer narrative that takes place largely through cutscenes, then what you're left with is gameplay that many label a "walking simulator", with intermittent sections of stealth or action that can often be avoided entirely. However, if story is something that you value, then what you'll find here is a [b]compelling narrative[/b] set in a very unique and interesting universe, with a cast of great actors to carry it. The acting and delivery can at times be a bit hit or miss, perhaps because of the writing, but the parts that 'miss' are often not important enough to detract from the storytelling. Some of the cutscene sequences are phenomenal - Mads Mikkelsen especially stole the show, and his character's backstory was so interestingly woven into the main storyline that I found myself excited to learn more (this game has plenty of cool reveals, and an important plot twist to boot). I previously quoted "walking simulator" - well, if you are invested in the story, these walking/delivery segments have a lot of meaning added to them, and I often found that the main reason I was continuing was to learn more of the story. Everything comes together at the end, and it feels amazing to finally understand everything (given that parts of the story can be confusing). 

The delivery segments are more than just 'walking', too. The game gives you a phenomenal [b]sense of progression[/b], dealing out various upgrades and new pieces of equipment over the course of your travels. A particularly unique feature that I love is [b]the ability to place down structures that will appear in the worlds of other real players[/b], and vice versa. You can award arbitrary 'likes' to such structures (or vehicles later on), and receiving likes on a bridge, zipline, etc that you yourself have placed down feels very gratifying. For some deliveries you will find yourself simply travelling from point A to point B, with only the terrain as your enemy. The environment itself is gorgeous - [b]this game is one of the nicest looking I've seen on PC[/b]. I often found myself stopping to take screenshots with the in-game 'Photo Mode', which allows you to pause time and apply various filters or photo effects to whatever scene it is you've captured. Sometimes, you'll find yourself doing deliveries that take you through hostile territory, and these hostiles come in one of two forms - BTs and MULEs/terrorists. A very unique and often intense mechanic revolves around the former - they are invisible enemies whose whereabouts are hinted at with a device that blinks based on proximity (and this device is hooked up to a baby, but that'll make sense if you play it for yourself). These segments can be quite spooky, and you always feel the atmosphere shift upon entering one of these BT areas. The latter, MULEs, are human enemies that are out to steal your packages. This is where I [b]recommend playing the game on hard or very hard[/b], because these encounters can be easy if you play it right - the MULEs go down easily and, especially later in the game, some of the equipment available to you can trivialise the fights. Nonetheless, MULE or terrorist encounters add a great spice to the gameplay. This game also features a few boss fights, and honestly the things you face in some of these (more so in the later ones) are breathtaking - I remember panicking on more than one occasion when something many many times larger than me emerged from the ground and started chasing me or flying around in the sky.

This game is great as a PC port. I'd say 99% of the time it [b]controls really nicely[/b], and despite there being heaps of mechanics everything feels very intuitive and smooth, with the same button being used for many purposes depending on the menu/context. The game is [b]very immersive[/b] thanks to a combination of the environment/atmosphere, story and sense of purpose, but another element that adds to this is the movement. Thanks to the need for [b]weight management, balance, being able to fall over obstacles[/b], etc, it really feels like you're in full control of the character (as opposed to typical WASD movement). The handling of one of the vehicles, namely the bike, occasionally feels a bit off - for example you can sometimes lose all momentum instantly when driving on uneven ground or when you hit a tiny rock or protrusion; arguably sort of unrealistic and annoying. This isn't something that occurs consistently though, for the most part the vehicles feel great and really help with the sense of progression. Sometimes they can trivialise deliveries (especially if roads have been constructed), and whilst this may sound like a bad thing, when you're actually playing it can be relieving after completing so many deliveries on foot. The same goes for the ziplines (which are essentially usable to skip entire areas of terrain) - they often trivialise deliveries, but after a difficult segment of trudging uphill through stamina-consuming snow, it can feel pretty good to be able to take a free ride to your destination. 

One last major point: [b]this game has a phenomenal soundtrack[/b], perhaps one of the most fitting that I've heard. Some really emotional songs play during important parts of the story, and other times you will be walking and you'll be hit with a sudden song that plays to break the silence, and to be honest it can be quite motivational. To make it better, songs are unlocked after you've heard them, and you can play them as you please in your private room (a feature of every major stop-off where you can rest). 

Lastly, here are a few random, minor game details that brought me amusement or otherwise just pleased me throughout my playthrough:
- don't quite know what I expected, but upon walking through a low doorway with a pile of containers twice my size on my back, a bunch of them got knocked off and that made me laugh for some reason
- whilst resting in the private room you can choose to drink to restore stamina, and in the later part of the game where beer is the drink of choice, he suddenly shook a can and let it explode onto the camera, saying 'right in your face'. surprised me and made me laugh
- you can urinate in snow and it melts (also you can control where you aim)
- half-life references (actual deliveries that you can choose to do which unlock you hl-themed goodies)
- oh yeah, there are three insane segments where [spoiler]you are placed onto battlefields (WW1, WW2, Vietnam, in that order) and it's honestly pretty mindblowing. really big shift from the ordinary gameplay cycle[/spoiler]

[u]Rating[/u]: 9/10

TL;DR - Masterpiece of a game with a few minor hiccups that, in my opinion, don't detract at all from the experience. I only recommend this game if you're likely to get invested in the story, because otherwise you may find the gameplay loop repetitive - and in a game about making deliveries, what reason is there for you to make them if you don't care about why you're doing it or who you're delivering to? Really good acting, really good actors, phenomenal soundtrack, beautiful graphics and environment - a great PC port.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The sense of ease, comfort, and peace I get from this game is like meditation. The visual style, technical graphics, sound and character design impress me beyond satisfaction every time I play. The story so far evokes a range of emotions from the cheesy lighthearted comedy of some side-quests, to the thought provoking deeply connecting emotional story of the main plot-line. I feel connected to this game. I feel connected to others players. I feel connected to myself. 

I am having issues with crashes and stuttering loading stop-starts while in-game. I've messed around with the graphics and my hardware settings, but I don't have the greatest PC, so it may be an issue my end. I can't recommend this game enough to everyone, it is an experience unique to the mind of Kojima brought to life by a brilliant team and executed with polish and heart.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is incredible, my rating is something that will only matter to me, but it's a 10/10 experience.

This isn't a game where the substance of the story is about 4 hours long and spread out across 40 hours of filler, it's story end to end and everything you do outside of required story events will frequently give you MORE pieces of the story and context. Investing in the story, paying attention, and not ignoring messages is incredibly rewarding as a result. If you can't invest yourself into playing the game you are doing yourself and the game a great disservice. There are dozens of questions I asked myself throughout my 104 hours about the story and each one was answered in time, by the end the entire experience just felt complete. I was invested enough to get everything in the game since much of the content rewards you with story and tools, I have the 100% "Greatest of Great Deliverers" achievement to testify that.

Gameplay is seemingly simple but brutal if you ignore the rules. Enemies are easy to deal with (I beat this on Very Hard) but can overwhelm you if you rush in, moreso if you didn't bring the right tools. 

If this game is a walking simulator, you're not using the tools you are provided. For me, I spent a good majority of the game in vehicles or using other buildable gagdets. Yes, there are walking mechanics but they're not difficult to manage passively, and many of the mechanics are made easier to handle simply through playing the game. 

If you're hung up about overblown hype just because it was made by Hideo Kojima I'd encourage you to ignore it and let the game speak for itself if you'd otherwise be interested, you would be missing out.

Overall I just wanted to address some common concerns I'd heard and to recommend it for people who want be part of a phenomenal story experience.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Overall: 10/10 This one's more than just a game... it's a simulator, a very long and beautiful movie/story, a unique and fulfilling experience, and more importantly... a brilliant work of art. I, like many others, took my time in the play-through. I just finished the final episode and let me just say that this is the most captivating game I've ever played. 

The story & character progression: Fair warning, as others have stated, it does start off slow. I promise this ends up being worth it as games need to have a feeling of character and story development; know that grinding through this slow start is simply just that. Enjoy the cut-scenes, as there are many at the start, and take in the story as much as you can. When it does pick up, it keeps picking up... I promise. Episodes get shorter and shorter as you start unraveling more and more of the story and you can't help but get further and further drawn to it. 

The soundtrack: absolutely f*** beautiful... enough said. Each and every song is presented at the right spot in the story to fit into the emotions of the moment, and I honestly don't think the choices could have been any better.

Gameplay: Intuitively unique... the system of "multiplayer" and helping others is extremely rewarding. The building aspect triggers the creativity of making routes and travel more efficient and to your liking, while at the same time making it available to others and building off what others have started to create your own world and system of travel. Combat is also unique and delicate... discouraged from using lethal weapons on anything living is a unique concepts that keeps the focus on being strategic with movement and combat that helped the feeling of personal development. The combat on the non-living (bt's, etc.) is also fun and engaging, as well as caters to multiple different preferences for combat; that being close ranged melee (cutting amb cord), long range AR, short range shotgun, grenades, rocket launchers... I mean it's not a combat focused game, so when it does come up, it's a thrill and is exciting to live through it. 

There's really so much more to be said, but to keep it short I'll just leave my final comment to this one is absolutely worth a try and a playthrough. I get that some may be discouraged by the pace at times, but if you're into really captivating stories and the ability to play through it - do it!

Only negative thing I can note is that there are some technical issues and limitations. For ex, my native reso is 3840x1080 UWD, but it's not a default supported reso, it's an easy fix to force to work, but just a heads up for those with odd resolutions like myself. I also had one occurrence where my save ended up corrupted and kept receiving an error when trying to load in... the support for the error was so vast and I had to spend a lot of time troubleshooting only to figure out it wasn't on my end and there was something wrong with the save; reverting a couple saves (about 10-15m back) resolved the issue and I didn't have any further issues from there.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Kojima's newest game didn't fail to be a unique experience. While not up to everyone's tastes, the gameplay is far beyond any "walking simulator" that games journalists lap up. There's a certain meditative feeling to it, most of the time when not throwing jarate at ghosts or aiming for the legs of any bandits, you'll be alone with your own thoughts, either of your own life or of the themes the game will hammer into you whenever you're not in control.
The boss fights are pretty lame and disappointing coming from the same man who designed Metal Gear Solid 3. Most of them are BTs that you just gotta lob grenades at and aren't challenging the skills you're developing alongside Sam.
Kojima's message of the importance of connections being important for humanity and using them to move on in the future are as subtle as a brick thrown in your window while a noisy jazz punk fusion band sings a song about how you should look out for that brick. But I wouldn't have it any other way.
All in all, a great game well worth the 40 or so hours it'll take for you to beat and the 60 dollars (or less depending on sales or price cuts). Not everyone's cup of tea, but a unique artistic experience that deserves a chance over any boring ubisoft AAA sandbox grindathon. If you value video games' potential as a valid artistic medium, you sure as hell want to play this game

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
What can I say....

I'm an older gamer, and the mechanics of the game (not the basic ones, but the social ones) took me a while to get used to. Now that I 'get it' I like them and they make sense (NOTE: playing with a controller).

The seemingly endless side-missions are a bit much. I wish there was a clearer distinction if they really matter or not. Maybe if player progression was more visible (and I'm not talking about the colored star filling in), that could help.

I also have to say... the BTs are getting OLD, FAST. I don't mind them on occasion, but when you've already cleared a route they should not be there again the next time you play a mission. Enough already. I wish I could just drive around areas that have already been cleared, take care of side missions, level up and learn more about the mechanics. Driving around, fast, on the reverse trike is fun!

Overall the game is visually well done, sound is good, voice acting is great. I just wish some of the annoying game play elements would be toned down. By the way, I am playing on 'normal' setting because lowering it impacts your progression speed to higher levels.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Where do I begin? I searched for reviews of this game before I purchased it and I felt that I knew what I was getting myself into.  That being said, the first couple hours are brutal. You're thrown into the wild, into a gruesome grind and I couldnt picture myself playing anymore of the game.
 I even asked for a refund (it was denied due to surpassing the two hour maximum). I cannot stress enough how happy I am that my request was denied. I kept playing and the game really opened up. The first boss fight was one of the best gaming experiences I have had in a while. It was like out of a movie. I Started my journey in the most difficult setting and I recommend the same to any gamer out there (exception would be if you dont really play much video games and dont have quite the gaming pallet). The tools you earn throughout the game are paced perfectly, always giving you just a little more to tackle even greater tasks.  This has become one of my favorite titles and has given me something video games have lacked in a long time; a true sense of adventure. If anyone is seriously considering purchasing this game I would look up non-spoiler reviews to see if it may be something you're interested in. If it sparks your curiosity, play on through and you will not be disappointed. I only wish that I could thank the developers myself for pushing gaming in the direction of the road less traveled, pun intended.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is quite possibly one of the most thought-provoking games I have ever played. You will hear from many people, myself included, that this game is a 'slow-burn' and that's absolutely true. Nothing however, could be more ideal for a game with such narrative ambition and complexity; you will *want* to take your time, not only for gameplay reasons but also to simply take in and understand the world you find yourself in. Some meals are best enjoyed with pace and Death Stranding is a pizza that needs to be taken one sumptuous slice at a time.

Some reviews will give you a synopsis of the story in an attempt to draw you in, however I will not as taking it in without any knowledge prior, like myself, I think allows for an even greater appreciation of just how well the themes, stories and ideas of Death Stranding are conveyed. Be it through dialogue, cutscenes or codex-like 'interviews' Death Stranding doesn't fail in giving you just the right amount of information to keep you thinking without getting frustrated. You simply *need* the pace of the game to be slow, lest you be swept up in the throes of the story with nary an idea as to how or why you got there.

The setting through which you'll traverse is largely, if not completely, based on Icelandic geography. At points you'll be walking along rivers flowing through mountain passes, others wandering across volcanic sand beaches lying in the shadow of snow-topped peaks. Death Stranding is a feast for the eyes and a marvel of photo-realistic graphical technology which is only further enhanced by its powerful suite of in-game capture tools which allow you take some truly breathtaking, and occasionally hilarious, photos. Students of photography may want to try this game for this set of tools alone, as it provides both the means and locations for some of the most staggeringly breathtaking screenshots I've seen in a video game to date.

The attention to detail is not only present in how the landscape is constructed; interior modelling, character detail, sound and effects are all produced with an immaculate level of polish. En route to deliver goods to a distant waystation I found myself caught in the rain; from the first few drops splashing from the shoulders to the steps being taken on the increasingly sodden ground I could have easily been forgiven for thinking that I really was caught out in it myself. Visually, the distant glow of player made structures stood out in the rain as beacons of hope moreso made convincing by the lack of overall visibility that comes with actual storms, not simply those in a game.

This is not to say, however, that Death Stranding does not have its weaker points. It falls into an all too common trap with its pacing towards the latter half of its story. Episodes and events switch from nudging you in the right direction to outright forcing you through it's denouement without much acknowledgement to it's pacing up until that point. It can be argued that the story requires this change of pace as dictated by the ongoing events, but personally I found there was too little room to breathe between segments in the last 10 hours or so of the game. This simultaneously leads to another, more minor issue; exposition. Death Stranding is an example of complex story-telling done in the right way, for the most part. Questions that might have been raised throughout the story in some cases, for the less observant or perceptive, are answered all at once through monologues by several key characters. Understandably, some information needs to be given for context and understanding however at times it feels more like spoon-feeding than overall story-telling. Little is left to the discovery of the player unless it is actively thought on and pursued, though this may be more of a benefit to some.

Death Stranding's gameplay is both visceral and rewarding. The core loop involves picking up orders at one location and delivering the goods to another with the challenge being in navigating the environment without causing too much damage to your cargo. This challenge is made harder by geographical constraints, be it wide rivers or steep cliffs, and enemy entities located throughout each region be they of the human or more supernatural variety. Investing time in finding and using the best route, along with performing multiple deliveries is rewarded with a wide repertoire of feature and equipment unlocks, making future deliveries easier and faster.

Death Stranding is not so much a multiplayer game as it is a social game (or not, if you're so inclined). Cargo, equipment, signs and structures left by other players can be seen throughout your game as you progress, which in many cases can serve to aid you on your journey. Fortunately, for those who want to be rid of eyesores from their sweeping vistas, the option remains to remove the creations of other players either partially or entirely. The Instagram generation is well served in Death Stranding, with players being able to positively rate others through a 'liking' system. The concept of 'likes' is both a gameplay mechanic and core concept to the America you find yourself in, though you'll have to play yourself to find out how. It both provides welcoming boosts of serotonin and a measure of social commentary which is simultaneously engaging and surreal.

Death Stranding is not a game that everyone will enjoy; dare I say not even a game that the majority of people will enjoy. It is, however, for those engaged by it an excellent and wholeheartedly recommended addition to their library. While not having the replay value of other games, it leaves you feeling satisfied with its finish while wishing there truly was more reason to 'keep on keeping on'. Death Stranding is both a technical and narrative masterpiece, truly an impressive first outing for Kojima Productions.

Repeated this process until I realized the buyers remorse of admitting I wasted $60 wasn't enough to keep me playing a game in which I didn't have fun a single time. I should have listened to the overwhelmingly negative feedback the game got, and you should listen to mine. Don't waste your money.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I recommend this with a caveat, that this game appeals to you. Technically speaking everything works, its a good port. It could do with some QOL changes. I'm enjoying the story, character and themes present, but that is entirely subjective and a big part of the experience. Id like to see more "Stranding" mechanics in other games too. There's not a lot of new things for me to say about this. If Kojima's games are an acquired taste, this would be an Islay scotch with notes of "burnt ham", "old leather" and "Grandpa".

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
With 17 hours at the time of this review, I'm hooked. I really really do like this game.

The game's a clear hit-or-miss, and it shows. Because if you're willing to haul cargo from point A to point B and find that interesting and enjoyable, you'd either put the game down and request for a refund or take up another order and keep playing. But that's just me saying it. The game's a unique case of needing to experience it in order to make any evaluation whether or not the game's for you. Because the idea of game sounds boring, unconventional for a genre, but it can hook you because how it plays out, how it gives you your own enjoyment to it.

It really is a Walking Sim. Through and through. Combat is there but not necessary, stealth is there but highly encouraged.

Play it for yourself. 

You don't like it? Game's not for you, and that's completely alright. 

Like it? Congrats, you like it, keep on keeping on.

All these reviews will tell you how good/bad the game is because the pacing of the game and how it's built is ultimately based on a genre rarely played.

For other basic aspects of the game:

Story's alright, Kojima-style acting/writing. UI is clean, easy to access and really intuitive. Graphics are astonishingly great. Love the scenery.

other then that its fantastic

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a experience that only comes once. It's going to take time and patience to understand this one, and I think there was a small amount of people who failed to see that when it first released on PS4.  

Its clear the Kojima productions knew what they were doing with clear gameplay design and principles. The story is rich with memorable characters. The graphics is of acceptable quality. Combat is surprisingly interesting, but needs work with the camera. And finally, the movement, where this game shines, And im saying all of this not even half way through the damn game. 

Overall a experience that is memorable, and one I hope I have the pleasure of experiencing again with a sequel?

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is easily Kojima's best game since Metal Gear Solid 3.

It is a truly unique open-world game with an asynchronous online component—the best one since Demon's Souls in my opinion—that incentivizes cooperation among players in order to traverse a post-apocalyptic landscape and avoid enemies that want to steal you cargo.

Try it out and remember to play it online!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Compelling story, immersive setting, and an engaging cast of characters.  An absolutely stellar game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't write reviews unless a game is very good, very bad, or in the rare case of Death Stranding, both.

Let's get the game review out of the way real quick. 
1. Story is, engaging, cinematic, does marvelous world-buildling.
2. Graphics are top notch
3. Gameplay is smooth (minus the occasional controller issue).
4. Blah Blah Blah, it's one of the best of all time, etc, etc.


Now for the bad and also important part. The game is entirely unplayable in its current form.

I built a new computer last month specifically to play Death Stranding when it was released on Steam in July. And for the first 35 hours is was all blissfully smooth sailing. However, now the game crashes due to internal errors and issues with the callstack at least every thirty minutes, and often times the game crashes in less than 3 minutes after startup. I finally gave up when I failed to make the same short delivery 4 times in a row due to repeated crashes. Just not how I want to spend an hour of my time.

I've done the internet forum circuit and this problem seems recent and widespread. Here's hoping to a fix coming soon or at the very least some communication from the devs, otherwise I'll be looking for a full refund. Haven't had to do that since No Man's Sky!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Went into this game extremely skeptical, having ever only played MGSV from Kojima before this. I was drawn in by how good the gameplay was in MGSV, and expected more of the same from this game-- got way more than I expected. While the game is a "walking simulator", it's more than that. You're a porter (delivery guy.)  You have to prepare for each delivery carefully, managing your inventory's space effectively based off the kind of terrain you're going through. Going through territory that has lots of steep inclines and mountainous terrain? You'll bring ladders to ascend slippery rocky terraces, heating pads to reduce your stamina depletion from the cold, and your exoskeleton will be one focused on maintaining balance rather than increasing your overall carrying capacity/strength.  
If you're venturing through territory haunted by BT's (ghosts), you'll occupy more of your inventory space with anti-BT weaponry. Every delivery feels like a carefully planned and executed adventure. There are even frequent Metal Gear-esque camps of terrorists, which you'll need to sneak through to get passed without potentially harming your packages.

The horror aspect is done well, but it isn't the scariest game. Eerie is the more appropriate word. I'm a huge fan of the horror genre and I wasn't disappointed with the aspects that made it through in this game.

The story also unexpectedly won me over. There are some extremely corny naming conventions at play here, but if you get past that, everything else is top notch. It's a mystery-type story, and you're constantly given or are finding clues about the story's answers before answers are actually divulged. It's extremely fun piecing together these bits, and then seeing how close you were to nailing the plot's twists (I wasn't as successful as I thought, but that was my misinterpretation of said clues!)

Multiplayer is asynchronous, similar to the Souls series and it's message system. During the game you'll unlock the ability to build structures such as bridges, watchtowers, stations to charge your vehicles, and etc. These structures appear in other player's worlds, and they benefit from using it. If a player uses your structure, you get "likes" from them, which incentivizes you by restoring your stamina and boosting your overall player rating. It definitely encourages creativity, and you get a sweet, sweet rush of oxytocin whenever a structure you built turns out useful for the community at large.

The review is really rambly, but seriously, if you're on the fence, get this game. I'm looking forward to whatever this studio puts out next.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If I had to describe this game to you in one sentence, it would look something like this: A post apocalypse amazon delivery man simulator with a story that's written by someone that's high as a kite. 

It's a game that's sound very bad on paper but when I played it, I couldn't stop until I finally beaten it. I was in the middle of persona 4 golden when this game dropped and I was only going to start it up to see what it's about and I end up finishing it. Some how, Kojima managed to make a walking simulator compelling, he's crazy but a genius, if I wasn't a believer after all the metal gears I played, I certainly am now. 

As for the story, it got some of the craziest concept every show on screen, think twilight zone on steroids. What ever Kojima was smoking when writing this game's story, I'm betting it was something VERY strong. The plot can be convoluted at times and some of the concepts are a bit "out there" but it's not what you're telling, it's how you tell it. Even though the story is confusing at time it stayed just interesting enough to keep you going. 

There isn't much replay value though, I've beaten the game once and I feel like I've squeezed most of what it has to offer. I reckon you can play it through twice at most before it gets old. It's more of an experience than a "game" game akin to Detroit become human or Beyond two souls. However, while it's a relatively short game, it was quite a ride and well worth playing.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Lore: 9/10
Story: 8.5/10
Gameplay: 7/10

This was a toughie. The game is something special, and weird, but in a unique way. You aren't a spy, or a trained fighter really, you're just a delivery man. Someone who can deliver packages despite how the world has become, which takes no lack of resolve to manage. The setting of this game is truly special in my mind and I genuinely enjoyed learning more about it. The lore is mysterious, but you figure it out as you go along. The game drops you right into the setting and overwhelms you with confusion, and expects you to figure out the lore by watching the characters.

Honestly I don't want to spoil anything and it's kind of difficult with a game of this nature. The gameplay itself is about you delivering packages, but it is not limited to just that. You can build structures to help you traverse the map better, along with other people's structures appearing in your game to aid you. You can unlock equipment and weapons as you go along, but you are just a delivery guy, it's best to avoid combat. I don't know... The structure building is honestly the most entertaining part of the game for me, minus the story.

One thing to note is the boss fights, and yes there are some. I would not say they are exactly fun. Your characters movements are somewhat realistic, which means movement is clunky, which also means you spend most of the time staring at your character to make sure they don't fall over, and not the bosses behind you. Jumping is hit or miss, you might run into a structure during a boss fight and try to climb only to fail to, you end up being slowed down by the environment and it's just a wholly unpleasant experience.

I love the cutscenes and I love the package delivering gameplay. But I cannot say the boss fights exactly work with the system put into place. A good solid 8/10 buy. It's worth playing just for the story and its lore, if nothing else.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
(Day 1 Review. Edit below)I would not buy this game in this state. The game is beautiful and all but there are a lot of issues that need to be worked out. Usually will get over 100 fps during gameplay but when in cutscenes zooming in on Sam's face drops the fps to 20. Also I am seeing a lot of polygons being stretched during gameplay and cutscenes. Sam's beard will be 20 feet long stretched and while it is hilarious in some other instances the whole room might just have everything scretched out everywhere not allowing you to see anything that's going on in the scene. Even in gameplay some vertices will just go all over the place. Rocks won't load in making you wonder why Sam is walking in place when you bump in a invisible rock. You can't see how far long wide rivers are because the water isn't loading in right and it looks like gravel instead of water. I couldn't take it anymore after entering the private room and the whole screen was covered with these broken textures. I couldn't press the escape or tab button to close out of the game since the private room doesn't allow you to do that. Had to move the mouse over and guess where the terminal was because I couldn't see and exit the game that way.

Edit: I ended up updating my Nvidia drivers and that fixed the broken textures completely and no more issues in that area. Everything is as it should be. No more invisible rocks and I can finally accurately see how long across a river is. Did experience one minor audio hiccup but it fixed itself pretty quickly. I highly recommend this game to anyone that is a fan of Kojima as there are a lot of Metal Gear Solid Phantom Pain vibes sprinkled everywhere.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is a beautiful, deeply atmospheric game with a rich and brilliant story and incredibly engaging gameplay. The gameplay mechanics are innovative and based around exploration, the challenges of terrain traversal and construction rather than combat and acquisition of objects, gear and items. There's also the added dimension of helping other players with your constructions. There is plenty of gear and items - and there is plenty of combat. But gear is absolutely functional - you won't feel the need to hoard it - only to use it, and you'll really feel it if you go out without a ladder or a pcc. The combat is something you try to avoid - a bit like doing a perfect stealth run in MGS5, but you have plenty of weapons both innovative (a sticky gun for stealing cargo remotely) and conventional (assault rifles, shotguns). 

To a greater degree than any other game I've played, the landscape is really almost a character in the game. Finding your way, conquering difficult terrain, hacking your way across snowy mountain passes while monitoring your water and power, trying not to fall and destroy your cargo, is what makes the game amazing. If you're the kind of person who loves to just trek out into an open world and see what they find, this game will very much reward you - and for the first time, it will really introduce you to that landscape as a challenge, something that needs tools and careful consideration. You can't just walk straight up that mountain or cross that waterfall. You need to use tools, bridges, ropes... 

Thankfully, the game builds in plenty of workarounds for things like losing your cargo - if you lose it, it's not a huge deal - other players can find it, pick it up and either deliver it for you or share it for other players to deliver. Similarly you can collect lost cargo and help people by delivering it for them. 

The fact that many of this world's desolate and forbidding locations are haunted, and need to be crossed extremely carefully to avoid truly disturbing enemy encounters, adds a dimension that few post-apocalyptic games have. This is a deeply troubling, mysterious enemy - and the apocalypse itself is something that the games' characters are still working to understand. There is an all pervading sense of mystery, and fear - humanity doesn't know what the hell happened. Against this backdrop, the fact of deliveries, connections, normality, take on a symbolic dimension as much as a practical. The very fact that someone is out there in the world, crossing landscapes and facing dangers to keep society functioning is a powerful emblem for the survivors.

On top of all this - what becomes very significant is the sense of your own connection to other players. Leaving warning signs, ladders, building bridges to cross rivers or chasms, or climbing mountain peaks to create zipline networks - all to help whoever else might come that way in the future, is a really fun part of the gameplay. The game tells you when other players use the things you've built, and it's a good feeling to have helped someone. You amass likes, which improves your capabilities - carrying capacity, stability and so on. 

It needs to be noted also that the fact you can create all of the objects and tools you use in the game means you actually use them. There is no potion hoarding, or 'stash' full of cool stuff you found. You have limited carrying capacity, and you can only take what you need - but all of the items have a vital role - and if you arrive on that high mountain pass and need to descend without smashing your cargo, you'll wish you had that climbing anchor...

This all takes place within a world and a story which are deeply affecting, unusual, and compelling - the nature of this apocalypse has torn a hole in man's understanding of reality, of the connection between life and death - together with the music, this all makes for one of the most brilliant games I have played to date.

ps - this game has made me never want to drink Monster energy drink.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
When the game isn't drowning in awful cryptic nonsense and very forced exposition it can be enjoyable, but more often than not, the 15 minute cutscenes and awful dialogue come too frequently for the hiking mechanics to build up momentum. And that makes this game uniquely frustrating.

I recommend Breath of the Wild instead. At least in that game, the bad writing is an optional experience.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Overall Score: 8/10

tl;dr: An experience that you won't be able to forget easily. Although it has some of the best artistic decisions ever taken, and some brand new ideas, its gameplay always drag around and annoy the player. While THAT is the basic premise of the game, it heavily wounds the storytelling and makes the experience less enjoyable. If you manage to get used to its abysmal controls and gameplay mechanics, you will at least enjoy the story and the scenery.

Death Stranding is... something else. It is the ultimate love/hate experience for me. I can easily say that i disliked a big portion of this game: Gameplay. But no matter what annoying thing the game had thrown at me, i managed to beat it and i'm grateful that i did. I played on Normal and thank god for that. 

What i absolutely enjoyed, is the cinematography of this game. Even when you're not in a cutscene and just... simply walking on vast cliffs and listening to "Don't Be So Serious by Low Roar", game never fails to make you feel that you're in a movie. Camera angles, the overall atmosphere, feeling of solidarity and the little semi-online elements that sometimes make you feel like you're not actually alone and can feel safe here and there.

The another thing i very much liked was the semi-online system implemented into the game. Developers tried this system in a few other games as well but this is the first time i'm seeing this used in an actually good manner. Although it is a single player game, thanks to it's community shaped open world it almost feels like a multiplayer game. Player feels that s/he is a part of a big broad community. This is something very hard for a single player game to accomplish. Kudos to the Kojima Productions team especially on this.

Decima Engine is an absolute miracle. Whenever i've had a PS4 and i played Horizon: Zero Dawn (which will be out on PC soon, yay), i knew how unbelievably great this engine is. Guerilla Games did such a tremendously good job while creating this engine and it really shines on PC at 1440p, ultra details. Scenery feels almost photorealistic. Character models, mimics, animations, everything is visually flawless. And it never pushed my system around. Gave constant 60 frames per second on a system with GTX 1070, i5 6600, 16 gigs of ram and while its on an SSD.

So let's get down to the dirty business and talk about what i didn't like about this game and what made me give it an 8 instead of a perfect 10. Because this game could've had a perfect 10 easily. Gameplay is so, so bad. Like, abysmal bad. Terrible. I know that they tried to go with a more "realistic" approach while designing the gameplay elements but instead of feeling realistic, it felt annoying. Vehicle controls were so annoying, i had to walk for a good part of the game. I can't get myself to drive around easily without crashing on to a small rock every 10 seconds. And it is a small rock, really. A rock that you righftully expect your 4X4 land cruiser to absolutely go over. But it doesn't happen. It's like, the vehicles in this game have magnets attached to them. Magnets that pull your vehicle to rocks and all kinds of obstacles around. I never enjoyed travelling around in this game.

The first 10 or so hours were great. There were no artificial difficulty enhancers. Mules were as dumb as my character, BTs were easy to avoid and were very thrilling-fun at first. But after around 5 or 6 episodes it started getting annoying. Now i knew how to bypass BTs. I knew how to beat them. They were not thrilling anymore. They were just another CHORE i had to deal with. See, when a gameplay mechanic feels like a chore, that's in my opinion, a failure. They could've added some variety at least to the BT encounters just as they did to MULES. They get new weapons and new strategies as the game develops further. But BTs always stay the same. Except maybe towards the end chapters. 

Combat wasn't as good, gunplay wasn't as good, the GAME aspect of this experience just wasn't as good. It is not a walking simulator, no. Do not believe the angry mob that mockingly calls this game a WALKING SIMULATOR. It is not. Although it is terrible, it still has a good chunk of gameplay in it. You constantly micro manage your strategies, your workload, your deliveries, equipment, route, etc. Gameplay is there, really. It's just not as thrilling when you hit the 20 hours mark. It gets old and boring.

The times i most enjoyed this game were the cutscenes and straight-forward story bits. No packages to deliver, no chores to accomplish, no backtracking, just you and the story carrying along together. I wish there were more of these moments in the game. Because the amount of "standard deliveries" is huge and if you try to complete all of them like i did in the first few episodes, you will get a burnout and will rush to end the story. Even the mandatory orders felt like chores. I remember yelling at the game a few times just because it didn't let me progress through the story which i'm very curious about and made me do another mandatory chore. I get the idea behind it but... it is a game after all. It has to be fun.

So yeah. I liked Death Stranding. It was not a pleasant journey sometimes. But overall, it was a great package. Solid story, great cast of characters, absolutely beautiful visuals, great cinematography, mind blowingly flawless sound design, some of the best licensed songs, great optimization and just plain bad gameplay. 

Note: Just as a suggestion, wait until Episode 4 to start with the standard deliveries if you're into completionist stuff.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Walking Truck Simulator, if You're into that its 10/10.
Also, typical Kojima story, hope You're an fan of mystery boxes XD

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Everyone said the first 10 hours are the hardest, but the first 10 have been the most interesting. What are BT's? What is Higgs up to? Its such a beautiful game, playing at a high refresh rate like I am able to do is just beautiful. When making a haul for the story and you break out into an open area, and music starts playing, it just transports me. The BT moments are terrifying and difficult to navigate, you need to think. I totally understand why people don't like or understand the game, it's very repetitive when it comes to deliveries but all the deliveries mean something, i feel like im actually connecting the UCS and making a difference. I have been totally absorbed by the story and feel this game slowly becoming my new favourite. Ive always been a fan of 3rd person story driven games but this is a whole new genre, an art form made interactive. 

Absolute 10/10 and thats from someone whos only 13 hours in. Apparently it's only up from here? Very excited :D

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
So this game is super fucking weird. It's gorgeous to start off, with some really great looking textures and lighting, and it's also the first game i know off to use DLSS 2.0 for us RTX cards owners. DLSS means you can get 4k quality images without losing the performance of lower resolutions, it is really amazing, and truly a game changer for the video game industry, and seeing it in action, I am a believer. 

The story, the story is strange as fuck, because Hideo Kajima basically got to make whatever story he wanted, so he... He kinda did. It's really preachy and vague, and ultra sci fi, and that is all all right. I know this game gets some shit for being very "pretentious" but I think Hideo Kajima truly means everything he is saying with this game, so as long as it isn't just some marketing bullshit, or story for the sake of story, I am OK with being preached at a little. It doesnt hurt that everyone involved gives amazing, albeit very odd and creepy, performances. I think if you have a 20 series graphics card and are looking for some excellent Kojima style gameplay, this MIGHT be the game for you, I say MIGHT for a reason, some of you may be turned off by the weirdness, and that's ok. 8.5/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Best medicine for these pandemic times.

But really, what an innovative, beautiful and immersive game.

I loved playing every minute of that journey with Sam and BB. 

Kojima did it again.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I can't recommend this game to really anyone, because if your looking for a game that gives you constant action, or a game like metal gear solid, then just turn away.  Because this game is an experience, it requires patience and commitment to invest in its story.

Death Stranding took me by total surprise, the game starts off initially quite dull and full of the true remarks of the game being a walking simulator, but as you explored more, and played along with its cargo deliveries and then took in more of the story the game wants to tell you, it became more than just a game of walking, the troubles you endure in this game is to show the pain and effort Sam Porter has to go through, and keep this to heart as you play, put yourself in his shoes. 

And so Hideo Kojima really outdid himself on this title, and really set out to do what he wanted, and that was to tell us a story. The game drives home a simple point as you play it, to think twice before you kill someone in any context, and to learn to connect with people.

Simply put, Death Stranding is not a game. It's a Journey, and I will never forget it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: needs more ziplines and roads built

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: A world and story you will get lost in for ages. The simple premise: you're a delivery man for a post apocalyptic America that is reconnecting the nation through every package you deliver. It's the post-apocalyptic science-fiction action-packed clusterfuck any open world exploring fan would appreciate. It's slow but if you can appreciate a calm pace with dramatic climaxes you will love this. Gameplay consists of traversing beautiful mountainous landscapes using rappels, ladders and vehicles to find the most efficient route to deliver the next package. Tasked with avoiding pesky "MULE" terrorists who want nothing more than to steal any package they come across, and horror-inducing "BT's" which, long story-short, are spirits from the afterlife here to drag any living soul down to the beaches they're "stranded" on.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Keep on Keeping On!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death Stranding is a solid 10. I think the controls could use a bit of work, and the vehicle physics are jarringly odd. But Mr. Kojima has done it again, and shown us that he is still an auteur even without the name recognition of Metal Gear. Those who say that "Death Stranding is unlike any other game" however, have either not played Death Stranding, or have never played one of Kojima's previous games. Death Stranding is not a walking simulator, but rather a Stealth Action Sci-Fi experience with deep political and philosophical arguments to make. And if you give Mr. Kojima the 40 or 50 hours he demands to make his arguments, I think you will find that Death Stranding is nothing new. No. It is the culmination of decades of Hideo Kojima making a style and a flavor of games all his own, and this one, perhaps even more than Metal Gear, feels like a direct expression of Kojima's design philosophy. And it is fantastic, and totally worth playing through to the end, and through the credits, and through the second ending... Yes. Death Stranding is a remarkable game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Went in thinking it was gonna consist of 30 minutes of cutscenes and then 30 minutes of walking and trying not to fall over, and that's exactly what it is. But somehow it's done in a way that is just amazing. I now can't and don't want to stop playing and am enjoying every minute of it. FYI the cutscenes aren't that long once you get further in the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is kinda hard to describe, you play as, basically, a delivery guy, but the story line has a very addicting slow burn sci-fi mystery element to it that makes it tough to put down.  Even the delivery elements which, on paper, seem like they would be a grind, but the landscape is hauntingly beautiful, and it blends just enough action in there to keep things from getting stale.

17hr update: I admit that I've intentionally gone super slow because I love Hideo Kojima, but if you actually try to move quickly through this game, you could unlock vehicles and highways pretty quickly, not to mention some pretty powerful weapons.

really cool setting and mechanics remiscent of mgs v but done masterfully and doesnt feel tedious/too repetitive yet to me really (i honestly find turn based jrpgs more tedious than this)
if youre an mgs fan buy it now, runs great on my gtx 1060

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Traditional Haggis

Ingredients:

1 ox bung
1.4kg lamb's pluck, (heart, lungs and liver)
500g of beef, or lamb trimmings or stewing steak
200g of suet
500g of oatmeal, (coarse)

SEASONING (ADJUST TO TASTE):

2 tbsp of black pepper, ground
1 nutmeg, finely grated
4 tbsp of coriander seeds
4 tbsp of fine sea salt


1
Rinse the whole pluck in cold water. Trim off any large pieces of fat and cut away the windpipe

2
Place in a good sized pot and cover with cold water. The lungs float, so keep submerged with a plate or a lid. Bring to the boil and skim the surface regularly. Gently simmer for 2 hours

3
Lift the meat from the pot with tongs or a slotted spoon, and rinse in cold water to remove any scum. Place into a bowl and leave to cool


4
Strain cooking liquid through a fine sieve and put back on the stove to reduce until you have roughly 500–1l of stock. Leave to cool

5
Whilst the stock reduces, finely dice the cooked heart and lungs. Grate the liver using the coarse side of the grater. Finely dice the trimmings. Mix together in a large bowl, along with the suet, oatmeal and spices

6
Measure how much stock remains from cooking the pluck, and make up to 1l with cold water. When cool, add to the haggis mixture

7
To check the seasoning, pan fry a tablespoon of the mixture for 2–3 minutes and taste. Add any extra salt, pepper or spice if needed

8
Spoon the haggis mixture into the soaked, rinsed ox bung. Be aware the filling swells as it cooks, so pack quite loosely, and keep a little bung at each end

9
When the haggis is the size required, expel any extra air, pinch, tie with string and cut with scissors

10
Tie the new end of the bung, and continue stuffing. Freeze any spare haggises

11
Before cooking, pierce the haggis several times with a needle. Place in a pan of cold water, and bring to the boil. Simmer for 1.5–2 hours. When ready, the internal temperature should read at least 74°C

12
Serve with mashed potatoes and swede. Or neeps and tatties

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This isn't usually my type of game. When you start the game you slowly unlock mechanics and the game holds you hands once you gets to grips with how it plays. As you advance through the story you unlock more abilities and things to do. People claim it is a walking simulator however, it is a lot more than that. It's more of a horror game where you have to micromanage walking around. Being grabbed by invisible oily ghost people that gets your adrenaline pumping. Then you get roaming NPCs that try to steal your cargo, It's a blast. I was sleeping on this game so long.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is a game about being a delivery man in a post apocolyptic world.

This can be repetitive for some, but if you are the kind of person that likes getting all the towers in a Far Cry game, but are interested in it taking 20 minutes to get between those towers and then finding ways to make that process faster, this game is for you.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: AMAZING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
listen, if you give this game the opportunity, it will blow you away. the store is very engaging if you're a reader, the game play is slow, steady, and somewhat tedious at times and seconds later it will explode in action and frightening moments and beautiful visual story telling. Death stranding is in no short order an incredibly bold piece of work, for a lot of folks, this game will be a boring walking sim with too much reading, but to others its a fun place to relax with your thoughts and occasionally throw grenades filled with your blood at floating ghost people. 

There is one aspect to this game that is very unique. You and the other players who play this strange and wonderful game literally shape the map as the story and game progress. The entire goal of the game is to build infrastructure for the other players in the game. Your travels form a foot path, clearing away rocks and obstructions with every time someone walks that exact path. Its sort of ever-changing in that aspect. 

anyway, just wanted to share my thoughts. i highly recommend giving this game and a game director like Kojima a chance.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm 36 hours in, and only now have I reached chapter 8 (out of 15, I'm told).

It's so easy to get lost in the world and doing side-objectives.
I was really skeptical, what with the "walking simulator" reviews and the fact combat really pays a less prominent role.
I got it anyways, Kojima had never let me down and I can confidently say he still hasn't.


Calling this game a walking simulator is incredibly diminishing, much in the same way calling Dark Souls an adventure game would be. It's something... different, new, and you certainly do much more than just walking.

That being said, the game very much centers around the idea of making deliveries from place to place - the fun lies in the challenge of getting it done. Could be horrid terrain, could be a groups of vandals who want your cargo, could be merciless terrorists who crave nothing but mayhem, could be something otherworldly and rather ominous - something I find difficult to explain even as I progress through the story.

You are given plenty of tools to achieve your goals, but because some of them are quite perplexing or surprising I am reluctant to mention them... I'd be delving into spoiler territory.


The game at points presents you with serious themes, attempting to suck you into this strange, familiar world, only to suddenly throw a curve-ball and do something silly or goofy. I think one of the first soundtracks the game played for me was titled "Don't be so serious" and I think that's exactly how the game is meant to be played. Don't be so serious! Enjoy the wild ride, because a wild ride it is.

A Hideo Kojima experience through and through, with all the good (and bad) that entails.

I absolutely understand why this game isn't for everyone, again, in much the same way I know Dark Souls isn't for everyone. It's very challenging, very different, and bravely attempts to do something games haven't tried before.

Dark Souls stopped treating gamers as babies, and told them to git gud.
Death Stranding attempts to teach gamers that simply traversing the terrain, taking in the sights, planning routes and dealing with the unpredictable can be a fun mechanic in and of itself.

I am enjoying far more than I ever thought I would. Maybe you will to!

(I must reinforce this: Don't buy it if you -absolutely- need combat to be the focus. You'll hate it, for even when conflict eventually visits you, the game discourages you from taking part in it, especially if you want to go lethal. Does it give you that option? Yes. Will it make the game easier? Arguably, it will make the game even more difficult. Trust me. Dealing with the aftermath of killing another human is quite complicated, a chore really.)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is deep and grim. Even the gameplay and mechanics are simple enough; the world building, lore, character developments are was well done. As you play, you become the string connecting dots from the past and to the future.

This game follows a linear story of 'chapters' regarding different characters whilst learning the story and the world. Crafting is heavily introduced into the game, from tools, structures to utilities; this game has 'some-sort-of' multiplayer which only applies to equipment deployed into the world, such equipment will then be shared to other players, as theirs will be shared to yours, connecting each player to each other.

Overall, this game is a solid 7.5/10, it may not be for everyone but there is a charm in this title. Would recommend getting this title when it's on sale.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is the kind of game that I can get to appreciate its unusual mechanics and weirdness. Of course, physics can be a nuisance at times, specially during snowing mountains. You will spend your time hearing Sam moaning each time you attempt to drive trough such environment. And there are those moments when you think you will safely go down from a short fall, only to see Sam stuck on the falling animation like there is no bottom; long enough for him to die right after he realise there is actually ground to fall on. I hope they get to fix those issues, as it can make for very frustrating moments.
Other than that, I can't say I did not spare some tears during the ending. It was very touching, no pun intended.
Also kudos for the facial expressions. I just wish there was less hologram talking. Mass Effect Andromeda could learn a few things from this. Although I wish Sam was less awkward. It is harsh to say that the BB had more character than him? 
Alright, I am getting carried away. I still recommend this game if you wish to try something different/weird.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Artists sometimes do shit. It defies current standards as to what to expect in a game.
The pacing of the story is masterful and twistier than the rainbow road on 300cc. Couldn't expect less from a cinephile like Mr. Kojima. There is weird to another level but not just for the sake of weird, there's a reason to the madness and the story keeps you hooked and invested.

If you need a generic mind-numbing BR/shooter/FPV experience, little to nothing to read and no cinematics to pay attention to - this game is not for you!

------
Finished it - story is amazing. Makes me want to 100% it after completing the main story line.

title: DEATH STRANDING

first i want to point out i get get migraines and they suck. i just got death stranding and im noticing a bug that makes my clothes and beard flash in a cutscene if you fix this i will give a yes because its a beautiful game

edit: i have since fixed the bug 
If you're on Nvidia, make sure you go with 451.67, not 451.77.

77, while it has a higher number, is an older base driver revision designed for streamers/video production.

67 is the version Death Stranding wants.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I figured this would be an easy game to just tune out and listen to music or a movie or podcast or something, but holy shit was I wrong.

Game looks great. Controls are okay. Story is batshit insane as per Kojima. The gameplay loop is passable and why I thought I could turn my brain off and veg. Music is pretty well curated.

Nope. I forgot that Hideo Kojima has been smelling his own fucking farts for the last decade and this game is the result of no one telling him "no." I'm so glad I skipped as many cutscenes as I could because the damn story is an LSD trip for "intellectuals" and if I didn't skip them, then I wouldn't be in the refund window.

Would I keep this game if it was about $30? Yeah, this game is perfect for that price. For a full $60, I want something just a bit more fun.  AND THAT IS SOMETHING THIS GAME IS MISSING. FUN. Too much time is spent on the trippy story, and then it rewards you with a gameplay loop of just delivering packages and getting harassed by shitty muk people and apparently there's a shooting section or two. I wouldn't know. I got so fucking bored in the first hour and a half that I refunded this.

Listen - if we're going to give Kojima a blank check to eat shrooms and make a....video game(?), then let's fucking go all in and hire glue-sniffing-champion Hideki Anno too. For real.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]The best gaming experience of my life[/h1]

[u] this review is spoiler free[/u]

I was nervous and unsure about buying this game when I first heard some people calling it “ just a walking simulator” or “just one big fetch quest” two things that certainly didn’t appeal to me. However after watching a REALLY good review for the PC version which I will link (https://youtu.be/7Q_fj-PO0JI) It convinced me to take the plunge. 

Now I’m not going to go on for ages about ‘what’ this game is because there’s thousands of reviews on here telling you about the premise of the game. Instead I’m going to tell you my experience and how a game that seemed to have almost zero appeal to me (by description) turned out to be one of the best games I’ve ever experienced. 

First off the first 2 hours appears to have mixed opinions from both fans and critics but I loved it ! It sets the world up beautifully and really introduces you to the world and it’s mechanics and characters and this start is needed for your investment in the story. After 2 hours it really opens up into the game you probably expected when you bought it. 


[u]the moment I knew[/u] 

It was about 2 hours in and I was on a delivery, I was scaling a beautiful mountain, I had used all my ropes and ladders so was crawling up and kept tumbling down and getting back up and climbing again.. this was a long trip.. my stamina was low.. my shoes had worn down, my feet was bleeding, I was limping and as I stumbled and tumbled down a section of the mountain for the third time I really felt all Hope was lost and I wouldn’t make my destination. 

Then as I dragged myself up and saw a rope another player had left who had scaled that same mountain I grabbed onto it and dragged myself up. As I scaled and limped across the summit, in the morning sunlight I saw my destination on the horizon and the song “don’t be so serious” by Low Roar started playing and it just felt so real and beautiful it was a moment I rarely had in gaming.. I felt and worked hard for every step of that journey I forgot I was playing a game. I can’t relate to saving the world from demons, I can’t relate to being a superhero and I can’t relate to been through military war.. 

but what I can relate to is going on a journey where the odds are stacked against you, everything is going against you, everything feels like it’s beating you down and wanting to make you give up only to against all odds come through to the other side and reach that ‘destination’ the music really amplified this feeling. 

[u]Story[/u] 

I’m going to keep these sections short as I want you to experience everything first hand but the story was INCREDIBLE it made me feel everything. And honestly the story coupled with the soundtrack is something that will stick with me forever. 

[u]Music[/u] 

Though a few different artists and bands are present in the sound track the vast majority is made up by the band “Low Roar” I would recommend you look them up and give a song or two a listen because if you like their music it will really amplify the enjoyment of the game. 


[u]Graphics[/u] 

What can I say it’s probably the best looking game I’ve played period. There was generally so many moments I was just looking around in actual awe and that’s no exaggeration.. 10/10 almost photographic graphics on the landscapes. 

[u]Summary[/u] 

The game was incredible and will stick with me for many years in my head and is in my top 5 games I’ve ever played easily. Sure.. if you want a 30 hour shooty shooty bang bang game (nothing wrong with that) you might not fully enjoy it.. though I must say in the later stages of the game you do have weapons and use stealth a lot and some of the later stage bosses are visually incredible.. though not dark souls difficulty they didn’t need to be because it was very satisfying. 

So it really isn’t bland I feel like if you can find it in your heart to try something new then don’t hesitate. I came into this game just hoping it was something with an interesting story that I could mildly enjoy and relax playing it while in lockdown. Instead I found a game with an incredible story, an addicting game play loop and a fantastic cast. 


[u]Extra mentions[/u] 

Story took me about 50 hours to complete, though I did do a few side quests so would of been like 40-45 had I not done any side activity. And yes there’s post game content once the credits role with a lot of extra goody’s to keep you going post game, I’m easily going to put 100 plus hours in at this point no worries. 

One other mention is the world connectivity with other players my god it’s fantastic! Building structures and leaving equipment for others on the same hard journeys as you is an addictive feeling and seeing all the ‘likes’ you get and knowing other players appreciated your effort and found what you built useful is a huge part of the game ! Though I won’t spoil too much about it. 

If you have the cash and are looking for something that’s not just another FPS give this a go because I nearly didn’t and I’m sooo glad I did.
