title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] Death Stranding [/h1]
[b] Death Stranding [/b] is that latest game from Hideo Kojima, which initially came out with rather mixed reviews. Now we finally get to see it on PC in uncapped FPS 1440p+ glory. The only way I can describe Death Stranding by words is ‘unique’. Everything about it from the story to gameplay is unique, there really is nothing else like Death Stranding. It shows gaming isn’t just about shooting demons it can provoke thoughts and emotions, video games are an art. And Hideo Kojima just made his masterpiece.

[h1] Story & Characters [/h1]
[b] Narrative [/b]
In the first couple hours alone there were so many moments that left me just puzzled wanting to know how any of what was being shown makes sense. And the questions you ask yourself are only beginning, the story for the most part is simple to follow but the mysteries just keep coming. I will not say much in detail about the narrative as you should experience it on your own, just my thoughts on how engaging the story actually was. You have a simple goal, and that is to reconnect the cities across America. While crossing through cities different objectives will arise that advance the main story, you come across countless characters some friendly and some not. While it seems like an easy to follow [b] Point A [/b] to [b] Point B [/b] kind of story it quickly adds many different obstacles, revelations to previous questions, and of course more head scratching mysteries. There are personal vendettas, US secrets, and much more to keep you guessing. The confusing nature pushed me to keep on playing, at any turn I could find the answers I needed. It’s an interesting narrative that kept me on the edge of my seat, and prolonging my play session just to see what happens next. Thankfully at the end of the game, all your questions will be answered and then some.
[b] Characters [/b]
Another strong aspect of Death stranding are the characters you meet throughout your journey. Just to name a few Diehard, Deadman, Fragile, and so much more are all real and going through their own struggles. The writing for their dialogue and backstories are really top notch. Their own personal struggles are revealed throughout which makes them feel believable and real. You grow to care for them and their own problems, which further strengthens your emotional ties to them. Even an antagonist such as Higgs which you will meet later on, are interesting and amazingly evil at times. This helps his character feel real with motivations, and not just a placeholder character to halt your progression. And Sam himself is excellently written, you will go through hell and back grow stronger wanting to see him succeed. You’re in for a real emotional trip in Death Stranding.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2173057438
[h3] Story & Characters rating: 10/10 [/h3]

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
[b] Main Loop [/b]
The concept of Death Stranding's main gameplay loop has been broken down as a delivery man simulator countless times in past reviews, but is that really a bad thing? On paper it might seem stale, but actually it’s refreshing and new something I didn’t know I needed. You will traverse beautiful vistas, marching through mud, snow, heavy showers and every bit of it’s stunning. You pick up your packages from a terminal, get your goods, plan your equipment and route, then set off to save America. Quickly you will try and test your limits to see how much cargo you can actually transport, keeping its condition well and delivered in a timely manner. There isn’t else to say, it's a unique concept never tried before, but implemented wonderfully here. There is also a multiplayer like element in Death Stranding, you can leave behind packages, bridges, and much more to help your fellow porters. I didn't think this would be as big of an aspect as it truly is, but leaving behind that zipline that got 4,648 likes by other players is rewarding on its own. And the countless times other players' structures helped me is staggering. It really brings the theme of ‘we’re in this together’ to life.
[b] Exploration [/b]
When you’re not completing deliveries you will find yourself just exploring this world. You trek across the unforgiving landscape of post apocalyptic United States. There are many mountains to discover, little caves scattered throughout and new routes to help on your next delivery. Traversing the environment is oddly therapeutic, taking in the beauty and looking through every nook and cranny is as much a part of the game as delivering packages is. You have many tools at your disposal such as ladders and climbing anchors to help you reach the summit of any mountain you see on the horizon.
[b] Combat/Bt encounters [/b]
While doing the main objective, or delivering packages you will come across MULEs and of course the infamous BTs. Firstly, combat is obviously not a focal point here, but the encounters were easily avoidable and spaced out that when they did occur they were a fun change of pace to making deliveries. Many weapons are at your disposal lethal and not, combinations of tools can also lead to fun ways to take care of enemies. Boss fights occur a handful amount of times, all having their own twist and ways to overcome them.. BT encounters are also a surprisingly fun but horrifying obstacle to overcome. Sneaking through holding your breath, fighting back with No. 2, or praying and speeding through with your bike. There are many options to keep every encounter fresh.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2166032928
[h3] Gameplay rating: 10/10 [/h3]

[h1] Visuals & Sounds [/h1]
[b] Visuals [/b]
Death Stranding is a visually stunning game, the vistas you will come across are second to none. Everything from footprints, Sam’s suit, BB, etc are incredibly detailed. It also comes with an impressive weather and lighting system. Add all these things together then boom, you get one of the most unique and interesting atmospheres in all of gaming. With the addition of photo mode, which I have a love/hate relationship with because I take so many photos. I took a total of 543 screenshots by the end of my journey, the mountains, characters, weapons are all so visually amazing that I found myself stopping often to admire and screencap. The visuals speak for themselves and elude feelings of hopelessness and dread. 
[b] Sounds [/b]
The sounds here perfectly compliment the vibe and visuals of Death Stranding. Each interaction such as footprints hitting the environment are realistic and help make this an extremely immersive experience. Paired along with the voice acting with such an amazing cast of actors, makes Death Stranding feel like a movie at all times. The lines are read beautifully by each cast member, delivered with emotion and really has scenes leaving a lasting impact. The soundtrack is also handpicked by Kojima to compliment what is happening on screen. There is no better feeling in this game than completing a tough climb over a mountain to have a licensed song play on your blissful walk down the other side. The combination of visuals and sound creates an incredible atmosphere paired with excellent presentation like no other.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2169259911
[h3] Visuals & Sounds Rating: 10/10 [/h3]

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Death Stranding is a piece of art that some may find unbearable and others may find their favorite game. The story is a mystery waiting to be uncovered, with fresh gameplay, and amazing presentation, all combining to form the unique game that is Death Stranding. You will never see another game like this, do yourself a favor and enjoy your time Porter.

[i] “Tomorrow is in your hands” [/i]

[h3] Overall Score 10/10 [/h3]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[H1]The toughest journeys begin with a single step...[/H1]

Death Stranding proves several things. Firstly - Hideo Kojima can exist (mostly) outside of the Metal Gear Solid IP. There's still some of the basics that desperately cling to the core mechanics that I swear you could say "This is a Kojima game" but he seems to be finding his way out of those. Secondly - He can tell intimate stories at the same time as he paints big grand messages about humanity in general. Most critically - The PC version is the definitive version but even then it misses one or two things that would have made this and perhaps all flavours of Death Stranding absolutely ideal as an experience.

Let's start with the good, because there is an awful lot to love about this game, and there is a lot to understand going in if you're interested in Death Stranding.

[H1]Reconnecting the world through the eyes of the worlds most dangerous delivery man...[/H1]

Death Stranding is one part walking simulator... WAIT. WAIT. DO NOT LEAVE THE REVIEW... by Walking Simulator I do not mean things like Gone Home, where you prod around a house in the hopes of pleasing Ben Kuchera. Here I mean "Spintires on legs". You have to get from A to B on feet, and unlike any game before it, that means traversing terrain.

Terrain that changes on a centimetre by centimetre basis. It can be smooth, firm dirt one moment, and then boggy, stamina sapping moss the next. It can be littered with rocks that try to trip you up, it can be flat, it can be steep, it can be a rushing river complete with varying speeds of current that you have to ford. This doesn't change too much even when you have access to vehicles, since the added size means paths you'd easily traverse on foot become inaccessible on vehicle and you switch from picking routes through harsh terrain to having to plan your routes and taking longer, detoured paths through easier terrain to accommodate your larger hauls.

In between making those deliveries and fighting and mastering the terrain, the occasional flashes of MGS genetic ancestry show through when you encounter the primary enemies of the game (BTs) and the secondary enemies (human foes), the game gives you free reign in how you tackle these foes, either opting to speed away from them or stealthing past them or in the later stages, opting to apply stealth takedowns or even just go loud and tackle them directly. The fact the game forces you to act from a position of weakness to begin with is a good choice as it means that when the tools are finally provided, you feel liberated, and you do not feel that shooting is your default option, there's "always another way" and you'll often switch up your approach depending on the challenges put in front of you.

[H1]It's not just the gameplay that's rich, the graphics, sound and music are too...[/H1]

Low Roar is an *inspired* choice of backdrop for the music in this game, their extensive use as the soundtrack for this game proves to be borderline addictive, and makes you wish there was a mobile option to generate music on your travels so you could have the music with you all the time, and not just when the game decides you are worthy of it. The sound backdrrop is always on point, with the environment here always offering subtle cues as to what is going on, your suit even giving you the appropriate notifications as for things like Timefall, and Mule/Demens camps being suitably tense when their communications sound like demented, digital howls.

And then there's the graphics...

Hoo boy. At Ultra/1440p the graphics are flat out bonkers. With no 30fps cap as with the Playstation you are treated to a smooth, polished experience where you can be more precise, where there is no judder, no frame hitches, and where the game feels like it was meant to be experienced all along. The scenery is, and always has been flat out gorgeous but the extra smoothness means it just -feels- so much better. There's a few *minor* improvements here and there, the biggest of which is the colour balancing has been adjusted and that lends itself to a better contrast on the PC, but outside of that it's the performance where things are most keenly felt.

[H1]And what of the issues?[/H1]

No in game sound player for "on the move" is an issue... sometimes I'd like to listen to Low Roar when I'm hauling stuff. Timefall is punishing on your *unupgraded* structures. If you want anything to live longer than a week or two realtime, make sure it's upgraded. Don't worry too much about ladders and climbing poles whining about the fact they're going to rust to death, you can always put down fresh ones.

Oh yeah, and vehicle physics can sometimes fall apart and be made of jank. So there's that. Whilst the "on foot physics" are a thing of beauty, the game doesn't handle wheels quite as gracefully, I've had a few cases of my truck doing... interesting things on account of being in places where the wheels have decided to have hot, heavy intercourse with a large boulder.

I suspect that the game expected you to run the vehicles on mostly flat ground, not try to run them up snowy mountains. Fools. Of course we're going to do that!

[H1]Closing thoughts[/H1]

This is *not* a game for everyone. Even MGS fans should be careful since this is a departure from the standard Kojima fare, you're going to spend most of your time "Not killing" and instead trying to pick your way through horrible terrain making sure medication gets to really out of the way places. If the human version of Spintires sounds like your thing, then buy this without hesitation, otherwise, make sure to watch a few youtubes of _actual_ gameplay. The story is very much in the Kojima wheelhouse and you'll know what to expect (no, I'm not spoilering any of it here, go in blind and strap in for one of his wild rides).

Verdict: [b]Essential. If you're in to hauling stuff and Hideo Kojima[/b]

[i]Written for [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/balancepatchers]Balance Patch[/url], if you'd like to see more of their work, follow the link in the italics[/i]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Up front, I had no performance issues whatsoever. I say this since many negative reviews are about that, but - worked fine for me.

It's unfortunately the game when working as-intended I don't recommend. It is without a doubt beautiful, and technically top-notch, but mechanically and cinematically it falls down as often as the main character.

In the unlikely event you're still reading at this point, these are my main criticisms:

Mechanically, fiddly inventory management and walking simulation are probably amongst the lists of 'do not dos' in most game design textbooks. It almost seems Kojima deliberately picked the two most renowned 'bad' game mechanics, and tried to make them 'good'. The problem then is that whilst he succeeded in highly-polishing them, he didn't revolutionise them; so Death Stranding is still a game with mechanics at it's core that aren't really much fun. Even with a beautifully animated avatar in photo-realistic terrain, spending 15 QTE-filled minutes walking from a) to b) is tedious. None of the stuff layered on-top solves this problem and in many cases doesn't merge well with it; stealth is notably worse than in, for example, MGS5, as a result; there's probably a reason every gadget Big Boss used wasn't carried in a giant container.

In terms of presentation, the game tries (often too) hard to be a movie. I don't really have a problem with product placement per-se, even when said placement is advertising is a leading cause of obesity to sedentary teenagers. What does strike me is how it's almost done in a 'Hey look! We're just like a Hollywood movie!' presentation style; almost as if the placement is an attempt to legitimise games as a mainstream thing 'worthy' of product placement. This runs through the pushing of 'Hey look who this actor is! Look! They're famous!' as characters are introduced, and it ultimately feels like cinematically the game is trying too hard to be good, rather than just *being* good.

This leads to the narrative, which is either the best or the worst bit, depending on how much you like mediocre Netflix mini-series. It's unquestionably quirky, which is not a problem in itself, but sometimes becomes one when the plot tries to take itself seriously. And it does try hard to take itself seriously, due to the cinematic aspirations mentioned above. It also doesn't shy away from cutscenes, but the narrative is too thin to support many of them, so many feel like wasted time that does little to advance the plot. Attempts to engage your emotions are so overt, you can sometimes see what's coming next with more foresight than when a guy in a red Star Trek uniform announces he's a day from retirement. The narratives are (literally) confined to a room - that wonderful idea we have GTA to thank for - so there's no meaningful interaction with characters outside sitting and watching them Do Acting.

This means that extra engagement that games can facilitate leading to real Aerith-death moments is missed. When one of the characters is an eerily-rendered-uncanny-valley-baby, and your main emotional reaction is 'hey, look at the subsurface shader on that!', you know there's not much connection going on. 

For all the criticisms, it's worth again noting the visuals and tech are pretty much top-notch, and there's few issues with the PC port. If you want a tech demo to validate your expensive GPU, certainly look no further. But if I'm to recommend, I feel like i'd need either a great mechanic, or a great story, and I couldn't find it here.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is in every way possible a masterpiece. The gameplay builds a little slowly but is utterly captivating in atmosphere, themes, and presentation. There's too much good to say about the game.

It's inherently different from other third person games - movement can be slower but is an intensely rewarding system. I wouldn't, however, call it a simulator in terms of movement. It definitely has gamey elements to it, especially as you unlock new technologies to use. 

The themes are exceptionally prescient given the current state of the world. The game is emotionally powerful, wonderfully fun, and so deep in terms of both its gameplay and messaging. Build connections, be altruistic, value the people around you.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Walking simulator
Postal service training
Boring
These are the phrases used by people that haven't played the game, or played it past chapter 4.
The game is not your standard game by any means.
If you go into this expecting action and sniper rifles you will be very disappointed.

Treat this game as a change of pace, something to play when you want to wind down and chill. Enjoy the  beautiful landscapes and perfect score to compliment them. Yes there is action but it almost plays third place to the story, which I will not spoil in any way. I will however say one thing about it.

Don't do drugs! 
What a plot and the twists. OMG! and then the emotion involved in the story, with the subtle messages about society and it's failings are brilliant. 

In summary.

If you're of the cracked phone screen generation and need instant gratification from a game like COD or PUBG, move along. However if you are capable of enjoying a game for its differences and story, 100% a MUST play.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't understand why this game got so much negativity on release for PS4.  Was it spoiling people's expectations because of the PT/Silent Hills got canned and the creative talent was working on this game?  Were people comparing this to MGS?  Was it quick judgement of it being a walking simulator? (which its not even close to).

In the end, you can't really compare this game to anything else and I think it's just best if you have an open mind and play it!  I can see if you are impatient and prefer shooters that this game might not be for you but that is the only reason not to play it.  The role playing elements, story, actors, cameos, graphics keep me sucked into my seat for more which is everything else in a game.  

Even though its a single player game other player's structures can carry over to your world and it can help you get across the country.  You can help others as well with your structures and it actually feels like you are helping the world become united because once you see the struggles of delivering packages, every bit of help is worth it and exciting.  

If you are wanting instant action, this is not for you.  It can be tedious at the start but its a journey worth taking and even 30 hours into the game I am still unlocking new tools and weapons.  Like I said earlier, this is something I never really encountered in a game before which makes it a game of it's own.  I'm already looking forward to a confirmation on a Death Stranding 2.  Have fun and just enjoy what it has to offer!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Great game so far (only played for an hour)

Looking good and running at max settings 3840x1080 with GTX 1080Ti
The sound is pretty damn good I have to bring that up it is just a party for my ears (Steal series Arctis 7) 

Looking very nice with HDR and G-Sync running and no jerky nasty frame drops.
Just me having a good time and enjoying playing so far what is stacking up to be a great story.

There  was some pain involved setting this up
By default there is NO aspect ratios other than 16:9 or 21:9  (Shame this still happens in this day n age) 


EDIT:- I have played for another 75hrs now 
So a 3rd party fix or work around is required if you want anything else 
 Fix / Workaround =

Modify the game executable to force any aspect ratio[13]
Open <path-to-game>\ds.exe in a hex editor (e.g. HxD).
Search for 55 55 15 40 as hex.
Replace it with 26 B4 17 40 (for 2560x1080) or any other aspect ratio in hex.
Save the changes.
Run the game and select the 21:9 aspect ratio in the Graphics settings menu.
 FMVs will remain affected by Vert- scaling.

[Source = https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Death_Stranding#Ultra-widescreen]

This review has been changed to reflect the fact that it is playable for me @32:9 aspect and 3840x1080 resolution

Super Ultra Wide is NOT a new thing :( There has been a lot of tears and people posting about lack of resolution / aspect ratio support with workarounds posted, so you never know the dev's might just pick up on it and do something.

Edit :- After playing another 75hrs I am still happy (I did notice the games performance drop off once half way through thou I suspect that later patch's may help fix this up or I could just turn my game down slightly) Dont forget I am playing on old hardware.

I am enjoying my time.

review:

Postman sim

OTTER HAT!!!!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I have been playing the game for some 50 hours, and I am very surprised how addicting and satisfying it feels to play. I give the game 9.5/10, reasons below. 

In short: Incredible story, innovative gameplay mechanic via asynchronous multiplayer (I spent many, many hours building roads with other people to help eachother and players to come) and the sound/visuals are breathtaking. The world is huge, and there are many places to unlock and many quests to be done. I passed the game in 50 hours although I spent a lot of time doing side quests and building facilities so I think that 30 hours is a fine estimate for the game length without any side quests. For beating the whole game - I am sure it will take atleast twice as long.

If you want a new experience in once place without any DLC or pay to win content, without the typical flashy gameplay, all while interacting with people and forming bonds with them, then this is definitely the game for you. The mechanic of deliveries is just that, a mechanic - some people might not like it just because of the premise that it is boring and repetitive. But I can safely say, it sounds boring, but definitely is more addictive and satisfying than I had initially thought.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I started this game skeptical, with all of the hype and the strange game trailers I had seen. At this point, 50 hours in, I can say I am extremely surprised. At it's most basic point Death Stranding is a delivery game, it's main challenge being weight distribution, balance, and rough terrain. If you do not enjoy looking at a mountain and thinking, "how the hell am I supposed to get these boxes over that?" then this is not the game for you. After looking at the core gameplay, we can look at the story elements and that is where the game shines even more. The story is a twisted, confusing mess and I have become almost obsessive about figuring out what is going on. The lore of this games goes very deep and is rooted in today's society, it has done a fantastic job of pacing the story and what you learn, as well as the gameplay additions and the rate at which your character (sam) get's new gear. As someone who was not a fan of Hideo Kojima, I can honestly say I believe this game is a work of art, and I don't say that about a game often. I would highly recommend anybody considering the game to pull the trigger, you wont be disappointed.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Let me start by saying this game is not for everyone. While that may seem obvious to anyone who's played a wide range of games, it's apparently not obvious to everyone. I also know that "not for everyone" is used to justify a lot of crappy games, so let's dive right in to the meat of the review. Keep in mind the review will have spoilers.

Death Stranding is a strange game, from concept to story. You play as a delivery man in a divided world after an event known as the "Death Stranding" occurred. Now, you'd think playing as a delivery man would be exceedingly boring, but there's a lot more to it.

Your primary goal at any point in the game is always going to be moving cargo from point A to point B, there's no escaping that. You're a delivery man, not a soldier or a spy. However, the cargo may require special care. For example, some cargo can only be carried by hand, which completely shifts the delivery process.

Before you even set out on a delivery, there are things you need to think about: your route, how much weight you're carrying, how you're transporting the cargo, just to name a few. You start out delivering on foot, but as the game progresses you'll unlock upgrades to your equipment, vehicles, and even the ability to build roads (you don't choose the road locations yourself, though). You also unlock fast travel between certain points, but you cannot bring any cargo with you.

Each terrain type is different and provides different challenges, but you'll always want to keep an eye on your stamina. If you're going over terrain that has many steep areas, you'll probably try to move more slowly to avoid falling. If the terrain is wet, you have to be careful not to slip.

I won't get into the specifics of delivering much more, lest this review turn into a guide, but you get the idea: delivering isn't as easy as going from A to B. This is [b]not[/b] a walking simulator, despite what the trolls may claim.

Equipment can be crafted at certain locations, including one piece of equipment that's essentially a 3D printer you use to create structures. You can make bridges, generators (to recharge your vehicles and your own battery), watch towers, and more. Equipment and structures decay over time, but structures can be upgraded, to slow the rate of decay, and even repaired. Naturally, upgrading and repairing incurs a resource cost.

Structures you build are shared online among a few people, if you're playing online to begin with. This means others may use those structures, as well as upgrade and help maintain them. They can also delete your structures from their game, but only you can destroy your structures from your game. Resources donated to build roads are also shared, though the specifics of how that works seem to be a mystery.

The story is way over-the-top, with some fourth wall breaks and comedic moments, but also philosophical musings and critiques of society. In other words, typical Kojima. There are also some plot twists; some you can probably see coming, others not so much.
One of the best things about the story is that every single story thread is given a conclusion. I had questions while I played the game, but every single one was answered by the game itself. This isn't one of those pieces of media that prompts the fans to ask questions it has no answers for so it can pretend it's "deep" and spark debate among fans to see which "theory" best fits the incomplete story. This game's story is complete and was thought out from start to finish.

The main characters' names are all puns, as is common in some works, but don't let that scare you off. They have depth to them beyond what their names might indicate.

The game, like the story, is complete. No partitioning pieces to sell off as DLC, no lootboxes, no microtransactions, nothing. You buy it and you get the full experience, end of story.
Disclaimer: There were a few colors for minor items that you could only get if you'd preordered the game, but I don't consider those to be significant.

From a technical standpoint, this is a very good port. Some people are reporting issues that the devs are working to fix, but for most players the game runs perfectly, as evidenced by its score.

Now for the parts of the game that some people might have issues with.
[list]
[*]The game and story take a while to really open up. Even then, the game focuses primarily on getting past enemies unseen, to protect your cargo. There's a lot of action in the game, but it's in very specific areas and parts of the story.
[*]Your character barely speaks even when people ask him questions directly. Personally, I find this incredibly annoying.
[*]The soundtrack can be a bit... odd, at times.
[*]Some product placement, which some people say "breaks immersion". I don't mind it because I know it probably had to be done to secure enough funding for the game, and it's not like there's no product placement in other games.
[*]Because structures are shared online, this may reduce the difficulty of the overall game in certain areas. Although this is the point of the game, some people don't like this. To avoid this, you can play offline or just dismantle the structures and build your own.
[*]There is no NG+.
[*]There's a certain part at the end where you'll just alt+tab out for about a minute at a time because it functions as a sort of unskippable cutscene. This is my main complaint about the game, which should tell you a lot given that it only comes at the end and you only have to suffer through it once.
[/list]

Bottom line, if you're someone who enjoys more slow-paced games that require you to plan for the journey ahead and can accept the negatives I pointed out above, I would recommend you get this game. If you're someone who needs a game to be full of action from start to finish, this is not for you and you will not enjoy it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I usually don't do many reviews but this game really deserves a proper one. I have already beaten it on PS4 so I probably wont have much playtime on pc an will update once I get a sense of what improvements come with the pc version vs ps4.

GAMEPLAY:
Everyone always says how tired they are of game clones and repetitive titles and want something new, this is as close as you can get to a completely brand new genre. You already know what you are getting when you look at gameplay, yes, it is a "walking simulator". This does not mean it is easy or boring. In most open world games getting from A to B is fun for the first couple hours and slowly becomes a chore as you try to get to the next mission. In this game getting from A to B IS the mission, and I loved every second of it. Figuring out how you're going to get over a steep cliff or through a BT infested zone requires thought and effort. You won't be able to hit forward and walk with no issue, you're going to have to stay focused. The addition of players building up the world with you is done in such a unique way too. The closest example is Dark Souls, leaving messages to help each other, but in this you are truly helping thousands of people simply by leaving a ladder in place or making a shelter. It's crazy how you will never actually see another player but you will feel much more connected to people than any other game I've ever played. The landscapes are incredible. The physics are incredible. The soundtrack, and how they use it, is incredible. The main thing here is if you look at gameplay and think "This is boring" it will probably be boring for you, and that's fine. It isn't for everyone, but you if you make something everyone will like, no one will truly love it.
STORY:
This is my second Kojima game. The first was MGS:V, and like most people who started with that (and tried to understand the rest of the story before) it was pretty damn confusing. The story here feels much more natural. It can be strange but this is a strange world. You will form genuine connections with the characters, especially BB, and become invested in the story. Kojima had something in mind when making this and there are messages that can be pulled back to our world. The product placement does feel funny and might pull you out a little bit but I didn't really mind it that much. 

Overall this is a solid 9/10 for me. It isn't for everyone, the story can be weird sometimes, and getting somewhere can be frustrating (in a difficulty way, not an unfair way). These are very light complaints compared to everything else being so solid. Even if you hate the idea of this game, or Kojima, you should try and respect that someone is actually doing something different in an industry filled with loot boxes and gambling mechanics.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Creation of a madman that was given money to do whatever he wants. Probably will never happen again, which is why we gotta appreciate this. 10/10 for me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This is a fantastic game. That being said, it isn't for everyone! If you're the type of player who loves a brilliant story and long moments of zen broken up by intense moments of action, this is a game for you. If you're the type of player who can't sit still through 10 minute cutscenes (that are amazing to watch) or you're the type of player that needs the constant pew pew pew of most first person shooters then I wouldn't recommend. It's a post-apocalyptic world that you're trying reconnect one delivery at a time. As boring as that might sound there are many forces of play against you, the biggest of which is life and death. This game will suck you in and immerse you in it's story then it will kick you in the teeth when you're least expecting it. If you're on the fence you should try it, I was, and I don't regret it at all.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Weird, majestic, and a little disturbing.  The PC port runs fabulously, and it's hard to know how to describe the gameplay.  Fundamentally it's a game about getting around, but I suspect I've only scratched the surface of it.  The beginning is really front-loaded with exposition / cutscenes, but after a few hours you finally get to play more than watch and it feels like way more than just a 'walking simulator'.

I really like the purely cooperative nature of interacting with other people, it's strangely fun to think about useful places to put stuff not just for yourself, but for others.

EDIT ON FINISHING:
I don't have too much more to add here, except that the second (and major) area of the game really expands on the mechanics to firmly pull things out of the 'walking' simulator genre.  I thought the gameplay wore out its welcome right about at the point where I was able to just ride the plot train to the ending, which was perfect.

It's really hard to get across whether anyone is going to love or hate this game, but I for one am really glad I took a try at it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
"Death Stranding" is a unique game. I'm now 10 hours in. My impressions so far are as following:

1. The landscapes are beautifully done. Same is true for the sound and the music. And both is important for creating the special atmosphere ingame and to transport the story.

2. The "body balance" simulation - active while walking, climbing or crossing rivers - is creative and interesting and well done. But it also means that each miss-step can have its cost for health and the carried goods. You have to be all the time alerted while traveling and that makes it more intense.

3. The interface and all controls are made specifically only for consoles. I hate both outright and I'm tired of halfbacked PC ports and its my only real problem with this game. Not really optimized for a PC game.  The interface is unintuitive and often crowded and I'm very disappointed that this famous Dev cannot achieve a better interface design that fits PC's more naturally.

4. What I really love in this game is the visual style. Its full of very small real life details and shows that the Dev is a real master of esthetics. It helps to connect more deeply with the world and the wellmade characters. And thats the only reason why I bought several of this Devs former games too.

5. The story itself (as far as I've seen it in 10 hours) is interesting. That said, when I want to read a book I buy one. Most ingame texts are just blabla for me and a waist of my time. Its a shame I can never end this game so I don't know what all the fuzz ingame is about in the end.

6. I play the game on 3440x1440 with a NVIDIA GTX 2070/Intel i5 3,4 GHz. I had most of the time between 70-85 fps, thats really good performace wise. But sometimes sudden lagging can happen. I had one CTD ingame so far, reason unknown.

7. The Fights are underwhelming and mediocre and most often fighting is just a mess. Fighting is certainly not a strenght of this game, rather a weakness... Paired with the control problems on PC it can get quite frustrating quickly and it does not feel natural at all. The potential is not realized at all.

8. Other things: The Motorcycle is a joke. Its design is hilarious and the driving and reach  sucks outright. What a disappointment, its so bad. And the advertisment for this shitty MONSTERdrinks ingame breaks any immersion outright and shows that a company paid a lots for ingame ads. An absolute nogo for such an expensive game.

Conclusion: 
As in all the former games of this famous Dev that I own it seems that console players are the only real target audience, not PC players. For consoles this game is probably great. Its a shame and a waist that this Dev cannot create games made and really optimized for PC controls. The movement can be tricky and annoying with mouse and keyboard controls, specially in restricted spaces and fights. For me its the only reason for a clear thumb down. 

It means again I will never ever end this high prized game - as it happened with the former games from this Dev too - so I will never experience all the great content I payed for - again. And it also means I will never ever again buy a game from this Dev. I love his unique esthetics and his highly creative and highly detailed worlds; but I'm really tired of it to see a lots of promising gameplay potential in his games - but never beeing actually able to play it to the end because of bad ports of controls and interfaces. 

My patience with this kind of unfinished console ports is definite exhausted.

PS: English is not my native language so forgive me my mistakes.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Make sure your PC is powerful enough before you play. My PC is very old and I get low FPS but the game is still playable. For some reason the menus have much higher frames than the rest of the game; eg whenever I open the UI to rearrange my cargo, the FPS suddenly goes way up. Don't use a non-PS4 controller, it makes the game run worse.

No game's ending has made me cry harder than this one

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is great. There's definitely more to it than being a "walking simulator," despite what some people say about it. It's very satisfying to unlock new equipment and gadgets to help you traverse the landscape more easily. Inventory management is a lot more interesting when you have to physically carry gear on your character rather than it disappearing into invisible inventory space. 
On top of all that, the story is intriguing and I was always motivated to progress and learn more. While the world and lore can be hard to pick apart, the actual main story is actually pretty easy to digest, so you won't need to read all the data logs or look things up on the wiki to know what's going on.
It's not the best Kojima game, but it's still damn good and I'm glad I got to play it.

Thats why [spoiler] extinction events [/spoiler] happens because its the mission of brethren moons to consume everything but since they died their soul remained and formed the beach and since they are now part of humanity, humans have beaches too. In short, [spoiler] extinction events [/spoiler] occur because of brethren moons. In the game many characters say make us whole again just like dead space. To understand death stranding you need to play dead space 1, dead space 2 and dead space 3. Yup thats it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Short review:
- Story 10/10
- Graphics 10/10
- Sound/Music 10/10
- Playtime 10/10

Long (spoiler-free)-review:

Story:
The story is just great. It's epic and full of emotions. 
DS has found a great way to show you the story: wtf-moment -> infos about it ->wtf-moment -> infos about it -> and so on. Many parts of the DS-Lore are including real theories ( I can't explain more to stay spoiler free)
This way allows the story to get bigger and bigger. At the same time it was always logical.

Graphics:
This game looks just outstanding. The characters, mocab, world. effects. 
It runs smooth on max. details/resolution. Just perfect.

Sound/Music:
Just perfect. The songs ingame always fit to the moment. A lot of earwigs. The sound effects are great and deep. 
The voice actors are great (german version). 

Playtime:
I have done my first playthrough (~55 hours) and I have not seen everything. I think there will be much more hours for me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Completed the main story, Kojima is a genius, people who say it's just a walking simulator haven't finished the game. The ending was genuinely beautiful and brought a tear to my eye. title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is timefall within itself. I swear I only played for an hour and racked up four last night!

This is my early take away about the game and may be geared differently upon mid story / completion. Regardless, this is what I think so far:

Engaging and unique Sci-Fi premise  //  This is what grips me from the start. The eagerness to know more about what the hell actually is the event referenced as "Death Stranding." The BT's, The BB's, and the LMNOP's.

Traversing harsh landscape // Plotting a course, picking up packages, arranging to make yourself the most stable, dodging BT's, dodging timefalls, all while using tools that you yourself put down or that another player has before hand!

HUD and Environment // Sleek and stylish digital HUD which just flows so fantastically. It can be overwhelming at first, but once you get over the hurdle of mass information that's displayed to you, it's a very nice look. Environment is beautiful as well.


In short, as previously stated, this game is for sure not for everyone. I would watch some gameplay footage to see if it might be something that strikes your fancy. What I really think makes this Hideo game shine, is it's abstract and fresh story (which I look forward to uncovering).

Updates will come later.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is like what you get when Hideo Kojima spilt his secret sauce all over his ideas notebook, slid it between two cheeks of bread, and realised you don't even need a burger for it to taste good. This game isn't a nothingburger, it's an ideasburger.

I thought the game was good; I enjoyed the majority of it. Still, I have a few gripes.

Kojima plays with the tools available in the Decima engine, particularly its filmic camera system. DS blurs the line between cinema and video game; it uses many of the tools and tropes employed in cinema, while also exploring things that can pretty much only occur in a computer-generated environment. This is done so well that the majority of times it broke immersion were due to poor delivery on the part of the actors, and the sometimes-clunky, overburdened monologues.

The game's story further expounds Kojima's concern around hostility between cultures, and the use of nuclear armaments. Death Stranding charts the progression of an 'everyman' character tasked only to do his job, delivering packages, but under increasingly hostile conditions and an increasingly bleak outlook. Kojima extols forming connections, and 'raging against the dying of the light' as resistance, or an antidote, to a climate of hostility and conflict which leads, ultimately, towards entropy. The player is praised highly for performing a task well, and the disposition of other characters towards Sam changes as you succeed more and more. This became excessive and repetitive by the later stages of the game, but is still appreciated.

Much of the game's story is highly symbolic, and much of what you encounter is loaded with multiple meanings, intentionally so. In some cases, the links are tenuous, and in frantically seeking to explain or justify itself, the story exposition can come off kind of preachy, pretentious, or both. This is exemplified more strongly in some characters than others, in part due to the performance of the lines they deliver.

I was super hyped for this game's initial release, but stayed away after holding off on the PS4 release when the PC version was announced, sometime last year. Reviews were hit and miss, and I was disappointed. But then I realised games journalism is mainly done by hacks now, and decided to risk my siddy dollars. Money well spent. Glad I got to experience it.

[b][i] PROS:[/i][/b]
[list]
[*][b]Stunning visuals.[/b] High level of fidelity with great lighting in the majority of scenes. Rugged landscape informed by real-world Icelandic terrain. 
[*][b]Fantastic animations.[/b] You can really see the mocap at work. Great transitions between animations. Everything feels seamless, you really have to look close to spot any flaws. Facial microexpressions in cutscenes really elevate some of the performances.
[*][b]Cinematic cutscenes.[/b] Much of the story exposition is done through cutscenes, and here the line is blurred between cinema and video game.
[*][b]Satisfying combat.[/b] Scales with difficulty, but still feels possible in very hard mode.
[*][b]Open-world environment[/b], but doesn't become the 'big, empty' that most games fall victim to.  Has enough points of interest to keep you occupied, terrain obstacles to overcome, and some routes not important to the main story give you a lot of breathing room if you feel like going for a hike and taking it all in.
[*][b]Effective, well-thought-out traversal mechanics.[/b] The game does a good job of equipping you to interpret the terrain and plan your route around it.
[*][b]Meaningful progression[/b] - it feels earned, and rapidly and greatly expands the choices available to you, without invalidating stuff that came before.
[*][b]A main gameplay loop that doesn't try to act like it's not a series of fetch quests.[/b]
[/list]

[b][i] CONS:[/i][/b]
[list]
[*][b]Generic side-plots:[/b] the majority of minor characters are shallow, with some poignant, but often melodramatic, lore shoehorned in, usually delivered via rambling mail messages.
[*][b]Meaningless side-quests in abundance.[/b] I can't think of an open-world game that doesn't commit this sin, except maybe some of the Witcher series.
[*][b]Many cutscenes between basic interactions.[/b] All skippable, but segmented so that you will find yourself having to hit skip repeatedly. An hour of my life spend skipping repetitive, generic responses.
[*][b]You spend a looot of time delivering packages.[/b]
[/list]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
//story spoiler free//

In Death Stranding, gameplay and story synchronise completely. 

The theme of connection is reinforced through the story beats, your gameplay actions, and online interactions; and because of this cohesion, Death Stranding is one of the most immersive games I've played. 
(note that I'm still not finished, and I don't think I'm even close)

What I've immediately noticed with Death Stranding's gameplay is my thought processes when navigating the game world, it felt familiar. The calm, methodical, and constant problem solving as you constantly alter your choice in path is exactly the same feeling I get when hiking or rock climbing! (two hobbies I enjoy). 

This calm and deliberate thought process is directly contrasted when you are faced with escaping, or fighting, a BT (Beached Thing). 

Moving through BT territory is incredibly tense. Your Odradek (the shoulder thing) will pulsate faster the closer you are to a BT, stopping for a moment will reveal the BT's visually; prior to this they are invisible. The bridge baby you carry helps you see the BTs for that brief moment. 

When you are caught by a BT, panic immediately kicks in. The ground in your immediate vicinity turns to oil, land masses crack open, the BT manifests, and everything begins to sink. You have one goal.

GET. OUT.

At this stage your previously calm pathfinding becomes a rapid assessment of whatever sinking landmass is the next step toward safety. And it looks GORGEOUS the entire time.

One thing I particularly enjoy is the online functionality, again I'll state that this aspect of Death Stranding further reinforces the theme of connection. Among other options; you can build bridges, place ladders, ropes, signs, and contribute resources to larger structures like repairing a road. These objects may show up in other players' worlds, and theirs in yours, once you have connected that area to the Chiral network. If you don't like something that has shown up in your world, you can remove it. 

These objects/icons leave me carefully considering the route I'll take for an objective. Oftentimes I'll note a well-signed path on my map and choose to take an alternate route. This may be more challenging initially but what I find is, if the path I take is rewarding, I'll add a couple of signs to give other players alternate and interesting options. It brings a smile to my face when I've been helped by someone's object or when I get notifications (likes) that my objects have been used by other players.

Death Stranding is very unique and is an excellent example of how well-crafted video games can deliver a more immersive story experience than any other media. How you move, the music, visual style, sombre tones, character and online interaction, and funny gameplay options (like slamming a Monster Energy or 4 then pissing off the edge of a cliff), makes Death Stranding feel so uniquely human.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hell yeah I reccommend this game.

The story is just so weird but sooo good. 

Gameplay itself resolve mostly around delivering stuff so think of it like being UPS in Detroit. If it isn't humans that want you dead it's already dead beings that want you dead.

There is building mechanic that can help you out quite a bit. Generators are easily the most important in the start.

The combat is fine, a bit too much grenade throwing on the special enemies for the longest time and then Bola action against the humans.

I could predict various stuff in the game and sometimes the characters seemed to act like they didn't know the truth when they easily did.
Like not telling people that the terrorist group royally screwed over Fragile Express. Among other things.

But still a really good game for the story part. Gameplay is okay.

General comments(ongoing)： Kojima is already near his 60s, I can't imagine how his team and he could pull this out.(Given the risks he would take and the overall quality of this game.) Players who enjoy this game should be really appreciated.


+ 审美（音乐，美术，场景，道具以及演员选择。尤其女性角色对比近期的游戏那真是貂蝉比母猪-对说的就是你对马岛的那谁谁）

+ 游戏内容（这个就属于比较分化的点，我个人非常喜欢体验这种节奏，尤其是步行穿越以及爬山的段落。）  
+ 游戏潜力是巨大的，但鉴于发售阶段的反馈和小岛的年纪，不知道续作或者继承作品会不会成为“有生之年系列”

- 战斗有些单调没有太大挑战性
- 个人观点，可以加入合作联机（游戏里其他的外卖员都是2、3人一组的）。喜欢这款游戏的- - 玩家谁不想和朋友一起体验历经艰险送达快递的过程

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This is undoubtedly the finest open world, in any game, to date. To build an entire game around traversal mechanics, and the many awesome toys you will consistently unlock to aid you in your journey, can't have been an easy task. It blew my mind when they introduced the weather forecast system, as I realised that the weather was, in fact, dynamic. Utterly stunning visually, completely engrossing in its asynchronous multiplayer elements, and simply phenomenal in every other aspect. It also runs like a wet dream. Undoubtedly one of the finest video games I've had the privilege of playing, and I give it my strongest recommendation.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hideo Kojima is probably the biggest hit-or-miss developer I can think of still working today, except maybe Suda 51. Kojima does what he wants with a video game he makes, player enjoyment or expectation be damned, which can often lead to many people being turned off by his games, or at least certain sections of them (the B&B unit from MGSIV has never sat entirely right with me). Death Stranding is no different, considering that the game takes a loooooooong time to get started, enough that you'll be past the refund point before you even start getting out into the world and making deliveries. There's also way too much exposition in the early stages, and you don't even get anything to fight the game's main enemies with until about 6 hours in. Not only that, the main gameplay can be compared to that of a series of fetch quests.

So, why do I recommend this game?

Well, while Death Stranding is a game that not a lot of people will like, and it requires one to have a certain mindset to go in, the experience can be very, very engaging. Being someone who likes games like Elite Dangerous and STALKER, the idea of being a post-apocalyptic mailman is something that I actually rather like, and I feel a lot of others would too. There's something engaging about carting supplies 3 kilometers on foot through rough terrain, where you can put on a podcast and drink in the beautifully destroyed scenery of post-Stranding America while managing your load, navigating mountains, and eventually, enter into tense situations that require you to think and plan ahead instead of brute-forcing your way through, simply because of the limited tools at your disposal. Even when you have said tools and weapons, hauling ass is often the best option. 

All in all, Death Stranding is a game that I recommend, but I would totally understand if you don't like it. Aside from normal Kojima weirdness and jank (Die-Hardman actually being a name someone un-ironically thought of and implemented into a AAA game is hilarious to me), it has a gameplay loop that won't be engaging to some. I'd say wait for a sale, even though I bought the game full price and would probably do so again, despite its flaws. If you try this game, just be aware of what you're getting into. Though, even if the game doesn't sound like your cup of tea, maybe opening your mind and trying it would do some good.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game should not work. On paper, everything about it sounds off. A walking simulator? A post-apocalyptic package delivery experience? With ghosts? What?

And yet, this may be the most surprising and compelling experience I have recently come across, one where the simple act of traversing unforgiving terrain in service of moving a story along is executed with such finesse and depth that every hill is a small triumph, every vista a reward, and every twist in the narrative a motivation to go on and delve deeper into this weird, richly imagined world. 

This game has a vast trove of deep lore to explore. Everything feels purposeful. Even as the most seemingly absurd of settings, the world and the events in it feel like they have a past, a story, a thread of internal consistency that turns them from fantastical oddities into their own sort of rationality. Someone has really thought about this. Nothing feels gratuitous or improvised. 

The world of Death Stranding is one I want to keep exploring, one step at a time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: What an incredible game. It has a completely brand new idea that is meticulously crafted into a rich world environment and story unlike anything else I've ever played. Also very happy that this was ported over to PC so I could enjoy it. You have to approach this game with a very open mind and be willing to read and take in everything in the environment and in the journal entries. If you do, the reward is great. Also, for anyone saying that this is just a "walking simulator," I'm happy to report that the gameplay is much more than just that. It requires intelligent resource management and uses stealth gameplay mechanics. The weapons are completely unlike any other game, and add unique, challenging, and fun gameplay. Overall, because of how revolutionary this game is in terms of gameplay and story, and how great the voice acting and cutscenes are, this deserves a 10/10 in my book!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's overland trekking, carrying cargo....trying to make it to the destination without damaging your haul(much). Work with other players to rebuild massive highways, as well as make other "paths" with acquired tools. You must also use stealth to avoid the supernatural entities/human enemies....or learn ways to 'take them out'.  If the movies "A Quiet Place" and "The Postman" had a love-child...it'd be this game. 

Incredibly detailed environments & characters.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hideo Kojima had set out to do something different that was far removed from his Metal Gear days at Konami.
I can honestly say that this game is a breath of fresh air in terms of game-play, story, and atmosphere. 

Like many before myself had stated; This game is not for everyone. This game does not reward a button push
with some instant gratification similar to that of Call of Duty or Fortnite. Death Stranding in all of it's frustrating glory is
unique and invites intrigue and even self-reflection in a world where connection to others is more important than ever. 
It's a cinematic gaming experience that could be akin to that of 2001: A Space Odyssey or Star Trek: The Motion Picture (Let me explain) which present very provocative ideas, but sometimes to execution of which is not perfect. 

At first, the game-play can be very overwhelming as you take control as Sam "Porter" bridges for the first time. You traverse very treacherous landscapes and as you make your first delivery - have to be extremely careful as to how you walk and carry your load. If you become overloaded Sam will move slower and less stable and you'd be more likely to fall over and damage your cargo. Over time as you upgrade equipment, finish deliveries, and level up - you'll be able to carry more as well as be more effective in carrying said cargo to it's destination. This, sadly, takes a lot of time to accomplish and does drag down the game in terms of pacing to almost near halt. Your first encounter with the paranormal beings known as BT's or Beached Things isn't any better. You have no true way to combat them and your best bet is to find the fastest safest route around or through them before Timefall erodes your cargo. As you progress - you will acquire weapons and tools to help you navigate through BT territory and even others can assist during this time. 
It's not perfect, but once the game play opens up - it gets considerably more fun.

The story is what you can expect from a Kojima produced game. All of it's convoluted-ness and intrigue is there, while lacking in most of the humor he's known for, Kojima does bring in it in terms of emotion and depth. You play as Sam Porter Bridges - a contracted porter working his way across the USA in order to reconnect those who have been separated due to the Death Stranding. Along the way - you meet a merry band of characters who are just as odd and unique as a Kojima written character can be who will assist Sam along the way.  The story pacing, as well, can grind to a near halt in areas and some of it does feel like filler, but for the most part - The story has heart, intrigue, and depth that you'd only find in a Kojima game.

All in all despite my gripes with the game itself - I enjoyed myself as I was able to get deep into the game as it opened up to other players assisting you, and the story starts picking up momentum. While I did find myself frustrated to the point of never playing again from time to time, I found myself enthralled enough to enjoy the games to it's very emotional and rewarding in. In a nutshell - it was worth all the hard work and frustration. In a sense, you go through what Sam goes through. I found myself very satisfied in the end. I will play again.

It scores an 8 out of 10 for me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I played flight simulator.
I played truck simulator.
Now I'm playing Death Stranding, and it's very simulative.
The perfect pandemic simulator. 100 out of 10.

===After 65 hours of playing===

Ridiculous vehicle physics just like Euro/Murica Truck Simulator. OK.
Un-destructable vegetation just like Truck Simulator. OK.

Very bad: Cut scenes everywhere.

Activating terminal: cut scene
Make delivery: cut scene
Recycle items: cut scene
Making items: cut scene
Exiting terminal: cut scene
Get on vehicles: cut scene
Get off vehicles: cut scene
Encounter BTs: cut scene
Get out of BT zone: cut scene
Open PDA: cut scene
Building structures: cut scene

Cut scenes everywhere and I think they took at least 1/3 the time I played. This is very bad in my opinion and I think Japanese developers love to do this bullshit since PlayStation 1 and they never learn to do real time interactions just those in GTA and many other western games.

And graphics detail need more improvement on PC.

The North part of the map needs more tweak in gameplay. But thanks to all the player who make contribution to all the things, it's acceptable.

===What I like===

Kojima's music taste.
The general environment and atmosphere.
The BT concept.
The idea of connecting people, which I strongly felt during the COVID-19 pandemic isolation.
The way players take part in building a better world in this game's world, and how players interacting with each others.
Constructing buildings, which make almost every delivery much easier. The way you change the in-game environment leads to better or worse result you get.
"Like". I'm a fan of hitting likes on almost every social network platform.

===To be continued===

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I were very skeptical about this game when i first heard about it, i thought to myself, "who wants to play a walking simulator where you deliver packages", but i was wrong, and i'm glad i was.


I bought the game recently to try for myself, i saw some negative comments but mostly positive, so i thought why not, and now i have 23 hours played as of writing this review i don't usually write reviews for games, so if this review is not as good as the others, that's why.

I would never have thought a game where you deliver packages and walk across terrain would hook me so hard, but it has. At first i thought this game would be yet another horror game with cheap jump scares, but were pleasantly surprised when i found out it wasn't, at the beginning the BTs scared me, i hated walking past them, but now, after many successful encounters, i am more afraid of the mules stealing my packages than a BT encounter.

This world Hideo Kojima has made is something special, and i'm glad i took a chance on it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It took me awhile to recognize the feeling that this game gives me. You see, not too long ago I was in the military. At a barracks, like any other 18 yr old Marine. One day I made the mistake of using an elevator. 
I was promptly told by a Corporal who was most certainly lying. (though i didn't see it at the time) That, "A man with 1 leg used the stairs to get to his 3rd floor room." And that "I would never use the elevator again because it's disrespectful."
 
So I didn't, and for the rest of my time there I used the stairs. 
Every Sunday I would go get groceries and shit. And every Sunday, I had wayyy too many things to carry up to the 5th floor of my barracks. But do you think I was going to make a second trip? No way in hell was I making a second trip.

So there I was, with 10 bags, arms turning purple, taking breaks in the stairs. I lost balance, I dropped shit, people gave me words of encouragement on the way up... every week.  This game reminds me of that, cuz there's no way I'm making 2 trips.
 
I believe that one day Hideo felt the pain we've all felt and wanted to make a game out of it.
I'm glad he did.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Once, there was an explosion.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
From the moment Death Stranding was announced at E3 2016 I, like many others, was both confused and intrigued as to what the game actually was. For the almost 4 years following I was always excited to see what the game would become. When reviews for the game came out I watched IGN's review only to be disappointed by how it described the game. I didn't own a PS4 and had no knowledge of a PC port so I ended up forgetting about the game completely. 

In early February of this year while listening to a Spotify playlist of video game soundtracks the song 'Don't Be So Serious' caught my ear. On a whim I decided to listen to the entire album for Death Stranding on Spotify. One hour and forty five minutes later I had preordered my copy of Death Stranding on Steam and began the long wait for the game's release. Between early February and the time of writing this review(mid July 2020), as anyone not living under a rock would know, alot has happened in the world. Regardless of anyone's political stance it should be easy to agree that the world, especially the US, is in a state turmoil right now. Through out all of that time I had been listening to both Death Stranding's album and soundtrack. Its in this atmosphere that I played Death Stranding for the first time.

[b] If you are willing to purchase this game, stop reading reviews and buy it. If you still need convincing or just want to listen to some random person's analysis, read on. I will remain as spoiler free as possible. [/b]

It is important to preface any discussion about Death Stranding by saying the tried and true: 'this game is not for everyone'. It isn't. To help you figure out if you would enjoy this game let me help you picture a scene that  I experienced:

[i] You've been walking for ages now. You plod one foot in front of the other, carefully scanning the snow ahead of you to ensure that you wont slip and damage your cargo, or yourself. All you can hear is the deafening roar of wind rushing through the snowy peaks and your own shivers. The wind begins to pick up and you stumble to one side, the weight of your cargo on your back weighing you down excruciatingly. You know if you damage this cargo too much you'll have to turn back and start all over again. As you look up you let out a groan, no longer able to see more then a couple feet in front of you through the snowstorm. You pull up your map and see that you are so close to the end of this miserable mountain range so you take a swig from your trusted Monster Energy® flask, put your head down, and force yourself forward. After painfully slow step after agonizingly slow step you realize that you are actually heading down. Finally, you must be so close. The view ahead of you clears and you see a beautiful lush valley stretched out before you. You missed the color green. As you hurry down the slope and trod along the rocky tundra towards a structure in the distance booming orchestral synths and calming vocals fade in. You relax, you made it. You turn in your cargo and get ready for your next delivery. [/i]

If the scenario I just described gets you as aroused as it does me, get this game and stop reading this review. The core gameplay loop provides that experience in spades. Especially if you play on the hardest difficulty, which I recommend.

Now, over 580 words into this, lets start my actual review.

You may have noticed that in the scenario I just put forward I used the first person when, in reality, the game is third person almost entirely. That brings me to my first point I want to talk about. I have always been attracted to first person games since I played Skyrim. Ever since I wandered from Riverwood to Whiterun, then to Bleak Falls Barrow I have always been enamored with games that made me feel immersed in their world. Previous to playing Death Stranding I had believed that to be truly immersive as it could be a game needed to be in the first person. Death Stranding proved me wrong. I have never felt more immersed in a game's world. Considering as much of the time in this game is spent walking from one point to the next alot of pressure was put on the sound design and environment design teams to keep that travel engaging, and it is. The ambient sounds in this game combined with the astounding landscapes in this game actually made me want to use the games included photo mode(which is very good). I cant say much for spoiler reasons but the sights you will see and places you walk through in this game are truly awe inspiring, and the sound rises to meet it. The game really makes you feel like [strike] spiderman [/strike] you are there.

Speaking of walking through places now would be a good moment to talk about the level design. Level design is not something that is brought up often in most open world games but in Death Stranding it is done so well that I would feel amiss not touching on it. Much of the moment to moment decisionmaking in this game is based around deciding what route to take to your destination and how to do it. Looking back on some of the paths I took it is becomes obvious that there are certain routes that were designed as the primary way to approach a destination. However, these routes were so well crafted and hidden that they made me feel as if I was truly making my own path to the destination, while in reality I was going exactly where the game designers wanted me to do. Especially in an open world game, I have never see level design done this well and this subtle.

Earlier in my scenario I mentioned the music. Its incredible. I don't much care for the genre of music that Death Stranding uses however every single song on the 'songs from the game' album as well as the soundtrack is incredible. And when the songs fade in as you walk through desolate America it truly does fit the game perfectly and really works well with the themes of the game.

Lets talk about the themes of this game and its story. If anyone is reading this who has already played the game you are most likely chuckling to yourself. The story in this game is complex. Very complex. There are many twists and turns that rely on you truly paying attention to the cutscenes and dialogue to grasp. This is not the type of game where you can skip cutcenenes and still get the gist of the story from the mission instructions. I mentioned the atmosphere that I played this game in because it connects significantly to the themes of this game. This is the closest I will come to spoilers to I will leave my description of the themes of this game under a spoiler warning. While it doesn't spoil any plot points, some may want to discover the themes of this game themselves. [spoiler] The major themes of this game include human connection, isolation, and depression. Its obvious to see how these themes tie into the time I played this game. These themes are woven into the story and gameplay in ingenious ways, but those are to spoilery... [/spoiler] It is also important to mention that the story is slow paced and takes its time building the plot. It isnt poorly paced, it just takes time for the story to really open up and start making sense.

Finally. Game made me cry at the end. It takes alot for a game to make me cry, not tear up, cry. 

If after all of this you think that the game might be for you, then get it. It is fully worth the price of admission. Death Stranding weaves a complex and deep story that was a wonder to experience along with its fantastic gameplay systems and genre-defying gameplay. For me at least, Death Stranding will go down as one of my favorite pieces of media ever. And if you are the type of person who looks at the gameplay and gets horny or starts drooling at the mentioning of a slow paced sci-fi story it may just be a favorite for you as well.

Had to cut out middle of review coz Steam has a dumb character limit. Find the rest [url=https://pastebin.com/NvBMkQbD] here [/url]

I hope you enjoyed reading this essay as much as I enjoyed writing it. Kill me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Masterpiece !

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Very walk yes, good game please.......

On a real note, I cannot recommend this game enough. Im sure it's not for everyone, but if enjoy story driven games this will definitely be for you, going into this game I heard the many "walking sim" comments about it and even after some spoiler free gameplay it looked to be so but even with that I was still into getting it. Now don't get me wrong. This pretty much is a walking sim, but that's not all that it is, the world and story building that has been done in this game is amazing, thought there are some issues with pacing at times with cutscenes and whatnot, it's still worth the payoff in the end in my opinion. Took me about 60 hours to beat the main story. I did do a fair bit of side mission and road building but this is still a very long game. 

As for the gameplay, there are unlocks riddled throughout the whole "campaign" that make you feel like your constantly progressing, though for mostly all of the upgrades you do have to put in work, if your smart with package delivery you can unlock them along the way.

MY ONLY ADVICE IF YOU ARE CONSIDERING GETTING THIS GAME,

If you have seen some spoiler free gameplay of the traversal and is looks interesting to you GET IT.

If you get the game and are struggling in the beginning, just know that there is a sizable learning curve to the mechanics of the game.

Please, please just make it thorough the first 7-10 hours of gameplay, around chapter 3 the game "evolves" and you start unlocking some very useful things that will assist you on your journey.

ALSO, the game did run fine on my pc (gtx 1070, ryzen 5 1600) at 1440p medium high settings, though I did have stutter issues during some cutscenes, only one crash.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I can not recommend this game, primarily because it sets a bad precedent with constant advertisement. Every time you drink from your canteen in the game, and you will do so frequently, you're not drinking water but, an advertised beverage. Say on average you'll need to maintain stamina by keeping your hydration up some twelve times per hour. Well that's TWELVE advertisements of this beverage, per hour, in a game you paid $60 dollars for. 

I like this game because it's interesting but the beverage is not the only advertisement you will see that completely makes you question if you're playing a game or watching cheesy television. If you're considering purchasing this game make sure you do so only after a steep discount, otherwise you'll be over-paying to play a video game with blatant and constant advertisements. You might as well be playing a free-to-play mobile game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is not a game. It's a movie with game-play elements that deserve the title of "Masterpiece".

I want to personally meet Hideo Kojima and give him a hug. He has blended a fantastic game-play experience, immaculate and enthralling story, and rose to the level of excellence we expect of game developers. He hit me in a very particular spot in my heart that I've never experienced intimately. 

There are many who are cynical because of their pessimmistic and reductionistic approach that presents to you a boiled down synopsis of the greatness that is Death Stranding. Some are not comfortable with the game-play elements and that is understandable, but I ask you to take a second and google, "Death Stranding All Cutscenes". 

It takes you 11 hours to watch the entire "Game Movie". 

Death Stranding is not a game, it's a movie with game-play elements. It is easily my GOTY for 2020. 

Thanks for Everything, Kojima.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hello KOJIMA PRODUCTIONS,

You guys obviously produced a marvelous game truly meant for todays generation of computing. I love the graphics and attention to detail. This game is going to be one of my favorite for sure. Although I'm just wondering, am I going to have buy a whole new mouse? Let me rephrase, one of the most important aspects of the game, is traveling. And while traveling you may want to mark your point. Well, I can't do this. As my mouse is not registering the keybind. Or the game isnt recognizing the mouse. So, not being able to correctly navigate in a game where thats half of the process of playing can be kind of difficult. And most may think, its not that big of deal, just change the keybind. Well, there is no keybind friends. If you need to navigate on the map somewhere, unfortunately you wont know the trail to take, just the general direction from switching into GPS mode. My mouse is corsair and this function has been compatible in many other games. It would be greatly appreciated if I could please have some help on how to fix the matter or if this is known and is being worked on. Thank you guys for the stunningly beautiful game, I would love to explore it more.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I will start off by saying if nothing else the story of this game is reason enough to play it, feels like a proper movie and you won't see me complain about that. Moreover, it is true that the gameplay can be clunky at times but this can be avoided by planning your routes with care and using all of the equipment at your disposal, since once you start establishing your own routes with proper support structures it becomes super fun and easy to make deliveries. All in all, one should come to terms with the fact that this game is future UPS guy simulator and is different from anything else I have played before, as such one should commend Hideo Kojima for his decision to try and make something very unique. Finally, the games has some minor stuttering issues and the solution varies from system to system in make case I turned off Microsoft Game Mode, reverted to previous Nvidia driver, and disabled DSR (was on for some weird reason), which worked so no more stutters yay!
