title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] I'll keep it short [/h1]
(This is my favorite game up to date) I spent 180$ (1 on PS4, 1 on pc, 1 for my friend) I have 90 hours (on PS4) + the amount of hours when reviewing this.
___Why its good. Super unique I can't find a Triple A title like this one that de-rails so far from the norm. Whole new play style for. Also its relaxing and a super chill game.
___The bad. This "super unique play style" Is what causes such a split between the audience. For some its a shitty walking simulator. for Others Its a open world majestic work of art where scenes of beauty follow you every where. 
___What I recomend from my experience. Look at a non-biace Video about it before you buy. 
___My opinion (at this point you can stop reading): I love this game to death mainly because a walking simulator can only achive so much. That said, there is [b] SO MUCH [/b] attention to detail gameplay and story wise. If you need a game where you are bored, nothing to do, this is a game to vibe with. If you do end up buying it. If you start getting bored just do the main objective, the lore is really good and picks up when it seems like its halting to a snails pace.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Will make you miss flat ground...

Literally probably my favorite game and first Kojima game. In a way the game literally makes no sense but then it does. Its a strange satisfying and its annoying to hear people say its a walking simulator when people play 1000s of hours of games with farming and building fatories as the main aspect lol. 

Pros:
-game looks and sounds beautiful
-feels like a movie and a game had a child
-Soo much OCD goodness in setting up routes and theres actually progression in it
-story is fucking sweet
-Norman

Cons:
-literally will waste hours moving supplies to build roads
-anything before chapter 3 is a waste of time in respects to making any additional deliveries
- deliveries are a little generic in terms of dialogue and you rarely see the npcs you deliver to outside of their holograms which makes it feel really fallout 76 at times.
-You wont see flat ground until maybe chapter 4 
-driving over terrain is a hot mess 

9.5/10

And just when you think you've planned a route perfectly, it starts raining.

Definite 11/10 for me. Buy it. Play it. Love it. You won't regret it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
To development team of Kojima Production:

Thanks for your hard-working on Death Stranding and the PC edition; however, there is one problem I found is deserved to be fixed by you. I don't know whether you will read this comment, but I would like to spend time typing because I already played more than 50 hours and enjoy this game. Now, here is the problem:

The maximum amount of the chiral brandwidth is so low that it is not enough to build both the zipline and other structures. I tried to get more chiral brandwidth as much as I can by delivering the goods and getting the S rank grade so the star's rank will increase to the five stars. However, only 30-35k is not enough to build any structures when you finish creating the zipline net that connected all stations of the UCA. I found many users built other structures such as the generators, bridges, shelters, and so on, which helps me a lot to proceed with the story or finish the standard orders. However, It is clear that those people who help me a lot will not be ABLE to enjoy the fun and the convenience of using zipline across America. They help me and others, and I think they deserve to have that fun, and I, too, have the right to build the generator and other structures to help others and be able to across America by using the zipline at the same time.

I think you limited the brandwidth to 35k for maximum because you don't want the server to save too many structures, and it may crash the game because the system will share the arrangements made by others in each player's world. However, I think the key to solving this problem is to limit the number of structures that will be shared. Generally speaking, only 1-3 structures is okay to be shared because the players are so many, so you don't need to worry about whether the online buildings are too few.

And to increase the bandwidth's maximum, I think you can let players get bonus brandwidth by complete the standard orders after the player receives five stars in each cargo station. By completing the orders, the player will earn 10 to 100 bonus brandwidth to build more structures depends on the amount of the cargo and the difficulties of delivering. This will make players play longer and have more fun, and the rank of this game will increase too.

The lack of the amount of the brandwidth is a problem that already existed in the last year when the Death Stranding of the PlayStation edition released, at that time, the only way to build more zipline is to looking at other's zipline and try to make use of their zipline to save your own brandwidth, and give up to built any other structures to avoid "wasting" the brandwidth. I have already played the Death Stranding on PS4 and I finish the story and built my own network of the zipline. Not able to create the generators and the shelters is the thing makes me sad. I sweared that I will use cheat engine to achieve the dream of infinity brandwidth, but I think it is good to not use cheat engine but asking you to solved this problem. Anyway, we need more brandwidth, and we like Death Stranding.

Fin.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
---Positives---
Great story
Compelling characters 
Weapons are cool toward the end 
The game is beautiful

---Negatives---
Game mechanics are flawed (Camera is a pain, the game pauses for 3-4 seconds EVERY SINGLE TIME a BT area pops up to make it MORE DRAMATIC)
Depending on the criteria, which I still do not know, you have to either hit ESC or click the Right Mouse button to skip a small cinematic which happens EVERY SINGLE TIME you pick up/deposit deliveries, take a shower, do a fragile jump, change something you're carrying, depositing building supplies to build ANYTHING. If I were to sit there and allow the cinematic to run, the 41 hours it took me to beat this game would easily be 55 - 60 hours I feel considering I built tons of roads, devices, depots, etc etc etc. 
Why is no one allowed to carry EXTRA AMMO? Why the hell do I have to go back to a supply depot to refill weapons? 
Why is the truck unlocked WAY into the game? Is it necessary to hobble the players and force them to steal mule trucks? You also cannot repair them which is great too. 

All in all, I liked the game but I was annoyed through most of it with hours upon hours of unnecessary cinematics, unskippable scenes and more.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Basic stuff that glistens my glizzies:
[list]
    [*]Native 21:9 support including cutscenes.
    [*]GRAFICS are nice apart from the AA (only FXAA and TAA are available) but I run an AMD card and FidelityFX does help quite a bit. Distinguishable difference ON vs OFF.
    [*]Overall, headphones-optimized audio is in desperate need of much more dynamic range. The sound stage is so small for audio cues that are most frequently listened i.e. the accumulated "likes" chime, the MULE shrilling riff alert, and the sign effect chime. The positioning is much too close to the ears, and I am using a pair of open-backed Philips SHP9500 which performs amazingly well in many other games and media, even Youtube and Spotify. Good job on toning down the sibilant sounds though, especially in dialogues.
[/list]

Not gonna say too much since I think I've barely even scratched the surface on this game (only up to the Wind Farm and went back down to the West Distro) but I just want to say this:

[h1]It has been a while since I last felt like jumping back into a game as soon as I wake up, and do nothing else but play a video game aside from taking short breaks to stretch my legs, go to the bathroom, and have meals.[/h1]

I am so glad to have taken days off work to play this!!!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's really not easy to describe this game to someone who hasn't played it yet.

somehow the opinion quickly arises that what you do has to be boring ... you just run around and deliver stuff. but if you play this game with other genres, you get the same effect. 
example: [list]
[*]racing games: you drive around in circles
[*]survival games like minecraft: you mine resources to build tools to mine better resources to build better tools to ... (you get the idea)
[*]Jump ’n’ Runs: u jump over stuff so u dont fall into stuff[/list]

it's not so much about what you do but how you do it!

and how you do it is just fun. After a short period of familiarization, the controls are really good and are only a challenge at the beginning. Afterwards, a lot of tools, weapons, vehicles and other constructions come into play to compensate for the ever increasing difficulties. 

the landscapes are beautiful and the soundtrack atmospheric and hypnotic. this is the perfect game to escape everyday life and immerse yourself in a decelerated world full of miracles and mysteries for a few hours.

To call this game ONLY as a walking simulator would be a gross misjudgment of the title as a whole, and many who take this opinion have only dealt with the title superficially to their disadvantage. The beginning of Death Stranding can be tedious, but that was exactly the intention. Only through hardship does the triumph feel real. Only through hardship can we experience the transformation from a simple errand boy to a high-tech logist as a satisfactory climb!

and once you're there, the game really starts!

So, if you are the least bit interested in the game, give the game a chance and try it out. you will not be disappointed. nobody can explain the fascination of death stranding, you have to experience it!

keep on keeping on!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The best walking simulator out there!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
At the time of this review I just finished the story, and all I have to say is that this game for me is a 10/10 it's an unforgettable journey and one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had.

It may be a slow game for starters but the fact that you need to put effort into this game makes it so much more magical in the end.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If you're looking for a fairly relaxed game to wind down with or just want a really relaxed open world experience there's definitely something here for you to enjoy. Also if you enjoy helping random strangers out while having zero actual contact with them, this'll work for you too.

That said:

-The story isn't great, it's got a lot of plot holes and things that are just never explained even slightly; beyond the normal strangeness you would expect for a Kojima game. The actual performances by the actors are good, it's just the writing doesn't support them what so ever.

-Combat's not great and kinda feels like an after thought that they tacked on to try and break up the pacing a little bit. It's not that the controls are terrible or anything, it's more that there's very little reason to ever fight anyone aside from if a delivery requires you to. ( Maybe that's the point? I dunno. )

-If you do end up playing this, make sure you set the animation that plays when you enter a BT area to "First Time Only" otherwise it'll get annoying REALLY quickly. ( Also you can skip virtually all dialog and animations with either Tab or clicking through them. )

All in all, I think if you're the sort of person that is very completion oriented you'll definitely get a lot of play time out of this. Or if you're the sort of person that enjoys trying to optimize your quest routes, you'll probably enjoy it as well. For the average person, probably wait until this goes on sale for like $20-$30 bucks.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Absolutely mesmerizing story, gameplay picks up after the first four hours.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I want to Love this game.  and in one way i do.
and will play it many times over. But.. can i recomend it for the price tag? No..
this game is very thought through.. nice caracters and quite a scary yet interesting story. 
beautiful graphics and quite cool mechanics.. but thats where it ends..
the gameplay is not fun at all after 10+ hours.. why?
well, you run from Point A to B... and there is bearly no danger, the Raiders/human enemies  as i call them. are always at the same spots.. shown at the map. you just walk round it instead of through.
th BTs are always scary and sometimes quite hard.. but i dont encunter then often.
The ground is plain flat... its a game about traversal... you need to go up a hill? well its already 4 different ladders and 4 ropes there from other people, at ALL TIMES... you dont need to bring youre own equipment, even then 9 out of 10 places can be walkable without putting out a single ladder/rope, and ropes only works if you want to climb down.. so dont expect to use it to get up. 

the terain is way to easy. i would say the starter area is way way harder, then the rest of the game.
 and when you carry stuff, it never takes you from 1 side of the map to the other, you always get a quest that brings you to the closest base of where you take the quest. so even though the terrain is very flat with some smal roks you just Run over with ease, you dont really have to walk that far. the only danger is that you run to much and stumble, easy to fix by holding both youre hands on the backpack that only drains a bit more of youre stamina.

it gets very repetive very fast. i played 30 hours and so far only unlocked a gun that shoots my poop (yea no joke, youre ammo is poop and pee). sometimes youre blood. 
and ive unlocked exo skeleton for youre legs..
so striving for these runs makes it feel very poinless and not rewarding at all.
 feels like if you play GTA and need to walk from 1 building to another.. thats how easy it is.
the world is also very empty. no "wow" experiences anywhere.. there is a huge waterfall in the walkthrough, but thats it nothing else but some rocks, gras, and snow. no forrests, or lakes etc.. exactly as bland missions/map as metal gear solid was.

Not worth it.. unless you wait for a huge sale where the game goes for 20 dollars.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: It's bizarre:  I bought a "Picking up heavy things and carrying them long distances, with Tactical Breath Holding" Simulator.  I"m glad I didn't know that before I bought the game, or I wouldn't have bought the game, and I really would have missed out on a different kind of game experience.  It's a deep dive in to a Sci-Fi story that is not always sophisticated, graceful in style, or consistent in exposition, but is compelling nonetheless.  The dialog can be clumsy, but the success of this story is as much in the open space, dream imagery, and creative art directionas anything.  Death Stranding proves the adage that "It's the journey, not the destination."

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Kojima and his team did it!
Finally, a triple A quality game with soul.
Nearly tens hours in to the game and I am still not killing anybody (not because I try perfect stealth run), still do not have a gun to shoot. Why would I need a gun?
I am a porter. 
I am not an agent of death and destruction. To wreak more havoc on the world?
My job is to connect.
My tools is the rope and the ladder. One to bring things together and one to bridging the gap.
In a world so device and fragmented. Kojima and his team make a game about connecting people, make us whole again. And I respect that.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Just an amazing game that grows on you over time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]Most unique AAA-game I have played.[/h1]

Not too long time ago before Death Stranding PC release I finished Red Dead Redemption 2 and I found found hard to recommend that game to everyone. In Death Stranding's case it's even harder.

As you can see in the Steam Store page, the most popular user-defined tag for this game is "Walking simulator". But that's only a half-truth. Heck, I don't even play "Walking simulator" genre games (or the games that I have played don't feel like one). If you ask from me, the way I would describe DS would be with tags like "Inventory management" and "connection/ connected genre". Inventory management-tag is on 8th spot on user defined tags for DS. However, as the head of Kojima Productions Hideo Kojima himself has stated, Death Stranding is partly a whole new game genre calling it himself "strand-genre". 

So what you do in this genre? Long story short you don't see other players running in the map, BUT you and around 40 other players are connected together and things you build/ leave on to the overall map will appear on others map. If someone build a bridge or repaired part of the motorway it is done in your map too once you have connected that part of the area to your faction's network by bringing delivery packages in your backpack.
Yes, as you can see in the store page screenshots this game is 95% about delivering cargo from point A to point B. While on the paper that sounds extremely boring.
But Kojima Productions have tried to do many things in order to make the cargo delivery fun/ engaging-gameplay:
+ BT's behaviour is mysterious
+ System filled gameplay
There are many different gadgets, weapons and couple of vehicles each with own advantages and disadvantages. While playing the game you get small stat upgrades to your player character, 90% of "getting good" in this game comes from learning to understand game's mechanics and ability to adjust your gameplay style to required one.

+ Visual presentation
This game looks visually amazing, pretty sure you can see that from the Store page pictures yourself.

+ Music
Seriously, it feels like Low Roar-band had prepared it's whole life to collaborate with Hideo Kojima all the way from 2011.

+ Writing
Hideo Kojima's Metal Gear Solid-franchise has always been filled with interesting writing for plot and characters that are totally out of ordinary and despite Kojima leaving Konami and MGS-franchise behind DS is still well written and thoughts provoking. Especially world building-writing is extremely up-to-date in 2020 with global pandemic and politically divided USA.

+ Moving to different locations with cargo is not just pressing W-key
While I played DS the closest game that came into my memory was when I played Zelda: Breath On The Wild in Hard-mode. In Z:BOTW Hard-mode you are most likely going to be wrecked by enemies so sneaking past them by flanking from side climbing the mountain was solid strategy. In DS this same philosophy is good strategy too but instead of just moving your character and camera when needed you also need to take care of your balance with cargo and keep an eye out for BT-monsters, environmental dangers and items that rust in your backpack.

DS is not a game without problems, nothing too serious ones if you ask me but I recommend to acknowledge them before plausible purchase of the game:

- Mission variety is VERY small
Like I mentioned at the start of this review, it's 95% about cargo delivery. It's hard to say what else I might have wished but maybe an optional task of rescuing a person from danger could have welcome etc.

- Why credits roll twice in the last two hours of the game?
In other words once you have seen credits once in final moments of the game you still have at least 30 minutes story to see.

[b]Verdict:[/b]
Death Stranding is a game that cannot be recommended to be everyone. Not because it's a hard or bad game if you ask me, but because the things you do in it will not "click" into many players. But for those who it does and have time to play over 35 hours long game, it's a must buy and play while connected to online game worth of the 60 to 90 bucks.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I left the capital heading west, with loads of supplies, to bring hope to those who I didn't give a damn.
I slided across the nation, grasses, rocks, swamps, snowstorms, to find the purpose of life and death.
I came back home with an emtpy backpack, yet carrying the weight of humanity.
I found that beyond entertainment the game is a piece of art and philosophy.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is a game about world building. I don't mean rebuilding the world, but exploring a world vastly different from our own. Where the unraveling of what is going on is the story, the characters know they lived it. But yes you do also play a role in rebuilding it the supplies on your back aren't all just "disc based media" which is probably porn DVDs. 

Combat is almost non existent which isn't a problem. Sure Sam, the player character, can throw a good punch and knock out MULES (raiders), but it's also easy to just avoid them. The world itself hates you enough that just moving from point A to point B can be a challenge, of course as you progress you can help rebuild and make it easier to travel completing other objectives in the area faster. 

The tone and world remind me of reading Stephen King's The Dark Tower series this world feels like it has "moved on".

You will deal with hazards such as sharp cliffs to climb, descend, or go around, invisible monsters, time traveling rain, and a crying infant.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is an Experience. The story is hard to follow, but that only invites intrigue. I [i]want[/i] to know more. I have the feeling that this game's world has so much to offer in terms of lore, and I find myself wanting to dive deeper.

The game runs wonderfully. I can have every setting maxed with discord running in the background, and it not just consistently but [i]constantly[/i] hits and even passes 60fps (RTX 2060 Super, mileage may vary). The game world is beautiful, and the art and design direction plays perfectly into the game's bizarre story.

The gameplay is surprisingly fun, I keep coming back to it even though it's mostly just walking. This game makes walking [i]enjoyable[/i]. There are many mechanics that go into it, such as balance, momentum, and the way the terrain affects your travel. Some guides say if you just always hold both balance buttons, you'll never have to deal with most of the traversal challenges. And while this is true, you shouldn't constantly do this. It defeats much of the purpose of the game's mechanics.

The music is rarely heard, but when you [i]do[/i] hear it, it invokes many emotions. The lyrics pace well with the environment you're traveling through at the time. Many complain that there's no music player in the overworld, and while that would perhaps be nice, I can certainly see why it's not a feature. The atmosphere benefits from both the presence and absence of music.

The enemies are perhaps my least favorite part of the game, though that's not to say I don't enjoy them. For the bandits, you can avoid the marked areas of their territory easily enough with the map. The BTs, however, have no territory markings, save for those that others put down. This makes any timefall that happens suspenseful, even when you aren't likely to have to start sneaking.

Finally, the online aspect of the game is one of its strongest parts. The way your structures help others as well as yourself helps foster the sense of connection that the game's themes revolve around, as do the player placed signs along the way. The game can and will still feel lonely, but you never feel like you're doing everything alone. The signs of other people working as you are towards a common goal are everywhere.


But none of that matters, because you can make Norman Reedus pee. 10/10.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Bought and finished the game back on release on PS4 and now bought it again on PC.
Gorgeous port, runs like a charm on PC, full controller support, and since I finished the story I can just take my  time and do things left and right as I feel like. Photo mode is also a nice little addition to tinker with when coming across a particularly nice view and such.

The addition of Very Hard difficulty is a nice thing for those who enjoy a challenge, personally Hard difficulty (the Hardest back on console) is the perfect balance of fun and challenge.

On a more personal level I find it to be a wonderful game to just unwind and empty your head while idly doing deliveries and such.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
While Death Stranding has a great story and universe, but the gameplay is far from enjoyable, especialy the fact that you get off balance way too often and can fall very easily. But most importantly, and even knowing that this game is not meant to be an action game, it is incredibly slow paced, especially the last part which are mostly very long cutscenes and a long flashback which you have already seen (albe fragmentarily) during the rest of the game.
So, all in all, i'll simply go with another critic I have seen around : this should have been a two and a half hours movie rather than a thirty/forty hours long game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Kojima did it again.

I really love this game, definetly going into my favs.
Music is awesome, gameplay is very original and fun.
Graphics are obviously fantastic, even on low.
Multiplayer is well done, it's very fun building roads and bridges with other players.
Combat is very simple but well made as well.
I'm enjoying the story so far.

i did bump into some bad stuff unfortunately.

Climbing feels quite clunky in my opinion.
Game difficulty seems to affect only the combat and not other things like traversal and BTs.
Invisible walls? Seriously?

Also i've been getting some really annoying crashes, not quite sure what's causing them, something about internal system error, DirectX 12 related stuff. playing on low and turning off wallpaper engine delays the crash by couple of hours.

in summary: The game has some hiccups, but overall it's worth 60€ and i'd vote it for 2020 Goty.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
*SPOILER FREE REVIEW*

First off: I have 37 hours in the game so far, and I am far from even the end of the story.

This game has "some grind". I despise grinding, I always did. In Death Stranding I don't even feel it. What you do helps yourself, and helps other players as well! It actually feels worth grinding. The actual first game I ever enjoyed grinding in.

Combat: Not too much, most can be avoided, but if You are the type You can find a ton of it. And it's actually worth not skipping the fights, as they are your greatest source of resources, and you'll want a lot of those if you want to make your file easier.

Quality:
The actors performance is top notch.
There are a few soundtracks, but they rarely kick in.
Graphics/aesthetics wise the game is "realistic"(?). The elements in the environments are well in unison, but are also distinct enough from each other so that they don't break immersion, while You can still find anything/everything easily.
World building is story wise is amazing. There is a lot of data (readable) scattered around, that you will gain just by playing, so if you care about that then worth reading.

Thank you developers.
Thanks you Kojima.

And last but not least. Thank you, Players in the porter community <3

(if you play the game you'll understand the last one ;-) )

The most insulting part was when the music soundtrack kicked in. I'm walking... I'm bored... and the music kicks in so that I can really enjoy the cinematic boredom. I tried disabling music but couldn't find the setting, then I just snapped and requested a refund. I'm at 2.9 hours so they might not refund it, but I just have to try. I'm so bored.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] DEATH STRANDING REVIEW [/h1]
If I could describe the game in one word is "[b]ATMOSPHERIC[/b]".
The game concept is as simple as it looks, delivering from point A to B, but with a few complexities here and there like inventory management, taking items that will come useful on your way, sorting your cargo in specific ways (back, arms, hips). Planning your routes, delivering different cargo for different destinations on one go, stuff like that is what it makes it engaging and entertaining. The combat system is pretty simple as well, the game encourages not to kill, so most of it is incapacitating with melee and there are fun, hilarious, and creatives ways to do so, (if you've played MGS games before you'll know) although it is not that fully integrated to the core of the game, but it does a pretty great job. 

There are simple mechanics in the game that you start to appreciate a lot the further you go like the online asynchronous features, after almost dying, having a vehicle stop working or having most of your cargo get ruined from timefall (rain), etc., you could find such structure that could fix your said problem and it was all because of that person who made that structure and therefore helped you on your journey, that for me was the biggest feeling of gratitude that you wouldn't find elsewhere. 
The items that you get as you progress helps a LOT on your journey. Unlocking each reward item as you progress is a sigh of relief, a bit of hope to make you through the tough terrains, the BTs, MULEs, and weather, all of the danger, so you can make it to the west to complete your mission of reconnecting America while you build structures for others to use and also people who helps you, and that makes the game extremely "[b]REWARDING[/b]". 
So, you make all this journey for a reason which is the story.
The story can be described as "[b]convoluted[/b]", definitely. It is a Kojima game so it will be very convoluted like the MGS storyline. From the beginning to the end of the story I can easily say it is very complex, hard to follow, and with a few cringy dialogues but honestly they weren't that bad as people say, but they are definitely corny. MGS games had very few of those dialogues as well, but the [b]emotional and major plot point scenes[/b] were what it made those games special. And man... This one has MANY of those, great scenes and performances absolutely. Most of the big revealing moments story-wise are dumped almost at the end, most won't like that but I liked it the way, there were many cutscenes before and throughout the game that asked the questions so at the end everything would be answered. However, as you progress you would get documents that would answer some, and give you more info about the world and science behind everything which I liked a lot. 
There was a part on the snowy part of the game on par with the story that I thought it dragged a bit, it was three orders in a row, go here go there for a sense of progressing that was done poorly. But, I digress, I'm playing it again on PC because I think it deserves an other playthrough, it was a great original experience that most won't even have.

I played it once on the PS4 from start to finish and wanted to keep on playing, but I thought it was better to wait for the PC version to experience it on its max potential, so I'm playing it again right now. In conclusion, the [b]ridiculously good OST and songs from the bands[/b] were combined [b]perfectly[/b] with the beautiful scenery and all the things I mentioned above. The game is a big atmospheric trip with a strangely addictive gameplay loop that was executed nicely and very risky to do. From the moment you look at the main menu and start the game, and see the opening credits and prologue, you can sense the tone of the whole game. While it is not a perfect game and certainly not for everyone, but could be for you and you don't even know. The pros in this game excels the cons absolutely. It is one of those games that will make you want to play it again in the future only to remember that you actually know everything and won't be the same as the first time, but at least you'll know that it will be enjoyable.

I love the feeling of logging in and seeing how my structures or signs helped others, and I swear I spent about 2 hours at the very begining just looking for lost stuff to finish and help others. This game really shows that re-connecting is snot only helpful, but a necessity of life. I hope others see the message left by Kojima here. And take this wonderful piece of art as more than just a game. But something that can help people mentally. Call a friend, Talk to someone, Send a note.... review:
This game is not for everyone.
If you have a short attention span and you like getting instant gratification, then you will not be able to get any enjoyment out of this game.

You need a completely different approach to experience this game. Ask yourself the following question -
"If the purpose of eating is just nourishment then why bother with taste?"
This game may be a walking simulator in a nutshell. But it gives you that right taste in the right place and time. And that is how Kojima delivers.

This is an Art.
Don't just play it. Experience it.

10/10 a Kojima Production™

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
So much is done right here that it immediately demolished my hesitation about jumping into a game that's being described as a "walking simulator."

[list]
[*]Traversal feels great.  Watching gameplay I was worried it'd have the "running up the side of a mountain in Skyrim and frantically trying to jump until I manage to get past this rock" problem, but that hasn't been an issue.

[*]Movement overall feels great and is meaningfully affected by how much you're carrying and weight distribution.  The movements and animations generally have a certain fluidity to them that is easy to compare to MGSV animations.

[*]The game doesn't waste your time.  This is a huge one for me.  The animations aren't painfully slow & drawn out, transition cutscenes can be quickly skipped, setting up ladders and tethers for traversal is very quick and fluid - it all feels good and doesn't slow you down.  I especially like how, while you can micromanage your carried cargo to distribute the weight and make traversal easier, you can just as easily press a single button to auto-sort your cargo to distribute the weight.  Everything feels snappy and responsive and navigating menus doesn't make me want to pull my hair out.  Hell yeah!

[*]Holy shit these keybinds.  A lot of console-first games that get PC ports later on end up having [i]godawful[/i] keyboard controls that have you constantly repositioning on the keyboard.  This game does not have that problem at all.  It's hard to put into words, but it's basically the opposite experience of playing RDR2 with a keyboard.  It's all just really intuitive.
[/list]

I greatly enjoy this game, and playing at double the framerate with visuals that exceed native 4K at times (using DLSS 2.0) without the performance cost is quite the achievement

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If I had a penny for every time somebody asked me a similarly phrased question "Is $60 worth playing delivery simulator?" I probably could have bought this game 10 times over. Going to write an early game preliminary review. I remember the earliest game play footage of babies, weird smokey figures, and Mads Mikkelsen cut scenes (the guy who plays Hannibal for those of you who don't know) and said to myself what the hell is this going on about? 

I should first start off by prefacing this game is designed by the same creator behind the MSG series but I don't see anybody telling me "How is the stealth simulator?" I mean really come on ... you all love MSG... so get over yourselves and take some time to actually know what this game delivers and the creator behind the message. 

First two hour expectations: 
- Long cinematic cutscenes. Very detailed and highly entertaining to watch.  The first 1-2 hours of the game is primarily cinematics along with two early missions. The cinematics early game were very encouraging to "get out there" and experience the world. They were very necessary though... theatrically it summarizes who, when, why, where, and how questions that many of you are left wondering for those trapped in the mindset: "it's a delivery simulator." Those plot line questions have interesting explanations behind them... Kojima wastes no time narrating during these cinematics about the story-line world set in front of you. I thought Del Toro's appearance was comical but his character has been the most interesting one so far... but, hey, I am not going to reveal the answers revealed but let me tell you one thing here there is a deep and captivating story behind what you about to experience that isn't understood in the early game play/teaser footage... poor marketing but it's the truth. I want to mention that I feel the story as it has been laid out has been an original experience. I can't quite think of a game similar to this one.. .and wouldn't be surprised if they scripted a TV show for it. 

Mechanics: 
- They were more interesting than I had realized. I have to confess all the negative simulator comments almost discouraged me from playing... the early missions play very similar to what the haters describe but they serve as tutorials nothing more... but when you start to encounter heavy load missions, complex terrain, stamina management, weather systems, BT (the monsters), BB meter, and raiders... you realize the game isn't as simple as "Hey, go to point A to B and drop off a box." You have to plot, prepare, and make calculated decisions... Think of the delivery mechanic of the game as the game's movie motif" it places you in the center of the story in the most interesting way possible. I found some of the most enjoyable scenes in the game for me was resting on a mountain top with loads of junk sitting on my back and the soundtrack playing in the background... really sets the mood and places you within the story like it should. The food/water system is really basic, but it exists, and it's there. 

Music/Visuals:
Absolutely great thus far ... I am not sure if the music sequences are played at random or in linear storytelling fashion but when you hear the music it really captivates you in the well designed topography. When I jumped over rocks, small water streams, hearing my footsteps against the ground, and my character suffering the pains of travel only to hear Low Roar - I'll Keep Coming play in the background and I was like blown away.. Strongly encourage you all reading the review to download the soundtrack... Gives me an Oblivion/Stranger things vibe at times... what a unique touch in my opinion. 

Community:
This is the most curious part of the game so far and I don't think I quite fully understand it but it really does have its moments. When you become involved in your missions and begin to "feel" the struggle and there's a community sign you run into giving you that stamina buff it's like the best godsend out there... or when you discover a left over ladder and/or bridge when you most need it.. because the game can sometimes be taxing and I can only imagine what is left to see further on... so discovering these left over structures encourages to push on with the delivery... You can build community markers/structures that other players not only benefit from but can "like" in the process and in doing so gives you buffs. It feels like a shared struggle experience although you never see them.. but if you get lonely just tap #5 all day.. 

Cons:
Yes they exist ...despite you playing an awesome 'moviegame' there are some cons worth mentioning... The menu system is long, and convoluted. Every mission requires you to sit through the score count. You can bypass this but after a few times it does become irritating. The vehicle mechanics don't feel smooth at all and I am really concerned how the bigger vehicles will feel. When you play without the vehicles you feel like your character belongs in the world. He is responsive to all the conditions around and reacts to your weight distribution. This touch is lost when you enter the vehicles.. I even wonder if they considered not adding vehicles at all at some point. They are clunky when they hit rocks, and terrible for coming down hill... but again I haven't tried anything outside the motorcycle. The map plotter is annoying to use and really needs a lot of work... unless I missed it being a noob I wish greater features could be added such as notes and better topography like features. What I mean by my last sentence is I wish I could see what the terrain ahead of me looks like a bit  better than the flat view so I plot better routes. And I do believe the return period should be longer than 2 hours for new players because the cut scenes will eat all the game time.. not a fair exchange. 

Is this game for you? 
- If you enjoy the MSG series you will find a lot you like here **creatively speaking**. It doesn't have that action pack punch that MSG serves but if you want to enter and be involved in a whole other world than this game can be a great turn of pace for you... 
- However... if the story, cinematics, atmosphere, and music etc ... isn't enough for you... you might be bored between delivery points.. but it's hard to even consider that but all gamers are different right? If you're a COD player this game might bore you to death for instance... but if you want to EXPERIENCE the world and be absorbed by it than this solemn game has a lot to offer you.

Is it worth $60?
MSG games were always worth their open price to me and I had no regrets... and I thoroughly enjoyed the game.. nothing wrong with waiting for a discount or steam sale... but I definitely feel I bought a complete product and I am satisfied with my purchase. 

to conclude ... 
I plan on playing the game and will update the review a bit better down the line... quickly wrote this up to address all the inquiries I've received. I hope this helps lend some light on the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The Earth is a solemn yet serene landscape. Time has beaten it's trees and structures to dust. Even so, the past just won't let go - just like the last scattered humans on Earth who press on against hope, in a world enshrouded by death. 

This is the world of death stranding, a game I've been curiously enthralled by despite all of my negative expectations. A walking sim, made by a game director I've never liked, set in a confusing world. Exciting, right? And yet I find myself totally engrossed in an atmospheric wonder, with surprisingly nuanced mechanics, and a desire to master the game's asynchronous multiplayer components.

I'm consistently surprised by the nuance of the game's mechanics. The game may be slow paced, but it does force you to constantly be making decisions. Just traversing the stoicly obliterated terrain requires calculation by the player. There's always too much cargo to carry, and useful tools will take up space. Plus more weight means slower and more difficult traversal, so it's always interesting deciding how to divy things up, looking at the map and wondering how many ladders you will need, if you will need hematic grenades, or if the terrain is too rough to max out your weight. It starts off very easy, but little things that seem irrelevant at the beginning will become more hazardous later as increased hazards and restrictions raise the stakes. And once you have an array of tools to pick from, choosing what you actually need becomes a more complex task. The game doesn't do a good job of explaining the mechanics. Almost every important bit of knowledge I have has come from a buried submenu called "tips" rather than exposed through a tutorial. I went in thinking this would be a game with no combat, and my attempts at stealth led me to be frustrated. But once I learned that you could fight the mules and BT's, the game became far more interesting. I've seen other reviews claim that vehicles make the game too easy. I think they must have not gotten very far, because enemy BT's annihilate vehicles and mules quickly begin to use their own vehicles. Much of the terrain is more difficult to traverse by vehicle so you'll often have to ditch the vehicles by the nearest road and finish your journey on foot. 

The game heavily pushes a singular theme in a way that connects everything. You may find it overly contrived, or you may find the themes of isolation and internet culture surprisingly pointed. For me, it mostly just builds a very consistent and compelling atmosphere. Not just in the atmosphere of trekking through whispering mountain passes and a brilliant soundtrack that constantly leaves you with somber undertones. Almost every aspect of the world is some form of allegory of the consequences of digital society. Kojima sometimes goes out of his way to turn simple things into complicated things just to make the analogies more on point. The mules are a perfect example. They aren't simple bandits, they are actually addicted to making deliveries, which is the true reason they want to steal your cargo. This makes no sense until you realize that it's an allegory for people living fake internet lives. While playing, you may be forced to ask yourself, does your interactions with your friends make you a Porter, or a mule? Are you connecting with your internet society, or are you isolating yourself? Is it possible to connect to people on the internet at all? It's all particularly relevant during the pandemic.

And to go along with this thematic bombardment is an asynchronous multiplayer system - basically once you "connect" a region to the network, you will start to see structures built by other players appear in that region, and structures you've built can appear in other player's games. Although you never actually see another player, they can influence your world, and you can influence theirs. They can leave behind helpful signs or bridges, and if you help other players they can give you likes (likes are essentially the XP progression of this game). The way the world is gradually populated by these things makes it feel a bit less desolate, and makes you feel like you're part of a community, but it's a distant type of community, where your only interactions are indirect and coincidental. It ties in really well with the core theme of the game and gives you an extra thing to strive for. It's hard to deny the feeling of accomplishment when something you leave behind generates a lot of likes, the game tracks all of this and you can go back into your logs and see which things you laid down helped the most people and see how many people you helped.

Anyway, I'll update the review as I play more, I think I hit a point where I mostly get where the game is going but we'll see.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Holy shit, I'm seriously impressed!

All those completely bonkers trailers (and supposedly disconnected from each other) that were launching before the game and presenting characters, are actually all part of the game and make sense in its story.
A story that I guess was written focusing on the characters first by the way it's presented. Some reviewers commented that it's a really weird way to present the story, but I did end up really liking it. The super strong and interesting characters pull their weight to help the flow of it all. 
It's not all perfect though. I really liked the point the story was making (hits even harder in the pandemics time) as it's a simple, but needed message for everyone. But I felt it way heavy handed for me. I don't usually like heavy handed stories as the subtext just turns into the superficial text with no meaning behind it to leave something to think about.

The gameplay, yes in a really bad reductive way can be described as a walking simulator. but it really is much more complex and interesting than that. It's a game that can make the prospect of a walk through a mountain super stressful.
I don't want to explain the mechanics because the surprise of how it all plays out was a nice surprise to me and I just recommend everyone wanting a inovative game experience to just play it.

An awesome and interesting experience that I'll think about and recommend probably even 10 years from now

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
At the time of writing this review, I have just finished the game (43 hours in)

i..... wish i had someone to hug right now. it's a lot. It's one of the best experiences that I've ever played (definitely up there with Night In The Woods).

It's a lot of emotions to handle all at once. But it really made me appreciate the connections I've made with other people, friends and family. and especially in the current pandemic where most of us have to live apart without direct contact.

It's a lot

play this game

P.S. Don't think too much about the discourse around the game itself. I myself have seen mostly negative reviews before playing this game and I was really positively surprised to find out I enjoyed this game as much as I did. And I don't like walking simulators nor grindy errand boy type of games. This game is way different than what I believed it to be. It's a journey.

And if you thought the pre-release media for that game was confusing, don't worry! Pretty much everything makes sense in the end.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game isn't for everyone. If you're looking for a game where it has lots of action, you're some kind of super hero that can tank everything and the story handed to with a book Stories for Dummies, then this isn't for you.

If you're looking for a game that has a very rich story which constant twists and turns and having to connect dots to figure things out and a bit slow paced gameplay, this game is for you. It's made by Hideo Kojima after all.

The game starts off slow, but not annoyingly slow. If you've played Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, it's almost identical to that (but actually finished and not rushed *cough cough Konami*). Instead of "missions" (Like mission 1,2,3 etc) you have "deliveries" (Delivery 1,2,3, etc), after doing some of the main "missions" (deliveries) some of the story unfolds. And after a while the [main story] deliveries are story related themselves. 

You might become annoyed at first at the lack of story telling, but once you just start to say to yourself "When is the story going to play out more?" it does just that. It drags you back in. The story gradually picks up, pieces start to connect, then twists and turns happen making even more sense that your current theory you thought you had right. The story plays out beautifully. 

The gameplay itself involves, as you most likely know, a lot of walking. There's very few times you're forced into combat, but the game does a good job of hinting towards it to prepare yourself. Any other encounter you can sneak by, or just run if you must. The combat is decent enough, plays just like MGS:V for the most part.

A big part of the gameplay is movement. It's annoyingly realistic. Land on some mud wrong, your foot is slipping you have to catch yourself. Jumping on rocks? Rock has a good chance of crumbling depending on the type of rock, making you lose your balance. Running in the mud during rain? You have a good chance of some foot slippage. Overall, when moving, move as you would in real life, or you will slip and even topple over a lot. There is equipment to help with that however.

I was like most people, skeptical of the game and the way it would play out, but the atmosphere, voice acting, story, story telling, gameplay, it's all amazing and very well worth buying

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] Tomorrow Is In Your Hands. [/h1]

Death Stranding is a game that, at launch, I thought I would hate. It's my first game from acclaimed developer, Hideo Kojima, so I didn't have any of the baked-in enthusiasm that (probably) most people had. I always thought it looked interesting, but I was never truly [i] sold [/i].

From the very first trailer that I saw, I thought it may be a cool, trippy, action game that I could pick up at some point. As I saw more trailers, my anticipation grew more and more. That is, until I learned what the core gameplay loop would be. 

[b] delivering packages [/b]

A walking simulator?!?! Or at least, that's what all of the early previews and reviews led me to believe. So... I passed. I didn't buy the game on PS4 when it launched, because all of what I had heard about the game killed any ounce of hype I had (that's on me). What i did buy, on the other hand, is the idea that the game was an over-hyped, 'arsty fartsy' flop. That notion couldn't be more wrong. 

Death Stranding is the second game in two months that taught me that I [b] need [/b] to experience a game for myself. See, the first game that did this to me, was [i] The Last of Us Part II [/i]. Now while this may take away any credibility i may have with some people, I love that game. Like, a lot. But it wasn't always that way. I expected to hate that game, but that was based on what i heard about it leading up to release. [b] Sound familiar? [/b]

Let me get some basics out of the way.

The music in this game is phenomenal. Both the original soundtrack and the music made by various artists for the game are breathtaking and beautiful. Fits the world so well. The lore and world building is out of this world good. The gameplay, for me, ranged from calming exploration of the gorgeous open world while delivering packages, to edge of my seat intensity when BTs showed up. To my surprise, I didn't get bored at all in my 37 hours it took me to beat it. The story is so original and unseen in games that I've personally played. Characters are well fleshed-out with stellar acting across the board. Character models are also excellent with a few npcs being obvious exceptions. 

Now, for the highly opinionated part.

Death Stranding is, without a doubt, one of the most impactful, moving, intelligent, and dare i say, fun games I've played in recent memory. 

It's a game that so clearly had a vision, and did not compromise on that vision. A game that has the fingerprints of devs who loved what they were working on all over it. Hideo Kojima knew exactly what kind of story he wanted to tell, so he did it, without watering it down or making it 'easily accessible'. (Again, I've never played a Kojima game before this so I had no allegiance to him) Sure, the story can be jarring and [i] confusing as hell [/i] at some parts, but that's also what I love about it. This game doesn't hold your hand. It doesn't care if you want more of the same, It's too busy committing to being what it is.

Now, I won't dive into the nitty gritty of mechanics and story beats etc. But what I will say is that I love this game. Not only because i genuinely enjoy playing and experiencing it, but because it's the kind of game I want to see more of. [b] Games that aren't afraid to be what they are. [/b] Games that might be a commercial flop (not sure if this was). Games that may divide a fanbase. Games that get poorly reviewed because people don't like it, not because it was a bad game. I'm fine with these things, as long as one thing can be said about the game. It didn't compromise. Death Stranding, I feel, did not compromise.

[b] Death Stranding is original, fresh, and my kind of game. [/b]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Apart from a terrible story and far too many cut scenes, it is a very awesome game. LIKE!

It offers an absolutely unique Gameplay idea.
Running, driving, "flying", building helpful devices, there are many ways to deliver a package - through a storm - climbing over snowy mountain slopes, with your own ladders and ropes. 
Sneaking, fighting, shooting through enemy areas, trying to steal theire stolen Goods - always keeping an eye on the good condition of the delivery and your own equipment.
Add to that breathtaking graphics, a fitting soundtrack, great atmosphere and! social interaction - the ladder of another player, exactly in the right place on a steep slope, without having your own - just feels so cool - to find someone else's vehicle in the middle of nowhere after your own runs out of juice - great ! 
Things like this (and others) made me enjoy the game, enough that I can easily see over the few minor annoying things like - endless cut scenes everywhere, unnecessary and repetitive info popups and questionable product placement.

The only thing I really find a pity about this game is the storyline. I like the basic idea, reuniting the country and overcoming the stranded death, i think it fits (at least the reunification thing) - the intro made me buy the game -  but from there it somehow goes downhill for me.

Probably it's just not my cup of tea, and maybe i am not getting what Mr. Kojima tryes to deliver here... i know the story pleases others... but for me this element of the game fails on most of the line.
There is some really cool stuff going on , Cliff - LIKE!, the concept of stranded death itself , the idea having an BB - creepy, but the bottom line is that I find the way the story is transported far too often, annoying, awkward or boring.
For me, it somehow ruins the good atmosphere that the game creates so easily. i.a. also through a good soundtrack.
If the developers had invested this time in even more gameplay elements, for me it wouldn't be a shame either ;)

Should that put you off? I´d say No. From my point of view, experiencing the gameplay mechanics, the great atmosphere and the rewarding delivery system more than makes up for it. Also the feeling of a walking simulator never really occurred to me in 70 hours of play;)
Death Stranding received a LIKE!

Other reviews say that you will get answers: They are not lying.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Its a pretty great game, albeit not for everyone.

Story doesn't make much sense in the beginning, but during the long game you pick up the pieces and glue the story together towards the finish. All in all; pretty gud.

Gameplay might seem a bit simple, haul stuff from A to B and all that. But i find it very relaxing, walking around, listen to the music, and just absorb the view of the world. And hopefully not wander into a bunch of ghosts or an avalanche while im at it. (Nukes and avalanches dont mix all too well).

Combat is pretty good, but its not the core of the game.
Sure you'll find yourself in cobat every now and then, and can be somewhat hectic if you stroll into a hornets-nest full of angry spirits, with nothing but a handful of grenades and a couple 'o 100kg's of raw materials on your back. But as said, its just parts of the game, not the majority (unless you actively search for it).

But the best part for me, is the fact that i can roam around in my truck and do nothing but gather resources and build a heck of a lotta roads... I love that stuff, i really do... And i probably wont stop doing that until all the highways have been restored.... when that day comes, ill take a break... atleast until the roads need maintenance...

So rest assured; all the stuff you people drop (that i find) wont go to waste, it'll go to infrastructure >:D

it takes time to plot routes, get the equipment you need, and being prepped while also being lightweight enough to be able to  manoeuvre the terrain, if you're looking for a strategy game with an open world and engaging story, this is for you.

review:
Breathtaking hiking/meditation simulator
Don't bother digging into plot its as complicated as Solitaire
It changed my view on long tasks that seem boring or aggravating but in fact take 5-10 mins
Take a deep breath, hold on to your backpack straps and take a first step

THERE IS AN OPTION TO DISABLE ODRADECK WARNING ANIMATION
hold alt - tilt map
t to switch map modes
ALWAYS KEEP AN EYE AT NETWORK COVERAGE - you cant put generators or zipline near preppers you havent seen
left/right click - rise motorcycle on one wheel
vehicle don't use battery on the lane in the Middle of highway - not all over
always follow your footpath - it will make a road that will clear small debris
always claim resources/chiral crystals from preppers and place it in their private locker - crystals don't weigh anything and if you will make a resource delivery above resource limit they will be lost

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death Stranding was my game of the year for 2019, and continues to be one of my favourite games on PC. I can just get lost in this game for hours wandering the beautiful open world. It's definitely not everyone's cup of tea, the gameplay is very unlike a traditional game. But that's what makes it so fun for me. To put it simply, it's like if Elite Dangerous or No Man's Sky was given a story by Hideo Kojima.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
So, I got into the game, selected Very Hard difficulty, and it's easy. I have never failed orders, never lost packages. Built some ladders, anchors, bridges... people started using them, I got recognized. I decided that since it's not really a struggle for me, I'll help people around me... and so it started.
I've spent days on deliveries of materials for roads, optimizing routes, setting up zip-lines. Every time I got into the game I got notifications of people riding on my roads, using all the stuff I set up, I got tens of thousands of likes every time.
Being recognized for your hard work, this is the strongest feeling this game has to offer.)
I absolutely love DEATH STRANDING and its community.) 
Keep on keeping on!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's not for everyone, but it really is a great game that has some incredible visuals and a unique, if not interesting, post apocalyptic plot. Yes, it's a walking simulator. A walking simulator with ghosts, rogue USPS employees, and terrorists trying to turn people into veritable nuclear explosions. It's good. Crazy, but good. 

I think most people who hate this game are going around the Eastern (beginning) region where you don't really have roads and vehicles, and they're getting bored. But it gets better after you get passed the eastern region. And I love the sharing mechanics for infrastructure built by other players, or how paths created by other players show up on your game. It's a unique take on indirect multiplayer, but I enjoy it. Spent the last 2 days just collecting mats to build a highway through the second region to help everyone out. It gives you a bit of a sense of community.

review: I bought this purely on the strength of it being a Hideo Kojima game (I loved MGS 5 and the Metal Gear series in general on consoles).  Ignore all of the internet saltiness and try this game.  In Kojima-fashion, he tries to make it more than a game, with social commentary and questioning.  I've basically been living this game for the last week and it does get you thinking about connections and the value of working together (you'll understand when you start seeing other player's structures - trust me).  10/10 - Would walk 500 miles and would walk 500 more to be that man who walks 1000 miles to fall down at your door.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
You know, "Kojima" is a common last name in Japan.
It's just funny how, you know, I'm part Japanese and Cecile's middle name is so close to "Kojima."
It feels like... destiny unfolding. Wait a second... Cecile Cosima Caminades... Cosima Caminades...
That sounds almost like the sentence "Kojima, kaminandesu" in Japanese. Well, "kami" is the word for "god" in Japanese.
"Nandesu..." Well, it's hard to explain, but placed after "god" it would turn the sentence into "is God."

"Kojima is God"... Cecile's name is a message!

I don't believe it... Kojima is God... Kojima is God...

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Definitely not a game for everyone, but I liked it. If after seeing gameplay and reading reviews you think you are going to like it, then you probably will. It is one the the best pc ports that I have played, the graphics are great including ultrawide support and the keyboard & mouse support is great. Initially I was getting quite a few crashes but they pushed a patch that completely fixed that and I haven't encountered any bugs since. My least favorite part of this game was by far the boss fights. They were frustrating and all you did was push damage into them and run away from attacks.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding, despite its status as a walking simulator, has managed to break itself out of that associated monotony through immersion, thoughtful mechanics, and tense moments that break up the heart-felt kindness lying underneath the horror game exterior. 

I have not played into the game too long, but I am enthralled already by the immersion of the basic gameplay. The goal is simple: deliver packages. Your journeys at first are long and hard fought: traversing rough terrain and windy mountain alleys only to find yourself surrounded by the terrifying and ever present mysterious and mostly invisible enemies, the BTs. Soon enough, your arsenal of methods with which to carry your cartoonishly large cargo grows, and so does the variety of routes to take. There has already been one part of the game in which I decided to take a plethora of ladder and rope out with me, to create a mountain pathway in order to avoid a daunting forest haunted with searching BTs. 

This brings me to my next point: the pathways you create using your tools become available to players in their worlds. Much like Dark Souls, you can leave signs all over the place, attempting to tell another player during their playthrough to take an easier route that you recommend. As mentioned, your tools that you use become available to other players- and they are able to use the same rope you used to scale down a steep cliff face, for example. This gives you the ability to form paths for other players that in thoughtfulness: create an easier way to get to their destinations in order to deliver important goods and continue on perhaps unscathed. In return for your deliveries and your shared tools, you get "Likes" from both NPCs and other players alike this drives you further to help others through these methods: including taking cargo deposited by other players to the destinations which they, for various reasons, could not reach. For example, maybe a player found themselves in trouble with the terrorist thieves in the game, the MULEs, and had to drop some heavier pieces of cargo into a mail station for safe keeping.. that heavy cargo can show up in your own shared mailbox for you to either finish the job, or hand it off to another player using the same method.

This game is all about helping others and establishing connections with other characters in the game, and other players too. 

I can tell a short tale about what had happened to me, for example. I found a bike at an outpost that was left there by another player, and it happened to spawn in my world. After building a generator, I could charge the bike's battery and travel around the immediate vicinity- picking up dropped and lost pieces of cargo. Some of the cargo was meant for my own final drop off location: the first city in the game. I traveled a couple of miles up to a large mountain, bidding the precious bike my inevitable farewell as I began to scale the mountain side with my massive cargo strapped to my back and my limbs. I threw down climbing rope periodically in order to make the journey easier on other players making the same trek that i had been, and finally, upon descending the other side of the mountain (which was easier), I came upon an area soaking in scary BT activity. My little BT detector had awoken and began to flash in the direction of the closest terrifying and invisible enemy. I used a ladder to get myself a bit higher up in order to skirt around the hotbed, and escaped eventually. I was able to get the cargo delivered, and get a ton of likes for the routes I had made in harder to reach places (albeit safer due to the lack of enemies there). It seems like he most challenging climbs are the safest!

Death Stranding is an odd game, but for those who love a good story and like to get immersed, I believe it will sate an appetite that you have no clue that you had. 

The soundtrack is top notch and the mechanics for showing off music in order to break the quiet serenity of travelling in the game are unique and work well. 

The story is confusing and vague, but very very well done and addicting to get into.

I can't recommend this game enough, and I have 9 hours in it. I will update the review if anything changes the longer I play Death Stranding.

review:
So far, I am 12h in and this game is fantastic. The attention to to detail is marvelous. The story is wacky and the gameplay is equal parts relaxing and exhilarating. The game runs like a dream and looks fantastic. Definitely a landmark technical achievement. It managed to do what most games failed this generation. Pull me into the world and keep me hooked within the first 15min. Very immersive experience and totally unique. A little bit like SpinTires on foot, while people and monsters are out to catch ya. Love it.

EDITED: After 30h with this game I can say this is my favorite open world game of the generation.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
In the current climate of the ever expanding list of run of the mill FPS games, this was quite literally a nice change in pace. I mean the loop is you methodically traversing either on foot or in vehicle over rough terrain, avoiding the occasional BT field, and your not so friendly package thieving rivals, the MULES. I would like to mention that the sheer amount of suspense/horror that is built in the opening 30 minutes is second to none from recent memory. After about 15 hours at the time of this review, it remains perplexing, albeit a tad convoluted.
My biggest gripe, unfortunately, being arguably the most important element to the game, are the physics. This makes vehicles and general movement feel wonky at best, and downright annoying at worst.  I'll point out that I do appreciate the way inertia is implemented, I just think it needed polish. Especially concerning vehicles and their suspension.
Overall, after giving props for originality for both the gameplay details and story, I'd give a 7/10. Even though I DO NOT regret paying $60, picking it up on sale for around 30-40 bucks is the best way to go.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The Graphics of course is just amazing and a work of art. The story is deep and meaningful and very intriguing overall. Its a lot like an interactive movie which you can play though or pause and just explore or build to really see and do all the things available. The concept of helping others is really awesome and i enjoy that part as well. The Character development has me interested to continue yet I find myself doing basic tasks to build my rep and help others. To me its like a really well done Sci-Fi movie that goes on and on and I get to interact with it and direct its outcome in some ways. I plan to crawl through it not just blaze through. Total recommend to those looking for something beautiful to play w/o constant kill count or grind being their only option.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I would want to start by saying, I stayed away from all reviews and all that until after I played through the game myself, so I can formulate my own opinion.  First the visuals are stunning and I think overall the gameplay is good, if you are looking for an fast paced, action packed game, this is not the game for you, this game is def slow and story driven.  This is a Kojima game so get ready for some weird plot points and things going on in the game to make you scratch your head, and also prepare for a lot of long cutscenes.  I can't recommend it for everyone, but if you have looking for a slow story that builds overtime and you like to walk/deliver packages in a game then I can recommend this for you.  I personally do not mind this gameplay mechanic so I really like it, but I can def understand why it would not be for everyone and how some people would find it boring and slow.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: While I wouldn't not recommend this, I'm not enthusiastic about it. The game is great in segments. Delivering packages over rough terrain is wonderful, fighting videogame bossfights is a lot less well done. The narrative has side stories for the supporting cast told with the charisma of Snake Eater but the main plot itself tries to go for an ultra melodramatic End of Evangelion type spin and it massively misses the mark. I was loving the game until its midway high peak (coincidentally the game's literal highest peak) but the second half was mostly an unpleasant drudge to make it to the end.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
"The mail is sacred, and sacred is the trust between the Post Man and the recipients of his precious parcels. You have made a solemn pledge to deliver this letter to the doctor, just as soon as you determine where this address is, or find any sort of discernible mailing address in this wasteland, for that matter. The mail is freedom. The mail is life. The mail is the very fabric of civiliz...

Wait.

Hold that thought for one moment...

The mail is the one final hope for resurrecting a dead planet from its ashes, and the letter carriers are the brave soldiers of God in this righteous crusade. They are the defenders of the light of knowledge, free communication, and the exchange of ideas. They are the bold toters of all those little papery conduits of freedom, the white postmarked angels that whisper a message on their deliverance, a promise to the yearning: "There is hope yet."

Liberty. Reason. Justice. Civility. Edification. Perfection.

MAIL."

Peregrine Mendicant

Ive been playing for maybe 2 hours, no horrible screen tears or framerate drops, i will say this is not your typical game but ive been loving it so far. There are a lot of cutscenes but they are so good i honestly dont mind. I'm not much of a big single player story person, but so far this has been absolutely gripping. Love the trippy post apocolyptic anomoly vibe. Also Norman Reedus, Guirremo del toro, and other A list cast makes the acting stellar all directed by hideo kojima i mean its just beautiful. I think some people are upset with the hype and the lack of massive explosions because hideo didnt put a lot of gameplay in the trailers but i mean like theres no excuse at this point go watch a couple gameplay videos if you arnt sure if you think it will be acitony enough. Ill prolly update this as i get further in to the game. I'm not sure if i'm just hyped on the trippy element or if it actually the big good.
UPDATE
still loving it, i as well am a ups man. and the nice hologram guy gives me many compliments which make me feel all warm inside. 8/10 so far

If you want an action shooter game go look somewhere else, but if you want a game with a great story and a new kind of gameplay then you've come to the right place.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Very intense without actually being frightening. If you're the kind of person into games with a tense horror atmosphere, but you have no interest in jumpscares or gore effects, this is definitely for you. More of a scifi thriller, this game keeps you constantly alert and on your toes pretty much all the time during your missions, without resorting to cheap scare tactics. When your character is allowed to rest and relax between missions, it really feels like you the player is also being able to rest and relax.

P.S. Going into this game blind is by far the best way to experience it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
