title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This is the most unique AAA game I've ever played. Metal Gear Solid was great in a lot of ways, but I feel like Death Stranding has finally given Hideo Kojima a chance to say something that's not just an ode to the movies he loves. The gameplay here is just as revolutionary as Metal Gear was with its stealth, and the current pandemic makes it almost seem prophetic. This game is not for everyone, but if you want to see a big-budget AAA game that's built around connections instead of violence, give it a try.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Seven hours in and this is already one of the most memorable games I've ever played. Very impressive work.

EDIT: I figured I would give a longer review for Death Stranding since I had been deeply anticipating it ever since the first trailer and then waited half a year after it finally released just for it to come to PC. Even though I have no experience with Hideo Kojima’s games, I knew from the first trailer that this was going to be a very special game and immediately realized the genius of Kojima, so I unashamedly jumped aboard the hype train.

To start off I would say that the gameplay is not for everyone (Some understandably call it a delivery simulator) but what the game lacks in gameplay for some people, it completely makes up for in story. The story is one of the most intriguing and memorable stories I've ever explored and it’s freshness and originality in approaching contemporary and future dilemmas of the human race was very pleasing. I will say I personally enjoyed the gameplay itself, but like I said, I know for sure it won’t please everyone. The gameplay is definitely unique and kept me very interested and immersed in it’s relation and integration with story development, but after finishing the game, I don’t have much interest in continuing the gameplay in free roam without a story to connect to it, so there’s that. Ultimately, the gameplay was enjoyable for me not in the traditional sense, but mainly in a kind of religious and philosophical sense of things like isolation and bearing the burden of the cargo through adversity, and how these concepts relate to the game’s storyline as well as the real life takeaway Kojima wanted for us in the contemporary world. The highly detailed environment and the occasional spontaneous song that pops up when wandering did an amazing job at facilitating the cinematic (And for me, religious/philosophical) immersion of the gameplay itself.

A couple critiques of the gameplay is that the main boss fights as well as the mini boss fights were very underwhelming for me, and even though I played the game on hard, it still wasn’t difficult. The bosses were very intimidating in form but in mechanics were about as threatening as their plastic toy replicas on the shelf in the safe rooms. The BT mini bosses can be run away from without even leaving a scratch on you, this made it hard to take the BT’s seriously and were more so just annoying.

My main critique for the story is that I feel like it happened too fast, like maybe this storyline should have been spread out over a trilogy with many more characters. I just feel like there could've been so much more depth explored in the characters and the lore behind the "Death Stranding", but this is only a minor critique and should be considered more of a compliment to the intense impact that the story and characters had on me. Also, the mid game storyline (After you reach Lake Knot City) was a little stale for me, but really picked up again after I got to Heartman’s chapter.

Overall, as expected from the first time I saw the initial trailers, Death Stranding was an incredible experience that I really loved and it without a doubt takes a spot in my top 5 most memorable games ever played.

Keep on keeping on.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I just wrapped up the last 2 boss-fights of Death stranding, and the ending as well, and my mind is just.. racing for a better word, replaying it again and again in my mind as I try to piece it together with the rest of the experiences I've had since-- July 14th, and it just.. blows my mind.. I'm just.. so much aware of things, like how politics had devolved(from its original intent) to such small things as physical contact have become less of a part in my life, how few "knots" I truly have in my life.. I'm actually considering moving back to my parents place and going back to school.
There's just, so many emotions to unravel from playing this game to its finish, I won't say its tear-jerking, but its just, so eye opening, things you took for granted because you were so focused on yourself, your situation, your advancements in the physical world, there's so much emotional stuff that is underdeveloped.
People keep saying that Kojima is a Meme Tier God, and he's only famous because he's connected to the Metal Gear Series, but honestly.. Deaths Stranding is just.. SO good.. both from a gameplay perspective and from the emotional sensations it provides.

But yeah, emotional rant and fanboying aside, the game has Cons and Pros
[b]Cons:[/b] 
[u]Tedious,[/u] this game will drag on if you want to get all the fun trinkets to play with, earning 4 stars with all the contacts the game offers, can take you well over 40-50 hours if you're doing it inefficiently like I was, and I was still missing 1/4th of the level 2-3 stuff that got offered to me.
[U]Scattered: [/u] the game's content is divided into 3 zones, so to speak, the starting area, leading up to south port knot, south of the mountain range, and north of the mountain range (There's also the end game area, but its kinda small so counts more as its own separate dungeon) and you'll spot a familiar pattern in the starting zone that teach you "Oh so there's packages to be delivered to people near them as well as to other place" and believing that to be the normal case I proceeded on my merry way, but OH BOY I was wrong. once you get to the Northern Mountain range you can find delivery items from one end of the mountain range to the other, and that is NOT a fun trip, so consider wisely if those 120 Likes from delivering it 10km is worth it
[u]Weird:[/u] Kojima has a weird sense of both storytelling and settings, so expect to be surprised or challenged in your average day to day believes, but in Death's Stranding, the world has change as has their understanding of norms, expect close ups and weird gestures everywhere, also there's way too much Naked Norman Reedus for my liking, but hey, someone is bound to like it.

[b]Pros:[/b] 
[u]Great content:[/u] if you like playing the mail-man this game is just perfect for you, there's plenty of logitical challenges to overcome such as managing your weight, energy, path taken, obstacles to overcome (human and natural) the gunplay feels a bit underwhelming but consider that you're mostly going to be sneaking around to try and deliver packages you can understand why there's little focus on things like Scopes, weapon utility and such, (Ammo not counting) each weapon has a use and that's about it, (My favorite part is using the Sticky Gun on a piece of cargo behind humanoid enemies to knock them out)
[u]A Kojima Experience:[/u] anyone familiar with the latter parts of the Metal Gear Series will instantly find themselves in the bizarre world of Kojima and will most likely appriciate it a bit more because of so, I can't wait for the next Kojima title to be announced.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Best science fiction writing I've seen in a long time by far. Simple but fresh mechanics turn inventory management and fetch quests into drawn out minigams that are surprisingly entertaining even 60 hours in. Excellently cast and acted by parties involved. Killer soundtrack. Directing on par with the best Metal Gear games regarding pacing, cinematography, plot delivery, etc. Futhermore this game fixes many of the issues from PS4, such as unskippable cutscenes that have been repeated.

The game stumbles a little at the climax (narrative and plot wise) and is definitely the weakest part of the game. There's also some clunky UI issues. These complaints are relatively minor in the grand scheme.

With that said, not everyone will like this game. It is not action driven. The game is surreal and contemplative with vast amounts of time with seemingly nothing happening, giving you time to ruminate on the themes of the game. The vast majority of your time is spent doing mundane tasks that you may find interesting if you can appreciate similar tasks in real life, such as being able to appreciate long walks while daydreaming and thinking about nothing. Or if you hike/climb and see every single move forward as monumental progress; repeatedly putting one foot in front of the other.

10/10 this game is the best video game I've ever played. Dethrones The Witcher 3 for my #1 spot.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Initially I was pretty put off by the PC port due to the significant stutter and bizarre controller related performance problems, but the first patched cleared all of that up for me. It looks great and runs buttery smooth now.

I love Death Stranding. It's a hard game to describe to folks who aren't already invested in Kojima's brilliant madness, so I find it easier to tell people what it isn't. Death Stranding is not an action game, not a stealth game, not an open world game, not a shooter, and not a walking simulator.

In Death Stranding the enemy is the terrain. Your weapons are boots, ladders, ropes, and powered exoskeletons. The challenge comes from choosing the right tools and route to get the job done. Executing your plan is mostly a relaxing experience, spiced up by encounters with the MULEs and BTs. It's a slow-paced experience, and if that isn't your thing, you better give Death Stranding a pass.

As for the story... well, it's best experienced first hand. Trying to explain it to anyone just makes me sound like a madman.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
What this game is: 
A deep story telling story by a Japanese creator who clearly created a deep, scary, uncertain story you must uncover, both about the far past, and uncertain future.  Some aspects like final fantasy, other ways totally original.

What this game is not: 
A shooter scifi adventure.  A typical adventure game or RPG.  A simple story you get right away.

The start of the game:
May seem slow at first. Basically you are dropping off items to places. The first map area will have 5 main locations that unlock as you connect them to the network. 

Take some time to do the main story missions as well as the secondary back and forth ones. This gets you up in connection and levels. But you don't have to spend to much time doing everyone, as they will repeat on secondary.  I spent time to over level 20 and released I needed to stop and go to the port ship to go to the new area (you cant take any delivery items with you, it is a new start region. You can take other peopes deposited items return them to base. DOnt go crazy putting out stations, once you move on to chapter 3, you wont use them, until a later return. 

Eventually at the start you start usign your blood to fight BT's in your way.

Basically anytime you take a new delivery of any type from a terminal, the BT areas respawn and will be there again.  When close on your bike , and BB goes crazy get off the bike. Crouch, stop moving let it show you them, then use the hema grenade to kill them and break strands. Then ride through. PS those enemies in camps are easy to pummle with fists, dont even bother thinking they are tough. 

(FOR THE BIKE you make a charger near the West distribution bike to charge and get it. you also put it on the circle ramp when you go to rest so it repairs)

The game gets more exciting as you progress.

NVIDIA GRAPHICS:

Top notch. Makes use of RTX cards, especially 2080 cards. A RTX 2080 Super and TI will play at 4k  ultra maxed out, make sure the nvidia settins is set. It is fluid and astounding.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death Stranding is about a lot of different things. Depending on the player, some things seem more important or significant than others. To a lot of people, Death Stranding is about tedious gameplay. If that's what you take from Death Stranding, that's alright. For me, Death Stranding is about being alone. It's the greatest escape from the real world. It's not just a beautiful world, it's an empty world. It's not empty in a depressing way. It's empty in a hopeful way. As you travel across the nation you build bridges, ziplines, shelters etc. and you feel like your rebuilding something important. Sam's Aphenphosmphobia (Fear of physical and emotional touch) is fully realized in the gameplay, making it an escape from not just the real society, but the fictional one as well. The only companion with you most of the time is your BB, Lou. A baby was the perfect pick for this. Their innocence, their lack of understanding about the world makes sure that they do not make the game feel less like an escape. By the end, Lou was my everything. I found myself talking aloud to Lou just like Sam and his company is invaluable by the end. As far as the story goes, if it's for you, it's for you. It's very Hideo Kojima and that's the best way to describe it.

title: DEATH STRANDING

not for everyone, but amazing for those it works for.
More than just a "walking simulator" or "delivery simulator". There are actually loads of game play mechanics that are engaging... for the person playing. I could see how this game would suck to watch a livestream of... but does every game need to be a smash hit on streaming services to be good?

review: This is a fantastic and different game. It is quite a unique experience and is definitely not for everybody but deserves to be praised for trying to be original among a sea of assassin's creeds, COD's, FIFA's, etc., while actually being fun and rewarding! I'm glad I gave it a try...

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Early into the game review. 

I love the ambition of this game.  The meta cooperation with other players, sheer beauty of the game and the acting are great.  However, it immediately becomes a sneak crawler.  

First there is almost an hour of cinematics with minor tutorial play mixed in before you really get into the game.  Yeah, you can skip it, but that defeats the purpose.  I can see it being worth it until, when the game starts to take off, it bogs down quick.

Most of the early quests have you going from outpost to outpost.  Predictably the BTs are in between and you will have to sneak by them.  If you mess up, you go through a long ordeal of sluggish muck crawling away from a Gaian-esque spirit porpoise channeling its inner Cthulhu.  Then once you get away, you get to run back and grab any gear you drop, fix it and begin again.  It's a huge time sink through the BT zones and it's not much fun to do over and over. 

So far, and yes I have not gone that far into the game, the BT zones are unavoidable.  So between the long trips, trying to not fall over, avoiding BTs, endlessly repairing gear, and trying to soothe a crying Kuato stuck to your chest, the game really becomes quickly repetitive and tedious. 

A reverse trike shows up soon enough, but it's all but worthless as most routes you need to go inevitably have unavoidable BT zones and/or horrendous to impassible terrain.  

I am going to give it a college try, but so far, I give it a thumbs up for creativity, but a thumbs down for lack of truly engaging gameplay. 

I am man enough to admit that I may have not gotten the gist of the game yet or misunderstood the target audience of the game, so maybe my view will change with additional playing.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Okay, What a cool concept for a game!  It is somewhere between 'The Evil Within II" and "Euro Truck Simulator" with a much more rewarding experience.  The game does a really nice job of blending mechanics and plot to make a very cool immersive experience.

Two helpful tips I found:  You cannot use the device manager to update your graphics card, you must DL geforce and update your Nvidia card to use the Decima engine.  Then I would recommend turning on FXAA and enhancing the anti-aliasing x8.

Two: I hated the Metal gear games.  For this game, get through the first two hours, smoke a bowl and buckle up.  The game requires a bit of investment and uses time as a mechanic to either slow you down (not resting at every distribution center) or generate a sense of accomplishment.

The game is an extremely unique experience with a okay music (nothing I'd seek out on my own) that fits the moments and the attention to detail (foley, physics, easter eggs) really does provide a cool enviornment to game in.  Some of the characters I currently really dislike (Amelie especially) so we'll see how that pans out.

If you want something different, cool, with a interesting story that blends with the game play, I'd give it a rec.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: After reading some very mixed reviews about this game, I decided to get it anyway, and I have several things to say. First: The game is beautiful. The game world is staggering in it's natural detail, and character models are some of the best I've seen. Second: the game throws you in with little back story and little explanation. It seems very shallow in the terms of lore and history, at least in the beginning. That being said, I have enjoyed playing it. It has those "Oh Shit" moments when you have to avoid BTs, and the cinematography is superb. The main character, portrayed by the actor Norman Reedus, does seem to be rather basic but is presented in a believable way. While this game may not be in everyone's wheelhouse, it can be enjoyable to the right people, and I suggest that it isn't overlooked simply based on sub-par reviews.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is quite unique, and I love every minute of it. Introducing Sam Bridges, Post Apocalyptic Delivery Driver, come rain, shine, snow, natural disasters or void outs, he'll get your cargo where it needs to be! The cinematics on the game are second to none, and really serve to immerse you into the game and story. You get a feeling of what the characters are going through, the decisions that they're making, and what your part in the big picture is. 

If you have lots of time on your hand, this game is for you. Even if you don't have tons of time available, you can still play this game in small chunks, pacing the story out as you see fit.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: You can do pee

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]NOT the uber-artsy, unapproachable high concept game you think it is- Just one of the good ones[/h1]

Okay, first, to address the burning question: [b]Is this game a walking simulator?[/b]

NOT by the typical use of the word players use to define games. I'm not the biggest fan of [i]those[/i] walking simulators [i](not because I think they're an inherently bad genre, I can enjoy a good one- it's because The Chinese Room indirectly damaged a lot of them in design inspiration IMO)[/i] as they usually are, but Death Stranding is a [b]literal[/b] walking simulator, as I'm sure you've heard; It's a game about getting from A to B, usually with craptons of cargo on your back.


[b]I think a lot of gamers[/b] [i](and, to be frank, game designers)[/i] [b]have been weighed down with the dogma that "Travel is boring" for years now.[/b] It's astonishing that we have an entire genre (platformers) and a subgenre (open-world games) both of which are massively popular for their style of movement and freedom of movement respectively, and yet the idea that Skyrim's [i]"click on location you've visited and PREPARE TO LOAD"[/i] system being the pinnacle of travel in videogames is still held as true by a surprising number of people.


This is despite games like Dying Light, Breath of the Wild, and yes, Death Stranding proving that you can make travel in games more complicated than just holding forward, implement such ideas into a variety of genres, and make such "skip travel" systems much less important and in some cases almost entirely redundant. We figured out how to make "How do I get from here, to here" interesting in 1982's Donkey Kong, so let's stop pretending other games that are also about that are inherently bad ideas.



There's also the argument that this game is "work". It doesn't take much longer to beat than the average AAA game and it [i]certainly[/i] isn't grindy in the slightest with resources being plentiful and no time when the game mandates you do sidequests before you can advance the story, but sure, package delivery sounds mundane. It also ISN'T the kind of game designed to get your blood pumping very often.

However, Death Stranding absolutely succeeds at putting players into a [b]flow state.[/b] That's often referred to in layman's terms as "The Zone", and everyone's experienced it- When you're doing something and you stop actively thinking about it, but you're still performing that task really well? Pretty much every good game ever made is designed to put you into one, and it's why people have played Euro Truck Simulator for hours upon hours. It's why a game that isn't explicitly "fun" can still FEEL like it's hitting the same nerves you associate with "fun", which is usually a confusing experience for [strike]practically all game journalists[/strike] laymen who don't understand why.



And Death Stranding, despite the unusual formula, hits all of the notes I wanted. It has low tension bits where you can just take in the atmosphere, it has high tension bits where everything feels like it's going wrong at once, but most points are inbetween, where I can relax, but still need to keep my eyes on the road- And it's a damn good feeling when a game nails that, whether it be juggling ammo capacities in a shooter, forming a plan in a stealth game, or moving along in Death Stranding with my cargo. [b]My point is Death Stranding is not an anomaly or even THAT experimental, it fundamentally follows the same design principles all decent games do, and IMO it follows them well.[/b]


How? Well, cargo has conditions you need to bear in mind (eg. "don't submerge in water", "fragile" "only carry by hand"), you have different vehicles to potentially transport it, different equipment to deal with obstacles along the way, different weapons to deal with different enemies along the way, having to determine what route out of several options to take in the first place, ecetera.

All this stuff is how the game creates its fun, as just walking to your location is not going to cut it after a point, and you're going to have to start driving like a speed demon, or beating the crap out of terrorists with your bare hands, or going guns blazing against a tentacle monster, or quietly stealthing through a snowfield holding your breath to hide from invisible threats, if you want your cargo to get delivered safely. I dare say, it's pretty fun.




Whew, okay, that's done. Aside from that, I think I'll highlight some of the things the game does WRONG, so those who won't enjoy it can find something else to pick up.

[h1]Downsides to consider[/h1]

Firstly, [b]the game has a slow start.[/b] Kojima loves his cutscenes, but it's also a bit more than that- The game gives you new equipment for every new location you visit, which is fine, but that means it takes several hours for the game to really get going, because a HUGE part of the aforementioned flow state I mentioned is having [i]choice[/i] in your approach to situations, which you don't really get enough of in the first zone of the game. Including cutscenes, it will probably take ~4-5 hours to get out of that phase, though it seems like for those who are especially slow-going it can take up to 10.



Second, [b]the game's story IS clunky, mostly early on.[/b] If I had to sum up the problem as quickly as possible, aside from usual "take it or leave it" storytelling tropes in Japanese media (lots of exposition, explaining the same concepts over and over, loads of sad backstories in flashback), [b]most times, characters are talking TO you, not WITH you.[/b] One of the most blatant examples of this is after you get the Weather Station online, when one character calls you up to tell you that "The weather report could be handy for plotting routes", and then IMMEDIATELY afterwards another guy calls you up to tell you that weather report could be handy for plotting routes. Even a saint's going to be skipping dialogue [i]that[/i] repetitive.


The story is ultimately good, and it IMO wraps up fantastically at the ending, but like the first point, you need to be willing to see it through. And, yes, Tommie Earl Jenkins does play a character named [i]Die-Hardman[/i], look, the sooner you make peace with that, the better.



Third, [b]if you're the kind of player who hates things like sorting through menus, making plans, or thinking about your inventory and what to bring or discard, this also probably isn't for you.[/b] [i]Death Stranding's focus isn't on moment-to-moment gameplay, it's on the decisions that lead to moment-to-moment problems[/i] , so if your reaction to running out of boot durability in the wilderness with no replacements handy isn't [i]"Oh, my mistakes have lead to an issue I'm going to have to adapt to, lemme think about how to handle this"[/i] and is more like [i]"What, my boots broke?! This is bullshit"[/i] that's also probably a count against you being likely to enjoy this game.


Performance/stability wise, it was okay. I encountered some mild stuttering (mostly in the intro cutscene and a couple of times for a few seconds throughout the rest of my playthrough) but the gameplay proper was usually buttery smooth (my rig's above average, your mileage may vary). The game itself looks gorgeous, obviously. I did encounter a select few nasty bugs, with one cutscene starting with the audio and visuals out of sync, and donating to Share Lockers sometimes causing the game to softlock, but everything else has been extremely stable. A mostly good port with some minor blemishes.



If this game's concept or weird presentation (or both) interests you and the stuff mentioned above doesn't sound like too much of a turnoff, this is a good one to invest your time into and worthy of the pricetag.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: its a good game

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Setting is awesome - it builds feeling at home but in this same time anxiety. Main story is the best story I've ever experienced, I think everyone should experience that. Characters are really good designed you can build a bond (or maybe actually "a strand" ? :)) with them, get close to them. Soundtrack is well chosen, fills the game well. Optimization is kinda nice - my specs: ryzen 7 2700 + gtx 970 - and I got it worked on the highest graphic settings in 1080p in 40-80fps.
BUT I wouldn't recommend this game to others right now, in this state. Game has got a lot of bugs and shortcomings. Riding a motorcycle is completly f*cking broken, hitting small rock will immediately stop your vehicle, but around 5-10 seconds later after just holding the gas pedal your motorbike will go off at the speed of light.
[url=https://youtu.be/aKk_2x7LfBY]Riding a motorcycle normally and braking will immediately stop your vehicle (first time I thought my game was just lagging lol).[/url]
Initially Death Stranding was published on Playstation 4, so most of the users have played it on controller. I don't know what went wrong, but using a controller on PC is broken aswell. Sometimes things are happens automatically (eg. after throwing one granade, Sam have thrown automatically two more after the first ¿?) Sometimes the game does not respond to buttos being pressed (eg. sprinting). And of course sometimes buttons respond with delay. (eg. I'm trying to sprint - game doesn't respond, so I'm pressing the analog once more and Sam starts sprinting and stops immediately ¿?). And last but not least you can NOT turn down the music volume, so if you have hearing damage you'll be forced to turn down the volume of all sounds (especially dialogues which are sometimes hard to hear). Well actually you won't be forced to do that - you can damage your already damaged hearing even more :)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
And amazing game.  Good story beautiful graphics.  But cashes over & over on a beefy rig.  And when it crashes it completely shuts down Big Picture mode & steam.  I get an error saying Callstack 121271737.  What a shame.  But it's frustrating replay the same thing over & over because of crashes.  This game is as bad as Red Dead 2 at launch.  Crashing every 5 minutes.  Weird things is when it's not crashing it runs smooth on highest settings. I would keep away from this game for a while.  Until it's playable 

WHAT DOES DEATH STRANDING FEEL LIKE TO PLAY?
If you ever played an RPG & you carry to much stuff/weight.  And you can barely walk.  This is Death Stranding.  In the beginning of the game it's not like this but an hour in. Watch out it's time for slow mo walking.  And what makes it worse is you walk for 15 minutes toward you destination just to hit an invisible wall.  So now you follow this invisible wall.  But it'll go right into the ocean.  So you turn around go another 15 to 20 minutes in another direction.  And what this another invisible wall.  This is the whole game of Death Stranding.  Keep following invisible walls round & round until you find that one little opening. No enemies or combat.  Just looking for the opening in a invisible wall.  Sounds like fun huh?  The only good thing about this game is the story.  The reason your here is because of that the story & actors. 
 Which is just the cut scenes.  Which I could just watch on Youtube.  The gameplay couldn't be anymore boring.  Like the game description says it's a walking simulation.  But what they don't tell you is how slow you'll be walking.  On the trailer they show you riding this awesome motorcycle.  But that's just the first minute of the game.  And that's it.   What a pile of garbage.  I'll be getting refunded for sure

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Put in easily 100+ hours on the PS4, re-bought on PC to get a taste of that sweet 60+ FPS.  It's a beautiful game that is hindered by it's game mechanics that some will find boring or to slow.  This is why a disclaimer is a must for those not knowing what to expect.  It's a methodical, slow burning, highly satisfying, journey that takes you on a wild ride with Kojima at the helm throwing you nothing but more questions than answers.  A lot of those questions can be answered through journal entries and emails as well as some plot hints given throughout the story progression, you just need to pay attention and my goodness, is it worth it.  In the end it all comes together for the most part, if at least somewhat depending on your interpretation of everything that was given to you along the way.  

Aside from story, the gameplay itself is a tad bit frustrating in certain situations.  Unable to fully brake on the bike which ends up sliding past your intended stopping point for no reason, Sam getting confused and walking one way when your pointing the stick in the other direction.  Mainly some vehicle mishaps but other than that, the game plays like a dream.  The progression and equipment upgrades found through the world are fantastic.  Each piece of new equipment has it's uses for each type of terrain you come across, new structures to build with ziplines and shelters from the timefall are just a few.   If you want a relaxing break from the world that is now I suggest you take a dip into the fantasy that is Kojimas Death Stranding.  You will find no high intensity action sequences in this game.  This is ment to engage the gamer in a sense of longing for a world that has come and gone, leaving them with the lonely world and her sometimes harsh environments and traversing them no matter the challenge.  Coming out on top with said deliveries in tact is a reward of its own volition.  This is a game for a select few, do your research and know what you're getting into before diving into this game.  It is an experience more so than anything.  The soundtrack by itself is almost worth the money, fits every occasion and really brings some weight or lightheartedness depending on the situation.  This is the innovation we all seek, now is it something we all wanted, maybe not, but it's innovation nevertheless.  I can only hope we see more risks like this game in the future.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Please note, my first review for this game was negative. I've maintained the original review below the dashed line for posterity.

So why did I change my mind about this game? Well it seems during the course of my play that the online environment has stabilized somewhat, there are still some issues, occasional crashes and such, but they're much rarer than when I first reviewed the game. I'm still annoyed by it, as I know that everytime I go to use one of the social features I risk crashing my game, but it's better than it was before. So now I can actually talk positively about the gameplay instead.

It's a walking simulator, and I mean that in the best way. If the idea of doing fetch quest after fetch quest interrupted by some occasional (And very easy) action sequences immediately turns you off then don't bother buying this game. If you're looking for something different, something relaxing, then maybe this game is right for you. The game has a way of making you feel like you're really making progress. It does what all those indie job simulator type games tried and failed to do. I like the game, and if you're looking to move away from the AAA gaming paradigm then this game is definitely worth a look.

--------------------
{ORIGINAL REVIEW}

I'd really love to give this game a good review but I just can't. What's the point of making a game about connecting people, when half the time using any of the online features such as donating equipment or entrusting cargo causes the game to crash?
I know people will tell me to wait for a patch, but consider that this game was already delayed, so it's not like it was rushed out and should need a day 1 patch. There is zero excuse. The only way I can play is offline, which has completely killed my mood to play, and searching around on various forums shows that I am far from the only one from this problem.
Maybe Kojima should stick to singleplayer games in the future.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: A lot of people have called Death Stranding a running simulator, but it's much more nuanced and engaging than I was expecting.  The visuals and sound are astounding.  The story is... well... weird.  I haven't decided yet whether that's subjectively a positive or a negative, but it certainly doesn't lose points for originality.  There is also some tedium - 5 hours in and I'm still being hand-held through tutorials.  Still, the core loop is more solid than I believed it could be, given all of the reviews and explanations I'd heard from other gamers.  You have to stay on your toes if you want to keep on your feet!  That's a joke that will make more sense if you play the game, and I recommend that you do (at least if you're a mature gamer and looking for something a little different).  It's certainly not like most games you've played, but as a result it manages to deliver a unique satisfaction and enjoyment.  If nothing else, it hints at solid potential for a new genre and proof that outside-the-hitbox  games can be lucrative for creative AAA developers.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
20 hours in and I have to say this is one of the most enjoyable gaming experiences I've had lately, especially after it opens up and the progression system starts kicking in. I highly recommend it to anyone who is open to Kojima's weird style and surprisingly engaging delivery gameplay.

Edit after beating: I honestly didn't expect the storytelling to be so fully realized or well done. It's absolutely crazy but by the end, if you're paying attention, all the weird stuff actually makes sense in one way or another. The key thing though is that the game really pushes its narrative through the gameplay in super powerful ways that I didn't know it would. I expected the story to mostly be done through cinematics, but was surprised that the most important part of the story in the end actually was what you built through the game along with the others playing and how you feel traversing it through the end moments. And in particular when you realize how much you have to lean on other player's contributions. It makes the cinematics super powerful because you really feel all the work you put into the game in a way I've never seen done before. It makes you way more involved in the themes of the story because you really put in the work, and the emotional payoffs are huge because of it.

This is the most emotional I've gotten from playing a game since MGS4, which took four games worth of plot and really drove it home with great fan service moments and cinematic presentation that was unparalleled at the time. Death Stranding managed to do it without relying on fan service or nostalgia for past games (although there is some of that, especially with one awesome call back to MGS4), and when the different parts of the story and themes come together to a climax... it's just some of the most intense moments I've had in gaming one after another for the last four or five hours. Hats off to Kojima.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
While it looked like a decent adventure at first (one where there's enough nice bits to keep your interest peaked despite all the flaws) - unfortunately, the more I played the more it was evident that the gameplay formula doesn't hold up.

Quite a lot of players criticize the "UPS sim" part of the game, but personally I'm finding it being the only part that warrants any positive feedback. It's quite simple yet not shallow, and it's reasonably original - there's clearly no games exactly like it, and not that many games with the same broad scope.

Unfortunately, I'd give a hard pass for ALL other gameplay aspects. I can't really stomach well Kojima-styled story & setting - too pretentious with way too childish presentation. And I'm finding any combat-oriented activity in the game (mobs, shooting missions, etc) to be mind-numbingly bland. It's not "bad", just very boring, lacking any real challenge (even on max difficulty), and extremely repetitious. And the further you go through the game, the more of it is thrown your way, and a lot of such "story-related" encounters you can't avoid at all.

It's a fairly strange game that tries so hard to sit on two chairs at once - but while one part of it is reasonably original and even a bit unorthodox, the other part is thoroughly bland.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
An excellent game of exploration and traversal. If you like ARPGs but thought "Let's rip out most of the actiony bits and focus more on terrain traversal and trade routes" then this is the game for you! Think the world of Mad Max-lite with Scifi components with the gameplay of The Postman.
The story is enjoyable but with it's Kojima eccentricities. The characters are caricatures of someone trying to be deep and thought provoking, their dialogue is every bad anime translation of a wise overly verbose bad guy ever.
The combat is severely lacking, it plays like an Indie Dev's alpha foray into Third Person Shooters. There's a solid foundation of what it could be, but it's as if it was never tested.
Non-Critical SPOILER BELOW
There comes a point where you get lethal weapons for the first time and it really reveals how combat was tacked on at the last moment for the game. As if Kojima, six months before release, said "fine, we'll put in some shooting" You're forced to track down someone who is more powerful than you with unlimited ammo and grenades who also has 5 baddies with him. On "Very Hard" it takes an entire clip to down one baddie, not a complaint. You can trip them with a shotgun blast as well so that you can switch to grenades... which is where the issues start. You swap weapons and it takes for freaking ever to pack away your gun, swap it with grenades, unpack the grenades, equip the grenades, aim the grenades, and then throw it. And this animation is all done FOR you.  Couple this with being outgunned and a hideous third person camera for shooting (you'll block your own view most of the time. There's an indicator when your shot will be blocked but it's not readily apparent when the obstacle is close because your own body will be covering the indicator) and combat is just flat out janky and best avoided in the game... except you cant avoid this one.
END SPOILER

The soundtrack is great. The audio levels need some massive tweaking (the recycling chime could wake someone in the other room even if the rest of the audio is quiet) and spatial awareness from sound is all but nonexistent.
All in all, a fun and eccentric ride into the weird and wild world of package delivery.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
***THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE***
This is the best game I've played so far in 2019-2020. The story is super good, character development is amazing,gameplay is different but definitely amazing. Yes its a pretty pricey game-usually PC games are way cheaper. But i definitely did not regret spending on this game. This game hasn't got boring at all since i started (I did play a bit on PS4 a while back).
HOW IS THE GAMEPLAY:
It's basically delivering cargo and other stuff from place to place along some super harsh environment from rocky mountains, rivers ,snowy mountains etc, while at the same time dealing with human enemies trying to steal your cargo and ghostly alien like creatures tryna kill you. You need to learn how to maintain your cargo,manage time and use your resources carefully. Your main goal is to connect America which was destroyed due to some incident.
STORY:
It's a Hideo Kojima game, its definitely amazing. A very cool concept, spectacular voice acting and an amazing cast.
APART FROM STORY:
There are side missions that are pretty good. And this game is kinda like Dark Souls where you leave clues for other players but here you can leave clues as well as build structures,place ladders and climbing ropes to make others journey easier and also donate weapons and equipment
 
**Combat is decent nothing great but still fun if you wanna mess around with the human enemies but the other ghost enemies things are pretty tense and kinda fun(trying not to spoil much).
SOUNDTRACK:
Its very good :)

OVERALL:
Its a different game but i found it very fun,its super slow paced but not in an annoying manner. Its definitely not for everyone , so if you wanna try it out maybe get it on a sale, I personally did not regret spending the full price on the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is my second play through, I bought and played through it on PS4 last year.

First of all, if you're not sure if this game is for you, don't worry about the memes about walking sims, you only have to ask yourself one thing: 

DO YOU LIKE KOJIMA GAMES SUCH AS METAL GEAR? If you love MG5, then you will probably love this game. The Kojima easter eggs, quirks, doing crazy random things with gear or vehicles you never thought would be programmed into a game is there exactly like you'd expect from a modern Kojima game. If you understand what I'm trying to say here, just buy the game. If you need more convincing, read on...

Not that I should have to say this, but this game has 15 chapters of content. Only the first ~2.5 chapters do you not have vehicles and other modes of transport other than walking/running. I don't want to spoil the insane amount of customization of gameplay, new vehicles, gear, weapons, replayability so I'll try to create a broader argument for this amazing game.

The point of the previous comment is to say that if you like immersive experiences, this game is by far in the top 1% of games in that regard. The game puts you in the shoes of a guy trying to find his place in the world, and at the same time "bridge" together the former USA. The world is mostly uninhabitable in the setting of the game and this lends to the reason you, yes, literally have to get places and much of the game is going from A to B. That does not make it boring or content-less. That is where the mechanics of the game and the experiences you will have shine. You will not find empty spaces with no purpose in this game, when much of the mechanics of the game revolve around getting over the terrain etc... There are easter eggs, different/challenging terrain, different enemies, and ways to get around/through all of the above.

But here's the thing, you can literally have gun fights, fist fights, drive motorcycles, raid a camp of baddies and steal their rides, ride zip lines, climb mountains, hover board, build structures, build yourself mechanical suit parts, sit in an onsen, deliver pizza... all in this "walking simulator"... And I guess that's my point. Anyone calling it that is being purposefully obtuse to a literal endless trove of gameplay. 

The game isn't necessarily hard, either, although you can change the difficulty and make it more challenging.

The parallel multiplayer system is absolutely groundbreaking and innovative. It makes playing this game so much more than what you see at face value. To build a road or a bridge and get likes from other players, which in turn makes your character "level up" and better at various parts of the game feels amazing. It also feels good to just give people likes. You will never be happier than when you're on top of a mountain and find a perfectly placed ladder or rope when you're out of gear on a long trip.

The visuals and sound design are top notch. The celeb cameos are awesome. The insane amount of little easter eggs and quirks are awesome. The game is awesome and new. The gaming world needs more new things and I don't think anyone should be arguing against that point.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I've played this game for 24 hours now and not a single second of it was wasted. So far I've only got to mission 21 because I enjoy the core gameplay loop so much that I spent a ridiculous amount of time in the starting area, I can understand where people are coming from when they say they don't like the game because it's boring but I just don't agree. Yes the bulk of the gameplay is simple and a little bit repetitive but there's just so many options that I can't see it ever getting stale for me. Every individual piece of the game is simple on its own but there's such an immense amount of different mechanics that when put together it really just flows perfectly. I'm very comfortable saying that this is my new favorite game of all time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Initial impressions are that it is a visually outstanding cinematic experience, with engaging story, interesting game-play, amazing attention to detail and great music. While the overarching story line resembles a certain Kevin Costner movie from the late 90's and slightly took the edge off the novelty of it all for me, it hasn't really detracted from the experience. The game draws you in and makes the walking around that you have to do feel important and enjoyable, giving you a chance to marvel at the game's visuals and atmosphere. It feels about closest you can come to going for a walk in the wild without leaving your home. So far, highly recommended.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
18 hours into this game, at the time of this post, and I am in love with it. It is very much a walking simulator.  Fetch quests galore.  The game gives you crumbs of convenience though and it pays off your hard work.  One of the best features of this game is that there are other players doing the exact same thing.  The multiplayer aspect makes the game feel alive even though there are hardly any npcs.  The structures they make in their game shows up in yours thus making your life as a porter even easier.  

Game play wise it feels like a new experience that no other game has done.  Story wise? Tons of lore and things to read in game and you are going to want to take some time out of your day delivering goods to catch up on the history of Death Stranding. The game makes this aspect interesting as well since you get emails from all the contacts you have met and it continues their story through this.  The more of a connection you make with these contacts the more emails you get from them and you get interviews that you are able to read that give more background about the game.  

Highly recommend if you want a new experience.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Metal Gear Solid was the first and last Hideo Kojima game I played (I was still in grade school) I was never a huge fan of any of the games, therefore I was initially skeptical about picking this up when it launched for PS4 back in November. However, after I saw the Half-Life X Death Stranding crossover (Thank you for bringing this to PC) I gained curiosity for it again plus I'm a huge fan of Norman Reedus from the film [i]The Boondock Saints[/i]

There aren't many games I feel I need to write a review for, but Death Stranding is an exception. This isn't just a game - it's an experience that moved me like a artwork masterpiece. The game makes me feel like I'm in Iceland or Alaska which happen to be two places I've always wanted to visit. The cutscenes are amazing, and the gameplay graphics are surreal. The attention to detail is some of the best I've ever seen, not just the visuals but the audio as well. The soundtrack is beautiful, and the voice acting in this game is superb; the entire cast did a phenomenal job. 

"[b]Death Stranding Is Not For Everyone[/b]" this is an understatement. People will say it's a boring walking simulator. It's unfortunate there are so many mindless reviewers out there, especially since many video game companies just keep feeding players the same garbage over and over again, and no one is bold enough to try to create anything new or innovative.  

We as human beings have become slaves to instant gratification. This game is extremely relevant through these trying times. I played this game during the prolonged quarantine of COVID-19. Hideo Kojima brought a very deep theme and ideal which the story portrays about life, and how we should value it while also helping others.

title: DEATH STRANDING

Keep on keepin' on.

Game is comfy and everything I wanted.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
One of the most interesting games I have ever played. Mechanics wise, it is not that different from other open world games. However, what Kojima has done is truly something interesting in the sense he turns what usually is a boring and monotonous task of delivering stuff from A to B, into an actually interesting and enjoyable experience. The integration with online features where other players' building structures showing up in your game to aid you in quite unique and it honestly made the game even better. It's a nice feeling seeing other people that have gone ahead of you, laying down bridges, rest stops and vehicles for other players. It truly makes you feel like you are part of the chiral network and was a big motivator for me personally to connect each region to the network.

Story wise, I would say this was one of the best stories I have seen in video games in a while. Witcher 3 and Detroit Become Human are the only others that come to mind with an equal story. Starting the game you are like wtf is going on there is no way I will be able to understand any of this even after the game ends. But Kojima slowly feeds you all the information you are missing and slowly over the course of the game it all starts to make sense. There were a few times I had to pause mid game and was like "Wait a minute, I get it now". Kojima left the whole story right in front of you the whole time, you just have to play to uncover the info. You also get large amounts of lore and back story through delivering packages that come in through "interviews" where you can read in your spare time. I like this because it gives those who persevere and grind out packages another reward if they are invested in the story, while at the same time not forcing it down your throat. It is only there for you to read if you want to read it.

Overall I think this is a great game but I only recommend it for certain types of people. If you are the kind of person who can't keep an attention span for more than 5 minutes and need constant stimulus, this is not the game for you. This game is an experience, not something you run and gun through. There is a lot of time where it will be just you and BB, walking through the world while music is playing. This game gives you the chance to understand there is something greater than yourself: helping others and developing relationships. This game brings up good thoughts about the meaning of life, purpose and the importance of connections and relationships. This game was an experience all the way through and if you are a patient person who loves lore and story, sit down and enjoy the ride. Keep on keeping on!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This review is a quick one.

If you like fast paced games with a lot of action and stuff…. Then, move along. Because although Sam can run, it is everything but fast paced, since you’ll be the delivery guy with a nightmarish long-distance schedule.
However, when you like story driven games with a lot of character depth and are into a more cinematic/game hybrid….. well, then stay for the ride (haul).

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I haven't played any other Kojima game, but this one is a masterpiece. The game isn't well balanced for PC controls (it's too easy), the bossfights are stupid and a decent chunk of the story makes no sense. However, everything else is pure gold.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
In a way, it's "a walking simulator" - you're a delivery-guy, and you're delivering packages.  But.  It's got Kojima's signature WTF world building, an interesting mechanic of shared constructions and packages across separate worlds, hostiles you have to deal with, on occasion, to deliver the packages, and a some truly beautiful sights.

There are some sections where it can get (extremely) frustrating, in the early game, where you've not yet acquired any real combat capability and have to sneak through enemy populated areas while your cargo quickly decays, but overall I've been quite enjoying the game despite the few warts.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: It has all of the subtlety of a bunch of college students getting high and chatting philosophy in their dorm, but I can't help but enjoy Kojima's specific brand of interactive storytelling. The æsthetics are extremely well done, and the core gameplay loop is deeply satisfying. Having been stuck inside for the past five months of pandemic, Death Stranding feels "of the moment" in a way I'm not sure it did when it was originally released.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Extremely difficult, annoying game play. Going out of the incinerator, I'm swarmed by things that want to kill me. No matter how or where I move, they kill me. Getting a refund. Not getting anything else by this developer.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is mostly suited for players who get a kick out of exploration and figuring things out. If you're a player that gets into the STALKER series and loves the world-building, the mystery, go get it. It looks beautiful and I highly recommend you have a GPU with 4GB VRAM or more. The game looks runs amazing on 1080p with an older i7 CPU and a gtx1660super. The main drawback for most people, is you just have to deal with not having non-stop action. You can make it more challenging for yourself when playing on hard mode. I'm playing it again after completing on the standard ps4 and it gives an interesting perspective on the story.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game has a bit of the zen of Shadow of the Colossus... but with the added antagonist that is the environment itself. The few gripes I have with the game are the product placement (I've only seen two instances of it, so its not terrible... but still a little annoying), and the fire-hose of information thrown at you, while leaving you with questions regarding the fundamentals of game-play. 

To be fair, those fundamentals are explained in time... but most games explain features when they're presented... in contrast, Death Stranding seems to take its time in explaining them... or requires you to go diving into its rather sizable tips section to get the information.

None of the issues really detracted all that much from the experience though. I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone who wants a little bit of a sense of reconnecting the world's cities to one another.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Absolutely one of the best games I've ever played. The game gives you such an incentive to keep performing the tasks that you're doing, which in turn feeds into the player's motivation to keep going further and further. If you're tired of other games giving you nothing more than "go here do this" then consider this as something that performs that formula but shakes it up so that the journey and gameplay loop is different. The story is great, and definitely no-where near as confusing as people make it out to be; it's a standard sci-fi story that I haven't seen before, and I enjoy it. If I had to give the game some negative criticism, I think there are some things that could be fixed in later patches. Specifically, I think it's silly you don't get to use your music player while you're out and about in the game, maybe that'll occur later or on NG+ but I'm not sure. Another issue could be menu management; if you like things like the Resident Evil 4 inventory system and organizing things gives you joy then you will have fun with this, but it *CAN* be a little tedious to have to constantly open a menu to perform tasks (think Metal Gear Solid 3 Standard Edition when you had to swap camo constantly). The vehicle movement in the first section of the game was pretty nice, but man hitting the second section of the game has made the bike physics sometimes go all over the place. Sometimes you'll "jump" with the bike and just float up a good 30 feet even though you were hardly going fast at all, but it's ultimately not taken away from the experience of the game at all. I've been having minor glitches with my Xbox One wireless controller in that on occasion the game will behave like I just rapidly hit X or the Start button over and over again, but I'm not sure what's going on there (could just be the transmitter getting interference rather than the game). Lastly, this is probably my biggest complaint, even though some people will just scoff it off as my fault— in the game you can trust your cargo to other people to deliver it for you, so you have a backup if you can't finish a delivery, and when you're returning missing/dropped cargo to a client while also carrying someone ELSE'S lost cargo, the game will finish the selection for Client 1's delivery, then transition into the Entrust menu for the other client's lost cargo. This is EXTREMELY annoying because I've accidentally missed the highlight on the menu title and just skipped through so fast that I've entrusted cargo I didn't want to. I think they really need to take this out of the game and just have the Entrust Cargo menu as it's own separate terminal option (which it already is, but stop transitioning to it after making a delivery). I know it sounds stupid but I've lost a lot of stuff accidentally by doing that. Either way, those are really my only complaints. This game is one of the best I've ever played, and it keeps me engaged. Compare this to other games like Mad Max where you literally have to go to places, look around, take objectives which are "go here do this, drive back;" Death Stranding manages to turn that experience into an entertaining one, and I don't think a game has ever done such a good job. I can TOTALLY see why this game is divisive for people in the industry, but in my opinion, it is absolutely worth full price.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I enjoy this game very much, simply because it's a breath of fresh air in gaming. 

It's not an action or combat focused game, it's a game for when all you want is to relax and play something that doesn't demand so much out of you. I enjoy this game in the same way i enjoy Euro Truck Simulator or Farming Simulator.

Now, what you do in this game? You get cargo in point A and take it to point B. In the way you'll have to deal with the natural environment that will make your life hardee, bandits and supernatural events like ghosts. So you have a tiny bit of stealth, with some bits of combat mixed in with a lot of traveling, and as you progress in the game, you'll see a bunch of cutscenes in the tradition style of Kojima.

It's very much an all or nothing with this game. If it sounds interesting to you, you'll probably like it, if you think it sounds stupid, you'll probably hate it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Nice movie, a bit confusing because everything has to be explained in the next second, but enjoyable nonetheless.
The main characters are confusing and funny. I can't relate to some of them because they just... don't grow naturally like a character should.
Deadman and Heartman are pretty cool though.
---
Oh, it also has a bonus walking simulator game in a desolate, empty-open world. I like the part where people has to work together in making highways and other amenities -- which fills the said empty open-world. It's fulfilling, so to speak.

The driving physics are pretty funny, I mean, you can't walk straight with 100 kg cargo on your back but you can jump high with a trike while carrying the same cargo and won't tumble down if you can land with the right attitude.
One-hit non-lethal combat is simple and satisfying. However, the forced lethal combats are annoying.

The most satisfying part in the game is when you get notified that something you have built helped someone else, I guess in terms of gameplay, the game is successful in sending the message about "connection" to the players.

Pretty good experience, I recommend it if you enjoy walking, sight-seeing, delivering packages, sneaking from evil invisible ghosts and people looking for dopamine rush from robbery, or like "likes" in general.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: A niche game, but one that has been funded to the gills. A strange experience - but an amazing one if you fall in the centre of the venn diagram of Kojima fans and Euro Truck Simulator fans. The core gameplay loop is the planning and execution of delivery expeditions back and forth. If that doesn't sound appealing you won't like this, but if that sounds interesting - you'll find a game that makes that a deeply appealing and engaging loop.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Awesome! A bold work of unusual genius. However, it will appeal to some much more than others. If you like simulator type games it will probably be right up your street, it's a bit like Mudrunner / Spin Tyres but walking, and with a compelling story, plus some combat and stealth. Oh and crafting and a little base building!

There is a sizeable number of story cut scenes in the first 5 hours of play. You will need to love treking across the wilderness, over rough terrain then sometimes sneaking around strange ghost like entities and occasionally fighting or running from Mad Max esque, rain coat wearing weirdos, who want to steal your stuff.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The best "walking simulator" I ever played to date. All the deliveries you make and the connections you form with others, helps bridge not only other people from around the world but brings closer Sam and the player. Often times than not we feel "disconnected" and isolated from the world. But the more you venture to go "outside" the more you begin to feel more content, that you are not as alone as you think you were. Death Stranding truly encompasses the meaning of journey. And is really relevant now at our time, more than ever.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Great game but not perfect. 

Combat is uninspired. Interface should be reworked. Controls are clunky at times. Many cutscenes are annoying. Gameplay is repetitive and unimaginative. 

However, the world is gigantic, beautiful, and well-designed. Characters are complex, interesting, and impressively well-acted. The story is frightening at time, yet captivating and fascinating. Such an heavenly soundtrack and unforgettable atmosphere! 

One of the most unique, creative, innovative, and thought-provoking gaming experience of the last 10 years.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Beautiful game, I would describe it as one of those games that is haunting. Not just to play, but you end up thinking about it when you are not playing it.
It is slow paced - no question, but I am old school and would prefer "ghost recon" gameplay over "quake style" - for those that have been around a while, they will know what I mean.

Following the story and doing essential missions does mix it up, but some of the "normal" delivery missions - well - they are a bit boring....running there and back - sometimes these take you through nothing but rocks and grass without BT's or any challenge.

However, some area's are spooky and BT's are a great enemy that can freak you out.

So far, love this game, but I never spend too long playing it. Drop in for a couple of missions and then go back to satisfactory or factorio for the "long haul".

I would have been happier paying £30 for this rather than £55, but you can see where the money went. I am sure that Daryl and Hannibal cost a pretty penny.

If you fancy it, get it, it is very original in a time where that get getting uncommon.

If you are on the fence, wait for a sale, this isnt quite an "URGENT, MUST GET NOW".

I hate cutscenes, especially when you cant skip, and this is FULL of them, almost like a whole movie spliced into the gameplay, but they are well done and I can live with them in this game...but again, a tad aggravating.

You are almost certain to like this game and "WOW" at the graphics...and it does get better when you get new toys to play with....this is a 75% overall for me.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Here is my comment under IGN's review (6.8) of Death Stranding after its PS4 release:

I think what people need to understand is that there ARE games that are not fully action-packed, adrenaline-driven, and visually-stimulating. This (IGN) review is primarily based on the subjective point of view where this guy is expecting something like guns and combats (as in metal gears solid) in Death Stranding; however, it is not STRANDING if you can just run it down and kill everyone. The protagonist is not a superhero. He is just a delivery man in a near-future setting. To feel the oppressiveness and the weight of the world requires players to sit down and really contemplate about these tough decisions or even philosophical questions. We all like different games, but just to give a game 6.8 because it does not match someone's personal taste can be misleading. (but if you argue IGN is there for the popular mass, then yeah, I would say this review suits the general taste)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Quite literally the most unique game i have ever played. I tend to not like games that have plethora of side-content, but in Death Stranding i complete most of the things i come across. Optimization is on point, PC controls feels natural, the sound design is top tier and so is the visual design. I have never seen a more beautiful map, it just sells the idea that it could be a real place really well. Of course, the game has it's bugs, but after 35 hours i have not encountered anything serious, the most annoying thing are the floaty vehicle controls. The story is great but some cutscenes feel a little cheesy, that's Kojima's trademark though. The game isn't for anyone, it's not non-stop action like a lot of games are these days (nothing wrong with that though), but i'd lie if i said that some moments in DS aren't intense as hell.
   

tl;dr: Kojima saw that there are no good walking simulators, so he went ahead and came up with the best walking simulator that exists. After this, i am extremely excited for Kojipro's next project.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: One of the best games I've ever played.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I was sceptical to this game which has been described what sounds like a cutscene storm on top of a walking simulator. I really dislike cutscenes in games, and usually just skip right through them if possible. I have precious little time for playing games, and when I do I want to play and not watch a poorly written movie, just interrupted with some linear gameplay. These kind of games tend to be popular though, so I guess I am just not a mainstream gamer.

However, I was pleasantly surprised to find myself intrigued by the bizarre story unfolding. There's a ton of lore in here, and it is all presented in an interesting way where the characters all have a strong personality that keeps me invested.

And the game needs an interesting story, because it does focus on it a lot. During the first hour or so, do not expect to do much except just watching cutscenes. But it gradually takes off the support wheels and let you take more and more control, so the world is opened for you and you can do what you want in it.

The game mechanics are very basic. Walk from A to B to deliver your cargo that you keep on your back. The bigger the cargo, the more you struggle keeping balance. Navigate through the gorgeous landscapes and keep pressing forward through all kinds of obstacles, ranging from easy ones like scattered stones and rivers to more challenging ones like vertical cliffs and ravines. You can use ropes, ladders and other equipment to solve how to get past a difficult area.

But the real challenge is the presence of some supernatural entities, that manifests during rain. There are also bandits who want to get hold of your cargo. So, as the game progresses, you find that there are a lot more to it than simply walking about.

But make no mistake, there will be a lot of walking around. At the moment I am not very deep into the story, but I am already not starting to feel my patience is getting stretched a bit. The most annoying thing that happens is you need to walk for a long time to get to some pre-determined even that will give you a real challenge. If you fail, then all the walking to get there has been in vain.

First of all the game is a fresh breath, as the AAA games typically tend to be quite stale without any new ideas. Most game studios throw themselves on popular genres like fortnite to cash out more with less risk, but in the process just flooding the market with similar games. So, kudos to the game designer here for taking a chance on what he believe in.

I am enjoying it so far, more than I thought I would. Can easily recommend to anyone who want to try something new and strange, with more depth and polish than the typical indie game studio can afford.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: At some points in the story its like your watching a movie unfold, you become invested in the characters and how the story lines will develop. Without a doubt you'll want to finish this game from beginning to end. The visuals are beautiful, coupled with the music, songs, and audio can truly make an impression. After a long haul it's not surprising to be facing an amazing landscape with touching background music, making the job feel that much more satisfying. The gameplay is fun and creative but some parts are a tad tedious, but the way they implemented multiplayer elements into a seemingly single player game was masterful and sure to be copied. You never see another player but you never feel alone in this journey, directly benefiting from the players before you and hopefully leaving something behind for the players following in your footsteps. Overall the unique worldbuilding and gameplay artfully tied together with touching and unforgettable characters and their stories will leave you craving for more. Is a must buy. 8.9/10

title: DEATH STRANDING

So I read the reviews and the game sounded pretty tedious.....'Walking Simulator' you say??

Well I bit the bullet and bought it, and I'm not disappointed! Walking plays a big part obviously, but it's not the be all and end all of the game - plenty of new and more interesting upgrades come into play as you progress.

There's the walking/climbing simulator side of things obviously, then there's some limited vehicular travel and even some limited fast travel thrown in. 

Buy it,  it will surprise you!!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I had heard this game was boring since it came out on consoles, still i wanted to try it out for myself and make my own opinion; I'm no stranger to enjoying "boring" games.

The game is not boring, It's suffocating.

You want to enjoy carrying cargo around?

Kojima will smother your screaming face in lengthy cutscenes full of nothing, pointless animations every time you walk in or out of BT territory (like you don't know you are about to) or perform mundane actions and endless tutorials explaining the obvious (sometimes for things you have already done) leaving out important concepts to figure out on your own.

You are here for the story?

Good luck!
It's so full of  metaphysical wanking to be completely meaningless; I find it impossible to get invested in any capacity, and in turn to enjoy it.

The less said about the "characters" the better, stupid people with stupid names doing stupid thing for stupid reasons; In other words Stupid at the power of 4; While said stupidity was enjoyable in stories like Metal Gear, here it's played without the slightest hint of comedy or self-awareness, making it absolutely miserable.

And let's not forget Kojima's trademark creepiness around women characters; I mean a girl named "Fragile"?!? For Fuck Sake!

I already played way past Steam's refund time limit, otherwise i would have already refunded it.

A Complete disappointment.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It may look like delivery simulator, but it's way more than that. 
there's ghosty bois, stealy bois, giant eldrich horror beasts, deadly rain, beautiful scenery, and a fantastic storyline.
I really enjoy the community interaction in building roads and other structures.

Ride your bike somewhere? low on power? maybe someone else will be in the same boat. Build them a powerstation. everyone benefits.
find a deep crevice and don't want to take the long way around? build a bridge 
scaled a tall mountain and don't want to make the next guy go through that? drop a climbing rope so future porters (or yourself, since you might want to use that route again) can have an easier time getting up that mountain.  
Want to warn someone of perils ahead? found a beautiful view? drop a sign to let your fellow porters know about it. 

you might be all alone out there, but it feels like you're with a big happy family of porters. even if you never see them, you can see their effects on the world... and they can see yours. 

10/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Played a few hours of this game, and it's a pretty nuanced one. That's what you get with Kojima. It's intensely cinematic, you're not playing a game with any real system here, you're living an experience. If your motto is "Enjoying the journey, not the destination" then this game would very much be for you.

The story is vague and sometimes confusing, but again, Kojima. All in all, something I'd wholly suggest to people who like to really immerse themselves into a story, and subsequently, a game.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a game that is like no other. It has graphics that rival RDR2, a story that rivals even the best-written TV shows or movies, and a soundtrack rivaled by no other. The gameplay is the only aspect that others may seem boring, but after an hour or so of gameplay, I wanted more. I was like the [spoiler] MULES [/spoiler], delivering any main quest package I could. 

The graphics make this game feel like you are watching a movie. The reflections in the water, the level of detail in the grass and snow, the amazing sunsets, it's incredible. 

The story is awesome, with all the little details, and well-written characters.

The music always compliments the scene in a perfect way. Every song is only played once, making every time they are heard even more special. 

The gameplay might push some away at first, and I totally see that. It doesn't change much, aside from [spoiler] action, driving, and some stealth[/spoiler]. But, its mostly just walking or running through a highly detailed and beautiful area. It makes you feel zen. 

This is where the graphics, music, and semi-calming gameplay all come together. As you feel so alone, and perfectly timed song starts to play. It gives you the motivation to either continue going or finish the trip right then and there. 

When I went into this game, I knew what I was getting into. But I did not know I would enjoy it this much. This is a game that needed to be made, and love it or hate it needs to be played. Kojima proved he could do this without a big studio. This game is one of the few games I want to play, and keep playing. I really would not change it in any way. 

And as I finish writing this, all I can think to myself is, "Why didn't I play on PlayStation?"

10/10, and my 2019 GOTY

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't own a console and was very happy to see this arrive to PC.
This is a very different game.
I was made aware that this was made fun of as a 'walking simulator', and so far it has been an absolute surprise and a joy to play. Lot's of problem solving and decisions to make on how you make your trek across the land.
Currently playing this with mouse and keyboard, I had though perhaps it would be better with a controller but so far this is one of the best PC ports I have ever tried; the controls are quite intuitive and definitely not hacked together.
Combat is few and far between, it really puts the player in their role that violence is a last resort. As a person who actually has naturally gotten less interest in pure shooting violence games, this one really gives me something to enjoy while still being a AAA title.
Absolute work of art, story is interesting (and oddly relevent despite having been created pre-covid. The story tries to explain to you this sci-fi concept of social distancing and quarantine as if it was not a current reality. Very odd and relatable)
Visually stunning, works with ultrawides but not up to 5120 x 1440, you will have to play in 3440 x 1440. This seems perfectly acceptable. 
So far very happy with this game, I don't usually finish story oriented games, and this one has kept me involved the whole time.
Not for everyone, but for those that would enjoy it, phenomenal.
