title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I feel I have only just started this game. I've heard people have finished it in under ten hours, but I have been doing a lot of side quests to unlock gear, and building stuff for my fellow porters, so I just got to chapter 4. Still a lot ahead of me. It's so incredibly weird and fantastic, so imaginative, I am savoring it all.

The whole 'walking simulator' thing doesn't do it justice. It really is so much more than that. A sense of meaning and accomplishment by arrival, the tension and adrenaline of a misplaced boot, planning routes using a map like a true explorer, the weight of the pack, all contribute to a sense of journey. This game does the best job I have seen anywhere to create an actual sense of scale, and the related awe one feels in a haunting landscape both green volcanic and of howling desolation. All to a movie-like soundtrack, and talented actors really nailing their parts.

The player helps others play, and brings some much needed relief to the suffering denizens of a disconnected and ravaged world at the same time. You will interact with other, real people from all over the world, and no one will be the wiser, a user name on a well-placed bridge to boost likes to. It is an empty world full of souls, some dead, some VR avatars, some footsteps just passed by a moment before, but the help is there, like the right amount of materials placed in a box by someone else next to a much-needed road. Sam rarely meets anyone in the flesh, but everyone is connected, real or imagined. The bittersweet and beautiful ache of loneliness echoes over the landscape. NPCs, grieving, upset, tears falling easily, or bitter and shut down, numb from all of this world's experience hide in their bunkers. The villians are terribly broken and evil. Main characters tell their captivating tales. Tears come very easy in this devastated place, even for hardcore warrior types like Sam, all he has to do is connect to BB to feel it. 

There are metaphors, social statements, political statements, such as a kind of hope for an idealized America that comes off as a global sentiment for success, one in which people care about each other, and hope for one another's successes and survival. Of course, the crushing tragedies that got people to this place is part of the story, as some are of a mind that life is futile, that only despair and torment as oily death remains for death's sweet sake.

Death Stranding is a pinnacle of the art, a masterpiece. It outsmarts all the ruts gaming has gotten itself into. All the murder-hoboing and toxicity, all the shaming, bullying and entitlement, all the isolation, distraction and disconnection, all the depression and avoidance of work that gaming has an internal struggle with is addressed elegantly and with grace. As a porter, you work tirelessly to make the world better. Sam is like atlas carrying the weight of a dying world. He speaks rarely, but with weight and by deed.  His comments often make me smile. There is a good bit of ridiculousness here to remind us not to take ourselves too damn seriously as we attempt to hide our packages from tormented and malevolent ghosts. It unfolds like a lotus and continues to unfold. And of course, at the top of the meaning structure, is our inbred avoidance/obsession with death. I can't go into too much more without spoilers, but I whole-heartedly recommend the experience of this game. 

Lonely, quiet Sam Porter Bridges, essential worker of the apocalypse, braving all dangers to connect the huddled remnants cringing from almost total extinction, to you sir I raise my glass. The deeper you are, the deeper it goes like a night's reflection on the calm ocean. Such is the eternal abyss, where death is a single strand among an infinite number of raindrops that capture us in our unknowing to shine with brave grief and heart-felt awe, or tumble awkwardly and numb into darkness with a feeling of never having experienced anything at all.


Peace

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Gameplay, world building, story is awesome. Acting is awesome. But compared to other "best" games of 2020, there's a distinct lack of player choice that influence the story. 

A problem I have is that the cities themselves feel largely empty and void of life. Why is this not addressed? To show what I mean, in the first scenes where you meet "Mother" and Die-Heart Man tries to convince you to take the job, you're inside the facility of the "President of the United States". Yet, there's zero signs of life from other NPCs, such as scientists / soldiers or other VIPs that would be around such an important figure. It's just you, Die Heart Man, in an empty building, in an empty world.

It's OK for the wilderness to be empty and not have people, but when you're in civilization, there should've been people. The game feels so boring otherwise, you're going from one ghost town. to another. No way for you to say "No" to people. No way for consequences to be felt, because Kojima didn't bother putting any frikin NPCs in the game. It's like cmon. Big let down. If you like walking in an empty world, with pretty scenery, that's fine. 

The only worth while mechanic is the walking and weight system. Art, music, plot, all decent. But the lack of NPCs is pretty embarasing especially since you're suppose to be fighting to rebuild, but if the only thing I see are holograms, what's the point.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
So pretty much, you're walking, taking care of a baby, carrying a tower of packages while enjoying the beautiful landscapes 90% of the game. Death Stranding has the best moss and that should be the only thing that matters. All jokes aside, the only real negative of it is the story pacing but it was not enough to sour my experience. Story is still worth experiencing despite it's blemishes.

First of all, if you like deep and meaningful experiences, this is it. If you're playing games solely to have mindless fun, look somewhere else. If you have a short attention span and zero patience, the game is not for you. In fact, I found that the most frustrating parts of the game was when I was trying to rush through it. When I actually slowed down to take it all in, things just clicked, I was hooked. The game punishes impatient players. For example, running down steep mountains resulting in Norman Reedus tumbling and dropping all his package which leads them to get damaged or destroyed. Another example being when trying to cross a river without checking how deep it is. Patience is the name of the game. 

The online aspect is my favourite thing about the game. Strangers can leave equipment for you or structures you can use. It really hammers home the theme that we are stronger together. 

This is coming from someone who played all the MGS games. I had EXTREMELY low expectations for the game due to the negative feedback from the gaming community but I was proven wrong after playing the PC port for the first time. 

Rating: 8/10 Oh and the MUSIC UGH SO GOOD

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
See the bottom for a TLDR.

The primary thing you do in the game is run trade-packs from point A to B, while seeing beautiful landscapes and experiencing a wonderful story. There's scary/suspenseful moments due to a neat mechanic. There's also a cool mechanic where you and other players have an effect on each other's worlds. The soundtrack is also incredible, and at the points where the music kicks in it really has an impact.

This isn't an action packed game where you're constantly in combat. It's something relaxing to play at times and stressful at other times (fun stressful, if that makes sense). The game really pulls you into the world with the story. I can't stress that enough.

There is a LOT of reading, and I mean a LOT. (Basically, the length of my review minus the TLDR is the length of most of the reading material). The game obviously has voice dialog but you get in-game mail which is not voiced and is pretty wordy or sometimes repeats some of the same material you've already read from someone else's mail but with extra information. I will say however that the game does a good job of highlighting text so you can just read that highlighted portion and you'll get the gist of it.

TLDR:
Gameplay: Lot's of walking, there's also vehicles. But you'll still have to walk a lot. You run trade-packs from one point to another.
Pros: Fantastic story, beautiful landscapes, incredible soundtrack, lots of suspenseful moments.
Cons: Tons and tons of reading (there's also voice dialog obviously), you may not like the game if you'll get bored doing cargo runs all the time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I'm currently 20+ hours into the game at this point. i have to say this is a solid game. For the past couple months I have been sitting around waiting for a solid single player game. This is it. There are times where it seems to slow down and you feel like its just another open world game. however once you start progressing passed that and earning new equipment to make your tasks easier it is absolutely phenomenal. The graphics are A+ and there is an endless amount of things to be done to help you and the community out that plays this. No multiplayer but the way they incorporate others into the same world as yours is absolutely outstanding. If you have patience and like a solid story line this is the game for you. Give your top of the line GPU a chance with this one and i promise you wont be disappointed.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't normally write reviews, but I felt the need to pop these quick tid bits out for those who may find it useful. This isn't really a full review.

1) 5 hours in and the game is real enjoyable, I'm digging the story, it's odd, but it's Kojima. I'm also enjoying the gameplay.

2) The 21:9 support is not quite 21:9 just as a heads up, you get 3360x1440 not 3440x1440.

3) Be prepared to sit through a lot of cutscenes that can last a decent while at times (at least in my 5 hour experience so far.) This isn't inherently bad, as you're getting the story with it, but there can be some decent gaps between actual gameplay, so it's something to consider.

4) The mouse and keyboard support is pretty solid in my book, though the "designed for controller" nature does exist to some extent.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
When Death Stranding was first revealed back in 2016 during the E3 Press Conference, I was intrigued to say the least. Once I saw that it was produced by Sony Interactive Entertainment as well, I was fearful that the game would be a PlayStation Exclusive. Not that I don't have a PlayStation, I just prefer playing on PC, and the annoyance of having to obtain the hard copy and install it on my console seemed, at the time, not worth it. However once Kojima Productions announced it was coming to Steam, I was ecstatic. Simply because I have been a fan of Hideo Kojima with series such as Metal Gear, and the cast line up of characters informed me of just how much of a treat this game would be.

Death Stranding is a game, all of it's own. There are not many like it, and I can see a potential revolutionary gameplay ideology that will influence games in the future. This game does a lot of things right, and some wrong, although I would claim that the validity of the positives far outweigh the validity of the negatives. Simply put, the cons of my experience was not game breaking, nor did it ruin the experience.

The story of Death Stranding is an absolute mystery to the player once you start the game. You have no context, no backstory, or character developing moments within the first 30 minutes of the game. 

You play as Sam Porter Bridges, played by Norman Reedus, and he is a courier of sorts. Not of just envelopes, or mail, but of valuable items, items that later become very useful as you continue throughout the game. You first see Sam on a motorcycle, driving throughout the countryside while the credits roll, portraying all of the cast members without the names of the characters in which they play. This was all intentional, seeing as you learn each of these characters as your progress throughout the story. As Sam is driving along, he ends up clearing this cliff and running into a woman, leading him to crash and his bike to fall off the cliff. So, stranded without a vehicle, a storm comes along with an inverted rainbow in the sky. As you take control of Sam, and collect his cargo, you learn the mechanics of traversal. Such as balancing using both of your arms, climbing, jumping, running, all of these actions which lead you to a cave to wait out the storm. During your time spent in the cave, you come across the women Sam hit while clearing the canyon on his bike, a woman named Fragile, played by Lea Seydoux. A character that seems to have a supernatural feeling about her, although you can't pinpoint why, and what she is capable of. Then, during your conversation with Fragile, you come across the hidden enemies. The Beached Things, or BT's for short. These terrifying opponent's are invisible to the eye, leaving tar filled handprints all over the ground. Now, although it's a newly introduced part of the story, without any context, you can assume they are dangerous simply because of how Sam reacts, crouching down, moving slowly, steadying his breathing, and covering his mouth, all while watching these handprints move closer and closer to him. Eventually the storm clears, the rainbow disappears, and the BT's are no longer around. You make the connection rather quickly, that the storms precede the BT's, which is an important game mechanic used later by the player. 

After Sam and Fragile's encounter with the BT's, there is a small introductory period of them both, learning that Sam has Aphenphosmphobia, or the fear of being touched, all the while learning that Fragile had been caught out in the middle of the Timefall, the storms that precede BT's and age everything it touches, and severely damaged and aged her own body from neck to toe. This is all a mystery to the player from the beginning, as to the reasonings why Sam has his phobia, and Fragile is scarred, something you learn more about as you progress through the storyline.

Then, after Fragile disappears, and Sam loads up his gear onto his back, you go on a small journey to a local city to deliver your packages all while listening to the soundtrack of the band, LOW ROAR. This feature pops up frequently while on your longer missions, music will be played on the journey, and at the end of the mission you can save the song to be played at any other moment.

That is the first 15-30 minutes of Death Stranding, absolutely confusing, but ridiculously intriguing, so much so to keep the player interested throughout the 20+ hour storyline.

Additionally the cast of this game is absolutely stellar, with performances from Norman Reedus, Lea Seydoux, Mads Mikkelsen, Guillermo Del Toro, Troy Baker, and others to keep the review list short. All of the performances by the individual actors are enticing, and moving. Sure there are moments where dialogue seems stretched and inauthentic as most games do. That said, the moments where you chuckle at the cheesiness or the downright confusion, it was all for a reason chosen by Hideo Kojima. Whether that be to portray his characters in a certain light, or flesh out details about how they would act if the Death Stranding hadn't occurred in the first place.

This game is very polarizing, and although it's polarizing, I haven't met many people who have hated the game as a whole, at least not enough to not recommend it. However, I believe as do a few others, the people who will enjoy this game are the people who will choose to buy it, to play it, understand it, and finish it all on their own. That was a choice I had made, paying the full $60 retail price, and I would not take back that money compared to the enjoyment I had from the story and the gameplay.

Death Stranding isn't for everyone but for those who are interested in playing a game that requires time and thought into things such as route planning, as well as patience, will thoroughly enjoy this game, in my opinion of course. The time spent playing this game, even if you do not enjoy some of the mechanics that surround it, the storyline as a whole is an absolute marvel of ingenuity in my estimation. There is nothing like Death Stranding, and I would love to see what Hideo can do from here with this style of game.

Now, would I recommend this game at a full price of $60. I'm inclined to say yes, no doubt, however my review isn't to sway you into purchasing this game, but to give insight into how someone might interpret the game after it has been completed. If you're interested, and are willing to spend the money for a game unlike any other while accepting some of it's inadequacies and flaws but enjoying it's tender moments, go for it! It's worth the buy, and a blast to play.

Anyways, have a good day y'all, and God Bless!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: 10/10 walking simulator

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is really good. Unlike many games these days, the core game-play loop is not combat. There is some combat, but that's not the focus of the game. Some people call it a walking simulator, which isn't wrong, but it forms the wrong associations. "Walking simulators" I've played before have all really just been a nice tour of a landscape, maybe with puzzles. They did not include the actually interesting mechanic of walking. Death Stranding does. It feels like hiking up and down a mountain, where suddenly you need to pay a bit of attention to where you step and how you want to approach it. It has captured the essence of hiking and trekking places in a way that nothing else has. Other games have captured the striking beauty of natural landscapes, but not the interesting and somewhat meditative process of traversing them. This gets thrown into overdrive when baddies arrive, and you're forced to figure out how to get around them, or get through an area fast. Do you want to abandon part of your load to move faster? Do you want to try to circumnavigate the area?

The story is standard Hideo Kojima so far, which is to say it's totally batshit and unintelligible, but the emotional beats and arc goes well. The unintelligible aspect of it doesn't make it bad, it makes it mysterious and eldritch imho.

Tl;Dr, I highly recommend it. It's very different from games I've played before and there's nothing I can easily compare it to. It's groundbreaking and interesting and definitely pushing the boundaries of what AAA games can be and how the experience of gaming can be different.

review:
So, I think people who disliked death stranding are either low attention span people or people who can not preform under high stress, the game require 100% attention, assessment, planning and thinking on the spot all at once, if you are not good at those it means you will HATE!!! DeathStranding, to me the game is fantatic so far am 6 hours in and if I was not obligated to stuff I would have not dropped the controller today, so far the game is 10/10 and running on my under preforming pc is a plus.

or who is interested
Cpu i7 3770k
Videocard zotac 1050ti 4gb 
16GB DDR3 ram
1TB HHD

The textures might not be crisp on my machine but It did not bother me at all and the framerate is butter smooth, am really damn impressed!!!

Audio is fantastic! it really get's you right there, visuals, game play fluidity, everything the game is just to dang good! 

and the immersion part of the game, I probably felt as tired as Sam, as frustrated as he, as terrified as him, I tap that damn button to fight off BTEs like there is no tomorrow, I really do not want to start a crater, felt so pressured and that sigh of relief getting out of the BTEs area, never felt the sense of loss so terrifying, without knowing what will actually happen if I do that, this game is making me terrified, awed with its visuals, and really not wanting to let go of the controller.

but again, it might not be for everyone, but I personally love it!

update: I forgot to mention the interactions for online, very interesting interactions and really encourage positive way of interaction between players placing guides for each other, leaving ropes and ladders to help improve travel for other players, super cool stuff.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is everything I expected it to be. I simply love it. 
It allows you to explore. The story is engaging. The characters are believable and relatable. The combat can be a bit clunky if you end up in an area with a lot of small obstacles. The BTs can lock you in place for too long due to terrain. But in general the combat is fun, especially against cargo thieves. The block and dodge mechanics work well alongside striking. I moved the default fighting button away from V though as it was a bit awkward to use in combat. 

The graphics are beyond top notch. This is what I expect from Cyberpunk 2077 on a PC, not a game made for PS4. I am truly impressed. 

I am glad I didn't wait for a sale for this game. It is worth every penny I paid for it, and I don't mind giving a developer who delivers this fine a product the amount of money they asked for (about $70USD). We need more real creatives in the game developer sphere and less market research driven ones. I wish more publishers would take chances on different games.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
PC Port is quite good, performance is fine, no major glitches in 30+ hours of game.

Game itself has some big flaws. It's slow paced to the point of exhaustion. Tutorials are intrusive, given via dialogue and go all the way to the late game. It's a bit too easy (I played at normal difficulty). Every "quest" is a fetch quest and Devs didn't do much to spice things up. Story is basically told thru exposition.

However, a lot of the criticism is undeserved. All the claims that the gameplay is bad or that it's too difficult to control are absolutely ridicule. Movement and controls are fluid and easy. Vehicles drive well. Sam is easy to balance, and running around is not difficult at all. The common "it's a walking simulator" line really does not sound true after a while. For the first hour maybe I could agree, but as soon as the first combat and shooting sections kick in, it becomes very clear that this is not the case. There is a lot more to the game than just walking from A to B. The number of things the game allows you to manage, for example, is abysmal. I don't think I have ever played a game where so much attention was put to each and every little possible detail.

And, to compensate all the bad things, the game also has some very bright and interesting moments in the story and mechanics. Many scenes are beautiful, tense and interesting. Characters are intriguing. The world itself is so well build that walking around into it makes it feel alive. Never have I seen a game where the main character interacts so beautifully - and precisely with his surroundings. There are A LOT of different ways to tackle deliveries, and details in how you manage things make A LOT of difference, so even if you are always doing about the same thing, it doesn't get all that repetitive. The lack of thought put in quests is very much mitigated by the incredible amount of complications brought up by the environment itself. You have to consider EVERYTHING: time, weather, wind, terrain, temperature, paths, obstacles and so on.

Overall, I think it's a great game with some bad, bad flaws. If you are the patient type and are not looking for a action game, but for a unique DEEP management and simulation experience where action is secondary, it's easy to recommend Death Stranding. Otherwise, you might want to pass on this one.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: It's been many years since I've played a game that has captivated me like Death Stranding has, 25 hours of playtime so far. I thought I might get bored of the play style but 36 standard orders (deliveries) later and I'm still going back for more; finding the easiest or fastest routes is so rewarding. The game itself is beautiful, I've found myself stopping often to marvel at this world, everything looks incredible from the topography to the textures. The combat is quite casual so far on the normal difficulty, if you're not caught unprepared. The online cooperative system they have in place is fantastic It feels great to help others out (even though you cant see one another) and of course its handy to have others helping you out too. If you're looking for a great game to play; you have found it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I haven't obviously finished this game yet, and I'll edit this review once I do, but here's what I can tell you so far:

All my high expectations have been surpassed! This is the Kojima's game that surpasses Metal Gear (even if they are not comparable genre wise). As a matter of fact, there's no genre that can define Death Stranding! It's a one-in-a-lifetime experience with contemplative, artistic and philosophical moments alternating with a powerful blend of stealth, survival horror, and adventure! 
The intensity of those gameplay segments  and interactive cutscenes is sometimes mitigated by the typical humorous insertions that only Kojima can conceive! From funny comments, amusing reactions, fourth-wall breaking scenes, to quirky or even kinky sequences!
Photo mode even allows you to create and immortalise your own hilarious or serious memories with some very cool editing options: poses, facial expressions (for both Sam and BB), filters, effects, and more! And you can even do that during the cutscenes to some extent!

This is the first game ever where I'm feeling more in control of the overall experience rather than the main character. It's a continuous flow of video poetry where every single second within the narrative counts passionately! It's more than just a game or cinematic experience. It's a ludic, visual, and touching immersion into the deepest philosophical meaning of connections. Completely unrepeatable! And brilliantly emphasised by the asynchronous multiplayer.

Watching this streamed on Twitch/YouTube or passively observing someone else playing it won't do any justice to it. It strictly requires to be felt and experienced to be judged. I also personally disagree with those saying that the first three hours of DS may feel tedious to become more lively later in the game. I actually felt entertainment and joy straightaway since the narrator said his first word, but I can't deny that the more your inventory grows the richer your experience will become.

I also COMPLETELY DISAGREE WITH THE WALKING SIMULATOR MEME! At no point during this game you're simulating any of your typical walks, unless of course you meet sinister creatures, futuristic terrorists or other obstacles during your everyday walks and you need to avoid/fight them whilst managing your inventory tactically! Also, you don't even walk. Precisely, during your connection quests you jog, drive, ride, skate, etc. instead!

Suggestion for players: make sure that DLSS is on, and that the latest graphic drivers have been downloaded. No, Denuvo anti-piracy system is not causing any problem whatsoever, unlike what was assumed by some nonsensical rumors.

PROS:
+ Jaw-dropping details!
+ Kojima's genius and humour are back!
+ Induces a natural urge to explore its immense beauty!
+ Unique and genre-defying gameplay mechanics and meta-games.
+ The asynchronous multiplayer feels organic and brilliant.
+ Decently satisfying combat system.
+ Photo mode is indescribably fun!
+ You interact with a non-stop flow of video poetry.
+ Mesmerising direction and fantastic acting performances!
+ Touching and mind-bending philosophy.
+ Memorable soundtrack.

CONS:
- The interface may feel intimidating at first.
- This title more than any other should become cross-play at some point.
- Combat may be repetitive
- We should be able to change the colour of the writing for the "Tomorrow is in your hands" frame in photo mode.
- The story ends, unfortunately!

SCORE: 10 / 10.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Wow... What a ride that was. I played the game on very hard for the challenge and it was indeed very challenging. The game made me wanna quit at times but I definitely was never going to lower it. It was worth playing on very hard I felt like you only get the whole experience playing it on that. It made it felt even more rewarding too, you can definitely go through the whole game without fighting except for the parts where you have no choice but to, there are many of those parts in the game.

The game is very long and beautiful visually with well written dialogue and a heartwarming story. The game at times made me upset with its crazy challenges it threw my way and definitely simulated the way it would feel to walk those miles in real life. At many points in the game I wanted to quit probably cause i played on hard but I kept going and it paid off.

The vehicles are a huge shortcut, you can kinda get away with it even when you're not supposed to but a lot of the time the game stops you in tracks.

At times of peace walking there comes a roller coaster of emotions, this game made me tear up at times, frustrated at times but most of the time calm. I didn't lose interest I just wanted to keep going, the game kept me engaged at all times even it rips your progress away. When you have to start from zero you just pick up and go again.

Overall a great game, a different experience that everyone should at least try, maybe not on very hard cause it does get very frustrating. Lastly, you're not alone in this game because there are other players like you that will help you as you help them along the way. GLHF

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death Stranding is best when it shuts up. Being a game by Metal Gear Solid creator Hideo Kojima, it's naturally filled with bizarre characters, lengthy screeds of exposition, and indulgent cutscenes. But it's in the long, quiet stretches between all this, when it's just you hiking alone across a stark, haunting post-apocalyptic wilderness, where it really shines. In these moments, Death Stranding is quite unlike anything I've ever experienced in a game—or any other medium for that matter.

this game is like nothing i have ever played before, 90% of your time is spent delivering cargo which is either given to progress the story or given to better relations with settlements or lost cargo you find out in the world to earn you more likes! thats it, sounds boring after all this game is advertised as a walking sim and a walking sim it is! but still theres something thats got me glued to this and im loving every bit of it, the world traversal is simple yet complicated, staying up right while trying to shift a tower of cargo on your back over miles of uneven landscape is an almost mini game in itself!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Well firstly, to all the people who call this marvellous piece of artistry, a walking simulator. You guys are right. But there are a few things you should know before you keep shaming this title. 
1)This 'walking simulator' is one of the best looking and playing game that has ever been made.
2)The weirdness , the eerieness and sheer tensed moments of these invisible creatures hunting for you whil you're delivering packages is what keeps me gripped, and will keep you too.
3)This game is genre-defying. Yep. You can't put this in any category that right, and this is the best part. You are experiencing something which is new and new sought before. 
4)I'm sure most of us all have played a lot of other next gen games. This is the epitome.
5)It's always fun to play a game which has new meanings and explores things that we never had thought of, that is what Mr. Hideo Kohima has done here brilliantly.
6)KOJIMA IS AWESOME. PERIOD.
7)NORMAN REEDUS IS DROOL-WORTHY
8)If these points still aren't enough. Dunno how many will.

Finally, yes this game is sometimes a bit clumsy and monotonous, but I assure you that you'll find interest if you try a bit to understand what's going on as the game answers your curiosities as it unfolds itself.
Not to mention how beautiful this game looks and how well optimised this is. Didn't experience frame drops.

So, before you go on terming this a walking sim,
I want you start this title and WALK this true

9.999999/10... Just cuz that price tag put a hole in my wallet:)
But nvm I'm IMPRESSED with my purchase :3

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Daryl survived the zombie apocalypse and met Guillermo del Toro in a Kojima production.

Baby-sitting simulator. Hiking simulator. Uber Eats simulator.

A mind-blowing audiovisual experience, and another Kojima's masterpiece! A literal walking simulator with a mysterious plot, and the perfect game for 2020.

If you ever enjoyed wandering around through Skyrim's landscapes, you will enjoy this game. Its gameplay loop is really relaxing and engaging.

This game is wonderfully optimized and looks fantastic.

Norman Reedus is the perfect videogame protagonist here, full of odd charisma, and incredibly represented by the game photorealistic graphics.

If you like virtual tourism in a videogame in a wonderfully weird story, try out this game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: awsome game

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hideo Kojima is BACK!

Death Stranding has guns... Death Stranding has gadgets... Death Stranding has an online feature that allows the sharing of tools, structures and items to make the trek across America easier for you and your fellow online Porters. Weapons and equipment, as typical with a Kojima game, are earned slowly over time. OSP! On-Site Procurement baby!

In a nutshell, if you boil down Death Stranding to it's elements, it is the natural evolution of Kojima gameplay. A thread started with the Metal Gear Portable games (bite sized missions, semi-open world) that was perfected with Metal Gear Solid 5 and now distilled into a totally different concept, but that core Metal Gear gameplay is there with a twist... you're really not going to want to kill anybody, stealth is more important as is non-lethal means of disabling opponents. Or you get the Big Badda Boom. Big Badda Boom is bad. 

Kojima's trademark humor is also back; urination; trippy babies; quirky easter eggs that reward the player for exploration and odd distractions like being able to play in the mirror and take a dump.

Like with Kojima's Metal Gear series, he has a story and message to tell... but what critics that complain seem to not appreciate is that you have a sandbox, where you can ignore missions and do zany things, engage in combat, torment and torture foes just like MGS. 

The package delivery is a barrier that many won't overcome, but if you do - you get a massive open playground where you can put ziplines anywhere, try to climb the highest mountain and slowly help to reconnect America whether she deserves it or not. [Sam is of the opinion not...]

You will encounter a myriad of pop culture references, a few nods to his former franchise at Konami, and get to experience some of Kojima's music, toy and automobile fetishes he believes you should know about.

I played this game on PS4 to completion, and still returned back to it time and time again to revisit earlier regions from the game, build and repair structures and help out other Porters by delivering their lost packages. I am hoping on PC, Death Stranding sees the same level of community cooperation that was present on the PS4... it is there when the game really shines.

Take for example the mid-way point. You will go into treacherous ice-capped mountains and hiking it is a chore and then some. Hell, the character you play, Sam Porter Bridges*, will even utter a "Damn it!" or other profanity and complain about the hike as well. In each region you can build structures like zip-lines and bridges, to make the trek easier, but you are capped how many items you can place. The struggle is real but... through support of the online porters, like yourself if you get the game, a network of zip-lines, bridges and watchtowers will emerge to compliment and support your own structural investments, allowing in many regions for you to travel from base to base through the air by zip-line which is absolutely exhilarating  as you ascend to mountain crests and descend through valleys.

There are vehicles. Some truly goosebump generating moments and until you get an arsenal of the right weapons, sketchy lunatics and scary monsters you'll have to avoid until you reach "Snake" status. 

So what are you waiting for Porters? The PS4 community is fine so don't need me there anymore... 
LET'S RECONNECT AMERICA TOGETHER ON PC!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Straight up, this game will not be for everybody. 

Death Stranding is a slow-burn title, which will have you walking across a disconnected, but gorgeous America, in aim to bring the country together again. Kojima took quite the gamble with Death Stranding, as a chunk of players could easily see this game as too slow to get into, as there's no other title out there that can compare to this. As it is, Death Stranding is a completely unique action game, with social elements to allow players to work together to rebuild highways, bridges, watchtowers and so much more. There is no feeling like it when you are rewarded with likes from something you have built, knowing it has aided another player on their journey.

The tasks are quite repetitive, as you'll be travelling from point A to B for most of the game, but that's what you're signing up for when you buy this. With quite a simplistic melee system, combat is never really a problem, whether that be fighting some mules or a boss, combat has never come across as a challenge for me. However, Kojima delivers a truly breathtaking world, with a storyline you'll be grasping at straws to understand, but its all part of the fun watching it all unfold and slowly understanding the lore behind the game. I've loved my time with the game so far and cannot wait to see what else is in store with future Kojima Productions titles.

Keep On Keeping On

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Let me start by saying that I honestly did not think this game was for me. I passed it on the PlayStation 4 for that exact reason. I saw some reviews, some gameplay, but it just did not entice me. Fast forward to now, when I saw that this was being released on steam I was excited for a few reasons. The first being that a Sony exclusive was making its way to the PC, And I see hoping that with future releases like horizon Zero dawn. I'm hoping the trend continues with games like God of War, Spiderman, uncharted, etc. I also thought to myself that Bing on PC would be the best version of this game. I've enjoyed previous Kojima games like Metal Gear Solid, and of course the silent Hills, So I thought I should support Sony bringing their games to PC and give this a try. Of course that was after I read a review for the PC version which I believe was dead on And I quote “this is a brilliant game, if it would just shut up ”. The story so far is amazing, and it completely pulls you in To the life of your character. What I take from that review is because the whole open world part of just exploring and working your way from one location to the next is brilliant. The graphics are phenomenal, the soundtrack is great, and the performance is hands down. I thought to myself if I did not like it, at least I could get a refund through steam, my first play session Lasted about five hours, but felt like 2 hours. So much for my refund but as of today I am glad that I have this game. I have not had a game that made me want to play in a while. Even though I am still early in the game, I would highly recommend this. Once I beat it, if I feel differently, I will edit this review.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
First Time playing the game skipped it on PS4 and waited for the PC release to drop.


Death Stranding starts off kinda of slow and very confusing, everything started coming together a bit more in Chapter 2 Story wise to the point of kind of starting to understand the story bit by bit, Also the Gameplay starts off pretty slow too but again once in Chapter 2 and picking up Order Tasks yourself the gameplay side of things also opens up quite a bit more making it more enjoyable overall. It Took about 2-3 Hours for the game to really open up and become fun. i was very nervous with Death Stranding because it was so slow to get going i was very on the fence of refunding it but now im very happy that i made the choice to play just that little bit extra past the return window and am very happy with my choice to keep Death Stranding.


The Graphics in this game are jaw dropping, the world looks beautiful and is quite nice to just stop and take a look around this beautiful game world Kojima has made for us, the game has no issues at all running in 2560x1440p (2K) @144FPS or higher. i am currently playing the game with a Ryzen 9 3950X and RTX 2080 Super, 32GB of DDR4 3600MHz Ram and Installed on an M.2NVMe SSD with all setting maxed out and DLSS turned on.

ALSO PS. i saw many people on reddit saying before the game was out that it would probably be better to play with an Xbox/PS4 Controller and KB+M would be unplayable, follwing this suggestion i played the first hour or so using an Xbox Controller before giving my KB+M a chance and i would say if the game feel a bit clunky and like there is a bit of confusion and clunkiness to the game to give KB+M a shot as it feels so much better to me personally. i can understand why people thought it would be a mess on KB+M like Dark Souls was but somehow the developers have Made the KB+M controls perfectly  atleast for me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I really enjoyed this game. If you look at the reviews you'll notice a pattern: most negative reviews have little hours and the people who pressed past the first little bit really liked the game. Most people's gripe with the game is that it's a walking simulator. In most cases you only have to walk somewhere once. After that, the game gives you tools so that you don't have to make the trip back by foot and you can actually get around pretty fast. I actually enjoyed the walking because the scenery was so good. It was pretty fun plotting routes and feeling like a mountain climber.

The game really gets you hooked on the story too. It's incredibly mysterious and it all comes together at the end. 

My tip: play to the community aspect of the game. Help build infrastructure for yourself and others and the game will be a lot more fun.

Also the game ran incredibly on max settings with DLSS 2. Never really had any bugs except a memory access violation crash that happened maybe three times in my entire playthrough

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game has been getting some negative reviews for being tedious and repetitive. well, what do you expect?
If you enjoy slow games with good storylines like Nier automata or Witcher 3 which rewards you for exploration then, sit back, immerse yourself in a whole wide world of interesting stuff. Try to understand the beauty behind the exploration and slow-paced adventure walking simulator. the main terrifying thing is the death mechanic. You literally leave a CRATER as a mark of shame.It starts off strong and gets repetitive eventually but, after a while the plot kicks in and boom. you are having a hell of a time. The only thing that bugs me is the lack of music player outside of private room. I mean, why? sure, the music does play from time to time. but, it's not enough and i want to traverse the landscape with favorite tracks from the game. not some pre-set tracks for specific locations. also the game is hell of lot easier to backtrack, because there is always a ladder or rope or gaint f-ing roads already bulit by some friendly Joe.

SO, don't expect intense action like Metal gear solid, relax and immerse yourself in this wonderful yet convoluted storyline

Plot : 10/10 (it's kojima damnit)
Gameplay : 7/10
Bugs: 7/10 (i encountered a few bugs which crashed the game)
Graphics 9/10 (eye-candy)
Overall: 8.2/10 had FUN!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game... is pretty awesome.

But maybe only if you are into weird sci-fi stories, traversing icelandic landscapes, sneaking around what can only be described as pure death and sometimes being completely freaked out by what's happening around you.

As a sci-fi lover of anything weird this game has some of the best story and lore I have played in a long time.
At some point I was so immersed in the story that I was just talking to myself about the whole SNAFU and my GF got freaked out and asked if everything was okay.
I was okay, the main character had some shit to process tho.

As an outdoorsman this game has some shockingly horrific imagery of the dystopia you find yourself in. But also has some of the best scenery out there (if you like the green/rocky parts of iceland).
Being completely free to pick your own route, placing ladders and ropes for yourself AND others gives this game a unique gameplay.

As a lover of doing everything sneaky when given the opportunity, this game just adds another level. Yes you can sneak around, but what if you can't even see the enemy? Just scary shit right there.

My only negative point for this game is the BB's. You straight up have an aborted fetus strapped to your chest!
While to me this is only a bit mixed and just adds more to get freaked out about.
This can be a VERY sensitive subject for other potential players. So far it seems to play a pretty important role but I wish there was an option to replace it with a brain in a jar and have some cut scenes and stories edited differently.

All out it's already one of my favorite games. But like others have said, it's really not for everyone.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Never thought I would enjoy a game where I played as a mailman. 

Lore/Story/Environment are all amazing and very well thought out. 
I love when games fuse mythology into there stories! 

If you want something with amazing story and exploration and shock and awe moments honestly grab it. 
The game can be peaceful one second and then running for your life the next while trying to maintain your course and take care of your equipment and packages.

The way the world builds around you, and the community places things that will most defiantly help you. It give you a feeling your not alone in your struggle trying to reconnect everyone together. 

This is going to sound mad but this game reminds me of a A plagues tale in the aspect of world building and watching how everything is unfolding around you and it's all starting to fall into place. While both these games lack "combat" I still cant help but absolutely love them and keep wanting to know more about this world and what is going on.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It is possible to run this game in different resolutions.  Just need a hex editor and a quick google search.  Amazing in 32:9!

1. Open <path-to-game>\ds.exe in a hex editor (e.g. HxD).
2. Search for 55 55 15 40 as hex.
3. Replace it with 26 B4 17 40 (for 2560x1080) or any other aspect ratio in hex.
4. Save the changes.
5 .Run the game and select the 21:9 aspect ratio in the Graphics settings menu.

https://mh-nexus.de/en/hxd/ <-- Hex Editor
https://www.wsgf.org/article/common-hex-values <-- Common HEX Values

Not mine just copying here to help.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Game looks fantastic, but there is no option to turn off or even turn DOWN the music volume.  I have hearing damage and this makes it impossible for me to hear all the other sound details due to the loud music.

EDIT: Since this generated some discussion, I just want to clear some things up. The issue I had with this game is not the *overall* volume (since that can be easily adjusted), it is the volume of the music only making it difficult for me to distinguish other sounds. This is due to how my hearing response is defective in certain frequency ranges, causing a kind of compression effect (its hard to explain). I have no issue with the music itself - it sounds great in fact, and I do understand it is part of the overall artistic vision of the game. I do absolutely intend to purchase this game again once the music volume slider is available.
developer_response: Hi - Thanks for bringing this to my attention. Noted and feedback will be passed on.

Beyond that, the story seems surprisingly interesting--probably my favorite Kojima story since Metal Gear Solid 3.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hideo Kojima make a Hideo Kojima game. So I'm in.
You probably have to be a certain type of person to appreciate this game I guess.
It's slow, it's brooding and it's not call of duty. so it's different gameplay. And it's good at being different gameplay.
However it has some seriously fucked flaws. 9 hours in, and twice TWICE have I been fucked by objectives that weren't as clear as they should have been. I have literally wasted 3 hours of my life now running back to pick up something the game didn't EXPLICITLY make clear I HAD to pick up. This is a chill game, so it takes a chill (read: LONG) time to do anything. when critical-game-progressing objectives are so un-obvious that you can leave the base, spend the amount of time required to complete the mission 3 times over but arrive at the destination without the critical cargo and be just told to go all the way back, pick it up and do it all again twice over...
well that's quitting time, I'm a patient man but fuck right off with that shit. makes you just want to go play some cod. I'll be back at it tomorrow but was looking forward to playing the game for 30 hours straight after downloading.

still great game just, be warned.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death Stranding is a fantastic Kojima game!  Loved it on PS4 and even more so on the PC!  It is PC eye-candy for sure.  Not sure why some people are complaining about issues as I haven't experienced a single one - then again I am playing it on an i7-9900k with two 2080 Ti's in NVlink and 64GB RAM.  A lot of the complaints about the walking simulator I believe are from people just starting out who haven't gotten far enough for the upgrades.  The game gets better and better and never stops until it's over.  Couldn't think of a better game to play when stuck at home during quarantine.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Let me open this review with one of the earliest and best quotes, one that defines the start, the end and the main point of our journey; 
"If you were a spy on a mission, you would have failed, but you're not, so be proud of these tracks, they're proof you existed." 

I've never played such a brilliant piece of art, it made me cry, laugh and smile way more than anything before. 
The game creates such connection between the player and the characters hundred times deeper than any other movie or game. You'll be given a duty, how you act across the path is up to you, creating bonds and not only with in-game characters, but also with random players you'll come across on your journey, and trust me when I say that I've lost the count on how many times those players that I've never seen, but only their traces, saved my life and pushed me up, specially during boss fights, so for those 1.418 players, my deepest thanks to all of you <3

If you want a different game, still a brilliant one, give Death stranding a chance. 
I would give Death stranding a solid and naked 9/10.
Death stranding felt almost perfect, but as you may know perfection is not a thing we human beings can accomplish, it gets even harder when it is based on the individual point of view of every person, but I think a 9 is a pretty fair number for such a masterpiece.

Go steal your dad's credit card and buy Death stranding, enjoy the game, take it easy, explore the remains of America and last but non less, you may find out a bit of yourself, when the game gives you the choices, the easy way or the hard way, with all his consequences.

Thanks for your time, take care <3.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Much of this game is slower paced, so it isn't for everyone. However, if you're looking for an engaging story, interesting gameplay mechanics, and great graphics, you might enjoy this.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
DEATH STRANDING is an action/adventure game from Hideo Kojima that pushes the limits on modern day AAA titles. Without even mentioning the superb story and cast, the gameplay and mechanics are newly innovated and something that I've never seen anything like before. 

The main gameplay stems from the idea that you are a porter in a world that needs deliverymen now more than ever, so yes holding and delivering cargo are big parts of this game, but are in no way the only things to focus on. The game makes your objective of delivering cargo challenging by putting you in rough environments and forcing you to adapt to your terrain as you walk, while also having to deal with different enemies that can have negative consequences to your world if you interact with them in certain ways. It's hard to get into specifics of these mechanics without giving away spoilers, but I would highly recommend experiencing this game first-hand without being spoiled previously to playing. 

The world and story of DEATH STRANDING are incredible and unique. I played the game on PS4 when it originally released and completed it with platinum trophy for context of this review. The story and lore kept making me want to find out more and more to what happened to the world and the characters you interact with. This game, like many others, has lots of readable material that can give you more information and insight to the lore of the game. The thing that stands out for DS is that it is insanely well done and interesting. This is one of the only games, if not the only one, where I actually read every piece of in-game text it gave me. The story is pretty complex, and it starts you out without really knowing much, but the more you play and learn about the game and characters the more invested you get. The characters and the world feel alive, almost like they really do exist. This game made me laugh, cry, shout, and feel a full range of emotions.

Look, I can't say enough good things about this game. I've yet to mention the score and soundtrack which both perfectly represent the game and are amazing on their own. Even now, just thinking about the game I have goosebumps. DEATH STRANDING is easily on my personal top-5 games of all time list, and honestly is probably number one. On a personal note, I find it pretty difficult to express myself sometimes, and if you look at the reviews on my profile none of them are nearly as extensive as this one, so that alone should tell you all you need to know about this game. If you are on the fence about this game, or are looking for a new single player game to sink a lot of time into, please give this game a try. At the very least watch a playthrough on YouTube. 

Thanks for reading if you made it this far.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is a very fresh and interesting game for those who like it - be warned, it is very much story driven and gameplay is of a slower pace than many other games, with a focus on planning and exploration. You may see it as a walking simulator, and I won't disagree with you, but you should bare in mind that means walking is not as simple as pushing W or a analog stick forward, there is more nuance to movement in this game than most others out there.

I would like to write about the various mechanics and things but honestly there is so much I don't think I can do it justice. To summarise, you are primarily going from one point to another, and you have to figure what equipment you need and the route you need to take. You have 3 main obstacles. The landscape itself (ie. mountains, rocky outcrops, weather), BTs (ghostly like creatures which you cannot ordinarily see, and have limited equipment to deal with) and MULES (humans hostile to those who carry parcels amusingly enough... likewise limited equipment to deal with them).

The game starts out very simple, Sam is very vulnerable and does not have much to help him. As the game progresses you gain access to alsorts of gear, such as the ability to build bridges, guns that can help you fight MULES or BTs, exoskeletons to name a few things I've unlocked so far. Alot of the fun in this game apart from the traversing new areas is unlocking new things to help you. It should also be noted due to the nature of the game's multiplayer, although singleplayer and you will never meet another player, objects players build can appear in your world. So for example making a return trip you may find a vehicle a player has left, or a bridge they made to cross a river that you would of had to navigate over yourself.

It's hard to really do the game justice with a review for me, I think if any of this sounds remotely interesting you should at least try it and see if you like it. As I said at the beginning of the review, I think this game has a niche audience, so I don't think it's for everyone. I certainly do enjoy it and find it relaxing however, so it's a definite recommended from me.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Finally, an AAA-quality game with a level of originality only indie devs dare risk.  Tons of opportunities to play the game as a sandbox and set your own goals.  My favorite type of co-op, where you work together to achieve common goal while not having to directly talk to or interact with anyone.  The common goals, creating roads for example, have a real impact on the world and real benefits.  Great acting and, as a father, I found the main storyline incredible.  I watched a full playthrough of the game when it released on PS4, but I'm still having great fun with the game.  At about one-third the way through the chapters, I'm already at 52 hours played.  Taking my time and enjoying the ride.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
So after finishing the game and doing a few premium delivery side order on Very Hard difficulty (How it meant to be played IMO) , what do I feel about this game. To me Death Stranding is a very interesting conceptual piece but sadly the writing is not that good although the delivery of it is amazing. [spoiler] pun not intended [/spoiler] Now is this game a masterpiece or a boring pretentious drivel from Kojima, the answer is both to me. There are some very psuedo-philosophy and basic Spiritualism in the game narrative that i found very jarring to listen. But the last few chapter is well presented in that aspect. Presentation is what this game narrative excels at not writing. It's definitely well acted by Norman Reedus and the other cast even though sometimes he sound death inside in some particular scene but that's just Sam character in the early chapters. I definitely like his character progression although not very memorable it serves the narrative pretty well. [spoiler] Kinda bothered though how all the game questions answered in the last few chapters which is just basically the Bridges member info dumping you everything and the true meaning of the game. Definitely would prefer a much more slow ease of the whole lore and all [/spoiler] The logs and messages that you get as you play is an interesting read and some have a "political message" but very contained to it's own narration and doesn't really gives much extra to the main narrative.

Now lets talk about the Gameplay, it is exactly as the box describe you bring stuff from A to Point B. But, of course with an interesting depth to it all, you can just yes technically just take the boring route of safe chasm and roads which makes the whole thing monotonous, but you can also do it like i do turning the game into a Map Based puzzle game where i find the most fastest route and arguably the most fun to do. The online components of it actually serve the narrative pretty well and i quite like the seamlessness of it, although it does make the game quite easy because of all the zip lines and generator present in my particular server. The gameplay is not for everyone is true this game is the definition of a slow burner the first few hours are and is objectively boring slog cause it's basically a drawn out on rail tutorial. After that whole long prologue, the game open up and you have a slew of gadgets and weapon that can even turn you running around and jumping everything using an exo skeleton and hauling refrigerator stacked goods.

Since this is a port of course you have to talk about how well does it run in PC, much like MGS V port this game runs flawlessly even with my none RTX Graphic Card on very high. The game barely have any hickups at all although there are some frame dips and I also crash two times out of the 40 Hours i spent playing as of writing. The game runs and looks better than on the PS4 Pro who would have thunk?

The game is an amazing ride, a breath of fresh air on open world games. It is far from perfect but for what it is and I damn fing enjoyed it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
pros:
.) amazing nature graphics. seriously astonishing
.) fantastic soundtrack, although you will barely ever hear it
.) interesting mechanics while hiking/delivering packages. it's surprisingly fun to just wander around and take in the beautiful environment
.) building bridges, placing generators or ladders for other players is really cool. often you will benefit from other players going the extra mile to make your life a little easier. it feels quite rewarding to give back to the community by helping them too

cons:
.) combat blows. melee is the worst thing since moldy bread.
.) you barely get to hear the soundtrack
.) invisible enemies sound horror inducing on paper but translate poorly into this game. it takes away 100% of the fun of charting a route only to learn that it's not only difficult to navigate but also littered with invisible enemies that will ruin your packages and annoy you. it's not horror, it's not fear inducing, it's just very very annoying.
.) the human models are beyond uncanny. don't get me wrong, it's really interesting how much work was put into it and they look almost perfect, but something is just so off about them.
.) character names are the silliest thing ever. actually feels like a very young child thought them up. impossible to take anyone called "die-hard-man" serious.
.) way too much redundant, terrible dialogue. you will frequently hear the same explanations from up to four different npcs following each other immediately. I REALLY understood that unlocking new areas will allow me to craft new gear the first time, thank you. (by far not the only example, sadly)
.) product placement. this might sound like a small thing but it's not only immersion breaking but also extremely stupid. almost every person on the planet has died but by some kind of miracle the monster energy factories survived and somehow managed to not only distribute pristine cans throughout the planet but also create water flasks that turn toxic rain into monster energy. not even a joke, this is a mechanic. every sip you take to replenish stamina reminds you that you're drinking monster energy. many cutscenes have carefully picked camera angles to show monster energy cans. it's just really stupid.
.) arbitrarily chosen "skip" functionality in scenes. sometimes a scene can be skipped only to see the exact same cutscene a minute later, this time it's unskippable though.
.) annoying pins from other players. idk if you can turn that off, I haven't bothered to check. it's nothing gamebreaking, it's just annoying to see dozens of smiley-emote-pins littered around the map while you're trying to escape from a soul-eating, invisible, umbilical-cord-tethered angel monster.
.) weird nature sometimes. it's established quite early that the exact route you have to take has been traveled by a convoy of heavy machinery, armored vehicles and infantry. yet sometimes there is no possible path with a small bike, forcing you to go on foot. I don't mind going on foot sometimes but I do mind this to not make any sense whatsoever

from what I could tell so far, the story was interesting enough and extremely out-there. very daring and pretty cool actually. sadly I don't feel like continuing since the rest is just kind of "egh".

if you REALLY want to try it out, wait for a sale. I'd kinda prefer to refund it.

EDIT: apparently the frustration in the earlier stages of the game are intentional and it gets much better later on. apparently it's done so you feel the frustration and get to experience as things get easier with practice. I will likely get myself back into it to see if this is true.
if it is, I would probably still not recommend it because I absolutely hate this concept. things should get easier by you becoming better at the game and forcing frustration to only alleviate it later on is like punching you in the gut really hard because "it will feel real nice once the pain subsides"
it's not a rewarding concept.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I had watched a lot of content creators talking about how they disliked this game on PS4 launch and so I avoided it. After playing it for myself on the PC release, I am enjoying it. The asynchronous multiplayer is something I find very interesting and I like looking for creations from players that I recognize throughout my journey. 

The mechanics of the gameplay I have experienced so far (the traveling, structure creation and maintenance, and cargo management) feel great. There are a few weird spots where you feel like you should be climbing on a rock or you want to move a rope you are climbing on and the game takes a second to understand what you're doing, but it never gets to the point of "bugginess." I have not experienced much of the combat, but it seems that the game lets you play to avoid combat if you want to and that is my plan for the time being. 

I am finding the story interesting, and it drives me to want to play more of the main story missions. I haven't progressed enough to see the end of the game but with it being a Kojima game, my expectations are that it is going to be an elusive story with lots of extra reading required. 

This seems to be an amazing port as well. My game has run smoothly without any issues at all. For the issues that I have read from other users, Steam and the Death Stranding folks are issuing patches regularly, including beta patches, to address small issues on hardware such as Ultra Wide displays and controller inputs.

Bottom line: This game has already been on sale on PS4, and it will be on sale on Steam at some point in the future. I wanted to play this game right now and I wanted it on my PC, so I bought it at full price and I'm happy with my purchase. If you are on the fence at all, I would snag this the next time you want a lot of hours in a great game while something is on your second screen and it's $40.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Well after playing more, I will say the best part of this game is to help other players deliver / build. The whole game encourages you to do this.

Yes it sounds silly at first, but now I understand why I feel satisfied even though this game's task structure is simple..
I will give my kudo to Hideo Kojima for this.
I think if you have warm heart and like to help other people in real life, you will probably like this game.

------

I will be honest: this game's story telling is not as good as some other (good) games. If you are looking for something like TLOU1 or GTA5 (or MGS), you may be disappointed.

But [b]to me[/b] it is fun to play (mostly because of the details in the game, and the different style and design of the game compared to others)

I think I will recommend this game to:
- the ones who like Hideo Kojima's works
- the ones who like Japanese-made games
- the ones who like cryptic stories
- the ones who like in-game jokes and references
- the ones who like finding details in game
- the ones who like relaxing in game
- the ones who just want to try something different
- [b]the ones who have warm hearts[/b]

Basically this game has:
- Hideo Kojima's style and feeling
- Nice scenery and good taste of music (traditional)
- Superb internationalization & localization
- Looks boring but somewhat fun (and satisfied) gameplay
- A cryptic but still interesting settings

Note about gameplay: A lot of people feel this game's boring when they watch others playing, but somehow people who played it feel it still fun enough. My take on this is that this game's delivery missions and tasks are all built around [b]"helping people", "making connection with people"[/b]. All the interactions are from this single type of activities. [b]It's kinda like the real world -- it is not quite satisfied (and fun) to just watch someone helping others all the time, but you will feel satisfied and meaningful if you do the helping by yourself.[/b]
The point of this game is that you "play" it, not trying to get something from it (and you shouldn't rely on games to "educate" someone anyways).

Also, this game is not like Call of Duty, which you can just rush to the target and make quick kills. It's quite slow-paced. I think it is really good for relaxing.
(But for all the character animations, it grasps the pace, looks natural, but is not making too long to annoy players)

--------

Personally, I treat this game as a "donation" to Hideo Kojima. I actually bought 3 copies (1 PC, 2 PS4 in US and Japan) and have played PS4 version before. It's not the best game I have played (even not as good as the previous Kojima's works), but I don't really care that much -- This is the first game Kojima was kicked out of [strike]KONAMI[/strike]KONASHIT. I understand how hard it is to make a game in such a situation ([b]in Japan[/b]). I even think he knows he cannot create another MGS from nothing, so he just chose a simple concept and polished that. If it was me as a game designer in such a situation I would probably do the same thing.

To me, I recognize him and his works in my heart, so I 'm fully aware, and willing to donate some of my money to him and his team just for doing things they like to do.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Spoiler free.

Love it so far (~33 hours in) but it's definitely not a game for a broader range of people.

If you've played Hideo Kojimas's earlier games such as the Metal Gear series you kind of know what kind of complexity the story and gameplay will offer. And also at the same time what kind of humor and easter eggs are involved.

Graphics:
Awesome! Great attention to smaller details. The facial animations can sometimes seem a bit stiff but the whole game is beautifully made.

Story:
Complex but good, although maybe a bit far out there for many people.

Gameplay:
Ok, how the hell do you say this in a good way? You deliver packages. And it's somehow fun and engaging.
And also you hide from ghosts.
No but seriously, the gameplay loop seems pretty lame the first hours but it grows steadily and you unlock loads of accessories and stuff along the way, and it's done in a smooth fashion to blend nicely with the story.
You should not buy this and expect an action game. There is action and excitement, but the major gameplay and feeling is more about travelling and managing to get where you want with as little problems as possible along the way.

Controls:
I've only played with a controller so far and it felt natural from the first moment.
It's smooth but a some actions require many steps to pull off.

Issues:
I have only one issue. The Xbox One controller (and many other controllers according to forums) gives off unintended inputs. Quite annoying if it happens at a bad moment.
You can combat this by unplug/replug the controller while in game and not touch the KB/M after that. Seems to be something interfering between them.

Other:
The game goes a long way for you to to get the "feelings" of the moment. Love it.

Online:
it puts a big emphasis on helping each other out online, which is a pretty neat feauture. Although I'm one of those who often plays Single Player and offline, I really enjoy the MP-aspect here.
You never actually see the other players but you can help each other by delivering packages and using the items placed in the world. You can also remove these from your own world if you don't want them there but they actually make you feel connected to your fellow delivery comrades and the game also keeps telling you when people use your stuff, so you feel you're helping others too.
The game can be cruel, so it always feels nice to give and receive some help but so far I've never seen any kind of exploiting or something that ruins the game. The online aspect is very well made.

I bought it for the full price.
Knowing Hideo Kojima I knew it was a game I'd enjoy. I've not regretted it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Disable full screen optimization to eliminate stuttering completely. 

I just can't get enough.

The world is perfect for a post apocalyptic setting, the game was known by a lot of people as a post office guy delivering package, it's not really about that only, it's about connecting every region in the U.S together, you get to see throughout the game the utilities used by other players, it can help deliver the package from point A to point B, there a lot of obstacles along the way. One of them are BTs (Beached Things) and terrorists who are trying to keep the country separated. The combat is simple, you throw grenades and they give you a gun early in the game, the guns are extremely easy and fun to use and can help you against the terrorists. The world is beautiful and extremely detailed, the LOD is one of the best I've seen in a video game. The only problem with the graphics are the textures and tessellations they look ugly at some places, the anti aliasing also has some series issue. Other than that, the graphics and optimization are among the best in this generation, a lot of developers should take note, this is a new genre, there are a lot of games that requires you to either walk to mine, this one is only asking you to reach your destination without damaging the cargo completely. I can't imagine how long they've been working on making this game, I didn't have any glitches so far, I'm still in Episode 3 and loving the game so far. I was wrong, this game is great and worth buying for sure!!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: One of the best single player experiences I've ever had. The only thing that I think can be better in the near future is Cyberpunk. If you've ever enjoyed walking simulators, this is what a AAA version of one looks like and its enthralling.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Not for everyone. But definitely for me. 
Best way I can describe is that. You know in some videogames you just want to "go" like forget where just focus on the journey and not the destination?

The only game I can think of that is remotely similar is Spintires. This game is basically spintires, but instead of trucks going through mud it's you walking across mountains.

This game is a hiking game, and how you can conquer and domesticate the landscape.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Where to start.. As most have said this game IS NOT for everyone. It does start out slow. I will never fight anyone on that. If you want something that is non stop action the whole way through, keep moving on because you won't find that here. But if you want a truly unique story and wonderful voice acting. A game that has a gorgeous landscape that seems both lonesome and endless. This game could be up your alley. I have 16 hours in the game and I have only just begun to scratch the surface. This game has a nice balance of making you feel alone, yet connected to others playing the game. You will come across a well placed ladder that another player has left in their journey. When this happens, you can't help but appreciate the aid they have given from afar. You will be traveling along to your next destination when you hear and see the rain start to trickle down. This can only mean that BTs can not be far away. Your first encounter with them is one I will not forget. The ability to hold your breath in game when passing very close to them is a nice touch that adds to the heart pounding moments of just barley escaping. Heaven forbid one should grab you, this now starts a huge "Oh crap" moment when a much larger BT comes down from "The Beach" (very hard to explain what that is, but basically an in-between death world) and now you have to run for your life. If you can't tell, I am a big fan of this game and I am still discovering more beauty the world has to offer and the pain the story presents as Sam moves on. But you don't really "start" the game until chapter 3. Don't let anyone tell you it's "Just a walking simulator". That's like saying The Last of Us is "Just a sneaking game". Most that will give a review like that either haven't played it or haven't played it for more than an hour. Do yourself a favor and don't let your choice to try this game or not be determined by those that haven't really played it.  If you are completely unsure about this game, wait for it to go on sale. But I for one am glad I decided to pick it up and give it a fair try.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
when i bought a 60$ dollar game that everywhere i looked it said "BORING" i was preparing myself to expect a BORING game with just walking, and i got that walking, but this people dont realize that the actual fun of death stranding is the progresion system that it has, building the highways to help other players, going to MULEs bases and getting all their materials to build more stuff and to make deliveries better, just like Minecraft, get stuff to do that stuff better.

But thats not the only thing, the encounters with BTs are nerve wracking Hideo did a great job making those encounters excellent leaving you with a feeling of acomplishment that you survived.

it might be repetitive and times but its not repetitive just for being repetitive is more grindy then repetitive, also it keeps it fresh with every new "location" that you find theres no copy and paste actors all of them have original lines and all of them have a story to tell.

The world building of death stranding is something that no other game has you talk to so many people and all of them have their specific views on the Death Stranding.

If you are tired of the same fps game or you are looking for an experience you will remember for a long time, dont think about it and buy it. if you are just looking for a game that you dont want to put too much thought into and just "turn your brain off and play" you wont like this game. the messages that it gives are great and this is a game that i hope it shows more game designers to take risks and to not limit their creativity.

Sorry for any spelling mistakes.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
The End of the world, with only a few groups of humans left and you are one of the only ones who can keep them connected. 

That's what the game says, but it is so much more than that. It was a test on human nature. What are we willing to do when all is down and out. This game has an optimistic view of humanity's compassion in the face of uncertain odds, and how we all need to come together to be stronger than each indivitual. Personally I think it is great, I spend a ton of time while on deliveries contemplating this idea. 

Game play wise, you are a delivery man who needs to avoid theives and ghosts. This game is not for every one, it requires patience and care.
