title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Played fully through the game on PS4 and Once again on PC. The story here is unlike any other game ive played and though the Gameplay may not always be for everyone the story is a masterpiece. I can easily say that this game is a 9/10 for the story and soundtrack alone, the visuals really bring it all together though.

This game also creates a community between the players unlike any other game. Any of the items you place in the world can used by others that are connected to your character. The game also tells you when others utilize them. The one issue with this system is that you cant directly connect to your friends, which hopefully is added at somepoint.

The main issue that stops this game from being a 10/10 for me is the overall physics system. Most of the time it works well but when it comes to vehicles, i cannot overstate how much i hate them. The way that vehicles interact with the environment make it feel like they where an afterthought or at least under-developed. 

It would seem that a majority of the day one issues and crashes have been ironed out as well, on day one i really only had 2 crashes and after the first patch i have not crashed once.



well worth 60$ 
Overall:
10/10 story

9/10 gameplay (1 point off for the bad vehicle/physics interactions)

10/10 soundtrack

10/10 visuals

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I don't own a PS4 and i remember the controversy surrounding this game with critics acclaiming it and youtubers panning the game. I have to say at that time it did look boring. But i decided to start watching a playthrough to see the real meat and potatoes of the game. Needless to say the beginning of the game made me stop watching the playthrough because the story and music hooked me. 
     Flash forward to release day on pc i started watching PC reviews because PC ports are usually botched or poorly optimized. I mean i love Red Dead but it does not render very well. At least on my average pc (ryzen 5 2600, 16gb ddr4 ram, amd rx580 8gb vram) But i have to say this game set to very high does run at 60fps at 1920x1080 and i have been enjoying it immensely. 
     Yes, you are delivering packages. But it is more than walking around. You have to manage the weight, you have to pick your route, you have to decide if you can take a side delivery, and plan for finding lost cargo. There is a huge crafting factor where you can build buildings and rodes, steal trucks from mules, find a trike in the middle of nowhere, there is stealth and hiding when you get into an area of BT's, and much more. I will be honest though, that stuff starts around 10 hours in so there is a little bit of grinding at the first but if you enjoy Kojima storytelling you will enjoy this game.
     Again i can't believe how competent this port is and i have to commend 505 for doing such a good job. I have had no glitches, no pop in problems and its just refreshing that we (pc players) got a competent port.
     If you like Kojima games and are okay with a game that isn't 100% action all the time i think you will enjoy the atmosphere and storytelling that this game provides.

Play the game for an hour and a half, if you don't like it then refund it, there's a lot of sidequests in this game and if you like that sort of thing then go ahead, but if you're just testing out the game before refunding it, I would play as much main story as possible! title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It took me about 10 hours of game-play before this clicked. 
If you look at just the surface gameplay you have a postman simulator. 
But once you dig deeper into what Kojima is doing here this is unlike anything else out there. 

The feeling of building useful structures in remote locations so that another player's game will not be so fraught is unlike anything I have experienced in a game before. You suffer and you work and the benefits are the likes from other postmen.
The game continually rewards you for helping others. People are kind, complimentary and supportive. This makes you feel valued for completing what appear to be menial delivery tasks.

The story I have yet to comprehend but it is classic Kojima in it's melodrama, philosophical subtext and outright ridiculousness. 

The game is beautiful to look at with almost photo real vistas, has superb and odd performances from it's main cast. A really solid indie soundtrack and a hell of a lot of charm. 

A meditative transcendent work of art.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: If I could describe this game in one word it would be surreal. The story is insanely out there and so is the gameplay. Everything was so unique and the worldbuilding was so dense that it initially seemed confusing and overwhelming. Once you get into it though the game seems oddly engaging and addicting despite the gameplay boiling down to "Hiking Simulator 2020: Post-Apocalyptic Edition".

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Played this on PS4, returned on PC due to widescreen incompatible.  Unfortunately, Kojima's idea about bringing together players in altruism also brought with it a dark side:  anonymity.  The PC version is littered with political messages.  I dunno... most play games to get away from that stuff.  We won't solve it until we give up anonymity, unfortunately.

My advice is if you play, turn off network features and enjoy the countryside as your own.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Been super excited about it, and I am loving it. Some crashes I am experiencing haven't gotten solutions yet, or tells me in any way what's causing them, and how I can avoid them, but aside from that, I still love Death Stranding to bit. Looking forward to more of Hideo Kojima-San's work, now that he and company are free.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Graphics, Key remapping, Ambiance, Sound ... this game has it all.  For you to enjoy this game, you must be aware that there is a lot of cutscenes and if you enjoy the story as I do, you will enjoy them as they appear. On the side note;  I should mention that this game is more of an Apocalyptic Opera (with the Hideo Kojima signature) on the same trend of Mass Effect being a Space Opera kind of game. This is not an FPS nor a action game; even though there is a lot of tense moments , shootings and actions required to maintain a stress momentum, this is not the main goal of the game. 10 hours in and I can't wait to go on.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I won't review the game it's self since that's been done to death and we all know what it's about...or sort of... I don't know lol.  I'd rather review the PC performance and my experience so far.

You either love it or you hate it. I personally love it. I played it on PS4 and now on PC just to experience it again. This time with better graphics and better controls. I prefer m&kb over controller therefore i had a much easier time. If you're like me, you'll be please the controls work great. Minor bugs here and there but nothing major. My game has not crashed once in my 30 hours of game time. Graphics are phenomenal, no issues there, especially with an RTX card. Loading times almost no existent. 

In conclusion, if your pc can run it and the idea of connecting back a nation using your imagination, with a crazy Kojima written story, incredible gameplay and a vibrant beautiful world than this game is for you. If you have not played this game. Keep in mind, it takes a while to take off. It's not a game you should quit after 5 or even 10 hours. New things open up constantly and make your journey easier and much more fascinating. I recommend everyone play this game :) 

Specs:
2TB HDD
16GB RAM
intel i9 processor
Nvidia 2080 Super

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Difficult to classify this game. I've been gaming since the Commodore 64 days and have never seen or experienced any kind of game like this. Rarely do I watch cut-scenes in games and typically hit ESC or space to keep moving but with Death Stranding you will find yourself wanting to learn more and can't tear yourself away from the cut-scenes. If you are looking for plain shooter then you need to give this one a pass and if you are looking for something new/refreshing then DS is worth every penny. This haunting game will surely be never forgotten long after the end.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I like this game a lot, it's very unique and challenging. It's not for everyone, this game is a pain in the ass if you have 0 patience.  You have to take your time and think.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The world's best post apocalyptic delivery man simulator. I highly recommend it to anyone who fancies the idea of trekking through rough terrain while carrying heavy cargo, and avoiding ghosts and cargo junkies. It surprises me that such a niche concept got the funding it did, but it gives me hope that experimental titles such as Death Stranding will be made by more than just small indies and basement developers. It's not for everyone, but damn does it tickle my 'tisms in all the right ways.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I've been waiting for this game since the first trailer. It's divine

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] A Damn Good Walking Simulator [/h1]

I never thought that I'd ever play any simulator in my life as the genre never interested me. However, Death Stranding had a deep story that kept me engaged, characters who I wanted to see succeed, and a world I wanted to explore.

To my surprise, I found delivering cargo quite entertaining in many moments of the game. Sure, carrying fragile cargo and being limited to walking might suck, but the game doesn't force you to do that often and allows the player to have some action, be it with the BTs, MULEs (essentially bandits), or Cliff's encounters. Boss fights weren't too difficult but showed some amazing artistic design.

Graphics were amazing, animation looked fantastic (all thanks to the motion capture), and the lighting felt right. 

Overall, a great game to play if you love a deep story and an added bonus if you love the actors who star in it!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is quite unique as it is one of the few video games that is thought provoking and not predictable like 90% of video games made today. The mechanics are going to take time to get used too, in the start it will feel like a slog until you start to build up your reputation as a Deliverer.

On a visual perspective, it's just amazing to see the different areas that you get to explore, how detailed the environment is and this could be because I ran this with DLSS enabled but it's quite a spectacle to behold. 

Overall if you want a game that is going to challenge you both in thought and gameplay, then this game is for you. If you are only really into linear mcbangbang shooters that needs constant action to keep in the game, this won't be any fun for you. 9/10 From me, the only thing that keeps it from a 10 is their is some stuttering but with a patch or two it will be fixed.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I will update this review as I continue through the game.

I don’t generally write reviews on Steam, but this game has been exceptional so far in almost every regard and I feel it is worth the effort.  Many traditional forms of entertainment I feel are now stifled of creativity; cookie cut-out movies and movies are pumped out with absolutely no thread of originality in any of them. Death Stranding has the courage to be different and it is courage which will polarise people. There is criticism of this game online; some have described it as a ‘walking simulator’. I would argue that these people, whilst entitled to their opinion, fundamentally miss the point of this game. 

Death Stranding follows the character Sam as he helps to rebuild a broken nation by delivering vital supplies between outposts and cities. Herein lies a huge difference in how Death Stranding approaches the concept of ‘difficulty’; whereas there are mountains of games that pile on harder monsters with increasingly bigger health bars, or vast arrays of enemies that must be shot to death (interestingly, nobody claims that the Battlefield series is a ‘gun simulator’ because of this), Death Stranding places the very challenge of the game in the environment itself. The environment is tough; traversing this game is incredibly difficult for a whole host of reasons that I won’t list here. Other players can gradually make improvements to the environment in order to make it more accessible eg. by building bridges. In this way, Death Stranding achieves something which is quite rare in the gaming community – it promotes altruism. Your efforts to bring the various communities of a broken nation together also helps other players, as they in turn help you. Despite the bleak overtones of Death Stranding, the ability to literally ‘build bridges’ and come together gave me a sense of hope and purposefulness whilst playing this game - a poignant message in 2020. 

The difficulty placed in the environment makes challenging deliveries and progression (for example, access to the motorbike) all the more rewarding. Elsewhere, the game is absolutely stunning and the environment is beautiful. I love being on delivery and seeing a massive ridge ahead of me and thinking ‘how am I going to traverse that?’ or seeing a fast flowing river and thinking ‘how will I be able ford this?’. The vivacity of the environment interplays with the gameplay very well. The soundtrack is superb as well; when a song starts playing and you’re on delivery the game becomes almost meditative. It’s a fantastic experience. There are also some quirky features (eg. if you take a pee outside, a mushroom grows) which are a really nice touch.  

When I saw this become available on Steam, I’m not going to lie I gasped at the price tag. My expectations were extremely high because of that price tag. Let me say this – there is no video game that has ever been made, that is like this. I’m engrossed in every second of it so far. I can’t recommend this enough to anyone and everyone.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This is a really dumb premise. Carry heavy cargo around and climb around rugged mountainous areas? Really? This is a thing? It's gorgeous looking - but boring as hell. This is not what I expected. I was bored after about 5 minutes of actual gameplay. The story is kind of interesting - the world seems fleshed out and deep - but the minute you're back to running around carrying cargo and tipping over and falling down rock sides it's a total yawn fest. Missed opportunity here. Wow.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Truly mesmerizing gameplay and atmosphere marred by cringy writing and underutilized voice talent. The sense of progression, attention to detail and character agency is what keeps me coming back. I don't think i've ever seen a game handle forward momentum so well.

The interactions between Sam, Fragile, Deadman, Hartman, Amelie and the rest of the cast is a trial of patience. Every cutscene worth of exposition can usually be summed up in about a few sentences. I don't understand how you can have someone like Guillermo Del Toro of LOTR fame and Sam Lake of Alan Wake/Max Payne fame help with mo-cap but not in the script-writing department.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
To call this game tedious would be doing it a disservice, but it's a REALLY slow burn, at least for me. The game seems to relish in putting just [i]one[/i] more obstacle in your way throughout your journey, be it the package-eroding timefall, rough and steep terrain, delivery-crazed MULEs hellbent on taking your lunch money (and your cargo), and spooky ghosts that are only deterred by the bodily fluids of a man crazed enough to throw them around inside grenades. At times, Death Stranding is a metaphorical (and occasionally literal) uphill battle that takes me from an otherwise peaceful walking/jogging session to a tense, curse-riddled crawl while delivering 2-3x Sam's body weight. And yet, somehow, I still come out the other side feeling accomplished, if just a little. 

In my opinion, learning to finesse your way around the terrain, utilizing other players' signs and left-behind equipment, and generally taking a moment to plan and think ahead is an absolute necessity if you plan to enjoy Death Stranding- sprinting at a breakneck pace from one goal to the next is a surefire way to have a bad time. A lot of the fun for me in Death Stranding has admittedly been self-generated: I don't find much fun in being cornered in a timefall-drenched forest by BTs (those spooky ghosts) with little-to-no equipment to get me out, but I did find fun in planning, screwing up, and screaming my way out of the situation by the skin of my teeth. It's difficult to get a good feel for good tactics from the beginning, but with practice I've found my footing and have really started enjoying the game. 

A word of warning, however- as narrative-based as Death Stranding is, the first hour(s) are absolutely saturated in jargon, iffy character motivation, and generally awkward (arguably cringe-worthy) writing. There's a story buried inside Death Stranding, but it feels like peeling back a particularly strong onion, crying included (but that's just an allergic reaction).

tl;dr Death Stranding can be a real slog at times, and you've [i]really[/i] got to want the piecemeal rewards it gives. Casual, confusing, but strangely keeps me coming back for more.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Im not sure if i would tell you to pay for this game.   First off- the story (i think im about 1/2 through) has been bizarre, creative, and interesting.  However my issues are with the gameplay.  
At some points it feels more like the demo that the frostbite engine or AMD people would give you to showcase their graphics.  Everything is BEAUTIFUL, but the physics and gameplay are just off.  Furthermore, there is very little to let you know how the intricate gamplay actually works.  There are menus with 100s of hints (which is impossible to navigate productively) but none really tell you anything.  Its a shame someone spent all that time writing stuff but didnt actually tell us anything.   I want to know how my objects affect the multiverse.  I want to know which signs are getting hits.  Telling me Mr. XYZ liked "my sign" isnt really helpful.

Summary of issues
-The vehicle physics is waaay off.  
        *Its hard to use any jumps because you never know where you will land
        +cars/bikes get stuck too easily and there is no way to rock them out
-Button layout and menu progress is annoying and unnecessary 
     *you have to go through like 5 menus to get to the save game
      *layouts are not intuitive and one wrong click can undo all the 15 checkboxes you had to spend 5 mins setting up for 
          cargo management
-Combat feels like they started to add it but then got rushed and said "F" it lets just go with what we got. 
     *There is one combat key, "V" which is impossible to hit using normal awsd movement.  yes. i know i can remap it
     *the mouse left and right click are used for balance AND using weapons so you cant really manage both at once which is FRUSTRATING.
-Delivery of loads.
    *This i think is the most shameful thing they have done.  Every time you deliver a load you get a message from the client.  THis is just a random message. THey end up repeating after 2 or three runs and they, much of the time, say things that are totally out of context with the reality of the game.  If i just dropped off a load 2 seconds ago- Dont tell me how great it is to see me again like i have been gone forever.   This is one of the main parts of the game and since they thought it was acceptable to get rid of all the other normal game aspects- they needed to nail this. I were Kojima, I would be embarrassed by this.  It really seems lazy.



THere are many more little things that will start to bother you when you play this game.  WIth the absence of pretty much any action you will find little else to do but get annoyed at the things that dont work.    This would have served better as a movie than a videogame.  Its a shame,  with a little more combat and a couple of refinements this could have been an AWESOME game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
One of the best games I have played, that I find hard to recommend to anyone.

A world where you guide Norman Reedus and his fetus through a post apocalyptic North America.

A world where the cut scene camera is strangely obsessed with Normans naked body and his body fluids are way more important than they should be (I leave it to your imagination what grenades #2 are made from).

Follow a red dressed women who goes by at least four different names in a quest to reconnect cities across the country.

Get hunted by the particle of god who wants to end the world and lick peoples faces.

Live on a diet of Monster Energy (TM) and worms which grow from other players pee. They told you the multiplayer in this game is special, right?

Look at the beautiful landscape and try to find the route with the least amount of rocks to your next destination. And don't forget to take a couple of photos while you are on the way.

Meet many silly named people who will deliver (cringe worthy pun intended) hours of cringe worthy dialogue.

Brace yourself when you find out that the US has switched to the metric system.

This game is so weird and different that the experience alone is worth the price of admission. If you are tired of the same triple A rehashes again and again, this will feel like a breathe of fresh air.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hideo, you crazy bastard.  He's the master of taking super-weird realities and immersing you into them so deeply that it becomes commonplace for you. As I've been playing this game, my SO has been looking over my shoulder and completely blown away and confused by what they see.  Now that I'm into the game a bit, none of it seems out of place, but to an outsider the common reaction is WTF? 
That's fun and involving and the world is beautiful, but the game is much more than the world.  It's the relationship we build with other porters that makes the game fun and different for me. It's certainly not another MGS and as much as I miss that aspect of the action, this game is just more subtle (so far). 
I look forward to more time with Sam and I'm excited to push forth across this decimated landscape.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A unique but nonetheless phenomenal game from Hideo Kojima and his studio. The graphical fidelity, frame rate and controls are all much better than playing on a PS4 with a DualShock 4 which breathes new life into the detailed environments, unique story and incredible soundtrack.

Performance is good with better than PS4 Pro settings for 60+ FPS at 2560x1440. Specs are 3700X stock clocks, 16GB DDR4 3200MHz and a GTX 1660 Ti. Game is running from a 2TB Samsung 860 QVO.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Very weird, very strange, very unique. Slow pace, long cut scenes but they thread through the story perfectly. Its like no other game world  else I have spent time and that's a great thing....... Visuals are great with my 2080TI.  DLSS 2.0 does a great job of  giving me performance and quality visuals. I'm happy I made the purchase.....sidebar the way that I rate a game is how long do I play in a single setting without fatigue...this game was 4 hours before I realized that I have been playing for a while. Highly recommend it to all that enjoy an open world RPG type world to explore with a surprising story different mechanics looking for something different that hack n slash shoot everything kill em up.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: So, I got the Platinum trophy on PS4 and I wanted to get it again for PC. It runs like a charm and it looks amazing on PC and I am using a GTX 980 with everything maxed but the streaming settings. It is an odd game and its mostly walking and delivering stuff, but it is also very diverse with how you can tackle the environment from choosing to go through BT aeras or go up a mountain to avoid them. Although me and everyone else who plays this game will never meet in game we can see our progress and what we’ve built to help each other and that idea is really cool (I hate making this comparison but think of dark souls and leaving hints). Overall, 9/10 incredible story, great environments, the OST alone is 10/10, combat eh kind of rugged, gameplay well for me it was interesting, but I do not know how others will feel with just walking.

review: It's incredibly pretentious, full of conspiracy theories, pseudoscience and Kojima patting himself on his own back for knowing cool people and apparently not knowing what north America looks like. It's also, somehow, a spiritual sequel to MGS, Stalker and Euro Truck Simulator 2 all at once: it uses a somewhat simplified sneaking system from MGS, it has an normalized-eerie world of Stalker (oh yes, those are the hand-shaped crystals that make things float, what about it?), and the same deep immersion in the routine and tools of a trade from ETS2. It's also a very pretty rendition of what I'm pretty sure is more Iceland than the continental US.

Some of the best graphics ive ever seen on my PC in 10 years

review:
Reading reviews for this game seems to show it is fairly divisive, so I will keep my review surface. We all like different things. And, I haven't played all the way through. But after about 10 hours I am finding I still very much enjoy it. The overall atmosphere of the game is just really good. Visual, audible, and general immersion. I also like the twists on standard game mechanics. The online integration is interesting and I like the way the world is affected by other players.

I will play this game to the end and enjoy the journey.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The game runs amazing, even on Day 1 I had no issues, never crashed and flowed like butter. It may seem like a repetitive walking simulator but it really draws you in and the next second you notice, hours have passed and your still taking on orders. Some of the environments are so gorgeous to look at, the camera mode is honestly icing on the cake, since the options to customize your screenshots and not just pop an F12 makes for some amazing scenes. The characters and interesting and well rounded, story is quirky in a typical Hideo Kojima sense, but engaging and enthralling. Soundtrack is to die for, normally not what I listen to, but I just love the song choice. Only downside is, I'd love to be able to have the music player outside of the Private Room, so that I can pop a song for any trip. This is a solid recommendation from me. Some gameplay needs a bit of balance, given that some features are really overpowered, like the vehicles making deliveries mostly trivial, but nobody is forced to use them. Game is pretty easy-going, you decide how and what you wanna use and do. A solid 9/10. If some minor changes, in my opinion of course are made, this will be a legit 10/10 game. Going to spend a ton of time on this.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is amazing, at first i played it on ps4 but after a series of unfortunate events (not so nice people entering to my house on christmas and stealing everything) . i couldn't finish it.
however here on pc i somehow feel it more enjoyable, and more personal.
this game is a really personal journey, an amazing journey i must say, helping other players, and knowing that other players find valuable your help it's kind of therapeutic and a little addictive.
the soundtracks are perfect of course and playing it on this quarantine provides a layer of epicness not considered by the developers (of course) it kinds of makes me sad to know that not all people liked it but if you're the kind of people who likes different special things, your going to love it (:

This game is also quite easy, and people that tend to be clumsy can enjoy this game too.

I really recommend this game!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Would give this a neutral review if possible. Game is enjoyable, but the bugs are very annoying. Also Denuvo made think thrice about buying this before winter sale. And the usage of a controller is another topic.

- Encountered the same bug multiple times now: Infinite loading between area switches/cutscenes. Restarting the game did nothing, restarting the PC helped so far in the end.

- Using a controller reduces my framerate considerably compared to not having one connected. Considering a controller is nearly mandatory that's a bug that should be fixed asap.

- Got serious frame skipping from time to time, no clue if it's related to Denuvo but I wouldn't be surprised.

- Music is playing too rarely and there is no way to change the frequency or even play the ingame songs like you would expect from a game with such a great soundtrack.

- Controlls with mouse + keyboard are horrible, but I guess that was to be expected.

- Button assignment for the controller can't be changed. It's 2020 Kojima! Layout is mostly fine, but I would really like to switch the scan button for example - but not possible in this PC game.

A game in a buggy state like this shouldn't hit release, especially not for a 60€ port that's nearly a year old.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Essentially truck simulator meets Metal Gear Solid. Super engaging story with that Kojima "charm" (You know, that good weirdness he tends to have lmao) as expected with an open world Kojima game.

With an all star cast of Norman Reedus, Mads Mikkelson and Guillermo del Toro (Unfortunately just his body and not his beautiful voice) you go on a post apocalyptic journey following the role of a Australia Post delivery driver fighting through Paranormal weather that includes Rain (Time Fall) that accelerates the rate of aging of anything it touches  and "Bridged Things" (BT'S). A paranormal enemy that causes events known as "Void Outs" which are essentially explosions with the power of a small atomic bomb. They arrived during the event known as the "Death Stranding" and arrived from the "Beach". A place where death meets life.

Your overall goal in this post apocalyptic age is to "Reconnect society through strands via the Chiral network". An advanced internet like network that uses the beach and Chiral energy to transmit data and messages with 0 latency and hopefully rebuild the USA into the United Cities of America with a side hussle of delivering packages 

If you were confused reading that BASIC summary and thrown off by it then you've probably never played a Hideo Kojima game lmao. (Dw, I'm just as confused as you are) but it shouldn't throw you off from buying this game. 

It's just a beautiful world with photo realistic environments and facial animations, quite  relaxing gameplay features but not slow enough to become boring and also dense controls and features but not overly complicated where you need to feel like a rocket scientist to understand how to play.

In short.... It's a Hideo Kojima game. Just buy it to experience it. 

(Will edit once completed for a better review of the overall story)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Literally the best game I have ever played.  No bullshit I'm serious.  Everything in this game is undeniably satisfying in every aspect from audio to visuals.  The cutscenes can be a bit cringe though.  I can't tell you how many times I have heard the exact same phrases over and over again like bruh stfu.  The UI makes me nut every time I launch the game, which is surprisingly fast even with my shitty hard drive.  The only thing I hate about this game is that I lost my bike in a deep river and couldn't get it back.  Out of all of this I still wonder why I like transporting cargo more than guns, war and violence.  10/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Not trying to make the Hideo Kojima fanboys salty, just a 100% no BS translation of my feelings towards Death Stranding. 

This game (without exaggeration) is not for everybody, myself included. You (boringly) walk around finding packages and deliver them while progressing through a (boring) and detachable sequenced story. I just could not continue playing beyond the 81 min I had already played at risk of falling asleep from boredom. 

Some will see my playtime and argue, (But you did not give it a chance). My reply would be that I have experienced plenty of amazing games that hooked me like a fish from the moment i began playing, but this was not one of them, and before exceeded max play time I decided to bail and seek a refund.   

I can tell this game had some talented developers behind it, however, even after considering such a fact the player base for which the game serves is very narrow. Regardless of how beautiful the game is, I'm left asking myself one question, what does it have to offer (ME) for $60, which amounts to very little. I know this game must have taken a lot of time and cash to develop, but in the end where is the marketing placeholder for it? This is definitely a buy on sale title.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Damn I love this game. It's so weird and very unique and oddly mechanical in many good ways. Lots of detail in animations and actions and movements and tactile feedback. Sort of finnicky with animations in the heat of the moment during action but you get the hang of when to expect tripping and stumbling and leaning around after awhile. It's REALLY beautiful too, and such a unique environment. Granted the environment is all from real life quixel megascans (I believe) so all the terrain and features look real because they are.

The game mechanics have a bit of a slow ramp up time, but the weird ass events and story will keep you there until things start really clicking. I'm 20 hours in and there's still new mechanics being thrown at me. The tutorial/tips list grows extremely long, so make sure you review them as they come in.

The building and helping other players out in the world is really addicting.

I really love this game so I'm gonna go back to playing it. This game feels immensely feature complete and runs extremely smooth to boot. Very very good PC game. Must have.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Brilliant game but different. There's an addiction level with this super deep delivery boy simulator....thought I'd hate the game considering some of the critical PS4 reviews. I am glad I can formulate my opinion rather than following the cool to hate crowd which are bunch of mindless retards. If you want something different and its.... different play this. There are no words to express it lol. This game is optimized well like insanely well. It will run at 4k close to 60 fps with a 2060 super dlss enabled its fantastic graphically. My 2080 Super has not one single hiccup. 
The game play consist of delivery of goods....the condition of goods when you arrive the time limit...the rain...how well stacked up everything is on your back. Navigating beautiful landscape has never been as cool as it is in Death Stranding. You can lay ladders  and other gadgets down in the world so other players can utilize them (genius) there are signs you can place to warn other couriers of danger. You have a freaking infant strapped to your chest that see's ghost warning you of their location. Cool cast of characters above average acting...most original piece of game art I have ever played. I recommend it. Freaking Kojima nailed it IMO!!! This is why people get excited when he works on something because you just don't know LOL

Honestly if this is his starting point in doing whatever the hell he wants then i can't wait to see what he does next.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I am literally stranded in this game.. I have walked so much in just 7 hours, that my hand fingers hurt..
I don't know what to do next very clearly, or where to go.. That's as stranded as I would wanna get..!

Let me start by saying this will not appeal to the people who crave action like in Witcher 3, Dying Light, Assassins Creed, Batman type RPG Games. This is not an Action RPG (ARPG). It is a WALKING SIMULATION (First time I heard of this term though). Beautiful world, beautiful graphics, slow & tiring gameplay for me atleast..

I had presumed it would have some action at some point of time, but the action in this game is not about fighting hordes of enemies & using your abilities to traverse worlds like Cirilla Fiona Elen Riannon (better known as Ciri by Geralt et al).. The action in this game is to flee from dire & life threatening situations.
That's what a PORTER will do.. he will not carry a gun / sword / arcane magic / dragonfire etc.. He is a Porter.. not a Tele-Porter (even he wouldn't have them either.. well except arcane magic, but.. yeah.. you get the point)

I was not aware of what this game would actually end up like and am not enjoying this game as much as I wanted to, but now i am playing this game with no presumptions & just trying to enjoy it the way Hideo Kojima meant it to be (like i have a choice now, i already paid full money for it & now i cannot refund it, but that is my bad..)

All in all, do not expect action packed Ragnarok fights etc. Most of the time you will be walking or riding on a bike, making deliveries & trying to escape whatever is trying to kill you. Hope you are able to Re-build America..!

I will try to find your LADDER in the game... You try to find mine...
See you atop that mountain.. Gotta run now.. I see a Rainbow..!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hideo Kojima's Death Stranding is one of the most interesting and fun games I have played in 2020 and I wholeheartedly recommend this to you who is considering on purchasing it.

Story wise without going in-depth, the game has a pretty well written story that while complex I found pretty intriguing and has an excellent soundtrack that goes with it.

Gameplay wise you will mostly be delivering packages while trying maintaining their condition throughout your travels, the more mint your packages is, the higher rating you will attain, quite like MGSV's system of grading your performance after missions.

The process of transporting your cargo is not as boring as mainstream reviewers tend to exaggerate, as you progress the story you get more equipment to help you better transport your cargo and you can even create ziplines to help not only you, but other players traverse the world easier, making deliveries smoother for everybody.

This game has alot of emphasis on helping each other out, both story and online wise, and it feels really fun and fulfilling to build and contribute to the dozens of buildings players have created.

Objects you place around the world, I.E postboxes (to store cargo), ladders, generators can be seen by other players playing as well, provided they have unlocked the specific object during their playtime, and can be utilized by them, objects can also be "liked" in order to show appreciation, you can "like" as many times as you want within a set period of seconds if you would like to show how much you appreciated that player's contribution, as you progress and unlock different materials, you can obtain these materials from various means in order to craft various tools you can use or repairing degraded buildings placed by players.

Cargo you or another player has lost will show up in each other's world, allowing you to help them deliver it to its intended destination should you wish to, this also allows you to also gain likes from delivering cargo and at the same time help a fellow player out, if you are not able to deliver it either, you can always drop it off at a postbox or safe area for another player to help you, help him get the job done.

Should you have too much equipment or materials, you can always donate it to a shared inventory space where other players can take and utilize the equipment you donated, you can also gain likes from doing this.

Though combat isn't a frequent thing unless you actively seek it, you will slowly get more options to tackle dangerous scenarios as you progress the story, from lethal to non-lethal weaponry, combat is extremely fun and relaxing, it will be very familiar to those who have played MGSV, the game very slowly opens up to giving you your first "gun" and you will understand why if you play, I do not wish to spoil anything for you.

Speaking of MGSV, for people who have played it, many elements of Death Stranding borrows from MGSV, like the Map, UI and even the way controls feel (Keyboard+Mouse).

This is a game I highly recommend anybody to try, I had so much fun playing it and I feel that you would too!

review: That soundtrack though!!! Honestly, I'm not far into it, but it's beautiful, story is immediately very interesting, but very vague and I can't wait to see where it goes, the cutscenes are some of the best I've seen, very gripping and extremely well acted and mo-capped. Gameplay is very simple, relaxing even, but has tense moments peppered throughout to give some good highs and lows. Game is gorgeous btw lol. Playing on an UW 35" 1440p monitor with a 2080 super and man...it's one of the best looking games out, if not THE best looking game out. Also, my absolute favorite part of the game...the soundtrack. Best soundtrack of any game I've ever played. Incredible! Definitely not a game for everyone, but if you come into it with the proper expectations (not an action game, not a horror game, not a stealth game, not really a game that solidly fits into a specific genre), then you'll love it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I have a first gen PS4 and wanted to wait for this game to run on my PC @ 4K Max settings, 60 fps. I am currently at the 2 hour mark and could refund the game and wait for it to go on sale, but I commend the Death Stranding team and will gladly give them full retail cost for achieving Kojima's vision. As is clear and has been stated many times already, this isn't a game for everyone and those that play it that don't understand or like the vision he set out to create, should just say, "oh well," and move on instead of throwing tantrums. For me, the game loop is fun. Run (literally) a mission and be rewarded with some eye candy. The community aspect is a nice touch and one I look forward contributing "down the road." When this game goes on sale, I would call it at least a "must try." For me, it's a must buy... and play right now. :)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: WTH Hideo. This Kojima fellow took an awesome game engine and made a crazy mess of a story with unintuitive menus and illogical and impossible physics. If I was any one of these big name producers and or actors in the game I would have raised serious questions. I can't believe they pulled Lindsay Wagner into this. Her bionic hearing should have alerted her to the BS when reading the story and script. Another really dumb thing that people don't mention is one foot step for Porter Bridges somehow is 1 mile on your map. You walk for 12-15mins and you almost halfway across the USA? Every part of this game is either crazy or illogical. The vehicles are crap. There is only 1 RL motorcycle like the one in the game and that is a dud. No one would ever make a truck like the one in the game. That is total fail for off road. You have weapons made from you own poop and pee lol. Its like a satire joke of the video game world and Kojima is laughing all the way to the bank. He probably said to his inner circle. Im gonna make the craziest game in the world and everyone will buy it because -- Kojima.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
There was a lot of talk about this game... whether it would live up to the hype, whether it was BS or not, people questioning what it even is....

Just get it.  It's worth it.

Unless you totally hate all third-person games, DS is worth playing.  I'm like 20 hours in, halfway(?) thru the game, and it STILL feels like I'm learning how to play the game.... [b]there's so much going on that even if you end up hating the game, it'll feel like you tried 3 different games.[/b]  Metal Gear Solid V was a bit like this as well, Kojima packs in like 6 different threads of games into one; there's a solo story campaign, there's like community-minecraft-server with your game world, you can walk around and explore, there are delivery missions for high scores, you can try to be an attention-whore by spamming signs for likes.... all of this is going on at once in the same game areas, it's very weird and a must-play for anyone who considers themselves a gamer.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Short Review: The Mandalorian but you're delivering packages instead of bounties in a horror setting.
Long Review:
The Good:
This game gives you a lot of freedom to solve a simple problem of getting something to where it needs to be. 
The atmosphere is fantastic. The base game play feels very smooth and rewarding. Combat feels like a jumbled mess early on until you know how to prepare for it and it felt like a big accomplishment getting the rhythm down for dealing with the human enemies as well as the ghosts. I have not had any major technical issues besides some server connection problems that have already been ironed out and can run the game at 144 fps at 1080. Vehicles and equipment feels like something important you need to take care of when you're just starting out on low resources. 
The Bad: 
The cut scenes kind of drag on at the start and the story feels a little flat till you know more about the setting, but the gameplay is what sold me. 
The Amazing:
Finding important or key areas to place certain structures can result in little communities or meeting areas forming around it where you can leave messages for the other players passing through.

This is not a quick action game you pick up and play through at break-neck pace. The game heavily rewards preparation and steadiness instead of break-neck speed (Except on the missions that require it but you're given some warning). Worth buying just for the gameplay.

review: i really like this game but there is something you need to be wary about depending on what controller your using, the game recognises Dinput and Xinput so if you have a controller that has both then there is a chance that the same button pressed once will be pressed twice and there is not option to choose what one you want it to recognise, for example i use a power dash on the reverse trike and i dash for about half a second until it just halts, so if you using something like an Astro C-40 with 360 firmware then its going to be a bit of a doozy

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Oh man this game is such a controversy. On one side, you have many people who love it for the beautiful atmosphere, amazing story and smart inventory management. On the other side, you have people who hate this game. People are hating this game because they say it is boring, minimal game play, walking simulator. UPS MAN! Honestly, I absolutely love this game. The scenery is just breathtaking, trekking up mountains with BB is addicting. Its one of those games that you can pick up and spend hours in, relaxing and having no worries. The story is really good, even from the start. The inventory management is basically identical to MGS5, but I believe is heavily improved now. The port is flawless, I have no complaints and runs perfectly on my 1070 I5 Processor. If you want a unique experience, with a hooking story, and addictive game play. Just buy it already, I promise you wont regret the decision.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Str-HIDEO KOJIMA PRESENTS-anding is a fantastic addit-A HIDEO KOJIMA GAME-ion to the PC marketplace and- HIDEO KOJIMA PRODUCTIONS- has yet again delivered a great game. WRITTEN AND DIRECTED BY HIDEO KOJIMA you get your standard weird a** KOJIMA experience IN ASSOCIATION WITH HIDEO KOJIMA PRODUCTIONS LTD LLC TM COPYRIGHT KOJIMA STUDIO 20--- Ok now that the title movie sequence is out of the way... (Sorry couldn't resist)

Death Stranding is the latest addition to Kojima's famous arsenal and is another masterpiece crafted with love and - whatever drugs Kojima is usually on. That said DS is definitely a game you should pick up. You play as Theoden King of Rohan's lookalike, who has retired to become a UPS Delivery person. Money has now been rendered useless and your performance is evaluated by how many Facebook Likes you received for each successful delivery. DS includes your typical everyday things like time shifting rainstorms, invisible skinwalker hel*beasts, lots of strange floating dudes, interdimensional magic space fetuses you strap to your chest and plug into with an HDMI cable, nuclear exploding corpses, etc. You make deliveries throughout Post Apocalyptic USA while eating bugs and trying not to lose your balance and getting a damage claim. UPS has also issued you a magic canteen that synthesizes Monster Energy Drink for you whenever it comes into contact with water... Yeah that's legit lol. The scenery is absolutely gorgeous and the soundtrack is fantastic. The characters and writing are all unique and memorable and the world Kojima has smoked - built is one that you'll keep coming back to. If that's not enough, you have full "science" team who enthusiastically monitors and collects your bathwater/bodily excretions and provide you with magic poop grenades (your own) to fight off the invisible monsters.  Definitely recommend the full Kojima experience. I give it 10 interdimensional magic space fetuses out of 10. Would throw poop grenades at my enemies again. 

Plentiful jokes aside this game is amazing.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I only play heavily action based games. I've never settled for less. Let alone have I played a game where controller is the preferred control scheme. But this game has some awesome story elements. And the terrain is so damn hostile sometimes its nuts. You can go from chill ass bike ride to being hunted by the Appalachian Taliban in seconds. Not to mention ghost zombies swallowing you whole and throwing your ass down a ravine where you end up having to pelt the fuckers with grenades. Nothings gets the adrenaline going like having a semi peaceful hike where the only worry is keeping your spine from slipping a disk. Then out of nowhere you get pinged by an enemy scanner. Next thing you know some dudes pull up in an SUV ready to snatch that amazon prime order off your back. You find yourself ditching the cargo in a hole just so you can go rambo, choke out 3 dudes with a paracord then beat the living shit out of the last few because fuck stealth. 

So far the games been far from a walking simulator. Unless its simulating post apocalyptic Detroit, then Sure.

I've sunk alittle over 16 hours into the game since it dropped on PC and i cant fuckin stop. I dropped Tarkov and Cod for this game and so far I haven't wanted to stop. 

And apparently you get your hands on an assault rifle at some point so there's that.

I say give this game a go. It dosent suffer from the kojima "over convoluted story" syndrome. It seems like allot at first but it explains enough of it fairly well. 

9/10 could use more early game threats, still fun

Message @Conner

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's a walking simulator alright. Except you've overloaded your cargo, your bike is damn near broken, and these spooky ass ghosts are scaring your baby. Oh and people want to steal your shit too, but just your shit. They don't care about you. But you can steal it back, and run giddy that the entire encampment is after you. 

It's gratifying to get infrastructure up, as the same infrastructure you put down can help other players too.

The game does pick up as you progress, and if you screw up your encounters with BT's things go 0 to 11 real fast, to the point where you really risk losing all of your cargo.

For anyone who likes map traversal and persistent tangible objects that will ultimately help in the long run, this is pretty good. Has all the trademarks of a Kojima game, but this is still a departure from Metal Gear, so don't go expecting much there.

Untill an option is made to turn off these stupid music watermarks or atleast move them to the corner of the screen I cant recommend this game because you wont be able to enjoy it as intended.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Ah, yes. Sam Porter. I always knew he looked familiar. He's the Amazon delivery guy who's been bringing me supplies once or twice a week since March.

This game isn't so much a game as it is a flawless vision of a very possible future, not for its metaphysical elements, but for its social and psycho-structural implications. And the same people who blasted this creation for what is, and for refusing to be what they wanted and expected it to be, are very likely the same people who now, in America, refuse to do their part in helping the country to get through COVID-19.

This is your story, America. And it's a cautionary one. Kojima-san is a prophet here, but one of impending doom. And if you're American and you think this review is funny, you should go inward and figure out why you're reacting in such an abnormal way.

I hope all who are reading this review are well and doing their part.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
So then, This game. This controversial game. I am currently playing through it on pc however I have extended experience with the game on Ps4 pro and well what can I say. 

I guess I better start by saying the usual - This isn't your next Metal Gear. This isn't your next Zone of Enders. What this is however, Is it's own thing and this thing is catering to a specific type of person. Gamer or not if you aren't of the mindset and life experience to appreciate the higher/deeper experience/Story this game provides then you will bounce off it hard and probably walk away hating the game - and you know what - That's fine this isn't for you and whilst I am a Kojima fan I wouldn't say this is his strongest work. Continue on to expand on what I mean.

The story is nonsensical at times with quite alot of frustratingly unanswered questions left open, whether on purpose, language/translation, or just the writing. However, if you can relate (like serious spoilers) [spoiler] to Cliff as a father, or to Sam as a child or in the shoes of any of the side (and superbly written) characters  [/spoiler] then I feel you will get it. Long short without spoilers - Family, friends and relationships are addressed here as well as Human needs, wants and values at our core. However the main story, can leave you half full.

Gameplay again, I will say it first up when the combat against human enemies happens whilst mostly non lethal is quite enjoyable and impactful. Classic Kojima feels. However I cant say the same for the BTs, the other enemies in the game. I hate and always have hated the encounters. They at times feel as though they were added in such frequency and number to pad the game out at times despite the huge amount of content and deliveries to do. Yes you can craft weapons and such to combat them, however I'm at the point where mashing the shakeoff button works wonders and I can continue on my travels.

So is it another life experience thing then?, do the BTs represent people/relationships trying to slow us down, drag us down and stop us from succeeding so we become as they are?. *ponders*

The rest of the gameplay is a nice loop of rewards and deliveries. Helping other players, being helped etc. However this is optional as is most stuff, however building infrastructure ultimately helps you in the end as much as everyone else.

Graphics - Im blessed with the ability to play at 60+ at 4k everything on max without DLSS. I had to use Nvidia inspector to change the Anisotropic filtering to 16x to get sharpness and clarity on ingame textures. I also forced a better form of AA in the inspector too. Your needs and wants will vary but for the most part the game is gorgeous with enough options to keep fiddlers and gamers happy. 

Also the environments. Holy balls. I havn't been to Iceland/New Zealand/Ireland but I certainly feel like I have now.

Audio - Voice acting is great. What do you expect from proper actors?! :). The music, regardless of how people feel about the game I feel as though most people will agree that the music - Licensed and environmental by Ludvig Forssell is as close to perfect for this kind of game with these themes as you can get. If you're a human with emotions and relate to the characters you will get destroyed late game so get ready for some deep breaths and some tears. Legit.

If any of the above sounds good to you, then you may have a good time. However do realise this is a different type of "game". Please do yourself a favour and watch gameplay videos on Youtube for a better understanding and to get a feel of what you'll be in for and if you come back, Welcome. I hope you get to use my roads and materials. They are there for everyone to use because none of us are forever.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game right here is a prime example of why frame rate matters in games. Controlling NORMAN at 100+ fps is a sublime thing and I admit I may be biased from playing on a 144hz monitor for 5+ years but I truly cannot fathom a locked 30fps experience being enjoyable in a game where a single misplaced step could be disastrous. Game supports up to 240fps on PC so crank that up and enjoy!

I have once again been enlightened by Kojima-san and his large cerebrum game play ideas. Now if you excuse me I have to strap 25 ladders onto the Leaning Tower of Reedus and URINATE on every mountain I conquer.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game brings back memories of how great Metal Gear Solid was for the original Playstation. Excellent story line, a character you can build around, a classic feel with a modern look! The physical dynamics in the game are unparalleled to anything I played. The only thing better; A VR headset on a omnidirectional treadmill while playing this game! It feels like I am playing a character inside of the HBO series Westworld! Thank you to the people who made this game possible. Without the collective effort on all parts to bring this game to life, Hideo Kojimas' vision wouldn't have impacted me like it did back in '98. To Hideo Kojima; The most immersive games I have played came from your ideas. Thank you Sir!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Is death stranding a 'walking simulator'?  Yes!  But it's a walking sim with a massive budget and a creative/eccentric director at the helm in Hideo Kojima.  It's a walking simulator that also includes combat, stealth sections, a wide variety of options in getting from point a to point b, amazing performances by talented actors, beautiful graphics and vistas, and a unique take on multiplayer that can be a simple convenience or highly hilarious/entertaining.  

Despite the great performances by the actors, the best character in this game is the world.  Its a dynamic world that can be structured by the whims of you and other players. some of these include:
- Placing a ladder to climb a cliff, or cross a river.
- Placing a climbing rope to safely decent steep slopes or cliffs.
- Building a shelter near dangerous areas
- Contributing resources to building a road system
- Leaving a vehicle at the edges of difficult terrain for other players to use after crossing through it.
- Marking upcoming dangers or paths with signs
- Simply walking in the same path repeatedly will make a path.

All of these things can show up in other players worlds, and other players structures/additions will show up in yours which can lead to moments where you're incredible grateful to some unknown stranger for easing your route, and moments where you're notified that 100s of other players have used one of your ladders and really liked it!  Also the pc port is solid.

It's beautiful, it's bizarre, it's satisfying, it's calming, it's engaging, and its directed by hideo kojima.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Shadow of the Colossus vibes, not much on the map to distract you from your goals, but those goals and the long journeys to them are like the bacon and the butter of the experience. Chill, beautiful graphics, cool story, fun humor, but I understand it isn't for everyone, in the same way shadow of the colossus and Ico aren't for everyone. My most played games at the moment are RDR2 on the PC, Kingdom Come, Metro Exodus, and this, and while they couldn't be more different they do a lot of the same things right, mainly atmosphere/aesthetic, pacing, and a real sense of scope.

I dig it, but it isn't a varied experience with random events and NPC's with full schedules and lives living in the world, because they're not able to do so, so don't go thinking this is a Skyrim type open world, it's much more linear and to the point, but since it's focused on the main plot and not a bunch of side quests and little differences that can occur, the story really comes together nicely and feels more fleshed out than any specific elder scrolls plot I've had the joy of playing through. There's combat and threats between each goal, and there's a lot of back and fourth if you're like me and want 5 stars with each "city" and individual hold, but I would actually suggest most people just play straight through and just make enough deliveries to get crucial equipment upgrades for mountain deliveries.

Keep on keeping on!

edit: I'd like to also note the quality of the port is amazing. I have 60fps constantly at 4k with max settings.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
To call this game one of the best of its generation would not be an understatement, in fact I personally did not want to buy this game after seeing the multitude of negative reviews that were pouring out. However I gave it a wing and boy was this worth it. 

At first glance this is much like a cinematic cut-scene game. However as you dive deeper into Sam's story you begin to realize this is not a game, it is a piece of ART. The emotions I have felt while "walking" dug deep into who I have become on this life long journey.
 Have I become a lost soul digging and moving along with the tide when the world is falling apart? or am I truly a soul looking for a reason to stay on this forsaken Earth. 
Death Stranding is a game that sits above AAA standards and try's something new. 
Something different
Something daring
Something that people don't try to understand. 
Something personal.
Death Stranding receives my utmost support, 12 hours in I still am yet to get tired of "walking". 
-When you play this game you will feel emotions no matter how you feel of the gameplay. 
You may get frustrated
You may get sad
You may get nostalgic
You may get angry
But that is exactly what this game is meant to be. A roller coaster of emotions.
10/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I balked at this game after seeing preliminary PS4 reviews because it sounded boring, but then picked it up at a discount.  I loved the graphics & story and the gameplay increasingly drew me in.  While it is kind of a walking simulator, I'd describe it more as a world building game that involves a lot of walking at first, but over time, you spend a lot more time using vehicles, and other transport.  It ended up being one of my most favorite games of all time and after reading positive PC reviews, I decided to go for it on the PC as well.  It runs great on my GTX 1080TI at 4K - I can't use DLSS (only for RTX) but the other upscaling feature is great ( I forgot the name).  It looks better upscaled than at native 4K and I get over 60fps with max settings.  I set sharpness to 50% to keep the edges soft (at 100% sharpness you start to see polygons if you look closely).  Its a great PC port and I'm really enjoying playing it again.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Imagine an npc that asked you to deliver a package for a quest. You know that you need to be careful when delivering the package. You have to run slow or you will drop it, you will need to awkwardly press buttons to keep from falling if you trip on a stone, if you pack too much you'll have to do several trips, etc... then you realize that the distance to the turn in is 20+ minutes and the developers have put rocks every five feet everywhere for you to trip on.

I gave the game my best today for 10 hours. The cinematics, story and world are great. But the game play is just soooooo bad. A chore at best. I don't mind running around. I despise pressing buttons to stay upright, as well as a game design that is intentionally grindy without thought to wasting a players time.

I am utterly confused with the praise this game gets.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is a bit of a headache, and not in a good way.
this is an example of plenty of content put into a product with the core not working.
from the start of the game you will be bombarded with cutscenes that are neither engaging, nor interesting.
normally not a problem, but you endure more time in cut scenes then gameplay by a huge margin, and by the time a character pops up that you like, you'll be completely numb and will skip their dialogue just like the rest.
the real problem with this game is that everything that happens, is a mismatch of content.
from the story that feels slightly "wrong" to the world that's supposedly america but simply seems like some random piece of land.
to mechanics utilizing tank controls(meaning every input takes 1-3 seconds before the game executes it depending on what the game is already doing.)
in short, this is an experiment and its not thought out especially well.
from start to finish, if i were to express my experience in 1 word, it'd be BORED.
3/10 - "despite talented developers, they clearly had no idea what they wanted from the game."

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Beautiful game.. mostly peaceful if you learn to avoid the hostiles. A rare trait if you ask me.. and something that is commendable. For me, this game works best in small doses.. I quickly grew tired of it on prolonged sessions, but maybe that's because I'm used to more action driven games.. I just commended it for being peaceful is played right remember? So I think it is a breath of fresh air.

Some things worthy of note though.. you need to read a lot. Not necessarily a bad thing.. but if you're not, you'll probably miss out on a lot of things.. things that will help explain the game for you. On the other hand, the game quickly throws jargon on you, without explaining any of it.. and to me, that breaks the game a bit. Since you'd have to dig up information for it. I'm guessing that less patient people will walk away because of it.. I blame the more recent games for this, that literally spoon feed people with information that would make absolutely no sense in a more serious situation. Imagine meeting a person whom explains everything when you meet them? ;) (they do exists)

Anyway, give it a bit of time, and put some effort into it.. it will grow on many people I think. I won't say most.. because I know most simply don't have that patience. I think that goes for critics as well.. but I won't dive in to that. (as a general rule.. if critics hate it.. it is probably worth checking out.. especially movies)

The graphics looks really good, but in this case I'd expect no less.. one word of warning.. If you have nVidia studio drivers.. you probably want to exchange that with the latest game drivers. Those contain fixes for the game made by nVidia. Maybe the Studio version will too.. but those are not updated as regularly as the game drivers. The reason is that the geometry (and I won't be too technical here) contain something that can be referred to as "corrupted" vertices. What this means is that you get polygons stretching out all over the place. I have a good guess what is going on here.. but I won't get into it. Just use the game drivers instead, and all should be fine.

I recommend this game... it is slow... not very scary (in fact I find the "monsters" uninteresting, boring, and I try to avoid them as much as possible) but for me that's a good thing.. I'm not too interested in scare games. I've so far enjoyed the rest of the game. I could have waited to give my impressions until I had finished it.. but given my play in small doses approach... it would be too long. Besides, I've played enough to have a fair impression of it, and I highly doubt I'd change my mind ;)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is a masterpiece that even after a year of its release stays deep in your heart, wanting to play more. On it's first release I only watched it' walktrough, but now I can enjoy it myself.Even though I know how the story goes it doesn't alter a bit of the enjoyment it gives when I play it. I loved everything about this game, the story, the characters, voiceover, graphics, soundtrack, gameplay, beautiful sceneries, and the ending. The gameplay is great in my opinion, it has a relaxed, but also tense atmosphere in different points, the way it conects other players even though this game is singleplyer has a nice touch to the game. For me this gameplay is very fitting, Il ike to go and explore and deliver packages from point to point, I even spend some time to deliver packages from other players just to be able to see more progress on my character and through the world. Another great thing about this game is the heavenly soundtrack that is used, it is really emotional and when you pass through a tough expedition it is nice to hear a song to relieve some of the tension that you went. The story is well writen and well played by the actors. At first it might be a bit confusing and migth not catch you up, but it gets better and better as it goes by. Having great actors playing the characters of the story is another plus for me, I mean seeing 2 of my favorites actor Norman Reedus and Mads. This game has some really good graphics and one thing that surprised me is the low requirements that it has for them, I mean I thought that I would need to lower the settings to get the game running, but I can easily play it with no problems at high settings, so I can enjoy the game as it was meant. 
I waited to write the review because I wanted to test it first, and all I can say is that it gave me a great impression about it: the mechanics (center balancing, weather conditions) work good, giving a bit of a challenge when controling your character. The keyboard input and controls are easy to use and well thinked, I played a bit with the photo mode and helps you get some great screenshots using it. 
At the end all I can say is that this game has been ported to Pc very well, it is fun to play it and keeps you hooked to it more and more as you progress through it. Keep on keeping on!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Writing this review with a bit of hindsight since I played the PS4 release to completion before.

Death Stranding is undeniably the most unique feeling game I've played in probably the past decade. It experiments with lots of ideas but the core of the gameplay is delivering stuff from point A to B and figuring out the most optimal way to do it. It's backed up by an interesting definitely-Hideo-Kojima story to say the least and it's really immersive. There's a lot of depth to the game's world and lore if you actually go and look up about it, and while some things may definitely seem random at first, there's an explanation for everything and I think it did a pretty good job wrapping things up by the end.

Also one really unique thing about it is that helping other players is a big deal. Most stuff you do are rewarded with Likes and there's loads of ways to play the game. You can go all out and focus on building the best roads if you wish and there's no defined order for doing stuff, save for maybe the early game (which lasts quite a while) and the main story progressing missions. I don't think any other game's really tried this kind of overall system before where you can complete other people's orders for them and where your and others' actions affect gameplay on the overworld. It's probably the closest thing to a singleplayer MMO one can get, and it does it in a subtle non-intrusive way for the most part (if the constant sign spam annoys you, you can turn off the multiplayer features you don't like, as well).

That being said I think the weakest points of the game are probably some of the boss battles and the combat system isn't really well suited for handling lots of weapons and cargo at the same time. The AI could also be a bit more challenging, but so far on the PC version there is a new "Very Hard" difficulty level and it's definitely been tougher than playing the game on Normal before. Still I wouldn't play the game for the combat or if you're looking for anything similar to MGS. Death Stranding is mostly a chill game about looking at nice scenery and thinking about the best way to deliver thing X, while enjoying a cinematic story. It DOES take skill plotting the optimal routes though and it requires a fair amount of thinking and micromanagement, especially if you want to commit to say, building a zipline network through mountains. Myself I ended up liking the gameplay quite a bit, so far to do most of of the optional deliveries as well, and I think the overall control scheme for managing your balance and weight is pretty smart once you get used to it.

Also the PC version is well optimized and looks fantastic. Likely one of the best looking games I've ever played. Even my 3 year old desktop with a Ryzen 5 1600 3.2 Ghz and a Nvidia 1070 GTX could run it at 2560x1440 at nearly max settings no problem (I only dropped shadow resolution to medium). There's lots of graphics options to tweak as well. Extra difficulty setting is also nice and I'm looking forward to seeing what the PC exclusive bonuses are.

review:
The superb storytelling, acting, music scores, sound designs and game mechanics are powerful. They create a beautiful depth in which to dive, as you 'deliver' your missions.
The spectacular vistas are immersive and they can be pretty clever too - for example natural paths and trails will form as users walk through it and lay down tools and constructions to help you along the way.

Some of the U.I. menus an lists could arguably be simplified, but that's almost an impossible task when you have to deal with in-depth inventory actions and game controllers.

12 hours in and I feel like I'm barely scratching the surface; happy days.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I think this is my first review... so let's go. I'll be fairly simple at first and I'll update after I complete the game.

I have about 150 hours in the PS4 release with the platinum trophy. I adore this game. It's so weird and so beautiful. It is what Kojima can do when that leach, Konami, isn't involved.

I hear a lot of people call this game a mail-man simulator; this is analogous to calling Batman an orphan -- it might be true, but there's so much more to be said.

This game has wonderful stealth sections that offer some unique strategizing opportunities. There are some really interesting combat sections with surprisingly fluid controls. 

There is legitimate strategy to carrying items. I won't give things away, but how high or where you carry things affects how successful you'll be.

The story is absolutely gripping and thought provoking. I won't go into it, but you absolutely should.

I'll update this later with some port-specific information, but 3 hours in I'm having no issues on a Ryzen 5 3600 and AMD RX580. Ultra-wide is gorgeous. I didn't know what I was missing!

1 final bit of advice... Stick to the story. Grind [b][i]ONLY[/i][/b] as needed. Otherwise, if you want to achievement-hunt, save it for post-credits. You'll still have time then. The story is the best part.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I'm in love with Death Stranding. The story (so far, I'm 24hrs in), subtext and sociopolitical commentary is phenomenal. 

As I follow the history of the game-world through the interviews and data that's discoverable during play, I find myself immersed in this broken and torn up world. It's an interesting experience to play as Sam, a singular guy doing his best at making deliveries and connecting people in a world that puts extensive pressure on the people living in it.

Gameplay... Sure it isn't for everyone. I understand why many people find it 'boring' because it's less of a game and more of an experiential journey. Personally, I find it fantastic. At it's core, it is without a doubt a walking simulator with inventory management. However, combined with the world you find yourself exploring, it becomes a brilliant and cathartic experience as you struggle to traverse the world and overcome the obstacles the world throws in our direction. Whether that be terrain, lack of materials, harsh weather or the fear of death. The resilience of our protagonist, Sam and the constant reminder to "keep on keeping on" just adds to the feeling that I get from this game, it feels good to help and do your part.

The core goal of the game is to deliver cargo, connecting people and society back together. Though this is mostly a singleplayer experience, the interaction with other players further adds to the 'togetherness' feeling that's required to help create a better future. Doing that by building utilities, bridges and roads is awesome. Another player is requesting a bridge to cross a ravine? Well, we've got the resources at hand, or maybe in a nearby postbox so let's help out. That bridge will be useful for you, but for so many other players as well. Instead of seeing it as some passing by co-op interaction, it's a way that people (in the form of players and NPC's) come together to improve the broken world they live in and you can feel good knowing you're sharing and doing what you can to help.

As a game, it's not much and anyone that thinks they're in for an awesome pure 'gaming' experience may find themselves disappointed. If you're willing to slow down, travel long and arduous journeys on foot, taking in a vast world by reading into the context that's provided through data entries, you may appreciate the experience that Death Stranding offers. 

If you're on the fence on whether or not to buy, first consider whether you will enjoy the gameplay. If you're still interested, I'd say if you can suspend your disbelief and immerse yourself as Sam in this tough world, you'll thoroughly enjoy yourself.

Happy walking ;)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
"I am absolutely in love and awe of this game . This game is so beautiful to look at. I love the terrain the environment the weather. If you love trekking across the woods and forest and exploring new locations then this is the game for you . As we all know that this game is literally a delivery simulator but I love it . It can be overwhelming in the beginning with all these new things to understand but trust me put some time into it and you will be hooked . 

I recommend you all to play this game at your own pace and don't rush it. Enjoy the view and understand it's little mechanics of gameplay. I am 24 hours into the game and I've got a good grasp of it.  You can literally spend hours and hours into one episode just by delivering side quest cargo. For me in particular it's fun. I love the walk :) Gameplay is simple, just manage your resources smartly because there is high chance of you losing them time and time again.

Story can be confusing but overall this game is a masterpiece made by Hideo Kojima. Give it a try and keep on keeping up."
