title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's an interesting game with a story that looks quite weird at the start but gets more interesting as you play and discover new places. Gameplay is a balanced mix of calm relaxed walks and stressful expeditions between enemies that hunt you, the change in pace keeps the game refreshing and fun.

It isn't just a walking simulator as it have quite a lot of gameplay elements, and the story isn't that hard to follow. The added touch of "passive" online mode, with players helpong each other is a cool concept.

In the 16h I've been playing I had lots of fun. Will update the review later if stuff change.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Amazing game, but will take a certain type of person/player to keep you engaged. I find this game to be incredibly gripping, the story is incredible, the art is beautiful, the characters are very fleshed out, the horror works very well, and the overall package is stellar. 

However, my room mate hates the game. Thinks there is too much dialogue, too much walking, too slow paced, and not enough action. 

It really depends on how you like to play games. This game can also require you to keep tabs on multiple things at once. Micro managing balancing and optimal paths to avoid enemies. There are a pile of different metrics in this game. Everything you do has some weight to it, it seems. Im only 4 hours in but theres a lot of things to keep track of. I use a little notepad to keep track of exactly what im doing along with the in gear, helps tremendously imo. 

I think its a love it or hate it thing. 

I love the hell out of it.

It's very satisfying when you manage to get an efficient route going. The premise kinda reminds me of current events too.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Hideo Kojima has done it again. He's made a game to tell a story about humanity. Gaming fans in the west know his most prestigious franchise Metal Gear (Solid 1,2,3,4, & V) made during his 20 + years with Konami. 

Fans of those games should feel right at home with Kojima's story telling, but this isn't the super soldier Solid Snake traversing a beautiful apocalyptic hell-scape. This time, you're Sam Porter Bridges, one of the people remaining after the Death Stranding, a cataclysmic event that has destroyed what we would recognize as the United States of America. Your task, is to help rebuild the ruined country and help reconnect humanity to each other. 

It's a connecting game. It's and introspective game. A marvelously refreshing take on what games can achieve as an art form rather than a commodity used to generate a massive returns.  

In a world where we are severing ties to each other in our politics, identities, and social media echo chambers; this game emphasizes empathy, dialogue and connection as a fundamental need for humanity to continue.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It took me a long time to figure out how to describe Death Stranding without giving away elements that are best discovered by the player.  In short, the closest I've come up with is:

Hideo Kojima was having beers at a local establishment.  A fan recognized him and posited a challenge, a challenge so preposterous that nobody thought it could be done.  To him he simply said "I bet not even you could make Kevin Costner's The Postman interesting."  Hideo Kojima deposited his beer into the man's hand, where it is rumored he still stands to this day.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A very unique game for people who like experiences. The game looked great on PS4 slim and is even more awe inspiring on PC. I have a 1700x with a 1070 ti  with slight overclocks and I get a rock solid 60 fps at 1440p with everything at max but with DOF and Motion blur turned off. This game can be very relaxing, crossing the terrain and trying to find the fastest route to your goal. The BTs can be very challenging and the Boss fights are very cool. This game is very well polished.
As far as people having issues, it has less to do with the game and most likely more to do with not having a fresh Windows 10 install and having corrupt drivers. I have experienced zero problems with this game and my PC. I really do like this game a lot. Really a breath of fresh air compared to the typical games we get now. This game isn't for everybody, its for people who like art i would say. And Art is sometimes an educated taste.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Honestly you could call it a walking sim and it would do the game a huge injustice.
It is so much more than that, and its amazing fun to go from point A to B and enjoying the journey.
There is action, shooting if you want you can go out and kill or disable bandits and loot their bases to build your own roads and things.
Riding trough the world is amazing when you realise that walking on paths of other players or your own old ones makes a dirt road for you and removes some hardship. 
Its a Kojima game its got so many small details that make this game majestic that its beyond counting.

The multiplayer functions make this world so much fun, when you are going over a deep river and you see someone made a bridge using ladders but they didn't have enough to make it all the way, so you drop yours to make the bridge whole for others that will come after you. 
I can't do this game justice with just my limited vocabulary and horrid explanation skills. 

In the end you will enjoy this game if you enjoy the journey.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is pretty incredible game.  The movement will be new to you as you run, stop, slide, stumble, wade through water.  The ambidextrous option when picking up your boxes, items is very cool, and new to PC gaming.

This movie, i mean game...Is incredible.  Its like a game/movie/game.

It's also pretty scary. Not like sub-nautica scary where you panic when you enter the water... lol

The atmosphere is perfect for a post disaster world.

I am a little lost in some of the things in the start since there is no explanation or description for the results of your 'Q' scans or what the red X's on the ground mean (i avoid them anyways).

The game is a definitely has some disturbing moments but all in all it is a great game, interesting and involving story and offers an esoteric view of the whirled/world if one can remove the literal associations.

Have fun!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Playing this game I am reminded of Jacob Geller's video essay regarding emptiness and hidden spaces in video games and the world around us. The common theme I see in the negative reviews is "Game's boring, why do I have to travel so much?" After playing this for a dozen hours, I found it anything but boring. The terrain makes it impossible not to stay laser focused on your movements, and as a result, you notice how downright pretty this game is. I'd compare it to STALKER SoC but with way less shooting and more artifact hunting & storytime (and not uhh in Ukrainian). The gameplay feels lonely, you barely interact with any people and when you do, you begin to wonder if they are real or if they are merely holograms of a once real person. Their memories locked in time, projected by a machine. You even get the option to literally scream into the void of the dead world. However, because of the games semi-multiplayer function in the campaign, you encounter things other players left behind. A sign they wrote that encourages you to smile, a storage box blasting Khalid across an empty field, a power station that saves your butt when you're ready to turn back and give up. All of these leave you feeling like this world is full of life. That you're sharing this experience with thousands around the world. That their Sam is just around the bend ahead of you and maybe if you hurry, you could catch a glimpse of him and trade notes about the monsters chasing everyone. But instead you find another empty place, dead yet still alive, empty yet full, and you strap those boxes onto your back and keep trekking to see more of this beautiful world that Kojima made.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Describing the game and actually playing it are 2 different things. On paper it sounds like a boring delivery sim with a weird plot. But the game is really good with making every small issue into a minigame. Crossing a river? in any other game you just hold up on the joystick, but here its an entire issue you need to solve. First you scan the river; is it deep? Looks like it. Now you have some options to consider: i could drop a ladder over it and balance across. I can make it a big project and build a bridge over it so future deliveries are easier. I could just jump in and paddle my way to the other side, but upset my bb. Maybe i go down the river and try to find a spot where its not as deep. 

This is how pretty much every decision will go.

Not to mention you will have bad guys on the lookout to steal your stuff, weird ink monster ghosts who wanna drown you in ink and then put you up against a dolphin squid boss fight (yes im serious), or just plain old rain except its called timefall and touching rain rapidly ages anything including your cargo.

This game is incredible in making every trip an ordeal. Everything you usually ignore in other games you have to pay attention to. Random rocks in the path are something you have to actually pay attention to, jumping steep cliffs wont break your legs, but they will screw up your packages or trip you up making you drop everything. 

You have to know what path you wanna travel and how the weather will be, is it gonna rain? maybe take a detour. 
Maybe the delivery is large and heavy, consider taking a motorcycle with you or string some carriers behind you. Or just be an absolute chad and carry the entire thing on your back.

I dont know who i can recommend this game to, but i really enjoyed my time so far. Its such a personal experience and is so different to modern AAA titles that i dont know if i enjoy it for being unique or for because its genuinely fun.

Either way, i will say that this game has me hooked. And i will continue to make deliveries for a while

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is so amazing and breath taking, alot of people call it a walking sim game, but its not as you get to use bikes, trucks and even get to create zip lines to travel on, its a unique game, there is no other game out there, that is even simular to this game, the port is excellent, no bugs so far, the graphics are out of this world, yes you make deliveries, but you dont have to do this all the time as the game lets you make roads, bridges and so on to build as well to make the journey easy, also when you make these, you then share them with other player's and they also share the stuff they created as well, its weird how it works really as this isnt a multi-player game, but it works.

My suggestion would be, before you buy the game, go watch a couple of play through's either on twitch, youtube, then make a decision if the game is for you.

I give this game a solid 9.8 out of 10.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
a game that is a work of art and a game and a movie that is a game... or something like that...

never even heard of Kojima, never played a game of his before (never owned a console) and did not expect this to be a game I enjoyed even for a minute.
I bought it anyway since the amount of work that went into it and the completely fresh gameplay loop. just wanted to reward that. 
but after I saw the steam reviews I started playing it.... and holy sh!t is this the real deal.....

I cannot understand the "criticism" I had heard last November. It all seems like trolling now, or reactions from some envious competition studios who must have hired a troll army... there is no way any of said criticism was valid or legit in any way.

I would hate such a game, and I still was in awe from the first minute. it is absolutely mind blowing. that atmosphere, that world, the detail in every second, the weirdly amusing gameloop.... I am not sure if I can finish such a game, but even if I drop it after a few hours, I will never forget those and it will have been worth every cent.

this is a must buy. it is something actually new and fresh, combined with cinematic crap that -- for the first time -- seems not misplaced, but fitting. it is a true achievement in game design.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: looking through the reviews for this game i see many people complaining about frequent bugs, stuttering, and even crashing, but i have yet to experience any of the sort. the only bug i've come across worth mentioning is when i was transitioning into chapter 2 and the loading screen sat at 0% loading for the 15 minutes i let it before restarting. other than that minor issue i was honestly blown away with how smooth the game ran for how beautiful it looks. i have a ryzen 7 3700x and gtx 1080 and i am able to run the game at absolute max settings at 1080p at around 90 fps. from what i've played so far i would definitely say this is one of the most beautiful games i've played with outstanding visuals and the absolute best 3rd party selection in music i've ever heard in a video game. (seriously, for every song i've heard so far, i immediately open spotify and put it in my playlist) the story is definitely odd but hey, its a kojima game. i would highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a very calming game to explore an incredibly rich world in. also the stealth is pretty fucking cool.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]PROS[/h1]
[list]
[*]Very immersive and beautiful world
[*]Deep game mechanics
[*]Satisfying progression
[*]Unique/ Very Helpful Online integration
[*]Interesting/unique story (haven't finished yet but so far so good)
[*]Good animation/Voice acting
[/list]
[h1]CONS[/h1]
[list]
[*]Can get a little tedious and repetitive to rank up your links with locations/farm likes.
[*]Few minor and brief moments of the game chugging/freezing
[/list]
[h1] SUMMARY[/h1]
So far I have not really found much to complain about with this game. I did not expect to like this game given what I had heard, but man am I glad I gave it a try. Now I am hooked. This game is amazing for so many reasons. A lot of things that I would have normally put as a con for other games actually work in this games favor. The game feels really slow at first which seems like it should be a con, but after progressing in the game a bit, the clunky movement and mechanics in the beginning only feed into the satisfaction of getting a new tool, improving your stats, or creating a path. Basically the game starts out really shitty and annoying and you build up quality of life improvements over the course of the game giving you a satisfying feeling of progression. I look forward to exploring the world further and seeing the rest of the story. I've been playing about 15 hours and I feel like I have barely scratched the surface of all this game has to offer.

review: I played this originally on the PS4 for about 60 hours then the holiday season hit hard so I never got to finish it. When I heard they were porting it to PC I was excited. I personally love how this game is made, many hate the amount of walking you have to do but... it's a game about being a porter lmao. It has beautiful landscapes and graphics and there's so much to do while you're getting to your next destination. Since it's release I have noticed that they've fixed not only bugs and glitches but special requests from players such as small text issues. This is a fantastic port to the PC, it is graphically beautiful and they've since added some very pretty textures and things to liven up areas. There are some small stutters and one glitch(fixed by restarting the game) I've noticed and I have faith that the team behind this game will fix it. For me, this game is a 10/10.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I bought this game just before launch so I could pre-load it. Started it as soon as I could. I loved it right off the bat.

The atmosphere is somber and the gameplay meticulous. It can be mundane and repetitive if you're trying to 100% it, but it's satisfying when you see how much people are using the structures and routes you set up.

I've played for 23 hours but am still in chapter 3, mostly because I'm setting up routes and trying to five star every quest giver I encounter. I couldn't buy this game when it launched on PS4, so I made sure I bought it on launch for PC, it was fun seeing other players routes and seeing how much people were using my routes. It's similar to geocaching.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Here are my thoughts about this game.

Death Stranding is definitely not everyone's cup of tea, because it's a slow burning game, but it is at its best for the walking simulator genre and Hideo Kojima know how to make this genre so damn good and intresting than any other walking simulator game out there and especially if you love Kojima's story telling. Below i will give you my thoughts on the pros and cons!

Pros:
-Game is really an eye candy

-The world is great

-Gamplay is good

-Story is great

-Enemy AI are good and boss fights are fun

-All of the actors did a great job playing their characters

Cons:
-Audio Settings! Why can I not adjust the volume of music, ambience etc.? Not that it's a big issues or anything, but it would be a nice touch if they would include this option in an update later on.

-I was expecting the controls with Mouse & Keyboard to be better than using a controller, but i find it pretty frustrating to play with them even after I changed all the keybinds to my liking. I use a DS4 controler after 2 hours of playing with M&K and I actually don't mind it. I find it even more enjoyable using a controller even though I don't usually play with it unless they are fighting games and non-shooter games. I guess this game is just made to be played with a controller.

I'm recommending this game if you guys like great story and especially if you guys are a big fan of Hideo Kojima's past games!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I can tell you that only 22 hours in and i have fallen in love with this game. The fact people have described it as a walking sim or just playing as a postman put me off but god damn it Kojima you've done it again. The game itself is so difficult to explain as it does require a lot of patience, a lot of walking, but then there is horror elements as well as pretty amazing stealth and combat and the atmosphere, o god the atmosphere just brings it all together. As you'd expect with Kojima there is a deep deep compelling story that keeps you driving on full of mystery, symbolism and at every turn leaves you wanting more answers. The game might not be for everyone but if it is for you, do not miss out on this experience. Ive honestly not played a game that has sucked me in and held me like this for over a decade. So many tiny details i can't mention without ruining any of the story, everything has been thought of. There is a pretty shameless monster energy plug but honestly who gives a fudge if it got this amazing game paid for!!!

I should also mention the graphics are out of this world specially on higher end PC's and for a day one port i have literally encountered no bugs. The only social side of it works like a dream and was such a fantastic idea, even if you prefer to be offline during games i would recommend having it on , you don't have anyone coming in your game just evidence of them around the world.

One final thing the talent in this game is heavenly all the voice acting is perfect, the animations, perfect. I have never been a kojima fan boy but i see now why they exist. I also love to throw in negatives with the positives but the only negative thing i can say about this game is it does require patience for the first chap especially, which isn't so much as a criticism its just a warning if you know for a fact you don't like being methodical. 

Seriously though this game was worth every penny and more in my opinion, never thought i would write a review this glowing. If anything changes i will update but i suspect it will only be sucking me in more.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
There are so many cutscenes and so much dialogue. Pacing is weird, feels way slower and more deliberate than most games - you get very slowly told things, repeatedly, by multiple people. Enemies are a combination of scary and frustrating. You revisit the same locations over and over again delivering stuff. You get cosmetics and mild upgrades from reaching certain ranks with the NPCs. Occasionally stuff built by other players shows up in your world and it feels kinda neat. You get notifications when other people use your stuff. Overall a unique concept, executed pretty well, just paced in a really weird Japanese way. Mechanics can be a bit frustrating.

But then you crest the mountaintop and see Port Knot City and "Asylums for the Feeling" kicks in and all the frustration melts away and you just sit there for a minute in awe. 10/10 unmissable experience.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
To preface: This game is not even close to being for everybody. If you are looking for an action or combat oriented experience, this is not the game for you.

Kojima was not at all kidding when he said Death Stranding was a walking simulator. However, it is quite possibly the only walking simulator that actually simulates walking. If you're still confused about what exactly you do in this game, as I was, you deliver packages on your back in a surreal sci-fi post-apocalypse. For reasons explained by the lore, that I shall not get into for spoiler purposes, the last remnants of humanity are isolated inside of fortified cities, and are unable to leave. Because they are unable to leave, and because planes and drones no longer work, they rely on so-called porters to deliver goods from settlement to settlement by hand. You play as one of these porters.

Almost everything in the game is in some way focused on delivering packages. The story and your character's part in it are a little more grandiose than simply delivering packages, but that is still the foundation upon which everything else is built. A standard mission consists of picking up an order at a settlement, arranging the goods on your back and on your suit in the most organized way so that you don't tip over from the weight, plotting a course to the place you have to walk to, and then walking there. This may sound very basic and boring, but the game does a surprisingly good job at making traversal a challenge that is just as interesting and engaging as combat.

The terrain is incredibly rough, and you will need the help of various tools to get to where you're going without damaging the goods. There are also two types of enemies that can get in your path: crazed bandit types who will try to steal your packages, and invisible enemies that can completely ruin cargo, and need to be stealthed around using a sort of marco polo mechanic, where the mechanical doo-hicky on your shoulder points to where the enemies are. The invisible enemies only come out in the rain, which damages your cargo due to story reasons; so it creates an interesting dynamic of trying to escape them as soon as possible to get out of the rain, while also not rushing through it and getting caught by them. 

On top of all this, there is a pseudo-multiplayer mechanic. You can place useful structures in the world to be used by yourself and other players, and you can use things placed by other people. You will also find various lost bits of cargo in the world that you can deliver for bonuses. Some of these lost packages will be randomly generated by the game, and some of them will be left behind by other real players. It's also possible to leave packages at safehouses for other players to finish the delivery, and you can pick up things left by other players and finish their deliveries too.

Overall, a strange and somewhat divisive premise has lead to what is, in my opinion, an extremely unique and engaging game. This is not even touching upon the story, which has that signature Kojima charm of being completely incomprehensible but also very symbolic and chock full of social commentary. My only major glaring complaint is that there is a baffling Monster Energy Drink product placement. Whenever you rest in a room, there are lovingly rendered cans of Monster on your nightstand. Your canteen in the game also magically converts water into Monster Energy Drink. I wish I was kidding. This is completely shameless, and honestly subtracts quite a bit from the game's artistry, but it's not a big enough deal to warrant getting fussy over.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Amazing game!  Character design and facial express are very realistic, I love the cinematic cut scenes!  The world is beautifully designed, and the soundtrack is phenomenal.  I find myself often just stare to the distance and admire how beautiful the world is while listening to the music.  It's the first time I'm playing this game, and I immediately fall in love with it!

The story is intriguing.  The way this game tells the story is genius.  I got hooked by this mystery behind death stranding after I just finished the prologue. I'm 10 hours in currently, and I'm in episode 2, but I still have so much questions and the game just makes me wanna explore more.  

For the game play, you do mainly walk from one point to another for the most part, but it's way more than just normal easy holding "W" kind of walking that's often find in every other game. This game is very unique in a good way.  You don't just walk anywhere you want, you gotta look carefully on what kind of terrain you are walking on, how many items you are carrying, how those items/cargo placed on you, they all impact how you walk! There's also a lot of route planing, thinking and cargo/equipment management involved with each delivery.  At the beginning of each delivery, you gotta think what kind of tools you wanna bring with you.  There's also combat and stealth on top of the character balance management with horror atmosphere.  

This is not all.  The mechanic of building the world with other players and helping each other on the journey is what makes this game unique and standout.  Often times, after I climb up a steep mountain, I would drop down a rope so others can have an easier way to get up here.  Every time someone uses the tools I left behind, knowing that I could help is really heart warming.  And there's way more than just little ropes and ladders.  You can even build big projects like bridges, and other players can even help you build it together!  It makes this solo delivery experience not lonely at all.  Cuz I know that doesn't matter how harsh the environment is, we are in it together to reconnect humanity.  

It's truly a Masterpiece!!!

review:
Ill preface this with, I mostly play fighting games, and retro shit, and of course PUBG, in my old age.  That said, I am like 38 minutes into the game, there is a guy named Die-Hard man, I am cremating a dead relative in the mountains,  there are babies strapped to peoples chests, and people talking about the end of America in something that feels like a post-covid landscape.  This shit might have been weird in 2019, in 2020 it's strangely appropriate. So yeah, this shit has me feeling some type of way.  

I hate the state of video games today, like i said... mostly retro and fighting games, but ill be playing this one all the way through because less than 45 minutes in and it's captivated me more than anything else has in years.  

All hail the return of the king.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I would like to thank all the people at Kojima Productions and at 505 Games for a wonderful game. With that said now it time i do my Review of Death Stranding. First of all this game is not for everyone liking so i say watch some gameplay on this and read the reviews before you buy it. The game is wonderful, made with a great storyline and some great actors and actresses. Kojima put a lot of his trademark elements into this game that he has for his Metal Gear games.
 
As far as people calling this a walking simulator then they either have not played it or don't understand the plot of the game and yes you do a lot of walking/running but you can drive as well. i do enjoy this game thus far after 18 hrs of playing it. I am new to this game because I don't own a console so I never played it on the ps4.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I came to this game expecting a weird, artsy walking simulator made by Kojima. What I ended up playing was a game that ended up making me actually feel things I didn't know a game could. I felt genuine fear, tension and panic that modern "horror" games didn't give me. Not only that but fighting and the stealth mechanics actually had depth. And somehow, despite the fact that I will never see another player, the game managed to make me care about the other porters playing the game for themselves.

Don't waste time and get caught up in the package delivery aspects of the game, you don't need to. Skip the fluff and go right for the meat of the game. It's more than just a walking simulator.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: When people describe this as a "Walking Simulator", they aren't necessarily wrong - but they certainly aren't doing it justice. Being the first game to expand upon that genres mechanics, and put a lot more emphasis on the "simulator" aspect; we become greeted with an entirely different sub genre of what is shaping up to be a pretty heart pounding action game. With a story hooking you with enough questions, but trickling enough answers to those questions at a steady rate - it keeps you engaged and wanting to accomplish the challenge that is walking to your next destination.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: One of the best parts of the game is the various tools left by other players that will help you streamline your pathing. This game is the purest form of human cooperation, with a story that ties in to that very idea (or so it seems based on the couple of hours I've played so far during the writing of this review). Definitely a slow burner compared to some other games out there, but the luscious scenery and the nice soundtrack make for a pleasant experience so far. Certainly haven't gotten to the tedious part yet, but off to a good start!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I can see why people like this game. Thought I'd try it expecting a walking simulator but it was so much more. The story connected me to its world and even tricked me to believe to I was connected to others. I think the fact that others share your journey and hardships, trudging through the environment, gives you hope and strength to keep going and see it through.

Only played it for 5 hours so far but I can say this is a powerful game for the games industry and I wish more games were like Death Stranding.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I had heard a lot of poo-pooing about the gameplay of Death Stranding being just "walking", but after getting a few hours in, it's a bit more complex than that. Navigating the terrain while invisible umbilical cord ghosts or a pack of bandits try to murder you ends up being tense and thrilling. Add in the effective time limit that comes in the form of killer rain, and you've got one heck of a unique stealth action game. 

There is an excessive amount of cutscenes, arcane tutorials, and uninteresting dialogue, but that's pretty par for the course for Kojima. As a game though, I'm enjoying it quite a bit.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I played this game on PS4, so I can attest to how this game plays and what it entails.

This game definitely has a slow start. The tutorial pretty much ends around the end of chapter 3, then you'll get to have a lot more fun with it.

It's pretty much a hiking simulator, with Kojima elements added to it: Like shooting, horror, convuluted fucking story. I still recommend this game if you want to go about a chill time just walking for hours on end.

The story is confusing, and kind of dumb at times, but the characters can really deliver once you actually get into it... Near the end of the game. With how the lore of this game's world is, you don't actually get to interact with other characters much, until the end where it piles on an insane amount of story. After I actually did the last action, it took me 2 god damn hours to get to the final scene. Kojima really likes putting in movies in his game

The soundtrack is amazing, that's pretty much all I can say about it.

The gameplay is hit or miss. You like it, or you don't. That being said, if you don't like the initial gameplay, you might like it further into the game. Unfortuantely, the gameplay only REALLY gets good 10-15 hours in. So if you play that much and don't like it, then you still gotta play more to see. With steam's 2 hour refund policy, you might not get to enjoy anything if the gameplay doesn't get you right off the bat. The gameplay is nice for me, and gets even better further into the game, so I recommend it based on that.

The bugs for this game? I haven't really seen any. I've seen other users have bugs that cause them to not be able to enjoy the game, but from what I've played so far I've encountered nothing. So that's also a hit or miss. There are also graphical bugs from what I've heard, but again, I haven't encountered those.

title: DEATH STRANDING

+ Just on Dafault Graphic Setting (not even the Highest Seting), looks outstanding.
+ Optimized pretty good too, i5 8400 + 1060 6GB + 16GB ram can run at pretty 60fps all the times.
+ The Keyboard setting is good enough.
+ The story is good but somewhat confusing if this is your first Kojima game.
+ This is no intense action game, if you want to go pew pew, looks somewhere else. If you''re here for the story and Kojima, you're looking at the right place. 

Personally I rate this game 9/10: SASUGA OUR LORD  KOJIMA! 
WORTH 60$ FOR THE PREORDER

review:
I have played only a short time and in my opinion words can't describe the beauty of this and the attachment I have begun to form. The look of this is how I feel games should be in this day and age. Now I am only running it in 1080 at 60fps with a 2070 and a Ryzen 5 1600X but it is still smooth and fluid, which surprised me considering how the trailer looked to me like it would be rough to run. The story is engaging and keeps me wanting to push on. The team behind this are amazing!

To compare this to a simulator is an insult in my opinion.

It is a good thing most if not all of the negative reviews don't allow comments. Most of them are from closed minded individuals and have zero useful insight into the story and mechanics behind this game.

This is by far the sexiest game of this genre that has graced the screen of my pc. I have never played this before and I am glad I haven't as it makes this that much better.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Aside from some stuttering in the beginning cutscene I haven't ran into any issues playing this game. Through the rainy biomes where the deadly BTs lie in wait or the waterfalls I've seen in my travels the game keeps a consistent FPS and amazing fidelity. 

I run the game at a native 1440P resolution @60FPS. I limited my FPS by choice since I stream to my living room TV via Steam Link which tops out at 60hz and even through the stream it's been solid. Although I don't get to experience the game at the full 1440p since I use the Steam Link, I do get a really great 1080p supersampling effect on my 4K TV. I played before installing the latest Nvidia driver so things might even run better for me now. I wish I could take advantage of the HDR but since I'm playing through the Steam Link I can't.

I play the game with a PS4 controller and I've really enjoyed how smooth the game feels on the controller. The only thing I'm a little upset at is that I can't set the BB to talk through my PS4 controller speaker. Maybe this will be added in the future or someone will figure out how to do it but for now I'll live with it. If I run into any issues I'll make sure to update but so far the game is smooth and beautiful.

My Specs are:
8GB GTX 1080 Windforce
I7 7700k Quad Core 4.2 Ghz Intel Processor
16 GB DDR4 2400 RAM
Steam Link Hardware

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's a Kojima game, so expect a somewhat bizarre story, an unnecessary amount of cutscenes. Yes, it's frustrating, but it's all skippable, so scenes you've seen before or are dragging on too long, you don't have to watch (but don't blame me if you miss parts of the story and get even more lost).

The game is the definition of a fetch quest, set over a visually stunning environment. The actually delivery elements of the game can be quite cathartic and peaceful at times, breaking into sudden bouts of tension and conflict whenever rain approaches or you encounter the fairly few hostile factions.

The game has been ported well, with native widescreen support, without lettorboxing, and makes use of NVIDIA's DLSS feature, though no support for RTX or HDR currently, despite the game being perfectly suited for both features. Additionally, the game throws in a bunch of Valve-themed content to go along with the Steam release, but these are all cosmetics basically. It's a cute idea which doesn't really impact gameplay.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This is an absolute masterpiece of game design, story and world building. Some say it would be better as a movie, and in some parts I agree but this game wouldn't have the amount of charm and satisfaction if it was a movie. Also, some say that its a "walking simulator" and I disagree with that claim 100%. This game absolutely blows my mind how visually stunning this game is, and how much lore and story packed into it. This game is not for those who like short, simple games. The community behind this game is amazing, and Kojima has given his signature charm like always. This is a 10/10, would recommend for the right audience.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I have a PS4 and when this game was in the process of being released for it I bagged on this game hard, I was one of the guys that said this game looks like shit and why would anyone play this, all that and more. now that I actually played it for myself I can say its honestly a masterpiece of a game. The graphics are great, sound is amazing, gameplay is great, each time i feel it getting repetitive a new mechanic is introduced, the story is by far the best part and this game constantly has me on my toes and wanting to learn more about this strange world. Your character "sam" is kind of a sour puss but learning more about him and playing as him is very fun and exciting. Overall this game is a 10/10 for me, I have yet to feel a bored aspect of it and i'm over 7 hours and haven't even scratched the surface of this massive game. There is so much that doesn't make sense but so much to learn.
Like I said in the beginning, I hated this game before I played it but I wanted to give it a chance so I took all those feelings of hate and just an over all bad attitude towards this game and tossed them out the window when I pressed the play button, going into this game not wanting to hate it is the ideal mindset to have when playing this because this game is not for everyone.

You will like this game if: you have strong feelings to wanting to learn lore and information about a new world, like fantasy books, love open world games, want a game different from any other game you ever played, a graphical enthusiast, open to new mechanics of gameplay.
You will hate this game if: You need constant action, do not like story driven games, hate learning about the game world, skip every cut scene to get to the game play, if you cannot shoot something in the first few hours of playing the game (took me 5 hours to get a bola gun, non lethal), hate side quests, are not a patient person.
if you do buy this game please do what I did and go into this game with a willingness to like this game, not the "ill just refund it if i dont like the first 10 minutes attitude" 

also do not skip any story cut scene
also do not skip any story cut scene
also do not skip any story cut scene
also do not skip any story cut scene

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Its a game for open mind players, a masterpiece that this generation needs to play to understand the value of helping each other, instead of fighting to show who is above.

This game is fantastic, beautiful, social commentary about social media and reconnecting with each other when we need it most. 

It has an addictive gameplay loop.

The story/lore is deep, interesting, and wholly unique. It's one of the few games where I don't skip the cutscenes because of how enthralled I am in the world and story.

The performances from the actors is phenomenal. 

The art style reminds me a lot of the works of Junji Ito/Lovecraft.

All in all I highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested/a fan of Kojima.

A solid 8.5/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
First of all, for a sort of tl;dr, the negative reviews aren't lying. If any of the talking points on those are an ABSOLUTE dealbreaker for you, steer clear, but otherwise, even if you're kinda on the fence, give this a shot. 

This game is longwinded, like much of Kojima's work, but in my opinion it's about on par with MGS4 in terms of gameplay-to-exposition ratio, and has all the eccentricities you'd expect from Kojima, for some (understandably) that's a turn off, but I've come to love that writing style, sometime since I first played MGS. The more important comparison between DS and MGS4, in my opinion, though, is that it doesn't feel as forced, or fatigued as it did in MGS4. He's allowed himself to express a new theme, untethered from what must have come to feel like an extremely oppressive canon. 

Ultimately, it is, as everyone has said, a walking simulator, but for whatever reason, I actually enjoy this one, and I haven't really gotten immersed into a walking sim since Firewatch, when it launched. 

Fuckin, I don't know what I'm trying to explain here, just give it a shot if you're on the fence.

title: DEATH STRANDING

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Over the past year or so while waiting for Death Stranding to be released for PC, I'd read basically nothing but negative reviews about how boring the game is and how "Kojima bought into his own hype" and so on. I don't know what that quote is supposed to mean as he pretty much just makes the kind of game he's always made so I don't think hype really enters the picture.

Although I read enough reviews to kind of get the gist of what the game was about, I never watched gameplay videos or anything so didn't know what to expect pretty much at all. The first hour or so was FAIRLY BORING but it picks up quickly as more and more mechanics and "things to do" are introduced in the early game.

The plot is very "Kojima", ie: nonsensical and sometimes cringeworthy. Character names like "Die-Hardman" just make me roll my eyes but some Engrish can be forgiven in a game that is otherwise very original and deep (gameplay-wise). I came away from my first 6 hours thinking this would have made one of the best sci-fi films ever produced if it were properly edited, but as a game it's fairly lackluster.

A lot of the plot elements are quite unique and original (on the surface... they do of course draw inspiration from numerous books and films that Kojima is a fan of) which makes the game pretty refreshing. That said after viewing something like 8 LONG cutscenes of pretty irrelevant dialogue in the first couple of hours, I found myself skipping the dialogue which is usually one of the parts of a game I enjoy the most. Not a good sign for someone like me who really gets into lore.

That said, I think that all of Kojima's games are a necessity for people who enjoy the more artistic aspect of game development. To me he's akin to directors like Wong Kar-Wai and Ingmar Bergman... most average people hate their films but they're so important to the history of cinema that it'd be a very different world without them.

I would rate it overall 8/10 so far.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Do NOT waste your time or money on this title.  It is not worth either.  The game sucks.  Its unbelievably tedious and boring.  It looks like it might have potential but i can assure it does not.  Sadly its made for people with no taste who only game and or are weaboo types.  Its as if they took some good ideas and asked how they could turn it to poop.  The gameplay is repetitive, the cinematic scenes are boring and poorly done, and the music is so awful.  In addition there is no volume except master so its mute or everything.  The main character looks just the way he did in charmed season six.  Sweaty and addicted to heroin.  Hes a truly awful person too.  His character makes you wanna wretch.  He kills his own mother for fear of being touched.  Beyond stupid and melodramatic.  There are better games, they exist.  Sadly id rather play system shock 2 than this new overpriced joke.  Ive had enough of product placement and bs instead of a well built world.  There is no rpg element or character building and the interaction with the npcs is extremely boring.  Its a delivery simulator with very little substance.  Dont mind the lack of combat in the beginning as strategy and immersion are paramount to the enjoyment of a title.  I just dont feel immersed.  I feel frustrated waiting for the game to become more interesting.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Its... Just ... Different!   When you think the game is one thing, and your attention deficit order as a gamer kicks in, the game changes the parameters. IE; they seem to have the game planned out to gamer's need to advance quickly, but pull on our strings to explore what we just learned via a game.  Its hard to explain. But so far, the explanation is spot on,  its Genre defining.  

    Who the hell wants to walk everywhere?! Wait, I get a vehicle.  How the hell do I deal with these antagonists all game?! Wait, There are weapons.  But its to the extent that you do not expect the game to shift as seemlessly as it does.  

    If your a Fan of Hideo Kojima, Then good God get this game.  Its filled with those quirks and attention to laughter that you love.  If you dont know Hideo Kojima, then buy this game, along with his others.  He is Untethered as this' game maker.  This game is worth its weight in gold.  Enjoy!!!!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
"Keep on Keeping on"

After playing the PS4 version, I can say I most enjoyed the teamwork mechanics such as the use of structures and signs for warnings. With how stamina and item management are so crucial, it's nice to find a bunker someone placed along the route to take a rest and regain your bearings. The "likes" system is addicting (as social media invented it to be) and it heavily encourages players to place structures and warnings in ideal locations to receive likes for character progression.

As for the port, the game runs smoothly for the most part and having so many options for resolution is appreciated. I'm glad HDR is also present in the port.

Great game for those looking for something oddly relaxing with doses of suspense and thrill.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Spend over 300 hours playing (three times on PS4 and never got bored) I decided to share some of my thoughts and feelings about this masterpiece. Hoping I might convince someone to give it a try and maybe even fell for it as much as I did. 

[i]Review mostly based on experience gained from playing on PS4. Not a lot of major differences expect of the better graphic capabilities if your engine allows for it (which is a big plus).[/i]

There will be a short version and a long one [strike]for those who honestly have nothing better to do with their free time[/strike]. I wasn't aware steam has characters limit so... the full review will be posted separately since I already wrote it.

[b]PROS(not in a specific order): [/b]
[list]
[*]NOT A WALKING SIMULATOR
[*]Magnificent graphic
[*]Legendary music: songs and background soundtrack
[*]A new way to show post-apocalyptic world / Kojima genius
[*]Weirdly genre-free
[*]Beautiful in-depth plot
[*]Amazing main characters 
[*]Marvelous casting 
[*]INSANE detailing
[*]Awesome backstory; a lot of backstory and background to discover
[*]Multiplayer without actually interacting with people
[*]Amazing basic mechanic 
[*]The great importance of weather phenomena
[*]The story isn't closed/finished in every aspect allowing fans for speculation and own theories
[*]The game with an actual message 
[/list]

[b]CONS: [/b]
[list]
[*]Not all the chapters are evenly divided
[*]Lack of Game+
[/list]
Is it expensive? Yes. Is it worth it? Hell yes, it is. 
So don't forget to take your climbing anchors, ladder, PCC, and go explore the beauty of Hideo Kojima's masterpiece of a brand new world with a company of our lovely grumpy Sam Porter and BB.

Highly recommended 10/10.

You can read the full reveiw here: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2166386279

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is ABSOLUTELY STUNNING!

If you are on the edge of buying the game, here is my input:

Hideo Kojima is a fantastic story teller. I was roped into the game as soon as I played the first few seconds of the game. From the amount I have played when writing this review it hasn't been crazy action packed but there have been so many really great moments of stress, relief, anxiety and calm. It makes you appreciate all the little things as well as planning every detail for your next venture. It has a feel that is relaxing, similar to Stardew Valley (Relaxing and can be played for hours), and one simple misstep could change that whole thing into pure panic.

Pros:
-Story Telling
-Cinematics 
-Graphics
-Smooth gameplay 
-UI
-Music
-Capturing Feelings (If you are really into the game)


Cons/Neutral:
-Not as action packed as other games (Which in this case makes perfect sense)
-You can't assume what's going to happen (Sorry if you like to guess everything before it happens)
-Small UI bugs that would make management a tad easier

As of right now it is very hard to write any cons and the ones that are in the list aren't even that bad at all! I have loved this game so far and can't wait to see what lies in store. 

This game is for the patient. If you like to rush into everything then this game might not be for you. Delivering cargo on foot is priority one, and if you can't enjoy the scenery and take a nice stroll then you will have a rough time. Stealth is your best friend. There is a lot I wish I could explain but I can't simply cause it would spoil the game. Just know that if you don't like stealth you are going to get into some nasty situations. 

Conclusion? 

If you are still unsure, you are more than welcome to wait for it to go on sale. It has been out for a while on PS4 so maybe there will be a good sale sometime in the future. If you have the money and you are willing to spend: Give it an hour & a half. Really be interested in seeing where this story and adventure goes. I couldn't sleep very well knowing that there were so many questions I wanted answers to. If you are looking up gameplay and you are watching as many videos as you can to figure out the story then what are you doing?! You are already hooked and curious where the story goes, so why not play it and carve your own path through the story!

Just don't forget to do a good deed to your other peeps and make sure to give and take support where it's needed.

You may feel stranded, but we are all part of the same strand.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Let me preface this review by saying I played through this game within 3 days of launch on PS4.

Death Stranding got a lot of hate when it released, some reasonable, some unreasonable but moreso the latter. People gathered the general opinion that a lot of critics had, saying that the game was terribly made, un-fun and a walking simulator, but all of that is wrong, and I'll get into that.

Story - When you think Kojima you think wild stories with wacky humor and insane twists, and this game is him turned up to 1000. This game was designed to connect people and the story itself does a fantastic job conveying that as well. You spend a lot of time traveling from place to place delivering things to people in need to form KNOTS, those KNOTS connect you from city to city across this games version of a post-apocolyptic America, a wasteland housing BT's (otherwordly creatures trying to kill you or anyone they come across), psychodic package snatchers, as well as terrorists trying to harness the power of BT's for their own gain. Your main purpose of connecting these cities while dealing with all those foes is to rebuild America (along with other things that are addressed later in the game), sounds kind of cheesy but the story absolutely nails it and then some.
I'm a big boy, I don't cry at many games I swear it, but man, there were points in this story that made me cry, and not in the sense of "oh hey lets build up a character that people like and then kill them randomly and destroy someones emotions" like a lot of games. None of that exists here, it's the story behind some of the characters that genuinely gets to you, like MAMA's character development, anyone that has played this game will tell you MAMA's background was so sad and insanely well written. If you want a story that keeps you entertained, makes you sad when it tries to be sad, makes you laugh when it tries to be funny, and actually destroys your mind when it wants to, this is the game for that, and I love it. Also, this game is long and well worth it's pricetag in cutscenes alone.

Graphics - Hooooly, this game is gorgeous and on PC it shines no matter if you're at default or max, but don't expect options up the ass like in most PC games, although the options that matter are here, and DLSS absolutely shines in this game.  I can't think of a game that does a wasteland so well that it's lively, if that makes sense. You could be walking or driving a vehicle and just stop moving with your jaw dropped at some of the views in this game, or you could be walking through an overgrown open field and feel genuinely at peace (until you get clapped by giant whale BT anyways). This game is beautiful and words can't give it enough credit, it runs like a dream as well.

Gameplay - Here we get to the meat of the complaints, the walking. Honestly if you play your cards right there isn't too much of it, aside from a few mandatory areas and the first few hours of this game. You obtain a bike within the first 3 hours of this game and it changes it completely. You gain the ability to choose whether you want to walk, ride a bike, or drive this games equivalent to an SUV, it makes the traveling a breeze and much faster. I feel like most reviewers didn't even make it a quarter way through the game because they almost never reference the fact that bikes and SUV's are almost always available to you to make this game less walking intensive, along with any player made structures that appear in your world that assist in your travels, or you could assist other players with placement of ladders, ropes and other items of your own. There's a lot of combat in this game as well but not in the general sense, a lot of it is avoidable, like with BT's, you can sneak by them, or if you're a madman you can let them succ you and fight their dad, both are fun and intense and it's done really well. When it comes to the walking itself, it's honestly not bad, and I'm the type of person that can't walk more than 10 feet outside my home without having a mental breakdown wondering where my mouse went and why it's not in my hands. It has it's own uniqueness and fun factor to it, and it can make you tilted when you trip on a ditch causing all your packages to fall down a mountain, so it'll give you a good laugh too, after you get over it that is. All in all you get a bike and if you're as versed in getting up mountains as I am with my horse in Skyrim you don't need to worry too much about walking.

Music - My god, this game absolutely caresses your ears at all times with its beautiful soundtrack, it's so fitting that it seems like the composer and all the groups who made the music for this game were all conjoined twins with Kojima at one point. You could be driving your bike and a song comes on that just makes the entire trip so much more beautiful and enjoyable, or you could genuinely be happy just listening to the soundtrack of this game on YouTube and that says a lot. PS. for some reason a fair bit of the music from this game isn't on the Official soundtrack, like Ludens from Bring me the Horizon, a song from CHVRCHES, and the other groups, I'm assuming it has to do with legal publishing reasons? Not sure, but either way the main soundtrack to this game slaps harder than my dad when I forgot to mow the lawn when I was 14.

Characters - Here's where the game absolutely crushes anything else without even trying. The actors/actresses performances in this game blow you away, Mads Mikkelsen especially, my god any part of the story with him in it were crazy good. Every character in this game is amplified by their Actor in such a way that it just sucks you in and makes you attached to them, no matter how much you love or hate them, you can't say they weren't incredibly voiced. I genuinely believe this game had better acting than most movies that the Oscars have nominated in recent years thanks to the talented actors that probably took up more money in hiring than I'll make in a decade. Best performances in this game compared to any other game I've ever played and it adds so much to the emotions you feel and how involved you get with it.

All in all, I love this game and it was very misrepresented by media outlets that couldn't make it past the first 3 hours where the game picks up speed (and gives you a bike). This game lets you see cooperation and change in a way that can genuinely alter your way of thinking of one another and the things we can do if we work together along with how important that in itself is. If you're like me and don't know if you'd like it due to the fact you heard bad things, play mainly shooters or other genres, I suggest you give it a chance, I did and it's one of, if not my favorite game.

This is my first genuine review so sorry if I didn't make solid points but I did my best, any feedback you have leave a comment and I'll answer any questions about this game I can or correct my review if I made something too confusing. I hope the review helps some people to enjoy this game as much as I did.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death Stranding features vivid landscapes, beautiful music, a wonderful cast, and an incredible story that consistently delivers. I am immensely impressed, despite some minor graphical bugs early on. In regards to those bugs, as many have said, make sure your drivers are up to date and you wont have any issues. I came into this game with little to no expectations and I have to see I am very impressed so far. I find myself stopping frequently just to enjoy the scenery and music that accompanies it. This game is at its core focused on deliveries. The focus behind the deliveries is what brings a real purpose to all that time spent walking. The game is what I expect from someone like Hideo Kojima. What I mean by that is that it's abnormal, to say the least. In a climate of what feels like the same types of games over and over, this game shines through as an example of a developer who wanted to tell a story in a unique way without following a standard format. The style is very reminiscent of his older works in MGS. So, fans of that franchise will notice his touches everywhere. When you come into this game you have to arrive with zero expectations to get the most out of it. I find it to be an endearing story and at this point i definitely recommend giving it a try.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Everyone always says "this game isn't for everyone". I think this is true, however I think the amount of people this is "for" is larger than you might think. Watching gameplay of this game does not do it justice, its an incredibly different experience to play it vs watch it. I totally understand how someone could watch gameplay and think it looks stupid - but actually playing it yourself is a different matter in my opinion. That said, there are going to be some people who play it and still just really don't mesh with it - this is fine too! But I do think it's worth trying. The first few hours can be especially "frustrating" (even though I personally enjoy them), but it's necessary tbh, and the game makes more sense once you hit chapter 3.

I played through this on the PS4 with low expectations and this game blew my mind. Very unique experience, and I think it was easily worth my $60. The story is interesting and entertaining, if a bit redundant and/or cringy at times. But I still enjoyed it. Some may say that it's a "story focused game" but I personally found the gameplay to be far more rewarding. The way the themes of the story and the gameplay work together to impart a message left a profound impact on me.

Do note, to run at 60fps you will need a gtx 1060/70+. I have a 970 and it runs ~60fps, but it goes from 45-60 depending on the scene. Which to be clear is still very good performance imo, just want people to have clear expectations for what they will need. It's a gorgeous game so you'll need the card for it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a very divided game, you will either hate it or love it. I personally have played it numerous times on PS4 since launch and was very excited to see a PC launch due to the high end gaming rig I own. If you own an RTX card, DLSS 2.0 really shines in Death Stranding. 

Death Stranding tells a story about one man, Sam, who along with other porters is working to help keep a divided America connected through the delivery of parcels. Sometimes it is a collectible figurine for the Luden's Fan and other times it could be sperm and eggs to help with human reproduction. After you make your delivery in the intro mission, you soon learn that there is more to Sam than being a simple delivery man in a disconnected world. 

The story is full of many twists and turn, true to the typical Kojima fashion, and can become a bit convoluted at times. I recommend a second playthrough to really start piecing more of the story together or even watching some clips online, it is interesting playing the game again with a fresh perspective. 

The game can start off slow but really starts to shine about 3-4 hours in, this is if you follow main story progression and do not try to get Wind Farm to 5 stars as quickly as possible so you never have to visit again. 

If you are on the fence on purchasing Death Stranding, with a $60 USD price tag, I would recommend watching some reviews on the game. The one review I have come across that really shows the game and what Kojima was going for, without pandering to Kojima fandom, is from Girlfriend Reviews. I recommend checking out the review and seeing for yourself if wondering a post-apocalypse America and trying to unite it is something you can enjoy. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lKdv-IeAv2g

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This is simply a masterpiece that carries powerful messages for a time that needs them.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
After wasting 8 hours on this garbage, The Evil Within has been bumped to second place for the worst game I've ever played. Hideo Kojima is no genius; in fact, after my experience with MGSV and then this game, I'm convinced his head is so far up his own ass he's getting high on his own farts like the people that drive hybrids in South Park. Someone needs to tell him "no" and stop enabling his bullsh*t.

The main gameplay element, ferrying packages while traversing a world designed to prevent you from going straight from point A to point B, is infuriating. I wasn't able to place a single ladder or anchor point because it was "outside permitted construction area." What? Climbing is often broken, with Sam stumbling and falling for no reason, even while standing still. Think vehicles will make things easier? Not a chance, because they get stuck on everything. A small rock that Sam can easily step over will bring a vehicle to a dead stop, but it can climb steep 45 degree slopes without tipping backwards with the weight of the packages. I guess center of gravity only applies to Sam.

The characters, and their performances, are just terrible. Fragile is fragile, but not that fragile. What a clever play on words, almost missed the subtlety there. Die-Hardman is hard to kill, did you get it? If you didn't, well, they're going to explain why, so don't worry if the subtlety is too difficult for you to grasp. There isn't a single character I didn't almost immediately dislike. All the acting talent in this game is utterly wasted by bottom-of-the-barrel direction.

The storytelling is lazy and self-indulgent. The constant expositional dialogue is abysmal. Hey, Sam, this is your mother, here's her first name in case you forgot, but the first thing she says to you is "I know you hate me" so I guess we're saying all this for the player's sake. Yep, I get it, Sam doesn't like being touched, you don't have to bring up and explain aphenphosmphobia in every conversation. Or Higgs explaining the Higgs boson, which is just so, so subtle I would have missed it. What I wouldn't mind being explained is the ridiculous number of terms and acronyms. DOOMS? Q-pid? They just chuck things at you and hope you'll stick around long enough to have them explained. Guess I'll never know, because I'm out.

Oh, and don't forget that Kojima thinks you're an idiot if you don't understand or appreciate his "art", whereas I'll think you're an idiot if you waste money on it like I did.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Does Truck Simulator but mostly on foot, in the apocalypse, with intricate cargo management, a healthy dose of bizarre storytelling and a sprinkle of third person shooter combat sound appealing to you?
You'll probably enjoy this.

Okay, maybe the actual gameplay isn't that similar to Truck Simulator but boil it down to the very core gameplay, and they're the same game. You deliver cargo from one location to another. That's it. First and foremost this is a game about delivering packages, mostly on foot.

Understanding this and knowing what to expect going in is the key to enjoying Death Stranding. Most of the negative reviews are going to come from people who are disappointed with what the game is. People who feel that the developers set themselves up for failure with cryptic trailers that showed little to no gameplay, leaving us to speculate from the breadcrumbs they left us. 

Because of this, setting the right expectations is important. This game isn't going to be for everyone.

This is a different kind of game. It's going to take patience to get anywhere. Combat and any action is only secondary to the bulk of the game, a ploy to spice up the gameplay at times. So if you're looking for an action adventure game this isn't it. There are bossfights and general moments of combat or suspense, but 90% of the gameplay is traversing the expansive and beautiful environments of the world of Death Stranding, as well as creating structures to aid in that traversal. If you play online, these structures also bleed into other players' worlds where they can give you likes should they find them helpful.

That's not to say the game is exempt from any criticism. Even if you know what you're getting into when you boot up the game, a lot of the complaints people have are valid. The pacing could be better, the story relies on heavy exposition and the game takes a while to really open up, to name a few.

Still, if you find the game's premise intriguing, I wholeheartedly recommend it regardless of any shortcomings it may otherwise have. 

Death Stranding has these Zen-like moments where it's just you, your cargo (and the supernatural baby you've got strapped to your body) trekking up the mountains, you're cresting a hill overlooking the town below as an eerily fitting song from Low Roar starts playing... Those moments are absolutely wonderful and exactly the reason why I love the game so much. The slow pace and the struggle to get anywhere pays off time after time.

This is very much a game that you need to play for yourself before you can fully judge it. Of course you're free to say that this isn't for you, or that it sounds boring. A lot of people are probably going to feel that way.

Just know that, in my opinion, moments like the one I just mentioned don't translate well into video format. And that they are the reason this was my GOTY of 2019. The difference between experiencing them through another person, and being totally absorbed in the moment when playing it yourself is like night and day.

Playing this game is a truly unique experience, and in a video game landscape where AAA developers are getting more and more flak for sticking to the same old formulas, Death Stranding is a breath of fresh air that I felt was sorely needed.


To finish off, here's the tip every newcomer should always be given before playing:
Focus on the story quests to begin with. Don't spend hours doing every little sidequest right away or you'll wear yourself out before the game gives you tools to make your life easier. The game opens up a few hours in. After that you're free to do whatever quests you please.

One of the characters will give you a "tip" that you can finish up the area you're in before proceeding. Ignore this, you can return to any area in the game more or less whenever you want.

That's it, keep on keeping on!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I did not expect anything, and I'm still disappointed.
The plot is typical of Kojima — a pile of esoteric delusional crap. The graphics are nice but even with everything maxed out the game is not breathtaking in any way. The gameplay lacks in smoothness, diversity, and realism at the same time: it's beyond me why the developers decided that unrealistic physics, unrealistic actions, badly calculated collisions, and simplistic leg movement would be fine for a game that revolves around delivering packages by foot. The music is ok-ish.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I can't overstate how much I have enjoyed this game so far. The walking mechanics feel very well done and I love how you have plan out each mission as far as the route and the weight distribution is concerned. 
The game runs at a very reliable 60fps on all settings maxed out (1080p screen, GTX 1060, 7thH seriers core i7, 16gb ram). 

If you want a more relaxed game, or perhaps one that has a lot of exiting action (which isn't a bad thing for the record), this might not be for you. But Id recommend the experience this provides to anyone regardless. 

For now, I'd give it an 8.75/10, really good stuff

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Game at time of review (5hrs) is wonderful and mysterious with intriguing mechanics when simply delivering cargo.  The way we can change the game world based on online shenanigans is very fun to experience.  I've found myself smiling just because billy on the other side of the planet left me some metal and a bike that is uncharged.

Please take into consideration what the game is before getting it.  The game is as many say it is..a game about delivering packages across a landscape.  If you find games with intriguing world building and mysterious subjects ( I'm still confused about what is going on and I love it) then the game is for you.

Many people are encountering issues on their systems but my system (2080 ti i7-9700k win 10 1080p) is running smoothly at 160+ FPS.  Please do your due diligence and look at system req's etc. before buying the game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
So, for some reason corpses can explode and become atomic bombs so i was helping this dude take a corpse to the incinerator for safe disposal but then it started raining and some handtand-walking invisible ghost things showed up.. long story short, i have no belly-button and there's a baby in my throat. 10 out of 10 must play. 

on a more serious note, if this is a walking simulator its the gran turismo masterpiece of walking simulators, mixed in with a collectathon game and some stealth elements.. kojimas weird bullshit is sprinkled in and i love it but there's not a whole lot of story, its mostly traversing terrain filled with challenges and unlocking gear to make your task easier and help others in a pseudo dark souls online experience (leaving messages and helping others build things)

its also trippy as fuck, go in blind, dont watch spoilers or the trailers, just go in.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I've played and finished this game on console but decided to double-dip.

Death Stranding is a beautifully atmospheric, third-person action adventure in which your main task is to deliver cargo in as good condition as possible to isolated bunkers across a post-apocalyptic USA, interestingly stylized after Iceland's landscapes mixed in with sci-fi and supernatural elements.

From the mossy landscape to Sam's suit and the ridiculously tall stack of boxes he can carry on his back, the look of DS's world and art style is strangely memorable and identifiable, despite appearing very desolate and naturalistic much of the time. Rain ("Timefall") makes everything age faster, plus there are BTs (short for "Beached Things", they're ghost-like beings from another dimension) roaming the wild, so people are afraid to even go outside. This gives couriers -- or porters, as they're also called in-game -- great importance in this universe.

It's a world that's become largely uninhabited, and with the exception of rare wandering fellow NPC porters and MULEs (human enemies) which will try to steal your cargo if you come too close to one of their encampments, you'll spend most of the time all by yourself. MGSV -- Kojima's previous and first attempt at directing an open world game -- often was criticized for its environments feeling rather "empty" and dull for how big they were. But in the case of Death Stranding, the world feels more dense and detailed and even the slight changes in terrain can affect the moment-to-moment gameplay because of how the movement works. Plus, that sense of loneliness not only fits but also enhances the setting and theme quite nicely. In that sense, Death Stranding has a more well-realized and coherent vision than MGSV.

On your journey, there will be some relief offered by signs and structures shared by other players online, but I'd go as far as to argue that further increases the feeling of solitude and melancholy peacefulness; there's never a "true" interaction with another person, only what they've left behind, even if their contributions can be extremely helpful.

The little action and combat there is feels pretty average and serviceable at best, to be honest. While I haven't thoroughly tested the new 'Very Hard' difficulty yet, most boss fights weren't exciting even on 'Hard'; they're just slow in their reactions and animations and they act like damage sponges more than anything.
Instead, DS is first and foremost a game about planning routes, resource management and traversal by vehicle or on-foot with a variety of tools to help the player overcome obstacles in the environment, with a couple of interesting ideas for stealth.

I'm not too interested in analyzing the narrative/plot in a game (also given the fact that most cutscenes and dialogue are easily and quickly skippable in DS, that might be one of the reasons why it clicks with me more than most other narrative-driven games), but nevertheless, there's this short quote from a review which sums up my personal feelings really well:
[i]"[...] and a story that - while messy - has a sweet emotional core that’s likely to stick with players long after the credits roll."[/i]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1]Death Stranding puts on display elements that would otherwise go unnoticed in other video games.[/h1]

(Completed this game on the PS4)

During these times, I believe you will be able to draw many similarities between the world of Death Stranding and ours.

You have probably already heard people throw around terms like “walking simulator”, “zero-gameplay” and my personal favorite - “pretentious” regarding this game. In the end, who am I to say that these people are wrong? Death Stranding is certainly one of the most divisive titles of 2019, and when you consider the immense popularity of Hideo Kojima, paired with the revered but cancelled ‘Silent Hills’ game that preceded it, it’s not hard to see why this game was bound to receive both massive praise, and bitter hatred. [b]I am not implying this game bears any resemblance to silent hills; it does not.[/b]

I am not going to spoil anything in this review, so I will not talk about what happens in the game. Besides, I do not feel my experience with the story will reflect what you will experience yourself. What I will say, however, is that Death Stranding was one of the most graphically impressive games I had ever played on the PS4, and seeing this game running on my PC in all it’s glory managed to blow me away again (Or maybe that’s just the exhaust from my PC). The soundtrack is phenomenal and does a great job of connecting the player emotionally to what is unfolding around them. The voice acting is obviously top-notch, and the characters themselves are brought to life with fantastic motion capturing. 

What I cannot deny, however, is the complexity of the story. If there are two words I would use to describe it, it would be “multi-layered”, and like an onion, you must peel back these layers if you are to appreciate the detail and virtuosity in the storytelling at play here. In saying that, I don’t agree with the premise that those who don’t like the game are “too stupid” or don’t appreciate Kojima’s message, I’ve met plenty of other people that loved the story, but hated the game. If you find yourself playing through the game and not understanding a thing, do not feel bad, I think most of us at certain points were wondering what the hell was going on.

Which brings me to my final point – the gameplay. It is frustrating, but not all bad. For the most part, the controls work intuitively enough that you do not quite feel like throwing your controller/keyboard at the screen. I thoroughly enjoyed exploring the landscape and finding the collectibles scattered throughout, and I enjoyed completing the “side-quests”. However, vehicle handling and balance are both equally frustrating, and the combat feels clunky and unrefined.

TL;DR – The game is not for everyone. In the beginning, learning the mechanics will be frustrating, and some design decisions will leave you scratching your head. That aside, the storytelling is captivating, the characters are life-like and relatable, and the visuals are outstanding.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
A non-standard game with a triple A budget, was my GOTY for 2019 on PS4 and doing a second playthrough just makes me respect it more. Whatever you think you know you've heard of this game from comedy youtubers or hot take twitter losers, you have to give it a proper try considering it's the first 'strand-type' game. 

Also, calling it a walking simulator is both on point and removes justice for it. Unlike other games in the 'walking simulator' category, this game actually does simulate walking to the point where the balance of your cargo or where you're stepping will affect your ability to walk, and watching your footing is actually important in this.
