title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
BEAUTIFUL BREATHTAKING ART!!!!!  I interrupted my game to write this review. I'm only 10 min into the game, but I know I will absolutely love this game. I paid for the art, scenery, actors and soundtrack. This is not a type of game where you just  mindlessly blow things up and level experience.  It's a cinematic journey.   I think everyone can truly appreciate this game from an artistic standpoint.

Edit: 3 hours in, I highly recommend everyone play this on an OLED gaming T.V., like LG CX or Sony Bravia.  Turn on Ray Tracing and prepared to be blown away.  I have a Ryzen 5 OC'd to 4.2 and a  RTX 2080 Super, with Ray Tracing on Performance mode with every single setting maxed on 4k,  I am currently getting 104 FPS average. The RTX 2080ti should be able to push this over 120 FPS average!!  The soundtrack is so amazing, comparable to the 2013 movie "Oblivion" soundtrack by M83.  That combined with over 100 FPS in 4k, prepare to be blown away.

Things I've learned from the first 90 minutes of playing Death Stranding:

1. Babies help me see dead people
2. Norman Reedus appears to have had a C-Section and I have a lot of questions about that.
3. Carrying a dead body is the equivalent of carrying a nuclear warhead.
4.  North America looks a lot like Ireland. 

It's a beautiful game to be sure. However, if you're all about the destination and not the journey, you'll probably hate this "game". 

I recommend.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is a great game, Hideo Kojima has brought this peaceful and innovative idea of connecting, building and constructing a broken world to his team and then they have made this real for the world.

I haven't finished this game yet; but what I can guarantee you are: it has beautiful scenery, great dramatic performance, it provides you with a very authentic and unique experience. 

Yes it has lots of terms and jargons, which might be hard to understand at the beginning stage, yet soon all of them will be very well explained by its great script writing, also because most of them are supported with rich, meaningful cultural references in our world.

Still there are some major problems, the one that I am having here is, when I put some objects of a standard handling mission to a postbox, the game will just stuck at the Connecting page, like forever (a postbox in a death stranding, man). This is obviously a bug, it needs to be fixed. Please notice this problem.

Thank you Hideo! And many thanks to each one of you and all of you, who have contributed your life and energy to this wonderful creation!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding is a modern day gaming masterpiece.  It is a masterful combination of beautiful visuals, epic music and brilliant story telling.  I think gamers needed this game so that they can experience something other than your typical shallow, soulless shooter (which I do enjoy as well).   This is more like being part of an art piece, or movie - you don't play this game, you experience it.

I've seen this referred to as a "walking simulator" and while that can be an easy description, you'd be missing the point entirely.  Turn out the lights, turn up the volume and immerse yourself in the life of "Sam" and his journey though a wasteland of complexity and the unexpected. You will not be disappointed.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Holy shit, this game is actually pretty good. From trailers it looked like a "walking simulator" actually it still looks like it, but the story and gameplay in between "walking" is very interesting and good made. I guess it's true what they say about Kojima's talent for making games.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Japanese games always seem so odd ... I mean how can you call a character "Mama" ?

now lets ignore the odd stuff in the game and so far focuse on the gameplay...

If you like Relaxing game with scary sneaking section that might get your heart pumping then this game should be for you.. Because thats what most of the game is about .. waling . sneaking and walking .. From time to time you are forced to fight but its not to bad. The story while hard to adjust how odd stuff is in it since its a Kojima game.. Its not to bad so far.

The game is on a technical quite impressing .. i am using what ?18-20 % of my GPU with pretty good fps ( above 60 FPS ) with everything maxed out on a 32 inch 2k screen ... The game looks extremely well and only CPU seems to get some harsher work. For what there is in the game the game looks quite impressing and even more impressing that my GPU seems to fall alseep and my GPU fans dont even spin up ? ... i find this really wierd that this is even possible.

Personally i like the gameplay but its sure not for everyone. So this game gets a recommend from me.

The online feature while only syncing some random structures are pretty cool too.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: (I played the game on PS4 and liked it enough to double dip) 2020 Simulator. A beautiful and deeply weird game with story elements that find a unique balance between "cool" and "cringe." It's often described as a walking simulator but that's a bit reductive- yes, the gameplay revolves around traveling between locations, but it's deeper and more detailed than any other game tagged as a walking simulator. There really isn't any other game like Death Stranding, and while it's not going to be for everyone, it's a very chill, meditative experience, punctuated by moments too bizarre to spoil. A perfect game to play while listening to a podcast, watching a stream, or hiding in our bunkers from whatever horror 2020 has waiting around the corner for us.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Special, but great. (I already played the PS4 version, I just wanted to have the game on Steam)
Some people call this game a walking simulator, and eventho this is what you do most of the time, it is way more then this. Kojimas storytelling and writing is amazing, the voiceacting is great, the cutscenes are are huge part of the game and are amazing and transition into Gameplay well. Eventho some might call the gameplay boring and annoying, I think it's pretty good, since exploring this wonderfully depressing world is great. The world is great, because together with the "monsters" and the events happening on it it gives you this feeling of unease, and also the landscapes really just look beautiful. The soundtrack is really good and the way it works with the world kinda reminds me of silent hill. The online feature is useful and a good idea, but I personally don't like playing with it because it kind of ruins the immersion for me. The monsters in this game are really good mostly because most of them lack any special particularities. A gigantic full black monster, even without any real features or just a straight up insisible monster is way more terrifieng then any skeleton or ghoul could ever be and they work really well with the lost depressing world.
I would say that this game is kinda like an interactive movie. 
Should you buy it? Well, if you don't have high patience this game might be boring for you. 
But if you like Kojimas writing, can tolarate some repetative gameplay and like amazing stories in video games, you really should buy this game.
(Also Sam is one of the most amazing videogame charackters ever created)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Got ~ 80 hours on PS4 for this bad boy.
Fantastic worldbuilding, really intriguing story from beginning to end.
Looking for the best way to transport the most deliveries at once is fun!
During all the point A to point B work, you're already planning on how to expand your infrastructure and manage future orders.

The PC version offers everything I could wish for, getting a steady 120 fps on 1440p and about 50 in 4k. Graphics Settings could be a bit more advanced, just left it on Default with TAA, no Motion Blur.
Everything looks cleaner without the checkerboard 4k of the PS4 Pro, really pleased with the visuals.
Thanks Kojima!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is possibly the hardest game to review, because on paper this game sounds really boring and tedious. But I can assure you, there is something ominously attractive about this game. Not only is it absolutely stunning in terms of visual quality, it also runs incredibly well with mediocre computer hardware. The story (So far) is thrilling, enigmatic and leaves you wanting to delve even deeper into the rich story and excellent cinematography. 

As for the gameplay, it is described as a "Walking Simulator" which is simultaneously accurate and dead wrong. You would be surprised how many factors go into "just walking from point A to point B", such as.... How many ladders should I bring (Each taking up valuable cargo space)? Will I need to cross through hostile territory? Will I need to cross rivers or large ravines? If I need to go through hostile territory would it be safer to take one large haul and risk not being able to outrun my enemies or should I take 2 separate deliveries which can allow me to run faster and possibly escape losing all my loot? All these and many many more.

The variety of situations you can land yourself in this game are seemingly endless and each decision you make can vastly affect the outcome of your deliveries. This is supported by the games (sometimes overwhelming) incredibly versatile and complex menu systems. Each piece of cargo can be carefully stored in different ways on your body, allowing for maximum efficiency when it comes to carrying large stacks of cargo at once. This also includes the use of vehicles, tools and weapons to take the approach that you want to take. 

All this and I haven't even mentioned that this game has online elements! There is no direct interaction between players, but instead the game utilises a system that allows for player's ladders, postage boxes, climbing ropes and even BRIDGES to carry across each others worlds. If there is a large river in a particular section of the map that is commonly crossed, you can guarantee that the community has collaborated to aid in the construction of a bridge that can allow players to safely cross. You don't see other peoples creations until you reach a specific building in that sector of the map, so the first time you enter an area you are made to adapt using only the tools in your disposal but once you reach the building, you can make use of the player created objects. This makes for easier trips when you have to go back and forth and really brings a sense of collaboration to the game.

Overall, I would highly recommend getting this game. Not only is it amazing from a gameplay perspective, but the story is one hell of a ride that not many other games can give you. This game can be and SHOULD be GOTY with this PC release. Trust me, you will get hooked a lot quicker than you expect.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
At this moment, I cannot recommend this game. I'm pretty sure it is fantastic and stuff, but...

[h1]It doesn't even launch and doesn't even display an error message that would explain why[/h1]

For such a premium priced game, the support for it is a joke.

The devs keep redirecting annoyed users from Steam forums to their website, probably to keep things behind closed doors as an attempt to cover up that they messed up. This would have been fine if they weren't ignoring people who need help. Customer support responses are as generic and as unhelpful as everywhere else and users who run into issues are left to their own devices. Every single response is literally identical - a redirect to the "Can You Run It?" website and a request for a dxdiag file, then silence. Wrote 6 messages to them after sending them the dxdiag file and waited for 12 hours - no response whatsoever. Absolute garbage.

One hypothesis among users is that the game doesn't support SSE-architecture processors (which are a standard in household computers), instead requiring AVX processors (usually found in laboratories and professional rigs intended for creative and scientific purposes). However, some users say that they are able to launch DS on SSE processors, and some say that despite having AVX processors, they still can't launch the game, so it might be dubious. This makes things even worse, as the game goes from [i]not-launching-due-to-a-pinpointed-but-hidden-reason[/i] to [i]not-launching-for-no-apparent-reason.[/i]

There are other issues which I couldn't run into due to the above reasons, like graphical glitches involving messy textures and weird physics which also didn't get addressed by 505 Games.

If this doesn't get addressed in the following 48 hours, I am refunding the game and I [b]highly recommend others who have the same issues to do the same[/b]. Developers won't do anything if we don't put pressure on them. Taking away "their" money from them is going to hurt.

PS. I paid 65 dollars for this game.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
To preface this review, Death Stranding was my GOTY for 2019. I put about 80 hours into the PS4 version of the game, a good majority of that time being spent reading the in-game lore notes. I absolutely adore this game. I am, however, incredibly biased, and am prone to overlooking moments of frustration I had while playing it simply because I found the overall package to be a net positive in every department. The question is, will you, potential reader, have the same amount of enjoyment as I did?

To get it out of the way and give you the short answer, no. But that's because I'm an obsessive weirdo. That doesn't mean you shouldn't give the game a chance though. While the initial 4-5 hours of the game are daunting, the gameplay builds upon itself, giving you more tools to work with, making the task of delivering packages easier with every mission you complete. If you allow yourself to engage with the mechanics, you'll find yourself carrying three times the load you should be allowed to, and still delivering well within the allotted time needed for a timed mission. Planning out routes, and executing them all while avoiding terrorists and tar ghosts is exhilarating despite the core gameplay boiling down to UPS routes. Topping it all off, there's a great sense of community, where helping each other out is mutually beneficial to all parties involved. Building structures helps you in the short run, but will have lasting impacts on the world helping other's out in the long run. Helping finish other porters' delivery routes nets them some bonuses as well as helps yourself as well. To go into every single thing that your actions affect for others would take too long, and ruin many of the genuine surprises, so take my word for it that even casually playing is helpful for just about everyone. 

To abruptly come to an end, I have to just reiterate that there's hardly a game like it out there, and is absolutely worth your time.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
☆☆☆☆☆
 5 Stars

It's dark outside. raining. you can't remember what day it is or if anything matters anymore. "Anything You Need" by Low Roar comes on as you climb your way up the mountain. All of your problems go away. It's 3AM and you're 16 again, staring at a screen burning your eyes. Death Stranding is not a game. It's an experience. It's staying up late Friday nights and watching Saturday morning cartoons in your pajamas. It's the day you got home and put in COD MW2 for the first time. This experience will not be for everyone, but it is fantastic for me. If you enjoy the thought of drifting away into long useless gameplay of not doing much of anything, and wondering where all the time went, then Death Stranding is for you. I haven't felt this way since the first Mass Effect. Reviews online do not do this game justice. The textures are a bit muddy and my framerate doesn't hit 144fps like I wanted it to, but for some reason I don't care.  I turned off my framerate monitoring software, picked up a controller, and loved every minute of the seven hours i've put into this game so far. This is without a doubt one of the greatest games I have ever played. When my friends aren't online for COD MW I will be playing this without a doubt. Thanks for making this grown man cry from the release of my pain for a few short hours. 

P.S. If you don't like the idea of a hellblade\mail delivery\walking simulator that eats up time then you will hate this game

it's 3:16AM: Let's see if I can get some sleep now

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
First of. I clearly haven't played that much in this game, just the literal beginning, But I must say this, and I will keep this review updated while I go through the game. 

 With an Intel 8700k (stock)
2080 (stock)
32gb ram
SSD
Acer Predator 144mz G-sync monitor 1440p. 

This is an excellent Port. The best I have possibly ever seen. I have all settings maxed out and I am getting 60-70 FPS. And this is with DLSS 2.0. And everything else maxed out and switched on (Motion blur off though) 

The game is VERY stable, VERY smooth, Keyboard and mice input is fantastic and responsive. Its not half arsed. Kojima did an EXCELLENT job on porting this console game into a PC game. You wouldn't think this was a Console port at all. You would think this was a 100% PC game and built for PC. So far. 

Will keep this review updated as I go along the story.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Played and beat the game on PS4 already, double dipped on the PC release. Overall a solid port, with some flaws. Both unique to this new port, as well as baked into the game itself. I highly recommend the game, but one should probably watch gameplay and look into what the game is, as a lot of the game's unique charm can either be incredibly appealing or a huge turnoff depending on the person.

The Good:
-Good mix of lows and highs in action. Walking around and delivering cargo is a very relaxing experience, until raiders and ghosts start giving you trouble.
-Good progression on gear. As you have longer stretches of terrain and higher mountains to deal with, you unlock gear to deal with it at a pretty good rate.
-Good story. Has some of the dumbness Kojima plots are notorious for, but the characters are overall very good, the story is very internally consistent, and it's interesting to see it unfold. For the most part. It's no Metal Gear Solid 3, but it does a great job all the same.
-Very impressive visuals, for the most part. More on that in a bit.
-Incredible soundtrack by Low Roar, CHVRCHES, and Ludvig Forssell. Might cause issues for Youtubers and streamers due to licensed music, but at least it sounds really, really good.
-Nice implementation of asymmetric multiplayer, in that other player's structures can help you out in a pinch, and vice-versa.

The Bad:
-Very, very slow start. Most of the criticism I see are from people who couldn't get past the first couple hours. And I can't really blame them, the game starts on a MASSIVE plot dump, and the gameplay doesn't really pick up until after.
-PC port needs work. It's really good, but far from perfect. Seeing people complain of bugs, and even on my high end PC I got stutters and frame drops. Seeing reports of crashes, particularly around the WInd Farm. The Graphics settings are also somewhat unclear (Medium, Default, Ultra High? What does Default setting even do?). A really good start, as far as console ports go, but it needs work.

The "Hard-to-explain":
-The walking, and delivery aspects of the game. It's very unique, and has a surprising amount of depth to it. But it's very much a "you'll either love it or hate it" sort of thing. I for one loved it, but it's hard to say if anyone else will unless they try it for themselves.
-The grind. Another "love it or hate it" aspect integral to the game. A lot of progression is tied to getting Likes, raising your ranking with various outposts by doing deliveries, and grinding up loads of crafting materials by, again, delivering parcels from the overworld. There's also a lot of back and forth, particularly when you try to build a highway. Take the game slow, and you'll have a great time. But if you want nonstop combat and ghost attacks, you'll likely be disappointed.
-Dialogue, and Kojima's penchant for overwriting scenes. Particularly at the start of the game, where characters will beat you over the head with things the player already knows. It gets better, and the characters become a lot more interesting later, but again, the start of the game is where most of the bad parts of the game are abundant.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
If you like weird Japanese things like Evangelion, JoJo's Bizarre Adventure, or nerdy sci fi classics like Half-Life, you will 100% enjoy this game. It is not for everyone as MANY other people have said, but if you like REALLY WIERD and bizarre Japanese experiences you will appreciate this game. 

The first 8 hours is not a slog. This game is a primarily story driven game, and the term "walking simulator" is not completely accurate because the movement is a lot more nuanced than you think. You have to balance yourself and scan the path for smooth terrain and plot your route. It is way more involved than just walking. You will have to be stealthy and avoid enemies and decide whether or not to carry extra packages or not.

Helping players is also extremely gratifying. The fact that you can put a rope down a mountain to help other players out from climbing something that took you 15 minutes is so satisfying. This game is all about bringing people together through struggle. 

The main story is can also be directly applied to our current society as it is going through corona. Nobody can be outside. You have to burn bodies or very bad things will happen.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] A far from perfect game, but if you're in the right mood, the game will take you for quite the ride.  [/h1]

[h1] What I think of the gameplay [/h1]

The story is beautiful and will definitely pull on your heart strings multiple times, but the gameplay loop can be a bit mundane at times.  Many tend to think of this game as a walking simulator, and although I agree that the the times of silence you have between missions can be a bit tedious, they can also be very atmospheric, and can be appreciated at times.  All of the intricate gameplay systems that are in place can add a lot of enjoyment to the game, such as finding vehicles, or setting up transportation across the map, such as building roads or using ziplines to get around the map.  The fun that exists within the game world doesn't immediately present itself, but if you're willing to put in the work, it can be quite the riveting experience.

[h1] What I think of the story [/h1]

I think Death Stranding has the most beautiful and cohesive Kojima story to date.  It's much more difficult to quantify how good the story beats are compared to the gameplay, but if I'm going to be honest, this game had me in tears many times when I played it back on PS4.  This game does an amazing job at giving its small cast of characters very unique personalities, and each of them gets their own time to shine in various quirky ways.  The story can be very confusing to say the least, but if you pay attention to details well, they explain what is happening in the world very clearly.  The mystery behind the Death Stranding itself was a not so stunning revelation, but learning the true intentions behind certain characters and why they act is one of the main appeals of this game's characters to me.

[h1] What I think of the PC port [/h1]

The port itself is less than stellar from a technical standpoint.  It is optimized relatively well, and you can still get a more than acceptable framerate at 1080p, max settings, even with a dated PC like mine, but there are some issues.  Mainly, cutscenes are locked at 60 FPS, and can dip lower, which is very disappointing.  I have a high refresh rate monitor, and it's jarring going from cuttingly smooth gameplay to suddenly seeing the framerate halved at random.  Some of the texture quality can suffer as well, and there is some pop-in, which didn't exist in the PS4 version, and cannot be solved by changing graphics settings on PC.

On a side note, some users have complained about not being able to change sound levels in-game, but for me personally, it's no bother, but still something to keep in mind for those with sensitive ears.

[b] Overall, Death Stranding is an amazing experience, but it's not something that I would personally recommend to someone who isn't already familiar with Kojima's work.  The game is so radically different than anything released to date, and because of that fact, I think that there is some serious intrinsic quality to the game, and it's worth at least trying out if you're tired of the majority of modern triple A releases.  [/b]

review: One of the best ports of a Japanese game I've played yet. It's not for everyone but I loved it on PS4. Turn DLSS and anti aliasing off, this gives the game a smooth look without ghosting. The only big criticism I have is the way DOF is implemented, it still uses the low rez scale from the PS4. You can turn off depth of field in gameplay which I appreciate, but not in cutscenes. This is the main thing I hope gets improved in the update, either let me disable it in scenes or upscale the effect. Other than that it all runs smoothly, even at max settings. I hope the community stays active and updates / mods come out soon. Great port.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I wanted to give this game a thumbs up but I really can't. The only reason it is a AAA $60 game is cause its using real life TV actors as avatars - producers must have to pay those actors well for this. 

PROS:
-Runs really nice on my super high-end-gaming-rig - 60-75 fps.
-Avatar animations are extremely fluid.
-Music background and songs are well tuned to set the mood - the songs are great.

CONS:
-Graphics - though thee landscapes are well done - ACO, Witcher (other AAA games) beat this game hands-down detailed wise - no ray-tracing - no night/day, painted ground - for a 2020 release RTX cards want to eat superb graphics and in my opinion this game does not deliver it or even close,
-Menus - The are SO confusing - ex: accept a job - takes you to a fabrication menu and no clue how to get out of it to get to a menu where you actually start a mission. (I finally figured it out but it was frustrating as hell). Then you run into other menus that take you to other menus that you loose the objective of the very first menu - totally TOTALLY bad design.
-Story: so far all  I have been doing is running from point A to B to C etc - not even an auto-run option either. You are alone with a baby in a enclosure strapped to your chest who starts crying a lot. 
-Gameplay: This is more of a interactive movie as there are a lot of long cut scenes, then you get to run from point A to B, rinse and repeat.

Not sure why there are so many thumbs up reviews here but this game is too expensive -not graphically current -annoying menus -not mush content except running a lot.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Sublime in its simplicity all the while surprising in the depths of its intricacies. 

The Man known as Hideo Kojima and his merry band of magnificent misfits have produced another masterpiece. You can disagree with choices made in regards to the writing or decisions in story telling, but there is no denying the sheer sense of scale and wonder on display here. In a world where everyone likes to think they are unique and talented Kojima never fails to make it seem effortless. 

I will never look at open world games the same, If you enjoy a grand mystery with fear,physics,and weight a constant fight against your best laid plans with an unhealthy amount of Lovecraftian lunacy, you would be hard pressed to find anything else like it on this planet.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Personally, this is my favorite game of all time! It's Sci-Fi, Post-Apocalyptic and horror mixed with a very strange, but interesting story. Some call it a walking simulator and sometimes i'll admit, it does feel like it, but this game is one of a kind. It's not everyone's cup of tea, but you go into this with an open mind and it should blow you away. There's a lot to learn for the story, everyone and everything has an explanation so read the emails, read the interviews and pay attention to why everything is the way it is.

I played this game on PS4 Pro and i was mezmorized by it so I couldn't wait for it to release on PC! Thanks Kojima!

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
WARNING: In its current state, this game causes some players to experience frequent, unpredictable crashes to desktop. And I do mean frequent: expect to crash multiple times between any two neighbouring outposts, and to end up re-watching every segment of cutscene several times before you finally get lucky enough to see the whole thing. (Fortunate indeed that the cutscenes [i]are[/i] segmented! -- it meant that once I finally got through one segment I could skip it on future attempts.) I'm running this on a bog standard ASUS gaming laptop that can handle it just fine for the most part, and I've tried every suggested fix and then some, but the crashes are still happening.

I'm sure this review will change to positive once the fix is in. Heck, I'm choosing to slog through the crashes instead of get a refund because I've been waiting for this game for months and can't be bothered to wait any longer. But in a game that's already about long slogs, forcing players to repeat progress they've already made is just bad form.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Death Stranding, is a fantastic Delivery Action RPG (Strand-Type Game) that while seen as overwhelmingly complex by outsiders, is yet deceptively simple. Now, I may only have 10 hours on the game (which is nowhere near completion) but I can speak on my prior experience on PS4. This game provides a very unusual story, I will not talk on spoilers but the story is A plus, straight out of a David Lynch film. Sam's journey across America is arduous and otherworldly, the twists and turns are surprising and admittedly long, but all is well in the end with the amazing payoff of an ending. 

Now, the gameplay is fantastic, best experienced here on PC. It offers a fun and challenging delivery simulator mixed with very well streamlined stealth combat. To describe it simply, Death Stranding takes the best of the disappointing Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain and works upon it so well to deliver an amazing experience that offers hours of enjoyment and customization, this game offers a truly open, yet somehow still linear world of exploration, combat and connection. I cannot recommend this otherworldly experience enough. 10/10, possibly my favorite game.

I'm loving it, but I know a lot of people that absolutely detest it.
It's definitely not everyone's cup of tea.

Buy if you like walking from point A to B, while traversing difficult terrain.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Kojima has done it again. Made a beautiful game with amazing environmental work and a lot of detail was put in. This game may not be for everyone but i know for sure it is for me. Sure it may be a "Walking simulator" but this "Walking simulator" has story, it has character development and beautiful environments to go through. This game isnt just about walking and delivering, its also about connecting and becoming one with mankind. And even if this is just a walking simulator, its much more story driven and entertaining than some train or golf simulator. Overall i would highly recommend if you love beautiful and rich story telling with amazing open world access and very very fitting music. But if not than all i can say is give it a shot and if you dont like it just refund it simple as that. 

Anyways i really do hope that this will be the start of kojimas everlasting success as a videogame designer.
Also shoutout to the amazing YojiShinkawa for staying with kojima ever since metal gear love you guys no homo.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: First note that I have never played a MGS title so I am coming to this blind, no fan-boy here. This game actually made me research who the heck Kojima is, which I am now embarrassed that I had to in 2020. Read some reviews, read "walking simulator" (EEECK!). Figured, why not, he seems like a renowned game maker . So far, never thought I would enjoy taking one package or stuff folks drop to their destination. Some folks gripping about the story. So far, no gripes from me. Been a while since a game's story took me in as fast as this one with the constant wondering of WTF is going on with sprinkles of the answers here and there. For all the gripes in performance, have only experienced vary slight and for just a few seconds, stutter during a cutscene, during the beginning of the game, around the time where he almost falls off the edge on his bike. That's it. Running on 4K, (i9/RTX 2070 Super). Go into this with an open mind, especially if you are a fan-boy, realizing that this is a Japanese title and the conventions of our culture's scenematics are completely different. You can't judge this with our western standards.

It's still early goings with respect to where I'm at in the story...I'm starting to form a theory about what's happening/happened, but I digress.

The game is polished and while it's mechanics could be considered repetitive, the overall execution of said mechanics within the world feel great and immersive.

While others may take issue, I enjoy a good soundtrack and I was surprised when the game first "deploys" music during a trek in the first hours of play, as it made the circumstances feel weighted...nice touch.

Technically, the game runs butter smooth using DLSS at highest setting, with great use of HDR.

I love enjoy the games outlandish quirks, preposterous premise(s) and the solid character acting from everyone that's turned up so far, and I know I'll continue to enjoy the ride until the end.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I was very worried that this was going to be a walking simulator, as I had done a good job of avoiding all spoilers and only seeing a few memes between the game releasing on console and today. However, I'm pleasantly surprised to find out that no, it's not a walking simulator, and there's a lot to the game.

You do walk a lot though. That's the base gameplay. Pick up a package, take it somewhere else. What makes it interesting is everything that can go wrong on the way there. The terrain may be more difficult than you expected, and what looked like a straightforward route on the map is blocked by a cliff face you have to figure out how to ascend. You may run into package stealing jerks called MULES or those weird umbilical cord ghost things from the trailers (BTs), who are both dealt with in a very Kojima way - MGS style stealth or overwhelming (nonlethal) violence. I've walked, ran, and fought a lot at this point, and ~12 hours in the game remains interesting.

Oh, right, it's also a Kojima game. If you don't like cutscenes, weird setting specific terminology that's never exactly explained, and exploration of contemporary issues, then you won't like the story side of the game.

As for complaints about poor performance: I'm running this with a Ryzen 5 2600, 16 GB of RAM, and the 6 GB version of the GTX 1060. So far I've had a smooth 60 FPS for the majority of the game, with the occasional dip into 50 - 55ish during particularly particle filled action scenes.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is a criminally underrated and misunderstood game. When it came out, many called it a "walking simulator" and acted as though it had no real depth or complexity. In reality, this couldn't be further from the truth -- strategically planning your routes and trying to safely and smartly navigate the harsh terrain is actually incredibly engaging, fun and rewarding. It may be a "walking simulator," but it's easily the most tactical and mechanically deep walking sim ever made. The game offers a ton of different tools and gadgets you can use to keep the game fresh, and has an incredibly unique multiplayer system where the items you place also show up for other players. You can build and contribute to other player's bridges and highways; the entire game is essentially a collaborative effort to turn a ruined world back into civilization. If this wasn't good enough, the game also has really intense horror stealth segments with the BTs, and more conventional stealth straight out of Metal Gear with the Mule outposts.

The story itself isn't perfect, but it [i]is[/i] incredibly unique, ambitious, and prophetic. Since the outbreak of COVID, a world where people rely entirely on UPS and are afraid to go outside suddenly makes a lot more sense. This game has a lot to say about isolation, social media, society, and video games in general. While most video games are about combat and competition, Death Stranding is about connecting with others, contributing to a community, and working together towards a common goal. This is not a game about making yourself stronger; it's a game about improving the world around you. The sheer ambition of the story [i]does[/i] cause some issues overall though, as the narrative sometimes suffers from weird convoluted logic and plot holes. If you can bear with the absurdity, you'll find a lot to enjoy, and a lot to think about.

Overall, if you're interested in the core concept, this is a fantastic port and the game is absolutely worth full price. If none of this sounds interesting or appealing to you, you should probably wait for a sale. Overall though, I think this is one of the most interesting and thought provoking games in recent memory and it's an experience you certainly won't get anywhere else.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's focken good so far alright.

For real tho, I've been losing interest in gaming over the past year, partly maybe because new games released are often times reincarnations of old classics that have been evolving the monotone way. HOWEVER, I have not for a long time had a game that has hooked me so much instantly. I played like 9 hours straight after buying it so rip my sleep schedule.

Look, it sounds really boring and I believe it can be boring for certain people. It's basically a glorified walking simulator with a story behind it. But there is a lot more behind that boring concept, trust me. It's not worth explaining it because it's rather complex and a lot more fun when you experience it yourself.

In short terms: You are a courier who brings stuff from A to B to C and back in a post-apocalyptic world with dangers. You have to balance out your load, think when and where to store it and plan your routes over different terrain depending on the amount of stuff your fat ass is hauling.

I've only gotten a few hours in so I prolly have just scratched the surface. There are minor annoyances like my mouse cursor keeps clipping in even tho I have a controller connected or not being able to play the epic soundtrack on command. HOWEVER I think the last bit is done on purpose I'm sure and I'm not gonna hold it against it.

That being said. The whole setting and scenery is epic. The terrain flows beautifully into each other and as a hiking enthusiast the whole planning and hauling is actually just epic. There is different terrain, so far having seen beaches, grassy landscapes, rocky mountains and a DENSE forest. You can indirectly interact with other players and do so many little things that make you appreciate it a whole lot more. The first hour into the game feels like a damn movie it's so epic. You may be walking the same route 10 times or 20 times but you always get to discover new ways to go over the terrain and leave behind a ladder for the next player or yourself. And as you progress you discover new landscapes so it shouldn't get boring.

This comes from someone who isn't biased. I didn't really follow the Death Stranding and only recently realized it gets released on PC soon. It's also the first Hideo Kojima game I've played. 

This review has gotten quite long I'm afraid but I hope I could bring across my first views of the game in the first 9 hours I've played. I will probably look at this again when I finished the game to see if I was as right as I explained it. 
The game was certainly quite expensive (at least for my standards) so you gotta decide yourself if it's worth buying it. If you're not sure first watch a "before you buy" or something although I kind of don't suggest that as for this game, in my opinion, watching gameplay and actually playing it are two COMPLETELY different worlds.

Hope I could help :D

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I have around 150 hours on the PS4 version and platinumed it, so you could say that I enjoy the game very much. 

Death Stranding is unlike any game out there. It's a thought provoking scifi world that brings fresh ideas and themes to the table, with a gameplay loop that's extremely satisfying and relaxing. This is one of those games where the more you put into it, the more satisfaction you'll receive. 

The story gripped me from start to finish. It's hard to comprehend how any individual could come up with this game's setting and scenarios it puts you through, how the world and it's story unravels around you. While there are some moments that I felt the writing could've been improved that's about the extent of my complaints with the game. 

The PC port is phenomenal, I expected nothing less from KojiPro after the masterful port that is MGSV. It runs at a constant 60 fps on ultra at 1440p. 

The further you get into Death Stranding the more tools are at your disposal. The start of the game can be very clunky and tedious, but it's done so on purpose so that you appreciate and enjoy how far you've come when you reach the later stages of the game. You are constantly rewarded, constantly given feedback about everything you do. Giving you that satisfaction and being shown and told how well of a job you're doing, by both the characters and real players. 

The online functionality of this game really took me by surprise regarding my enjoyment of it. I became utterly addicted to creating the roads for the players I shared the same world with, reveling in the amount of Likes players gave me. Something about the melancholic world and tone that harmoniously compliments the online infrastructure of DS. For me at least, it helped me appreciate others, strangers. It helped me feel kindness towards strangers. Similar to the message system of Dark Souls, players can leave messages saying a number of things. Most of what I see are motivational messages left by others to keep pushing forward, it's a unique feeling. 

Music and the use of your soundtrack is one of my favorite elements of gaming. If implemented correctly, the right music at the right time can heighten your sense of emotion. Death Stranding understands that completely. Key parts of the story or environment when triggered will start to play a song, mostly from the band Low Roar. Their music fits the world and message of the game so perfectly it almost seems they were created side by side. The original soundtrack is composed beautifully, as expected from masterclass composer Ludvig Forssell who also created MGSV's score. 

There are many moments in Death Stranding that filled me with awe and a sense of serenity I never thought existed in gaming. Death Stranding is one of my favorite games ever created, and in my opinion one of the best scifi worlds filled with such rich lore ever created. It left me in tears, and in love with the story that KojiPro has told. Most importantly, it has helped me appreciate and show kindness towards complete strangers in a world where it's far too easy to forget that you're not the only one living in it.

review:
First things first: If you hate the idea of truck driving, logistics type games, you're not gonna like this one.

That being said, if you have the patience for a slower paced game with strange but fun social networking mechanics slapped on top of an off-road trucker simulator game (minus the trucks), you might find a gem here that hits a niche not a lot of other games can.

My only complaint so far is that the cities you will visit feel very empty. You'll only see one other person in hologram form in the one building that has any sort of utility for the player. Most of the rest of the city will be inaccessible.
There's plot reasons for it, I believe, but it still feels like you're mostly just carting supplies from one abandoned ghost town to another.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Let me start with the TL;DR - After beating this game on PS4, I put down the controller, walked over to my computer, and - immediately - purchased this game on steam. 

TL;DR over. So, why purchase this for the computer if I've already beaten it? Was it for the wide screen support? The photomode? No, fuck that shit, those things don't really matter. 

I purchased it because, even if I never complete it on the computer, it is well worth supporting because this game is one of the few original and perfectly executed IPs to come out in recent memory. It's not a recycled CoD/HALO/Counterstrike game. It's an entirely new and unique world, built from the ground up, and fully worthy of AAA status....more so than some of the more recent entries in the aforementioned universes.

In other words: it's innovative and not derivative.

Word of caution, if you've heard anything about the game, most of it will probably be true. There is no multiplayer in the traditional sense - it's more like echoes of online players. It is also mainly a logistics game in the sense you are trying to figure out how to move cargo from point X to point Y while not damaging it/reducing the damage sustained. There are Third person shooter mechanics, but there is also a larger emphasis on clever routing/stealth and a potentially game ending mechanic if you go in guns blazing, and it manages to be suspenseful without an overemphasis on violence. Again, it is the worldbuilding that makes this game exceptional, not any one particular mechanic. 

So be aware of all of that before picking it up. It's a unique experience, but it depends on one allowing oneself to be subsumed into the game.
If you can do that, you will be well rewarded.

Also, the soundtrack is BELLISSIMO
---
Also, a word regarding people complaining about crashes and stuttering. As I've mentioned before, I simply do not understand the GenZ/Zennials simps who expect concierge developer support when they are in the minority who can't get their computers to function. If you are unable to get games to work when most everyone can, IT. IS. YOUR. RIG. Which means it is your fault. No, you don't get to demand personalized patches to get your porn riddled computer up and running, that shit is on you, NOT the developer. 

Own it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I doubted Hideo Kojima coz of the extreme difference in PS4 reception, and almost had the game refunded before launch day on Steam.
Yes, this game may not be everyone's taste or those who expect this to be MGS, but honestly this is something new and it lives up to the Kojima legacy.
I love playing games with rich story, playing interactive-movies like Beyond Two Souls & Detroit Become Human, and no one would doubt these games have the best directed cutscenes. Death Stranding pushes it to the next level with the use of different camera positioning and panning, perhaps part of the reason is that Kojima san was so wise to have Oscar winning director Guillermo del Toro onboard, who directed my favorite movie Pacific Rim.
Actors definitely play an important role, who could have ask more from actual movie actors like Norman Reedus, Mads Mikkelsen and Léa Seydoux etc??
DS is the ultimate movie-game experience package to date, well balanced around 40% movie & 60% game.
Game is well optimized on day 1, without the help of DLSS2.0 game runs at average 70fps on a 1080Ti @ 3440*1440.
Many people in the game discussion section complaining about the game runs at weird 21:9 resolution, 3360*1440/2500*1080, I mean that little black border on both sides is not that obvious at all, at least way less annoying than the one on a 16:9 resolution.
Full price (SGD$79.9) may not be ideal in some regions around the globe, but Kojima Production has delivered a fine port to PC players, tailor made specific PC options and exclusive contents, I am very satisfy with what I have paid.
DS certainly has the best graphics among others, perhaps Kojima Production should add a benchmark option in the future, like Horizon Zero Dawn did.
Kojima Production (not 505 Games) should also be praised for the decision to have the game available on several storefronts, however with recent news of Sony investment into Epic, there is uncertainty with future PS exclusive games and I hope that my fellow Steam community will send Sony a strong message with me.



This review will be updated when I get to spend more time into it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I hate to admit it, but I'm having a ton of fun with the game. The story is jumping all over the place but I assume that's intentional and you're not suppose to understand anything that is happening. It's keeping me curious and engaged with the story, plus there is something surreal about delivering cargo from point A to point B. The music is fantastic as well, and I also like the fact that you're assisting other players and vice versa by constructing things. Just a neat feature, kind of like Dark Souls in a way, where players could leave messages to other players. That feature is also in the game as well. You can construct signs to warn or guide other players. Even the little things like being able to take a shower, use the toilet, customize color schemes, etc. All these things I have found to be somewhat comfortable and sometimes I feel like I'm not really playing a video game at all, but I don't mean that in a bad way. I mean that, it sometimes feels like I'm just a delivery man doing his thing. The game doesn't feel stressful, well it can be at times with the cargo weight limit and loadout, but the game gives the player the option to manage their loadout and the game also rewards you for how good of a delivery you make, which encourages people to do a better job. I enjoy the aspect of the game as well. Feels rewarding when the game gives the player a fair reward for a job well done, and as you level up you'll gain access to higher stats and equipment. 

I'm only on chapter two, but I really wasn't expecting to enjoy the game as much as I am right now. It might not be for everyone but this game really goes to show that you can't judge a book by it's cover, which is what a lot of people did, and are currently doing. Sure it's a WALKING SIMULATOR, but oh, it's so much more then that. So much more.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Truly one of a kind, Death Stranding is not a game for everyone. Its slow, dreamlike pace and long stretches without combat may turn some people off, but if you can stick with it, it opens up into something very special indeed. It is a thoroughly unusual experience about the things you can do to make the experience of other players better, and the satisfaction that comes with it. And the combat gets better too : ) 

Having played this on the PS4, I can say that the PC port is a step up in terms of performance, running at well in excess of 100 FPS at max settings on my mid-range hardware. The graphics are good, especially the downright life-like character models, but it isn't as much of a step up from the console version as it could have been.

The game has its flaws, mostly due to the ridiculous amount of hand-holding and over-explanation in the beginning, but I can still recommend Death Stranding to anyone with some patience and a taste for the strange.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This game is literally the perfect sort of game for me. The gameplay isn't as in your face as other games and a lot more about traversing interesting environments and following a weird but interesting story. Minute details are here where fast travelling for example makes sense in the lore. It's these sorts of details that I absolutely love in games. 

The combat is surprisingly fun as well, you have multiple options of how to go around a situation some riskier than others. The multiplayer component to the game is super cool as well as you're helping out other porters on your journey with bridges or generators to recharge your vehicles. You can "like" other peoples tags on the floor and their builds which gives you a boost to stamina or a boost to your BB's happiness.

There are so many cool things in this game it's difficult to talk about as it's something that should just be experienced. I really recommend picking this up and giving it a go. Be patient for the first few hours, it's very heavy on the story at the beginning and might not make much sense however everything in the cutscenes down to the weird random crying or the odd mechanic with the rain all makes sense overtime and are actually super interesting and unique mechanics.

Granted, there have been a lot of people expressing frustration about some graphical or FPS issues. I, myself have not had any of these issues so maybe I got lucky or something idk. If this may turn you off, this will most definitely be fixed at some point (obviously) so for that reason, I can't see why giving it a negative review would make sense.

Also amazing soundtrack :)

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I don't typically play AAA/cinematic style games, especially not at full price on the day of release, but this is not your typical AAA cinematic game. Despite buying it today, I was still skeptical that it would run smoothly and equally skeptical that I would enjoy the basic game mechanics. I didn't bother to throw on an FPS display or anything, but I set everything as high as it would go and my god it looks incredible and runs butter smooth. I'm only in the beginning of Chapter 2, so I can't speak for any deeper mechanics like gunplay and vehicles that come later, but the basic concept of moving along the terrain and keeping balance, holding your breath and sneaking past enemies, etc exceeds my expectations. It was challenging at parts while never really frustrating me. Holding down both mouse buttons at the same time to keep balance does get a bit tedious at times, but that's about the biggest gripe I have with the whole game so far, and it's a pretty small gripe. This is utterly brilliant and absolutely bonkers. To say anything more would spoil what's one of the most breathtakingly unique video games I've ever played. 10/10

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
This is my second copy as I owned the ps4 version but it made my console run so loud it sounded like a jet engine at take off so I quit playing it. Just too loud and immersion breaking.

With that out of the way this game is something quite unique. Its mesmerizing in a way that isnt boring. Yes, the walking simulator analogies are somewhat accurate in a literal sense but at the same time theres something quite satisfying about it. It will be MANY hours in before you get into any proper combat and the journey to that point can be a bit dull but once youre there the encounters open up the mundane traversal that is the early gameplay. Eventually the traversal does indeed become challenging and an integral part of the gameplay and vehicles and weapons become a thing. The asymetrical multiplayer is quite interesting as your creations appear in the worlds of others and theirs in yours but this is no dark souls. The messages that you can leave for other players are quite frankly pretty stupid and serve no real world purpose. It is fun to leave ladders & ropes to nowhere to troll other players but even thet loses its appeal after all the back tracking.
If you want a game to just relax with and enjoy a somewhat convoluted story without worrying about real in depth gameplay then jump right in. If youre looking for good stealth or action then avoid this title.

Kojima is a tallanted individual but a genious? gtfo with that nonsense

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I get that the main gameplay is not for everyone. But to say it's boring and it's just walking is an understatement, unexpectedly (to me anyways) this game has stealth and combat which was a pleasant surprise.

Even then the walking itself requires you to think of how you walk and how you control Sam. It's intuitive and I like it, the ground and environment where you are walking makes a lot of difference in how easy it is to get somewhere, so planning and careful walking pays off in the long run.

You can help other players with various structures and tools, and they can help you in turn. This makes it really nice to see something someone else built that helps you on your journey. I love this aspect of collaboration.

I usually don't like fetch quests, but for some reason Death Stranding makes them feel more meaningful, and fun. That's because it's fun to traverse the world in general.

The soundtrack and sound design is really good as well, but honestly I'm not super well versed on this front so I can't really say more.

On top of all that, this game is gorgeous. On the highest settings with DLSS on 1440p I hit 90+ frames for the most part. I think this is the best looking, best peforming game I have played using my RTX card so far. I'm of the opinion every game should support DLSS 2.0 it's simply that good.

At the moment I'm on chapter 2, been taking my time traversing the world and delivering packages. It's been a blast, can't wait to play more. I might change up my review later on in the game if I feel like it.

I think I prefer this game over Metal Gear Solid V.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: This game is fantastic! Not only is the story interesting, it keeps you constantly on edge and wanting more. The graphics are stunning, and if you can, play with them on the highest settings. The "multiplayer" aspect of the game is unique and helpful but does need a little time to fully understand. If you're looking for a great summer game, this is it.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
After years of asking, we got Death Stranding at last, 8 months after it originally released. This is a monumental occasion, as this is the first true Playstation exclusive to get a PC port, and it won't be the last. So, did Playstation's first outing on PC and Kojima's latest game leave a good first impression? Well the answer, is yes.

Death Stranding...is weird. This game is a dark post apocalyptic courier simulator set decades after a doomsday event caused the afterlife to connect with our world. As a result, undead monsters known as BTs now roam the earth, causing implosions known as voidouts in their wake. The whole world has become isolated as a result, and couriers like your character Sam Porter (played by Norman Reedus) help keep it going with essential and personal deliveries. Kinda reminds you how the world is now huh?

Now let's get this out of the way: You probably heard by trolls a lot to tease Playstation fanboys that it's a "walking simulator." Well...it is true. The game is a walking simulator...But in a good way! What I mean is, this game has one of the most advanced locomotion systems I've ever seen in a video game. It factors in weight, wind, irregularities in the ground, and other outside factors that could mess with your balance, so as you travel you need to maintain your load to make sure you don't drop it. If that wasn't trouble enough, you got BTs to worry about, your own food and drink, and hostile factions who would rather stay sovereign trying to steal your shipment. As you take deliveries making people happy along the way, you will try to get them to rejoin the United Cities of America, rebuilding our shattered nation one package at a time.

But the big thing about Death Stranding, is what Kojima calls the "Social Stranding." Despite the game not having multiplayer, everyone who plays it is connected in some way. You can build structures, roads, leave tools, vehicles, supply caches, and other helpful items around the world in convenient locations to help other players playing like you are. This creates an empathy loop as the whole theme of the game is uniting together to help each other. You will be rewarded for your generousity by other players as well, so remember, united we stand, divided we fall.

Performance wise, it's better than it ever was on PS4 Pro. The game is at 60 FPS and beyond, runs great, looks great, and is solid all around. The only issue, is the fact it has Denuvo, which has it's own problems so if you wanna learn why this DRM is AIDS, Overlord Gaming has a great series on the subject on why PC gamers hate Denuvo.

All and all, this is a great game. It's a nice calming postal walking sim that feels so satisfying everytime you make a delivery making someone happy, or other players happy. Definitely get it, especially if it pushes Sony to release more of their 1st party exclusives over.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Did I finish the game? No. Do I have experience with the PS4 version? No. But I feel like I've reached far enough to give a review/general impressions of the game. 

Main thing off the bat.....is it fun? Well it depends on what kinda mood your in and your tolerance for what I'll call "completing" the game. 
For me, yesterday was the start of my 3 week vacation. Preloaded, got it all ready and went to bed. 10am unpacked it and played for about 5 hours which I will break down now. The first hour was great if your into mysteries and trying to piece things together. After the first long cutscene.....well I kinda was like, "eh I'm over it I just want to bang this one out as soon as I can, get my monies worth and roll on".........then I cracked my first beer. WOW that shit changed everything. Suddenly I was enthralled with the story, Stillmother? What's that? Why is Mads Mickelson in flashbacks? Why does Die Heartman wear that mask....then I cracked the second and third beer. My Girl friend came into the room and started watching....the BTs started to drag me into the black goo, who are these mules? Why does this baby warn me when these BTs are near? I started to pick up more and more loose cargo, then I could pick up lost cargo from other players and started to deliver it. 2 beers later and my title is elite handler. It's great. I would say this game is similar to watching a movie on a walk. It's got enough to keep you engaged but what makes it fun is watching out so you don't walk off a curb into traffic. It's got a strange balance to it. Yes for the most part you picking things up, putting them down. But something about it is fun. 

Graphically (4k very high settings) it's good. I'd still put RDR 2 or FFXV ahead of it graphically (as far as how well it does terrain). Sam has only what I can call a "Doll" like skin to him for some reason. But other then that it's definitely a nice looking game. Nothing ground breaking or hard to run. It gets done what it has to, to get its point and art style across. 

Gameplay.....yeah get used to holding the trigger buttons. The more cargo the more top heavy you become. Staying upright it part of the fun and honestly it's very forgiving. There has been plenty of times I should have gone face first but hitting a rock or something set me upright. But for what you do?......ooooh a piece of candy....oooh a piece of candy.....ooooh a piece of candy. Packages are all over the place and picking them up and delivering them is part of the fun. 

In conclusion, is this like metal gear? Yes, without the guns. The objective is metal gear is "go here, get this, go other there" but with some shooting and sneaking in between. This is just like that without the heavy action. There is action when the BTs show up and drag you away for the first time but after your 3rd go around it's sorta the same. Untill you poop in a bottle and throw it at the enemies (not even a joke, that's 1 of the grandes you can get)  

Get the game, drink some beer, thank your UPS guy or lady, and just chill.

This game "delivers".

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
First of all, I HIGHLY recommend playing with keyboard/mouse controls rather than a controller. I played over 270 hours of this game on PS4 so I can say with confidence that a controller is not the greatest experience. "Walking Simulator" isn't quite an accurate tag, there is a lot more upkeep for ensuring your deliveries go smoothly than that description would make you think, and it's for that reason that you'd probably do better with KB/M controls.

Like I said, I played nearly 300 hours of this on the PS4. I love the game, but it's not perfect. Don't go into it expecting to come out a different person or anything. It's a hell of an experience, story-wise and gameplay-wise, but expecting anything beyond a unique set of game mechanics and a thoughtful story (which can feel vague and stretched thin, but does satisfyingly come together in the end) you're going to be disappointed. It also doesn't take anywhere near 300 hours to complete, I just took the time to try and perfect every delivery I could. I really like the game's aesthetic and content a lot.

Here are some things I liked and disliked about the game:
Likes:
- The game world is beautiful, and it looks even better on PC. The photo mode is great for getting screenshots.
- The soundtrack is great, both the original tracks and licensed tracks by Low Roar (and a few others). The songs pop in during story-related deliveries and it's a very nice mood setter.
- The 'strand' system, or whatever they call the multiplayer aspect, is really satisfying. Getting to see other people's structures makes the environment feel less barren and more collaborative. It's also gratifying to see how others interact with your structures. Don't forget to share likes!
- The story isn't "deep", I'd call it thoughtful. IMO, it's not trying to get your to feel one way or the other, it's more like sharing thoughts aloud, bringing you along for a ride but not being too overt with it's themes. (When I started playing the game in November 2019 a lot of the themes and issues weren't so relevant so you'll probably feel differently /shrug)
-  There's always something new to experience as you make progress. New equipment, new structures, new enemies, it's refreshing but not overwhelming.

Dislikes: 
- Characters repeat themselves too often, and when discussing a seemingly vague concept at times the effect is amplified.
- (Using a controller on PS4) The physics are a bit wonky. You'll learn how to work within the bounds of the game engine eventually, but don't expect Sam to move in predictable ways on complicated terrain. Pro Tip: Just hold a wheelie while riding a trike through rough terrain, steering is sacrificed a bit but holy hell does it improve the ride.
- The difficulty selection is almost 100% exclusively an enemy health bar size selection. AFAIK there are no extra rewards from playing on the higher difficulties (PS4 only had 3 diff's) so save yourself the effort for your first run.
- Some of the equipment in the game is borderline useless. When new things unlock, craft them once and then donate/recycle them if you don't like them, you'll develop our own methods for dealing with issues.
- The weather system is annoying because you have to rely on it for certain deliveries (some packages require being kept cold or being kept warm). Just put those orders off at first, or post up at a hot spring and tab out to watch youtube, idk.

Is it a masterpiece? Eh... no. I love it a lot, like a lot a lot, but it's not at all a perfect game. It's polished as hell, I never experienced any objective 'bugs' beyond some of the engine/physics quirks. The story is fairly well paced with and it DOES in fact have a satisfying conclusion. I think it's greatest value is that it will like affect the games industry in more ways than one. I think we'll start seeing more actors in games, like how Giancarlo Esposito is in FARCRY 6. I think the 'strand system' of multiplayer will be accepted and iterated upon by other games in unique ways. All in all, I'd highly recommend the game and give it an 8/10.

TL;DR 12/10 KOJIMA IS A GOD EVERYTHING HE TOUCHES IS GOLD I AM INCAPABLE OF SEEING FLAWS IN HIS WORK THIS REVIEW IS ALL BIASED SHILLING DON'T YOU DARE CRITICIZE ANYTHING IN THIS GAME

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Have tried this game on PS4 pro and the game is optimized to run at 4K and with HDR support, making you have a movie-level visual experience.  After 8 months, Death Stranding has finally come to PC, and it brings DLSS 2.0 along for the ride and it delivers a serious boost all around. (After testing on RTX 2080 ti, the frame rate was over 100 FPS on 4K max setting.) 
As many predicted, Death Stranding is indeed a post-apocalyptic delivery man experience. The game almost entirely revolves around delivering packages across a desolate but beautiful landscape, as the protagonist Sam Bridges attempts to 'reconnect' a broken America piece by piece.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: The story of UPS, the world's largest package delivery company, began more than a century ago with a $100 loan to jumpstart a tiny messenger service. How we evolved into a multi-billion-dollar global corporation reflects the history of modern transportation, international commerce, logistics and financial services. Today, UPS is customer first, people led, innovation driven. It’s powered by more than 495,000 employees connecting more than 220 nations and territories across roads, rails, air, and ocean. Tomorrow, UPS will continue to lead the industry and connect the world, with a commitment to quality service and environmental sustainability.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
I already got Platinum for this game on the PS4 with over 100hrs for completion, Death Stranding is an experience and it’s something very different, a game that in my opinion creates a new style of game play and storytelling. 
The music selection is perfect and plays at ideal moments giving the player an emotional connection to Sam’s journey.
The story is other worldly yet simple to follow and just adds to such a strange concept for a game, while at the beginning there are many cut scenes, these soon become far less often allowing the player to explore and gain new equipment to traverse the huge environment. 
Keep in mind that Death Stranding is something very different and is a breath of fresh air, some will find it boring because it’s not a shooter and some will not like it because it’s not a RPG, its something new and different.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
Nearly platinumed on PS4, got lazy and distracted by other games. Spent nearly 120 hours on it. tl;dr: 10/10. I would change nothing about the game. [b]Extremely strong recommend.[/b] Excellent port that looks gorgeous with the right hardware.

---

Death Stranding is a really hard game to recommend off-the-cuff. That being said, it is nothing short of a masterpiece of design and storytelling. The gameplay is absurdly unique and acts as less of a focus, but more of a framing around the story and the journey. The story is amazingly well-written and better-than-a-movie quality. tl;dr: This is a must-buy.

Call it a walking simulator if you want, but the whole "99% boredom, 1% sheer terror" meme spawned from EVE Online applies here too-- you're going to be walking around comfy, gorgeous landscapes a lot, seeking out packages and delivering them. Then, every once in a while, either a chance encounter or a bit of story is going to come along and slap you down to the ground, then leave you with some more base gameplay loop to process everything. The pacing is perfect in this regard. 

Early on in the PS4 release, I saw a lot of angry comparisons against MGSV, as if the bad reviews expected Solid Snake to be on the screen fighting spooky ghost babies. [b]MGSV and DS are polar opposites.[/b] While MGSV had a story that was effectively background noise (yeah, sorry MGS fans) vs its amazing gameplay, DS has gameplay that uses itself as the background noise to let you sit and process the story and encounters. 

In short: the game is giving you a chance to think about and figure out what the fuck just happened. You're going to need it.

Anyways, buy Kojima's game. 10/10. Best game I've played in years.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: So this is my first review ever. So many people called this a walking simulator and while it basically is one... There's something so relaxing and fun about walking everywhere figuring out ways to get around the terrain planning out a route with what to bring such as Ladders, Rope and building bridges and other buildings so other players can use. There's no actual multiplayer but there is at the same time. I really like getting notifications about how people liked a bridge i built or a ladder i dropped in a difficult area. I was getting chased by The BT's and i was in a tough spot up on a hill with no way out, just to do a scan and find a rope that a player left with a sign. That was such a big moment for me that i ended up loving the game at that point. I started loving the game for the fact that i was helping other players and not my self. Knowing i can build certain stuff in certain areas to make it easier for other players to have a easier time. The game looks beautiful and runs great, i haven't had any crashes. The Port to PC is one of the better ones i've played. The game is very relaxing and just a chill beautiful game to play while having some suspense to deal with and building. Honestly very surprised for the game i would def say that if you're on the fence about trying it then go in with a open mind. Also go in with the idea of helping other players in there gameplay and not just that this is a single player game where it only effects you. You effect other players and there interaction with the world. It's not for everyone, but it was def for me and it was very unexpected how much i've liked it so far.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: I have finished this game on a PS4 Pro already, but this PC version one-ups the PS4 version in every technical aspect. If you are looking for a unique experience; something that deviates from the norm and isn't ashamed to be bold and different, Death Stranding is a game you should not skip. But be prepared to tolerate some of its flaws in order to fully enjoy it; I believe that this is part of its design.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
[h1] 9.6 / 10 [/h1]
Delivering items around the world with the help of other players who are connected to you via the strand system is the main objective to help rebuild and reconnect the world. I can't say too much about the game without spoiling it so here's a short review.

Visuals, audio, gameplay, input, feedback and overall quality exceed anything you will expect from a game. Replayability is perfect if you enjoy the delivering side of things but if not then it may not be for you.

Story fits the games theme so its expected. [spoiler] If you have played Peace Walker, Ground Zeroes, The Phantom Pain, Playable Teaser and Survive then you may get a bigger picture of what it may have been about since all of these games are connected. [/spoiler]

[b]PC Port:[/b]
Positives:
[list]
    [*]Mouse & Keyboard support is fantastic. [i](It's nice to see what mouse support in MGSV would have been like)[/i]
    [*]DLSS 2.0 looks absolutely fantastic. [i](requires rtx series)[/i]
[/list]
Negatives:
[list]
    [*]Anti-aliasing only has FXAA and TAA.
    [*]Game has 21:9 support but only specifically the 21:9 ratio. Sadly no 21:9 monitor is "exactly 21:9" as they are actually a bit wider. So as a result, there are black bars on the sides for any "ultrawide 21:9 monitor".
[/list]

title: DEATH STRANDING
review: Death Stranding is truly an unexpected experience. As much as I don't want to admit that Kojima has created an entirely new genre, I really can't compare Death Stranding to any other game out there (except for maybe MGSV lol). Everything this game does, it does right. It takes your typical stealth-action gameplay that we have all come to expect from Kojima and blends it with mechanics that you might normally see in your typical survival horror games, like inventory management, etc. There's something just tremendously satisfying about going through and organizing your cargo and then plotting out a route to your next destination. I can't say that I'd recommend this game to just anyone though, considering that it truly does require a lot of patience, especially toward the first half of the game. But you gotta believe me when I tell you that the pay off in this game is most definitely worth a few minor annoyances that you might experience. I give it a 10/10 and that's why I'm playin' it again biotch.

title: DEATH STRANDING
review:
It's an amazing game.

For those who have performance issues, i.e. low GPU usage below 50%: if you are using a controller, turn off steam controller support, or individually at game property setting to "Force off". This game has native controller support so if you just plug in your Dualshock4 controller it will automatically register support. But if you have steam controller support at the same time, it will glitch and cause significant performance issue, i.e. low GPU usage.

I'm running maximum graphics at 144FPS butterly smooth at 1440p by i7 8700k + RTX2080ti. If you have the same config but experience major performance drag, do have a look into your steam controller support.
